column2: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- David Sarnoff, new chairman of the National Security Training Commission, promised today a maximum effort toward the success of the six-month reserve training program.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29-- As the minor league baseball convention moved into its second session today, the American Association and International League held the spotlight.
The sponsor of "This Is Your Life," a television program, told a grieved tale of its own to a state hearing yesterday.

IN THE excitement finally of finding just the thing for Grandma, some women during the next few weeks will leave their wallets on a store counter. Others, in the fatigue that follows a day of shopping, will step out of taxis, their purses on the seats behind them.

A four-story walk-up building containing forty-three apartments at 1207 Fortyninth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the H. W. Realty Company to a client of Lionel Fisch, attorney. Joseph Deutsch and H. Kornreich were the brokers in the sale of the property, which has an assessed valuation of $125,000.
Stock prices staged a modest recovery yesterday. Volume dipped, however, and no strong forward movement was discernible. Aircrafts were the firm spot, notably in the late trading.

As the pre-convention campaign gets under way for next year's Presidential election responsible leaders of both parties have initiated a laudable effort to maintain the bipartisan basis of our foreign policy, which is the key to its success, and to keep that policy from becoming a political football to the detriment of our own and free world security.
The first full-fledged cold wave of the season chilled residents of the metropolitan area yesterday as pre-winter Arctic air enveloped most of the East.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 (AP)-- Owner-Trainer Alan T. Clarke of Clarksville, Md., and Jockey Joseph Regalbuto teamed to win two races at Pimlico today, including the featured Tally Ho Purse with Our Year, who returned $5.80 for $2.

An American edition of Will Dexter's "The Riddle of Chung Ling Soo," the "marvelous Chinese conjurer" of the English music halls at the beginning of this century, will be distributed Thursday by Arco. Soo, in his lifetime, erected a facade about his life "as illusory as his most dexterous" magical feat.
PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 30-- Dissolution of the French National Assembly appeared imminent today as a result of the overthrow of Premier Edgar Faure's Government last night.

An issue of $18,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of San Diego Gas and Electric Company heads the list of securities being placed on the market today. It is being offered by an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at 99.619 and accrued interest to yield 3.27 per cent to maturity.
A young male onager made his debut at the Bronx Zoo yesterday, kicking up his heels like his namesake--a medieval stone-throwing catapult.

LONDON, Nov. 29--The stock exchange trading account ended quietly today on a dull note. Activity was confined only to trading in recently-issued industrial shares. Among government stocks several long-dated and undated funds had small losses.

The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission urged television viewers last night to take issue with stations, producers and sponsors if they felt the programs they saw did not meet with the public interest.
BERLIN, Nov. 29--The Soviet commandant asserted today that the Soviet occupation of East Berlin had ended.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29-- Former President Harry S. Truman charged today that the Republicans had "just about ruined the country and the Government."
The death of Helen West Heller, distinguished wood-cut artist, at Bellevue Hospital on Nov. 19 became known yesterday. For ten days her body has remained unclaimed at the Bellevue morgue.

YESTERDAY (Nov. 29, 1955) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Assembly adopted resolution reaffirming its intention to seek early solution of Korean question. Special Political Committee --Discussed three-power resolution to continue aid to Palestine refugees.
A split that developed between the Sergeants Benevolent Association and Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy widened yesterday when 262 more sergeants were ordered transferred, effective tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The Department of Justice pledged cooperation today with the states in problems dealing with racial segregation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The White House Conference on Education today adopted a set of goals for American education.

The mighty Sooners of Oklahoma, acclaimed as 1955 national college football champions yesterday after finishing first in the final Associated Press ranking poll, moved into second place in the college rankings over a twenty-year period as a result.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 29--Moroccan nationalists asked today for the abolition of the International Zone of Tangier and for a formal pledge by Spain recognizing the independence of Morocco.
Sponsored by the State Department, three tennis players departed yesterday on a six-week tour of Asia arranged by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
The first profit-sharing plan covering all employes in a major cigarette company was approved yesterday in Richmond, Va., by stockholders of Philip Morris, Inc.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Nov. 29--Israel regards hints in Cairo about negotiations for an Arab-Israeli settlement as a smokescreen to cover preparations for aggression.

A fireman touched a match to material from a window display in a Times Square bar yesterday noon to see if it was dangerously flammable. Apparently it was. Moments after he had snuffed out the flame, the material exploded. It ignited the rest of the display. Flames raced through the interior of the bar, the Silver Dollar, at 1548 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) --A spokesman for automobile dealers charged today that factory pressure to get rid of cars was forcing dealers to use deceptive advertising, unsound credit terms and unethical business practices.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 29 --The Brazilian press embarked today on an experimental "honor system" of censorship.

The most authentic All-America team of all, perhaps, was named in Philadelphia Monday, when the National Football League conducted the first three rounds of its so-called college draft. That's the procedure whereby the professional clubs stake out priority claims on the future services of the varsity gridiron heroes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday 2 to 18 points (10 to 90 cents a bale).
Russia is "way ahead" of the United States in the use of educational films in classrooms, William Benton, former Democratic Senator from Connecticut, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- Following is the transcript of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' news conference today, including his statement on foreign policy in the 1956 campaign: SECRETARY DULLES -- I understand that we have here a number of distinguished journalists from other countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board disclosed today that his agency plans to authorize "in the near future" stand-by credits for member savings and loan associations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- Following is the text of the report of the White House Conference on Education on "What Should Our Schools Accomplish?" It was prepared by Dr. Adam Bennion and Dr. Carr in behalf of the conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Secretary of State Dulles, commenting on the Soviet suggestion that nuclear tests be ended, said today the subject was complex and the United States had not reached a definite conclusion on it.

A community blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will be made today from 2:30 P. M. to 7:30 P. M. at the armory at 321 Manor Road, West Brighton, Staten Island. Appointments may be made by calling GIbraltar 7-0810.
FOR fifty-five minutes last night the National Broadcasting Company radio network paid honor to the memory of Jerome Kern, who died ten years ago this month.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 29-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's principal lieutenants in the Bundestag sent up a trial balloon today to test Western reaction to the idea of bilateral discussions with the Soviet Union on Germany's reunification.
The exclusive regulation of private insurance companies by the states is in danger of Federal intervention, a nation-wide meeting of state insurance officials was told yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 29--A Scotland Yard detective sergeant with twenty-six commendations for police work was sent to jail for two years today for conspiring to obtain the acquittal of a burglar.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 --The television film activities of Twentieth Century-Fox will move into high gear after the New Year with the addition of five, and possibly seven, new TV film series to the current schedule of two.

LONDON, Nov. 29--Britain protested today against a Soviet charge that, in company with the United States she was to blame for the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941. This was part of an exchange of protests between Britain and the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, Nov. 29--A small-town physician from eastcentral Pennsylvania was chosen today as the outstanding family doctor for 1955. The honor of "General Practitioner of the Year' was bestowed on Dr. E. Roger Samuel of Mount Carmel by the American Medical Association.
The women's coat and suit industry proposed last night that management and labor join in a long-range program of "negotiation by research" to settle future differences in collective bargaining.
If taxes collected from highway users were, used solely for highway purposes, most road bond issues would be unnecessary, according to a former Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The General Motors Corporation unwillingly told a Senate Labor subcommittee today about its management of the group insurance plan covering its employes.

HEAVY hitters carry an instant and irresistible appeal, be the sport baseball or boxing. Carmen Basilio and Tony DeMarco, two artists with the left hook, will dabble on canvas for the entertainment of a vast television audience tonight and the color motif undoubtedly will be red, blood red.

American Felt Co. Directors of the American Felt Company have declared an extra dividend of 75 cents and a regular dividend of 25 cents on the common, payable on Dec. 15. The company paid a 50-cent extra dividend in December of last year.

A group of Radcliffe alumnae will act as hostesses and guides Saturday for an art tour to benefit the Radcliffe College Scholarship Fund of New York. Six collections will be on view in the homes of their owners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)--Employes of the General Aniline and Film Corporation appealed today for sale of the concern to private American interests as soon as possible. A representative of employe groups said continued Federal control of the company seized under the Trading With the Enemy Act is having "deleterious effects."
The American Federation of Labor's maritime trades department is aiming at greatly widened coverage of the shipping and waterfront industries.

AS THEIR children grow and need less of them, some mothers seek a job outside their homes. Not so Mrs. Ann Roe Robbins of New Canaan, Conn. Making a small career out of cookery, Mrs. Robbins seems to have withdrawn into her kitchen as her three daughters have matured.

Several novelties will be presented at the concert on Sunday at 5:30 P. M. honoring the ninetieth birthday of Jean Sibelius. The program, which will be played in Carnegie Hall by the Symphony of the Air, lists what is called the first American performance of "The Lover," Op. 14, a suite for strings and drums.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Florina Lasker Foundation has generously offered $250,000 to build a recreation center for older men and women. The Park Department proposes to locate this building in the part of Central Park known as the Ramble, and is asking the city for $320,000 to fence in and replant the area.

The likelihood that the West Indies may become one of the world's major shipbuilding and ship repair centers was increased yesterday with the announcement of plans to construct a large shipyard in the Bahamas.

Revolution in the Office The walls are shaking in every office in the country. Revolution is in the air. For Uncle Sam, one of the greatest exponents in the land of paper work and the use of business machines, is about to undertake an experiment that could upset the daytime activities of millions of men and women--mainly women.

The Chicago Black Hawks, a threat to the second-place standing of the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League, will be at Madison Square Garden tonight. The third-place Hawks are 3 points back of the Rangers although the New Yorkers have won two more games.
A 69-year-old alien who fled Germany to escape persecution by Hitler charged yesterday that Immigration officials had tricked him into agreeing to deportation.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 (UP)--Unexpectedly heavy support for the ex-champion, Tony DeMarco of Boston, dropped the betting price to "even money" tonight for his attempt to recapture the welterweight title from Carmen Basilio tomorrow night in their return fight at the Boston Garden.

Police Inspector Michael J. Murphy will take the oath of office as the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission's executive director tomorrow at 11:30 A. M. The ceremony will take place in the headquarters of the bi-state agency at 15 Park Row.

PAUL HINDEMITH was 60 on Nov. 16, and Bohuslav Martinu will be 65 on Dec. 8. Trust the alert Eugene Ormandy to make something of these neighboring birthdays. His concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night wished the composers happy returns with performances of their music.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29--The United States advised the Arab states today to cooperate on long-delayed efforts to develop agricultural lands for the benefit of Palestinian Arab refugees.
PARIS, Nov. 29--Two major French dressmakers, Givenchy and Balenciaga, maintained today their decision to hold their spring showings three weeks later than their fellow couturiers.

A sixteen-family building known as the Park View Apartments at 8600 First Avenue in North Bergen, N. J., has been sold by Marie and Ludwig F. Beiser to the Jack Realty Company. The structure contains forty eight rooms in suites of three and four rooms.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The United States has informed Israel and the Arab Governments that it sees real prospects for bringing about peace between them.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 29 --An F-84 Air Force jet fighter plane crashed through a row of houses today, killing the pilot and ten to thirteen other persons, mostly civilians. The plane had failed to gain altitude on take-off.
LONDON, Nov. 29--Officials here expressed interest today in reports that an anti-Communist front was being planned in certain Asian countries.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 29 --The Administration put an increasing emphasis on defense planning today as President Eisenhower scheduled meetings with his top military advisers and the National Security Council.

Commodity futures price showed no trend yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cottonseed oil, rubber, copper and tin rose; cocoa, onions, potatoes, hides, burlap and wool eased, and moves in zinc, sugar and soybean oil were mixed.
Two Soviet automation specialists prepared last night to return to Moscow, disappointed at the limited view of advanced American industrial technique they glimpsed in a fortnight's trip.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Grain and soybean traders were reluctant to follow upturns today, and there was local selling at times when the demand slackened. Outside trade was still comparatively light.

The grim task of counting the dead and injured in automobile accidents tomorrow marks the climax of one of the most intensive campaigns ever undertaken to drive home the challenging fact that pedestrians and motorists alike must cooperate in year - round battle against a common enemy that last year claimed 36,000 lives, many of them needlessly.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 29-- Plans for a $10,000,000 cement factory in the Steep Rocks section of Kingston were announced today.

The widespread national interest in the White House Conference on Education is a hopeful sign that the American people are really determined to take some effective steps toward relieving the crisis in the public schools. For it is a crisis, getting worse every day, a crisis of teachers and salaries and classrooms; and as the shortages become more acute it is inevitably devolving into a crisis of quality, too.
NEWARK, Nov. 29--Mayor Leo P. Carlin realigned his top administrative aides today and for the first time since he took office in July, 1954, he will be able to confer with a complete cabinet.

THE New York City Ballet last night gave the season's first presentation of George Balanchine's "Ivesiana" at the City Center and thereby reached the peak of its distinction. Here is an adventuresome work with the courage of its convictions and its skills and its powers of communication are phenomenal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- John Foster Dulles welcomed today "constructive" foreign policy debate during the Presidential election campaign but appealed to both parties to avoid uninformed "partisan excesses."
Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, the brilliant halfback of Ohio State's Big Ten champions, was established yesterday as the 1955 winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy.
Thomas D. Bolles, athletic director and former rowing coach at Harvard University, has been elected manager of the United States Olympic rowing squad that will go to Australia in 1956.

The 1956 Hudson cars have improved styling and a new 220-horsepower engine. The line was announced yesterday by the Hudson motors division of the American Motors Corporation. The cars will go on display in dealer showrooms here tomorrow.

FORT POLK, La., Nov. 29-- United States fighter-bombers delivered simulated attacks against "enemy" airfields this morning in the opening of the final combat phase of Exercise Sage Brush, the largest joint maneuver since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The branding of a man as a security risk on the basis of kinship was denounced today as being against the rules of justice laid down by the Bible, the marriage ceremony and the United States Constitution.
WARSAW, Nov. 29--Government authorities here assert that Poland has become one of the leading steel producers in Europe and that her industrial production per person surpasses that of Italy.

The consumer will continue to buy at his current rate, but his appetite for more goods cannot be counted upon to provide any further impetus to the national economy, a University of Michigan survey predicted yesterday.

FOR the first time in several years the Museum of Modern Art is devoting a major show to its new acquisitions, more than fifty paintings, pieces of sculpture, collages and a few smaller objects that fit with difficulty into any strict category.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29--A General Assembly committee approved today an article on self-determination for the proposed Covenants on Human Rights.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29 (UP)--The top minor leagues today drafted thirty-eight players thirteen infielders, twelve outfielders, twelve pitchers and a catcher--from circuits of lower classification.
With a midnight strike deadline before them, eight private bus lines and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will make one final try today to find a peace formula.

Profits of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad shrank almost to the vanishing point last month as a result of flood conditions along its lines. Patrick B. McGinnis, president, announced yesterday that earnings dropped to $15,280. In the comparable month last year the road had a net income of $1,002,087.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would be a sad commentary if, at this crucial moment, the American people were to withhold substantial technical and economic assistance from the people of India. Whether such aid is to be presented as an outright gift or a loan is of secondary importance.

PARIS, Nov. 29--The French Government that has just been defeated might be called the Faure-Pinay Administration. For Antoine Pinay, the Foreign Minister, was as much a pillar of it as Edgar Faure, the Premier.

The defense rested yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of Elmer F. (Trigger) Burke. Burke is accused of the 1952 slaying of a friend, Edward (Poochy) Walsh, in a bar at Columbus Avenue and Ninetyfirst Street.

UNTIL last Friday noon I had never read a word by Charlotte Jay, an error of judgment for which I will now do public penance. Miss Jay writes books that are labeled "novels of suspense." Although I admit to no bias against that particular variety of literary entertainment, other more ambitious varieties had occupied my attention when her earlier books were published.

The fall of Edgar Faure's Government in France was so thoroughly expected yesterday that it would have been truly astonishing had it survived. The French Parliament quite simply had enough of M. Faure and his skillful but tiring and confusing political maneuvering.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) --The Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay, said today the department would drop the controversial Echo Park Dam from the proposed Upper Colorado River storage project.

Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and associates and Salomon Brothers Hutzler were low bidders yesterday for an offering of $22,441,000 of New York City Housing Authority short term loan notes. The notes will mature on June 26, 1956.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The United States has appealed to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek not to block the admission of eighteen new members to the United Nations by vetoing Outer Mongolia. Apparently the appeal has been in vain so far. Reports that President Eisenhower had sent the Nationalist Chinese leader a message to this effect drew a blank reaction today in the State Department and at the temporary White House in Gettysburg, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- Two Administration leaders indicated clearly today that they envisaged no bold new program of foreign aid.
A steel diesel-electric tugboat for the Pennsylvania Railroad, the 105-foot Buffalo, will be launched Friday morning at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard.

The New York Knickerbockers, victors in their two previous games against Fort Wayne, fell before the Pistons, 104--99, in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 --Twentieth Century-Fox, following in the footsteps of United Artists, disclosed today its intention to tackle the subject of drug addiction. Film treatment of this issue is proscribed by the Production Code.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 29-- Jaques Soustelle, Governor General of Algeria, went before the Algerian Assembly today to plead for reforms designed to integrate Algeria more fully with France and to raise the standards of living.

CAIRO, Nov. 29 (Reuters)-- Britain and Egypt reached agreement tonight on the procedure for the Sudan to determine its political future. The territory has been jointly ruled by the two countries since 1899.
A city-wide program is under way to make Safe Driving Day tomorrow worthy of its name.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The British Government opposes any international agreement to end tests of nuclear weapons because it believes the Soviet Union now leads in this experimentation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A preliminary countrywide report on school housing asserted today that "the present rate of school construction must be considerably increased."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today a 1956 control program that would require most growers to reduce planting of burley tobacco by 15 per cent.

Three Brooklyn youths were sentenced yesterday to long prison terms by Kings County Judge Carmine J. Marasco. They had pleaded guilty on June 16 to an indictment charging them with killing a 16-year-old youth as the result of a gang feud in the Bedford-Stuyvesant district.
The Transit Authority started action yesterday to eliminate the De Kalb-Myrtle Avenue bottleneck of the B. M. T. subway.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today development of a mechanical sterilizer for killing viruses in the production of vaccine.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A public assistance program to enable anyone capable of self-support to stay off relief rolls was advocated today by the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Premier Adnan Menderes submitted his resignation today, but President Celal Bayar rejected it and directed him to find a new Cabinet.

In his otherwise excellent report of the interview with me on my recent visit to Communist China (The Times of Nov. 20) Arthur J. Olsen makes one inadvertent misstatement which I must beg leave to correct.

ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the South Pacific, Nov. 30 -- For the fourth straight day, this Navy icebreaker was being buffeted by gales. The Antarctic bound Glacier -- 8,600 tons in weight and 310 feet long -- took one roll of 45 degrees during the night.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30 -- Acting President Nereu Ramos has warned there is a possibility that "serious internal commotion" may erupt in Brazil.

HAVANA, Nov. 30 -- Groups of students fought policemen with sticks and stones various incidents in Havana today. Havana University was the center of the rioting but high school students also joined in the disorders.

New Yorkers going to work today or doing their Christmas shopping early will be able to use their customary form of transportation. The strike against privately owned bus lines threatened by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union has been avoided by negotiations that continued through the final day of the contract year and produced a 17-cent package as expected.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox today announced the purchase of Luis Aparicio, a 21-year-old Venezuelan shortstop, from their Memphis farm club of the Southern Association:

Life aboard ship is not always so glamorous as depicted in the travel brochures. The men of our merchant marine will testify to this fact. The sea can indeed be cruel -- in storms, of course, but also in periods of calm, for when seamen are not performing their routine duties there is a fight against boredom to be won.
Two rather well informed citizens disagreed yesterday on whether or not Americans will heat their homes economically with energy from the sun or the atom in ten years or so.

Buying has been light at the fifteenth semi-annual Popular Price Shoe Show of America despite heavy attendance. Most retailers had covered spring needs in advance of the five-day show because of the early Easter selling period and fear of price increases.
One of the country's biggest unions has slammed the door on efforts by the left-wing United Electrical Workers to get into the merged labor federation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The annual dispute over the size and type of foreign aid to be given to foreign governments is on again, and it will soon be placed before President Eisenhower for decision.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee issued a special memorandum today on "the Republican record on mixing politics with foreign policy."
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson took the Eisenhower Administration to task today for the way it has dealt with the problem of meeting the nation's housing needs.
Enlarging on the season's spirit of giving, three benefit bazaars scheduled for this week might well have as their slogan: "One gift; many recipients."
VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- The Austrian Government has resumed the granting of asylum to all seeking refuge here from political persecution.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation said today it was soliciting proxies from stockholders of Diamond T Motor Car Company in an effort to block a proposed sale of Diamond T assets to the White Motor Company.
Labor unity presents to American unions an opportunity and an obligation to prove that their vast strength can he used to promote the general welfare.

The Alleghany Corporation, holding company, now owns directly or indirectly 835,000 shares of New York Central stock and figures its book profit on the investment, at the issue's recent high of 49 1/2, amounted to $19,000,000.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The thirteen-store group of the Foodtown Supermarkets of Cleveland was reported ready today to join the growing list of concerns merging with the ACF-Brill Motors Company.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- "I was fighting with one hand from the second round," said Carmen Basilio tonight after repeating his June technical knockout of Boston's Tony DeMarco.

THE impulse on reading about the major league draft of some ten minor leaguers is to yawn politely and offer the remark, "So what?" The only name of consequence in the collection is that of Monte Irvin, but the ex-Giant is 36 years old, a trifle creaky, perhaps, to be of overpowering use to the Chicago Cubs who drafted him.

THE fragmentation of sound and the reassembling of the bits and pieces into strange patterns seemed to be the main business of last night's brouhaha at Town Hall. The sponsoring agent was Camera Concerts, Inc., a new organization which evidently looks fiercely to the future, and the performers were not only the conventional live musicians but also recorded tapes and a two-channel stereophonic system.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- Soviet expedition left today to explore Antarctica. It is the first official Russian expedition to the region since Admiral Thaddeus von Bellingshausen, for Alexander I's Imperial Navy, circumnavigated the continent in 1819-21.

Social page note: Gil McDougald, designer of shoe fashions and well known as a major league baseball player, and Mrs. McDougald have just returned from an extended trip to the Orient. They are "at home" again to their friends in Nutley, N. J.
NEWARK, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Too little off-season exercise and a resultant shorter playing career are two reasons why modern players do not match the baseball heroes of old, according to Ty Cobb.
The Minute Maid Corporation, producers of frozen food, attained the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

ONE-OF-A-KIND gifts that have the appeal of individuality are hard to find in the regular commercial sources. Christmas shoppers may find such items at the many charitable and institutional sales of the current season. Among them are the following:
A secondary Communist leader sought for four years by the Federal Bureau of Investigation surrendered yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Only two or three states were reported today to be able to meet their school building needs in the next five years.
The American Fund for Israel Institutions started its fourteenth annual campaign last night for $5,000,000 to maintain and support its cultural and educational institutions in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that manufacturers' shipments of goods rose in October, but less than the "usual seasonal amount."
WHAT will the up-to-the-minute woman be wearing next spring?
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Air Force reported today that the death toll had reached fourteen in yesterday's crash of a fighter plane into housing units at the Eielson Air Force Base here.
Three hours before a midnight strike deadline, the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight private bus lines reached agreement last night, averting a walkout by 8,200 drivers and mechanics.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- A 500-tube electronic translator has mastered the idioms but is still stumped by literary nuances, it was revealed here today.
Paul Muni, who came out of retirement to star in "Inherit the Wind" and then was forced to withdraw from it because of an eye ailment, will return to the courtroom drama tonight.
John P. McGrath took office yesterday as this state's member of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission

PAINTERS, sculptors, architects, graphic artists and water-colorists, all members of the National Academy, are holding a large exhibition of their work at the Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. It opens today and will remain open until Dec. 18.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. advocated changes in the Federal security program that "would open the floodgates to wholesale Communist infiltration of our Government."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Washington's political community treated reports of improved prospects of peace between Israel and the Arab states with extreme skepticism today. Highly placed United States officials reiterated that these prospects were based in fact.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A poll tonight showed that the thirty-six discussion groups at the White House Conference on Education were in favor of Federal aid to school construction and twelve were opposed. The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, sponsors of the poll, had no word from 118 other discussion groups.

Two buildings of the old plant of the Alexander Smith Carpet Company in Yonkers have been purchased by investment concerns. The buyers were the Nepperhan United Corporation and the Saw Mill United Corporation.
The police homicide squad in Queens is being interrogated as to why recent homicides in that borough remain unsolved.

Flotations of new securities here increased sharply in November over those of a year earlier. Public offerings of new bonds for the second successive month exceeded a billion dollars and were more than double the amount marketed in November, 1954.
The Police Athletic League is seeking 110,000 toys, gifts and articles of clothing in its twentieth Christmas campaign, which started yesterday.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The recall of Arkansas' delegation to the White House Conference on Education is being demanded by two militant pro-segregation groups. They contend the meeting is a front for racial integration in public schools.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 -President Eisenhower called a nation-wide conference today of mayors and other local government officials to meet in Washington on Feb. 16 and 17, 1956. He appointed Val Peterson, the Civil Defense Administrator, to coordinate the conference program.

TORONTO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Earl (Dutch) Reibel's third - period goal with the Toronto Maple Leafs two men short gave the Detroit Red Wings an uphill 3-3 tie before a crowd of 12,627 tonight. The deadlock was Detroit's tenth in twenty-three games.

The stock market rose sharply in November. The New York Times industrial average rose to a new historic high, while the rail index hit the highest level since 1930. The gains were the largest for any month since November, 1954.
Prisoners in the Tombs have been able to buy nearly all the comforts of home from prison guards at "fixed prices," District Attorney Frank S. Hogan declared last night.

HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- Richard R. Tenneson, 22, former G. I. who chcose communism as a Korean war prisoner and then changed his mind, arrived at the Hong Kong-Kwangtung border today on his way out of Red China.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Howard (Hopalong) Cassady today was honored for the second time in less than twentyfour hours with an award as college football player of the year.

The Cigarette Merchandisers Association, Inc., five corporations, a labor union and five individuals were fined a total of $104,000 yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld. They pleaded nolo contendere (no defense) to a charge of monopolizing the sale and distribution of cigarettes through vending machines in the New York metropolitan area.
Volume shot up on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to the largest total since Oct. 11 -- 2,900,000 shares, against 2,370,000 on Tuesday -- and prices were stronger.
MIAMI, Nov. 30 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech today to the thirty-second annual congress of the American Municipal Association:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 30 -- The details concerning three devices designed to eliminate a substantial amount of air pollution in the metropolitan area, and field tests now being given them in New York City, were disclosed here today.
The gradual and spotty upward trend in metals prices, evident over recent weeks in a rash of minor increases by individual companies, continued yesterday with these developments:
A steamship terminal costing $9,300,000 is scheduled to be built at Port Newark, N. J., by the Port of New York Authority for occupancy by Norton, Lilly Co.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -John H. F. Haskell, vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, was appointed today defense adviser to George W. Perkins, permanent Ambassador to the North Atlantic Council.
With 15,000,000 members the new American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations will be the largest national workers group in the free world.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, will open a Bundestag debate tomorrow on the reunification of Germany with a statement rejecting any suggestions that West Germany hold bilateral negotiations with the Soviet Union.
Detectives arrested three men in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of illegally possessing narcotics valued at $500,000 if sold at retail.
The second annual Yuletide Dansant for the benefit of the Gold Star Sons and Daughters of America will be held on Dec. 15 in the Ambassador.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Investment banking leaders took a long look today at the growing part that nuclear energy is going to play in the peacetime life of the nation.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The opening of a new bookkeeping account restored firmness to industrial shares today. Government issues were extremely quiet.
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 30 -Burma prepared today to give a roaring welcome to the Soviet Union's Premier, Nikolai A. Bulganin, and the Soviet Communist party's first secretary, Nikita S. Khrushchev.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Marshall Field Co. reported today that sales and net income in the three months ended Oct. 31 were higher than the corresponding period a year ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The United States charged today that Communist nations did little business with the rest of the world because the Soviet Union wanted it that way.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu ordered today the dissolution of the Peronist party and the return of the newspaper La Prensa to its former owners.
Al (Dusty) DeStefano of St. John's University probably is the "wealthiest" basketball coach in this sector.
The unification of American labor brings to a climax a century and a half of union progress from bloody repression to economic, political and social strength.

HOUSEWIVES revive favorite money-savers the week following Thanksgiving. It is a time when thrift may be needed in restoring a budget. Call it chopped beef or hamburger; by either name it long has been an excellent economy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 30 -- Announcement of a $50,000 gift to establish a nuclear engineering department at the University of Toledo and confirmation that a $15,000,000 atomic power station would be constructed near here were revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The men and women from the forty-eight states and four territories who are participating in the first White House Conference on Education are taking their responsibilities seriously.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- United States investments of more than $26,500,000,000 abroad could be imperiled by failure to make full return of seized alien property, a Senate Judiciary subcommittee was told today.
Stock splits gained momentum yesterday when five companies in diversified fields announced plans to divide their shares.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 -Lighterage operations are to be introduced to San Francisco Bay. The Tide Water Associated Oil Company, a spokesman said today, would begin the practice of unloading ships into barges because increasingly large tankers will have difficulty in getting fully loaded into refinery docks.

The industrial building at the northeast corner of Frelinghuysen Avenue and Wharton Street in Newark, N. J., has been purchased by William Wolf through his 350 Halsey Corporation. It was acquired from the Realty Corporation of America and the Bim Management Company through Lehman Associates, Inc., as broker.
Carmen Basilio was born in Canastota, N. Y., on April 2, 1927. His people are farmers and he is one of a family of seven brothers and three sisters.

As a newspaper which has consistently supported American aid to the Nationalist Government of China we urge that Government to reconsider its present decision to veto the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations and thereby upset the whole "package deal" by which new members would be admitted to the U. N.
ATLANTA, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A pro-segregation group urged Georgia Tech today not to play Pittsburgh, which has a Negro player, in the Sugar Bowl.

In your editorial of Nov. 24 "Due Process on Passports" you state that the Federal courts have "struck another well-deserved blow" at the State Department's long-established habit of denying passports "on the basis of evidence known only to itself."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Government ran head-on today into its own money squeeze. Charles E. Slusser, Public Housing Commissioner, announced cancellation of an $89,997,000 issue of short-term loan notes by seventy three local housing authorities.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 30 -- Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef today formerly asked his closest friend and adviser, M'barek Bekkai, to form Morocco's first national government.
Leffert Holz, State Superintendent of Insurance, yesterday called for a compulsory indemnification law that in effect would tax uninsured motorists to protect the victims of irresponsible drivers.
THE day youngsters finally succumb to realism in the world of myth surrounding St. Nicholas may be harder on parents than offspring.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Kentucky's burley tobacco crop brought a record high of nearly $58 a hundred pounds yesterday on sales opened for the 1955-56 season. The average was $57.78 a hundred pounds, or $5.24 above the opening day average of the 1954 crop.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Fifteen 8,500-horsepower gas turbine-electric locomotives, believed to be the most powerful rail units ever designed, have been ordered by the Union Pacific Railroad from the General Electric Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The United Nations will begin debate tomorrow on the issue of the admission of eighteen new members.
A state hearing was told yesterday that Charles V. Gris, a private detective, had sent an employe to buy eavesdropping equipment and to say he "came from the West New York, N. J., police."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 23:
ALTHOUGH surrounded by some of the best bakeries in the world, many New York housewives nonetheless will bake cookies, cakes and pies during the coming holiday season.

The Western Natural Gas Company announced yesterday it is offering holders of its common stock of record Nov. 30 rights to subscribe for 183,003 shares of its 5 per cent convertible preferred stock, 1955 series,
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Paul G. Hoffman, former Foreign Aid Administrator, testified today that the United States was losing friends throughout the free world because of its immigration law.
YONKERS, Nov. 30 -- This city was said today to face almost certain loss of $2,500,000 in state aid for its schools next year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- A United Nations committee approved today an appeal to governments to continue to support assistance for Palestinian Arab refugees The approval, by the General Assembly's Special Political Committee, was voted by 38 to 0.

A bright, sunny day was predicted for today, Safe Driving Day. The twenty-four-hour period, which ends at midnight tonight, is dedicated to the preservation of lives, limbs and motor vehicles, with a national goal to eliminate all fatal accidents on streets and highways.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- The General Motors Corporation's annual industrial show, Motorama, will open at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York Jan. 19.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Frank Sinatra, the busiest star in Hollywood, is looking ahead to March, 1957, in connection with his second undertaking as an independent producer. This will be a musical comedy called "The Jazz Train," in which Sammy Davis Jr. is scheduled to co-star with Mr. Sinatra. Mervyn Nelson wrote the screen play.
The best way for a middle-aged man to avoid a coronary thrombosis, such as that suffered by President Eisenhower, is to keep weight and temper down.

NEWMARKET, England, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Rex Ellsworth, owner of l the 1955 Kentucky Derby winner, ended a three-day buying spree at the Newmarket thoroughbred sales today by paying $29,400 for a 2-year-old filly named Weeber.
CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 30 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru tried today to quiet worries aroused in the West by India's fervent welcome to the Soviet leaders.
President Eisenhower will give his blessings to the merged labor movement in a telephoned talk from his Gettysburg headquarters Monday afternoon. The President's decision...

Eleven members of the United States Olympic Alpine team were the guests of the New York Ski Council at a reception at the Hotel Paramount last night. The team will compete in the winter games at Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy, Jan. 26-Feb. 5.
Directors of American Machine and Metals, Inc., have declared an extra dividend of 75 cents and the usual quarterly of 50 cents, both payable on Dec. 22.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company's earnings this year are expected to hit a new high of $1.80 a share, Walter C. Becklord, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. This would compare with the previous high of $12,735,248, or $1.71 a share, set in 1954.
These two books, published recently, may be of interest to homeowners seeking to improve their property:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Republicans who have been indicating that international perils require the opposition not to attack even the measures and methods by which foreign policy is being conducted by the Administration would sound a little more grown up if they would acknowledge the realities of politics in a free land and the duty of the party out of power.
The prospect of a large-scale center of the performing arts in the Lincoln Square redevelopment area took clearer form yesterday.
Sidney Kingsley, playwright, is discussing a proposed deal with the Columbia Broadcasting System whereby his services would be utilized in television.

Grace Kelly and James Stewart were selected as the leading actress and actor of 1955 in the annual poll of exhibitors in the United States and Canada conducted by The Showmen's Trade Review. "Mister Roberts" was named the leading motion picture.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Grain prices dropped following early strength today on the Board of Trade. But corn and soybeans had a good recovery from the low spots, while wheat and oats were inclined to lag. Closing prices were generally above yesterday's final levels.
Some light was shed yesterday on why no arrests were made during a hushed-up raid on a wiretap center here last Feb. 11.
The Port of New York Authority sold $16,000,000 of consolidated bonds yesterday to help finance the purchase and development of two miles of choice Brooklyn waterfront.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Republican leaders opened a proEisenhower rally today amid official indications they might not know until March whether the President would seek a second term.

H. W. Morrison, president of the Morrison - Knudsen Company, Inc., announced yesterday that the consolidated net income of the construction and engineering company and its domestic subsidiaries in the first nine months of 1955 had amounted to $4,820,363.
The bird watchers have won the Battle of the Ramble.
Berlin, a divided city in a divided state, has been an object of controversy between the West and the East since the end of World War II.

Senator Hennings, a quiet Democrat from Missouri, has just concluded the first phase of some interesting hearings designed to throw light on areas where the government itself -- Federal, state and local -- may have transgressed on the liberties of American citizens as described in the Bill of Rights.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 -President Eisenhower sent warm personal greetings today to Sir Winston Churchill on his eightyfirst birthday.

POTHOLDERS, tablecloths, bedspreads, table mats, and the like -- the loving handwork of some of the nation's finest crocheters -- will be on view at the Henry Hudson Hotel through tomorrow. They are the work of prize winners from 860 fairs throughout the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Edward D. McDougal Jr., a 59-year-old Chicago lawyer, was named today treasurer of the National Stevenson for President Committee. The nonprofessional group is working for the nomination and election of Adlai E. Stevenson.

S-D Day is one of those apparently necessary anachronisms of modern life. The horror of 40,000 highway deaths each year should be with us always. A visitor from another planet probably would be amazed that one twenty-four-hour period should be given over each year to the need for Safe Driving.

Following are sketches of prospective vice presidents of the unified labor movement. The American Federation of Labor still has two places to fill. The leading possibilities for those vacancies are Richard F. Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, and Abe L. Spradling, president of the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Following are the texts of two reports made public today by the White House Conference on Education:

An increase of 2,286,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks during the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 155,866,000 barrels, compared with 153,580,000 a week earlier and 149,191,000 a year ago.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 30 -- The all-Texas contract bridge team of Oswald Jacoby, James Jacoby, George Heath, Paul Hodge and Ben Fain took the lead this afternoon over a field of twenty-nine qualifying teams in the first of two final sessions for the 1955 open-team-of-four championship.
A Polish-born couple, victims of enforced separation for the last fourteen years, were reunited yesterday when the wife arrived here from Moscow.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 30 -The Algerian nationalist leader, Ferhat Abbas, issued a statement here tonight in which he implicitly offered himself as the instrument for a negotiated settlement with France.

David L. Cole, one of the nation's foremost arbitrators in labor-management disputes, was acclaimed yesterday by union leaders, business executives and government officials for his contributions to industrial peace.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 30 -As the convention proper of the minor leaguers got under way today, the major leaguers got around to some more baseball trading.

Batjac, the John Wayne-Robert Fellows producing company, announced tonight temporary suspension of production activities. The company will complete its ten-picture financing and distribution agreement With Warner Brothers upon delivery of the completed negatives of "Goodbye, My Lady" and "Seven Men From Now." Photography has been completed on both pictures.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 19 points (95 cents a bale) higher to 3 points (15 cents a bale) lower.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 -- A man in love with his land received a free tractor today. The gift gave him a chance to show a large group of interested visitors just how fond he was of his rolling Pennsylvania acres.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Farm prices fell 2 per cent in the month ended Nov. 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The drop put prices 7 per cent below a year ago.

Newspaper advertising linage smashed more records in October. A report issued jointly yesterday by Media Records, Inc., and the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, noted that national advertising, as measured in fifty-two "index" cities, rose to a new high for the month, with a gain of 18.8 per cent over October, 1954.

Events today: Frederick L. Swann, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Eugene Istomin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Jacques Abram, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 30 -The Virginia Legislature convened in special session today and got to work without visible emotion on a program designed to prevent the forced attendance of white and Negro children in the same classrooms.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (UP) -Dick Lawless booted home three winners at Pimlico today to share honors with Mrs. E. E. Robbins' Midafternoon, victor in the Balko Purse.
CAIRO, Nov. 30 -- Israel fears peace negotiations that might result in justice for the Arabs, an Egyptian spokesman said tonight.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30 -Mexico will adopt a policy this year of cutting down on Government spending in an effort to head off an advance in the cost of living and also to bring about a balanced budget.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Carmen Basilio knocked out Tony DeMarco in the twefth round tonight to retain the welterweight championship of the world. The unbelievably strong fighter from Canastota, N. Y., rallied to turn back the Boston challenger's bid for the crown in a cruel, savage exhibition that was a throwback to the era of barge fighting.

The Dayton Power and Light Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the quarter and twelve months ended Sept. 30, plus the largest tax bill for any twelve months in its history.
The New York Board of Rabbis will appeal to Mayor Wagner and to the Board of Superintendents for hearings to set forth its views on moral and spiritual values in New York public schools.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The House of Commons struck a blow tonight at those of its members who are radio and television commentators.

AT a time when everybody is deep in MacKinlay Kantor's Civil War novel, "Andersonville," there is a special pertinence to some striking photographs in James D. Horan's excellent new biography, "Mathew Brady, Historian With a Camera."* They show the Andersonville stockade in all its stark squalor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Carmine G. DeSapio took Governor Harriman of New York out of the "token" class today and projected him as an active candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Residents of Jackson Heights, Queens, will give blood to the Red Cross today. The donations will be made at Public School 148, Thirty-second Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, East Elmhurst, Queens. Blood will be collected also at Pace College.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Continental Baking Coming today acquired all business and property of Morton Packing Company, producers of frozen products.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A Missouri auto dealer told Senate investigators today that he had lost his thirty-five-yearold General Motors franchise because General Motors officials thought he was not selling enough Buicks.

Samuel Guy Inman's almost hysterical letter on Nov. 11 attacked our ally Spain and its chief of state, General Franco, and scolded The New York Times for printing a picture and communique of the Dulles-Franco meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan indicated today that he thought something stronger than the adjective "hypocritical" could be applied to a Soviet charge that Britain and the United States set off the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941.

Sandra Wirth, the Miss Florida entry in the Atlantic City beauty pageant last September, will become mistress of ceremonies for the "Super Circus" television show beginning Jan. 1. She replaces Mary Hartline.
Mr. Khrushchev has his nerve with him when he rewrites history to say that the United States and Britain "started the second World War; they sent the troops of Hitlerite Germany against Russia."
A COUPLE of anglers called to report that it is as cold off shore codfishing as it is deer hunting, but the angler is more certain of bringing home food for the deep freeze.

The pseudonymous C. W. Ceram has written a continuation of his panorama of "the most ancient world" as presented in "Gods, Graves and Scholars." The new work, called "The Secret of the Hittites: The Discovery of an Ancient Empire,'' will be published by Knopf on Jan. 9.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Wes Santee, this country's fastest miler, kept his amateur standing today as the deadline passed for protesting his return to the good graces of the Amateur Athletic Union.

Surrogate William T. Collins signed a decree yesterday admitting to probate the will of William Woodward Jr. The sportsman and financier was shot dead by his wife, Mrs. Ann E. Woodward on Oct. 30 on their Long Island estate in the belief that he was a prowler.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill, who celebrated his eighty-first birthday today, received a special gold medallion from President Eisenhower. The inscription on the medal, three inches in diameter, said it was presented on behalf of "millions of admiring friends in the United States." ed by his immediate family, his grandchildren and a few friends.

The near-by positions on the "M" coffee contract tumbled yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The "S" and "B" options were slightly lower. Reports of increased supplies at port areas in Central America and Colombia weakened the "M" futures.
MR. RODGERS and Mr. Hammerstein have written a pleasant, lazy romance. "Pipe Dream." which opened at the Sam S. Shubert last evening.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union returned today to its old charges against the United States.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- British and Australian Air Force bombers began today an aerial bombardment against Communist terrorists in the fifth day of Malaya's biggest antiterrorist battle in nearly a year.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The West Berlin Government reacted sharply tonight to what seemed to be a Soviet move to terminate the special status of the Western Allies in East Berlin and perhaps ultimately in the entire city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The State Department published tonight a 306-page record of the Big Four Foreign Minister's Conference in Geneva that ended two weeks ago.
The United Israel Appeal reported yesterday that in the last year its agencies had spent $93,153,000 for immigration, rehabilitation and resettlement programs in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Representative James P. Richards, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that Republicans would be "naive" to expect criticism of foreign policy methods to be kept out of the 1956 political campaign.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- A railroad industry task force moved into Boston today to hunt out support for changes in Federal regulations on interstate commerce.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- This Mohawk Valley city rolled out the carpet today for the man who local residents hoped would solve the critical unemployment problem here. Sidney W. Grossman of Quincy, Mass., had never been in Amsterdam before Oct. 24.

GILLO DORFLES, prominent esthetician, journalist and painter from Milan, is showing a group of his monotypes at the Wittenborn Gallery. 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. In most of his prints, the emphasis is on a personal calligraphy that can be read for meaning, like handwriting.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Self-sustaining thermonuclear explosions that might destroy the world are quite impossible under any circumstances. Prof. Maurice H. L. Pryce declared today.
The New York Rangers riddled the Black Hawks' defenses in defeating the Chicagoans, 6 -- 1, in their National Hockey League match at Madison Square Garden last night.

The widow of Prof. Donalo Randolph Charles, geneticist, who committed suicide in a hotel here Saturday, claimed his body at the morgue yesterday. Mrs. Leonie M. Charles of Woods Hole, Mass., said an old friend of her husband's had provided money to bury Dr. Charles in Rochester, N.Y.

William Faulkner of Oxford, Miss., the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, delivered an address before the Southern Historical Association in Memphis, Tenn., on Nov. 10, wherein he deplored "the shame" of segregation.
The Board of Higher Education disclosed yesterday that twenty-four faculty members of the four municipal colleges within its jurisdiction were under investigation for possible Communist ties.

Although many tickets have been purchased, orchestra seats are still available for the Dec. 14 performance of "The Vamp," which will benefit the New York City Mission Society. The musical comedy, starring Carol Channing, opened Nov. 10 at the Winter Garden.

The new mutual assistance pact between American Federation of Labor teamsters and the independent International Longshoremen's Asociation contains no provisions for financial aid to the dockworkers and none will be forthcoming.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Britain's golf fathers today tightened the rules of entry into their amateur championship and announced that in the future the field would be limited to 200 players.

THE children's concert season is under way against and just about every Saturday, somewhere hereabout, a hall is filled with music and with youngsters. Most listen attentively and with delight but some, at least, squirm, yawn or wait in resignation for the parental-imposed ordeal to end.

A serious situation of unforeseeable consequences is developing in Berlin as the result of a startling declaration by the Soviet commandant there which in effect unilaterally abrogates the existing FourPower authority over "Greater Berlin."
The man who will head the combined labor movement is the man who did most to bring it together.

Members of the New York Yacht Club learned last night that De Coursey Fales' 59-foot staysail schooner Nina had added the Cygnet Cup to her large collection of racing trophies. The occasion was the annual awards dinner at the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union has legalized abortion for the first time in almost twenty years.

Six four-story store and commercial buildings at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Eleventh Street have been sold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a client of the Seaboard Funding Corporation and Allan Haymes, brokers in the sale.
DUBLIN, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister John A. Costello condemned political terrorism tonight in the first ministerial comment since the attack on the Northern Ireland police barracks at Roslea last week.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The French Government decreed tonight the dissolution of the National Assembly.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Authorities said tonight that they had solved the murder of the Dellwood Country Club's maintenance superintendent, Myron Hough. They said Mr. Hough's assistant, Donald L. Theis, had signed a confession. He was arraigned and waived examination.

Loans to business by major New York City banks climbed $90,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, bringing these loans to a new high of $9,033,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Robert S. Byfield, an investment broker and adviser, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Doctors Hospital. His age was 58. He resided at the Lombardy Hotel.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- Detroit's three major newspapers, with a total daily circulation of more than 1,300,000 on weekdays, were shut down for the first time in history today by a strike of 120 stereotypers.

Richard Sorge, "the most successful secret agent of World War II," is the subject of a book by Hans Otto Meissner. Rinehart will publish it Jan. 5 under the title "The Man With Three Faces." Sorge, posing as a Nazi and a German foreign correspondent in Tokyo, was chief of the Soviet Far Eastern espionage apparatus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A 20 per cent increase in medical care expenditures from public assistance funds in the last year was reported today by Wilbur J. Cohen, the Social Security Administration Research Director.

SELECTING a gift for someone else's home is a chore that requires tact and imagination as well as taste. For, unlike many fashion fripperies, home accessories are not meant to be used briefly, then discarded but are built to last.
Labor unity became virtually an accomplished fact yesterday.

WHEN Francisco Pizarro and his bloodthirsty comrades destroyed the Inca Empire by treachery, murder and slaughter they were not accompanied by any historians, anthropologists or war correspondents. This oversight is a pity, because the benevolent despotism of the Incas is probably the most interesting example of a planned economy and a welfare state the world has known.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -The Army has enlisted slightly more than 4,500 six-month trainees in the first eight weeks of the new Reserve program.
The Maritime Administration purchased the small coastal motor cargo ship Ann Marie from the Bull Line at 11:30 A. M. yesterday and four hours later turned her over to the Korean Government.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Commissioner of the Metropolitan London Police said today that six of eight policemen, accused by a convicted burglar of bribery and corruption, had been cleared in a departmental investigation.

I was greatly disturbed by the report in The Times of Nov. 21 on the speech of Msgr. John J. McMahon, who so astonishingly criticized your newspaper for its defense of personal freedom in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan charged today that the immigration law violated the national ideal of human equality.

Strength in London and Singapore sent rubber prices soaring yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The March position climbed to a new high for the move. Most options closed at the highs of the day. The near-by months were strongest.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The text of the note of Dr. James B. Conant, United States Ambassador, to George Pushkin, Soviet Ambassador to East Germany on the Berlin Government situation follows:

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- On the eve of his basketball squad's opening game of the season against the University of Toronto, Jim McDermott, Iona College coach, faced two problems today. One had to do with Rudy Eckhardt, the team's tallest player, the other with uniforms.
A former patient at Wassaic State School testified yesterday that a 15-year-old fellow patient had been kicked in the stomach by an attendant and died a week later.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Federal Government has authority to set minimum wages on a nation-wide basis in industries working on Government contracts.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1 -- The Virginia Legislature moved rapidly today toward setting into motion a program designed to prevent forced attendance of Negro and white children in the same schools.

The Committee to Save Carnegie Hall issued a statement yesterday welcoming the possibility of an art center at Lincoln Square but said it had not changed its conviction that "Carnegie Hall should and must be saved."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The White House Conference on Education was criticized today for not having taken up the segregation issue.

Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturer of boilers and heavy equipment, has declared a stock dividend of 5 per cent and the usual quarterly dividend of 75 cents. The cash dividend is payable on Jan. 3 and the stock dividend on Jan. 4.

The Red Cross here collected 9,507 pints of blood last month, as compared with 9,995 pints in October. The high day in November was Wednesday, when 798 pints were collected. Manhattan College personnel contributed 376 pints; employes of the New York Telephone Company office, 101 Willoughby Street, 146, and residents of Staten Island, 130.

Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, Ohio State's star halfback, and Ron Beagle, Navy's outstanding end, won All-America recognition for the second straight year on The Associated Press team, which was announced yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP) -- In what was believed a record $18,700,000 deal, S. I. Newhouse, the publisher, added today two Alabama dailies to his newspaper properties. He also acquired a television station and three radio stations.
College football attendance increased 2.7 per cent this year with the South and West providing the biggest gains.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 1 -- Royal Air Force jet bombers rained thousands of pounds of high explosives throughout the daylight hours today on jungle areas known to be concealing Communist terrorists.

Jack Webb's "Dragnet," which doesn't attract as many viewers as it once did, will make some changes a month from now. Involved in the long-pending changes are two shows, two sponsors and a network. Surprisingly enough, all seem to be happy with the new look.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 1 (UP) -A 25-year-old Tampa boxer knocked into a coma by a punch to the head Tuesday night died today without regaining consciousness.

THURMONT, Md., Dec. 1 -President Eisenhower met for two hours with the National Security Council today at his Camp David, Catoctin Mountain retreat near here. It is twenty-five miles from his Gettysburg farm.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Relations between France and the theoretically associated state of Vietnam have become more strained than ever in the last few days.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a telegram sent today by President Eisenhower to the Republican National Committee, meeting here:
A 74-year-old woman returned yesterday to her former place of employment to take a look at the Christmas toy drive she began thirty-nine years ago.
Some straphangers with flexible habits found subway seats during yesterday's morning rush hour.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Carmen Basilio was in a happy frame of mind today. He was kindly disposed toward everybody except Vince Martinez.
The New York Telephone Company's efforts against illegal wiretapping were termed "obviously inadequate" yesterday by Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr.

SOLOMONS, Md., Dec. 1 (UP) -- Numb with cold, a 35-year-old Navy diver was rescued from 120 feet of water in the Patuxent River tonight after being submerged nearly nine hours on what was to have been an eighteen-minute dive.

THE grand ballroom doors in the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel will close at 2:30 this afternoon on 1,500 to 1,600 men and women assembled, after a sixty-five-year-old New York tradition, to hear the annual Bagby Music Lovers Foundation Concert.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Two witnesses testified today that representatives of General Motors Corporation had asked them to make false car registrations to help Chevrolet maintain its national sales pace.

The need for a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab nations that would benefit "the peoples who live and suffer" in the Middle East was emphasized last night by Pierre Mendes-France, former Premier of France.

The French people now plunge into what promises to be one of the stormiest election campaigns in their recent history as a result of the Government's decision to dissolve the National Assembly and to call for new national elections early in January.
President Eisenhower probably has "average life expectancy" despite his heart attack. Sherman Adams. The Assistant to the President, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Senate investigators heard today that premiums collected by a New Jersey concern on employe group - insurance plans were "embezzled" in "kickback" payments to union officials, a judge and a plumber.

GEORGE SZELL is fond of Beethoven and likes to conduct his music, and these things show in the results he gets. He took over the New York Philharmonic for the start of a four-week visit as guest conductor at Carnegie Hall last night and led it in a program of luminous Beethoven.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Government, which owes more than $70,000 in tax arrears, penalties and interest in Nassau County, Glen Cove and Brookville, exhibited today for the first time in two years a sign of interest in the matter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A Government examiner ruled today that the Federal Trade Commission had no regulatory power over insurance companies operating in forty-four states.
Braniff International Airways announced yesterday that it had ordered five jet-powered transports from the Boeing Company at a cost of $30,000,000.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -Stockholders of the Rock Island Railroad approved today a 2-for-I split in the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -The counsel for a Senate Civil Service subcommittee said today that only a fraction of those Government employes listed as dismissed under the Administration's security program had actually come under the order setting up the program.

Some pitfalls in a type of market study on which agencies and advertisers lean to map a campaign were outlined yesterday by Stanley Frame, director of marketing research of the National Biscuit Company.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway announced yesterday a net income of $53,467,000, or $6.69 a share for the first eleven months of this year. This compared with $33,067,000, or $4.15 a share, earned in the like period last year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- The formation of a new television production company, Nugent Productions, to make a series of TV films titled "Growing Up in Hollywood," was announced today.
The largest liquid bulk carrier in the world, the 47,750-dead-weight-ton Spyros Niarchos, will slide down the ways today in Great Britain.

The drumfire of protests from individuals and civic organizations against the proposal to construct an old-age recreation center adjacent to the Ramble in Central Park has led the Florina Lasker Foundation to withdraw its generous offer to give the city $250,000 for that purpose.

Space for a supermarket has been leased by the Key Foods Company in a seven-story apartment building under construction at 11-49 East Thirty-fifth Street, in the Flatbush district of Brooklyn. The building, known as the Minnesota, is being erected by the Lefrak Organization.

The United Nations is in process of renewing for another year the mandate of its Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees. As of last June there were nearly 906,000 of these refugees -- nearly half a million in Jordan, whose normal population is only a little over three times that number.

Plans for altering the four-story brownstone dwelling at 53 East Sixty-fourth Street into ten apartments were announced yesterday by William Alfred White, broker, who sold the property for cash over mortgages amounting to $45,000.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- The American Medical Association took steps today to preserve the dignity and increase the stature of the family physician.
Paul Muni returned to his starring role in "Inherit the Wind" last night at the National Theatre in an atmosphere fraught with more emotion and drama than is contained in the average Broadway play.
The American Federation of Labor's seventy-fourth and last -- convention was strictly business yesterday -- and with a minimum of oratory.
A strange medical research finding that could lead to a new method of countering the principal physical concomitant of the aging process was reported here yesterday.

A color scheme of white and blue provided the setting last night for the annual White Wing Ball of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. The dinner dance, the organization's chief fund-raising event, took place in the Carnaval and Crystal Rooms of the Sherry-Netherland.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the first-degree murder conviction of Williams Byers, 17 years old, of New York, who was found guilty of plotting and executing the death of his girl friend's mother in March, 1954.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, rejected today suggestions for bilateral discussions with the Soviet Union on German reunification. He took this stand in a statement opening a two-day debate in the Parliament on foreign policy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1--President Eisenhower pledged today an active role in the 1956 Presidential campaign. But he did not commit himself to seek reelection.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 23 -- The Melbourne Olympic games are now a year away, which makes a stocktaking of preparations timely.
The intramural champions of the Fordham and Iona touch football leagues tied, 6 -- 6, yesterday at Edwards Parade on the Rams' campus in the Bronx.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The pace-setting Montreal Canadiens scored a pair of first-period goals and made them stand up for a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the last place Boston tonight. A Boston Garden crowd of 7,073 saw the Bruins' non-winning streak extended to nine games with their fifth straight loss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 676,685 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced !today. This was 94,963 cars, or !12.3 per cent, fewer then for the preceding week; 93,165 cars, or 16 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 80,455 cars, or 13.5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The Parmelee Transportation Company filed suit today in Superior Court for $8,500,000 on the basis of its services in connection with Chicago's railroad terminals.
LAFAYETTE, La., Dec. 1 (UP) -- The excommunication of two Roman Catholic women accused of beating a woman lay teacher of a racially integrated religious class was revoked today.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, maker of plumbing fixtures, heating and air-conditioning equipment, is planning to broaden its operations in the kitchen equipment field through a merger with the Mullins Manufacturing Corporation.

KUMQUATS, looking like miniature elongated oranges, derive from the Orient, which has a special appreciation for the small and the dainty. In recent years, more of them have been appearing here, particularly in gift packages of fruit from Florida, California, or the nearest delicacy store.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson agreed today with John Foster Dulles that "partisan excesses" should be avoided in next year's Presidential campaign discussions of American foreign policy.

Owners of black and white television sets in the metropolitan area and northern New Jersey will be able, beginning next week, to apply the full purchase price of their receivers up to $400 as a trade-in allowance on a CBS-Columbia color set.
Haverhill, Mass., sold in the public market yesterday $3,280,000 of various purpose bonds maturing from 1956 to 1975.
A plan to set up a Benjamin Franklin Scholarship Fund of $250,000 next year to provide for 100 college scholarships for young men and women was made public here last night.
