MICHAEL RENNIE and Zsa Zsa Gabor made a fascinating pair of felons in last night's comedy, "A Man of Taste," presented over Channel 2.

The Port of New York Authority's announcement of plans to build at once a $9,300,000 four-berth marine terminal at Port Newark in New Jersey, to be leased for ten years to Norton, Lilly Co. for general cargo, poses once more the question of what New York City is going to do about its own waterfront modernization problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 10 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
All the top jobs on the New York - New Jersey Waterfront Commission were filled yesterday for the first time since September.

Dual announcements, just made by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of the same, set golden clarions blowing. They proclaim simultaneous exhibitions about to open, the one of American paintings which hung in New York's epochal Armory Show of 1913, the other of examples -manuscripts and bibelots -- "celebrating the extraordinary flowering of American poetry since 1912."
A big retailer charged yesterday that not a single "really modern supermarket with adequate parking" exists on Manhattan Island.
THE maximum effective killing range of a shotgun, using No. 4 or 5 shot, is not 200 yards, as so many duck shooters seem to believe.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 1 (UP) -- Willie Hartack was only three victories away from becoming the second jockey in racing history to gain 400 victories in a year today after scoring a triple at Tropical Park.
THE happiest moments of Jacques Abram's piano recital last night in Town Hall came in the songful slow movement of Chopin's B minor Sonata.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 1 -The Soviet leaders, who took their political roadshow today to a stand in Burma, have left behind in India a feeling of warmth in the Indian masses and some second thoughts among Indian officials.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 1 (UP) -- The National Amateur Athletic Union opened its sixtyeighth convention today with top executives seeking ways to prevent another "Wes Santee case" by cracking down on promoters who proselytize amateur athletes, as well as the guilty contestants.

Events today: Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; PhilharmonicSymphony, George Szell, conductor, Eugene Istomin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Ramy Shevlov, violinist, and Warren Small, baritone, Town Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Swapping Song Fair, Circle in the Square Theatre, 12 midnight.
State officials expressed astonishment yesterday at the laxity of the system of licensing private detectives and said stringent new requirements would be imposed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Labor Department spelled out the details today of its long-awaited study showing the rise in productivity of American factory workers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Corn futures developed considerable strength on the Board of Trade today largely because of the further increase in premiums for cash corn. No. 2 yellow sold at 1 1/2 cents over the December price, compared with a discount of 11 cents a short time ago.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The United States, Britain and France rejected tonight the Soviet contention that the four-power status of Berlin was at an end.
A city ordinance that prohibits the sale or possession of realistic toy pistols was deemed invalid yesterday by Magistrate Louis I. Kaplan in Bronx Magistrate's Court.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 1 -- Full support for private schools should be provided by those who choose to maintain them, the National Council of Churches General Board said today.

Three men, including a New Jersey securities broker, were indicted here yesterday on charges of mulcting 1,400 persons out of nearly $900,000 in the sale of unsecured bonds The securities were issued by the Alaska Telephone Corporation of Seattle, Wash.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following are the texts of today's reports of the White House Conference on Education:

Four witnesses testified yesterday as to the good character and high integrity of the Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., as the contracting stevedore opened defense of its application for a permanent Waterfront Commission license.
The merged American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations will not become a political party, but it will have a political action committee, a ranking union official said yesterday.
The Community Service Society announced yesterday the formation of a technical advisory committee to aid in its study of the problems associated with aging.

Albert Conway, chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, said last night it might become necessary to put the increasing number of automobile negligence cases "out of the courts in order that the courts may be saved."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -A Government examiner ruled today that the Civil Rights Congress was "conceived by the Kremlin" and operated as a money-raising front for the Communist party conspiracy in the United States.
NOTHING has happened since 1927 to temper the beauty of "The Cradle Song," which was acted at Circle in the Square last evening.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- The Republican leader of the Assembly urged Governor Harriman today to allocate $50,000,000 of what were termed excess state revenues to a highway construction program.
The nation's drivers failed to make yesterday a meaningful Safe Driving Day.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The French Government again plans to pay a part of its international debt ahead of time.
Prince Albert of Belgium completed yesterday a two-and-a-half month tour of the United States, which seems to have been highly educational but not much fun.
Now that the basketball season has arrived, reactions soon will be pouring in on the effect of the 1955-56 rules changes. There have been two major revisions of the collegiate court code.
Yesterday for the first time in the United States, a railroad passenger car was operated by remote control on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The Missouri - Kansas - Texas Railroad once more is going to try to rid itself of $100,000,000 of dividend arrearages that have piled up on its 667,004 shares of $7 preferred stock. It will be the third such attempt the company will have made in the last three years.

A LIVELY selection of prints by more than fifty contemporary American artists, most of them experts in their chosen media, is on view at the RoKo Gallery, 51 Greenwich Avenue. Selected to demonstrate the wide expressive range of the graphic arts, the show includes works by many established printmakers, among them Frasconi. Crawford, Yunkers, Casarella and Wald, as well as a host of works by younger names.
The man who made the lever that formally split the labor movement in 1936 looked down the years yesterday and had no regrets.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Premier Edgar Faure was ousted from the Radical party today for his decision to dissolve the National Assembly and necessitate new elections without reform of the voting law.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Jenney of Walnut Hall Stud at Lexington, Ky., today purchased the trotting stallion Kimberly Kid for $150,000. It was the second largest price paid for a harness horse.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 1 -Six hundred of this city's 1,500 unionized hatters did not show up for work today. They went to a party instead -- and with the boss' approval.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer installment credit rose to a new high in October. But it said the month - to - month increase was the smallest since February.

Three of the seven guards in Manhattan City Prison arrested Wednesday on charges of selling favors to inmates have arrest or conviction records, it was disclosed yesterday after their arraignment in Felony Court.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz returned to his homeland amid cheers tonight to resume control of his family's celebrated newspaper La Prensa.

THE story that best illustrates the iron will of Carmen Basilio, the world welterweight champion, is one they've been telling along the concrete strands of Jacobs' Beach, the lounging spot for boxing's idlers. It happened in 1948 when the sharp-featured, granite-jawed refugee from an onion farm reached his big decision.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Matthew J. Connelly and Theron Lamar Caudle, who held high positions in the Truman Administration, were indicted today for conspiracy to defraud the Government.
Copal Mintz' letter in your issue of Nov. 26, in which he discussed the manner and method of selecting judges in our state courts, though persuasive, is not at all convincing.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 1 -- The United States and Czechoslovakia have opened preliminary negotiations here on some old economic problems between the two countries.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 1 -Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet party secretary, arrived in Burma today following their tour of India.

The New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle is expected to be ready for opening to the public on April 28, 1956. The question is, Will New York be ready -- as to traffichandling preparations -- for the Coliseum?"
VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 1 -- Communications, a subject brought before the Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects almost everywhere it has traveled, was the chief problem tackled again today.

As chairman of the Traffic Committee of the Greenwich Village Association and head of the Sixth Precinct Coordinating Council, which deals with area recreational needs, I am in a position to speak with some background and authority on the current Washington SquareFifth Avenue problem.

A Santa Claus of Old Amsterdam dropped in yesterday on New Amsterdam, via Grand Central Terminal, to spread Christmas cheer in traditional Dutch style. The bearded St. Nicholas of the Netherlands, dressed in the scarlet robes of a jolly Bishop, paid his annual visit to the station's upper level as a reminder of the Sinterklaas heritage of Dutch-developed New York.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 1 -- An Israeli Army spokesman reported tonight a fifth shooting incident in twenty-four hours along the Gaza strip.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP) -Twenty-nine persons at the Pimlico race track were clutching daily double tickets worth at least $5,500 for several minutes today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- Six United States priests of the Russian Orthodox Church accused the State Department today of harming the national interest of the United States by refusing a visa to Archbishop Boris.
The National Lead Company announced yesterday that it had succeeded in producing automotive engine blocks of aluminum by means of what is believed to be the world's largest die-casting machine.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 30 -- The Guatemalan Government has before it ninety-two applications filed by twenty-nine oil companies for exploration rights under the Petroleum Code signed by President Carlos Castillo Armas on July 7. Most of the companies are American.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu today attacked the Soviet Union's recent nuclear tests and said "international tensions are once more mounting apace."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The British Government is gravely concerned over evidence that the Soviet Union intends to use its foothold in Egypt as the starting point for a campaign of Communist infiltration and subversion in Africa.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- Archibald S. Alexander is expected to resign on Monday as New Jersey State Treasurer. His appointment as director of the National Stevenson for President Committee was announced by Adlai E. Stevenson in Chicago last week.

ONE American artist who has steadily grown in stature, as one show has followed another at intervals of three or four years, is Karl Knaths. In the exhibition of his most recent work at Paul Rosenberg's, 20 East Seventyninth Street, his palette has been somewhat stepped up, with greenish blues, burgundies and luminous mauves brought into play among the familiar tans, grays and blacks.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 -- Argentine football fans will have to change their sleeping habits if they want to see their favorite teams in action. And when they get to a game they will no longer be able to buy soda pop.

Research, clinical facilities and patient-aid services for sufferers from arthritis will be supported by the proceeds from the Feb. 6 performance of "Pipe Dream." The musical comedy, starring Helen Traubel and William Johnson, opened on Wednesday at the Shubert Theatre.
The traditional holiday garlands for the friendly lions outside the New York Public Library at Forty-first Street were put in place yesterday.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 1 -- A unanimous Michigan Supreme Court decision today cleared the way for construction of toll roads in the birthplace of the automobile. The court upheld the constitutionality of the state's toll-road law.

GILBERT AND SULLIVAN without Sullivan is like beer without hops. At least, that is the impression one got from last night's performance of "The Mountebanks," for which Albert Cellier composed the music to Sir William's libretto.

The Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Wednesday moved contrary to its present policy of permitting credit to tighten by adding funds to the money market, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., transacted the largest annual sales in its history in the fifty-two weeks ended Oct. 29, while volume for the quarter ended Oct. 29 was the best for any similar period on record. Earnings were the highest for any corresponding periods of the last five years.

The Metropolitan Opera has engaged Oleg Briansky to appear as premier danseur in Zachary Solov's new ballet, "Soirce," and in the ballet in "Fledermaus." He is the third featured dancer to join the opera ballet this season.
RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 1 -- Andre Dubois, French Resident General in Morocco, left today for a tour of areas where the Berber tribesmen revolted two months ago today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 1 -Australia's economic and foreign policy for the next three years will be determined by the federal elections to be held Dec. 10. The broad choice for almost 7,000,000 voters lies between economic conservativism or a semi-Socialist program at home and between a strong free-world alliance or a policy approaching neutralism abroad.
Walter P. Reuther predicted yesterday that the 1956 elections would result in a Government "more responsive to the needs of people rather than big business."

Plans were completed recently for the eighth annual Bachelors Ball at a meeting held in the home of Miss Nora F. Francke at 156 East Seventy-fourth Street. The ball will be held on the night of Dec. 17 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
The stock market moved uncertainly yesterday, strong in the morning, weak in the afternoon and closed with moderate losses.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- An agreement to sell Shapleigh Hardware Company, 102-year-old St. Louis firm, to Harold C. Schott and Associates of Cleveland was announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Sweden said today the prospects of agreement on the prohibition of nuclear weapons were so poor that the world should concentrate on trying to cut nonatomic weapons and armed forces.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Aluminium, Ltd., officials said today that the corporation's principal subsidiary, Aluminum Company of Canada, would be forced to make a temporary cutback in aluminum production this winter because a drought in Quebec has cut water power supplies.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The critics gently but quite thoroughly disapproved of "Anniversary Waltz," which opened last night at the Lyric Theatre.

A one-story industrial building under construction on the north side of Queens Boulevard, east of Fifty-eighth Street, in Woodside, Queens, has been leased by the Udylite Corporation, manufacturer of electro-plating equipment and chemicals. The property is being improved by the owner, Herman Hinsch.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, charged the Democrats today with having stirred "a witch's brew" for solutions to the farm problem. He put forth a six-point program to alleviate agriculture's difficulties, saying President Eisenhower had agreed on it at a recent meeting.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union linked today the fate of German war prisoners held here with the repatriation of Soviet citizens living in West Germany.
The largest North American newsprint producer informed United States customers yesterday that it would cut deliveries by 7 1/2 per cent beginning in January.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today slashed by 10 per cent the world sugar export quota and fixed the 1956 quota for Cuba at 2,025,000 metric tons.
New York City office workers won an average pay rise of 4.6 per cent in the last year, the Commerce and Industry Association said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Only if Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle are proved unquestionably guilty of the malfeasances in public office, almost four years ago, with which a grand jury in St. Louis has now charged them can anyone with true respect for a high commandment of Anglo-American law venture to condemn them.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Labor party asked the Government tonight to seek an agreement with the United States and the Soviet Union to end tests of nuclear weapons.
Dr. Maurice J. Lewi said on his ninety-eighth birthday yesterday that he was "too old to retire." But he was not too old to enjoy his annual birthday interview.
Washington, Dec. 1 -- The State Department is being careful not to exaggerate the significance of last Sunday's incident in East Berlin.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -Georges Simenon, the French writer, has a chance to earn $3,000 a day for writing the screen version of his new book, "The Hitch Hikers."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1 -The minor leagues, still heavily dominated by the major leagues' far-flung farm systems, took one bold step today that should irk the big fellows.
The City Administration's broad plan for stricter multiple dwelling standards was approved unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Prices of cototn futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 18 points (90 cents a bale) up yesterday. The strength was most pronounced in old-crop months.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Dec. 1 -- More than 900 members of the Young Democratic Clubs of America met here today to open their organization's ninth biennial convention.

Argentines spread out the red carpet yesterday when Alberto Gainza Paz, owner and publisher of La Prensa of Buenos Aires, came back after four and a half years of exile to resume publication of that great newspaper in freedom.
FORT POLK, La., Dec. 1 -- A cold rain bogged down United States forces and an "aggressor enemy" in Exercise Sagebrush today.

It is disturbing to find in your editorial "Moscow's Newest Bomb" the question "* * * is it sound policy to base civil-defense planning on the assumption of atomic-bomb attack alone * * *?" I think you will agree that, couched in this form, the reader must infer that civil-defense planning is oriented solely to A-bomb attack.
The separation of church and state would be violated and thousands of summer church programs here adversely affected if a proposed city code became law, religious leaders fear.
McINTOSH, Ala., Dec. 1 -Governor Harriman of New York chided President Eisenhower today for "telling the world" that Soviet leaders were "desirous of peace."

Having scored a bull's-eye with "Silk Stockings," the source of which was the successful MetroGoldwyn-Mayer film, "Ninotchka," the firm of Cy Feuer and Ernest H. Martin has its collective eye on another Metro product.
The St. Joseph's basketball squad went on a scoring spree in the Fordham Gymnasium last night and defeated the Rams, 89-71, in the season's opener for both teams.

Today's new film is "Lady Godiva," at the Palace. The Universal - International period drama is in Technicolor with Maureen O'Hara in the title role, George Nader, Edward Franz and Victor McLaglen. The screen play was by Oscar Brodney and Harry Ruskin.
The Atlas Corporation, investment trust, has bought a 66 1/2-per-cent interest and working control of the Almar uranium mine in Utah for slightly more than $8,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Federal aid to education received strong support on two fronts today.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 1 -- A father and son team won a national contract bridge championship for the first time in the thirty-four-year history of bridge tournaments today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Hog prices tumbled to new lows since 1941 today on a heavy outpouring of offerings from the country.

Harris J. Klein, former member of the Transit Authority and now counsel to the New York Civic League, and Nelson Seitel, City Labor Commissioner and chairman of the Transit Advisory Committee, clashed over bus fares yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- West Germany intends to participate in the economic development of southern Italy. This was announced here today by Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of Economics, at the end of a six-day visit to Italy.
Trustees of the United States Trust Company yesterday proposed a five-for-one split of the stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A broad program to end the critical teacher shortage and to raise teaching standards was presented today by the White House Conference on Education.

A television antenna was tossed from the chimney of one of the oldest houses in the nation yesterday as the first step in the demolition of the structure. Change, which since 1776 had come slowly and constructively to the historic Bennet house on Ninety-fifth Street at Shore Road in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, became swift and destructive as demolition workers moved in with axes and sledgehammers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Canada called on the United Nations today to admit eighteen applicants for membership as a move to strengthen the international organization.
A bank hold-up in Brooklyn was foiled yesterday because the manager had changed his habits after an earlier robbery.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -The investment banking industry was told here today that it was still backward in public relations. It was warned that any substantial improvement hinged on how effectively the young men coming up in the industry could "sell" its function to the public.
The world champion Brooklyn Dodgers will play seven regularseason games and one exhibition game in Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States is ready to back Greece as a compromise candidate for the United Nations Security Council if the Philippine-Yugoslav deadlock is not resolved next week.
A "revolution in foreign missions" is foreseen by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

The New York Newspaper Women's Club presented awards for outstanding work in journalism to five newspaper women last night. A $50 United States savings bond and a parchment scroll were given to each winner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People complained today that Sixth Army headquarters at the Presidio here was using "race-tags" in designating military personnel eligible for foreign service.

Just in time for the holidays is a new idea for a little girl's homemade party costume. Proposed by the Necchi Home Arts Center, it is intended as a basic ensemble suitable for a variety of uses. The costume consists of a gray felt skirt-and-vest combination, to be teamed with a cotton blouse.

A GIRL'S chances today to marry tomorrow's millionaire are as good as they were in the Twenties. For the American Dream that the poor farm boy can rise to the top of the great corporation is still a fact.
HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- Ten students and several policemen were injured today when the police broke up a student demonstration against the Government near Havana University.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The "spirit of Geneva" is not dead, the chief of the Soviet delegation declared today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Municipal censorship of a painting of two nudes touched off a rebellion in the Baltimore art world today. Seven artists stormed Peale Museum and stalked out with their pictures under their arms.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- An armed robber held up and kidnapped four company employes in their automobile this afternoon and freed them unharmed a half hour later, after taking a $3,800 payroll. The gunman escaped in a car with an accomplice who had trailed him during the hold-up.

FORT POLK, La., Dec. 2 -- Much improved reconnaissance, better intelligence and increased mobility are essential to match the increased volume of fire and destructiveness of modern weapons, Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Two top officials of General Motors were confronted today by three angry automobile dealers. The three charged the giant company with forcing "wilder and wilder" sales practices."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be guarantor for a family of six who have been trying to emigrate from the Netherlands to the United States for two years, a Dutch newspaper reported today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies appealed to the nation tonight to return a conservative majority in the Senate in the elections Dec. 10. His aim is to avoid a possible government stalemate if his Liberal-Country party coalition retains the lower house, as expected.
EAGLE PASS, Tex., Dec. 2 (UP) -- A 400-foot section of a bridge across the Rio Grande collapsed today, hurling about 100 men to the dry river bed thirty feet below. Thirty-two were injured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower's Cabinet threshed ideas today for improving farm prices and income through legislative action.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Seven Soviet newspaper men charged today that they had been followed by "hordes" of detectives during their thirty-three-day trip to the United States this fall.

Tom Gola, former La Salle College All-America, will make his first pro appearance of the season at Madison Square Garden tonight. Gola is slated to start at right forward for the Philadelphia Warriors in their National Basketball Association contest with the New York Knickbockers.

In the face of the new Soviet threat to Berlin, and despite the failure of Geneva, the West German Government and Parliament have categorically rejected all suggestions for separate negotiations with Soviet Russia. Instead they have reaffirmed their unwavering allegiance to the West.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Production of cars and trucks since Jan. 1 will top 8,500,000 units late tomorrow, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2 -- Premier Pibul Songgram said today that Thailand was not drifting toward neutralism like that of India and Burma.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits yesterday rebuked Vincent P. Carney, Deputy Commissioner of Motor Vehicles and district tax supervisor (Long Island district). Mr. Carney had permitted the use of his signature and tax department title on form letters soliciting funds for the Brooklyn Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

Mayor Wagner broached one of the baffling problems of urban life in his address to the American Municipal Association in Miami. How can the modern metropolis function properly when it bursts its political boundaries and, as in the case of New York, may overflow into the outlands of three states?
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Hog prices firmed today as producers cut shipments to 10,000 salable head, 6,000 under the advance estimate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker suggested today a shortened version of his proposed constitutional amendment to limit treaty powers. He said that the new proposal included "all the major objectives" of the original.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The grain and soybean futures markets today were generally firm, but there was the usual inertia in following rallies, and the action was choppy.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 2 -- Emigration of skilled labor from Canada to the United States should be a matter of great concern to Canada, the Royal Commission studying this country's economic prospects was told today.
William Vassar has been named director of engineering of CBS-Columbia, a division of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 30 -- Two major problems are troubling South Africa's governing party, the Nationalists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A high Justice Department source said today that the indictment of Matthew J. Connelly and Theron Lamar Caudle, who held important posts in the Truman Administration, was based on information recently uncovered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Hawaiian Steamship Company, Ltd., today designated the Pacific Far East Line as agent to operate the vessel with which it proposes to introduce low-cost Honolulu-San Francisco passenger service next summer.

The Associated Licensed Detectives of New York State, Inc., representing 350 of the state's 500 detectives, demanded yesterday that it be allowed to testify before the Joint Legislative Committee to Study Interception of Communications.

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, urged Southern Democrats and Independents tonight to unite under the Republican banner to "make America a greater and a better nation."
The Congress of Industrial Organizations ended its independent existence yesterday with words of high idealism from several of its leaders and a bitter blast from another.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The New York Rangers made two first-period goals stand up tonight for a 2-1 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawk's to extend their unbeaten string in the National Hockey League to six games before 7,886 fans.

Events today: Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic - Symphony, George Szell, conductor, Eugene Istomin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:45 P. M.; "La Boheme," Rossini Workshop, 5 West Sixty-third Street, 8:30; Swapping Song Fair, Circle in the Square Theatre, 12 midnight.
The death toll for the nation on Safe Driving Day this year was 35.3 per cent higher than it was in 1954.

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 -- Gov. Marvin Griffin today called on the State Board of Regents to prohibit Georgia football teams from playing against teams that use Negroes. He urged the regents to call an immediate meeting to act upon his proposal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles joined a visiting statesman tonight in denouncing remarks by Soviet leaders now touring Asia as an attempt "to foment hatred between the East and West."

Six American watch manufacturers and importers and a Swiss watch manufacturers association and its American agents were charged yesterday with violating the Sherman Antitrust Act and the Wilson Tariff Act.
ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Georgia Tech students tonight hanged Governor Griffin in effigy from a big tree outside a dormitory on the campus.

A "possible group care code" that would affect churches and synagogues was said yesterday by the chairman of the group working on the document to contain "nothing final." The suggested code has been criticized by Roman Catholic and Protestant spokesmen.

Some interesting facts about New York State's economy emerge from the analysis of personal income in 1954 as published in the State Commerce Department's monthly report, Commerce Review. New Yorkers last year enjoyed a per capita income of $2,163 in money or in kind, which was $13 better than in 1953 and which compared with a $20 decline experienced in the nation as a whole.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- A Chicago labor leader facing contempt prosecution marched into a Senate hearing today with two bodyguards, seven cartons of records and a belated offer to testify.

Isaac Logart, a welterweight boxer from Camaguey, Cuba, gained the decision over Virgil Akins of St. Louis in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 3,000 witnessed the contest, in which the decision for the Cuban was unanimous.

The latest attempt to resolve the deadlock over admission of new members to the United Nations is another instance of the lack of endurance on the part of the free nations for prolonged negotiations over a problem on which they have, as a matter of principle, refused to give in for a number of years.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 2 (UP) -- Gov. James E. Folsom scoffed at Air Force disapproval of using National Guard planes to attend football games today by announcing a giant Gator Bowl "weather survey."
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Industrial shares extended their gains in more active trading today.

NOT many years ago, when you looked up Lord Acton's remark about power in your indispensable "Bartlett's Familiar Quotations,"* you found this: "Power tends to corrupt; absolute power corrupts absolutely." And Bartlett's authority was cited as follows: "Quoted in Time, July 22, 1946, Page 28," while the author was given as Sir John Francis Edward Acton, 1736-1811.

Directors of Lucky Stores, Inc., have approved a proposed merger with Dolly Madison International Foods, Ltd. The transaction is subject to approval by stockholders of both companies. Lucky operates a chain of retail supermarkets in northern California while Dolly Madison International owns food stores in southern California and Miami and also an institutional food distribution business in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
A Federal prosecutor charged yesterday that an inmate in the Federal Penitentiary in Leavenworth, Kan., had directed the operations of a $500,000 automobile theft ring in the metropolitan area.
An off-duty policeman captured a hold-up suspect in Times Square last night.

The three-story commercial building at 8777 Nineteenth Avenue in the Bensonhurst district of Brooklyn has been purchased by Onofrio Tripo. The building, on an irregular plot about 37 by 83 feet, contains a store and two lofts. The new owner plans to use the property for a showroom in connection with his Tripo furniture store at 1942 Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United States today signed a new monetary stabilization agreement with Mexico. The agreement extends arrangements by which the United States agrees to help stabilize the value of the Mexican peso for two years, until Dec. 31, 1957.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The broadcasting industry has become a billion dollar business.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, widow of the former President, Thomas K. Finletter and a group of other well-known Democrats are organizing a New York "Stevenson-for-President" committee.
A third inquiry into the Department of Correction was begun yesterday, this one by the Department of Investigation.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- The Government coalition parties approved today the Bonn regime's policy of rapid armament and integration with the West. By a show of hands, they gave this answer to the Soviet refusal to agree to the reunification of Germany in peace and freedom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Treasury revealed today an unusually cool response to its offer of new, higher-yield securities for old ones coming due on Dec. 15. Holders of only 86 per cent of the maturing securities owned outside the Federal Reserve System have accepted the new ones.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Thomas E. Dewey tonight called for "drastic" revisions in Civil Service examination procedures, "both at the entrance levels and in promotion fields."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin received a patent this week for the latest of his many contributions to television -- a color tube for home receivers. Dr. Zworykin has improved television both at the scene and in the living room. He invented the Iconoscope, the first practical "pick-up" tube for television cameras.
Charles Leo Farley, a father of four, was arrested yesterday on a charge of having robbed a Long Island bank of $33,265 on March 21.
HAVANA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Mike Souchak of Grossinger, N. Y., retained his three-stroke lead in the $15,000 Havana invitation pro-amateur golf tournament after the second round today.
Flatbush residents will give blood to the Red Cross at the Flatbush Savings Bank, 1045 Flatbush Avenue (BUckminster 4-5200) today from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M.
Reference is made to your article of Nov. 28 on the forthcoming Presidential election in the Republic of Korea.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Names of leading contenders in the Audience Awards contest conducted by the Council of Motion Picture Organizations were revealed here today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union has entered a new phase of its relatively short history. This is true economically, politically and psychologically. And in each sphere changes can be detected on the surface.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Fog continued to blanket Western Europe today, grounding dozens of commercial airliners.
The Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross observed its fiftieth anniversary yesterday by dedicating its new headquarters in the Brooklyn Civic Center.
The American Federation of Labor revoked yesterday the charter of one affiliate for strike-breaking against another.

I have been much interested in the issue (reported in your columns and in letters addressed to you) of the appointment to the Children's Court by Judge Hill of probation officers in number proportional to the case-load of the court -- Catholic, Jewish and Protestant.

Prince Albert of Belgium, younger brother of King Baudouin of the Belgians, sailed from New York for his home yesterday after a two-and- a-half-month visit to the United States. It was a quiet, modest, unofficial trip in which the 21-year-old naval lieutenant stuck seriously to the itinerary worked out for him by his father, former King Leopold.
Another secondary leader of the Communist party in this country voluntarily surrendered yesterday, the second one to do so this week. He had been a fugitive since 1951.

TOWSON, Md., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Larry S. MacPhail, former baseball owner and once president of Bowie Race Track, won an award of $99,971.10 today from the Bowie management in a breach-of-contract suit. A jury of seven men and five women took a little more than an hour to agree on the verdict.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The British Government is considering revision of its tax structure to place more emphasis on indirect taxation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Harry Sherr, a Department of Agriculture economist, predicted yesterday that an expected 1956 increase in the amount of money a person to be spent for goods would go to "the more expensive and highly processed foods."
After three weeks of rehearsals, Jack Segasture, producer of the musical, "Pleasure Dome," has had to close it because of "financial difficulties."
TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- The Port of New York Authority is planning to establish a new Port Elizabeth on a 400-acre tract of marshland adjacent to Newark Bay.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- About 150 West Coast ships are threatened with a tie-up in a dispute over vacation-pay for the firemen in their crews.
The attainments of the National Municipal League and its leaders were reviewed yesterday at the dedication of its new building at 47 East Sixty-eighth Street.

A torch commemorating the victory of the Maccabees over their Syrian oppressors will be kindled at a special Hanukkah festival at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15. Hanukkah, known also as the Feast of Lights, begins next Friday evening and is celebrated for eight days.
An offering of $50,000,000 of New York State Thruway Authority bonds heads the list of municipal offerings next week. Its scheduled to hit the market Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Defense Department's new budget will exceed Secretary Charles E. Wilson's economy goal by about $500,000,000. This is the conclusion reached by high Pentagon officials who are in the final stages of preparing the Army, Navy and Air Force budgets for the 1957 fiscal year, which starts next July 1.

The three apartment houses at 506-10-14 Concord Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by H. Lipshitz, operator, subject to a first mortgage of $135,000. They were sold by Abraham Zalaznick, who had owned them twenty years. The buildings contain sixty-three apartments. Langsam Siegel were the brokers in the transaction.

The Jesuit, one of the famous orders of the Roman Catholic Church, is the subject of a book by the Rev. John LaFarge and Margaret Bourke-White, which Farrar, Straus Cudahy will publish next year. The text, by Father LaFarge, traces the development of American Jesuits from their first manor settlement in Maryland to the president. Miss Bourke-White's photographs "illustrate and complement" the text.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Representatives of Southern newspapers, feeling a recent increase in paper costs, today endorsed a plan to establish a newsprint plant at Palatka, Fla.

THE upland game hunters who failed to get their share of pheasants can remedy this and get some post-season exercise for bird dogs at the various shooting dog trials that will be held near the city during the next two months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Federal contributions to the general assistance provided for the needy were urged today at a meeting of the American Public Welfare Association.

Today's new film is "This Strange Passion," at the Trans-Lux 52d Street Theatre. The drama was filmed in Mexico by Tepeyac Productions and has English titles. Luis Bunuel directed and wrote the screen play. Oscar Dancigers produced. Heading the cast are Arturo de Cordova and Delia Garces.
Twenty million calendars were ordered yesterday. Purchasers jumped the annual gun in a sense. The orders were for 1957 calendars.

" EVERYTHING for the Christmas fruit cake," reads a sign tucked among trays of succulent candied fruits in the window of Black Koenig. 52 Dey Street. It is no idle boast, for the old-fashioned Downtown grocery offers not only glaceed cherries, pineapple, citron and citrus peels but also a wide assortment of nuts, unusual as well as familiar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The Interior Department announced today a proposed contract calling for the creation of $13,500,000 in new tourist facilities at Yellowstone National Park in the next ten years.

" ANDREA CHENIER," the only opera by Umberto Giordano to hold the stage in America, was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time this season. It continues to maintain its position as one of the most successful revivals of Rudolf Bing's regime.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- A worldwide investigation is needed to aid in solving the riddles of heart disease, Dr. Paul Dudley White said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The Interior Department's Conservation Advisory Committee recommended today that Congress ban construction of any upper Colorado River dams or reservoirs on national parks or other conservation lands.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Diplomats reported today that the British Government had made a guarded offer to grant eventual self-determination to Cyprus.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Dee. 2 (AP) -- The daily double pay-off at Narragansett Park today was $1,769, the second largest of the New England season.
The United States Government moved a step closer yesterday toward winding up its tremendous surplus ship sales account.

JUST why there have been fewer eminent women artists than men is one of the mysteries of human nature. For sensibility and imagination, the artist's two chief attributes, are by no means male monopolies. Social conventions and the relegation of women to domestic duties have undoubtedly had much to do with their minor artistic role in the past. But not all.
Children often misbehave to please their parents, a psychiatrist asserted yesterday. A delinquent child, he said, thus carries out acts that the parents themselves would like to do, but do not dare.

The enthusiasm and interest generated by the White House Conference on Education should provide Congress with needed encouragement to take speedy and effective action at its next session to relieve the crisis of the schools.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Dec. 2 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan, referring today to his recent criticism of Adlai E. Stevenson, declared that no "state of war" existed between them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Ezra Taft Benson's mail has multiplied since Nov. 23 when he called on "everyone" to send suggestions for solutions of farm problems. He has received 2,335 letters from all parts of the country and with all shades of ideas and opinions.

Price changes on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday. Most of the light volume involved evening of holdings for the week-end. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, onions, soybean oil, wool and copper closed mixed; rubber, zinc, tin and hides rose, and potatoes and cottonseed oil eased.

Walter J. Lawrence in his letter of Nov. 18 wrote an excellent reply to your "Traffic Fable" editorial because it deals with the ridiculous signals and warnings and instructions to pedestrians and motorists alike. And now come "penalties for jaywalking," whatever that means.

A dozen Latin-American nations have borrowed $642,405,000 from the World Bank in the last ten years without defaulting on a single payment of principal or interest, Dr. Luis Machado, the bank's executive director, said yesterday.

The resonant baritone voice that millions of television viewers hear singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" on fight nights in Madison Square Garden belongs to an assistant corporation counsel of the City of New York.
Elmer Francis (Trigger) Burke, escaped convict and gunman extraordinary, was found guilty of first-degree murder by a General Sessions jury last night. The death sentence is mandatory.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 -- Governor Harriman declared tonight that "the lines of the great alliance of free peoples have been seriously breached" by Soviet successes at the Geneva conferences.

DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 2 (AP) -- North Carolina, which hasn't beaten its neighborhood rival, Duke, in a football game since 1949, is going to make a try at it tomorrow before a nationwide television audience.

W. R. Grace Co., active in a wide variety of industries in the Western Hemisphere, announced yesterday a major realignment of officer responsibilities. Directors have named Hugh S. Ferguson executive vice president of the chemical group.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia regained the world pocket billiard crown with a 1,500-to-676 victory over the defending champion, Irving Crane, Rochester, N. Y., in a week-long match concluded at Allingers' tonight.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower met with his top military advisers today. He then prepared for a morning of work with the Republican leaders of Congress tomorrow.

The magnitude of the problem of mental retardation is not generally recognized. Affecting as it does 3 per cent of our population, it exceeds all other afflictions of childhood combined. Experts estimate that out of every 100,000 children fifteen are likely to be blind, seven cerebral palsied, 7.26 polio victims, 200 rheumatic heart patients and a staggering 3,000 mentally retarded.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America yesterday declared an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. Both dividends will be paid on Jan. 23 to stockholders of record of Dec. 16.

Julius Helfand, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday interposed a "road block" to the promotion of a welterweight championship fight involving the titleholder, Carmen Basilio, and Johnny Saxton, an ex-147-pound king, in this state.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 2 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev threw barbed criticism today at France, Britain and the United States.
Bill Rigney yesterday received some of the best news he has had since being appointed Leo Durocher's successor as manager of the Giants last September.
TWO gifted young artists, Ramy Shevlov, violinist from Israel, and Warren Small, baritone of this country, made their debuts in a joint recital at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Protective headgear, one of the major controversies of the sixty-eighth convention of the National Amateur Athletic Union, was made optional for amateur boxers today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 2 -- Two Opposition newspapers have requested the assignment of police censors to their offices, rather than continue with the voluntary censorship established by the Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Those close to the educational picture see 1956 as the year in which the problems plaguing the nation's schools since the end of World War II will be resolved, in part at least.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The death rate from lung cancer among men who smoke two packs of cigarettes a day is ninety times that of the nonsmoker, a New York cancer expert said today.
Ship traffic at the Port of New York last month showed an increase of 102 ship movements over November of last year.

RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 2 -- Morocco's largest nationalist party demanded today the end of foreign rule throughout the country and sweeping internal reforms to create a "truly sovereign and independent state."
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday eased 1 to 29 points (5 cents to $1.45 a bale).

Seven youths were held in $15,000 bail each yesterday in the stabbing of an IND subway conductor on Nov. 24. The defendants appeared on charges of felonious assault before Magistrate A. Lawrence Acquavella in Brooklyn Adolescents Court.

With the right cards, one can go almost anywhere and enjoy the trip with all its trimmings without immediately feeling the financial strain. Credit cards, used for on-the-cuff purchases of goods and services, help defer the expenses.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Argentina unexpectedly entered the seventh winter Olympic games just before the deadline today, bringing the total number of nations entered to a record thirty-three. The previous record was thirty nations, at Oslo in 1952. The 1956 games will be held Jan. 26-Feb. 5.

Allegations of brutality on the part of attendants at the Wassaic State School for Mental Defectives are being investigated in private to protect both patients and state employes, Paul H. Hoch, the State Mental Hygiene Commissioner, said yesterday.

The four-story business building on lot 46 by 60 feet at 142 Maiden Lane, corner of Front Street, has been sold by the Rosely Realty Corporation to Jack Luben for investment in a deal negotiated by Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker. It is assessed at $75,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $35,000.
The Municipal Court at 8 Reade Street got a second constitutional question yesterday in a landlords' suit. This time it was whether a member of the State Legislature could be called to testify.
TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- The shape of things to come sketched for a special session of the Japanese Diet today by the Government looked very much like the shape of things as they are.

SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Gov. William G. Stratton of Illinois and others here today assailed Federal control or the threat of such control over the oil industry. They addressed the opening general session of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission, of which Governor Stratton is outgoing chairman.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Under the handling of Bennie Green, the Pin Oak Farm's War and Peace gained a nose victory over the favored Blazing Home in the feature at Pimlico today.
George Meany's valedictory to the final session of the final convention of the American Federation of Labor yesterday was a defense of labor unity.

STUTTGART, Germany, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Walter Gieseking, German concert pianist, and eight United States soldiers newly arrived in Germany were injured in a bus accident near here today. Two passengers were killed.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 2 -- The word is going around Europe's top banking circles that the boom wil continue well into 1956, at least.

The Permanente Cement Company cleared a net profit of $5,346,000, equal to $1.88 a share, for the nine months ended Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday. This was 29 per cent above the $4,144,000, or $1.46 a share, cleared for the similar nine months of 1954.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A Senate investigation into the Government's security program was recessed indefinitely today when sharp partisan notes disrupted it.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 2 -- The Virginia House of Delegates approved today the first step in a program designed to circumvent the Supreme Court's rulings against racial segregation in the public schools.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The United States' campaign to win support for President Eisenhower's "open sky" disarmament proposals moved into high gear today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Bill Virdon, the fleet-footed, bespectacled outfielder of the St. Louis Cardinals, was named today as the National League's rookie of the year for 1955.

Stocks moved disparately yesterday. There were sharp gains and losses on corporate developments. Here and there tax-selling could be suspected. Here and there solid support for "blue chips" seemed to hint at institutional buying.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Construction has started on a u16,000,000 ($45,920,000) iron and steel plant in a Cairo suburb near Helwan. It will be the first of its kind in all the Middle East.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States Ambassador to West Germany, visited Berlin today to reaffirm the determination of the United States to stay here despite Soviet efforts to end its special status.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The French national election will take place Jan. 2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Proceedings of the General Assembly's Economic Financial Committee were slowed today by an unscheduled two-hour debate on whether Afghanistan was being subjected to an economic blockade by neighboring Pakistan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Nationalist China announced today it would oppose, with utmost determination, the admission of five Communist states to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The index of average primary market prices declined 0.1 point over the week ended on Tuesday to 111.0 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Declines in the indexes for farm products and foods accounted for the dip, as the index for all commodities other than farm and foods remained unchanged.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Angry racegoers rushed the offices at near-by Windsor track today when fog forced cancellation of all except the first race and the stewards refused to return admission money.

An all-steel. Diesel-electric drive tugboat that may become the standard harbor workhorse for the large railroad fleet in this port was launched yesterday from the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard. The new craft, named the Buffalo, was sponsored by Mrs. Park N. Roeper, wife of the manager of the New York region of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 2 -- Coke made in experimental quantities from briquetted brown (soft) coal has been successfully used commercially for the first time to smelt iron at a Melbourne foundry. The test is the climax of five years of research at the University of Melbourne.

All the official proclamations, all the admonitions delivered on radio, television and in the press, all the education directed at making the motorist take special care failed to produce a Safe Driving Day on Thursday. The last count showed sixty-nine dead on the nation's second observance of this day.
Double-headers in Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium and in the University of Pennsylvania's Palestra in Philadelphia stand out on tonight's Eastern college basketball program.
WARSAW, Nov. 29 -- Poland is revising the system of piecework for labor.

Mrs. Rose Marie Di Giovanni still is trying to explain to her daughter, Joann, 3 years old, why papa was not there to meet them when they reached New York on the Liberte Wednesday. But how can you tell a child that her father is a "prisoner of war" captured while guarding a wrecked tank on Army maneuvers in Louisiana?
BARNES, England, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A flaming train wreck killed twelve persons and injured fifty here tonight.

Governor Orville L. Freeman of Minnesota extended an invitation yesterday to businesses and industries to take up residence in his State. But he served notice that Minnesota would not engage in "headlong competition" to "buy" industry by means of tax concessions.

Someone has placed a few sprigs of bittersweet around the mirror in the hall. There are two seasons when anyone pays much attention to the mirror. This is one, when the bright bittersweet is brought into the house to make, with the dried strawflowers, bright spots from which fresh cut flowers have disappeared.

Nine private bus companies moved yesterday to raise fares from the present 13 cents to 15 cents a ride. Eight of them had agreed with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., on Wednesday night on a two-year contract giving employes a 17-cent hourly package increase.

TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- The construction at Newark Airport of a device designed to eliminate the hazard of low-flying planes over Elizabeth and adjoining communities will begin next month. The two-direction instrument landing system will permit aircraft to land from the north under poor weather conditions and free the southward lane for straightaway take-offs.
Twenty years of civil war in the ranks of American labor ended yesterday.
The city has made a new move to keep the site of the abandoned Neponsit Hospital in the Rockaways, Queens, from becoming a park.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 -- Athens representatives of the Cyprus Ethnarchy called on Premier Constantin Karamanlis today and urged the Government to appeal immediately to the United Nations in protest against the emergency measures in Cyprus.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Bill Virdon recalled today that he could hardly have had a worse start last spring on the season that was to bring him the National League's rookie-of-the-year award.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Television rights to "Benefit Performance," a novel by Richard Sale, have been purchased by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The network plans to use it as a vehicle for a ninety-minute Bing Crosby television film.

Underprivileged children here and abroad will benefit from the International Press Ball of the Foreign Press Association, which was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The proceeds were donated to the United Nations Children's Fund and The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The Illinois Supreme Court today upheld the validity of the toll road law. The decision will probably clear the way for the sale of $415,000,000 worth of revenue bonds on Dec. 20.
The Knickerbocker Ball, in keeping with its theme, a Symphony of Stars, was held in the grand ballroom of the Ambassador last night in a setting emblazoned with silver, gold, blue and magenta stars.
HERMAN GODES, who gave his second New York recital last night in Town Hall, is a pianist with big concepts and powerful personal convictions.
Color television school credits will be a prerequisite for the electoral college session next year.

A "critical shortage" of nickel threatens to curtail production of receiving tubes and hamper the entire electronics industry, according to the president of the Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturing Association.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The Government announced today that all collective labor contracts involving the General Labor Confederation's 2,400 unions and 4,000,000 workers had been ordered canceled.
The Army will have only one representative in the epee trials for the United States Olympic team which start here next week.
A third count in the indictment against John G. (Steve) Broady was dismissed yesterday in General Sessions Court by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein. Seventeen of the original twenty counts still stand.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 -- A picket line was thrown up around a Netherlands ship here today to halt the unloading of its phosphate ore cargo.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading rider, came within one winner of entering the exclusive "400 club" when he completed a double on the Winfield Stable's Fabulous Fox in the feature at Tropical Park today. It was his 399th of 1955, and his thirteenth of the first five days of the session here.
The poet at work, from the inception of a new idea in a first rough draft to the polished cadences of publication, is presented in an exhibition opening today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 3 (UP)--Gov. James E. Folsom, whose use of National Guard planes is under investigation, flew from Mobile to Oklahoma City in a Tennessee Air National Guard plane yesterday, it was learned today.

FORT POLK, La., Dec. 3The tactics of Jeb Stuart, the great Southern cavalry leader of the Civil War, were applied to the swamps, bayous and pine forests of Louisiana this week as Exercise Sage Brush drew to a close.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 3--Luis Batlle Berres, Uruguay's head of Government, leaves tomorrow for the United States on an official visit that has raised quite a storm here.

IN Spain, in 1879, a 5-year-old girl, Maria de Sautuola, led by her father, climbed down into the so-called Cave of Altamira. There, for many years, her father had been digging out bones, clubs and arrowheads of the glacial age.

HAVING published two books on photographic techniques last year, "Successful Photography," and "Successful Color Photography," Andreas Feininger now produces a third, completing a series, on the potentialities of the medium.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--On Thursday more than 120 "WOC's" held a reunion here and pledged their word to return to the capital "anytime our country needs us."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The country is now engaged upon a recurring and basically insoluble discussion as to what is proper bipartisanship in foreign policy in an approaching election year.

Aluminum, a household word today, was so little known half a century ago that its only producer on this continent had to go into the pot and pan manufacturing business to convince people of its merits.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 --President Marcos Perez Jimenez opened today the first of a series of huge public works that cost more than $330,000,000 during the last twelve months.
Manhattan College athletes captured two of the four tests yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union handicap field event meet at St. John's University's Jamaica (Queens) campus.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 3 -- Northwestern University Technological Institute was the scene this week of a professors' revolt.
The Navy appealed yesterday for youths of 17 to 18 1/2 years old to enlist in the Naval Air Reserve at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station, Brooklyn.

THE charm and luck of the Irish, along with good looks, are Gort Craig's a inheritance. He needed it, too, for his gambling and lawlessness was a constant worry to his wife, Nell, and their six children. More than just a chronicle of light-hearted events in the Craigs' life, this story is a picture of an era, the wild Nineteen Twenties, and of a family deeply affected by it.

The pre-holiday rush of group exhibitions and one-man shows is in full swing. European and American artists are represented this week in gallery events of the widest range. Old and modern masters and newcomers to the New York exhibition field, paintings, sculpture and graphic work appear among the gallery presentations.

GENEVA, Dec. 3--The tenth session of the Governing Body of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) ended here today. It hammered home what delegates hope will become one or two bolts in a permanent structure for orderly world trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)-- Democrats were reported piling up ammunition today to center their 1956 campaign fire on Vice President Richard M. Nixon if President Eisenhower runs again.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 3--The fact that the Town of Babylon never adopted a resolution creating a "police department" will prevent double taxation in the three incorporated villages of Babylon, Lindenhurst and Amityville.

CHRISTMAS is like two mirrors face to face Within whose opposite reflections gleam Bright Christmas trees repeating back through space To where reality dissolves in dream. For this one day is time wrenched out of place: All Christmases that we remember seem Part of this present joy and hurly-burly That kept us late from sleep and woke us early.

School curriculum problems of large American cities will be the subject of a three-day conference starting tomorrow at Teachers College, Columbia University. One hundred twenty school officials from twentyseven states will attend.
LONDON, Nov. 29--A slice of England that many a Sherman in the United States could call his ancestral home will be sold at auction here Dec. 7.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda today edited out one anti-Western remark made by Mr. Khrushchev in Burma yesterday and said another had been made by a Burmese diplomat.

PARIS, Dec. 3--The Government sought today to protect the franchise of two important classes of voters, Algerians and those who have just come of age. It was thought that they might not be able to cast ballots in the legislative elections Jan 2.

IN an effort to get at the Soviet ideology in art at its very roots, we spent a couple of hours with the dean of the school run by the Leningrad Academy of Art. The dean says there are two such top schools run by the Academy, one in Leningrad and one in Moscow.

Someone escapes from a Communistoccupied country every minute of the day, every day of the year. Flights to freedom across broders in the third quarter of 1955 produced that average, the International Rescue Committee said in a report just issued.

EVER since the last Ice Age there have been incomparably more different kinds of native animals, birds and plants in North America than in Europe --for instance, nearly 800 birds here against 450 there, 131 trees in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park alone against eighty-five in all of Europe.
Miss Sarah Wellington James of 34 Gramercy Park and Dr. Field Case Leonard of Enfield, Conn., have become engaged and will be married early next year.

A ragged start cost the New York Knickerbockers heavily last night as they went down to their fourth straight National Basketball Association defeat. On hand to keep the Knicks on the downgrade were the Philadelphia Warriors, who triumphed, 109 to 102.
Labor mobility and the need for trained personnel minimizes the danger that unemployment will result from automation, the National Association of Manufacturers reported last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Post Office Department is looking for new career workers who cannot be stayed by snow, rain, heat or gloom of night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3-- Under the cover of darkness on the evening of April 31, 1898, Admiral George Dewey took a United States fleet into Manila Bay under orders to "capture or destroy" the Spanish fleet.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3--Mrs. Hirsch Jacobs' Searching won first money of $10,975 in the Gallorette Stakes at the Pimlico track today. It was easy money. The 3-year-old bay filly figured to outclass the field. She did.

AS lively as it is informative, as informal in style as it is evocative in its many illustrations, this unusual text-andpicture volume shapes up as precisely the "panorama" of Mississippi River life its publisher calls it.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (UP) --Muhlenberg College registered one of the young season's major upsets tonight by defeating La Salle, 69--58, before 3,537 fans at the Palestra.
The merged labor movement made a bid yesterday to add 300,000 organized railroad workers to its initial roster of 15,000,000 unionists.

A library of noise records is being assembled by General Electric engineers at Fort Wayne, Ind. The records will be used to compare noises of different origin, so that noise sources can be eliminated.

THIS Christmas, if booksellers are energetic, hundreds of thousands of men and women in this country will receive books inviting them, to take up a hobby or, what is more probable, further a hobby already acquired--from a book received last Christmas.
TAUNGGYI, Burma, Dec. 3-- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party leader, toured the colorful lakes and highland of Burma's Shan states today.

BERLIN, Dec. 1--Life behind the Iron Curtain has been changing lately, according to many persons living there. Economic conditions have been improving, and infringements by the police have been lessening.

TO THE EDITOR: Surely it could be only the more myopic wearers of the Old School Tie and the stage Yanks depicted in the West End theatre that were gently satirized in Wilfrid Sheed's whimsy "Is It Cricket to Kick at Football?"

TINSEL, ribbon, candles, cones and greens--when they are all put together --spell Christmas. Everywhere housewives, gardeners, teachers, designers and school children will be putting these ingredients together to see what they can do to make a holiday decoration.
"EACH work is a new problem in style--or I like it to be so."
Varig Airlines of Brazil is planning an extensive tourist promotional campaign to increase travel and mutual understanding between the United States and Brazil.
ALBANY, Dec. 3--Legislation giving Governor Harriman broader authority to extradite prisoners who are fugitives from other states is under consideration for the 1956 session.

December is the year in age and wisdom, a woman with starlight in her frosted hair and a snowflake on her cheek and a sprig of holly on her coat. The light in her blue eyes is young as this morning and old as time. She has known youth and love and age and heartbreak, and she still can smile, knowing that life is not all of either.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 3--A strike of captains of coastal ships began today and the worst tie-up of coastal shipping in twenty years was threatened. The masters of tugs also have joined the strike, and hundreds of passengers already have been stranded in various ports.

GOODMAN ACE, video Voltaire, has for some years been delivering saucy soliloquies on the state of television in "The Saturday Review." Some of the best of these he has now selected for hawking about the stalls in a volume unfortunately titled "The Book of Little Knowledge."
HARTFORD, Dec. 3 -- Connecticut lawmakers are in a deadlock over how to pay for flood relief costs in the cities and towns.

Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Nov. 26 were 10 per cent higher than in the comparable week last year. It was the thirty-first consecutive weekly increase reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

Chairmen and members of committees working in behalf of the Yuletide Assembly Ball will be guests of honor at a tea to be given by Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, honorary chairman of the ball committee, on Tuesday afternoon at Gracie Mansion.

PHOTOGRAPHIC projects concerned with recording the contemporary scene of a community with an eye to its information value for future generations are frequently attempted, but seldom succeed. Failure of such ventures may be usually attributed to a lack of understanding of the required approach and the types of pictures that would be useful in view of the desired goal of documenting the community with historical objectivity.
A summing up of the year's activity so far shows that 1955 may be the best year Westchester's home builders ever have had.
THE new 22,000-gross-ton liner Ivernia, the second of four sisterships being built by the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., for its Canadian service, will make her maiden appearance here on Friday.
Some years ago the claim was advanced that life begins at 40. Since then television has presented the thesis that life begins at 80.

Each year at this time the Book Review editor asks a literary question of some of the leading and best-selling authors within reach. This year the question put to them was, "What book (or books) was the decisive influence in your life?"

ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, in the South Pacific, Dec. 1--In his quiet way, Commissaryman 2/c Stanley C. Povilaitis of Mount Cannel, Pa., is an outspoken foe of pemmican. No, matter how it is fixed, "it's still pemmican," says the cook.
PARIS, Dec. 3--While many of its members looked on in outrage, the French National Assembly was dissolved this week and new elections were scheduled for next month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You published a letter on Nov. 11 by Kenneth Holland encouraging American families to invite students from other lands into their homes. There was an article on Nov. 13 by Harry Schwartz suggesting 100,000 young people from Russia be invited by American families for study or to visit our country.
The pre-Christmas flood of merchandise to the auction houses will build up to its high water mark this week and in the following next two weeks or so.
Dr. Wernher von Braun, one of the top men in the nation's guided missile program, believes that missile development is endangered by the boom in the industry.

TO many a turtsta from the north Mexicans are odd people--pleasant enough, but (in many cases) too dirty and poor, superstitious rather than respectably religious, and awfully haphazard. Despite its obvious sincerity, Robert Ramsey's third novel offers no compelling counter-argument to these absurdities.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Dec. 3 (UP)--O.H. Babcock's Writer, the 7-5 choice, sped to a a threelength triumph in the Au Revoir Purse at Narragansett Park today as the New England racing season ended.

With the annuncement in recent months that life expectancy in the United States is now on the threshold of the legendary three-score-and-ten, it is encouraging that the annual clinical session of the American Medical Association held here this week devoted considerable attention to the medical problems of the later years.

GIFT boxes of Oregon holly will soon be crossing the continent to carry Christmas greetings to homes in very state of the Union. Unfortunately, though, this year a black frost swept through the Korthwest's holly lands, and virtually ruined a large percentage of the crop.

When the first troops were converging on Western Louisianna for the start of maneuveres recently an executive of the United Service Organizations, Inc., and his small band tackled an unusual assignment.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 3-- Thirty-two Rhodes Scholars will be selected throughout the United States next week for two years of study at Oxford University, England.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 2--Political activity is going into high gear for the nation-wide Congressional and municipal elections set for Dec. 18. However, some political quarters have urged abstention from voting as a protest against the recentlyenacted electoral law.
Some 4,000 physicians flocked to Boston, Mass., last week to attend a meeting of the American Medical Association which had little to offer that was outstanding.

A garden-type apartment building is planned for New Canaan, Conn. The first building of its kind in the community, it will occupy a corner site of about one acre opposite Mead Park, which is within walking distance of the railroad and the shopping center.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3--The Big Ten holds its winter business meetings next week and the Rose Bowl subject may get a thorough, if informed inspection in the wake of recent postseason play criticism by Michigans' president.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Soccer and rugby results in Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Birmingham City 4. Arsenal 0 Burnley 2 Manchester City 2 (draw). Charlton Athletic 4. Huddersfield Town 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3--A library that embraces every language of the world, not only in books but every other form of publication, is tucked in the shade of the thirty - eight - story secretariat building of the United Nations.

THE author of "Pictorial History of American Presidents" might well have added "And Their Wives" to its title. In text as well as pictures, each section gives a biography of the President, a summary of the highlights of his Administration and a onceover-lightly of concurrent nonpolitical events.

THERE is a curious contradiction in the American language between our use of the words conservation and conservative. "Liberal" administrations from the time of the first Roosevelt have stood in general for more public ownership, for strengthening the federal arm in controlling our natural resources.

SECOND only to the hammer, the screwdriver is probably the most important tool in the home. Most of today's mechanical wonders-- washing machines, refrigerators, toasters, television sets, mixers --are put together with screws or bolts.

THE long, low lines of contemporary one-story houses are best complemented by small-size evergreen shrubs in foundation and entrance plantings. Increased attenion, therefore, is being given to the moderately proportioned shrubs such as pieris of andromeda.
Knoxville, Tenn., Dec. 3--The Government's defense plants in the Tennessee Valley region are expected to use more than 31,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours during this 1956 fiscal year that ends June 30.

THE mere size of this novel is deceptive. It lacks bulk, indeed, it is slim, almost attenuated. It uses words sparingly and tellingly: none is wasted. It creates a mood, yet is never moody. The action covers a few hours of waning daylight and a black, stormy night off the rockbound Hebrides.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Dec. 3--Governor Harriman of New York criticized President Eisenhower by name tonight on agriculture and foreign policies.

The Madison Square Boys Club will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Pipe Dream," starring Helen Traubei and William Johnson, on the night of March 1 at the Shubert Theatre. H. Howard Babcoak is chairman at the board of the Madison Square Boys Club and James M. Trenary is president of the organization.

TO THE EDITOR: In Arthur Daley's fine article "Pros and Cons of Pro Football" (Oct. 20) he stated that Tom Harmon, the great Michigan All-American, failed to get into pro ball until 1946 with the Los Angeles Rams.

The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity for the week ended Nov. 26 rose to 208.1, a new high since Atomic Energy Commission power use was deleted from the working electric power figure. The index for the preceding week was 205.1.

The Top Notch Winter Ball Friday at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be preceded by several cocktail parties. Ball proceeds will be donated to a fund to finance the expenses of the United States Olympic Ski Team that will compete in the Winter Olympics at Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy, in January.

COLD is icumen in, and with it Christmas, and with it gifts of books, and if you know a Blakian--by which we mean a lover of the gifts and visions and emanations of the poet William Blake--you can amply take care of him.

Shoppers and sight-seers thronged Thirty-fourth Street yesterday and kept Fifth Avenue busy, too. It was very warm for Santa Claus--52 degrees at 3 P.M.--but the crowds enjoyed it. One store spokesman said business was "fabulous."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 3-- Giant earth-moving equipment is bringing into reality here one of the first urban renewal projects undertaken as a cooperative effort by Federal, state and local governments.
