TO THE EDITOR: "Q. and A. in the House of Commons" (Nov. 20), by Robert K. Carr, is an excellent and thought-provoking article. How can we in the United States arouse action for some similar procedure whereby executive officers of the Administration might be questioned on major issues of the day by members of the Legislature?
The embattled producers and sellers of women's coats and suits hope to demonstrate that their industry need not remain a step-child of America's boom in consumer goods.
TRENTON, Dec. 3--The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here on Monday, ending a two-month recess. The session is expected to be brief and the accomplishments few.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--Once more a President of the United States has puzzled the politicians and the people with an equivocal sentence about his intentions to run again. Once more the true meaning of this sentence will be constantly disputed until it is resolved by the President or by events beyond his control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--There is a new party line for the G.O.P. which may never get official sanction but which certainly dominates the thinking of its upper hierarchy at this moment. It is: "Buck up, mates, tha worst may not happen after all."
Irish Shipping, Ltd., Ireland's 5-year-old venture into the maritime world, has just added contracts for two 18,000-deadweight ton tankers to its program of ship construction.
Two employes of the Department of Hospitals and a private X-ray technician were accused yesterday of stealing $25,000 worth of city-owned X-ray equipment from Welfare Island.

THE physical description in this first novel about a British freighter carrying out a rescue in a great Atlantic gale is the finest kind. One could seriously recommend it as outside reading on cyclonic storms for students in merchant marine and naval academies.

ON the late afternoon of July 4, 1946, when the American Ambassador was holding his annual reception for the diplomatic corps at Warsaw's Polonia Hotel, an ugly, almostforgotten word was whispered around the crowded garden.
The Soviet Union has begun work on what is intended to be the largest hydroelectric station in the world, a 3,000,000-kilowatt installation on the Angara River in Eastern Siberia.

THE dudgeon expressed by colleague Jack Gould in his column in this section last week because the Screen Producers Guild had the audacity to decline an invitation to do a series of weekly TV shows was one of the nicest compliments the producers have ever received.
THE library of the cultured home of the early twentieth century held rows of books bound in tan, blue and red leather with gold tooling, wedding-present "sets" of Thackeray, Scott and Dickens.
HOLLYWOOD. "IF it takes an act of Congrass to outlaw boxing, I'm going to get it," Philip Yordan, who wrote the screen adaptation of Budd Schulberg's book, "The Harder They Fall," declared.

AFTER moving into a new home recently my family and I became overly conscious of the view from the stair-landing windows. All that could be seen was the neighbor's house which had a not too attractive brown shingle siding.
HOLLYWOOD. LEO DUROCHER, the exGiant pilot who recently signed as a National Broadcasting Company executive, will don the uniform of a National League baseball manager on Dec. 12.

WHEN all is said and done museums are judged on the quality of their acquisitions. Special exhibitions come and go but the work that remains is, if not necessarily a joy forever, the most reliable indication of progress or decline.

THE two main dishes detailed here today represent two quite different ways of cooking easily for a party. The Chinese combination of duck with vegetables, called chow opp peen, is the kind of thing for which guests wait.

THIS book is for men only, "for only men can take exciting pictures of women," Carl Bakal writes firmly in introducing his "How to Shoot for Glamour" (San Francisco: Camera Craft Publishing Company. $2.95), a pleasant distraction from the cares of photography.
Ralph T. Reed, president of the American Express Company, believes the money American tourists spend overseas could reduce and "perhaps" eliminate the need for Federal foreign aid.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3--Yogi Berra, a potent factor in the seven pennants the Yankees have won in the last nine campaign, again has been named the American League's most valuable player.

JEZEBEL, the girl from Tyre, who married Ahab, King of Israel, has lured Mrs. Wilson into a good deal of pulsating, pagan prose. The heathen queen, according to the Book of Kings, played a large part in causing Ahab to do "more to provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel that were before him."

IN the first of these three quite dissimilar travel books, the Johnsons, Captain Irving and his wife, Electa, with the substantial aid of a crew member, Lydia Edes, describe the Yankee's sixth voyage westward around the world.
BOSTON, Dec. 3--The official "welcoming" of convicts to the new state correctional institution at Walpole this week posed new problems in Massachusetts' penal reform program.

The Atomic Energy Commission has announced that Soviet scientists have detonated a hydrogen bomb with results as frightening as those of last year's test at Eniwetok. When an atomic bomb of either the old A type or the most recent H type explodes the upward rush of air, visible as the now familiar mushroom-shaped cloud, carries with it an enormous amount of dust which is radioactive.

IN 1431, when she was perhaps 19, Joan of Arc was burned at the stake in Rouen, France. It was "not the end for her," as Bernard Shaw has written, "but the beginning." Since then her name has been burned indelibly into the history of mankind, and has fired the imagination of artists, writers and musicians, all of whom have sought, through their art, an answer to the question: What was Joan like?

THE year 1955 will remain a memorable one in Austria's history. Liberated and occupied by the victorious armies in May, 1945, Austria regained her liberty and independence ten years later. The Austria that emerged in this decade was only geographically the continuation of the Austrian Republic which the vicissitudes of World War I had created.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3--California's 1956 United States Senate race is warming up even though so far there is only one avowed candidate. And an unexpected Senate contest has shaped up in Nevada.

STUTTGART, Germany, Dec. 3 (AP)--Walter Gieseking, German pianist, was reported out of danger today after having suffered severe head injuries in a bus crash that killed his wife and a United States soldier.

BOSTON. "I AM in my sixtieth year, you know," Ruth Gordon said. So nakedly numerical a statement is not visual to stage stars. But Miss Gordon's confession wasn't the only thing that surprised a visitor to her Boston hotel.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 3-- Minimum wages varying with each industry were recommended by most persons who testified here the last two days before the Labor and Education Committee of the United States House of Representatives.

BROADWAY'S fare still continues to be Hollywood's meat. Last week it was learned that the latest dramatic dish to tempt a movie producer is "A View From the Bridge," the two short plays by Arthur Miller now on the bill at the Coronet.

Thirty young women will be introduced formally to society at a reception to be held in advance of the thirty-fourth annual Debutantes New Year's Ball. The fete, arranged under the direction of Mrs. Thomas W. Edgar, chairman of the event, will be held on the night of Jan. 2 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
There is no reason why Puerto Ricans living new lives in this city should "wear the mantle of slums, ghettos, disease and privation," according to a report issued here yesterday.

SET in ancient Egypt (15901465 B.C.), this novel spans, with devoted historical exactitude, the reigns of the four Pharaohs known as the Eighteenth Dynasty. These include Pharaoh Thothmes I, his moronic son Thothmes II, and the combination reign of "King" Hat-shep-sut, daughter to the first of the line, and her nephew and stepson, Thothmes III.
TORONTO, Dec. 3 -- Canada has designed and developed a fast, powerful, anti-submarine vessel that has drawn the praise of United States and British admirals associated with the Atlantic alliance.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Like my former colleague S. Walter Washington I should like to refer back with gratitude to your editorial of Oct. 14, "Our Foreign Service."

SPURRED on by the extraordinary increase in use of the national parks since the end of the Second World War, the National Park Service has been developing a program designed to meet the needs of the system by the end of the next decade.

URUAPAN, Mexico, Nov. 29-- Paracutin, one of the world's youngest volcanoes, has been dead for nearly four years but its imprint remains heavy and black on the countryside of Michoacan State near here.

IT is not often that a ballet dancer becomes a famous composer. But the eighteenth century provides an instance in the person of Jean Marie Leclair. In addition to making this transition, Leclair has a claim on the imagination by also being a composer who was murdered mysteriously.

THE cowpoke of story, song and television thriller has won some new spurs; he has been analyzed. Two college professors have looked him over and found him booted, saddled and rarin to ride--on and on.

Can the Soviet Government afford to give economic aid on any large scale to non-Communist underdeveloped countries? This is a central question facing Western policymakers as they seek to find answers for the new economic offensive launched by the Soviet Union in Asia and the Middle East.

IN Kabul, capital of Afghanistan, business men in kullah caps and peasants in sheepskin coats stand in line in bitter cold waiting to enroll for English lessons. In Baghdad, police are called out to hold back a crowd after the announcement, "Registration Opens Tomorrow for English Classes," appears in the local papers.

Horace Stoneham, president of the New York Giants, will leave today for the major league meetings in Chicago "without much hope" that he can complete a player deal. The three-day baseball sessions open tomorrow.

A large part of the plottage is used for a private garden in an unusual arrangement of buildings at the Sutton House apartment development at 415 East Fifty-second Street. The brickwork is now being completed on the buildings where occupancy is scheduled to start in February.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 3-- A strong move is under way to replace Suffolk County's patchcd-up seventeenth century form of government with one designed to meet the needs of a suburban-agricultural area.

TORONTO, Dec. 3 (AP)--The Montreal Canadians clicked for a goal a period tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--1, and drop them into fifth place in the National Hockey League. It was the Leafs' first loss in four games.
LONDON, Dec. 3--The visit to Britain next spring of Nikita S. Khrushchev and Nikolai A. Bulganin is regarded with increasing apprehension and distaste in London.
The St. Lawrence Seaway is going to have to pay its own way from the tolls it collects. Furthermore, it can expect no financial assistance from this country's taxpayers.
A 16-year-old high school senior has invented a drafting tool that can be used accurately and handily to perform the designing work now requiring five separate drawing devices.

Fingerprints left in wet clay by a sculptor modeling a head of St. John the Baptist almost 500 years ago are to be compared next week with impressions that an art appraiser hopes to find in clays in the National Art Gallery in Washington.
SOUTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 3--The Navy demonstrated for the first time this week a new weapon against coastal attack.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Edmund Joyce, executive vice president at Notre Dame, today backed Iowa's stand in a recent television dispute with the National Collegiate Athletic Association on the telecast of the Irish-Hawkeye game from South Bend Nov. 19.

BERLIN, Dec. 3--Through a quiet and seemingly amiable conversation between two generals in East Berlin this week Berliners learned that a fundamental change had taken place in their city--one which may have farreaching consequences.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The prospect for any major Congressional struggle next year over civil rights or the TaftHartley Labor Act has declined almost to the vanishing point.
Mayor Wagner said last night that some of the employers who fear the power of a united labor movement really fear the loss of an un-American advantage they hold over their employes.
TORONTO, Dec. 3--The East and the West battled to a 6-6 tie today on a muddy and rainsoaked field. Canada's first All-Star football game was climaxed by a wild finish.
LONDON, Dec. 3--The bobbies in this town have a good deal in common with their counterparts in New York.
The New York Giants, with no chance to gain honors in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League, can help the Cleveland Browns clinch the crown today.

FOR the past few years Arthur Koestler has been writing like a man preparing for death. Several volumes of an autobiography have already appeared and they read like Memoires d'outre Tombe--Koestler speaking from beyond the grave; the present volume continues in the same vein, with Koestler trying to wrap it all up and settle his last earthly score with politics.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3--Negotiations are in progress for appearances here by several leading American artists including Artur Rubinstein and Isaac Stern.

IN the complicated process of moving products to the consumer, retailers play a vital part. They have done an excellent job this year, with record volume and a high rate of turnover. Inventory accumulations have been kept to a minimum and there is reason to believe that by the end of the Christmas selling season, stocks will be exceptionally clean.

There is more than only scientific interest in the news that the first Antarctic expedition ever sent out by the Soviet Government has left Koenigsberg and is now on its way toward the South Pole. Ostensibly this expedition is concerned only with the Soviet contribution to the important work planned by many nations for the International Geophysical Year, 1957-58.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today the time had come for this country to end poverty, rather than be content with relieving it.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 3-- The Maine Turnpike Authority will open on Dec. 13 the $55,000,000 second link of its toll highway, connecting this city with the state's capital, Augusta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP)-- Representative John W. Byrnes, Republican of Wisconsin, a member of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, today opposed the Administration's announced intention of seeking tax cuts next year if the budget was balanced.

HOUSTON, Dec. 3 (AP)--The University of Houston turned a blocked punt, a fumble recovery and Kennie Stegall's 69-yard punt return into three fourthperiod touchdowns today to complete its conquest of Sun Bowl football teams by defeating Wyoming, 26--14.

TELEVISION'S intriguing power to penetrate the surface of a personality has been illustrated in two recent and most interesting programs. One was the appearance of Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, on "Meet the Press"; the other, the Chicago speech by Adlai Stevenson after he had decided to queue up for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

BESIDES following his career as a violinist, Alexander Schneider likes to take a fling as an impresario every now and then. In 1950 he was a leader in the conceiving and working out of the Prades Festival that brought Pablo Casals out of retirement.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 3 (UP) -- Paul Dietzel, Louisiana State University's 31-year-old head football coach, received proof today that you can have a mediocre season as far as the won-and-lost record goes and still get a new contract and a rise in salary.

ONCE again the stars shine bright on Fifty - fifth Street. By dint of her usual dauntless efforts, Jean Dalrymple, the lady who takes charge of the drama at the City Center, has managed to compose a thoroughly exciting program.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP)--The scheduled world light-heavyweight championship bout between Archie Moore, the titleholder, and Yolande Pompey of Trinidad was postponed today because the champion had sprained his ankle.

THE winter tournament of 1955 is drawing to a close at Miami Beach today. It is the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-ninth annual national championship tournament, the first fall auction bridge) having been held in Chicago in 1927.

AN aircraft classification of fairly recent vintage-- S.T.O.L.--is attracting increasing and significant attention. The letters stand for "short take-off and landing," but they fall far short of adequately defining this airplane category.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, moved today to block possible Congressional action to fix quotas on imports of Japanese textiles.

ONE damp evening recently the sidewalk outside the backstage entrance to the Century Theatre was crowded with more than a hundred high school girls. They were waiting to get a look at Eddie Fisher, the popular young singer, who had just finished one of his regular two-a-week television shows on the stage of the playhouse.

France to the Polls The French Republic was only two years old when, in 1877, President Patrice de MacMahon, a Royalist, dissolved an anti-Royalist Chamber of Deputies for obviously partisan purposes. The move backfired; an anti-Royalist Chamber was re-elected.
Any suspicion that the speedboat racing year has terminal is just a snare, delusion and illusion. Back of the scenes the is activity aplenty.

ESCAPERS are powered by different human engines, judged by "We Die Alone" and "Valley of the Shadow," two stranger-than-fiction stories of men who got away at different times and places. One man runs on religious conviction, another on broad concepts of liberty for country, family, self, plus perhaps training for survival.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 3 --Fast starts at the beginning of each half helped Adelphi defeat City College, 71--64, at Woodruff Hall tonight in the opening game of the basketball season for both teams.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 3--The Yankee trader is back in business in diplomatic attire.

In the First World War the Germans came twice to the River Marne in France, once in 1914 and once in 1918. Both times they nearly won. We are now engaged in another kind of war, fortunately bloodless, in which the Russians are on the aggressive.

The following list of 250 books has been selected by the staff of The Book Review from the approximately 10,000 titles published this year. Obviously such a list can suggest only the high points in the main fields of reader interest.

WHEN the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (A.F.L.C.I.O.) convene as a single organization in New York's Seventy-first Regiment Armory tomorrow morning, the merger of the nation's two major labor federations will have just begun.

Islands of the Southwestern Pacific appear to be fragments of an ancient Melanesian continent which broke up 10,000,000 or 20,000,000 years ago, according to Dr. Albert C. Smith, botanist of the United States National Museum, in the annual report of the Smithsonian Institution.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2--The first new edition of the Russian Orthodox Bible since the Bolshevik Revolution will be published here early next month.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 28-- Nuclear research in West Germany is showing symptoms of revival after the post-war years of inactivity.
Two Bronx truck drivers with an asserted weakness for bargain whisky gave the Federal Bureau of Investigation its first break yesterday in a week-old investigation of a liquor theft.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3-- Westchester is scrutinizing its fields and woodland, wondering if more parks, play fields and reservations should be established while space is still available.

Mechanization and diversification are not unknown in the highly individualistic fashion industry, but they are rare. The world's largest manufacturer of women's apparel has employed both to build its sales to some $36,000,000 a year.

In planning for future home developments on Long Island, builders have been urged by Hyman Loshen, head of the Loshen Brothers construction concern, to keep in mind the features that are most often sought by the increasing number of potential buyers who are now home owners.

An assemblage of 1,100 lots has been completed in Sayville, L.I., for Lindy and Fred Crisafulli, builders. The property, on the new Sunrise Highway and facing the Island Hills Golf and Country Club, will be improved with 255 one-family dwellings. Construction is scheduled to get under way about the middle of next year.
A large list of patrons and patronesses has been announced for the Big Brother Christmas benefit at the Radio City Music Hall the evening of Dec. 15.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3--The United Nations refused today to include nonmember lands -- Communist China among them--in its forthcoming survey of the effects of atomic radiation.

COOPER UNION--Report The nation's small colleges should blaze the trail for the educational developments in the second half of the twentieth century, Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, president of Cooper Union, said in his annual report. The tuition-free art and engineering school was founded in New York ninety-six years ago by Peter Cooper.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 3-- Without losing a game, G. Diehl Mateer Jr., the United States open squash racquets champion, advanced to the semi-final round of the Gold Racquet tournament today.
SCHUBERT'S great song cycle, Die Winterreise, is one of the most searching tests in all song literature of a singer's attainments.

ALBION, N.Y., Dec. 3--The construction of a $10,500,000 suburban water supply system to serve communities in Niagara and Orleans counties is being scheduled by the Northwestern New York Water Authority to start early next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--To the surprise of many, the White House Conference on Education, which closed its meetings here on Thursday, came out wholeheartedly for Federal aid to education. It was not the fact that the conference so voted that surprised most persons.

THE next to last segment of the main New YorkBuffalo Thruway, twentyeight miles from Suffern to within three miles of its terminus at the Bronx-Westchester line, will be opened to traffic on Dec. 15 and the benefits of the world's longest expressway at last will be available to motorists in the metropolitan area.
The corset has changed remarkably in the last decade or so, according to persons who should know. So, too, has the advertising thereof.

The stock market moved into the final month of the year in a rather hesitant fashion. There was little disposition to put stocks up--except for a few selected issues--and more of a tendency to give ground whenever a forward movement failed to attract buyer enthusiasm.

We are not in sympathy with some of the methods employed by students at Georgia Tech in the protest against the action of Governor Griffin in respect to the Sugar Bowl football game. We are in entire accord with the motives and instincts that prompted the protest.
Why Wiretapping? If you live in New York, what are the chances that your telephone is being tapped?
That religious education is the responsibility of church, synagogue and home--not the public school--was the tenor of several hundred sermons preached yesterday by rabbis in New York.
CAIRO, Dec. 3--Britain and Egypt signed an agreement today granting to the Sudan the right to determine its future.

CARMEL, N.Y.--Artificial, machine-made snow on a public ski area within a "ski-heil" of New York City is about to become a reality. William Gilbert of Scarsdale Manor North, president of Gilbert Edwards, Inc., has announced that such a center is about to be opened at the stateowned Fahnestock Park.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 3--A controversy over headguards for amateur boxers, raging throughout the sixty-eighth annual National Amateur Athletic Union convention, was knocked out with a single parliamentary blow in the final round today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP)-- Congress appeared likely today to act next session on a bill for Federal aid to education. But friends and foes said its fate was doubtful.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 3 --Frank W. Packard, New Jersey retailer, has definite convictions about retailing procedures and domestic and foreign trade. Many of his tenets are orthodox; others may seem anomalous. Yet all have enhanced his position as one of New Jersey's most successful merchants.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 26-- El Salvador's new fishing law places this country in the position of legislating for an area three times as large as the republic itself.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3--A philosopher of ancient Greece is supposed to have said any traveler can change the sky under which he moves, but few succeed in changing the ideas they carry with them.
With his "life toward evening, but eyes on the morning," an elder statesman of Protestantism entered his 100th year yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 3--Mike Souchak of Grossinger, N. Y., posted a 2-under-par 70 in the third round of the $15,000 Havana invitation golf tournament today for a 204, but saw his lead cut to 2 strokes. Art Wall of Pocono Manor. Pa., moved into second place with a 68 for 206.
BERLIN, Dec. 3--The licensing of barge traffic between East Germany and Berlin has apparently been made conditional on recognition of the legal status of the East German regime.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 3 -- An unheralded sophomore halfback, Oliver Rudy, raced 35 yards for the only touchdown today as Duke gained a 6-0 edge over a rugged North Carolina team in a nationally televised football game. A crowd of 34,000 saw Duke move past North Carolina's 20-yard line three times, but the Tar Heel defense held on each occasion.

To the Music Editor: THE beginning of the opera season invariably brings forth a crop of stories about standees, their flaming enthusiasm, their romantic bivouacking for days for that precious possession, a ticket to enter into the gates of heaven.

The Detroit Red Wings will skate against the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. It is likely that the tussle, which will start at seven o'clock, will attract a crowd of 15,000.

THINKING to avoid the maelstrom, or to be precise, the female-strom of midtown Christmas shopping, and figuring, too, that elbows can be bent at home to happier purposes than gouging the ribs of one's fellow man, many people these days are earnestly perusing the pages of holiday gift catalogues.

While New York is getting ready to open its new Coliseum next spring, Detroit and Chicago are planning competitive new convention and exhibition halls.

Mrs. Thomas H. Barton and Miss Mildred Thorwart are serving as co-chairmen of the junior committee working for the cocktail dance on Feb. 3, which will benefit the Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center. The center is sponsored by the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children.
The new colossus of American labor is only half as big as it hopes to be.
LONDON, Dec. 2--A sharp decline in Britain's rate of juvenile delinquency during the last four years has pleased and puzzled authorities.

SINCE, to judge by the theatrical ads, there's hardly a show on Broadway that hasn't earned at least one "hilarious," "electrifying" or "delightful," business this holiday season may be expected to be little short of stunningly, dazzlingly superlative.
"Fathoms deep beneath the exhilaration and joyousness of Christmas, there is a world of desolation and hunger which few of the dwellers in light and air have had time or chance to realize * * *."

BOSTON, Dec. 3--The Right Rev. John Insley Blair Larned, former Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, died this morning in Phillips House, Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 72 years old.

SO sang James Stephens in "Christmas at Freelands," one of the fifty poems included in one of the loveliest holiday books that we have had for a long time, Anne Thaxter Eaton's WELCOME CHRISTMAS! A Garland of Poems (Viking, $2.50, all ages, decorations by Valenti Angelo).

THOUGH the season of the New York City Ballet is only at the halfway mark, it has already presented the three new works scheduled for production, and at least one of them is in every way worthy of inclusion in the permanent repertoire.

FOR the first six or eight years of our reading experience, my sister and I must have believed that books, like candy canes and shimmering ornaments for our tree and mechanical steamboats that wound up by a key poked down the funnel, like a new pair of roller skates and a velocipede, were peculiar to Christmas.

To the Radio-Television Editor: AROPOS of Jack Gould's column last week, the Screen Producers Guild statement concerning its decision not to enter the TV field at this time was not intended as an attack on the TV industry, nor on those engaged in making film for TV release.

AFTER World War II, the young Philippine Republic was gravely menaced by the Communist - led Hukbalahap movement. By 195O the danger was so acute that the actual survival of democracy in the Philippines hung in the balance.

SEVENTY-FIVE years ago last March, a stocky, bearded man and seven seasickwracked women tottered down a liner's gangplank at Castle Garden, New York. Once ashore, they knelt in a circle to pray in cockney voices supremely oblivious to the eighth letter of the English alphabet.

BACK in 1923 Ludlow Griscom, a leading naturalist, wrote: "Probably no locality in America has been visited so often, so regularly, and by so many people, as Central Park. It is an ideal station for studying the migration of birds, and is unquestionably the best place for the insectivorous transients of the region.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., Dec. 3--The Schroon Lake Chamber of Commerce has organized Operation Stagecoach to dramatize its protest against what it terms the state's "gross negligence" in failing to reconstruct this year a section of Route 9 leading to Pottersville.

HOLLYWOOD. DESPITE the fact that he is currently at work in Columbia's musical remake of the 1934 "Oscar" winner "It Happened One Night," which represents his sixth successive Hollywood comedy in the two years since he left Broadway and a record of hundreds of TV appearances.

Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven, said a few days ago that "the railroads should adapt themselves to automation" and that "the railroad industry in general has been backward." The occasion was the trial run of a commuter car which was started and stopped by a system of remote control devised by the Union Switch and Signal Company.
The Long Island Rough Riders defeated the Squadron A polo team, 15--4, in the feature game of an indoor double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. George Haas led the way with eight goals.

AS December's chilly blasts grow more persistent, birds will be seen huddled in the protection of a shrub or tree. But when they venture out on foraging trips, can they still find enough berries, beetles, bugs and grubs to keep going?

I HAVE always thought that anything a director of a film has to say about it should be said in the picture itself. However, on account of the preliminary publicity that has been given to "The Prisoner," there is a possibility of a misunderstanding as to its theme and subject matter.

LONDON, Nov. 29--King Edward VII was warned most solemnly by his Private Secretary that if he persisted in his friendship with Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, the British Government would resign and it would be impossible to form another from a largely hostile House of Commons.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3--The General Assembly, without the participation of France, approved a resolution this morning looking toward a satisfactory solution of the Moroccan question. The French delegation remained outside the Assembly chamber while the Moroccan matter, the first item on a heavy Saturday agenda, was disposed of.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3--Efforts to wipe out or at least modify baseball's present bonus rule, which got nowhere in the minor league convention at Columbus, will be renewed when the major leaguers open their three-day conclave here on Monday.
Frowns and Smiles The Russians last week were dispensing smiles and frowns depending on which direction they faced.
Natural gas, and still more natural gas, is at last coming to s Pacific Northwest.

As the Earth Turns Visitors to the United Nations in New York are to have visible proof that the earth does move even though debates in the Security Council and General Assembly may be doing nothing at the moment to help it along.

Japan has made huge economic gains this year. Her foreign trade now has a strong favorable balance. Her reserves of gold and foreign exchange at the end of October stood at about $1,400,000,000, where they represented 100 per cent coverage for all Japanese currency in circulation.
The concept of color is seeping from men's sportswear into the suit field. As yet, most of the color is hidden up the sleeve or is used for lining the jacket.

GENEVA, N. Y., Dec. 3--The influence of emotional factors in catching and spreading colds, sore throats, virus ailments and other upper respiratory infections is being studied by the Laboratory on Housing and Illness. The laboratory is operated by the Armed Forces Epidemological Board at Sampson Air Force Base Hospital here.

PREVIOUSLY published in a magazine and purchased for motion pictures, this vagrant trifle by a talented director, playwright and scenarist is a neo-Runyonist account of how a number of hoodlums get mixed up in the music business.

DURING the past year this column has reviewed about seventy-five Westerns, plus a score or more other books on the western scene which appeared elsewhere in the Book Review. Now may be the time to sit back, roll a "quirly," and ask, "Whither Westerns? What changes are apparent?"

THE American Broadcasting Company bought 100 British feature-length movies last week amid growing signs that the network is staking its future on film programs. This is in contrast with the other two television networks-- the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company -- who rely heavily on the live "spectacular" to generate excitement among viewers.

PHOTOGRAPHS by Gertrude Kasebier (18521934), who was one of the founding members of Alfred Stieglitz' historic "PhotoSecession" group at the beginning of this century, will go on exhibition with an opening, reception from 3 to 5 P. M. next Sunday at the Village.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3-- The United States Trotting Association said today harness racing purses soared to a record high in 1955. The number of participating owners and horses also increased substantially, U.S. T.A. directors said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--Vice President Richard M. Nixon moved today to put the new Commission on Government Security to work.

BONN, Dec. 3--This week's dreary debate on reunification in the Bundestag reflected with startling clarity the widespread confusion in this country. True, Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, the new Foreign Minister, made an excellent debut in the Bundestag with a statement unmatched for style and content by any other Government Minister since the founding of the Federal Republic in 1949.

ATLANTA, Dec. 3--Two thousand Georgia Tech students demonstrated early today in front of the Governor's mansion and the State Capitol. They were angered by Gov. Marvin Griffin's move to keep Tech out of the Sugar Bowl game against the University of Pittsburgh on Jan. 2.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 3-- Dr. Jean Paul Mather, president of the University of Massachusetts, opened a drive this week to free the institution from what he terms undue state interference with faculty policy.
A new Argentine Ambassador arrived here yesterday.

NO civil liberty battle is ever finally won. But since the censors seem to be forever on the march, a freedom-loving people must be particularly solicitous about that most basic of liberties- the right to read. The citizen who is concerned about this right cannot do better than to turn to this excellent volume by Paul Blanshard, American sociologist and journalist, in which current censorship threats to the right to read are carefully set forth.

WHAT is a mystery novel? By which I do not mean, "What is the classic form of the detective story?", but rather "What do readers and publishers mean when they say 'a mystery novel'?" -- and more immediately, what books should be reviewed in my weekly Criminals at Large column ?

TUCSON, Ariz.--A sample week-end in the West, actually four galloping days, recently gave a group of Easterners a thoroughly buckskin-and-sombrero experience from the instant when a sheriff, his posse and their rataplan of pistol hots, greeted us at the landing field here.
DESPITE the availability of the compass and the survey map, the number of hunters who were "lost" in the woods this fall seems to have increased over last year.

THE spoor of James Reynold's spooks in this handsome if harrowing volume leads us over some twenty states and three centuries--ranging from Cape Henlopen, Delaware Bay, in 1655 to the South Dakota prairies in 1943--and into such strangely assorted high and low places as Manhattan and Nob Hill brownstone mansions, Tidewater Virginia and Louisiana plantation estates, Ohio and New York state farmhouses, and Spokane, Carson City and Natchez-under-theHill brothels and dives.
Leaders of the nation's lumber industry have predicted a bright future for wood particle board, a recently developed compound of wood shavings and other substances.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 3 -- Miss Caroline Boardman Greene, registrar emeritus of Mount Holyoke College, died this morning in a nursing home in Hadley. She would have been 90 years old on Jan. 7.

Colorful Bouquets Colorful and cheerful bouquets --small ones at least--are possible during the rather dull period before it's time for holiday decorations to appear. Although flowers from the garden are no longer possible, shrubs can contribute their berries.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3--Willie Hartack rode his fourhundredth winner of the year today, the second jockey in history to perform the feat. Then he received a ten-day suspension along with a gold cup from Tropical Park officials.
Opry IN the December issue of Harper's Magazine the reader will find one of the late Bernard DeVoto's last essays. He will find it quite fittingly in Mr. DeVoto's old department. The Easy Chair.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3--The United States and the Philippines will not immediately seek a compromise candidate for the "Eastern European" seat on the Security Council, it was made known today.

RELEASE by Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer of the figures on stamps bought and philatelic covers serviced when the 6-cent with Theodore Roosevelt's portrait was released on Nov. 18, initially in New York, makes it possible to record that collectors and dealers paid $409,747.38, representing 2,706,525 stamps, at six first-day sales in six cities during 1955.

Tremendous Phrases THE history of our time * * * is a history of phrases, which rise to great power and then as suddenly pass away: the "merchants of death," the "malefactors of great wealth," "monopoly," "reactionaries," "liberals," the "labor power," "America first," "cash and carry," "unconditional surrender," "peace in our time," "collective security," "bring the boys home," "disarmament," "the Red menace," "the atomic potential," etc., etc.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 3--A Congressional investigation of the handling of Federally owned timber in the Pacific Northwest ended at Spokane this week.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored in every period tonight to deal the helpless Bruins their sixth straight National Hockey League loss, 5--0, before 9.374 hooting Garden fan?.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our Federal progressive income tax rate system, varying from 20 per cent to 91 per cent for individuals, behaves as a deterrent to American business enterprises. It also works a hardship on taxpayers whose annual earnings are sporadic and not uniform, such as those of actors, lawyers and business enterprises.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 3-- Implicit in British policy on this island is the hope that after the Cypriote and Greek people have had their fling they will settle down peacefully under British rule.
HONG KONG, Dec. 3--It all seemed so simple when Richard R. Tenneson of Alden, Minn., a Korean war turncoat, reached the Hong Kong border Wednesday on his way out of Communist China.

FASHION is a killer. One may well wonder what is the fate, in uncompromising hands, of the passe pet-dog when some rage for a new breed comes in. The old must always bow before the new. Not so long ago, for instance, one could still see the shop sign Plumassier --but now it is gone, declined with my lady's love for osprey and egret, for swansdown and a dead dove on the head.
Colder weather in most of the country has spurred sales of men's, women's and children's apparel, and has brought sizable reorders into the New York market, resident buying offices reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Congressional leaders were divided as to whether the White House Conference on Education would have any effect on legislation when Congress meets next month. They agreed that the conference had created intense interest.

Psychoanalysts were urged yesterday to recognize the enjoyment they obtain from their work. A fellow analyst, Dr. Thomas Szasz of Chicago, recommended that they acknowledge and talk frankly about the many satisfactions they derive.

Tha House of Detention for Women must be restored as a place solely for persons awaiting trial and apart from a prison for convicted criminals, Judge Mary Donlon of the United States Customs Court declared yesterday.

TOOLS require care and maintenance to do their work properly and give long life. Like children, tools respond to a lot of T C L (tender, loving care). Not only should the worker use the proper tool for the job, but he should give it proper attention after the job is over.

CRISWELL, Ore., Dec. 3--The rambling old farmhouse of the Harry Holt family is full of happy people.

Wednesday's noon to 2 P.M. recorded concert at the New York Public Library will pay honor to Jean Sibelius on his ninetieth birthday. The tribute to the Finnish Composer, in the Central Building on Fifth Avenue, will be the playing, about 1 P.M., of his latest large work, "Symphony No. 7 in C," Opus 105.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 3 -- This is a story about the successful convalescence of a hospital.

THE Jersey City Dodgers have graciously consented to play seventy games of their seventy-seven-game home schedule at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn next season. It's a jolly decent thing that Walter O'Malley is doing in his role as president of the Dodgers, bringing major league baseball to the outlying provinces--meaning Brooklyn and not Jersey City.

PAGANINI was a jealous and suspicious man. He was eternally afraid that other violinists would copy his music and his technical secrets. Before a concert he would personally--so goes the story, and there is no reason to disbelieve it--distribute the orchestral parts of his music to the players.

LISBON FALLS, Me. THEY had a bit of a tiff in Watertown, Conn., recently over Yankee Ingenuity. WASHINGTON -- This capital, a fortified town, will be an open city for all during the Christmas season--as it is, despite the military establishments in its environs, the entire fiftytwo weeks of the year.
BUFFALO, Dec. 3 (AP)--Niagara recovered from a bad case of nerves tonight to turn back the Fordham quintet, 72--70, at Memorial Auditorium. Tom Hemans scored 40 points for the Purple Eagles.

OTTAWA--Officials who gathered here last week for the tenth annual Dominion -Provincial Tourist Conference, found their big problem was to please the American tourist. The second biggest was to find a way of encouraging more Canadians to spend their vacations in Canada.

LONDON, Nov. 27--The recent British excavations at Beyce-sultan in Turkey have strengthened the suggestion that Hellenic civilization was derived from Anatolia and not, as commonly accepted, from the Balkans.

Members of the Westchester County Council of Social Agencies have chosen "Pipe Dream," the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical for their third annual theatre party. It will be held on Jan. 23. Helen Traubel and Bill Johnson head the cast of the show, which is at the Shubert Theatre.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3--Informed Western diplomats here think that the Soviet regime is now speaking with more self-confidence than ever before.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would accept the Democratic nomination for Vice President if it were offered to him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Federal Trade Commission today hung out the red flag on "bait advertising."

NEW ELEMENTS-- Nobel laureate Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg predicts the creation of seven new forms of matter within fifteen years. He has in mind elements numbered 102 through 108. Probably they will be produced in an accelerator or atom smasher which is being constructed at the University of California with a grant from the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A new kind of Soviet "cold war" offensive, in the guise of economic and sometimes military aid to underdeveloped countries, has stirred fierce controversy here over the future of United States foreign aid programs.

WINTER is on its way. So gardeners should make preparations for protecting their plants, trees and shrubs through the long cold period ahead. Since the average home grounds have many types of trees, evergreens, shrubs and perennials, protection will have to be designed to fit their individual needs.

JEAN SIBELIUS, a creative giant whose music bestrides the last years of the nineteenth century and fifty-five years of the twentieth, is a living legend. Craggy, remote, immemorial, he sits in the Villa Ainola, a house he built fifty-one years ago in a forest fastness of Finland, seeking the seclusion and peace he needed to compose.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3-- On the stated assumption that Adlai E. Stevenson would enter the California Presidential primary, in June, 200 of his supporters from twenty-two counties began preliminary organizing work here late this week.

In Australia, the Conservative coalition, led by Robert Menzies, is following suit and new elections are to be held this Saturday --within little more than a year of the last Australian poll.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 3--Virginia, deeply rooted in the traditional Southern concept of complete separation of the races, is grappling unsurely but with determination with the greatest challenge to its way of life since Reconstruction days.
