ON Broadway as well as off Broadway, things are humming this season. For the first time in several years the theatre is full of vitality.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 3--This city's retail merchants are intensifying a campaign to force competitors to keep their doors locked on Sundays. Their principal adversaries are the highway shopping centers that have been springing up in outlying areas at an increasing rate.

DETROIT--For a half century, the automotive industry tip-toed nervously around the edges of the room whenever the conversation got around to the fact that, improperly used, the automobile can hurt and kill people, some of them innocent victims.

Eleven youngsters on West Eighty-seventh Street became gardeners yesterday morning, when seventeen London plane trees were planted on their block--between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. Wearing shiny, new green and yellow buttons signifying their membership on the junior committee of the Eighty-seventh Street Park Block Association, they were ready to assume their duties as the street's tree patrol team.

TO THE EDITOR: I read your most interesting article on the Menninger Clinic "New Laurels for the Menningers" (Nov. 6), and as I have a 21-year-old daughter who is extremely nervous, and has been receiving therapy for nearly five years and doesn't seem to be improving too much, I wrote to the clinic asking if perhaps they could help.

THOSE interested in the conservation of our wildlife are, happily, no longer regarded as fanatics. There are practical as well as emotional reasons for the movement which began in the Eighteen Seventies. Today we are fortunate in having more than thirty national refuges, in addition to National Parks and private refuges, for the protection of the breeding grounds of threatened species.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 3-- The Senate and House Republican leaders agreed today that President Eisenhower would sweep the country if he ran for re-election next year.

NO art save painting and sculpture suffers so much from ancestor worship as music. A few composers of the past have been raised to the rank of deities, and an overwhelming preponderance of performances in opera house and concert hall, on the radio and even on the phonograph in private homes pays repeated homage to them.

THE first comprehensive sampling, here of Japanese photography by members of that country's 5,000 camera clubs is displayed in an exhibition of nearly 300 prints which opened last week at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue.

SEVERAL interesting questions about, the design and styling of the 1956 automobiles were raised in a recent letter from a reader. The questions posed by Bernard Turteltaub of Jersey City were forwarded to the major automobile manufacturers, and the first set of replies came from the Ford Motor Company.

QUEBEC, Nov. 26--The Municipal Town Planning Commission has saved from impending demolition the house in which legend says General Montcalm died, Sept. 14, 1759, after the French defeat at the hands of the English General James Wolfe in the Battle of the Plains of Abraham.
The Community League for Retarded Children held its fourth annual luncheon yesterday in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. It was attended by 1,000 persons.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 3--A cookbook of Eastern Long Island recipes that helps to keep this village beautiful and well fed, too, is going into its second edition this week. Proceeds of the book's sale are fed into civic improvement projects.
A SCHOOL for judges of stereo slides will open at the meeting of the newly-formed Metropolitan Stereo Club at 7:30 P. M., Friday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.
Another outcast union has found a haven with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

TEN THOUSAND books--give or take a suitable number-- were published in 1955, according to a crystal ball that will be unveiled on New Year's Day. Moody critics may then spread a canard that most of these were about Troubled Africa.
PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 3--The nonviolent Hutterian Brethren are prepared to do battle for survival of their communal existence in South Dakota.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3-- Captain Bill Thieben scored 32 points tonight to equal the Dillon Gym record and lead Hofstra's basketball team to a 69--60 victory over Princeton.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP)--Sugar Ray Robinson will try to cap his ring comeback at the age of 35 Friday night by recapturing the middleweight title from Bobo Olson, a fighter he defeated twice in his heyday.
Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann, executive chairman of the Imperial Ball--A Night in Monte Carlo, has announced the names of the members of the partially formed junior committee for the event.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP)--Manchester United scored a 2-1 victory over Sunderland today and took the lead in English League soccer.

THIS week in London, Sir Winston Churchill will become the first recipient of the Williamsburg Award Instituted by Colonial Williamsburg, this is intended to serve as "a continual reminder that there are today, as there were yesterday, vigorous, courageous and eloquent leaders," who have championed and advanced the basic principles of liberty and justice in the world.

UNTIL the appearance two years ago of Conrad Aiken's "Collected Poems," it was easy to say that each of his books as it appeared represented a fresh start, a new direction. It was equally easy to say that for Aiken the musical phrase, the lack of a clearly developed theme, and a diffuseness of emotion were as obvious in the new work as they had been in the old.

Loss of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., for the first forty weeks of 1955 aggregated $2,019,000. This compared with net profit of $612,000 for the same 1954 period, the company reported yesterday.
MANDALAY, Burma, Dec. 4 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev again attacked colonialism angrily today. This time his attack was along racial lines.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Despite the low level to which business has fallen, the stock markets are presenting a firm front.
RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 4 -- Several French generals arrived today from Algeria for a conference with Andre Dubois, Resident General, to review the military situation in North Africa.

More New Yorkers are going to hospitals these days and getting better care than ever before. There is less crowding although the over-all number of hospital beds in this city -- about 49,000 -- is substantially the same as fifteen years ago.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 -The Brazilian Labor party, whose leader has been elected as the nation's new Vice President, is moving to break its pre-election alliance with the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Backers of Adlai E. Stevenson, whose call for "moderation" was criticized by some of his colleagues, are finding support for his plea in the nearest book of quotations.

George Washington has as many faces as the different portraits made of him. One of the most frequently portrayed men in history, Washington, as he really looked, remains a mystery in the midst of the graphic disagreement.

Organized lawyer and civil liberties groups sponsored a free six-page pamphlet yesterday that outlines rights of a person who is arrested in the city. The two groups are sharing the cost, with 25,000 copies in the first printing.

Fog that hung over the city from early morning hindered operations at the New York airports yesterday. Hundreds of scheduled flights were delayed or canceled. Some planes due to land here were diverted to Washington, Philadelphia and other airports.
A plan by which new probationers share the experience of those who have been rehabilitated by probation has been effected by Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of the Court of Special Sessions.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 -- The contract bridge pair of Pvt. Emanuel Hochfeld of Fort Dix, N. J., and Milton Q. Ellenby of Chicago took a commanding lead this afternoon over an 108pair finalist field in the 1955 Open Pair Championship.

HAVANA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Mike Souchak, the former Duke University football player from Grossinger, N. Y., won the $15,000 Havana invitational golf tournament today. He shot the final round in 3-under-par 69 for a seventy-two-hole total of 273.
The biggest labor federation in the free world will be born in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, operating savagely on defense, poured across three secondperiod touchdowns today to rout the San Francisco 49ers, 28 -- 7, in a National Football League game.
Leases of facilities in shoppi centers being built in Nass and Suffolk Counties have be reported by the sponsors of t developments.

I have had the misfortune to ride in the new Lexington I.R.T. trains several times during rush hours, and I would like to protest against the thinking that made these trains possible. They are nothing more than well-lit cattle cars, designed so that the maximum number of bipeds (not human beings) can be crammed into them with no thought of comfort or dignity.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -Dick Bielski, a fullback, scored a touchdown, kicked two field goals and converted three extra points as the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the Chicago Cardinals, 27-3, in a National Football League game at Connie Mack Stadium today.

In your editorial of Nov. 27 you draw attention to a warning by Lewis L. Strauss that this country is falling behind the Soviet Union in the numbers of scientists and engineers being graduated annually.

David Sarnoff, chairman of the boards of the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company, announced yesterday that the two companies are jointly forming an opera company. It will be called the N. B. C. Opera. Starting next fall it will make annual tours in the United States and Canada with a repertory of operas in English.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- Soviet commentators are demanding new legislation to cope with juvenile crime.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 4 -- It is Understood that, probably beginning Jan. 1, the Netherlands Bank will abolish its temporary embargo on the issue of long-term foreign loans in Holland. This embargo was introduced some months ago to pave the way for the unattractive 3 1/4 per cent Government loan, which has proved no success at all.

Since last spring the Russians have been going through the motions of turning East Berlin over to the so-called German Democratic Republic. This curious Government is not German, since it is controlled from Moscow; it is not democratic, since its people do not determine how it is run; it is not a republic, since it is neither responsible nor representative.

A pipeline project that would have displaced 260 American-flag coastwise and intercoastal tankers appears to have been shelved by the combined efforts of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee and Senator Warren G. Magnuson.
James P. Warburg's letter on foreign policy published Nov. 22 contains some interesting views on the present situation but reaches the wrong conclusion.

The proposal to introduce religion into the New York City public schools (New York Times, Nov. 25) is frightening indeed and contains implications which call for an unsentimental consideration of the consequences of such a plan.

It is understandable that there should be opposition from some persons in Virginia -- and elsewhere in the South -- to the Supreme Court decision that outlawed racial segregation in public schools. The opposition, however, ought to be frontal and not evasive if it is to do credit to those who really believe that the highest tribunal in the land was mistaken.
Representative James G. Donovan, a Democrat, and Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., a Republican, both of New York, appealed yesterday for strong support for Israel.

THE Knickerbocker Chamber Players presented a new work at their Town Hall concert yesterday afternoon -Ezra Laderman's "Music for Strings, Woodwinds and Harpsichord." The piece was written for the Knickerbocker Players.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The French Communists made a formal bid today for alliance with the Socialists in the elections to be held Jan. 2 to choose a new National Assembly.

ZURICH, Dec. 4 -- Interhandel common stock, quoted last Monday at 1300 asked, closed on Thursday at 1310. But on Friday it jumped to 1380 after hearings before a United States Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on amendment of the "Trading With the Enemy Act."
CERVINIA, Italy, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A big advance guard of the United States ski team reached this mountain resort today to train for the Winter Olympics at Cortina D'Ampezzo.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 4 -Donald H. Loughridge, dean in Northwestern University's technologist Institute since July 1953, submitted yesterday his resignation as dean to Dr. Roscoe Miller, president of the university.

Visa difficulties have blocked or seriously delayed 100 foreign scientists invited to the United States in the last few years. In addition, they have led seven international scientific organizations to prefer meeting abroad.

Ch. Barrage of Quality Hill, the 2 1/2-year-old boxer owned by Mr. and Mrs. Jouett Shouse of Washington, added another best in show to his record last night. The Brooklyn Kennel Club event he won was his eighth.
Four teen-age panelists on The New York Times Youth Forum agreed last night that both good and bad works had been published in three musical categories -- classic, modern and jazz.
MAURICE CHEVALIER and his nostalgic songs and Marcel Marceau and his extraordinary pantomime lent a varied Gallic touch last evening to Channel 4.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 4 -- American interest in South Africa, financial and otherwise, is not always cordially received.

Robert Henry Schlesinger, missing since his indictment here last June on a charge of grand larceny, was found in Canada yesterday. He agreed to return to New York this morning. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said Schlesinger was wanted in the investigation of a $180,000 oil swindle.

The fifth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will offer a guest appearance by the Italian tenor, Gianni Poggi, as the Duke in "Rigoletto" on Wednesday evening, Dec. 14. The first Metropolitan performance of "La forza del destino" since the 195354 season will be given on Friday, Dec. 16.

MARIA TALLCHIEF returned to action with the New York City Ballet on Saturday evening after two weeks as a guest artist in Rio and a third week nursing an injured foot. She showed every sign of complete recovery, however, in one of the best performances she has ever given in "Swan Lake."

WASHINGTON, Dec, 4 (AP) -- Hnry F. Holland, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said on returning from South America today he was more convinced than ever that the Western Hemisphere was "the great land of opportunity."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Colombo Plan nations of South and Southeast Asia were cautioned today that, despite their hard-won gains in economic development, "much more has still to be done and some of the tasks ahead will be even harder."

The New York City Youth Board is scheduled to ratify on Wednesday its contract with Combined Artists, Inc., for participation in a full-length motion picture based upon its fight against juvenile delinquency.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 4 -- President Eisenhower may take up for the first time tomorrow the growing dispute within his Administration over foreign-aid programs.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 -- When all the figures are in they will show that, on a daily average basis, new steel records were made last month. But the way steel demand is holding up -- and expanding -- it is virtually certain that output this month will establish still another record.
The United States-flag shipping industry has embarked on a dynamic program designed to move more American agricultural products abroad.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Native municipal councilmen representing seven Algerian cities resigned today with an attack against "unprecedented French repression" in Algeria.
Alton Jones, pianist, who returned to Town Hall last night after an absence of two years, played music of the eighteenth and twentieth centuries with real delight.

General Teleradio, Inc., which acquired 750 feature - length films last July in the purchase of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, is about to sell them to a television program syndicator for $12,000,000 in cash.

New state and municipal issues scheduled to be sold this week total $147,426,765. In addition there are $14,367,000 short-term notes. This compares with a revised total of $77,100,020 bonds and $5,400,000 notes last week.

A sensible proposal has come from the State Rent Administrator, Charles Abrams, that $120,000 be invested in a comprehensive housing survey of New York City, to be made on a sampling basis, promising less than 3 per cent error, by the United States Census Bureau.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Ellis Kinder, 41-year-old pitcher patriarch of the American League, became a National Leaguer today.
Basketball is here again and eyes that just were becoming used to split-T option plays and buck-lateral machinations out of single wing have to be refocussed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Defense Department has laid down strict procedures to be followed by overseas commanders to protect to "the maximum extent possible" United States military personnel tried in foreign courts.

News that the American Academy and the Institute of Arts and Letters here are "commemorating the extraordinary flowering of American poetry since 1912" with an exhibition which evokes the Teens of this century reminds us that those were indeed singing years.

J. FRANK DOBIE, the dean of Texas writers and the author of any number of books about his native state, is 74 years old now and still going strong. His competitors come and go and leave behind them masses of inferior books about Texas. But Mr. Dobie goes on forever (seems like), and if his Texas books don't get any better (that would be difficult) they remain better than almost anyone else's.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The message taken to South Asia by Khrushchev and Bulganin is calculated to appeal. Indians schooled in the nonviolent tradition of Gandhi and Burmese Buddhists are told the Bolshevik revolution would have been bloodless -- save for intervention of what is now called the Western bloc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Ross Rizley, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, is expected to resign soon to become a Federal judge for the Western District of Oklahoma.

In 1939 Colin Clark completed work on a comparative study of all the investigations that had been made by all the principal countries into national income and the economic characteristics associated with it in each case. That stimulating work, published in 1940, is to be found today in almost every economic library worthy of the name. Its title is "The Conditions of Economic Progress."
Cotton prices moved irregularly last week but closed again with net gains, the New York Cotton Exchange reported over the week-end.

The University of Georgia has received a grant of $110,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York to reproduce examples of American painting, sculpture, architecture and crafts for classroom study.

HAVANA, Dec. 4 -- A Cuban national baseball championship game here today was interrupted when a group of about twenty students rushed onto the field carrying anti-government banners and shouting "Down with Batista!"

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, in jury-ridden but full of spirit hobbled Alan (The Horse Ameche today and coupled grinding ground game with Quarterback Norman Van Brocklin's passing to trim the Baltimore Colts, 20 -- 14, in drizzle. The Rams retained first place in the Western conference of the National Football League by a half game.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 (AP) -The Cleveland Browns clinched their sixth straight Eastern Conference title in the National Football League by defeating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 30 -- 7, today.
NO pre-Christmas feasts in town in the last decade have matched in sound and color the annual spreads for shipowners, for executives in shipping and industry and for marine engineers and Navy brass.
The efficacy of Roman Catholic prayer and action in fighting communism was the theme of speakers at two communion breakfasts yesterday.
Apartment buildings in Brooklyn passed to new control in deals reported over the weekend.
"The Matchmaker," Thornton Wilder's farce about a scheming widow out to trap a husband, will have its Broadway premiere at the Royale tonight at 7:45 o'clock.
The surrender of two Communists for trial after four years in hiding was described by their party yesterday as "an expression of confidence in the rising democratic strength of the American people."

SEASONED scholars after nearly three months of formal education, kindergartners at Public School 75 talked over, one morning recently, what they had expected of the academic life, and how reality differed from their anticipation of it.

David Oistrakh will give the United States premiere of Dimitri Shostakovich's first Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony on Thursday evening Dec. 29. He will repeat it with the orchestra on Dec. 30 and Jan. 1.

The Business History Foundation, Inc., has chosen a real attention-compeller for its first publication. Ralph W. Hidy and Muriel E. Hidy have written the first part of a monumental history of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). It carries the company up to 1911, just before the law shattered it to bits. Two more volumes are promised.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The world crisis with the Communists is beginning to have a profound effect upon the Government's policy toward the school crisis at home.

In an Old World atmosphere 175 members and guests of the Gourmet Society sat down yesterday afternoon to a threehour feast. It consisted of Boar's Head Farcie; Consomme double, Noel; roast goose Strasbourgeoise, Baumkuchenringtorte (the traditional German tree Cake), old English plum pudding flambe, and accompanying wines, cordials and brandy.
AN engrossing and valuable glimpse into the problem of alcoholism was offered last night over Channel 4 in the "March of Medicine" series.

"20 July," a reconstruction by Constantine FitzGibbon of "the officers' plot" against Hitler, will be published Jan. 9 by Norton. The author is a former intelligence officer on Gen. Omar Bradley's staff who interviewed captured German officers of higher rank in an effort to uncover the facts behind the assassination attempt.
An epicure's selection of chiefly seventeenth century music was presented by the Concert Society of New York late yesterday afternoon in the Carl Fisher Concert Hall.

RECENT news from the vicinity of Pittsburgh has been disquieting. Honus Wagner, aged 81, has been on the critical list all week. If what follows seems to be tribute unstinted, that's precisely the idea.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 4 -- The discharge of John F. Cronin as city editor and the suspension of James H. Ratliff Jr. as a columnist of The Cincinnati Enquirer were announced here today by Roger H. Ferger, president and publisher of the newspaper.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 -- A delegation of three high Russian Orthodox churchmen from the Soviet Union arrived here today to seek to establish relations with the United Church of Canada, this country's largest Protestant body.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Economics experts here are engaged in a discussion to determine whether or not it will be possible to maintain the increase in French production next year without inflation or price increases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The approach of the decisive year 1956 finds the basic pre-Presidential convention situation in both parties markedly similar to what it was four years ago.
Labor's new federation has ambitious organizing plans, but they include no immediate blitz of the white collar workers.
Carmine DeSapio said last night there was "no competition" between Mayor Wagner and Governor Harriman for places on the Democratic national ticket in 1956.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 4 -- The Protestant foreign mission enterprise of 1955 would be unrecognizable to the old line missionary of fifty years ago.

When a citation praises a contemporary American journalist for "the courage, consistency and clarity with which he has defended our traditional liberties at a time when they have been seriously challenged and frequently violated" the name of Elmer Davis may not be the only one to come to mind.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The parliamentary battle that led to the calling of a snap election Jan. 2 in France was largely a personal quarrel between two old friends and political allies, Premier Edgar Faure and former Premier Pierre Mends-France.
BERGEN-OP-ZOOM, the Nethlands, Dec. 4 (UP) -- A Dutch girl whose marriage to a Moslem at the age of 13 later caused rioting in Singapore, announced today she would soon wed a Dutch cabinetmaker.

A statue of Ceres, goddess of corn and harvests, stands high atop the skyscraper home of the Chicago Board of Trade. It is a fitting agricultural symbol for the board -- the world's largest commodity exchange.

The American Civil Liberties Union criticized yesterday the Federal law providing immunity for witnesses in certain cases. Its constitutionality will be argued before the United States Supreme Court tomorrow.
The Board of Estimate may indicate today whether New York intends to continue the operation of its own piers or whether it is open to proposals that it transfer the facilities to an outside agency.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 4 -- India was drawing up tonight an angry protest to the United States against a statement issued Friday by Secretary of State Dulles and Portuguese Foreign Minister Paulo Cunha.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 4 -A battle is raging over the old McMillan house, in a twelve-acre plot in the Gettysburg National Military Park.

NORTHPORT, L. I., Dec. 4 -- Officials of this little harbor village, faced with having to pay $50,000 toward the Huntington Township police budget, will start a study this week on the advisability of dissolving the fifty-eight-year-old village form of government.

Plans for altering the ten-story store and loft building at 165-67 William Street into offices have been announced by Lee Gertner and Samuel Werbach, realty investors, who bought the property from Gordon Sedren.

THE names of Jean Sibelius and Olin Downes were coupled at Carnegie Hall early last evening, as they were joined in friendship and mutual respect for many years while the late music critic of The New York Times lived.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Administration is considering a ceiling on farm price support loans.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Grain futures moved up irregularly toward the end of last week after a weak tone early.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 4. -Representative Adam Clayton Powell favors "more independence" for Puerto Rico. He said today that the island should be given a status in the United States political system equivalent to dominionship in the British Commonwealth.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross said yesterday that she would begin a house cleaning of the Manhattan City Prison (the Tombs), starting early today.

HALINA CZERNY-STEFANSKA, a descendant of Carl Czerny -- he of the practice studies and an associate of Beethoven -- made her Town Hall debut Saturday evening. She played two piano concertos with the Symphony of the Air conducted by Izler Solomon.
Saturday night's "Un Ballo in Maschera" at the Metropolitan included the first appearance of Sandra Warfield, contralto, in the role of Ulrica.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. (UP) -A top Government education official insisted today that Federal aid to schools must be in construction grants and not for operation or teachers' salaries.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 -- Glenn L. Martin, aviation pioneer whose career ranged from production of 25-cent box kites to work on man-made earth satellites, died here tonight at the age of 69.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Twelve Southern states will pack more power than ever in the 1956 Republican National Convention. But leaders privately doubt any of them will back the Republican Presidential candidate next November.
Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation plans to spend $280,000,000 for new plants and other facilities, D. A. Rhoades, vice president and general manager, announced over the weekend.
Arthur Feuerstein, Morton Siegel and Abe Turner triumphed yesterday in the first round of the Manhattan Chess Club championship tournament.
Five new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
A five-day meeting sponsored by local units of the American Dental Association will open this morning in the Statler Hotel.

They have been saying around the National Hockey League that the New York Rangers are a flash in the pan. They're not saying that any more after the way Phil Watson's skaters manhandled the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues won by 7 to 3.

Shareholders of American Bantam Car Company will vote at a special meeting called for Feb. 10 on the merger of their company with Pressed Metals of America, Inc. The surviving company will continue under the Pressed Metals name and retain listing on the American Stock Exchange.
Mayor Wagner has revived the long dormant proposal to create a world fashion center in New York.

Uruguay is so democratic that it does not even have a President in the sense of an executive like our own, with strong powers. The distinguished and welcome visitor who arrives in Washington from Montevideo today, Luis Batlle-Berres, is President of the National Council of Government and he can serve for only one year, like the President of Switzerland whose government Uruguay has partly copied.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN, who gave a lecture on jazz on the Ford Foundation's "Omnibus" program of Oct. 16, gave a lecture on conducting yesterday on the same program. Like the previous talk, it was written by Mr. Bernstein himself, and it ran to three-quarters of an hour.

Cpl. Hugo A. Weiss, a survivor of the chartered airliner that crashed Nov. 18 in Seattle, gave his family a second spell of anxiety yesterday. Threatening weather at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, almost caused his plane to be diverted, but the plane landed, and Corporal Weiss went home with his family for their Thanksgiving dinner ten days late.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins finally ended one of their most discouraging losing streaks in recent years when they blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 0, tonight after five straight National Hockey League setbacks. The smallest Garden crowd of the season, 6,670, cheered the end of the Boston streak.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 4 -- Memorial High of West New York, N. J., won the Hudson County football championship by defeating Lincoln of Jersey City, 33 -- 6, at Roosevelt Stadium today.
Two Republican Senators took contrary views yesterday of organized labor's political activities.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Alternate fullbacks of the Jacksonville (Ala.) State Gamecocks bulled through the heavier University of Rhode Island line for two touchdowns that beat the Rams, 12 -- 10, in the Refrigerator Bowl today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored two goals in the first period and three in the third chapter tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In propaganda and in world trade the Soviet Union is working more and more through its European satellites.
SINGAPORE, Monday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Alfred Hitchcock, film maker, solved the mystery of his own disappearance today. He wired that his plane had been held up in Bangkok by engine trouble.
Is small business able to raise the capital it needs, when it needs it, and if so where does it get the funds and what terms does it obtain?
BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The Communist press continued today to insist that Berlin was the capital of East Germany. At the same time West Berlin newspapers sensed a blockade threat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today added 1,500,000 bags to its estimates of world coffee production in 1955-56. The revision was sharply upwards. The estimated addition would swell an expected surplus which already has caused serious concern to coffee producers.

December mornings when the sun is coming up fiery red at the horizon line from beneath a pink-cloud coverlet -- soft as an eider-down quilt -- the shore birds are beachcombers. The ungainly long-necked Merganser duck comes up on the beach and swaggers about.

One hundred students from thirty-six foreign countries celebrated their second annual International Students Day yesterday at the Presbyterian Church of the Master, 122d Street and Morningside Avenue.

FORT POLK, La., Dec. 4 -- The biggest lesson of Exercise Sage Brush is that there probably can be no such thing as a limited or purely tactical nuclear war. This generalization must be immediately qualified. There are geographical and political exceptions.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 4 -Governor Harriman of New York met this morning with about fifty leaders of Oklahoma's Demthe state chairmanship.
Commenting on a proposed project to identify an artist by fingerprints, two officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art said yesterday they had never before heard of such a method.

This is a fish story. It centers around the half-acre pond in back of the three-century-old Ambrose House on the campus of Governor Dummer Academy, South Byfield, Mass. From last March through May students made 600 catches of trout in this tiny body of water.
CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 4 -G. Diehl Mateer Jr. of Philadelphia retained the honors in the annual Gold Racquet tournament today,

Mordecai Namir, general secretary of Histadrut, Israel's Labor Federation, saluted the American labor movement yesterday for the moral and political aid that unionism here had given to Israel. Pie spoke at a reception given by the National Committee for Labor Israel at the Commodore Hotel for leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The steamship charter market resisted charterer pressure on rates again last week. Coal was relatively inactive, even at fractionally lower rates. But gains in lumber and grain kept the over-all freight rate index on its upward trend.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States launched a drive today to clean up amateur sports on a nationwide scale. Its primary objective is to eliminate the payment of "exorbitant fees" to amateurs under the guise of expenses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- To remain in the Eastern Conference race of the National Football League, the Washington Redskins needed at least a tie in their game with the Giants today at Griffith Stadium. They didn't get it.

CAROL BRICE, contralto, sang a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She gave the disconcerting impression she had succumbed to the mania for "big tone" that is at present almost universal in singing circles.
Labor leaders attending the A. F. L.-C. I. O. merger convention were welcomed in New York churches yesterday.

The violinist Joseph Szigeti famous for his introduction of thorny contemporary music showed afresh in his appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Saturday night at Carnegie Hall that he has equal love for the great simplicities of classicism.

Few achievements of the United Nations have been as spectacularly successful as the campaign against yaws, a disfiguring tropical disease of the skin. Since 1948 almost 10,000,000 cases have been treated and cured. The disease has been stamped out entirely in Haiti.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the South Pacific, Dec. 2 -- A two-time veteran of Little America is making preparations aboard this icebreaker for a trek across the Antarctic ice.

Birds that ordinarily would be coping with Long Island hunters are taking advantage these days of the newest sanctuary in the area. It is the Elizabeth Alexandra Morton National Wildlife Refuge, covering 113 acres on Jessup Neck in Peconic Bay.

Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, announced yesterday several top personnel changes in the system's operating department. Effective Jan. 1, Karl A. Borntrager, vice president of operations and maintenance, will become senior vice president; K. L. Moriarty, chief engineer, will become vice president-operation, and A. W. Laskoske, general manager of "Line East," will be come assistant vice presidentoperation.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Edward J. Chalmers, a retired fishing reel manufacturer, plans to seek permission this week to develop what he hopes will be commercially profitable uranium ore in New York's Westchester and Putnam Counties.

Although the outlook for the control of tuberculosis in the city is better, it still costs $50,000,000 a year to treat the disease, public and private organizations agreed in a statement released yesterday.

OF THE many recipes for eggnog that will appear in print this month (including some in this column, the most novel may come from Mabel Mercer. A singer famed for a unique style that jazz critics have struggled to define.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Glenn Foster, sailing Ordeal, broke the Arthur Knapp monopoly at Larchmont Yacht Club today. Winning four of seven races, Foster headed twenty-two rivals by collecting 204 of 210 points. Bill Kelly was his mate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Jules Levey will return to independent production by filming Thomas Costain's latest bestseller, "The Tontine." Mr. Levey has started negotiations with Spencer Tracy to star in the movie version, which will be made in England and continental Europe.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4 -- Yale University announced today that the Ford Foundation had granted it $1,600,000 to help finance a major revision of its Law School curriculum.

A machine developed to sell hot soup, introduced at the convention of the National Automatic Merchandising Association in Chicago last month, was ordered heavily. It is to be delivered in quantity by Jan. 15 to sell Campbell Soups.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ed Brown's 20-yard touchdown pass to Harlon Hill -- in the final five minutes -- provided the Chicago Bears with a 21-20 victory over the Detroit Lions today.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- Many diplomats behind the Iron Curtain, including many Americans, believe the time is ripe for change in tactics of behavior toward satellite regimes.
The Downtown Community Association announced yesterday that it would ask to appear as a friend of the court in the city's appeal from the Neponsit Hospital ruling.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Brown University will send a football team to the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on Jan. 2.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A brief Moscow radio broadcast disclosed today that Georgi M. Malenkov, who was ousted as Soviet Premier last February, had received an important promotion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Carmine G. DeSapio, Democratic National Committeeman for New York and Governor Harriman's chief political supporter, said today the Democrats could whip any Republican candidate for President.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Britain seeks the complete coordination of her foreign policy with that of the United States before the start of next year's election campaign in the United States.

With the bang of a gavel yesterday morning America's two greatest labor organizations formally became one. Thus the wheel of the American labor movement, taken as a whole, has turned full circle in the short space of twenty years: from the federation, to the bitter split of the mid-Thirties, and back to unification again today.
The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee reopened yesterday its investigation of Communist infiltration of the press, which was recessed last July.
The city will get another $999 out of the demolition of the Third Avenue El.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 5 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union and Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet Communist party leader, completed their tour of north central Burma today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, declined 8 to 27 points (40 cents to $1.35 a bale) yesterday.

The cards, says the lady of the house, are here. This means, to the head of the house, that the Christmas cards ordered a couple of weeks ago have arrived. And he sinks low in his chair behind his newspaper and hopes against hope that The Question will not be asked.
John G. (Steve) Broady took the witness stand yesterday in his wiretap trial in General Sessions Court and denied that he had ever illegally tapped telephone.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- President Luis Batlle Berres of Uruguay received an impressive military welcome and greetings from high United States officials on his arrival today for a state visit.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A court test of segregated transportation loomed today following the arrest of a Negro who refused to move to the colored section of a city bus.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Ray Robinson and Bobo Olson were examined by the Illinois Athletic Commission doctors today and found in good condition for their fifteen-round middleweight title bout Friday night.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Parliament today ratified an agreement with the Iraq Petroleum Company under which Syria will receive nearly $30,000,000 a year in pipeline royalties. The vote was 56 -- 19.

A National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight will send the New York Knickerbockers against the Rochester Royals, following a 7:30 preliminary between the Philadelphia Warriors and the Minneapolis Lakers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- A Chicago union official facing a threat of contempt prosecution testified today that he regarded the $9.15 a month collected from his members as "dues" regardless of where the money went.

Domestic steel production declined slightly last week to 2,356,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, with the industry operating at 97.6 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Never before yesterday's founding convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations had so many labor leaders, representing so many workers, appeared in the same place at the same time.

WITH a theme as absorbing as the renowned court-room clash between William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow during the 1925 Scopes trial, "TV Reader's Digest" should have been able to provide some exceptional viewing last night.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, the Labor party chief, is campaigning to oust Robert Gordon Menzies as Prime Minister of Australia on a straight program of "soaking the rich" to increase social benefits to the wage-earning class.
TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- Japan was entertaining today one of its most welcome visitors since the Meiji restoration, and there were at least three good reasons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Senate Democrats are preparing to seek a general accommodation with the Democratic National Committee on the foreign policy issue for the Presidential campaign.

It is welcome news that Prime Minister Eden and Foreign Secretary Macmillan are coming to Washington at the end of next month to confer with President Eisenhower and his aides on "affairs of mutual interest." Such a conference has become an obvious necessity to lay the groundwork for Western political, military and economic strategy in meeting Soviet Russia's open resumption of the cold war in word and deed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today the net income of Class I carriers during October at $92,000,000, compared with $77,000,000 in the same month of last year.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The auto industry's bigger producers are roaring along at close to record levels, heading for a year's car total that will top the combined output of any two years prior to 1948.
Rails, motors and rubbers held about even in yesterday's stock market but steels, metals, oils, tobaccos, telephones and some aircrafts staged vigorous advances.

A survey of the monetary aspects of international trade and capital transfers published today by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York finds that the world in general is moving toward more liberal foreign exchange practices.
RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 5 -- Moroccan nationalist leaders came out today for an independent, united and democratic Morocco.
Sidney Kingsley and the Columbia Broadcasting System have reached an agreement whereby the playwright will-create properties for the television network. The contract, however, has not been signed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a death sentence imposed on Amos Reece, a Georgia Negro, for rape.
The last of four second-string Communist party leaders who became fugitives after their Smith Act indictment in 1951 surrendered voluntarily yesterday.

If a new low could have been reached in Communist mendacity and hypocrisy it has been achieved by the Soviet Union's "traveling salesmen" in Burma. Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin have distorted fact and history in an appeal to prejudice that can have no honest purpose.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 -- The right of motion picture companies to limit distribution of 16mm prints of feature films and to keep them off television to safeguard the producers' self-interests was upheld here today by the Federal Court.
Construction of public improvements would cost the city $706,834,433 in 1956 under a capital budget in that amount approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3 -- The assessed valuation of real estate in Westchester County has reached a record $2,097,730,220, the County Tax Commission reported today to the Board of Supervisors. This was a net increase of $93,298,254, or 4.65 per cent, for the year.
People are gnashing their teeth more than they used to. This was reported yesterday at the opening of the thirty-first annual Greater New York Dental Meeting.

TRENTON, Dec. 5 -- The New Jersey Assembly tonight unanimously adopted and sent to the Senate a bill increasing state aid to schools next year by $4,100,000. The measure is expected to be approved by the Upper House when it reconvenes on Dec. 16.

Friday's total of blood donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 375 pints. Included were 131 given at the Montefiore Hospital Medical Group, 3455 Steuben Avenue, the Bronx, and 126 pints from employes of the Arabian-American Oil Company at the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind, 115 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Earnings of the New York Central Railroad dropped last month to $4,169,091 from $5.592,203 in November, 1954. It was the first time this year that monthly earnings on a year-to-year comparison basis fell below those of 1954.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- A major United States-Canadian air defense exercise was under way tonight amid unusual secrecy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy attacked the Fund for the Republic tonight as "a vicious anti anti-Communist propaganda machine."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States Government is taking a marked and sympathetic interest in the efforts to create an international federal-type authority for the development of nuclear energy in West Europe.
MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Consolidated Paper Corporation Ltd. became the latest Canadian company to increase its newsprint price when it gave notice today of a $4-a-ton rise effective Jan. 1.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Frederic W. Ziv, board chairman of ZIV Television Programs, Inc., said today that advertisers purchasing present or future ZIV TV shows would find them "plug free."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5 (UP) -- Howell E. Jackson's Nasrina, winner of two big stake races for juvenile fillies during the season, today was named the champion 2-year- old filly of 1955 by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has sold the five-story building at Fiftieth Avenue and Second Street, in Long Island City, Queens, to the Schwartz Chemical Company, at the same time leasing back one-third of the space to continue to house railroad generating machinery.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5 -- Brazil's war minister put an end today to speculation over his feelings about Joao (Jango) Goulart, the controversial Vice President-elect.
The Iron Curtain may be lifted for Broadway drama critics next month when the American production of "Porgy and Bess" opens in Moscow.
State Controller Arthur Levitt called yesterday for "immediate steps" to improve the schooling received by Negro and Puerto Rican pupils in this city.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- The advance party of the Soviet embassy staff arrived in Bonn tonight.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press) -- A two-price system for the sale of Canadian wheat was proposed today by the Interprovincial Farm Union Council in a brief to the Federal-Provincial Agricultural Conference.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 5 -- A Czechoslovak group is in the Soviet Union studying the construction and operation of a nuclear reactor and cyclotron.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Dec. 5 -Theodore L. Bristol Sr., president of the Ansonia Water Company, died here today. He was 85 years old. His home was at 67 i%lorth Cliff Street, Ansonia.
Following are the text of President Eisenhower's telephoned address and excerpts from the talks by George Meany and Walter P. Reuther at yesterday's combined labor session:

MARGARET HILLIS last night increased the debt she is owed by concert-goers here who are seriously interested in the choral repertory. In the second concert of her New York Concert Choir's local subscription series, she led thirty-six skillful singers in five interesting works at Town Hall.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Increasing support has developed in favor of having the General Assembly meet in Europe next fall to avoid conflicting with the United States Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the retirement of Rear Admiral Frederick R. Furth, Chief of Naval Research, who has been directing technical preliminary work on the United States earth satellite program.
WACO, Tex., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Baylor, which has just finished a disappointing football season, today named Sam Boyd as head coach. He succeeds George Sauer.

A helicopter carrying a pilot and four passengers made a safe emergency landing yesterday in Central Park. The only jarring part of the incident was a summons served on the pilot by a policeman for landing in a public park without a permit -- a misdemeanor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- The Hollywood Coordinating Committee, the agency that brings together talent for benefit and service men's shows, appears destined to terminate its activities after the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. offered a prayer today that the Republican party in the years ahead could continue "under the leadership of our great President, Dwight D. Eisenhower."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- Six young women from the New York area were among the sixty-nine debutantes formally introduced to society tonight at the season's annual Bachelors Cotillon or First Monday German, one of the country's oldest coming-out parties.
Many presidents of life insurance companies want their organizations to contribute to higher education -- with important reservations.
The new labor federation slowed the power drive of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday.

Trading was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Only zinc, rubber and cottonseed oil approached normal volume. Prices were generally higher. Rubber, wool, zinc, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead, cocoa and hides rose; changes in coffee, sugar and copper were mixed, and potatoes and onions eased.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Corn again was strong today, with more general buying. The firmness in corn tended to bring buying into other pits.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 5 -- A clergyman from India declared here today that neither American democracy nor American Christianity could be taken seriously so long as racial segregation was common practice in many areas.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 5 -- The Israeli Government is stockpiling food and raw materials in view of the security situation.

ALTHOUGH Lytton Strachey's "Eminent Victorians" was published in 1918, when I was too young to read it, I doubt if the word "Victorian" became approbrious at once. Changes in intellectual fashions take time to ferment and don't occur instantaneously. But within five years, perhaps in less, "Victorian" had come to mean prudish, sanctimonious, stuffy, ludicrous and old-fashioned.
The American Civil Liberties Union appealed yesterday to the motion picture industry to scrap the Production Code by which the major film companies govern the content of their movies.
Stanley R. Broff, Manhattan real estate man and builder, has purchased the southwest corner of East End Avenue and Eightieth Street and will build a twenty-story apartment house.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Premier Edgar Faure indicated today he would not engage in a personal campaign battle with former Premier Pierre Mendes-France. He implied this course of action despite the bitter accusations made against him by his former friend and fellow Radical party member.

JELLY that tastes like a Manhattan cocktail and tiny tomatoes pickled with dill are among the new appetite provokers in the renovated delicacy shop at Hammacher Schlemmer, 145 East Fifty-seventh Street.

ATLANTA, Dec. 5 -- The Board of Regents of Georgia's university system turned down today Gov. Marvin Griffin's move to take Georgia Tech out of the Jan. 2 Sugar Bowl game against the University of Pittsburgh.

Subsidiaries of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation, the Ohio Oil Company and the Continental Oil Company have been granted oil exploratory concessions in North Africa on a total of 35,000,000 acres, according to an announcement by these companies yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- Britain has asked the United States to reduce other tariffs to make up for a tariff increase imposed recently on bicycles.
The beginning of a "complete reorganization" of the Department of Correction was ordered yesterday by Commissioner Anna M. Kross.

Maurice D. Hopkins, the principal at the new Van Buren High School in Queens Village, wasted no time getting the V-Bees into the Public Schools Athletic League. The school, which opened in September, has no seniors and only seventy-two male juniors among its 1,700 students, but it already is active in basketball, bowling and track.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Harold Tribble, Wake Forest College president, was burned in effigy by a mob of 400 to 500 students who milled about his house tonight shouting "Down with Tribble." "Down with Tribble."
WOODFORD, England, Dec. 5 -- Sir Winston Churchill declared tonight that the two top Soviet leaders had been making an "exhibition" of their tour through India and Burma.
THE yearly yuletide decoration of the city's streets, parks, buildings, doorways and windows gives parents and children the chance to share at leisure wondrous sights seen but once a year.
ATLANTA, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Regents' decision probably will bar Georgia Tech and Georgia from future southern bowl games and doom them as national football powers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The New York Yankees declared tonight that as far as they were concerned, any deal with the Washington Senators at the major league meetings was doubtful.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Treasury announced tonight plans to raise $1,500,000,000 in "new" money through the sale of ninety-nine-day tax-anticipation bills.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru warned today that a statement issued last week by Secretary of State Dulles and Portuguese Foreign Minister Cunha had "far-reaching consequences."

Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad, estimates the book profit on his Central investments at $3,100,000 at the recent high of 49 1/2 reached by the company's stocks. His associate, Allan P. Kirby, president of Alleghany Corporation, a holding company, estimates his book profit at roughly $7,900,000.

Philip Joshua Fabrikant, president of M. Fabrikant Sons, Inc., diamond merchants of this city and Antwerp, Belgium, died at his home, 49 East Eightysixth Street, late Sunday night after a heart attack. His age was 54.
How does a rumor get started? This is one way:

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union is not in a position to use the Polish-held Oder-Neisse territories for bargaining purposes in the struggle for Germany, according to many resident experts in Eastern Europe.

I should like to inform your readers that medical colleagues and personal friends of the late Dr. Thomas T. Mackie have established a future in his name at the Roosevelt Hospital in New York to memorial the important scientific work carried on there for many years.
Truck loading conditions on the piers are worse now than they were under the outlawed public loading system, two trucking executives told the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Milton Q. Ellenby of Chicago and Pvt. Emanuel Hochfeld of Fort Dix, N. J., captured the Blue Ribbon Open Pairs Championship today. The event ended the twenty-ninth annual winter National Contract Bridge tournament.
Archbishop Patrick A. O'Boyle of Washington called last night for a liberalized imigration policy to admit 250,000 persons a year.

Directors of the Manufacturers Trust Company voted yesterday to split the bank's stock two-for-one. Horace C. Flanigan, president, said the management would recommend in March an increase in the dividend.

The British Overseas Airways Corporation has contracted to move its North American headquarters to the Bank of New York Building, now under construction at 530 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.

Just as Jack Kramer was about to send out a police alarm, Rex Hartwig showed up from Australia late yesterday to join the national champion, Tony Trabert, for their professional tennis debut at Madison Square Garden Friday night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Nationalist China was advised in her own "interests" today not to veto Soviet-sponsored candidates for United Nations membership.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The fact that the runaway the Dodgers made of the National League pennant race in 1955 hurt attendance in that circuit was revealed today when both major leagues released their official figures.

THOSE interested in hunting deer with the shotgun and buckshot, or the bow and arrow, will have an opportunity to hunt the northern hills and southern pine barrens of New Jersey, where the five-day season opens next Monday.

The number of metropolitan colleges that will have football teams in 1956 was increased to six yesterday with the announcement that C. W. Post College plans to field a junior varsity intercollegiate eleven next fall. Post is the new liberal arts branch of Long Island University and is located in Brookville, L. I.

Manufacturers of women's foundation garments expressed hope yesterday that showings of spring merchandise earlier than has been customary would make possible a longer retail selling season and enable stores to exceed their record 1955 sales.

Kurt Singer, author of "The World's 30 Greatest Women Spies" and "The World's Best Spy Stories," has a new volume about secret agents that will be issued Friday by Wilfred Funk. In "Spy Stories From Asia," Mr. Singer has gathered "Incredible true-life thrillers" from the Near East, India, Hong Kong, Korea and "the frozen steppes of Siberia.''

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Commissioner Ford C. Frick today presented to the major league club owners his long-awaited report on a survey he had made last summer on baseball's ills in general and the impact of radio and television on attendance, particularly in the minors.
GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- A senior Canadian diplomat has warned that the free world will be "confused and dismayed" if the United States does not join the Organization for Trade Cooperation next year.
The United States Navy Hydrographic Office, charged with keeping an eye on more than seven-tenths of the earth's surface, will celebrate its 125th anniversary today.

The Mojud Company, Inc., hosiery and lingerie manufacturer, announced yesterday that both parties had "agreed to a discontinuance of the legal actions arising out of the lawsuit" brought by David L. Judson, a director, against Mojud and certain other directors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Democratic contest for the Presidential nomination next year is beginning to take on aspects of what was known as "the battle royal" to boxing fans in the rugged American past. In this spectacle five or six pugilists fought for the survival of the fittest in a single ring, and craft triumphed more often than brawn.

A leading concern of management consultants soon will start asking questions around the country on behalf of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks to see how the nation's savings banks can hold their position in the thrift field, among other things.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- Harold E. Stassen warned today against what he called the "dangerous" political implications of the merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Net assets of Television-Electronics Fund, Inc., reached $105,847,907 on Oct. 31, end of the fiscal year, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This was equal to $11.05 a share and compared with $55,868,018, or $9.47 a share, a year earlier. Shares outstanding increased to 9,574,053 from the 5,901,271 of a year ago.
Apartment houses and commercial property were involved in recent Bronx realty deals.
New York's International Airport is in the midst of a construction boom. Permanent structures are going up at a rapid rate to replace many makeshift buildings of earlier years at Idlewild, Queens.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Shots fired by French security forces in a crowded market square at Lamy, Algerian village near the Tunisian frontier, took a heavy toll of life yesterday.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Andrea Chenier" on the night of Jan. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York. Mrs. John Hejinian is chairman of the benefit committee, Miss Jeanne Parker Ford is vice chairman, and among their aides is Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley Jr.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 -- Two of the closest advisers of Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, former provisional President, were arrested early today. They were taken during the course of more than 100 surprise raids by the police.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The nation's professional golfers were urged today to do all in their power to help "check and destroy any gambling influences in golf."
An economic downturn next year was predicted yesterday by Ralph D. Paine Jr., publisher of the magazine Fortune.

Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, received last night a citation from the City of New York and a March of Dimes award for distinguished services in philanthropy and other humanitarian causes.

With world-wide sales of major products up 14 per cent over a year ago, a continued high level of earnings for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the fourth quarter of this year was predicted yesterday by M. J. Rathbone, president.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Pete Elliott, Oklahoma s 29-yearold backfield coach, today was announced as Nebraska's first choice as head football coach.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Most high-class industrial shares advanced today on all-around increased demand.
Milton Eisenhower should be the Republican nominee. If he were elected President his closest confidant and most helpful adviser would be his older brother, Dwight Eisenhower.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Pacific Coast Conference directors fined the University of California at Los Angeles the maximum of $1,000 today for offering an athlete an academic scholarship when there was no chance of furnishing it.

SEVENTY years after its founding and five moves northward with the shifting center of the art world, the Kraushaar Gallery has opened its first exhibition in new and attractive quarters at 1055 Madison Avenue. Starting with landscapes by Thomas Moran and pastoral paintings by William Watson, the gallery under several members of the family has kept pace with the development of American art.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Eden will visit President Eisenhower at the White House for a few days at the end of January.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Dan Reeves said today after a meeting with the three other owners of the Los Angeles Rams pro football club that "after fifteen years as head of the Rams I have no intention of stepping out."
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 5 -- John (Honey) Russell, Seton Hall University's basketball coach, will know late Thursday night what to expect from his team this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- State Department officials asserted today that it was United States policy to maintain neutrality in the dispute between Portugal and India over Goa.
Seald-Sweet Sales, Inc, promotion and sales subsidiary of the Florida Citrus Exchange, is making plans for a season-long advertising drive for its Florigold and Flo Indian River fresh citrus brands.

Peter Muller, German middle-weight, gained a unanimous decision over Ray Drake of Far Rockaway. L. I., in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Muller weighed 157 pounds and Drake 159 3/4.
NOW that the fox-hunting season is in full cry along the east coast, New York equestrian shops are busy outfitting those tweedy types who can ride to the hounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a test of Nebraska's "right-to-work" law. A court decision could affect similar laws in seventeen other states.
George Meany dedicated the new labor federation yesterday to serving the nation and advancing the welfare of workers throughout the world.
Decorated yesterday by the Polish Government-in-Exile for her services to Poland, Mrs. Preston Davie urged that the United States recognize that Polish Government.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The British Government's position on the future of Cyprus moved slightly but perceptibly today in the direction of concession.
Two veterans in the field of naval and marine construction have been promoted to new posts with the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- The twenty-fifth exposition of chemical industries opened here today with some 500 exhibitors participating in the largest displays in the group's history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Six leading economists advised Congress today against cutting taxes in the 1956 election year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Federal Government and Eastern Air Lines were held by the Supreme Court today to have been jointly negligent in an air crash here in 1949 that killed fifty-five persons.

When the Azuma Kabuki Dancers from Tokyo open their second New York engagement of three weeks at the Broadway Theatre on Dec. 26 they will introduce two traditional phases of the Japanese Kabuki theatre art. One will be the playing of female roles by male actor-dancers, and the other will be the form of stage acrobatics called "tombo," which, among other things, requires the performer to fall from great heights.

Substantial recovery of trade and commerce in Europe presents a new problem for Canada, Gordon R. Ball, president of the Bank of Montreal, told shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Montreal.
Julius Gregory, architect of homes, died Sunday night in the Amity Nursing Home, Ringoes, N. J., after an illness of several months. His age was 80.
One of the major performers in "Uncle Vanya" will be Felicia Montealegre, wife of Leonard Bernstein, composer-conductor. She will interpret the role of Elena.
President Eisenhower cautioned the united labor movement yesterday to safeguard the right of its 15,000,000 members to differ politically.

A story headlined "Chinese People Called Satisfied," by Arthur J. Olsen, appeared in The New York Times of Nov. 20. The story quoted Gerald Bailey, observer at the United Nations for the Religious Society of Friends of Great Britain, as saying: "* * * The Chinese people seem to be satisfied with their Government."
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Willie Hartack, starting a ten-day suspension tomorrow, rode four more winners at Tropical Park today.
AFTER convulsing the British for a season, Thornton Wilder's "The Matchmaker" has settled down at the Royale where it began convulsing New Yorkers last evening.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 5 -- The White House press secretary said today that it was a "good assumption" that President Eisenhower had discussed foreign aid problems this morning with two White House aides.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Twenty thousand Americans working for the Defense Department overseas will be brought under the Civil Service System April 1, the Civil Service Commission said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A Federal judge gave the Government fifteen more days today in which to decide whether it would appeal an order to give Leonard B. Boudin a hearing in a passport case.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General of New York, today challenged Democrats who "seem willing to jettison bipartisan foreign policy."
New York's banks were alerted yesterday to unsound practices in automobile installment lending by George A. Mooney, New York Superintendent of Banks.

Mutual insurance underwriters came out yesterday for streamlined compulsory car coverage. Their stand is at direct variance with that of the stock casualty companies, which advocate keeping auto liability protection on a voluntary basis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission testified tonight that he attended three White House strategy conferences while the Dixon-Yates contract was at issue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A conference on children and youth was told today that services for children must compete with autos, television sets and housing for consumer dollars.

The letter on farm surpluses which appeared in The New York Times Nov. 11 seemed particularly important, as it was from a former CARE executive director, Paul Comly French, who has been engaged in the distribution of foods.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. assured 2,500 members of the Uniformed Firemen's Association last night that the City Administration was sympathetic toward their objective of a $7,000 annual salary for first-grade firemen. He added, however, that this objective might not be attained for two or three years.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 5 -- President Eisenhower, a veteran broadcaster, confessed today that he still felt strain while waiting for radio experts to let him begin a broadcast.

Sales of the Allied Stores Corporation for the nine months ended Oct. 31 rose 7.6 per cent and consolidated net profit climbed 13.8 per cent above the results for the corresponding nine months of the preceding fiscal year.

The Pepsi-Cola Company is looking for an advertising agency to handle its account. Its billings in all types of media are estimated to exceed $8,000,000 a year, plus $2,500,000 in cooperative dealer advertising.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 -- Fifty coastal ships were held up tonight in Sydney, New castle and Melbourne by a strike of masters throughout Australia. Additional vessels were standing idle in other ports.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The United States Secretary of Agriculture predicted today that the Eisenhower Administration's farm record would not handicap the Republican candidate for President in 1956.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A Washington source revealed today that George Weiss of the Yankees had offered "three or four players" on the Denver club for Mickey McDermott of the Senators.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The United States appealed to the Soviet Union again today to agree to President Eisenhower's proposal that each authorize the other to take aerial photographs of its territory.
Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that the State Power Authority would ask the Legislature for the right to control billboards along a thirty-five mile stretch of the St. Lawrence River.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- The official Soviet attitude toward the Western press has hardened considerably in recent days. Attacks on Western correspondents here and in India and Burma have increased notably in vehemence.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 5 -- The first land-based fighter-interceptor squadron in the Navy's aviation history has just gone into operation at the service's North Island base here.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- A leading East German Communist newspaper indicated today that barge traffic to West Berlin would stop New Year's Day unless an agreement was reached between East and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Defense Department ordered the military services today to make full use of each other's hospitals, physicians and dentists. It also ordered that they get together on planning for future expansion or changes in their medical facilities.

The Wellesley-Smith Alumni Clubs, in association with the Mount Holyoke College and Radcliffe College Alumni Clubs, have leased part of the seventeenth floor for club rooms in the Belmont Plaza Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation has entered the ranks of nylon producers with a heavy-type yarn for industrial purposes. Within a year, the company will become the third largest producer of nylon in the United States as its yarn plant in Hopewell, Va., reaches its full capacity of 20,000,000 pounds annually.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A New Jersey concern that had offered to invest in a new transit system here was said today to have been barred by a Federal court injunction from selling its stock in interstate commerce.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Steady investment demand kept prices firm in a quieter stock market today.

OF THE many cookbooks published this year, five come to mind as excellent possibilities for Christmas gifts. None are basic cookbooks and none would take the place of one. But each treats soundly and with interest some phase of the culinary art.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Canada insisted today that the United Nations expedite action on a Canadian proposal for the admission of eighteen new members.

The defense rested yesterday in the wiretap trial of John G. (Steve) Broady in General Sessions Court. Summations will be begun at 10:30 A. M. today by Assistant District Attorney Aloysius Melia and Sol Gelb, the defense counsel.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "The Last Frontier," a western adventure in CinemaScope and color with Victor Mature, Guy Madison, Robert Preston, James Whitmore and Anne Bancroft, is at the Paramount.
GONZALES, Tex., Dec. 6 (UP) -- Sheriff L. O. McGinty announced today that a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had been killed with a fence post.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 6 -- Burma is negotiating agreements with the Soviet Union in the economic, cultural, scientific and technical fields.

The major cause of all tooth loss may some day be countered with injections of medications such as female sex hormones. This was reported here yesterday at the thirty-first annual Greater New York Dental Meeting.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry's Press Department denied today that Georgi M. Malenkov had been identified as a First Deputy Premier in a broadcast yesterday by the Soviet radio.
Gov. Joseph B. Johnson of Vermont denounced as "a living lie" last night the argument that flexible farm price supports were unworkable.
Twelve witnesses, including a woman, appeared yesterday before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in its investigation of Communist infiltration of the press.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Medical Association reiterated today its opposition to the ban on heroin manufacture that is planned by the Gevornment for Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Angelo Inciso, a Chicago union official, told Senate investigators today how he scattered $1,200 diamond rings, watches and $360 gold money clips among other union officials who befriended him.
The Cudahy Packing Compan, the nation's fourth largest meat packer returned to profitable operations in the fiscal year ended Oct. 29, according to the sixty-fifth annual report released today.
Four outstanding athletes, three of them major league ball players, were honored last night at the Harlem Y. M. C. A., 180 West 135th Street.

School is really humming, now. American Education Week is long past -- that week in which parents went to school to see if the science teacher (or the biology teacher, or the English teacher) could possibly be as unfeeling and unreasonable as certain people say the are. (As usual, these teachers turned out to be hardworking, congenial folk, interested in their work and in children, and appreciated--with few exceptions--only by adults).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire majority stock control of the Central of Georgia Railway Company.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 6 -- A Pennsylvania legislative committee agreed today to consider a request from New Jersey lawmakers that their state be allowed to increase its participation in a proposed dam in the Delaware River.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 6 -- The chairman of the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission described as "disgraceful" today train performance records offered by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad during a hearing here on commuter complaints.

The National Association of Manufacturers will alert its membership against political and economic threats "implicit" in the merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, Kenneth R. Miller, its managing director, said last night.

THE way the story goes is that Ed Barrow made a trip down the Monongahela Valley to scout a ballplayer named Al Wagner. On the way he became fascinated by a big rawboned kid in dungarees who was picking up rocks along the railroad right of way and unconcernedly scaling them across the river.
The police in Brooklyn captured six men wanted for two hold-ups yesterday.

PEOPLE are the prime concern of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society. The other day the society found in its mail something that was, as George M. Galloway, assistant executive director, put it, "a little out of our line."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The New York, St. Louis and Chicago (Nickel Plate) Railroad, fighting for its independent existence, appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for protection from merger overtures of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 6 -- The winners of the first Audience Awards Election were announced tonight to a festive gathering of Hollywood notables at a banquet in the Beverly Hilton Hotel.
A City Council minority David appeared yesterday to have floored the twenty-three-man Democratic Goliath.

KACICE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 6 -- By present official standards the Novy Zivot (new life) cooperative farm is about halfway between the richest and poorest of such enterprises. If it is, then by any standards the Czechoslovak farmer is doing well for himself.
