THE city's shops abound with gifts for the home. The homemaker who is her own domestic staff looks expectantly toward Christmas, when she may receive a handsome, new appliance designed to be of daily aid to her, and giving her more time with her family.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Army has ordered top priority for guided missile production and has assigned a major general to the task of getting speedy results.

For the first time in eighteen years, a Delicious Monster at Hunter College is in bloom. An uncommon tropical plant, the Delicious Monster was presented to the college in 1939 by the Firestone exhibit at the World's Fair.
Sales of commercial property in Brooklyn and in Hempstead, L. I., to investors, were reported by Thomas G. Sarris, broker.

An investor has purchased'a] site for an office building on the[ northeast corner of Enos Placel and Newkirk Street, at Journal] Square, in Jersey City. The buy-] er, who was unidentified, is a client of Ben Schlossberg, Inc., realty broker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States took the first step today toward making Thomas A. Edison's laboratory a National shrine.

Even New York, accustomed to taking calmly the almost daily changes in its famed skyline, must sit up and take notice with some excitement of the gigantic plans announced yesterday for rebuilding substantial areas downtown in the oldest parts of Manhattan.
Dr. Joyce Brothers, a 28-year-old psychologist, won $64,000 last night by answering a question about boxing that ranged from ancient Rome to the modern-day ring.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The French Socialist party rejected today an electoral alliance with the Communists and set the stage for cooperation with Pierre Mendes-France, former Radical Premier.
Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday plans for the construction at Windsor, Conn., of a $5,000,000 nuclear engineering and development center.
An important change in the competitive problem faced by suburban branches of department stores was forecast yesterday.
Subscription books will be opened today on $90,000,000 of new investment grade debt securities and preferred stock of public utility and railroad enterprises. The offerings are as follows:
A 39-year-old former Brooklyn bank clerk was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on a charge of embezzling $240 from his employer even though he had made complete restitution.
Nashua, the horse of the year, and sixty-one of his stable-mates were listed for public sale by the executors of the estate of William Woodward Jr. yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The Soviet Union offered the Western powers today several of Moscow's much needed disarmament proposals as the basis for a new round of United Nations talks.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- Communism in the U. S. S. R. has always been conjugated in the future. The day will come, it is boasted, when individual wants can be satisfied according to need, not work. It isn't stipulated who will measure this. For the Utopian stage has admittedly not been reached.
WACO, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP) -- A murder trial was televised today for the first time.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the 81-year-old dean of America's trainers, saddled his first winner of the winter when the Wheatley Stable's homebred, Dark Ruler, beat seven rivals in the feature at Tropical Park today.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Siboney Development and Exploration Company announced yesterday acquisition of 100 per cent of the outstanding capital stock of eight Cuban oil companies from Caribbean Petroleum Associates, Inc.
The New York Public Library will dedicate next Tuesday a new branch building, fulfilling plans made in 1896 by an immigrant benefactor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell announced today an antitrust consent judgment requiring R. Hoe Co. of New York to withdraw from alleged international cartel agreements covering the manufacture, distribution and sale of printing presses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A high Administration official said today that it was now up to law enforcement agencies rather than Congress to prevent racial segregation in the public schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Secretary of State Dulles accused the touring Soviet leaders today of an effort to incite India to the use of force against the Portuguese in Goa.

Like many other educators and citizens who have been thoroughly dubious of the Eisenhower Administration's attitudes and actions concerning problems of American education, I had been skeptical also of both the motives and results of the White House conference on education that has just been concluded.
This port's restive waterfront today faces another crisis, and a work stoppage on lower West Side piers may materialize.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Iran rejected today the Soviet protest against her joining the Baghdad Pact.

Dave Beck backed down yesterday on his demand for "all or none" representation in the Industrial Union Department of the new labor federation. But he was still doing some fancy footwork and swinging hard as he retreated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- More than a score of college units of the Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps will be shut down because they are not producing enough officers who qualify for pilot instruction.
This could be the season for Brooklyn College to return to the winning side of the basketball ledger.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A conference of experts has been called tomorrow to consider spreading supplies of the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine by giving children only one shot next season. The polio season starts in April.
The board of directors of the Motion Picture Association denied its seal of approval yesterday to the forthcoming feature film "The Man With the Golden Arm."
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 6 -- The modern missionary was described today as carrying his Bible in one hand, a pickax in the other and using both with equal facility.

Stockholders of the McWilliams Dredging Company at a meeting here yesterday approved an increase in the authorized capital from 400,000 to 1,950,000 shares. They also voted in favor of moving from Illinois to Delaware to broaden the prowers of the company so that it can pursue a program of diversification and acquisition.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 6 -- Israel instructed her delegation at the United Nations today to direct attention of Security Council members to repeated Egyptian "aggressions."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- A General Assembly committee appealed today to the countries of the world to avoid attacks on civilian aircraft that inadvertently violate international boundaries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Guy S. Meloy Jr., commanding general of the First Infantry Division at Fort Riley, Kan., and a combat veteran was named today chief of public information for the Army.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- A French-German dispute over the arming of West Germany was said today to be on the way to settlement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett of Israel told Secretary of State Dulles today that he saw no reason whatever to suppose that prospects for peace in the Middle East had improved.

In a sharp rejoinder to Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin, Secretary Dulles has rightly denounced the Soviet leaders for their fraudulent campaign to stir up Asia against the West. As Mr. Dulles said, this is certainly no way to ease international tensions or to save whatever is left of the "spirit of Geneva," to which, incidentally, the Soviets still pay lip service for their own purposes.
MIAMI, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Belair Stud's Nashua was chosen as the champion 3-year-old of 1955 by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations today.
Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that its jet-age expansion program has been decided upon and that the first of a new fleet of twenty-six DC-8 jets would be ordered today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Navy awarded a $100,000,000 contract today for production of the Crusader jet plane that it hopes will wrestle the world's speed record from the Air Force.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 3 -- The political outlook here is dominated by the expectation that Governor General Jacques Soustelle's plans for the closer integration of Algeria with France will fail. It is expected that Algeria will soon move toward greater autonomy.
Vinyl plastics producers will report a sales increase of 20 per cent this year, compared with the 517,773,346 pounds sold in 1954, an industry spokesman predicted yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The Dodgers and Cubs completed a three-player deal today just as the major league owners wound up their joint session.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- A forty-passenger rotary-wing aircraft, described as the world's largest turbine-powered transport helicopter, was demonstrated publicly for the first time today.

A new exhibition, "The Age and Stage of Harrigan and Hart," portraying the colorful period of the New York theatre from 1873 to 1906, will open today in the Theatre Gallery of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d to 104th Streets.

MEXICO CITY Dec. 6 -- The gross national product of Mexico will reach a new high this year of 80,600,000,000 pesos (about $6,443,000,000, it was reported today by Nacional Financiero, the Government investment corporation.

The New York Knickerbockers halted their four-game losing streak by defeating the Rochester Royals, 116 -- 105, in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Army and Air Force said today that they would continue to court-martial military dependents accused of crimes abroad until a higher court ruled on the constitutionality of the procedure.

As the year ends, the economic soothsayers are preparing their forecasts for 1956 and even beyond. Many factors will be weighed before the final words of wisdom are spoken, but few, it is safe to assume, will receive greater attention than consumer spending.

An industrialist said yesterday that laboratory researchers with imaginative interest in consumer needs as well as in test tubes should be freed from penny-saving tasks and allowed to dream up dollar-making ideas.
Prices of cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was 9 points (45 cents a bale) higher to 12 points (60 cents a bale) lower than on Monday.
Walter L. Rothschild has purchased the fifty-seven-family apartment house at 213-17 West 238th Street in the Bronx. The property, on the northeast corner of Review Place, is assessed at $160,000.
Sales and earnings of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for the six months ended Oct. 31 were the highest for any corresponding period in the company's history.

TRENTON Dec. 6 -- Gov. Robert E. Meyner warned today that enactment of a bill now pending in the Legislature might well lead to a "shart increase in accidents and deaths" on New Jersey highways. The measure would reduce from two to one the number of automobile inspections in 1956.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Government is determined to continue the manufacture of the hydrogen bomb, the Prime Minister declared today.

COURTLINESS of portraiture and unbridled picturesqueness of landscape, the traditions of Winterhalter and Sorolla, return to art in paintings by Juan Antonio Morales, contemporary Spanish artist, at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

TODAY many intelligent men expect the future to be worse than the present. Their pessimism is based upon a whole series of frightening facts and sinister trends: atomic and hydrogen bombs, guided missiles, Russia, China, communism, the immense popularity in Asia of those two affable traveling salesmen, Messrs. Bulganin and Khrushchev, population statistics and the mounting pressure for social and intellectual conformity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union today formally recognized Austria's "perpetual neutrality."

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- British officials in Germany agreed in October to relinquish their role in controlling barge traffic on East German canals into Berlin. This was revealed today by a Foreign Office spokesman.
GREENOCK, Scotland, Dec. 6 -- The leaders of both great British political parties -- Conservative and Labor -- are closely watching the final build-up of the parliamentary by-election here.
The stock market sidled its way through the historic high yesterday, but failed to hold all the gain. Prices sagged in the final thirty minutes.

The tenth anniversary luncheon of the American Association for the United Nations will be given on Friday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of Mayor Wagner, is honorary chairman of the luncheon committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 -- The Merchant Service Guild agreed in Sydney today to instruct the masters of four interstate passenger ships to take them to sea without demanding pilots. The ship captains have been on strike over the pilot issue since Dec. 3.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The General Assembly failed again today to break the long deadlock between the Philippines and Yugoslavia for a seat on the Security Council.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- William Dozier, new production chief of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, announced today that the company hoped to make from twelve to fifteen pictures next year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The Chicago campaign headquarters of Adlai E. Stevenson, the only announced candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, denied tonight that Mr. Stevenson had knowingly passed a picket line here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The first test of the constitutionality of the Immunity Act of 1954 was argued in the Supreme Court today.

Following are the texts of the addresses yesterday by Governor Harriman and Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell before the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations session:

HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- The situation created by a wave of student disorders throughout the island since Nov. 27 is causing grave concern in Cuba. The demonstrations have resulted in about fifty being injured and more than 100 students jailed.
Governor Harriman accused ranking members of the Eisenhower Administration yesterday of plotting to weaken labor and strip it of its political rights.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- Automobile company officials here expressed interest today in the General Motors announcement. But there was no immediate indication of whether others planned changes in their dealer agreements.

The Childs Company, restaurant chain, which last September broadened its operations into the hotel business, is now going into the manufacture of shoe polishes, dyes, fabric cleaners and spot removers.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has been called for Jan. 30 to act on the proposal 3-for-1 stock split. The meeting will be held at 2:30 P. M. at the Mosque Theatre on Broad Street in Newark.
The question of providing the safest bad weather route for the Sixty-ninth Street ferry was discussed on the spot yesterday. A short detour around a ship anchorage was the probable solution.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A shareholder today filed suit to force the directors of Montgomery Ward Co. to repay to the company $692,250 spent on a proxy battle last spring.
Yale's varsity swimming squad will be trying to extend what probably is the longest winning streak in any college sports field when it opens its 1955-56 season at Amherst today.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 6 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party First Secretary, continuing his anti-Western attacks, charged today that the Allied powers were preparing West Germany for war against the Soviet Union.

A three-day drive to recruit 6,000 Girl Scout troop leaders and committee women opened yesterday in the city's five boroughs, i%rs. Irving Berlin, vice president of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, officially opened the campaign at the First Federal Savings and LoaR Association, 1274 Avenue of the Americas.

JEWELRY Designer Nadja Buckley will set a precedent for the Parke-Bernet Galleries today when a collection of her original designs is offered for sale at auction. The galleries have had previous sales of jewelry, but never before have they offered the collected works of a single designer.

Lower Manhattan realty that once formed part of a grant made by King George III in 1754 has been sold by the trustees of Columbia University to Dewey Carver for investment. It is in the downtown hardware center and is occupied largely by concerns in that line.

OZARK, Ala., Dec 6 -- The Army, rather than the Air Force, the Navy or the Marines, maintains the busiest air base this side of the "iron curtain." At least that's the belief of officers at near-by Fort Bucker, the Army aviation center and site of the Army's new aviation school.

Plans for the creation of a new park site for historic Touro Synagogue in Newport, R. I., were announced yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., New York real estate development concern.

School districts of Los Angeles, Calif., borrowed $20,000,000 on serial bonds in the public market yesterday. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank at a price of 100.4099 for obligations bearing 2 3/4 per cent interest.
MIAMI, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Jim McDonald, missing for a night deep in the Florida Everglades, turned up safe today five hours after the Coast Guard had started combing the sawgrass jungles for him.
Most plan and office employes here will get three-day weekends at Christmas time and New Year's. Some will be off for four days around each holiday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations sheived today further discussion of race discrimination in the Union of South Africa.
An extra dividend of $3 a share on the common, payable Jan. 13 to holders of record of Dec. 16, was announced yesterday by Fred G. Gurley, president of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway.

G. L. Arnold, an editor of the British monthly The Twentieth Century and a contributor to American periodicals, has a book on Dial Press' list entitled "The Pattern of World Conflict." He describes it as "a discussion of the current world situation as well as an investigation into modern totalitarian politics; both a descriptive study of cold war and peace and an essay on political analysis." It will be published Monday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 -- Approximately fifty vessels faced the possible prospect tonight of spending the winter in an evertightening grip of ice as the plunging thermometer kept turning the water in the locks between the St. Lawrence River and Lake St. Louis into huge patches of ice.

Commitments for future business loans are slackening some, J. Stewart Baker, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, second largest in the country, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.
BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Of the six major colleges and universities in Greater Boston with R. O. T. C., Harvard University was the only one reporting an end to Air Force operations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Six film directors have been nominated for the third annual television film directorial achievement award of the Screen Directors Guild, George Sidney, the group's president; announced today.

Tax reduction, debt reduction or increased Government expenditures -- which should have the highest priority of claim should the estimated budget figures for fiscal 1956-57 indicate a sizable excess of receipts over expenditures?

OTTAWA, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada has held confidential talks with chartered banks about the rise in consumer credit and indications are the banks will tighten up on certain phases of their lending operations.

Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross said yesterday there might be further shifts tomorrow involving the personnel of her department. Yesterday twenty-five members of the Correction Department's supervisory staff reported to new assignments in the beginning of a "complete reorganization" of the agency.

THE December exhibition at the City Center Art Gallery, opening to the public today, was judged by artists John Heliker, John Hultberg and Robert Vickrey. The fifty pictures selected range from the literal to the extreme abstract with the bulk of the work based in some degree on representational elements.

A handful of desperately ill cancer victims at Memorial Hospital have been deliberately exposed to new virus infections. It is hoped that the viruses may attack the cancerous growths without harming the patients.
Columbia College has been notified that its unit will be discontinued at the end of the 1956-57 academic year. The unit was established in 1951.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 6 -- At 4:10 this afternoon James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary, informed his regular afternoon news conference that he had "an unusual little story that Mrs. Eisenhower and the President have asked me to tell you about."

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec 6 (UP) -- The former world heavyweight champion Ezzard Charles avenged a recent setback by Toxie Hall and kept his comeback hopes alive tonight by boxing his way to a unanimous ten-round decision over Hall before a crowd of 4,700.
RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 6 -- The first representative Government in Moroccan history was formed today.
Details of the new "Rockefeller Center" development planned for downtown Manhattan were announced yesterday by the city and the Chase Manhattan Bank.
MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Newsprint Association of Canada said today the industry appears unable to meet newsprint demands because of a "remarkable increase of consumption."

PEARL HARBOR, Dec 6 (UP) -- A monument to American Navy men who died in the Pearl Harbor attack on Dec. 7 fourteen years ago will be dedicated tomorrow near "Battleship Row." More than 2,000 men were killed there in the Japanese attack.

TENNESSEE ERNIE FORD was just one of the stars appearing on the "Chevy Show" over Channel 4 last night. He was part of an array that included Ethel Merman, Robert Cummings, Shirley MacLaine and Jonathan Winters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- General Motors offered its 17,000 retail automobile dealers today a five-year franchise contract to supplant its traditional one-year agreement. Harlow H. Curtice, corporation president, announced an immediate revision of existing contracts to safeguard the goodwill of General Motors in the face of widespread "misunderstanding" of the current contracts.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 -- High military officers of the eight nations in the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty will meet here in January. Australians hope that this meeting will be the one that will "put teeth" in the pact signed in Manila in September, 1954.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- One of the most important political facts of life in India today is that millions of Indians are contrasting the attitudes of the Soviet Union and the United States on the two international controversies closest to the emotions of India.
BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- Five West German ministries are making a .detailed study of the implied threat of the East German Government to halt river barge traffic between West Germany and West Berlin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Strength in December wheat was the feature in Board of Trade operations today. The near-by delivery went to a premium above, the March and gained sharply on the May. Absence of deliveries on December contracts, strong local cash markets and firmness of spot wheat to the southwest encouraged buyers of December.

Committees have been meeting at the Pierre to arrange a theatre party for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Sweet Briar College Alumnae Club of New York. They have chosen the Jan. 17 performance of "The Great Sebastians" at the ANTA Theatre.
The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday a $50,000 libel verdict that W. Kingsland Macy had obtained against the New York World-Telegram Corporation earlier this year.

A story of luxurious living on someone else's money was unfolded yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. The man who lived so well is William W. Stirling, Mr. Hogan charged. He has been arrested for grand larceny, conspiracy and bribery.

Devotees of the theatre in all parts of the United States will be able to purchase all-inclusive theatre tours. The trips will guarantee, among other things, orchestra seats to Broadway productions and transportation with one of the leading airline companies.
Offerings of more than $21,000,000 of common stock of industrial and public utility companies will be made to investors today by underwriting syndicates, as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Following is the transcript of the record of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dulles:

On opposite sides of the net in the doubles match that decided the fate of the Davis Cup last August, the national tennis champion. Tony Trabert, and Rex Hartwig of Australia are in agreement that the international trophy should remain in Australia's keeping after the 1956 challenge round.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Terry O'Malley scored three goals to lead Harvard's hockey team to an 8-3 victory over Northeastern tonight in the Crimson's opening game of the season.

The letter of Julius Epstein The New York Times, as published on Nov. 24, poses an important problem to the United States. The problem is whether the United States can morally acquiesce in the forcible repatriation of persons, matter from or to what country.
Church leaders attacked last night a proposal that the city's Department of Health regulate summer day camps and vacation programs for children.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden Dec. 6 -- The American biochemist who won this year's Nobel award in chemistry said today he had not known where he was going when he began his prize-winning research.

Cardinal Spellman will spend his fifth consecutive Christmas season this year with the armed forces in Alaska, Japan, Korea, Okinawa, Formosa and the Philippines. He recently returned from visiting forces in Labrador, Greenland, Baffin Island and Newfoundland.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- President Eisenhower's special assistant declared here tonight that the President would decide whether to run for re-election next year with the "best interest of the nation first and foremost in mind."

The political situation in Peru is shaping up into one of the most interesting and, from the viewpoint of principle, one of the most important in Latin America. The question in a nutshell is whether Peru will or will not have a fair and democratic Presidential election on June 3, 1956. The decision has to be made soon.
CHICAGO. Dec. 6 (APl--Butchers dropped 25 to 50 cents while sows were fully 25 2cots do'rl today. At the close all butcher showed the full 50 cent decline

Commodity futures moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and burlap eased; cottonseed oil, lead, copper, wool and sugar rose, and changes in potatoes and tin were mixed.
Adlai E. Stevenson arrived in New York yesterday for a series of political conferences and a speech to the newly merged American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Internal Revenue Service filed charges of managerial laxity today against its Chicago district director, a career employe with twenty years' service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The major leagues, sitting in joint session With Commissioner Ford Frick, today expressed a willingness to work out their problems with the minor leaguers before a new pact was drawn up a year hence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Three groups concerned with children and youth agreed today to pool efforts again next year in a joint conference to further health, education and welfare programs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A study group of leading business men said today that tax relief should have precedence over reduction of the national debt under present economic conditions.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey last night outlined a legislative program that included restoration of 90 per cent farm price supports and an increase in personal tax exemptions from $600 to $800.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Sam Snead tuned his golf game after a long layoff with a five-under-par 65 to win the La Gorce pro-member tournament today.

Admittedly in the formative stage is the production of "Little Glass Clock." However, the principals conceded that contracts had been drawn for Eva Gabor and Reginald Gardiner to appear in the Hugh Mills comedy.

A total of 391 pints of blood were donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Monday, including 153 pints given at the downtown branch of St. John's University. 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn. At the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 32 Avenue of the Americas, 151 pints were given on the first day of a two-day donation.

As an educator and psychologist I am naturally most interested in whatever data are available concerning causal factors involved in juvenile delinquency. An article appearing in The Times of Dec. 2 entitled "U. S. Games Condemned" told of how a Spanish league had related such games as "cowboys and Indians," "cops and robbers," and other "shoot-em-down" play to cruel, violent and criminal behavior.
CAIRO, Dec. 6 -- The concern of Western diplomats here over the rapid expansion of the Soviet bloc's efforts to spread its influence in the Middle East is growing.
THIS is the saga of "one of those days" that occur not infrequently in the life of a wildfowler.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 6 -- A plan to carry Dodger fans across the seas to watch their team in action here next spring appeared stuck in the mudflats of Newark Bay today.

LYTTELTON, New Zealand, Dec. 6 -- Five days behind schedule, the antarctic-bound U. S. S. Glacier arrived here today after a voyage of almost four weeks. She left Panama Nov. 10 on the 7,500-mile journey across the Pacific.

IF WILLIAM FAULKNER'S novel, "The Sound and the Fury," had to be adapted into a one-hour play for television, last night's version on "Playwrights '56" over Channel 4 filled the bill satisfactorily. It was an intelligent video treatment of a theme that was almost bound to result in a thoroughly depressing theatre.

American companies' investment in advertising abroad will be in excess of $320,000,000 by the year-end, a joint meeting of the International Advertising Association and the Export Managers Club of New York was told yesterday.

A recent dispatch in The New York Times from Cuba describing the congestion at the United States Embassy because of the flood of visa applications dramatizes the orientation of our immigration law toward Latin America.

The New York Rangers, with five victories and two ties in their last seven starts, will Seek to keep their string intact when they face the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League match at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Edward Lamb, Ohio and Pennsylvania broadcaster, won a battle today against Government assertions he should lose his broadcasting licenses because of alleged pro-Communist activity.

The departure of Clement Attlee from the leadership of the Labor party will be loss not only to the British Socialist movement, but to Britain and the whole free world. Mr. Attlee, in his quiet, unassuming way, has been one of the great statesmen of our times, and this can be said however one may disagree with Socialist tenets.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 7 -- Federal aid to education was strongly supported today by Herbert Brownell Jr., United States Attorney General.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The repeated attacks on Britain by the two Soviet leaders touring in India and Burma are irritating more and more Britons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The resignation of William A. Brown Jr. as president and director of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation was accepted by the board of directors at its meeting here today. Mr. Brown is being retained by the company in a consulting capacity.
Michael J. Quill played the first scene yesterday in a new script that is expected eventually to call for full participation of his union in the united labor movement.
Leon Lowenstein, board chairman of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturer, disclosed yesterday that he had protested the Government's proposed sale of cotton abroad at cut prices.
Fifty feet of roadway buckled when a twelve-inch, low-pressure water main burst in front of 176-178 Canal Street at 9:30 o'clock last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Booming industrial conditions gave a bullish tone to Government reports on employment, personal income and plant expansion today.

Both sides summed up yesterday in General Sessions Court in the wiretap trial of John G. (Steve) Broady, 52-year-old attorney and private investigator. morning at 10:30 Judge Jonah J. Goldstein will deliver his charge to the jury.

As you properly point out in your editorial of Nov. 27, the Supreme Court ruling against segregation in interstate travel was a sound stroke on behalf of both freedom and equality in the right of movement. You are correct also in your statement that freedom of movement is a right Americans take for granted -- so much so that it has never been specifically safeguarded by the Constitution.

MOTHERS concerned with their children eating an over-abundance of holiday sweets will be interested in an extraordinary nutritious cookie just developed by the Missouri Experiment Station. Unlike many other seasonal confections, this cookie contributes more than calories.
The New York City Youth Board voted yesterday to drop plans for a motion picture to be written by Arthur Miller, Pulitzer Prize playwright, on the board's work with street gangs.

MANILA, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Danny Kidd, the flyweight champion of the Orient, retained his crown and Hachiro Tatsumi of Japan won the Far Eastern middleweight title in a pair of twelveround bouts at Rizal Stadium tonight.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 6 -- Israel received thanks today from the chief official of the Roman Catholic Church in the country for the settlement of damage claims growing out of the 1948 fighting.
Business activity in the nation will rise to a new high in the first half of 1956, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks predicted yesterday. He based his forecast on a...

A jury of prominent advertising men, gathered to select the winner of the Advertising Award for 1955, sponsored by Printers' Ink, decided that the problem was altogether too tough. They compromised at their meeting in Detroit last week by selecting two advertising leaders to receive the award.

ALL of New York plays host now; everyone, from toddlers to dowagers, entertains friends. For those welcoming guests during this happy season, this department today suggests menus. Geared to adults, teen-agers and small children, they are intended as inspiration rather than prescription.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Bob Baker of Pittsburgh methodically prodded to a unanimous decision over Nino Valdes of Cuba tonight in a dull ten-round match that probably eliminated both heavyweight contenders from any chance of a title shot with Rocky Marciano.
Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, urged last night a more stable defense program to achieve security against such surprise attacks as Pearl Harbor and Korea.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- West Germany's leading diplomats abroad have returned to Bonn to confer with Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, the Foreign Minister. They are to plan resistance to force recognition of the East German Government.

AN ideal time for the art shopper to take stock of what the New York galleries offer is the holiday season, which has brought forth dozens of diverse exhibitions. Most galleries have selected their group shows in order to give the widest possible range for both taste and pocketbook.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The British Cabinet was debating the surrender of British power in India. There were forceful, aggressive men in the Labor Government and they spoke heatedly and at length. Only a small, bald man in the center of the table, industriously doodling, was silent.

Prices on the New York commodity futures markets moved irregularly yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, hides, burlap and onions eased; zinc, tin, copper, sugar and potatoes rose, and coffee, rubber, soybean oil and wool closed mixed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Maritime Administrator says United States shipyards will be kept in business by new ideas and better planning -- and by Congress' continued willingness to grant subsidies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov failed to follow up recently a suggestion that normal trade possibilities between the Soviet Union and the United States were good.

The decline at one time yesterday of $9 in the price of Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway common stock reflected a general belief by Wall Street professionals that shareholders had been left waiting at the tracks.

RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 7 -- Premier M'barek Bekkai announced today the composition of Morocco's nationalist Government. The Cabinet was sworn in by Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef, who relinquished his absolute powers to become Morocco's first constitutional sovereign.

The present hearings on the trade practices of General Motors and their dealer policy are but another illustration of our antitrust confusion, which must be expected when we try to enforce the spirit of the Sherman Act with lawyers who do not know economics and economists who do not know law.

The Election Day mandate against governmental borrowing and higher taxation seems to have been accepted by the Board of Estimate in its adoption of a $706,834,433 capital budget for 1956, reduced more than $94,000,000 from the schedule submitted by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Seamaster, described as the world's first multi-jet attack seaplane, exploded at 5,000 feet this afternoon and plunged into Chesapeake Bay at the mouth of the Potomac River. One person was killed, and three are missing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Big Ten football coaches today recommended a change in the college rules to permit the defense to advance the ball on a fumble. They also proposed that a tenth or "tune-up" game be added to the schedule of each Western Conference team.
The deal by which Ransom Jackson was acquired by the Dodgers for Don Hoak and Walt Moryn brought in its wake conjecture that waivers had been asked on Jackie Robinson.
PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Official reports from Vientiane, Laos, today said powerful forces of Communist - led Vietnamese and Laotian rebel forces launched violent attacks on Laotian troops Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors, asked Congress today to help his corporation eliminate the "deplorable" practice of bootlegging new automobiles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- A fraud in which the Federal Government may have paid many millions of dollars at premium prices for supposedly domestic tungsten that was actually mined in Mexico was revealed today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 7 -- Republican and Democratic party leaders and legislators agreed late today on temporary state tax increases to finance an estimated $36,453,000 flood relief program.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- December wheat again was in demand today on the Board of Trade. It made a new high for the current move and at one time sold 1 cent over the March future.

Giovanni D'Ambrosio of Cleveland had an anxious two hours yesterday afternoon after the liner Roma docked at West Forty-eighth Street. On board were four of his children, ranging in age from 4 1/2 to 11 years old, whom he had not seen for four years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee overwhelmingly endorsed today a deal for the admission of eighteen countries.

The election of George Leib of New York and Roy L. Shurtleff of San Francisco as vice chairmen of Blyth Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles R. Blyth, president and chief executive officer of the investment banking concern.
Lower West Side longshoremen continued their slowdown yesterday, refusing to start work until dock gangs were at full numerical strength, but their threatened walk-out did not develop.
New issues of corporate securities valued at about $40,000,000 will be offered to investors by underwriting syndicates today. The offerings are:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Washington representative of an Ohio engine-building company conceded today that, as a Government official serving without pay, he probably violated the conflict of interests law in 1952.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The performance capabilities of the new Soviet military aircraft are estimated to be "commendably high," according to the latest issue of Jane's All the World's Aircraft.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 7 -- An official hearing here on commuter complaints might have received a new earful today -- if a certain luckless batch of travelers had shown up.

A biography of Clare Boothe Luce by her friend Alden Hatch is planned for Jan. 4 publication by Holt. It will be titled "Ambassador Extraordinary." 'Mr. Hatch traces her life from "comparative poverty," through her Success as a child actress, editor, playwright, Representative from Connecticut to her present work as envoy to Italy.

Final plans are being made for the Silver Cross Day Nursery Benefit Buffet Dansant to be held next Tuesday in the grand ballroom of the Ambassador. Miss Louise Marock, dansant committee chairman, has announced additional chairmen and committee members.
United States production of antibiotics for medical purposes this year will amount to 2,000,000 pounds, worth roughly $260,000,000, a major producer estimated yesterday.

The city's Department of Air Pollution Control is giving local field tests to three devices designed to reduce air contamination by converting apartment house incinerators to smokeless operation. The department estimates that at least 25 per cent of all complaints concerning air pollution in the metropolitan area result from smoke, ashes and odors caused by such incinerators.

Stock prices rose an average of 5.8 per cent in November, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. The average market price of the stocks that were listed both at the end of October and the end of November rose to $57.33 a share from $54.17.
The number of Massachusetts colleges that are to lose their Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps units rose to five yesterday.

Maj. Gen. Charles T. Lanham, United States Army (retired), yesterday was elected chairman of the 118-year-old Colt's Manufacturing Company. Colt's, a newly acquired subsidiary of the Penn-Texas Corporation, is a leading maker of firearms.
Sharp objects cause more than 25 per cent of eyes injuries among children, according to Dr. Franklin M. Foote, executive director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
A DIRECT way to become the light of a man's life is by giving him wisely selected smoking material for Christmas.

Top-flight athletes usually get indoctrinated in the sports in which they excel while they are still youngsters. There are some exceptions. At Mount Snow -a rapidly expanding area in southern Vermont -- there is a dazzling skier who put on wooden slats for the first time at the age of 21.
" The Man With the Golden Arm" pulled the United Artists Corporation out of the Motion Picture Association of America yesterday.

FOR several centuries men of letters, general busybodies and historians have wondered and been mystified by the strange romantic alliance of Jonathan Swift, the British satirist, with his two ladies, Stella and Vanessa.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards said today that Federallysponsored public housing was "losing ground."

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 7 -A new two-inch aircraft rocket, improved and more accurate bazooka anti-tank ammunition, and refined versions of the Army's Honest John field artillery rocket are among the latest products of the Army's Redstone arsenal here.

It is a distinction granted few artists to become classics in their own lifetime. But it would be reasonably safe to say that Jean Sibelius, who celebrates his ninetieth birthday today, has achieved that status. No concert season passes that does not include his music and there is no major orchestra that does not have his music as part of its active repertoire.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 (UP) -- A Navy jet that brushed an other plane in flight, exploded among fine homes today but all the residents escaped serious injury. A baby boy was saved by a laborer who scaled a drainpipe to get him.

THE "Screen Directors Playhouse" struck out early in the game last night on Channel 4 with a half-hour saga of baseball and newspaper men entitled "Rookie of the Year." Since the show is directed by John Ford, the results might well have been expected to be more impressive.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Arab spokesmen told the West today not to interfere with purchases of arms from Communist nations.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- Two uniformed United States soldiers were reported today to have been arrested by East Berlin People's Policemen, who immediately turned them over to Soviet authorities.

The Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation has purchased about 87,000 more shares of the Diamond T Motor Car Company under its invitation of tenders at $25 a share. This, with the 50,500 shares of Diamond T it previously held, gives Bohn about 32 per cent of Diamond T stock.
Directors of the Neptune Meter Company of New York and of Eastern Industries, Inc., yesterday agreed on a merger of the companies.

Any lingering doubts on the wisdom of free higher education should be dispelled today, when a number of the buildings that grace the St. Nicholas Heights campus of the City College are redesignated for distinguished alumni.
Christmas arrived yesterday for fifteen New York area employes of the Maritime Administration.
The unified labor movement drew up yesterday a rigorous code of direct and Government action to rid unions of crooked leaders.
J. C. Mayer, realty operator, has purchased apartment properties in the Chelsea section and lower Third Avenue and in the Ridgewood district of Brooklyn.

Henry Payson, operator, has sold to Frances Sapin for investment the five-story apartment house for ten families on lot 25 by 98 feet at 23 East Thirty-seventh Street for cash over a mortgage of $54,500. The property is assessed at $75,000 and was sold through Harold M. Silverman, broker, who said it was the third time he had negotiated a sale of the house in the last two years.
The National Committee on the Aging heard business and labor representatives endorse "portable pensions" yesterday to make it easier for industry to hire older workers.

TORONTO, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Consolidated accounts of Rootes Motors, Ltd., British automotive company with operations in many countries, show trading profit before taxes for the year ended July 31 of 3,557,325 ($9,960,510).
The management of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was accused last night by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. of "carelessly or willfully" failing to report fires.

The Copper and Brass Research Association, a large trade group representing copper and brass producers and fabricators, asked the Government yesterday to trim export quotas on copper and coppy-alloy scrap.

The State of New York advanced the permanent financing of its $1,000,000,000 Thruway yesterday, but administrators of the Connecticut Turnpike decided to wait out the bond market before undertaking another public borrowing. Following up its $50,000,000 bond sale of Oct. 13, the New York Thruway Authority yesterday sold $50,000,000 of State-guaranteed bonds due from 1985 to 1995 to a syndicate headed by the First National City Bank of New York and Lehman Brothers.

PANCHO GONZALES has driven one of those automotive hot-rods at 114.8 miles per hour, accelerating to that speed from a standing start in twelve seconds. He also has driven a tennis ball, also from a standing start, at a speed of 113 miles per hour. Except for the similarity in speed quotients and the fact that Pancho supplied the human force behind each of these measured bursts, there is no true connection between them.
Rapid advances in advertising in Brazil were detailed yesterday by Caio Alcantara Machado, director of the Almap International Advertising Service of Sao Paulo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The United States looked with moderate satisfaction today on results of the recent Geneva meeting of adherents to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
Take the word of Coach Dan Lynch, St. Francis College's basketball team may be a surprise this season.
Leading finance companies increased by 1/8 of one percentage point yesterday the rate, or yield, on commercial paper they issue to raise short-term funds.
Standard Brands, Inc., a leading processor and distributor of a diversified group of food products, is planning to expand into the corn processing field.

Year-end tax-selling and replacement continued to dominate the stock market yesterday. As a result, trading was almost without pattern. Although aircrafts were generally strong and motors and rails generally weak, there were exceptions in these groups.

The Senate Internal Security subcommittee ended three days of closed hearings here yesterday on asserted Communist infiltration of the press. Fourteen witnesses were heard during the day, making a total of thirty-five since the hearings began.

Cold weather has caused a sharp drop in the nation's fuel oil stocks. Light fuel oil supplies last week dropped 5,271,000 barrels to 140,103,000, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A year ago, they amounted to 131,432,000 barrels. Heavy fuel oil stocks declined 889,000 barrels to 44,156,000. They were 54,355,000 barrels a year ago.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Clement R. Attlee resigned today the leadership of the British Labor party. He had held it in victory and defeat for twenty years.
Wallace M. Staub has joined Sanders A. Kahn Associates, Inc., and will specialize in appraisals and investments. He was with the appraisal division of William A. White Sons.
Increased or extra dividend distributions were announced yesterday by three New York banks.

With representatives of most of the 101 member colleges and twenty-one affiliated organizations in attendance, the nineteenth annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference opened yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 7 -- The touring Soviet leaders left Burma today after a visit marked by cordiality but not overwhelming mass enthusiasm.
Robert W. Sarnoff was elected president of the National Broadcasting Company yesterday by the board of directors of the huge radio and television network.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Milton Berle stepped back into the television ring today after more than a week of rest and recuperation ordered by his physician. He had collapsed at his home on Nov. 28, the day before his scheduled hour-long color show on the National Broadcasting Company's television network.

Max Factor Co. reported yesterday that sales in the nine-month period ended Sept. 30 rose 29 per cent over the same period last year, while earnings were 34 per cent higher. The result, according to Max Factor Jr., president of the Hollywood cosmetic concern, was the best nine months in the company's history.
A leading chain store official urged small retailers to "study the needs of the community and work to serve it" as a means of countering the inroads of chain stores.
A garden-type apartment house will be erected in Bronxville, N. Y., by Charles Cavaliere, Westchester builder and head of the Charpeg Construction Corporation.

A father and son, both city employes, sat nervously for twenty-two minutes yesterday as Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh read fifty-nine unanswered traffic violations against them. Then they pleaded guilty.
Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts called yesterday for a program of national disaster insurance to be run by a partnership of public and private enterprise.

WHEN Jack Lenor Larsen arrived in New York City just four years ago, he brought along two hand-weaving looms, thirty-nine boxes of yarn, $60, and a lot of ingenuity. How well that combination has paid off was evident in the large collection (his fifth) of new fabrics that Mr. Larsen introduced here yesterday.
Dentrifice advertising that promises miracles in preventing tooth decay and gum diseases was condemned here yesterday at the thirty-first annual Greater New York dental meeting in the Statler Hotel.
Mayor Wagner said last night that he hoped to run for reelection in 1957 for another four-year term.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 7 (AP) -- An explosion at dawn today demolished a new five-story apartment building in midtown Frankfurt, killing twenty-five of its thirty-two occupants. Seven of the dead were children.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7 -- The Provisional Government of Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu was reported today to have prevented the first counter-revolutionary plot against it.
ACCORDING to Bart Allen, rabbit harrier and woodchuck stalker extraordinary, Bugle Anne of song and story was a whispering hound compared with his basset, Singer.
Bravo to you for your editorial of Dec. 4 "Outburst in Georgia" and orchids to the rambling wreckers of Georgia Tech.
EATING fat does not necessarily make you fat. This black-is-white statement may cause the diet-watcher to drop her calorie counter, but it has its basis in a scientific study.

By far the most important public issue raised by the merger of the A. F. L. and the C. I. O. is the role of organized labor in American political life. It is there that the two federations have had the greatest direct impact on public affairs, while the constituent unions have carried the ball for labor on the economic field -- through their dealings with employers and in their organizing efforts.
LIKE a good New Englander, Walter Piston makes no claims for his Sixth Symphony, which had its first New York performance at last night's Boston Symphony concert under Charles Munch at Carnegie Hall.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) higher than on Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7--Victor Mature will be starred in "The Sharkfighters," which Samuel Goldwyn Jr. plans to start filming in March as his second production for United Artists. The first, "Man With a Gun," starring Robert Mitchum, now is going into release.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 7 -- The inspector general of the Brazilian Navy was removed today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he hoped to see this month a plan to relieve overcrowding at the Women's House of Detention at 10 Greenwich Avenue.

ROME, Dec. 7--Pope Pius XII today promoted Msgr. Philip J. Furlong, parish priest of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, to titular bishop of the diocese of Araxa in Syria. He also appointed him auxiliary of Cardinal Spellman of New York for that part of the Cardinal's duties that have to do with his position as vicar for Catholics serving in United States armed forces.

Richard Duckett, captain of the St. John's University basketball team, learned long ago that life with father is fun. The reason is simple. Elmer Duckett, a better than average athlete in his younger days, finds it is easy to share his son's success.
The failure of the latest Geneva conference recalls the comment of George Meany after the Geneva meetings "at the summit."
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- President Eisenhower, in a message read here tonight, said that no man "in our time" had given more to the cause of freedom than Sir Winston Churchill.

A double-header will start the collegiate basketball season at Madison Square Garden tonight. New York University and Georgetown will meet in the opener, with Seton Hall and Western Kentucky paired in the second game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 30:
Record sales and earnings were attained by Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday by R. W. Moore, president.

Sunset Hall, an estate on West Mountain in Ridgefield, Conn., has been purchased by the Eastern Province of the Congregation of the Mission of St. Vincent de Paul. It will become the St. Vincent de Paul Novitiate, run by the Vincentian Fathers.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- J. F. Beck's Myrtle, the 1-2 choice, won the feature at Tropical Park today.
Henry Ford 2d has been writing to critics of the Fund for the Republic that he believes some of its actions "have been dubious in character and inevitably have led to charges of poor judgment."

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Members of the Westchester Committee for Asthma Research are sponsors of the Jose Greco Dance Company performance to be held Tuesday night in the Wood Auditorium here. Mrs. Paul H. Krieger of New Rochelle is chairman of the benefit committee.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 7 -Eight years after coming to power, the Czechoslovak Communist party is bidding strongly to enlist "old school" technical specialists in its drive for increased production.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 7 -- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, aimed sarcasm today at Governor Harriman of New York.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., has concluded preliminary plans to buy a thirty-eight-story building, with entrances at 15 Broad Street and 35 Wall Street, from the Chase Manhattan Bank, according to a joint announcement made yesterday.
The 1955-56 combined campaign for $2,396,000 for two institutions of American Reform Judaism was started last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 7 -- Archbishop Makarios has turned down the latest British offer for settlement of the Cyprus dispute. The reason given was that the offer was "made dependent" on "certain prerequisites that rendered self-determination unattainable.''

Smelter shipments of zinc last month were the largest since last June. Production rose to a record high on a daily average basis, and smelter stocks of the metal dwindled to the lowest level in three and one-half years.
Stockholders of Atlas Plywood Corporation at a special meeting in Boston yesterday voted in favor of a proposal to change the company's debt limit.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP)--Herman Taylor, a leading boxing promoter for a quarter of a century, today was charged with taking over the management of a fighter by "coercion and a threats."

Members of the American Veterans' Committee led by the national chairman, Mickey Levine, marked Pearl Harbor Day yesterday by making a mass blood donation at the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross. The donation will continue today.

ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- A small amphibious plane flew from here at 4:20 P. M. yesterday with two experienced pilots aboard. Nothing more has been seen of the men, but tonight a wing-tip float resembling those of the plane was found drifting on Long Island Sound near Glen Cove, L. I.

Combined net income of the companies owned by the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company and the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., for the first nine months of this year climbed to 113,459,000 ($317,635,200) from 99,327,000 ($278,115,600) in the corresponding period last year.
The nation is confronted with a penny shortage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The illness of the President and the subsequent rise in power of the Assistant to the President, Sherman Adams, have raised some new questions for both the Administration and the opposition in Washington.

Brotherhood Awards for outstanding contributions to the cause of human relations were presented last night by the National Conference of Christians and Jews to three leaders of the financial community.
GONZALES, Tex., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Police officers said today a 15-year-old boy had confessed to the killing of a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Attorney General has signed an order suspending deportation of Jacob Burck, Pulitzer prize-winning cartoonist.
MIAMI, Dec. 7 (AP)--The Foxcatcher Farm's Parlo, chosen the best 3-year-old filly in the country a year ago, was honored again today by being picked as the champion filly and mare of the 1955 season.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 7 -- A move by the Australian Olympic Organizing Committee to sell sole television and newsreel rights for the Olympic Games here next November to one English company has aroused a storm of protests from overseas interests.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A jury tonight found Mrs. Ida Pontery innocent of the fatal shooting of her husband, a physician, but the legal troubles of the Pontery family remained snarled. The 58-year-old mother broke down when she heard the jury's verdict, returned after four hours and forty-six minutes of deliberations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 7 -- Eric H. Louw, Minister of External Affairs, said today that the decision of the General Assembly yesterday to discontinue its investigation of South Africa's racial situation "opens the door for the return of the Union delegation to the 1956 session."
A warning was sounded yesterday against making permanent the various stop-gap measures now being used to ease the nation's teacher shortage.

In place of the annual suggestion to readers that they do their Christmas mailing early, we turn this space over to Edward J. Quigley, Brooklyn Postmaster. His eloquent communication to the Women's News Editor of The New York Times needs no embellishments.
Soviet Russia's rapid advances in science are threatening our world leadership and national security, one of this country's foremost nuclear physicists warned yesterday.
Thirty-seven business, civic and welfare organizations argued before a City Council committee yesterday for repeal of the Lyons Residence Law.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Butcher hogs sank to a new low since 1941 today in a very slow market. Some lightweight butchers sold early at steady quotations but the main market was down 25 cents. Top was $11.75 for 300 head. This was the lowest top quotation since Dec. 31, 1941, when the top was $11.30.

Federal excise taxes are back in the news this week. With a national election eleven months away, the biennial flood of tax-cutting proposals has begun, and one of the first to be advanced is for a reduction in excise taxes at the coming session of Congress.
LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A businesslike gunman, who said he had keys to eleven more banks, imprisoned eight employes of the First National Bank today and escaped with $74,293 in cash.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Administration is considering asking Congress for special legislation to help Egypt finance the High Dam at Aswan on the Nile. Congress would...
A key project in the six-year $94,000,000 off-street parking program of Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley received only qualified approval by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The fourteenth anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor was marked today by a military ceremony at the base of the Marine Corps Memorial here depicting the flag raising on Iwo Jima.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 7 -- Israel warned Lebanon today that her contemplated military alliance with Syria would put her in a position of responsibility for hostile acts against Israel.

As baseball officials returned yesterday from their annual conclaves in the Midwest, all were more or less agreed that not much was accomplished. Neither the major league meetings, which ended in a grand rush on Tuesday in Chicago, nor the minors' convention, which preceded in Columbus, Ohio, cracked any records.
The new labor federation established an Industrial Union Department yesterday without a ripple of controversy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Secretary of Defense has vetoed Navy plans to try for a speed record with the F-8U Crusader, its new supersonic fighter plane.

" Rise Up and Walk," a play first televised nearly four years ago on the Robert Montgomery show, has been purchased by "Goodyear Playhouse." Producers of live drama shows do not usually repeat a script used on another program.
MASSENA, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The State Power Authority approved today a revised plan for the construction of a new transmission line to carry St. Lawrence power to Plattsburgh and the State of Vermont.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 7 -- Three hundred Protestant church leaders rang down the curtain here today on "old and ineffective" methods of missionary endeavor.

Members of the bassoon-playing fraternity owe a vote of thanks to Gordon Jacob, the English composer whose Concerto for Bassoon and Strings had its first New York performance by the Sontag String Sinfonietta at Town Hall last night.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- In the first major speech of the election campaign former Premier Pierre Mendes-France said today the choice was between "a dynamic, constructive majority" and a return to a bogged-down and hopeless predicament.

Mindful of the damage done them by the Toronto Maple Leafs in the seasons immediately last, the New York Rangers event after the forces of King Clancy with savage intent last night. Before a crowd of 10,805 in Madison Square Garden, the Broadway Blues battered their way to a 3-to-1 triumph over the Northern outfit in a rough National Hockey League contest that produced sixteen penalties.
Orson Welles will confine his appearance at the City Center this winter to one play, instead of two as originally planned.

In their latest cold war campaign the Soviet leaders are now resorting to falsifications of history that are an insult to Asian as well as to Western intelligence. Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin not only continue their propaganda attacks on the Western powers as "imperialistic" and "colonial"; they now accuse the West of having started the second World War by grooming Adolf Hitler as their "bloodhound" to war against Soviet Russia and the "East."
An extra lane for week-day morning traffic into Manhattan through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel will be provided, starting Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--A group of polio experts unanimously advised today sticking to the three-shot dosage for Salk vaccine.

A WEEK-END devoted to reading Arthur Koestler's new book of essays, "The Trail of the Dinosaur,"* is like spending three solid days at an intellectual bicycle race. He has one of the liveliest and most probing minds of our time. But he numbs you with the swiftly changing paces of his astoundingly wide-ranging ideas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 728,216 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 51,531 cars, or 7.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 66,439 cars, or 10 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year and 66,190 cars, or 10 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

Although Christmas still is some distance away, it does sometimes seem that a certain share of it already has passed. This sounds like a contradiction in terms, it may even sound a little like Scrooge sounding off a bit earlier than usual, but it is true.
Manhattan College won the two-mile relay as the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union opened New York's indoor track campaign at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.
A young man who has been described by his coach as "half running back and all football player" received the nation's top gridiron award last night at the Downtown Athletic Club.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Selective buying of industrials continued on the stock market today. Oils closed at their best levels. However, Government stocks fell but were said to be recovering at the close.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Harvard Crimson tonight suggested that Centre College be put on the 1957 football schedule to boost "sagging home ticket sales" and quoted the Kentucky school's approval of such a move.

An exciting overtime contest, in which Seton Hall outlasted Western Kentucky, 87 -- 85, helped raise the curtain on the twenty-second consecutive season of college basketball at Madison Square Garden last night. The thriller followed a 74-69 victory for New York University over Georgetown in the opener before 6,523 fans.
QUONSET POINT, R. I., Dec. 8 (UP) -- A Navy man risked his life in Narragansett Bay to rescue a downed airman from the carrier Leyte, it was disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A new group dedicated to seeking more liberal official interpretations of the Antidumping Act made its bow here today.
Leo Durocher seems to be rapidly changing his status from television executive to television artiste.

FOR the thirtieth time at this season of the year, the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, has put on its annual exhibition designed to appeal to the collector of moderate means and -- more important -- the would-be collector.
GREENOCK, Scotland, Friday, Dec. 9 -- The Labor party retained its parliamentary seat at Greenock in yesterday's by-election.
Plans for a $23,000,000 public housing project on the old Luna Park site at Coney Island were submitted yesterday to the City Planning Commission.

Another country has emerged from feudalism and is on its way to emerging from "colonialism" as a result of the abdication by Sultan ben Youseff of Morocco of his theoretically absolute powers and his appointment of a broad representative Government, pledged to create a new order in both internal and external affairs.
A dance will be given tonight in the River Club by the Guild Chapter of the Women's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.
Directors of the Northern Pacific Railway voted yesterday to split the line's stock two for one and raised the quarterly dividend to 90 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Picketing that incidentally affects employes of concerns not involved in a labor dispute does not violate the secondary boycott provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act, the Federal Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The release of 1,017,054 more cubic centimeters of poliomyelitis vaccine was announced today by the Public Health Service.
The spring program of the New York City Light Opera Company is set.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Paced by the brother act of Maurice and Henri Richard, the Montreal Canadiens rallied tonight in a penalty-ridden third period to down the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1. A crowd of 13,800 saw the National Hockey League game at the Forum.
WASSAIC, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A "closed" type of security institution for more difficult mentally retarded patients was advocated today by the director of the Wassaic State School.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Educators who urge Federal aid now expect the Administration to ask Congress next session for a school assistance program costing $500,000,000 annually for three or four years.

CREME de menthe frappe is not the sum and substance of all liquers. The drink that puts the period to a memorable meal can excite nose and palate in a way to make that mint cordial seem sugary and obvious.

The controversial feature film "The Man With the Golden Arm" passed a crucial test yesterday. The Motion Picture Division of the State Education Department (New York State film censors) licensed it for showing here.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Belair Stud's Nashua tonight was named American horse racing champion of 1955.

I have read the communication dated Lima, Peru, Nov. 22, which appeared in The New York Times of Nov. 27, under the heading "Peru Presidency Lacks Aspirants." After saying that former President Prado had banking, newspaper and real estate backing, the article goes on to state that he "* * * is feared by many business men and farmers as the result of the rigid controls and restrictions established during his previous term."
North American Airlines applied yesterday for Federal permission to provide trans-Atlantic air coach service at sharply reduced fares.

The R. Hoe Co., Inc., consent decree entered in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York on Tuesday does not adversely affect the operations of the company and will not bring about any change in domestic sales or manufacturing policies, J. L. Auer, president, said yesterday.

The number of failures among retail apparel and accessory stores in the nation increased 4 per cent in the first eleven months of 1955, compared with the same period a year ago, the credit clearing house of Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday. Liabilities rose by 15 per cent.

Christmas cards for out-of-state delivery and all Christmas packages should be in the mail tomorrow to assure delivery before Christmas, Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer of New York said yesterday. Christmas cards for local delivery should be mailed before Dec. 15.

A syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago and Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $6,750,000 of bonds of the Cook County, Ill., School District 97.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower will get a review of the farm situation tomorrow that is expected to include a proposal for slaughtering hogs to aid pork producers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A new action by the Office of Defense Mobilization in connection with the projected $74,000,000 aluminum plant of Olin-Mathieson Chemical Corporation indicated today the company has chosen a site in the immediate area of Cresap, W. Va.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 -- Army and Air Force units have taken over control of police stations in Mendoza, reports from there said today. The action in the capital of the Andean province of Mendoza was taken shortly after retired Brig. Gen. Hector Raviolo Audicto and several other high Army officers had been arrested and flown to Buenos Aires.
The Rockefeller Foundation has made a grant of $50,000 to the national council of the Boy Scouts of America toward support of a five-year program in conservation education.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The text of the speech of Secretary of State Dulles before the Illinois Manufacturers Association here tonight follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Montgomery Clift, who heretofore has aligned himself with Hollywood only on an individual picture basis, is understood to have entered into a multiple-picture agreement with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Today's new film is "The Crooked Web," at the Palace. Frank Lovejoy, Mari Blanchard and Richard Denning are featured in the melodrama. The Clover production, presented by Columbia, was directed by Nathan Hertz Juran. The story and screen play were by Lou Breslow.
Mayor Wagner yesterday signed five of the six housing reform bills recently passed by the City Council and the Board of Estimate.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Leaders of major dairy cooperatives in the New York milkshed welcomed today the Court of Appeals decision. But they indicated they expected the case would be carried to the Federal Supreme Court.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point lower to 22 points higher yesterday. The strength was most pronounced in new crop months.
Henry Ford 2d was commended yesterday by the heads of the American Legion and the House Committee on Un-American Activities for criticizing the Fund for the Republic.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh is right in rebuking the Waldorf-Astoria management for not having immediately reported three recent fires in the hotel and for failure to cooperate with the department after it had been alerted by anonymous phone calls.

SUMNER, Miss., Dec. 8 (UP) -- A white man charged with the murder of a Negro filling station worker faces a hearing Monday in the same courtroom where two other white men were freed of murder charges in the slaying of a 14-year-old Negro boy.

Bernard F. Gimbel, who has long been devoted to a department store that bears his name, did something extraordinary yesterday. He went to Macy's. Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus. But Mr. Gimbel did not go to Macy's to see Santa Claus, who also works for Gimbels. Quite the contrary.
An optimistic financial note to the tune of $1,900,000 was sounded yesterday by the Transit Authority.
A clinic for reconstructive plastic surgery of the face was dedicated yesterday morning at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street.
Columbia opened its basketball season last night by coasting to an 83-to-67 victory over City College. The game marked Columbia's first visit to the C. C. N. Y. court since 1919.
A Harvard University Professor warned yesterday that patients who look as though they were anesthetized may be "capable of feeling, hearing and remembering things that happen in operating rooms."
The National Association of Manufacturers was told yesterday by its new president, Cola G. Parker, that the United States was "well on the way" toward communism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- For three months Uncle Sam has been coining 6,000,000 pennies a day -- three times as many as usual -- and still the pinch is on.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 9 -- Commuters on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad may soon count on getting to work and returning home on time.
This year's cotton crop is proving to be some 1,000,000 bales larger than last year's despite the 14 per cent cut in acreage ordered by the Government.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- A West German personnel committee was reported today to have vetoed the reactivation of five leading officials of the Defense Ministry. No reasons were given for the decision by the committee, which screens and selects all high-ranking Army officers.
Adlai Stevenson worked hard yesterday to build support here for his candidacy as the Democratic nominee for President.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange recommended today a $13,000,000 increase next year in the State Department's exchange program.
BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Paul Dudley White said today the family physician had an obligation to discuss heart disease intelligently with a victim of an attack.

The firm money policy of the Federal Reserve Board -- which has become increasingly firm almost without interruption since the first of this year -- has succeeded in raising the cost of money, but judging from the most recent indications has not yet greatly dampened the demand for, and expansion of, credit.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Sailing Free, at home in the sloppy footing, defeated eight other juveniles in the feature at Tropical Park today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- The Screen Cartoonists Guild is moving closer to a strike against individual members of the Commercial Film Producers Association.
The national commander of the American Legion asserted yesterday that the United States could not hope to win the "cold war" by negotiating with communism.

James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, suggested last night that the 55,000 striking employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation take a secret poll on proposals to end the eight-week walkout.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The formation of an electoral "common front" by the French Socialist party and the Radical party followers of former Premier Pierre Mendes-France was announced formally today.
