CONCHITA GASTON, young Philippine mezzo-soprano who sang the title role of Bizet's "Carmen" with the New York City Opera in 1950, made her local recital debut last night at Town Hall.
ABOUT 7:30 every workday morning, a young man up on Eighty-second Street solicitously but firmly urges his wife out of bed into her clothes, then to the breakfast table and finally onto the bus.

Futures trading on the New York commodity exchanges continued dull and featureless yesterday. Prices moved irregularly. Changes in rubber, coffee, sugar, potatoes, soybean oil and copper were mixed; wool, cocoa, zinc and hides declined, and cottonseed oil, lead and onions rose.
Shareholders of the Liberty Products Corporation approved yesterday at Farmingdale, L. I., the sale of the company to the Penn-Texas Corporation.
Operating revenues of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 were the highest on record and earnings were the best in four years.
WACO, Tex., Dec. 8 (UP) -- A murder trial that is being televised live, for the first time anywhere, has almost halted the normal flow of business in this central Texas city.

The appointment of Prof. Walter L. Willig as president of the new Staten Island Community College was announced yesterday by the State University of New York and the city's Board of Higher Education. He is now Professor of Civil Engineering and assistant dean in the School of Technology at City College.

Plans for erecting a sixteen-story business and apartment building on a site surrounding the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street were announced yesterday by Maurice Epstein. He recently bought 745 to 749 Madison Avenue and 32 to 38 East Sixty-fifth Street for the purpose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- On the second anniversary of President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace proposal, the United States is about to extend to non-Communist Asia a helping hand toward mastery of nuclear power.
City College paid honor yesterday to four graduates and one former faculty member by naming in memory of each a building on the North Campus.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A $350,000 ski jump was dedicated here today as Italy virtually completed preparations for the 1956 Winter Olympics.
Al J. Hayes was reported last night to be a likely choice to head the Ethical Practices Committee of the new labor federation.

It looks like a week-end with plenty of traveling for those metropolitan skiers who intend starting their seasons now. As of yesterday afternoon, the picture was bleak for areas within a 250-mile radius of Times Square.
SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Magistrate Charles Stevens of Raritan resigned "immediately" after a two-hour hearing today into his conduct before Somerset County Court Judge Joseph Halpern.
MADRID, Dec. 8 -- The Spanish Government indicated today it would refuse to acknowledge any agreements signed between France and the newly formed Moroccan Government in Rabat.

The Chemical Corn Exchange Bank plans to offer 590,425 additional shares to its stockholders on the basis of one new share for each eight held. N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, who made the announcement yesterday, said the price of the stock and time of the offering will be made known later.
MASSENA, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The State Power Authority was told today that there was a good chance that Congress at its next session would authorize it to develop Niagara River hydroelectric power.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The Security Council will meet Saturday morning to take up the General Assembly's proposal for the admission of eighteen new members to the United Nations. A resolution asking the Council to approve the applications of all countries "about which no problem of unification exists" was adopted by the Assembly this morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Luis Batlle Berres, President of Uruguay, insisted today that his country deserved more attention than it was getting in the United States.
THE last few days have shown an improvement in the duck shooting on adjacent marshes and waters, and the reports from Southern coastal areas indicates the season is about at its peak.

The resumption of negotiations between the Netherlands and Indonesia, scheduled to open tomorrow, is another significant easing of tension at a sensitive point. The groundwork for this meeting has been carefully laid and the agenda clearly defined.

New York State's proposed new code for nonresidential construction was attacked by a State Labor Department official yesterday as compromising safety standards and providing a "blueprint for administrative chaos."
Where are all the pennies going?
Infiltration by Russian technicians rather than war with hydrogen bombs appears to be the Soviet plan to draw more countries within its orbit, William Benton said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The underdeveloped nations have been selected by the Soviet Union as "the new targets of their guile," Secretary of State Dulles declared tonight.
A tract of 290 acres in Mount Pleasant in northern Westchester County has been purchased for future development by Millard Shroder, his son, William, and Richard Scheuer.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Butcher hogs sold steady to 25 cents higher today while sows mostly gained 25 cents. It was an active market with a complete early clearance.
Adlai E. Stevenson charged yesterday that two members of the Eisenhower Cabinet had joined other top Republicans in an apparent plan to play the "ugly politics of group conflict and hatred."
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America dedicated its $40,000,000 forty-one-story building today. It will be the company's Midwest home office.

The story of an African safari from a woman's point of view is planned for publication early next year by Houghton Mifflin entitled "The Nylon Safari." The author is Rehna Cloete. Her husband, Stuart Cloete, wrote a book about an African journey that was issued by Houghton Mifflin in September.

For the third time in his eight-year National League career, Roy Campanella won the most valuable player award yesterday The other great local catcher. Yogi Berra of the Yankees, recently gained the American League honors for 1955, also his third such citation.
The united labor movement resolved yesterday to double its membership in the next few years.
The philanthropic fund of the Texas Club of New York will benefit from a cocktail dance to be given by the club this afternoon in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to help Burma establish industrial plants, undertake major irrigation projects and prepare an agricultural development program.
To 6-year-old Freddy, who wants to be a policeman and is not afraid of anything, it was all "a lot of fun."
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named G. Joseph Minetti today to replace Josh Lee, former Democratic Senator from Oklahoma, as a member of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., believes that proposals for expanding trade between the West and the Soviet bloc should be considered in company with proposals for having the Communist countries resume interest service on $218,605,000 of defaulted dollar debt.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Government of Ceylon has produced what it believes is a solution to the problem of Communist-front organizations. It quietly has cut the supply lines from Moscow that have been financing Red groups here.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8 -- Eugene Cook, the Attorney General of Georgia, stated his case against public school integration before an overflow audience at the Yale Law School tonight.
Rhode Island men who are fathers and eligible for the draft are being given a sixty-day induction postponement that may turn out to be permanent.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Alex Louis Greenberg, wealthy one-time financial adviser to the old Capone crime syndicate, was assassinated tonight as he and his wife left a South Side restaurant.

The State Superintendent of Insurance described yesterday his plan for establishment of an unsatisfied judgment fund as a practical means of providing 100 per cent coverage against uninsured automobiles.
J. Carlisle MacDonald will retire on Jan. i as assistant to the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, in charge of public relations, it was announced yesterday.

The Army has purchased from the Radio Corporation of America a $4,000,000 electronic data-processing system, it was announced yesterday. The system, known as Bizmac, is said to be the largest and most comprehensive "giant brain" yet made.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Unless President Eisenhower announces he will run by the end of next month, Senator William F. Knowland of California intends to enter the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

THE Metropolitan Opera put on a stunning "Tosca" last night. The impedimenta of routine were cast aside, and the work was restudied under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos as though it were a new opera.

A letter from a Mississippian published in your columns on Dec. 1 indicates that Mississippians will never agree to integration in the public schools, no matter what becomes of the system of public education.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 8 -- Nationalist China remained adamant tonight against Outer Mongolia's admission into the United Nations. Top Foreign Ministry officials here said their Government still intended to use the veto in the Security Council, if necessary, to keep Outer Mongolia out of the world organization. Nationalist China has the power to cast a veto as a permanent member of the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington today authorized a credit of $23,033,000 to subsidiaries of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., in Mexico.
JAIPUR, India, Dec. 8 -- The Khrushchev-Bulganin traveling troupe clapped on floppy colored turbans today and made a smash one-night stand in the land of the warrior princes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Prices for wheat rose in early trading today, but there was enough profit taking by longs to halt the three-day advance and to cause moderate recessions. The decline ran into better support from commission houses, which steadied the market.
Mayor Wagner ordered an inquiry yesterday into the qualifications of relatives of Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross who are on the public payroll.
LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Paratyphoid cases in this southeastern Pennsylvania area rose to at least seventy-eight today, an increase of twenty-four in the last twenty-four hours.

THIS has been a good year in the world of books. More good books were published than usual and far more books of all kinds were sold than usual. Fiction may still be selling less well than nonfiction, but the total volume of business done by publishers and booksellers was much more than last year's, which was excellent, and was the best since the peak of the war years.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8 -- One of New Jersey's foremost planning executives predicted today a trend toward tying in new school construction with housing developments.

Events today: Gounod's "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Puccini's "Tosca." Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell, conductor, Edmund Kurtz, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall. 2:30 P. M.; Excerpts from Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus," Choir of Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, 5:30 P. M., and Handel's "Messiah," Lenox and Trinity School Glee Clubs, 139 West Ninety-first Street, 8:15 P.M.

The Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America admitted Notre Dame, Iona and Adelphi College to membership yesterday. The election of the three schools to the college track and field organization by a mail vote was announced in a meeitng at the Yale Club.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Princeton University's Triangle Club opened tonight its sixty-fourth annual production, "Spree de Corps," in McCarter Theatre

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 8 -- An award of $1,245,312 was announced today for a fifty-five-acre estate on the Palisades condemned by the New Jersey Highway Authority to make way for the Palisades Interstate Parkway.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Cigars, claret and congratulations flowed in for Jean Sibelius, the Finnish composer, on his ninetieth birthday today.
At a reception for the press in Jersey City yesterday, the Brooklyn Dodgers posted the schedule of National League games the Brooks will play there next year.

One hundred and twenty-five new passenger cars are now in service on the Long Island Rail Road, the line reported yesterday. The cars are eighty feet long, with fluorescent lighting, foam-cushion seats, rubber tile floors and year-round air-conditioning.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The British Government is trying to convince those tending to favor the unification of Germany in neutrality that such action would mean the abandonment of Europe by the United States.

A NEW work turned up at the Philharmonic - Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall. It was Bernard Wagenaar's "Five Tableaux" for 'Cello and Orchestra, and Edmund Kurtz played this first American performance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, announced new regulations today stepping oil and gas leasing in areas endangering "rare" wildlife species such as whooping cranes, trumpeter swans and remnant big-game herds.
PROVIDENCE, R, I., Dec. 8 Brown University announced today plans for a $3,000,000 residential quadrangle, to be completed in February, 1957.
The immediate removal of John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State was demanded yesterday by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. In a letter to President Eisenhower, the Harlem Democrat said:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Administration will probably ask Congress to continue foreign aid at its present annual level of $2,700,000,000, officials said today.
A blueprint to guide proposed metropolitan area study commissions was offered yesterday by Dr. Charlton Chute, assistant director of the Institute of Public Administration.

Arthur Miller, Pulitzer Prize playwright, struck back yesterday at the eleven members of the New York City Youth Board who had rejected him as script writer for a proposed motion picture based on the board's work with street gangs.

Maryland and Oklahoma are not any prouder of their unbeaten football teams than Rensselaer Poly is of its unofficial volleyball squad, which swept through ten matches without a defeat to capture the recent Schenectady Intercollegiate Tournament.

JONESBORO, Ark., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bill Penix, an attorney here, charged today that opponents of racial integration had created a "reign of terror" at Hoxie, and that peace had been restored only under the protection of the Federal court.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, headed by Jerome Dansker, has purchased the apartment house at 1419 Shakespeare Avenue in the Bronx. The building has seventy-one apartments that bring an annual gross rental of $45,800.
Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, said last night that the Soviet Union's leaders had not yet shown that they were willing to create the conditions necessary for a secure peace.
THURMONT, Md., Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower conferred for five and one-half hours with his top advisers at near-by Camp David today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- A large majority of the forty-eight state farm bureaus favor a system of flexible price supports on commodities similar to those of the Eisenhower program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Egypt told the United Nations today that her purchases of arms from Czechoslovakia were for self-defense and in the interests of peace and stability in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A full-scale investigation was demanded today of action within the Commerce Department that led to suspension last year of speculative trading curbs on some food oils.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- After sixty-eight years of regulating public transportation, the Inter-state Commerce Commission has acquired its own private conveyance -- a rented Cadillac.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Three candidates have been nominated for leadership of the Labor party, left vacant by the resignation yesterday of former Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee.
Buildings soon to be razed on Fifth Avenue to make way for new ones are causing two well-known stores in the area to move.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in a final report of the year, today estimated this year's Government - controlled cotton crop at 14,663,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight.

A union proposal to end delays caused by "short gangs" is being considered by representatives of dock labor employers. The proposal, it was reported, entails prior exchange of information between employers and the union concerning work to be done and gangs available to do it.
LYTTELTON, N. Z., Dec. 8 -- New Zealanders by the hundreds have been turning out to give the U. S. S. Glacier anything but an Antarctic reception.

Social workers wondered yesterday how their program could keep pace with the rush to the suburban areas around the country's great metropolitan centers. The National Social Welfare Assembly, holding its tenth anniversary meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt, was told the great cities were ringed by 'solidly white, solidly middleclass" communities of highly specialized types.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson's comeback will reach the "all-or-nothing" stage tomorrow night when the former welterweight and middleweight champion faces Bobo Olson, the world middleweight king, in a fiften-round title match at the Chicago Stadium.

Labor's new federation called on Congress today to bring to United States private shipyards the shipbuilding being done in foreign yards for American shipowners and for the Government in its offshore procurement program.

The Federal Reserve stepped in and helped ease the squeeze on lendable funds in the commercial banking system in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The "right - to - work" laws of eighteen states that Adlai E. Stevenson attacked before the A. F. L.-C. I. O. convention today render illegal in those states the management-employe contracts which make union membership requisite to continuation of employment.

It would be interesting to me, and I think to many other women, to learn whether stores that require potential customers to "park" their shopping bags with the cashier are within their legal rights in so doing.

The main thesis of Edwin White's letter in your Dec. 1 issue seems to be that desegregation produces ipso facto racial mergers, resulting in intermarriages and a racially mixed population. This may or may not be true, but it would have been a stronger argument had Mr. White indicated evidence to show that either major Southern race is "pure."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Federal Court of Appeals here upheld today payments to dairy cooperatives in the New York milk marketing area for services they performed for dairy farmers.

The National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Pipe Dream" on the night of Jan. 10 at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Nathan Straus and Miss Margaret Halsey are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Department instructed security review officers today to hold up performance information about new weapons and aircraft until there is reasonable certainty that national security will not be jeopardized.
Frank Costello will spend the winter in and around New York -- by court order.
Two pedestrians were struck by buses yesterday afternoon in separate accidents at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street.
John G. (Steve) Broady was convicted last night on sixteen counts relating to a wiretapping conspiracy here. Sentencing was set for Jan. 13.

THE election on Wednesday of Robert W. Sarnoff to the presidency of the National Broadcasting Company was not unexpected. It came as the climax to a corporate drama that long has held the attention of the television world.

Selection of a name for a product at times has meant a costly headache, with lawyers and trademark and copyright experts joining with the advertising and marketing men to select one that is unique, describes the product and does a reminder-selling job of its own.

Directors of M. Lowenstein Sons. Inc., yesterday increased the dividend to 37 1/2 cents from 30 cents, placing the common stock on an annual basis of $1.50 a share. The dividend is payable on Dec. 29. In addition the textile producer voted to distribute a stock dividend of 2 per cent payable to common stockholders on Jan. 3.
Following is the text of the address made to the A. F. L.-C. I. O. convention yesterday by Adlai E. Stevenson:
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The supporters of Pierre Mendes-France, who have taken the offensive in the election campaign, issued reports today on two subjects that can arouse much emotion in France.
The world's top amateur tennis player takes on the king of the professionals tonight in Madison Square Garden.

EVEN when Joe Louis was in his prime, the experts were agreed that the finest fighter and most exquisite craftsman in the ring was Sugar Ray Robinson. He had blinding speed of foot, hand and brain. He could box like a dream and punch like a demon. He was the king of the fisticuffing trade.
IN New York, even on these bitingly crisp winter evenings, or in crimson-flooded twilight, you do not look toward heaven for the dwelling place of the Greek and Roman gods.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System experienced a slight easing in lendable funds in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
HONOLULU, Dec. 8 (UP) -- A twin-engined Navy patrol bomber crashed into the ocean last night, and the Navy said today seven members of the ten-man crew were missing.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 -- New York's noise-saving ban on jet aircraft at fields in its metropolitan area brought on much joshing of the sole American passenger on a special demonstration flight of the new British Comet III this afternoon.

Hugh (Duffy) Daugherty of Michigan State won the 1955 coach-of-the-year award yesterday by the biggest margin in the twenty-one-year history of the poll conducted by The World-Telegram and Sun and other Scripps-Howard newspapers.

Fifty-two members of the United Nations General Assembly voted yesterday to admit eighteen new members: five Communist, thirteen non-Communist. This is the so-called "package deal." The resolution, which will go to the Security Council, is of no legal force whatsoever.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its offer of $1,500,000,000 of ninety-nine-day tax anticipation Treasury bills were sold at the high rate of 2.465 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A vice president of the General Motors Corporation, pictured in various testimony as bullying its dealers to meet sales quotas, asserted today that some of the complaining dealers were unable to keep up with the competitive parade.
Hanukkah -- the eight-day Festival of Lights -- will be ushered in tonight by Jewish people here and over the world.
Americans will buy some $3,200,000,000 worth of room and central year-round air conditionhag units next year, Cloud Wampler predicted yesterday.

Both "blue chips" and low-price issues were active and higher in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The close saw good gains. Virtually every group shared in the advance, but aircrafts were strongest.

" The Gandhi Reader," a biographical work edited by Homer A. Jack, has been scheduled for Jan. 30 publication by Indians University Press. Subtitled "A Source Book of His Life and Writings," the volume includes extensive material from Indian publications, hitherto unavailable in this country.
Russ Meyer, the temperamental right-handed pitcher who started his major league career with the Chicago Cubs nine years ago, has been returned to that club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The United States income tax system is full of special provisions, undermining the idea that the system is based on ability to pay, witnesses told Congress today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The National Stevenson for President Committee announced here today the formation of the first state group of that organization in Minnesota.

For more than twenty years Outer Mongolia has been controlled completely by the secret police of the Soviet Union. It is less independent than any one of our forty-eight states. It joined in the Communist attack on China in 1947 and in the Korean war against the forces of the U. N.

Two new entries were made in baseball's indispensable record book during the past week. Most valuable player awards for the season past went to Yogi Berra in the American League and Roy Campanella in the National. This year's citations by the committee of the Baseball Writers Association are marked by coincidences.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The United States and Canada today announced agreement on Lake Ontario levels. Thus the way was cleared for final excavation of a major portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
Michael J. Quill has decided his Transport Workers Union belongs in the united labor movement after all.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Defense Department today pegged the February draft call at 6,000 men. This is the lowest level since the start of the Korean War.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- Senator Estes Kefauver today postponed until "about Jan. 15" an announcement of his Presidential campaign intentions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Wilson Co., third largest domestic packer, today declared its first dividend on the common stock since 1952. The dividend, 50 cents a share, will be distributed next year in four payments of 12 1/2 cents a share each.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 9 -- After a Government crisis that lasted ten days, Premier Adnan Menderes formed a new Turkish Cabinet today.
George Meany, president of the united labor federation, accused the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday of attempting to silence the labor vote.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The Security Council faces a frustrating procedural snarl when it meets tomorrow on the admission of new members.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today the Soviet Union could relieve world tension "instantly" by accepting President Eisenhower's plan for control against surprise attack.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Dec. 9 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin expressed the hope today that his visit to Kashmir would help renew ancient contacts between the Soviet Union and this remote northern Himalayan state.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Britain's Monopolies Commission recommended today the abolition of a number of practices in the tire industry that it said were contrary to the public interest.
Residents of Canarsie, Brooklyn, will give blood to the Red Cross in Holy Family School, Flatlands Avenue and East Ninety-eighth Street, today from noon to 6 P. M.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Tears streaming down his face, Sugar Ray Robinson, middleweight king again, was led into his dressing room after his smashing knockout of Bobo Olson tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- One of the trade unions involved in a twenty-nine-day strike that has paralyzed airports in the Paris region decided tonight to return to work.

Your coverage of the recent White House Conference on Education provided another example of complete and interpretive reporting which your readers have come to expect. Those of us whose professional lives are daily dedicated to the issues that confronted the Washington conference are particularly appreciative of the objective and balanced presentation.

YOUNG Joan of Arc said to the Dauphin that she herself would last a year and scarcely more in the fulfillment of her mission on earth. And that was how the event turned out. But her story has already stirred the hearts and minds of men for more than five centuries, inspiring new plays and novels and historical interpretations in every modern decade, as it will, one cannot but believe, forever.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. met yesterday with a group of Hilton Hotel Corporation executives in his office at the Municipal Building.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 9-- Members of the Iowa Hospital Association voted today to appeal a recent District Court ruling on charges to hospital patients.
President Luis Batlle Berres of Uruguay defended here yesterday the ideals of democracy against governments of "strong men" and the "evil seed" of communism.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- East Germany announced today its border police had taken over from Soviet troops the guarding of the country's frontiers.

An accident that inspired a brainy Scot an age ago to develop a method of making paper boxes by machinery will pay handsome -- although unforeseen -- dividends this year. They will come from record annual sales of nearly $1,000,000,000 by the folding paper box and carton industry. Volume last year was about $800,000,000.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Chilean Cabinet resigned today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The daring Spanish driver, the Marquis de Portago, narrowly escaped serious accident today as he outsped two of America's best sports car pilots, Phil Hill and Sherwood Johnston, to win the 105-mile Governor's Cup race.

Ray Robinson, whose correct name is Walker Smith, often has been proclaimed the best fighter "pound for pound" in modern ring history. At the peak of his career, from 1945 to 1951, Sugar Ray exhibited, in the finest degree, the qualities of aggressiveness and of defensive finesse that are such necessary parts of pugilism.
The National Broadcasting Company plans to extend color television to a number of other shows this winter and next spring, Robert W. Sarnoff, president of the network, announced yesterday.

The nation produced more steel last month than in any other November. And its output of 106,534,168 tons for the first eleven months this year exceeded the tonnage for any full year except 1953, when production was 111,609,719 tons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Top executives of the General Motors Corporation, including its president. Harlow H. Curtice, ended tonight a week of testimony before the Senate Antitrust subcommittee.
Net income of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for the six months ended Oct. 31 increased to $10,337,103 from $9,318,030 earned in the corresponding period last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A revised hull design will make the Navy's new atomic submarine faster than its two predecessors and greatly increase the capabilities of three conventional submarines.
The National Social Welfare Assembly, which is celebrating its tenth year, considered yesterday how far to go in speaking out on social issues.

WACO, Tex., Dec. 9 (UP) -- A jury wound up the nation's first televised murder trial tonight by finding Harry L. Washburn guilty of killing his former mother-in-law by a bomb attached to the starter of her car. He was sentenced to life in prison.
Canada's gross national product -- the total value of all goods and services -- is expected to exceed $26,000,000,000 this year, the greatest in the country's history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Ezra Taft Benson, backed by President Eisenhower and the Cabinet, rejected today a proposal for killing female hogs to aid pork producers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 -- J. Carroll Loughlin, Commissioner of Revenue and Finance for Long Beach Township, was elected president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards at the thirty-ninth annual convention today. He succeeds Arthur D. Van Winkle of Rutherford.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 -- Mexico in 1956 will be in a position to furnish her entire needs for petroleum and petroleum products, according to Antonio J. Bermudez, director of Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), the nationalized oil producer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences will be asked sometime after Jan. 1 if it would care to be the custodian of a proposed new code of ethics for the television industry. This would be the final step in the time-table under which the committee drafting the new code is working.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A proposal to make Iowa an "overlapping state" in regional football television was endorsed today by the Big Ten, which declared that more "flexibility" was needed in the TV program of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- One of the week's 833 patents, covering a prosaic hatbox, aroused the immediate interest of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. For the inventor is Harry Lev, the Chicago cap manufacturer who enlivened recent hearings by accounts of his many gifts of smoked sturgeon to procurement officers, and his own fondness for turtle steak.
PARIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- French officials announced today that a Polish military attache had been arrested as a spy in the French sector of West Berlin three days ago.
Stocks pushed to a new historic high yesterday, sagged a little and then turned firm near the close.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- West Germany declared today it would break off diplomatic relations with any country that recognized East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- House investigators said today they had been unable to substantiate charges that Navy Reserve pilots at Dallas, Tex., had been forced to use an unsafe plane.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 -- Juan D. Peron expects to come to Mexico, perhaps to live, if his visa application is granted and if he finds the political and social climate agreeable.

A performance new to this country of Bach's "Art of the Fugue" was reviewed in this newspaper recently. In the review the writer mentions that any new arrangement of this incomplete masterpiece always unsettles critics In the past they have disagreed on both the arrangement and the instruments to be used, for Bach left these decisions to those who played his music after his death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved present and past "per diem" rates that one railroad collects from another while its freight cars are off its own lines. The charge in $2.40 a day, which some railroads considered too high.
It was sixteen days before Christmas yesterday morning and not a creature was stirring at Gimbels department store. Then, like a sudden explosion, 1,100 youngsters arrived for a shopping spree.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The race for the so-called ultimate weapon, the intercontinental ballistic, or rocket-like, missile, has been markedly accelerated. This is partly because the Soviet Union is reported to have developed a ballistic missile of 600-to-800-mile range.
GREENOCK, Scotland, Dec. 9 -- American big business is blending successfully into the life of this Clydeside workshop.

Two recent and seemingly unconnected events have prompted me to write this letter. First, the New York Metropolitan Opera is considering a new theatre to be located on Manhattan's West Side; second, building lots are ready for construction on Forty-second Street near the United Nations Plaza.
The most important urgency faced by American churches is providing a ministry for rapidly shifting and new populations, according to the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 8 -- Lancashire is completing another chapter in the modern world's longest industrial history. It has been a rather unpleasant chapter, but it seems to be having a happy ending.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Frank Holeman, Washington correspondent for The New York Daily News, was elected president of the National Press Club in annual elections today. He was unopposed.

A convicted second-string Communist leader now serving a three-year prison sentence moved yesterday in Federal Court to prevent the impounding of his old-age benefit checks by John J. Bennett, Federal Director of the Bureau of Prisons.

THE holidays can now be considered officially here, for last night at the City Center, the New York City Ballet gave its first presentation this season of the full-length "Nutcracker." This ballet -- of, by and for children -- is to occupy the company's attentions for all but six of its performances between now and the end of its engagement on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today the appointment of Louis H. Mayo, assistant dean of the George Washington University Law School, as executive secretary of a staff that will study radio and television network operations.

WHEN snow blankets the rocky peaks of the Dolomites and the roads to Turin are glazed with ice, northern Italian housewives engage in the winter chore of making sausages. These are not the hard, ready-to-eat salami and pepperoni. Nor are they much like the country-style fresh pork sausage of this country.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The French- West German dispute over West Germany's armament program was said by officials to have been settled today.
Matthew J. Connelly, former appointment secretary to former President Harry S. Truman, surrendered here yesterday in connection with a tax conspiracy indictment.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Harriman will ask the 1956 Legislature to take the first step toward lowering the voting age from 21 to 18. He said today he would urge the Republican-controlled Legislature to approve a constitutional amendment.
Two teen-age boys were arrested last night as suspects in the killing of Jacob Bernstein three weeks ago in a hold-up of his drug store at 426 Grand Street, on the lower East Side.
A union leader's offer to present the strikers' case before the company's directors was rejected yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric Company.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France continued tonight his purge of the Radical party ranks. Seven prominent members accused of failure to follow party directives were dropped.

The great labor merger is now an accomplished fact. The convention, in which the biggest labor organization in the world's history was born, is over -- a greater success than even the optimists predicted. The few maverick leaders who had threatened to kick over the traces have fallen into step.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Atlantic Coast Conference shelved adoption of grants-in-aid for prospective athletes today. The Conference moved for discussion of the matter on a national basis at next month's meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Reductions in acreage allotments and price supports for the 1956 rice crop are virtual certainties, Department of Agriculture spokesmen said today.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9 -- Criticism of Eugene Cook, Attorney General of Georgia, featured tonight's panel meeting on problems of desegregation.

Reservations may still be made for children between the ages of 4 and 8 to participate in the annual holiday carnival of the Museum of Modern Art, starting Tuesday and continuing through Jan. 15. They must be made in advance by telephone only (CIrcle 5-8900) for the sessions held at 10 or 11 A. M. or 2, 3 and 4 P. M.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Ray Robinson is back on top of the head. Sugar Ray of Harlem, once the welterweight and middleweight champion of the world, again became the middleweight ruler of pugilism tonight. He returned to that eminence by scoring a two-round knockout over Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 9 (UP) -- Stu Holcomb became North-western's athletic director today. He said it would take "three or four years of hard work" to build up the Wildcat athletic program.
Eight apartment houses on Morningside Avenue have been purchased by B. L. Wyckoff Associates, operators and investors. They were sold by the First Operating Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Army announced today that it would be able to maintain nineteen combat divisions, one more than planned, in the fiscal year 1957, which begins next July 1.
All funds handled by the Department of Correction, including the commissary funds of the city prisons, are being audited by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney.
ROME, Dec. 9 -- The Liberal party, part of the Government coalition, split in two at the start in Rome today of its seventh national congress.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -- The provisional Government of Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu today froze the "ill-gotten" fortunes of 239 former officials and supporters of the deposed Peron regime.
Mankind's only alternative to the United Nations is utter annihilation, Prof. Ahmed S. Bokhari, said yesterday. He is under secretary for the world organization's Department of Public Information.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 9 -- The American Machine and Foundry Company, has taken options on more than 2,000 acres near Huntsville, Ala. It is studying the construction there of an underground industrial manufacturing plant, Charles Bartlett, the Washington correspondent of The Chattanooga Times reported today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Dec. 9 -- The annual spring team matches for the Amorita Cup between International Class sloops of Long Island Sound and Bermuda will begin off Hamilton on April 23. The date was announced at tonight's award dinner of the class in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- A softly worded appeal to South Africa was quietly dropped into the record today with the endorsement of forty-three nations that hoped some good might come of it.
Senator William F. Knowland, in a speech and a press conference here yesterday, criticized by inference parts of President Eisenhower's foreign and domestic policies.

The Board of Education has filed plans with the Department of Housing and Building for a four-story elementary school at 116 West Eleventh Street. The site, on the south side of the street between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, now is occupied by the old Rhinelander Gardens apartments.

In an address delivered after consultation with President Eisenhower and the National Security Council Secretary Dulles has outlined more fully than before the policies which this nation proposes to pursue after the stalemate of Geneva. In doing so, he has also provided answers to both Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin, now touring in Asia as merchants of hate and strife.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers this week will produce 181,479 cars, the second highest weekly automobile production mark in the industry's history, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today.
A new adaptation of "Six Characters in Search of an Author," by Tyrone Guthrie and Michael Wager, will be presented tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Phoenix Theatre.
MIAMI, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A gusty wind hampered the favorites today as five outsiders tied for the lead in the first round of the Miami open golf tournament with three-under-par 67's.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Miami High came from behind two tonight with some neat footwork by Halfbacks Bill Butler and Jack Westbrook to beat New Britain, Conn., High, 20 -- 12, before 15,210 fans in the Orange-Bowl.
The 22,000-ton liner Ivernia, latest addition to the Cunard Line's North Atlantic luxury fleet, will pay her first visit to the Port of New York today.

ABOARD, U. S. S. GLACIER, Saturday, Dec. 10 -- The Glacier sailed today for Antarctica from Lyttelton, N. Z., in the United States' greatest effort to learn the secrets of that continent's 6,000,000 square miles of ice and rock.

The current acrimonious political debates over farm policy seem to be based chiefly on mechanical variations of the commodity price support system. Given the political necessity of subsidizing farm income in some manner, a more fundamental change in approach could provide a less expensive and less inefficient alternative policy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission upheld today the right of railroads to give cut-rate transportation to service men.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- White House aides are trying to cut an hour a day from President Eisenhower's work schedule.

A special stockholders' meeting has been scheduled by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for Dec. 21. Stockholders will be asked to approve a $10,000,000 loan by a group of insurance companies. Part of the collateral to be pledged for the loan is an additional issue of $7,500,000 first and refunding 4 per cent Series A mortgage bonds due July 1, 2007.

The British Government is considering a revision in its tax structure under which it would place greater emphasis on indirect taxes as a source of revenue than at present. This is the construction that has been placed by many persons on recent remarks by Great Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler.

IN his "Paintings of Two Worlds," at Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue, James N. Rosenberg expresses anxiety for the future by contrasting the beauty and amenities of Adirondack landscape with visions of the world and of humanity after the atom bomb has done its worst.

ALTHOUGH the archery licenses issued for deer hunting show an increase in many Eastern states, the success ratio has decreased, which is not a reflection on the ability of the archers but a result of poor hunting conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today that R. Karl Honaman was resigning as Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary for public affairs. He has been a target of critics of the Pentagon's public information policies.

GOOD furniture design, an intangible associated in the public's mind with high prices, is the subject of the fourth annual Christmas exhibit of Pratt Institute. This year students at the Brooklyn school combed retail stores for examples of furniture under $25 that still met their standards of excellence.
The fate that usually befalls the amateur tennis champion on its bow as a professional at Madison Square Garden overtook Tony Trabert last night as victory beckoned.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Free selling of wheat met advances in prices on the Board of Trade today. The December future showed relative weakness, as there was considerable switching to March credited to longs.

Celebration of the eight-day Festival of Lights -- commemorating the rededication of the Temple at Jerusalem more than 2,000 years ago and the victory of the Maccabees over the Syrians -- was begun at sundown yesterday by the Jewish people.

Power cruising predicted log racing was wrapped up for 1955 last night at a meeting of the American Power Boat Association's cruiser racing commission and cruiser technical committee. The meeting was held at the Hotel Shelton.

VOLKEL AIR BASE, The Netherlands, Dec. 9 -- The first group of four new jet-powered fighter-bombers equipped to deliver small, atomic bombs was turned over to the Netherlands by the United States today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today the Senate Commerce hearings, soon after Congress reconvenes, on the question of construction and operating subsidies for ore-carrying vessels.

Employer acceptance of a "clarification" of hiring rules appears to have solved a principal complaint of the International Longshoremen's Association. The union had charged that employers were not giving sufficient prior notice of extra gangs required.
Federal aid to education was attacked and defended here yesterday.

Today's new film is "The Prisoner," a British-made drama starring Alec Guinness and Jack Hawkins, at the Plaza Theatre. The screen play was adapted by Bridget Boland from her play. Vivian A. Cox and Sydney Box produced and Peter Glenville directed.
GENEVA, N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- American Stores, Inc., of Philadelphia, the nation's fourth largest supermarket chain, has agreed to buy the Market Basin chain in a $3,600,000 transaction.
A 16-year-old boy accused of setting off a small home-made bomb in a Brooklyn school was arraigned yesterday on a charge that could send him to prison for twenty years.

A farm-estate in Carmel, in Putnam County, has been sold by B. Altman Co. of New York to realty developers. The property, known as Hazen Hill, was used until about a year ago by employes of the department store for a rest home.
WASSAIC, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Continued investigation of asserted mistreatment at Wassaic State School was pledged here today. But its form became a matter of doubt after an exchange between lawyers.

Directors of the Midvale Company have called a special stockholder meeting for Dec. 21 to vote on the sale of major physical and operating assets of the company to the Heppenstall Company, Pittsburgh.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- A "no work" policy against West Coast shipping was called off today by the Marine Firemen's Union.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Interest in industrial shares broadened further today. Price changes were accentuated by a lack of offerings. Only South African gold mining stocks remained dull.

George Meany went into industry's house yesterday with all of labor's ancient battle cries left behind. But his bitter post-luncheon exchange of slogans with the chief spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers wiped out the conciliatory effect of the union head's plea for better understanding.
THE National Broadcasting Company's version of 'Whiteoaks" yesterday afternoon was solid, if lukewarm, hour-long dramatic fare for viewers of the "Matinee Theatre."

Six artists, writers and composers have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the society announced yesterday. They are Marianne Moore, poet; Maxwell Anderson. playwright; Lewis Mumford, author; Walter Piston, composer, and Andrew Wyeth and Edward Hopper, painters.
Dental X-ray machines were described yesterday as a major source of radiation and a hazard far surpassing the publicly reported hazard of radioactive fall-out from bomb tests in this country.
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 -- What started out as a huge student demonstration against recent bus and street car fare increases erupted into violence in Montreal tonight.

THE why's and wherefore's of grade-schoolers' fluctuating friendships provide a never-ceasing source of wonder to many parents, and a recurrent source of exasperation to some others. Parents who feel that their children seem always to single out the most unlikely possible classmates as pals may find some comfort in a psychiatrist's explanation of this phenomenon.

More than eight months ago former Ambassador to the Soviet Union George F. Kennan expressed serious concern over the State Department's handling of the case of Archbishop Boris of the Russian Orthodox Church. After permitting the Archbishop to come to the United States on a sixty-day visitor's visa the department refused to extend his stay.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Any new, low-cost air coach trans-Atlantic service would require long and careful study, officials of the International Air Transport Association, said today.
Fifty champion lambs, New York State's first winners of top honors at the nation's biggest livestock show, went to slaughter in Brooklyn yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Lloyd Nolan signed today for his third movie since ending his long stage engagement as Captain Queeg in "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The Republican leader of the Senate today ordered a study of providing hospital and medical insurance for state and municipal employes.

Bavasi, irked at a story quoting Jack Dunn, assistant general manager of the Orioles, that Baltimore is "definitely interested" in Jackie Robinson "if Robinson is available," dismissed the affair with this comment:

Rubber prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The drop was influenced by lower prices in London and Singapore. Prices closed near the lows of the day here after fluctuating sharply.

In bringing its nineteenth annual convention to a harmonious close yesterday, the Eastern College Athletic Conference unanimously endorsed the present national - regional control plan for the televising of football games.
December cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 points yesterday, but other months declined 12 to 44 points (60 cents to $2.20 a bale).

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 9 -- Lights gleaming on eight-branched candlesticks signalized tonight the beginning of the Feast of Hanukkah. In many ways a martial aspect seemed to have gained at least a part of the emphasis usually reserved for this holiday's message of spiritual dedication.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (UP) -- W. D. Andrews' Optimum, who has finished either first or second in his last ten starts, notched his third straight victory today in the feature at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush announced his retirement from the Carnegie Institution of Washington today with an eloquent philosophical plea for "fundamental research" to help a world in trouble.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9 -- J. Dinsmore Tew 2d, a member of a prominent New York family, was killed here today after the car he had halted on a railroad track was crushed by a speeding train. He was 49 years old.
GOUNOD'S "Faust," which received its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last night, remains a colorful spectacle in its restaged version with sets and costumes by Rolf Gerard.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The Republican leader of the Senate today ordered a study of providing hospital and medical insurance for state and municipal employes.

Bavasi, irked at a story quoting Jack Dunn, assistant general manager of the Orioles, that Baltimore is "definitely interested" in Jackie Robinson "if Robinson is available," dismissed the affair with this comment:

Rubber prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The drop was influenced by lower prices in London and Singapore. Prices closed near the lows of the day here after fluctuating sharply.

In bringing its nineteenth annual convention to a harmonious close yesterday, the Eastern College Athletic Conference unanimously endorsed the present national - regional control plan for the televising of football games.
December cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 points yesterday, but other months declined 12 to 44 points (60 cents to $2.20 a bale).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 111.1 per cent of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A slight decrease in the index for processed foods balanced the increase in the average prices for farm products and all commodities other than farm and foods.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- November retail sales totaled $15,600,000,000, the Commerce Department reported today. This is 1 per cent below October but 8 per cent above the level of November, 1954.

While new construction, for both permanent residents and seasonal guests, has been tremendous, this area along the Gulf of Mexico, labeled the Suncoast, is still green, well-watered (without floods), sunny and warm.

Buckley's proposal that the alumni of a college should control its teaching staff.

FOR years there has been a tendency among one school of meteorologists to laugh at the old weather lore of country folk. But after what has happened here in the Northeast the past few years some people have their doubts that meteorology is an exact science.

LONDON, Dec. 10--Although crisis has become the normal state of the British Labor party nothing in the last four years of discord equals the present situation. Clement Attlee, who ruleed the party for twenty years, resigned as leader this week.
