Snyder, the President's personal physician; Maj. Gen Leonard D. Heaton, commanding officer, Walter Reed Army Hospital; Col. Thomas W. Mattingly, chief of cardiology, Walter Reed Hospital, and James C. Hagerty, press secretary to the President.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10--The Nobel awards in science and literature were presented today to three Americans, a Swede and, for the first time, an Icelander, a writer and a teller of ancient sagas.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 10--Jim Brown from Manhasset and Vin Cohen, a former Boys High star, paced Syracuse University's quintet to an 85-69 victory over Fordham in the second half of a double-header tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee made public today a staff study into the pros and cons of Federal or Federally supported disaster insurance.
NEWARK, Dec. 10 (AP) -- An increase in intrastate fares on seven railroads, agreed to by the state Board of Public Utility Commissioners, goes into effect New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The chairman of a Senate investigating panel charged today that many citizens were being asked to sacrifice their constitutional rights "on the altar of bureaucratic authoritarianism."
Small meat processors are reaping a bonanza from the demand for finer meat products and the ability of consumers to pay higher prices for them.

RAY BRADBURY'S latest collection of short stories shows a gifted writer making a play for the designation of the poor man's Poe. For some time now there has been a feeling among critics that this author was really on the verge of something significant.
A Hilton Hotel had a quick opportunity yesterday to make good on its corporate executives' promise to report promptly all hotel fires, no matter how trivial.

DETROIT, Dec. 10--John D. Dingell Jr., 29-year-old son of the late Representative John D. Dingell, is making a bid at a special election on Tuesday to win the seat in Congress formerly held by his father.

THE Mississippi River is really two rivers--the Upper Mississippi and the Lower, and the folklore of these two quite different rivers is also of two kinds. One is the folklore that belongs to the river proper, to the boats and the boatmen, to whom the land is something that flows by the river.

THREE years after the publication of his first book of photographs, "The Decisive Moment," which introduced a phrase in camera work that has become a symbol and an inspiration to photographers everywhere, Henri CartierBresson offers his second group.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 10--United States techincal assistance for Mexico has become the center of a struggle between nationalistically and internationally minded political forces here.

ABOUT eleven years ago, my United States Army unit was stationed in a town in the north of England, near the Lake District. In spite of the times, quite a few English used to get to this scenic area for hiking and bicycling over the week-ends.
Another yacht basin is being planned by Commisioner Robert Moses' Department of Parks. This should please the many boat owners who feel New York has far too few public marinas.
IT seems as though the home craftsman or handyman should be the easiest person in the world for whom to buy a Christmas present. After all, tools are limitless, both in variety and in price.

To the Art Editor: THE exhibition at the American Academy commemorating the Armory Show has stirred memories in many artists. I have been recalling what we learned from it. We learned exuberance--that we could actually kick over the traces, have a grand emotional spree and not get arrested.
Mayor Wagner is studying over the week-end a preliminary report by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney on the handling of $500,000 of commissary funds in the Department of Correction.

Virtually all auction galleries here have sales scheduled this week, at the peak of the holiday shopping season. For most galleries the week's end marks the beginning of the annual winter break, with sales resuming shortly after the new year.
One of Santa's most welcome presents is a crisp new bill, and banks are now coping with the public's annual rush for "new money."

Goffredo Petrassi, an Italian composer born in 1904, is little known in this country. Not long ago his Violin Concerto was heard in this city. Yesterday afternoon the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch introduced to New York the Fifth Concerto for Orchestra.
DALLAS, Dec. 10 (UP)--The Southwest Conference today turned down the proposed membership of Texas Tech and Houston and declined to modify Texas A. and M.'s probation.
Two unrelated new items last week illustrated the different aspects of the dynamic growth of the aluminum industry.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10--The United Nations Security Council today fought to at least a temporary deadlock over the proposal to admit eighteen new members to the world organization.

Courts in at least two states have been called upon to rule on the validity of minimum housing standard laws and the right of municipal agencies to enforce them, it was reported by the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials.

A warning to veterans to take advantage of their rights to obtain Government-insured mortgages under the G.I. Bill of Rights before these privileges expire has been issued by Robert Hill, president of the Tri-County Mortgage Company, of Teaneck, N.J.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens' power play clicked for three goals tonight as the National Hockey League leaders stretched their unbeaten streak to eight games with a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before 13,711 fans.

THIS latest addition to memorabilia about the Miamis (the city proper, and Miami Beach) is a well known columnist's version of the metropolis sparkling in the sunshine along the lower flange of South Florida's fabulous playground.

Former mental patients who are facing the adjustment to normal life will be helped by the Dec. 19 performance of "Janus." The comedy, starring Margaret Sullavan, Robert Preston and Claude Dauphin, opened Nov. 24 at the Plymouth Theatre.

An all-Wagner concert for the benefit of the opera house in Bayreuth, Germany, has been arranged by members of the American Friends of Bayreuth, assisted by the New York Federation of Music Clubs. The benefit will be held on the night of Jan. 15 at Carnegie Hall.

LONG before he came to worship the Virgin as a symbol of power, Henry Adams made a cult of admiration for woman. He often admired the wives of his friends more than the friends themselves. It was a woman who dominated his political novel, "Democracy," and the second novel, "Esther"-- any page of it was worth more than a volume of his "History," he said--centered entirely on a woman who was palpably his wife.

LOS ANGELES--California's winter sports areas seem to be taking the long view, all the way to the winter of 1960, when Squaw Valley will be the site of the Winter Olympics next-after the forthcoming international games taking place next year in the Italian Dolomites.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP)-- Carter L. Burgess, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Manpower and Personnel, said today that, despite a slow start for the military reserve program, it was too early to write it off.

SEVENTY-ONE of the 448 prizes awarded in the recent contest conducted by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for the best pictures of the state have been won by New York photographers, according to an announcement made last week.

INFORMATION regarding the 1956 stamp-issuing program of the United Nations was made available last week by Reldar Tvedt, head of the world organization's postal administration. Eight commemoratives are scheduled, Beginning with 8cents blue and 8c carmine items on. Feb. 17 in honor of the International Telecommunication Union.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 10 --The Amherst College quintet defeated Army tonight, 66 to 57.

A BIT of special pieading may help the reader to savor "Peace at Bowling Green." The special pleading revolves about the fact that there still exists in the mid-Appalachian area a breed of individuals who speak a version of the King's English more attuned to past centuries than the present.

The Harvard Business School and Radcliffe College have taken a further step in bringing the two institutions closer together. The Radcliffe Management Training Program will become the HarvardRadcliffe Program in Business Administration.

ANTARCTIC-- Comdr. Robin M. Hartmann, a member of the advance American expedition, announces from Wellington, N. Z., that it hopes to land men at the South Pole this antarctic summer by plane or parachute. Snow is to be surveyed for its possible use as a landing field for transport planes.

IN almost every garden are plants which give especially fine performances. Gardeners, being as they are, eagerly recommend these superior plants so that others may share in the pleasure of growing them. In my West Virginia garden this past year were several such "best" flowering bulbs, perennials and annuals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--Another General Assembly committee wound up its work today, and the diplomats who have been gathered here since Sept. 20 moved that much closer to being home for Christmas.

Slowdown for President Time is getting short. Congress will return in less than a month. The Administration must have a State of the Union message and the Budget ready. The word-handlers can quickly turn out a State of the Union speech--but only after the Budget is settled.
MILLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 10 --The Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys here will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Jan. 14 performance of "The Great Sebastians."

THE preface to this book opens with the statement: "To his contemporaries George Moore was a very great writer." He was indeed, but hardly to the young people of Dublin where he lived during an important epoch.

HOW should judges be chosen? The only honest answer is that the method is less important than the true source of the appointment. Here is one method now in use: "Dwight D. Eisenhower, President of the United States of America to all to whom these presents shall come, GREETINGS:

Property values have been found to rise both adjacent to public housing sites and within blighted areas that have been taken by eminent domain, cleared and sold for redevelopment by private interests. This was reported by the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials when it gave the results of two recent studies.

News that Dr. Vannevar Bush will retire on Jan. 1 as president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington will be received with regret not only by scientists but by a grateful nation that recalls the efficiency with which he directed the Office of Scientific Research and Development during the Second World War.

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations moved under one roof last week. By the end of their first day together, the delegates looked and sounded so much alike that you could not tell who was who without a scorecard.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10-- With one of the longest and bitterest hydroelectric power fights in Oregon history as a backdrop, the West is awaiting the next act in a drama of state water rights.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--Rome, famed for centuries as a repository of art masterpieces, is on the verge of acquiring new significance in that field. It is the site selected by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for establishment of an international center for study of the preservation and restoration of cultural objects.

While Southern states are devising various legislative means to prevent Negro children from entering white public schools, another organization is helping gifted, talented young Negroes from these same states to enter nonsegregated colleges and universities.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 11 -- Israel has received assurance that Britain has no design to press her into cession of Negev territory.

A group of German corporations have joined to fight any court action by bond holders seeking to collect on bonds that have been denied validation by a mixed American-German commission, it was announced over the week-end.

Cloaked in secrecy for the most part, a grim race has been going on these last few years between the United States and the Soviet Union -- a guided missile race. Each country is striving to perfect weapons which can deliver nuclear and conventional bombs accurately to a distant enemy.

BERLIN, Dec., 11 -- The official East German news agency, A. D. N. reported tonight the arrival of a new contingent of German prisoners from the Soviet Union. Repatriation of the prisoners had been suspended by Moscow more than seven weeks ago.

Plans for a new apartment building in the Murray Hill section have been announced by Maurice Epstein, who has bought a plot on Lexington Avenue near Thirty-eighth Street. Recently Mr. Epstein reported the purchase of a site surrounding the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street for apartments and stores.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey received the fourth annual Bill of Rights award here today.

Two dancers, Mary Ellen Moylan and Oleg Briansky, will make their debuts with the Metropolitan Opera in the second new production of the season Friday evening, Dec. 23. This will be a double bill, consisting of the ballet, "Soiree," and Donizetti's "Don Pasquale."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Barring an unexpected postponement, the Assembly begins tomorrow the final week of its current session, with the outlook unfavorable for a decision on the major issue of new memberships.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 11 -- Thirty-two young men were named today as recipients of Rhodes Scholarships. The names were announced by Dr. Courtney Smith, president of Swarthmore College and the American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears staved off Pete Pihos and a sharp Philadelphia Eagles passing attack today to gain a 17-10 triumph before 34,783 fans. The triumph clinched second place for the Bears in the National Football League's Western Conference.
ELMER RICE'S theatrical trifle, "Dream Girl," was the third Maurice Evans television production of the season yesterday afternoon on Channel 4. It was not very good.
A group oif high school pupils at the New York Times Youth Forum expressed a cautiously optimistic view of automation last night.

Since October a contingent of one of the finest and most colorful units in the British Army -- Her Majesty's Scots Guards -- has been spreading a delightful mantle of goodwill over these United States.

At a special convocation last night, Yeshiva University conferred honorary degrees upon Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and Charles H. Silver, president of the New York City Board of Education.

The Board of Estimate's decision last week to allocate more than $20,000,000 for city waterfront projects next year has been interpreted by the Department of Marine and Aviation as a major victory in its fight to keep city-owned piers under city control.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 11 -- Two deserters from the French Foreign Legion entered Israel as spies for Egypt but surrendered to authorities here, the Israeli Army announced today.

The steamship charter market finished strong last week, primarily because of the reappearance of coal interests. The overall dry cargo rate index inched upward for the fifth week in a row and business volume held firm.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 11 -- American protestantism was taken to task today today by a New York church leader. He said it was "creating the impression" that it was more interested in fighting bingo than juvenile delinquency.
Five new films, including an importation from Switzerland, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

IT doesn't approach the complexity or the obtuseness of the Einstein Theory. It is simple mathematics. In 1954 the large Roy Campanella batted .207, hit nineteen homers and drove in fifty-four runs. The Dodgers lost the pennant. In 1955 the large Roy Campanella batted .318, hit thirty-two homers and drove in 107 runs. The Dodgers won the pennant.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 11 -- Leaders of the New Jersey State Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations expressed "cautious optimism" today on the prospects for a smooth merger with the state Federation of Labor.

The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., has asked Mayor Wagner to send back to the City Council for further study the bill granting tax exemption and abatement to property owners who rehabilitate substandard dwellings.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- King Saud of Saudi Arabia and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India today called for a peaceful and non-militant" approach to issues dividing the world.
Soviet legislators are engaged in a detailed scrutiny of the proposed 1956 Soviet budget, Pravda has indicated.
In his series on the Australian Federal election campaign, Robert Trumbull erred in a reference to social security payments, published Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The blazing controversy over whether the Central Intelligence Agency shall build a "Little Pentagon" on the beautiful Virginia Palisades is headed for a decision this week. But the embers are expected to be a long time dying.

Jon Sandrilla, the swimming coach at Poly Prep of Brooklyn, was working with his third-string diver the other day. He watched the boy go through his six routines. Then Sandrilla asked him to try a front half-twist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -Louis S. Rothschild, the Under Secretary of Commerce for transportation, is regarded as the key man behind the ouster of Frederick B. Lee as Administrator of Civil Aeronautics. Mr. Rothschild paved the way for the change by creating in May the post of Deputy Administrator for Charles J. Lowen Jr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The time has come, the United States said, to talk of many things -- of spectographs and billiard cloth, of boiler plate that rings.
A two-day tournament in which three metropolitan contract bridge championship titles were at stake ended last night at the McAlpin Hotel.

THE ninety-two musicians left leaderless and stunned when Toscanini retired fourteen months ago now speak through seven of their strings -- a board of directors made up of a double bass, two violas, two 'cellos and two violins -- yet they can be heard around the world.

The creation of oversize classes to solve local schoolbuilding shortages not only will lead to poor teaching but also will mean financial headaches in the future, according to a report released today by Teachers College of Columbia University.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., shot into the lead at the start and fought off a late challenge by the Marquis De Portago of Spain to win the 210-mile Nassau Trophy sports car race today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Monday, Dec. 12 -- Israeli forces captured a network of fortified Syrian positions dominating the northeast corner of the Sea of Galilee, Army headquarters here reported this morning.

President Luis Batlle Berres, the chairman of the National Council of Uruguay, became a sightseer for five minutes yesterday afternoon. For the rest of the day, however, he was the center of attention on a round of official calls.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- A white woman living in Nebraska has the best chance to live to be 85 years old.

Charles B. Clark of Washington College (Md.) was elected president of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association yesterday as the organization concluded a three-day convention at the Statler Hotel.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns crammed three touchdowns into the closing four and one-quarter minutes today to overcome a 10-point deficit and defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 35 -- 24.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Toronto Maple Leafs battled to a 3-3 tie in the Chicago Stadium tonight. The result dropped the Hawks into fourth place in the National Hockey League.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- After shattering the course record with a 6-under-par 29 on the back nine to tie for first, Sam Snead won his sixth Miami Open golf tournament today in a sudden-death play-off with Tommy Bolt.

The Twentieth Century Fund has chosen August Heckscher, chief editorial writer of The New York Herald Tribune, as its new executive director. Mr. Heckscher will succeed J. Frederick Dewhurst, who will make a study for the fund of European economic resources.

Suggestions for recreational programs for older persons are contained in "Creative Activities for the Aging; A Manual for Organizing Activities for Older People." It has just been published by the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee today accused California Democratic party leaders of attempting to freeze him out of the California primary election next June.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Although the approach of Christmas is acting as a brake on Stock Exchange business, it is evident from the steady advance in prices that the public is again making a cautious approach to the markets.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- A British Army sergeant and his wife tonight won Britain's biggest television jackpot -- the equivalent of $3,080 -- by mastering a juggling trick that had baffled other husband-and-wife teams for eleven weeks.

The theory that if a boy is old enough to fight he is also old enough to vote has gained some ground in recent years. In Georgia and Kentucky the state constitutions have been amended to permit it. Now Governor Harriman, speaking to a group of 300 youngsters in Albany, has come out for it.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- Somewhere in the vicinity of Moscow Marshal Ivan S. Konev is supposed to have an international headquarters which is the Communist world's equivalent of SHAPE. Here he presumably has facilities for the joint staff of the Warsaw pact, or, as it is often known in the West, Anti-NATO.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins rallied behind Eddie LeBaron's passing today to defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 28 -- 17.
Amor Musicae, a chamber group specializing in music of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, presented an appetizing list of baroque works yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The temper and tone of election-year relations between the Republican Administration and the Democratic Congress nay well be set tomorrow and Tuesday at two White House conferences.

Columbia University will conduct a $50,000 research project covering public liability in the atomic energy field, it was announced yesterday by Walker L. Cisler, president of the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc. The forum, with headquarters at 260 Madison Avenue, is a sponsor of the project.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A House investigating subcommittee recommended today that the twenty-year-old Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce have its wings clipped.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Ernest Robbins has an eighty-eight-acre dairy farm, twenty cows and a big problem.

Twenty-five new schools and four additions to existing buildings have been listed for construction next year by the Board of Education. The new units have a total enrollment capacity of 34,700 pupils. They will cost $58,700.000.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 -- A runaway scrap market last week appeared to make more certain that some steel companies will be forced to raise their prices soon. Non-integrated producers who use substantial tonnages of purchased scrap are caught in one of the tightest squeeze plays in their history.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, at Sea, Dec. 11 -- At a speed of fifteen knots, this Navy icebreaker was proceeding smoothly today toward her Antarctic destination -- McMurdo Sound, 2,500 miles due south.
THIS column is devoted to gifts for the Person Who Has Everything. There's at least one on every list, haunting us like Scrooge's Christmas ghost.

The College Entrance Examination Board proposed yesterday two steps to draw into colleges 200,000 of the nation's brighter high school graduates who, it said, were "lost" to higher education each year.
The remarkable economic progress of Venezuela has been made possible by the stable relationship between the Government and the foreign companies developing the nation's oil resources.
Michael J. Quill announced yesterday that the international executive council and executive board of the Transport Workers Union had voted to keep the organization in the merged labor movement.

Representatives of seven organizations of "free Poles" merged their units yesterday into a United States branch of the Polish Council of National Unity. They met in the Carnegie Endowment Building, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Postmaster General said today he would present to President Eisenhower in a few days a long-range program to modernize and rebuild postal facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney credited General Motors leadership today "with two important declarations" as a result of the month-long public hearings on the corporation's activity.

UPTON, L. I., Dec. 11 -- An atomic medical research center will be constructed at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a major research installation of the Atomic Energy Commission. At the medical center radiations from the inner core of the atom will be used to probe some of the major mechanisms of the living process, in health and in disease.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 11 -- Late ballot counts today in Australia's national election have brought Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies' conservative Government a strikingly large majority of at least twenty-nine seats in a lower house of 122 voting members.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Jane Wyman's next picture for Warner Brothers will be "Two Wives," described by Jack L. Warner, studio production chief, as being an "adult romantic drama" with a New England background.
The brilliant piano recital of Robert Casadesus at the Hunter College Auditorium Saturday night demonstrated afresh the distinctively French virtues of this artist.

A young Canadian pianist, Ray Dudley, played a debut recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He exhibited a fault common among debutants, that of making up a program from the most difficult works in the repertory.
RIVERDALE, Conn., Dec. 11 -- With an ancient and a seldom-used ritual, St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church terminated services in its Chapel Lane edifice today.
A self-described "middle-of- the-road" slate has defeated its opposition in an election of board members by the New York local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen declared today that there was a fundamental foreign policy difference between the Eisenhower Administration and the Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The Soviet Union is continuing to express a generally optimistic outlooks on international problems while intensifying its efforts to detach West Germany from the North Atlantic alliance.

The vigorous growth of interest in the conservation of our country's natural resources is reflected and at the same time will be greatly stimulated by a $50,000 grant to the Boy Scouts of America that has just been made by the Rockefeller Foundation.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 11 -- Belgium has become Western Europe's reluctant pioneer in achieving a shorter work week.
ERNA SACK, coloratura soprano, appeared in a recital at Carnegie Hall last night, offering a program designed, among other things, to display her ability to soar to astonishing heights above high C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A North Carolina Democratic Senator said today there were strong indications that the Interior Department had "concocted a frantic scheme" to pass $500,000 worth of publicly owned timber to a private company on the basis of questionable mining claims.
Sales of Christmas tree decorations this year are expected to set cash registers jingling to the sparkling tune of $125,000,000.
The Commerce and Industry Association proposed yesterday a state legal limit of $30 a week on employers' payments to laid-off workers under "guaranteed annual wage" plans.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The league-leading Montreal Canadiens broke up a rugged game with the Boston Bruins tonight by scoring three last-period goals for a 4-2 triumph before 11,572. The triumph was their sixth straight in the National Hockey League.

FUKUOKA, Japan, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Veikko Karvonen, a long striding Finn who closes stoutly, raced away from Japan's Kurao Hiroshima in the final two miles to win the Asahi international marathon in 2 hours 23 minutes 16 seconds today.

THOROUGHLY in the mood for a bird and bottle, local cooks turn attention to squabs, those elegant morsels that even supermarkets stock. The tender young of the pigeon, in which all activity is discouraged during their six weeks' existence, have a succulent flesh of an off-white hue.
FROM almost any point of view, Pirandello's "Six Characters in Search of an Author" is a brilliant play. And the performance, which opened at the Phoenix last evening, is brilliant also.
An operational failure in the New York Central Railroad's $24,000,000 new bridge over the Harlem River stalled four trains from nine to thirty-four minutes yesterday.
MONTREAL, Dec. 11 -- Dockhands, skippers and meteorologists won a running battle with winter last night when the last ship cleared the Lachine Canal.

Negro and white worshipers exchanged pews yesterday in the "borough of churches." The exchange took place in Brooklyn between two Protestant churches as a pilot project to promote racial understanding.

LOIS MARSHALL, Canadian soprano, in her third Town Hall recital last night, showed again that she is an impressive artist, a notable technician and a fine musician. Her singing roused her audience to the sort of enthusiasm that one seldom hears at a song recital nowadays.
A three-part stained-glass window and a marble memorial plaque were dedicated at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday by the rector, the Rev. Terence J. Finlay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Communist party activity is increasing in Western Europe, according to reports reaching intelligence agencies here.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 11 -- The gifted child is going to get a better break in this state. A five-point program to help the youngster with brains and talent has been adopted by the State Education Department. This was disclosed today at the opening of the seventy-first annual conference of the New York State Association of Secondary School Principals.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The burden of taxes on the French economy has diminished, according to a study by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs.

The Field Foundation gave $758,766.79 to philanthropy in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, its president, Marshall Field, said yesterday in his annual report. The foundation has given $5,964,928 since it started making grants in 1941.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11 -- Efforts to interest Scandinavian countries in surplus farm products at bargain prices have hit an old snag.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 11 -- As Dutch industry and trade continue in excellent shape, generally very good financial results are expected in the near future.
Anthony Quayle, co-director of the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon, England, said yesterday that his troupe probably would accept an invitation to come here for a limited run.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A Congressional study group predicted today that many persons would suffer hardships with the advance of automation to a level that "may well surpass the limits of modern imagination."
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 -- The Soviet leaders returned to New Delhi today and immediately began a series of political and economic conferences with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Senator Prescott Bush urged today that widespread flood and hurricane protection for New England be given a prominent part in President Eisenhower's 1956 legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Some of the radiant good feeling of the Geneva conference of the Big Four leaders last summer infected the Army and was not dissipated by the sobering effect of the subsequent parley of Foreign Ministers.
Legislative control over spending is being undermined by the earmarking of state tax revenues, the Tax Foundation reported yesterday. The foundation is a private nonprofit research organization.

The University of Pittsburgh, opponent of Georgia Tech in the Sugar Bowl game at New Orleans on Jan. 2, received, the Lambert Trophy at a reception at the Metropolitan Club yesterday. It marked the third success for Pitt in the twenty-year history of the Lambert Torphy.

THE great skill and charm of Alec Guinness in light and comical roles have obstructed somewhat the general knowledge that he is a dramatic actor of rare competence -- a fact not too clearly demonstrated in his performance heretofore on the screen.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The traditional Olympic torch will be carried to the winter games here next month by automobile, airplane and men on foot, skis and ice skates.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- A six-race regatta staged in a 15-to-18-knot westerly at Larchmont Yacht Club today failed to produce a skipper able to win more than one race.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ron Waller, a rookie halfback, made a 55-yard touchdown run on the fourth play of the game and the Los Angeles Rams swept to a 31-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers today. The triumph wrapped up the Western Conference title of the National Football League for the Rams.
Choosing an agency is no longer easy. Here is how the Manhattan Shirt Company did it:
Robert. F. Kennedy, counsel to the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee, called yesterday for a United Nations inquiry into Russian "colonialism" in Soviet Central Asia.
Car thefts are declining in this city, while recoveries and arrests are increasing, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy reported yesterday.
After a bad start, cotton prices in the domestic market turned firmer last week until the final day's sessions, when they weakened sharply, the New York Cotton Exchange reported over the week-end.

The outlook is for plenty of meat on the nation's dinner tables. So much pork, beef and lamb is in prospect, in fact, that the country's food chains are planning three advertising drives early in 1956 to dispose of the packers' heavy supplies.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- The Jews of Rome, who contend that they have the longest unbroken history of any Jewish settlement in the world, opened today a modern community center. It was patterned on United States models and has been financed in party by United States contributions.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 11 -- By a single game in the third set of the final match, the Philadelphia court tennis doubles team defeated Long Island, 2 to 1, today to regain the Payne Whitney Memorial Trophy. The matches were played in the Greentree court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Ezra Taft Benson charged today that it was Adlai E. Stevenson who was trying to set one group against another for political benefit.

LAST October during the high tide of the autumn publishing season two books about Africa were published that could not then be noticed in this space. Admiring tribute had just been paid to John Gunther's excellent "Inside Africa" and to Stuart Cloete's excellent "The African Giant." Enough seemed enough.
People are doing their Christmas giving early this year, according to the first day's report on the forty-fourth annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Mayor Wagner has been asked by the Civil Service Reform Association to support a pending City Council bill for repeal of the Lyons Residence Law.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Yesterday's release of two United States soldiers arrested in East Berlin, plus other events of recent days, are believed to indicate that the Soviet Union wishes to avoid a crisis in Berlin.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11 -- Prof. Edmund W. Sinnott, dean of Yale's Graduate School, will retire next June 30, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, the university president, announced today.

ZURICH, Dec. 11 -- Feeling on the Zurich Stock Exchange was highly agitated last week by the terms of the bill approved by the German Cabinet for the liquidation of the old German Reichsbank and compensation of the free stockholders of the Gold Discount Bank, a subsidiary of the Reichsbank.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- The City Charter Committee (Democrats and independent Republicans) won five of the nine seats in the new City Council, the Hamilton County Board of Elections announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The Democratic Governor of Minnesota and the Republican Governor of Iowa exchanged charges today over foreign policy.

The Dead Sea scrolls "will not radically alter our picture of Christian origins," the Rev. Dr. J. Carter Swaim said in a sermon yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of Jamaica, 89-60 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 11 -- A 4-year-old Doberman pinscher with a famous sire became best in show tonight in the twenty-fourth event of the Camden County Kennel Club.

This is one of the cleanest cities I have ever seen. I thought you might like to hear how it is kept so and some of the reasons for it. I had a talk about it today with your opposite number in Prague, Josef Jaburek, and his chief engineer, Antonin Bucek.
The political pundits are now in fairly complete agreement, it would appear, that "the farm problem" is going to be one of the major domestic issues in the 1956 Presidential campaign.
More than 31,000,000 Christmas trees are being rushed to markets across the nation.
Excitement spread like a three-alarm fire through the New York Founding Hospital yesterday as Santa's helpers in firemen's uniforms toured the wards with gifts for 270 youngsters.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11--In January a new phase of the atoms-for-peace program, which President Eisenhower announced to the General Assembly two years ago, will get under way in Washington.

" Do not wait for extraordinary circumstances to do good," a wise man once said. We are reminded of this as we read the family histories that underlie this year's appeal for the Neediest Cases. The misfortunes that beset these families would be, if taken singly, the ordinary stuff of life in large city or small: illness, sudden catastrophe of one sort or another, desertion by father or mother.

J. B. Priestley and his wife, Jacquetta Hawkes, who collaborated in a play, "Dragon's Mouth," that was published last month, are co-authors of a book Harper's will issue next month. It is "Journey Down a Rainbow," which explores and contrasts the oldest and newest ways of life in the American Southwest.
A rector of the Holy Catholic Church of Japan (Episcopal) posed a two-part question here yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Indian demonstrators paraded through the streets here today shouting condemnations of a recent statement on Goa made by United States Secretary of State Dulles.

If Nationalist China had been willing to consent to the admission of the comic opera Communist satellite called Outer Mongolia the United Nations would now have eighteen new members. This would make seventy-eight in all, of which ten would be ready at any time to vote what we might call the Communist ticket.

Running a seminar for business men is a difficult enterprise, primarily because levels of economic understanding vary so widely. On the one hand is the man who has built a successful manufacturing company but hasn't read a book since he left the sixth grade.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Two Detroit rookies, John Bucyk and Glenn Hall, combined tonight to lead the Red Wings to their first victory over the New York Rangers this season. The defending National Hockey League champions gained a 2-0 triumph before 11,422 fans at Olympia.

There have been recent suggestions from the Far East that the time may be ripe for again trying to bring about a rapprochement between Japan and Korea. In some quarters it has been urged that the United States act as a "mediator." While this country might be reluctant to accept that role as such, it should not be averse to giving any help that it can.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The A. F. L.-C. I. O. Detroit Mailers voted today to ask their international union for authority to go on strike officially against Detroit's three metropolitan daily newspapers. The papers have been closed for eleven days by a walkout of A. F. L.-C. I. O. stereotypers.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 11 -- Diplomatic observers foresee the Soviet Union's economic penetration of Afghanistan following the visit this week of Premier Bulganin and Mr. Khrushchev to Kabul, Afghan capital.

The Alleghany Corporation has been registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 to clear up certain questions that have arisen in connection with the issuance of its 6 per cent preferred stock, Robert R. Young, chairman, announced yesterday.

A warm, songful performance of Chausson's Concerto in D for violin, piano and string quartet was the high point of the Chamber Music Circle's second program of the season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Canadian Javelin, Ltd., which plans to develop an iron ore deposit in Labrador, announced yesterday it had learned from Premier Joseph R. Smallwood of Newfoundland that two members of the Newfoundland cabinet had been nominated to the company's board of directors.

The Board of Superintendents of the New York City Board of Education adopted a "guiding statement" for supervisors and teachers on the teaching of "moral and spiritual value" in the schools. This statement is not yet operative and it is for this reason that we urge every parent to secure a copy and ponder its implications.
Eighty-two-men and one woman with a total of 4,200 years of printing behind them were honored yesterday by New York Typographical Union No. 6.

AMERICAN men spend half their childhood talking their way out of short pants, and half their manhood talking themselves into wearing them again. Now they will be comforted to hear that about 60 per cent of the world's male population is still in skirts.
Nine members of the Armed Forces team were chosen yesterday by the United States Olympic soccer committee for berths on the All- Eastern squad.
Former President Herbert Hoover called yesterday for the establishment by Congress of a new office of Administrative Vice President to help operate "the biggest business in the world."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Eisenhower rested at the White House today after his physicians had announced publicly that he was showing "slight indications of fatigue."

With reference to your editorial of Nov. 21 "Red 'Goodwill' in Asia" permit me to indicate that no Asian is more aware of the baneful effects of the subtle techniques of the Communists than an intelligent Indian.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Battle lines for France's elections Jan. 2 have split the non-Communist forces badly, increasing the likelihood of Communist gains in the new National Assembly.

DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Seymour Korkes, 33-year-old Duke University biochemist, died about midnight yesterday from internal chest injuries suffered in a traffic collision here four hours earlier.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- A general advance in grain prices last week was due to various influences, including Washington reports intimating there would be a return to high support prices for high quality grain; strength in the cash markets for wheat corn and soybeans; continued dry weather over most of the hard winter wheat belt, and the overextended position of short sellers.

Leonard Gelberg, in his letter which appeared in The New York Times of Dec. 8, says "a close examination of dealer complaint reveals that the dealers are competing among themselves, where in the past they competed only with dealers franchised by other auto companies."

Thirty towering Christmas trees, each topped by a glowing star, sprang into colored light on Park Avenue last night. The traditional ceremony featured by the illumination of the trees took place outside the Brick (Presbyterian) Church at Ninety-first Street.

Welles Hangen's article published Dec. 5 on Soviet juvenile delinquency fails to mention among the causes enumerated by the Soviet authorities two basic factors. They are the low living standard that forces most mothers to work, abandoning their post-nursery-stage children to their own devices after school hours, and the terrible housing conditions, that crowd families into single rooms, without privacy.
This may come under the head of a "So what?" piece because the number of dogs affected is small, but is offered on the chance that dog fanciers in general will be interested.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- It was with a feeling of regret that the Giants, having beaten the Detroit Lions, 24 -- 19, concluded the National Football League campaign today at Briggs Stadium. Uppermost in their thoughts was the wish that the season, rather than being finished, had just started.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- A compromise plan has been formulated to resolve a major Federal-State water controversy.

CHICAGO, Dec 11 (AP) -- Swift Co., meat packer, today reported net earnings of $22,893,155 for 1955, a 20 per cent increase over last year's net of $19,050,891. Earnings per share were $3.87, compared to $3.22 in 1954.
Abe Turner defeated Mario Schroeder in forty-four moves yesterday to take undisputed first place in the Manhattan Chess Club championship tournament. Turner has a score of 2 -- 0.
An investigation was ordered yesterday into all private detective agencies licensed by the state, their employes and their use of wiretapping equipment.
The two leaders of the newly merged labor federation declared yesterday that labor would continue to fight for its right politically, but that it would not try to impose its will on the nation.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- Italy's newest political party, the Radicals, in its first public meeting today, asked the support of all Italians standing politically between the dominant Christian Democrats and the Marxist parties.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzales tonight whipped Tony Trabert in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, in Tony's first appearance as a professional tennis player in his home town.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals, leading throughout the second half, turned back the Boston Celtics, 101 -- 89, today for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory at home.

Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted the New York Chamber Ensemble, formerly known as the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble, last night in what the musicians believe was the first New York performance of Darius Milhaud's Fifth Symphony for ten wind instruments.
MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 11 -This great textile region is seething with developments that are ominous for the American cotton farmer.
Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Musicians Guild, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Chamber Music Associates, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

The northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and West Fifty-fifth Street, north of Rockefeller Center, has been purchased by Simon Brothers, builders and realty investors, for future development. It consists of five five-story store and apartment buildings on plot 100 by 100 feet.
Two Coast Guard helicopters were bedded down on East River islands last night after a rescue merry-go-round that ended in two forced landings. No one was injured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--President Eisenhower engaged today in his longest work day since his Sept. 24 heart attack.

We have no need to worry, apparently, about ever completely losing our worries. According to one news story worry is normal and will be around for a long time. The latest thing about worry, according to a more recent story, is that it has developed a new and growing symptom -- teeth gnashing.
The head of the world's free trade unions declared yesterday that admission of Franco Spain and five Soviet satellites to the United Nations would represent a "time bomb" for democracy.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign, transactions in goods and services produced a record current account deficit of $89,000,000 in the July-September period. The Bureau of Statistics re-
The Ford Foundation's grants yesterday of half a billion dollars were applauded by educational institutions and medical groups throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its short-term borrowing costs were still rising.

Blood donations on Friday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 742 pints. Included were 246 pints given at City College, uptown, to make a three-day total of 824 for the college. Two hundred fifteen pints were given by employes of the New York City Housing Authority at 270 Broadway.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Lubanski of Detroit, the 1954-55 runner-up, took a commanding lead tonight in the men's division qualifying trials of the national All-Star bowling tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The National Aeronautics Association announced today the names of fifteen Americans honored as "elder statesmen of aviation."
The state's 590 licensed private detectives were ordered yesterday to reveal all cases in the last three years in which wiretapping was involved.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Prime Minister Eden attacked tonight "fantastic" assertions by the Soviet Union's leaders about Britain and the West. Tolerance and understanding are necessary, he warned, if co existence is to work.

The constantly-overburdened often-maligned basketball officials had a good day yesterday. The way they were being praised at the weekly meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers' Association at Leone's Restaurant, one might have thought it was "Be Kind to Basketball Referees Day."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Steve Nelson and four associates today won a Supreme Court review of their conviction of conspiring to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force.

" We, too, are over 70 but blessedly together and in good health," wrote a New Jersey couple in sending a $100 contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Their contribution will help prevent an elderly couple from being separated.
The new starting time for all National Basketball Association double - headers at Madison Square Garden will go into effect with tonight's twin bill.

The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation will earn $900,000 in 1955, the trustee estimated in a report yesterday to the Public Service Commission. The company, which operates buses and trolley cars in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester, earned $2,754,000 in 1954.

The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission "probably would upset" a new agreement on hiring procedures worked out last week by the union and shipping companies.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 -- United Nations observers found today that an Israeli raiding party destroyed a Syrian Army post and a farm residence last night and killed at least forty-one soldiers and civilians.
Mayor Wagner referred to New Yorkers as "people with hearts" because of the $5,601,118 they contributed this year to the Greater New York Fund.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 -- Pakistan's High Commissioner to India accused the Soviet leaders today of deliberately trying to stir up bad feeling between the people of India and Pakistan.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Richard Tenneson, 22-year-old United States soldier who chose to remain in Communist China after his capture in Korea, but later changed his mind, crossed into Hong Kong today.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The new broom swept clean today at Northwestern as StuHolcomb, hired as athletic director three days ago, dismissed the head football coach, Lou Saban, and his entire staff.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (UP) -- A State Health Department spokesman said today that there had been five times as many paralytic cases this year among unvaccinated children as among those receiving the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Leading industrial stocks turned dull today although price relapses were relieved when selected stocks went against the trend.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Sale of the assets of the Diamond T Motor Car Company of Chicago to the White Motor Company of Cleveland was defeated today. The transaction failed to win approval of two-thirds of Diamond T's shareholders as required by Illinois corporation law.

Events today: Puccini's "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15 P. M.; Menotti's "The Telephone" and "The Medium," Brooklyn Academy, 8:30 P. M.; Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" and Monteverdi's "Combattimento di Tancredi e di Clorinda," in concert form, Town Hall, 8:45 P. M.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Supporters of the proposed United Nations membership deal refused today to give the special assurances that the Soviet Union had demanded.

The Educational Film Library Association and the New York Film Council will conduct an Eastern regional film workshop on Jan. 26 and 27 at the Carnegie International Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street. The theme will be "special purpose films--their production, presentation and potentialities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Nearly fifty years of jurisdictional strife between butchers and store clerks ended here today. The Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen and the Retail Clerks International Association signed a five-year agreement delineating their jurisdictions in the handling of meats in the retail trade.
Paolo Rosi, Italian-born lightweight who now lives in the Bronx, scored a surprising victory over Lulu Perez of Brooklyn at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 12 -- The Greek freighter Makedonia was in drydock here today after a record salvage tow of 3,200 miles from the northwestern Pacific Ocean by a former Canadian Navy corvette.

BETWEEN Labor Day and Thanksgiving the picture books bloom in the book shops in rich profusion. This year their variety is even greater than usual. Although all kinds of books make fine Christmas presents, it is clear that publishers believe picture books are the most appropriate. They are bigger and splashier and look more festive than ordinary books. They cost more, too.

Many more securities dealers who have been holding customers' cash or securities for more than minimum periods are going to be required to file certified financial statements, if the Securities and Exchange Commission gets its way. A large proportion of the broker-dealers of the country who are not members of registered securities exchanges will be affected -- exactly how many is not known.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Route 9 stagecoach, riding "piggyback" most of the way, rumbled into Glens Falls just before dark today after a fifty-mile trip from Schroon Lake.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Two "private eyes" clomped through the marbled splendor of the National Art Gallery today searching for fingerprints of a Florentine sculptor dead almost five hundred years.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday moved to abolish the Boxing Guild of New York. Its members, chiefly managers of boxers, have until Jan. 15 to sever connections with the organization.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 -- Two major automobile companies have received Federal rulings specifying that payments into trust funds for lay-off benefit plans will be deductible business expenses for income tax purpose.
The National Association of Manufacturers insisted yesterday that it had shown more eagerness than George Meany to promote labor-management peace.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Ted Williams, slugging outfielder of the Boston Red Sox, said today the chances are good he will play baseball next season.

" Children's Corner," a program designed for youngsters but one that tries to amuse adults as well, will resume over the National Broadcasting Company television network on Saturday, Dec. 24, from 10 to 10:30 A. M.

Record sales and earnings were achieved by Food Fair Stores, Inc., in the twenty-eight weeks ended Nov. 12, Louis Stein, president, disclosed in the report to stockholders yesterday. Net income increased 24.8 per cent on a sales gain of 15.8 per cent over the corresponding period last year.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Edward Lamb, publisher and broadcaster, has acquired a major stock interest in the Seiberling Rubber Company, of Akron, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Governor Harriman arrived today to discuss with Congressional leaders legislation he considered important to New York. He said he planned discussions with Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate majority leader and others.

An ancient but lusty comedy of Aristophanes, identified by the jawbreaking title of "The Thesmophoriazusae" (The Women at Demeter's Festival), will be resuscitated at 7:45 this evening. The event will take place at the Rooftop Theatre, 111 East Houston Street.

Farmers in all twenty-one cotton producing states will vote today to determine whether marketing quotas shall apply to next year's crop. If two-thirds of those voting approve the quotas, such controls will be put on the nation's cotton crop for the third successive year.
Congratulations on your fine editorial of Dec. 2 on "The Coliseum and Traffic." New York citizens will applaud your condemnation of the "wait-and-see-what-happens" attitude of the Traffic Department.
Retired bakery drivers in the metropolitan area will be "in the dough" as a result of a pension plan established yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the legality of so-called "fair trade" price-fixing agreements between manufacturer-owned wholesalers and competing wholesalers.

CHILLY weather agrees with mussels, the black-shelled bivalves most delicious steamed and served with French white wine broth or Italian tomato-garlic marinara. Though the shellfish is available the year around, quality is best in winter.

Mayor Wagner filled yesterday three approaching vacancies in important posts in his administration. Henry Epstein resigns as Deputy Mayor to go on the judicial bench Jan. 1. Dr. Luther Gulick, City Administrator, is resuming the presidency of the Institute of Public Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--A Presidential emergency board recommended today a package increase of 16 1/2 cents an hour for 750,000 nonoperating railroad employes.

The J. L. N. Realty Corporation of 342 Madison Avenue, headed by Harry H. Nadel, has filed plans with the Department of Housing and Buildings for a nineteen-story apartment house on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Many dinner parties will be given before the Big Brother Christmas benefit on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall. Members of the woman's committee of the Big Brother Movement of Greater New York have taken over the mezzanine seats of the theatre.

A demonstration by angry spectators marked the conclusion of the feature wrestling match between Antonino Rocca of South America and Lord Leslie Carlton, California, at Madison Square Garden last night.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Extreme dullness ruled in Board of Trade pits today, with a generally steady undertone.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 12 -- The Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport described today as "entirely unauthorized" a parish bulletin by a Stamford priest that advised parishioners not to sell their homes to "agents for Negroes."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The chairman of the Senate Aviation subcommittee accused high officials of the Commerce Department today of attempting to seize control of "all civil aviation."

THE New York Conservation Department believes it is approaching a solution to the problems of propagating and stocking pheasants. This should cheer hunters who have feared for the future of the bird in this state.
There are about 7,000 foundation in the United States, of which the Ford Foundation is by far the largest.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 -- The West German Government is planning to use economic inducements to support its campaign against recognition of the East German Communist regime by the under-developed and neutralist nations.

The au] thor entered.the Foreign 'Service* in 1944-and soon thereafter waiS sent to Yugoslavia. as economic officer of the American Embas sy. in Belgrade, *i-eturning i.'i 1946.

Major food chain stores in the city cut the price of milk yesterday by one cent to 23 cents a quart for homogenized milk. Independently owned stores here have been cutting prices for more than a month.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- The United States, in effect, rejected today a compromise Soviet proposal designed to give the Moscow Patriarchate permanent control over part of the Russian Orthodox community in North and South America.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev told 50,000 Indians today that mechanized, collective farming and political power in the hands of the peasants were the way to spiritual as well as mental and physical development.
The Yankees yesterday announced their 1956 spring training schedule. It consists of thirty-five exhibition games.
THE Musicians Guild with its nucleus, the Kroll Quartet, opened its tenth season last night in Town Hall with a consistently fine and often exciting concert.

The largest lump sum of gifts in the history of philanthropy -- $500,000,000 to the nation's privately supported colleges, universities and hospitals -- was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
A gold-bound, gem-encrusted tribute to men of the 107th (old Seventh) Infantry Regiment who died in this nation's wars will arrive here tomorrow aboard the Queen Mary. It is valued at $50,000.
The self-help or "do it yourself" fad is being introduced here by the Government in the preparation of Federal income tax returns.

TORONTO, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press ) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., had net profit in the nine months ended Sept. 30 of $2,958,021, or $1.25 a common share after allowing for preferred dividend accrual. This compared with $1,623,156, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year.

Allegheny County, Pa., announced yesterday that it planned to borrow publicly $6,000,000 on Jan. 10 for institutional purposes. The county will offer an issue of serial bonds dated Feb. 1, 1956, and due on Feb. 1 from 1957 to 1986.
The chairman of the State Mediation Board offered yesterday to promote a "non-aggression pact" between management and the merged labor movement on a state-wide level.
The editorial of Dec. 8 "The Big Soviet Lie" rightly calls attention to the Communist practice of rewriting history to serve the purposes of diplomacy and propaganda.

The college basketball season already is old enough for such well-regarded teams as Kentucky, Illinois and Oklahoma City to have taken their first tumbles, but nothing has happened so far to shake the experts' belief that the University of San Francisco has the nation's best college team.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Sixteen-year-old Johann Steigerwald stopped off here tonight on his way from a Yugoslav orphanage to the United States for a Christmas reunion with his mother. He has not seen her since he was 5. He will leave Frankfurt tonight or tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP)--The Government today loosened some restrictions on home mortgage credit. Some $1,000,000,000 in new mortgage credit may be made available.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Administration and the Republican National Committee have embarked on a public relations program calculated to turn a sow's ear into a silk purse.
Following are sketches of the three persons named to new posts yesterday by Mayor Wagner:
Executives of leading contracting concerns in New York have formed a state-wide organization under the name of the General Building Contractors Association of New York State.

CAIRO, Dec. 12 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Humphrey Trevelyan, informed Egypt today that the British Government General in the Sudan, Sir Knox Helm, had tendered his resignation "for personal reasons." Sir Humphrey said Britain was prepared to accept the resignation.
President Eisenhower in a message at the dedication yesterday of the Trade Show Building said that the new display center should stimulate sales and add to the strength of the nation's economy.
TIBERIAS, Israel, Dec. 12 -- The Sea of Galilee's eastern coast was reported calm today after last night's battle, in which six Israelis were killed and ten wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Diplomats representing eight Arab nations called on Secretary of State Dulles today and said they hoped the United States would not force them to rely on the Soviet bloc for arms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today denied a California request that Colorado and Wyoming be made co-defendants in a pending suit over use of waters of the Colorado River system.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 12 -- The conflict between rival Tunisian leaders has deepened in the last three weeks and divided nationalists into two camps here.
Directors of Stop Shop, Inc., grocery chain, yesterday proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock and announced their intention of placing the new stock on a 40-cents a year basis.

That remarkable elder statesman Herbert Hoover, still full of ideas at the age of 81, proposes that Congress create the office of Administrative Vice President to help ease what the first Hoover Commission has well described as the "crushing burden" of the Presidency.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 33 points off to 3 points up yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether employers could refuse to disclose their financial records to a labor union if they rejected wage demands on the ground of inability to pay.
DORRANCE, Kan., Dec. 12 -- Winter wheat is beginning to push its dull green stems through the ground of the drafty plains of central Kansas.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 12 -- Westchester officials took steps today to eliminate "bugs" from the state's Permanent Personal Registration Law so that the county could exercise the option next year of adopting the system for its 377,000 voters.

Whether or not President Eisenhower decides to run in 1956, his recent heart attack focuses the voters' attention on the nominee for Vice President. Too often in the past the nomination has gone to a man on geographical grounds, because he was a genial politician or was felt to deserve some recognition for service to the party.

A committee of the United Nations General Assembly yesterday passed a resolution approaching the problem of preventing war by limiting or abolishing armaments. The trouble with this approach is, of course, that it does not and cannot remove the reasons that make nations willing to go to war with one another.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson voiced sharp criticism today of the Government's security program. He predicted that "none too soon" the "pendulum of passion" would swing back and "these excesses will be corrected."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Warren Lee Stephenson, former Republican leader here, was indicted today for a second time on charges of falsely denying that he had sought to collect fees on Government contracts.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Public school students are not so courteous as they used to be.
Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga ruled yesterday that the dismissal of Melvin L. Barnet as a copy editor on The New York Times was not subject to arbitration.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A drop of 25 to 50 cents pushed butcher hogs back to around their lowest level in 14 years today. Final prices were down the full 50 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Democratic national chairman said today the Republican party had been "the aggressor" in a campaign of class warfare by favoring wealthy taxpayers and big corporations over wage-earners and others.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Twentieth Century-Fox is considering the production of a film about loyalty investigations among Government workers.
Bob Smith, the swimming coach at Bronx Science, has two major training rules that he quotes repeatedly to his squad, "no smoking and no swelled heads."

SINCE Otway's "Venice Preserv'd" is only put on in this town about once a century, students of the drama should be grateful for a chance to see it on the stage. Anyone who did not catch the last performance, in 1838, could have seen it at the Phoenix last evening, where it was offered as the second of the "Sideshow" series.
The wife of a convicted bank embezzler was cleared yesterday of a charge of conspiring in the theft with her husband.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Clint Pace, director of the White House Conference on Education, said today that an exaggerated impression of the endorsement given Federal aid had resulted from the reporting on the conference.

Americans are a freely giving people. Free with their sympathy, free with their advice and knowledge, and generous with their money. So say most of the visitors to the United States. And an impression like that has to start at the huge entrance to the country -- usually the first meeting with the New York public: the porters, taxi drivers, policemen, shopkeepers, and any friends they may then make.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Hamilton House, which stands in Piccadilly a stone's throw from Buckingham Palace, occupies what used to be part of Charles II's extensive orchards. Its Adams green and plastered interior was a thoroughly appropriate backdrop for the fashion collection held privately last week for Queen Mother Elizabeth and Princess Margaret.

Joe Coviello soon may turn to the college ranks in search of new football coaching worlds to conquer. The 41-year-old Memorial High School coach has just completed his tenth straight year of spectacular success at the West New York (N. J.) institution and his record hardly can be improved.
Shouts and catcalls marked a Greenwich Village debate last night on various proposals for handling traffic at Washington Square Park.

WILLINGTON, Conn., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two Army men from New York City and Brooklyn were killed today when their car crashed into the rear of a trailer-truck on the Wilbur Cross Highway here, State Police Lieut. Harry Taylor reported.

Henry Suydam was a first-rate newspaper man and a first-rate public servant. After years of experience as a correspondent and an editor he went to the State Department as liaison officer with the press corps. For the last two years he has been chief of the department's news division, and in that capacity its "spokesman" on matters of international importance. It was a position requiring tact and judgment and an ability to inspire confidence.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 12 -- The Navy will request funds in 1957 to construct the world's first atomic-powered aircraft carrier, Navy officials disclosed today. It would be an 85,000-ton warship.
Continental Air Lines yesterday became the fourth scheduled airline in the country to order Boeing 707 jet transports.
In another typical "year-end tax-selling market," stocks yesterday suffered their heaviest losses since mid-November and closed near their lows for the day.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12--A Western-sponsored disarmament resolution was approved today over Soviet opposition by the General Assembly's Political Committee.

The thermonuclear, or hydrogen, device detonated by the Soviet Union last month was unique in several particulars. The explosion, announced by the United States Atomic Energy Commission on Nov. 23, has caused much speculation in the United States, chiefly because of some of the unusual circumstances surrounding it.
Lawyers were asked last night to give a "proper and unprejudiced appraisal" of the coming report of the Temporary State Commission of the Courts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The busiest public defender of the Eisenhower Administration is turning out to be Harold E. Stassen, the Minnesota boy from Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- British imports last month exceeded exports and re-exports by $196,000,000.

YONKERS, Dec. 12--Four police precinct commands were shaken up today. The shake-up followed nine gambling raids made by Westchester County authorities last Thursday without consultation with Yonkers police.

ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, at Sea, Dec. 12 -- Despite pounding by wind and wave, this Navy icebreaker was moving south today in an attempt to reach and pass through the Antarctic pack ice earlier in the season than almost all expedition ships of the past.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- An Indian proposal for a plebiscite under United Nations supervision was adopted tonight by the Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.
The nation's chain and mail order companies continued their record-breaking 1955 sales pace last month, with volume 11.1 per cent higher than a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court decided today not to disturb a state court judgment that a home in which children are taught that God approves plural marriages is "an immoral environment."
Commercial banks in the New York area had to resort to borrowing from the Federal Reserve System at the end of last week because of the continuing tightness of the money market.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Three Cabinet members will leave tomorrow for the North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris beginning Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Jim Trimble, one of the few National Football League coaches who had held his own with Paul Brown's Cleveland Browns, was dismissed today by the Philadelphia Eagles after his first losing season in four years.

Despite continued Communist threats to Berlin the Soviet military authorities have demonstrated again their control of their sector of the city and thereby acknowledged the quadripartite status of "Greater Berlin." They did this by releasing two American soldiers who were seized by East German police in an area which the Soviet commandant has declared to be under the control and the "laws" of the "sovereign" East German puppet regime.

The Pennsylvania Railroad boasts it is now the owner of the biggest freight-car repair facilities under one roof. James M. Symes, president, announced yesterday that the system's new Samuel Rea shop at Hollidaysburg, Pa., near Altoona, has two of its three and half-mile long assembly lines rolling full speed.

Two former neighbors -- one a 6-foot 6-inch German baron, the other a woman artist-- greeted each other yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court. Each found the other was there for the same charge---ignoring traffic tickets.

It is certainly no "interference" in Australia's internal affairs to take a vital interest in the election that has just been completed there. The Australians are our good and close friends, and the things that concern them rightly concern us.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Mayor Wagner urged today that the Constitution be amended to give New York and other cities immunity from interference by the Legislature with their local affairs.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Kenneth (Jack) Mollenkopf, whose powerful lines made Purdue the best defensive team in the Big Ten this fall, was promoted to head football coach today.

AFTER a week-end of meditation, boxing fans were still wearing stunned looks yesterday. They were unable to comprehend the sheer brilliance of Sugar Ray Robinson in his swift destruction of Bobo Olson for the middleweight championship. The enthusiasts kept groping for parallels in boxing history, and kept bumping their heads against the ancient truism that "They never come back." Yet Robinson came all the way back at the age of 35.

A ten-year study in Newburgh and Kingston, N. Y., has provided "irrefutable evidence" that fluoridation of drinking water is safe and effective, State Health Commissioner Herman E. Hilleboe declared last night.

Following is the complete list of voluntary nonprofit hospitals in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that the Ford Foundation believed yesterday would be eligible for its grants to improve and extend services. In addition, there is listed the hospital with the largest grant in each of the remaining states and territories. In each case, final determination of eligible hospitals and exact grant remains to be made by the foundation.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Because of the large number of tax certiorari suits brought against Yonkers in connection with the 1955 real estate tax assessments, the city may face a problem in returning large sums to taxpayers in the coming year.

As New York adorned herself in lights for Christmas, other signs of the Yuletide developed in the city. There was music yesterday to ease the commuter's way, the party pace had quickened, and Santa's helpers turned up in such places as banks and offices.
Continued heavy cargo, passenger and air movements last month sent customs collections soaring here above the $43,000,000 mark.
Steel production rose to 2,416,000 net tons last week, equaling the record set two weeks previously, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- Since yesterday about 415 former German prisoners have returned to their homeland from the Soviet Union. It was the first shipment since Moscow suspended repatriation Oct. 20.
The Federal Housing Administration started a court action yesterday to recover $3,158,000 in asserted windfall profits from a major Brooklyn housing project.
OTTAWA, Dec. 12 -- Archbishop Boris questioned today the christianity of the United States Administration in an interview here.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- East Acres Phar Wind, a son of Priam II, won the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today. The 4-5 shot was the only favorite to score on the nine-race program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today he would hold hearing next year on the Hoover Commission's proposal to lighten the load of the President.

LANDSTUHL, Germany, Dec. 12 (AP) -- John D. Jones, French-born United States airman, has recovered his childhood memory blanked out by a Nazi air raid, and found the parents from whom he was separated during World War II.
NIGHT rules the north at this time of year, and Scandinavian Christmas traditions are based on symbolism of light and hope.
New issues of corporate securities totaling $10,320,000 will be offered to investors today as follows:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- The high-pressure world of New York modeling and fashions is the basis of a new filmed TV series being packaged by the William Morris Agency.

Following is the statement issued by the Ford Foundation trustees announcing $500,000,000 grants to increase teacher salaries in privately supported colleges and universities, extend services of voluntary nonprofit hospitals and improve instruction in privately supported medical schools:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate Democratic leader, expressed the hope today that President Eisenhower would be able to run for a second term if he so chose.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- If the major parties really want to help the farmer they should remove the question of price-support levels from campaign platforms, Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, declared today.
