QUEBEC, Dec. 12 -- Measures to establish Government control over the pulp and paper industry will be introduced in the Quebec Legislative Assembly when the session resumes tomorrow, Premier Maurice Duplessis announced today.
Mayor Wagner absolved Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross yesterday of any wrongdoing in her administration of the city prisons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Eisenhower held out hope today for an early balance of the Federal budget. He did so in putting his new legislative program before the Republican Congressional leaders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A threat to expel the Air Line Pilots Association from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has been suspended.
I have read the letter of your correspondent bemoaning the passing of the pneumatic tubes through which the mail used to be transported in the New York district.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Dec. 12 -- The Protestant churches of the United States will have spent nearly $8,000,000,000 on new church construction during the twenty-five-year period that began in 1950, it was predicted here today.

QUEMOY, China, Dec. 11 -- The Chinese Nationalist commander here declared today United States policy was keeping him from harassing construction work designed to increase the Communist artillery potential against this island.
LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Lancaster County's paratyphoid outbreak was declared under control today with the number of cases reported so far at 153.
Needy city boys will enjoy summer camp vacations as a result of the twenty-fourth annual Groton-St. Mark's School dance to be held on Monday at the Roosevelt Hotel.
MacManus, John Adams, Inc., one of the top twenty-five agencies in the country, announced yesterday a major expansion and reassignment of its top officers.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Greater sharing of information on defense, including nuclear weapons, will be urged upon the United States, Britain and Canada by the other countries of the Atlantic alliance.

Futures trading on the New York commodity exchanges was unusually dull yesterday. Most items moved narrowly in featureless activity. Changes were irregular, with cottonseed oil, copper, rubber, hides and sugar higher; coffee, cocoa, onions, potatoes and wool lower, and soybean oil mixed.

Following are the 615 privately supported colleges and universities receiving endowment grants from the Ford Foundation to help increase teachers' salaries. Those marked with an asterisk are also receiving "accomplishment grants" in addition. Both sums are included in the listed grants, which remain approximate and subject to correction. Where grant listings are blank, information remains incomplete.

The Ford Foundation's program of grants, announced yesterday, is literally stupendous. Its total comes to $500,000,000 -- by far the largest amount given by any foundation for a single program in all history.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 -- Recent crucial tests of atomic power plants have increased confidence in their safety, the Nuclear Engineering and Science Congress was told today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that the solution of the water problem of California and much of the West depended on the economical de-salting of sea-water.
A traffic experiment to end congestion in Queens succeeded yesterday -- but it created chaos in Manhattan streets.

JUDGED within the context of contemporary television, last night's presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty" was enthralling viewing. For perhaps millions of set owners the TV medium has opened up another new world.

People who buy Christmas seals in the Cathedral Post Office usually get also an affectionate pat on the shoulder and a sparkling smile. Most of them are now friends of the 88-year-old volunteer, Mrs. Louisa Newkirk, who has kept her post in the lobby for four years.

TELEVISION undertook an ambitious project last night when the National Broadcasting company devoted a color broadcast of an hour and a half to the Sadler's Wells Ballet in "The Sleeping Beauty" on the "Producers Showcase" program.
Legislation that would provide American exporters with credit guarantees against political risks abroad was urged here yesterday by a United States Senator.

Last night's premiere of the motion picture "The Rose Tattoo" at the Astor Theatre realized $40,000 for the benefit of the Actors Studio, according to a spokesman for Paramount Pictures, the film's distributor. Tickets were $50 each.
Three top posts in the City Administration were filled by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
The Public Service Commission upheld yesterday an increase of 10 cents a month in minimum rates for gas sold by the Consolidated Edison Company.

My congratulations for publishing the full text of Atomic Energy Commissioner Thomas E. Murray's epochal Fordham University address of Nov. 17. Six days after he warned that "America has invented nuclear weapons capable of destroying all human life" the Atomic Energy Commission revealed that the Russians had matched the American achievement -- the invention of a fission - fusion - fission bomb more powerful than a million tons of TNT.

The Texas Company plans to spend about $1,500,000,000 in the next five years to improve and expand its facilities "all along the line," Augustus C. Long, president, said yesterday. He estimated that more than one-half of that sum will be spent on drilling and exploration activities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Directors of City National Bank and Trust Company declared an increased quarterly dividend today of 75 cents a share on the capital stock payable Feb. 1 to stockholders of record Jan. 20. Previous quarterly payments have been 50 cents a share.

Miss Ronna Hitchcock is among the young women who will be presented to society at the twentieth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball Monday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Hitchcock is the daughter of Mrs. Herschel V. Williams of Washington and of William Hitchcock, and is a granddaughter of Mrs. Cahill Cates of the Carlyle and Burlingame, Calif.
ROME, Dec. 13 -- Reports that the Roman Catholic Church is seeking a compromise or truce with communism contains no truth L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, said today.

Blessings and questions poured down on the Ford Foundation yesterday. Throughout the country, private colleges, universities and hospitals were reckoning how best to use the record $500,000,000 in grants announced Monday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 13 -- Industrious Sweden reported for work as usual today but the mental and physical exertion in offices, factories, mines and on farms will not raise productivity levels.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Following is the speech on the membership problem by Dr. T. F. Tsiang of Nationalist China in the Security Council today:

The Yankees' 1956 schedule of home games, released yesterday, lists the same number of night games the Bombers have played in recent seasons. The American League champions again will play sixteen after-dark encounters.
Three vice presidents and six directors were elected yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council at its annual meeting in the Statler Hotel.
A sculptured head by an unknown artist was returned here yesterday after undergoing fingerprint tests in Washington to determine whether it was a treasure of Florentine art.
Carmen Basilio, a Canastota (N. Y.) fighter who holds the welterweight championship of the world, yesterday was named the "fighter of the year" by the Boxing Writers Association.
Nasty weather over most of the North Atlantic -- gale force winds and high seas -- is delaying inbound passenger liners from one to three days.
Three network television programs and three movies were among the award winners last night in the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation's first National Mass Media Awards presentation.
Jim Lee Howell yesterday signed a second two-year contract as head coach of the New York Football Giants. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- the once-canceled sale of $68,985,000 in short-term loan notes of eighteen local housing authorities finally came off today.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that every deterrent to communism should be used, including the threat of the hydrogen bomb.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Former Premiers Pierre Mendes-France and Antoine Pinay, leading political rivals, opened the electoral campaign for a new National Assembly tonight by advocating less military service for youth.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A new peak of $10,875,000,000 highway expenditures throughout the non-Communist world will be reached this year. This represents a 21 per cent increase over the previous high set last year.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 13 -- A county by county census of church and synagogue membership in the United States is expected to be released late next year.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Union has recently concluded discussions about new long-term trade and payments agreements with its Eastern European allies. At the same time further steps have been taken to promote regional specialization within the Communist bloc.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Britain is "stumbling" into the air age for want of a clear lead and determined support by the Government, a private group of aviation experts declared today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 -- A basic policy disagreement has caused a mass resignation of some of the principal scientific personnel from the missiles division of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
"Too Bad She's Bad," an Italian-made romantic comedy, will have its United States premiere at the Bijou Theatre on Dec. 24. The film stars Vittorio De Sica and Sophia Loren.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Despite misgivings at the high cost of a world organization the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today a 1956 budget of $48,566,350, a record amount for assessment against the sixty member countries.
The National Association of Concert Managers, now its holding its annual convention at the St. Moritz Hotel, presented a discussion of managerial ethics yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The State Court of Claims held today that five athletic commission physicians were negligent in failing to suspend a boxer later injured fatally in a welterweight bout. The court awarded $30,000 to the fighter's estate.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Buckingham Palace reassured Britons in an unusual statement today that Prince Charles and Princess Anne still believed in Santa Claus.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- The American Motors Corporation had a net loss of $6,956,425 for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, compared with a net loss of $11,071,237 in the previous year. But George Romney, president, reported that the company had made substantial progress this year in the automobile and appliance industries.

Taking a brief respite from it successful series of performance of the full-length "Nutcracker, with which it regales its junio clientele at the City Center these days, the New York City Balle last night devoted itself to it senior clientele by a return to its repertory policy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Prof. Herbert Fuchs today named thirty-four persons he said he knew as Communists employed by the Government before and during World War II.
The use of new "peace of mind" drugs to treat the mentally ill has been complicated by disturbing side effects, a leading neuropsychiatrist reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Both the Soviet Union and the United States have been moving warily toward greater exchange of contacts. Diplomatic discussions on this have been somewhat barren. Nevertheless the past year has seen farmers, engineers, newspaper men and even occasional tourists sailing across the broad ideological ocean.

A number of commuters from Connecticut visited the Public Service Commission here yesterday. They entered pleas that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad return to punctuality. An official of the line promised that it planned to do that, and more. He said things should be much better around Feb. 1.

While attention has naturally been focused on the phenomenal production and sales performance of the auto industry's Big Three, the independents, or Little Three, have been quietly putting on quite a show themselves. So far this year, their output has amounted to more than 330,000 cars, a jump of 48 per cent over last year's level.

Joe Stratton, a 5-foot 10-inch guard, scored the winning basket with thirty seconds to go last night as Colgate scored a 67-66 triumph over Columbia at University Hall on the Morningside Heights campus. However, before the decision was final, the teams were called back on the court to "replay" the last two seconds.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 13 -President Eisenhower flew back here today from Washington. He settled down at his farm for an extended period of light activity in sharp contrast to the last two weeks.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 13 -- Yugoslav Government leaders believe that the Soviet Union still is seeking relaxation of tension with the Western world.
UNTIL "The Thesmophoriazusae" was produced at the Rooftop Theatre last evening, Aristophanes was a man with a reputation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- American importers apparently took more seriously than did the Reds the era of freer trade talked about at the summit meeting in Geneva last July. Government figures released today covering trade between this country and Russia and her European satellites showed that the Reds purchased only about $1,000,000 worth of American goods during the three months from July 1 to Sept. 30.

PROBABLY one of the last places you'd expect to find a 345-year-old Jacobean room would be high in the Empire State Building, built less than thirty years ago. Yet that's where one is, linked by ancient doors with a Gascon chamber originally put together in a chateau near Dax in southwest France and a Georgian room made for the Guildhall in London in 1730.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 13 -- Premier Pibul Songgram will leave tomorrow for neutralist Burma with the hopes of the anti-Communist nations in his hands.
Dr. Otto John's plunge behind the Iron Curtain was the deepest mystery of a cloak-and-dagger career.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 13 -- It is understood on good authority that the Government has accepted British proposals that Jordan should join the Baghdad Pact and that the present British-Jordanian treaty should be displaced by a new treaty similar to the British-Iraqi treaty.

The Dramatists Guild has taken its first official step in the dispute with United Scenic Artists Local 829. Members of the guild have been instructed not to sign individual agreements with the union. The guild's action, which was authorized at a special meeting of the governing board on Dec. 6, became known yesterday.
Stories of the city's Neediest have taken at least one mind off personal troubles and helped swell the current total of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to $140,177.02.

By a simple rearrangement of the street traffic pattern, an experiment to move three lanes of vehicles into the city through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel was successful yesterday. The first day's test on Monday ended in chaos at Second Avenue near Thirtysixth Street because there was only a single exit from the south tube, converted to twoway flow for the morning rush.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court was accused today of hypocrisy in expressing his views on the Soviet Union.
The Correction Officers Benevolent Association unanimously called last night for a City Council investigation of the Correction Department.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 13 -- Syria's military alliance with Egypt was a factor in the Israeli decision to attack Syria Sunday night. The move was made after consideration of the adverse effect it might have on Israel's appeal to the United States for arms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Ezra Taft Benson promised farmers today a limited easing of Federal crop controls and "new programs" for corn, cotton and other surplus farm products.
The amateur standing of Wes Santee, America's premier miler, is still under investigation by the Amateur Athletic Union.
A sightless old fellow padded into the Christmas Sale for the Blind yesterday behind the dog that always leads him. He had come to help out.

MARY MacKENZI, a New York-born contralto, made her debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall as the 1955 winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation award. Miss MacKenzie is a graduate of the Julliard School of Music and a winner of awards from the National Federation of Music Clubs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that more Americans were available to work in the third quarter of this year than any time in the nation's history.

AT the Salpeter Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, is a holiday group show including both artists of the gallery and major twentieth century figures. There is, for example, a Gorky oil relating to Gris and Braque, which reminds us how close Gorky's generation of "new talent" was to the French tradition.

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 13 (UP) -- The television spectacular of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus here on Friday will be the final performance for Merle Evans, conductor of the circus band.

ALMOST 500 years ago (in the year 1457 to be precise) James II of Scotland issued a decree that "The futeball and golfe be utterly cried downe and not be used." The Scots' enthusiasm for those sports was interfering with military training.
A former Baltimore police magistrate was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of twenty years to life because he hired the killer in a Brooklyn murder.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of the "Christmas Show" at the Radio City Music Hall on Monday night for the benefit of the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women. The entire mezzanine has been taken over to raise funds for the beneficiary.

An investment banking group headed jointly by the First Boston Corporation and A. E. Ames Co., Inc., will offer publicly today a new issue of $50,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent twenty-five year debentures of the Quebec Hydro-Electric Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- A summary of today's voting in the Security Council on membership applications follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Spokesmen for disappointed applicants for admission to the United Nations were divided tonight on who was responsible for the rejection of the membership deal.
George Meany charged yesterday that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia were allies of Russian communism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Congress notified the Civil Service Commission today that it wanted to know more about securityloyalty files the Executive Branch had collected on Congressmen.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -Dr. Otto John, West German intelligence chief who deserted to East Germany in 1954, returned yesterday.

GEORGE VOSKOVEC had an actor's dream assignment last night. Appearing on the "Armstrong Circle Theatre" over Channel 4, Mr. Voskovec, a native of Czechoslovakia, played himself in a true story of his detention on Ellis Island and eventual admission to the United States.

IN the old days the toffs and the aristocrats condescended to serve as "patrons" for various fighters. One of them, the Marquis of Queensberry, even devised the code under which the supposed Manly Art of Self-Defense now operates. But that slumming expedition long has ended. Boxing lapsed back to normal and the jungle reclaimed its own.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 -- Hundreds of starlings that descend each dusk on Stamford's City Hall clock have almost put the venerable timepiece out of business.

The solid faith of children -and of mothers, too -- in the powers of Santa Claus was manifested yesterday among the thousands of letters addressed to him at the General Post Office, at Thirty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy made it clear yesterday to business representatives that he did not want policemen to accept Christmas gratuities.

QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Delegates from Chile, Ecuador and Peru said today their countries were ready to permit commercial fishing and whaling within their territorial waters provided that foreign fishing craft obtained the necessary permit and submit to existing regulations.

The 105 - family apartment house that was erected in 1932 on the blockfront at 735 Pelham Parkway North in the Bronx has been acquired by a client of Tricap Realty Corporation in the purchase of the stock of Parkview Manor, Inc.

AS CHRISTMAS draws nearer, the panic begins. The gift list narrows down to the difficult items, something for a bachelor, an older 'woman; the business acquaintance. If large stores are too crowded for lunch-hour shopping, the smaller shops in the Midtown area may have some suggestions to solve individual gift problems.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- John D. Dingell Jr., 29-year-old son of the late Representative Dingell, was elected today to the seat formerly held by his father.

Chlorophyll is no longer green gold. Not very long ago it blossomed in all sorts of products and caused rivers of green ink to overflow in advertising. Toothpaste went green, sheets, shoe linings, chewing gum, dog food, mouthwash, even cigarettes and tobacco, diapers and bubble baths, socks and shampoos, mothballs and deodorants -- all went green.
ROME, Dec. 13 -- Failure of the United Nations Security Council to reach agreement on new admissions caused keen disappointment in Italy.

The Board of Health has completed a comprehensive and favorable report on artificial fluoridation of the city's drinking water. Mayor Wagner is expected to receive the study around the end of the year.

HONG KONG, Dec. 13 -Richard R. Tenneson, turncoat former prisoner of the Korean war, refused today to explain his return although he knew he might face serious charges when he returned to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House, urged caution today in an approach toward tax reductions, even in the 1956 election year. This was in the face of predictions made by Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, and a leading member of the Finance Committee, that perhaps $3,500,000,000 could be cut from income revenue payments next year.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Communist leadership has embarked on a campaign to uproot inefficiency from provincial organizations preparatory to the twentieth party congress early next year.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 13 -A. B. (Happy) Chandler took the oath as Governor of Kentucky today for his second term. Later he told a news conference: "I have no other political ambitions now; my only ambition is to do a good job for my people."

SOUTHERN recipes for beaten biscuits dating back a century or two direct that the batter be pounded with a hatchet or a club for twenty-five to thirty minutes. Too much work for the modern, muscleless cook, of course, but she can obtain equally good results by putting the dough through a food chopper.

The Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., maker of television receivers and communications equipment, has sold its plant at 1500 Main Street in Clifton, N. J., to the Getty Clifton Corporation. The property consists of seven acres, a powerhouse and two buildings, two and four stories high, with about 150,000 square feet of space.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 13 -The Maine Turnpike Authority officially opened to the public today sixty-three miles of toll highway, from here to Augusta. It joins the original forty-threemile section beginning at Kittery, which was dedicated just eight years ago today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- An orderly shrinkage of agricultural production should be the first step in any new program to improve the farm economy, Charles B. Shuman declared today.
David O. Selznick, the motion-picture producer, has sold nine feature-length films to a television distributor for an amount said to be "over $1,000,000."

Charles H. Hills has been elected president of 345 West 145th Street Management, Inc., agent for the 211-family apartment house being erected by the Bowery Savings Bank on 145th Street, between St. Nicholas and Edgecombe Avenues.

WHEN there is skating on the lakes and ponds, the ducks are on the bays and rivers, so Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey wildfowlers should have their best shooting during the rest of this season.

While apparently agreeing with my analysis of the failure of our European policy, Livingston Hartley in his letter published Dec. 5 says that in proposing the neutralization of Germany have "reached the wrong conclusion." He advocates, instead, the political and economic integration of West Germany in a more closely knit Atlantic community.

THE accolade of the Museum of Modern Art is granted to artists of promise as well as those of fame. And now, in the eighth New Talent exhibition of a series, work by a sculptor, an etcher and an oil painter is being shown.

Harness racing purses this year totaled more than $20,000,000. One horse, Adios, was sold during the year for $500,000. These figures show that harness racing is a big industry. It is far from a millionaire's sport, however, as members of the Weequahic Park Amateur Trotting Club can attest.
Christmas trees burst into electric bloom last evening at parks and plazas in the five boroughs.
Forty-two per cent of the pupils who entered the city's academic high schools last fall are reading below their potential ability.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -The state's high school principals protested today that they were the forgotten men of the school system in respect to salaries.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities with a par value of $23,700,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates following purchases made yesterday at public sealed bidding. The offerings are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The State Department got a pat on the back today for increasing its fitness to wage this country's diplomatic battles around the world.

The World Council of Churches announced plans yesterday to build new headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. The announcement was made by Dr. Eugene Carson Blake of the council's executive committee at the annual meeting of the Friends of the World Council of Churches.

WHEN it revived its production of Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" at Town Hall last night, the American Opera Society had the happy thought of filling out the bill with Monteverdi's "Il Combattimento di Tancredi e Clorinda."

Basketball tournament time is here. Starting this Friday with the DePaul competition in Chicago and continuing almost without cease through the following two weeks, the nation's top varsity quintets will assemble at various points for showdown play.

"Background to Bitterness," by Henry Gibbs, will be issued Jan. 16 by Philosophical Library. Mr. Gibbs, who has traveled widely in Africa, traces from the first Dutch settlement the historical events out of which arose the present racial and political conflicts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -The Air Force is taking a new look through psychologists' eyes at its controversial "brainwashing" interrogation course.

QUEBEC, Dec. 13 -- The Quebec Legislative Assembly today gave a first reading to a law that would subject the giant pulp and paper industry to Government control of production prices and distribution within the province. It also would ban the export of raw pulpwood for manufacture elsewhere.
A union appeal was made yesterday for some kind of highlevel Federal intervention -- by President Eisenhower if possible -- to end the fifty-nine day strike against the Westinghouse Electric Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Warner Brothers has decided to jettison the "King's Row" section of its A. B. C. television show, "Warner Brothers Presents." The dramas, built around a turn-of-the-century physician's attempts to change prejudices about psychological medicine, will be replaced by a more adventurous type of anthology series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Treasury Department reported today that sales of Series E and H savings bonds during the first eleven months of this year were 11 per cent ahead of sales in the same period of last year.

"SEE IT NOW" last night had a most apt subtitle: "Two American Originals." The program on Channel 2 offered television portraits of Grandma Moses, the painter, and Louis Armstrong, the trumpeter, in an hour that was immensely interesting.

The old adage that truth is stranger than fiction has been proved again by the latest development in the case of Dr. Otto John. It was sensational enough when the then chief of the West German security service defected to East Germany in the summer of 1954.

A Bronx lad took another crack at military life yesterday. When John S. Coyle Jr. of 4523 Hill Avenue was 15 years old he enlisted in the New York National Guard and served for several months before discovery of his age demobilized him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -President Eisenhower put before the Congressional leaders of both parties today an expanded defense and foreign information program and besought bipartisan support.

A real showpiece of a great library system began its service to the public yesterday when the Donnell Regional Branch at 20 West Fifty-third Street opened its doors. The four-story building of Indiana limestone in the busy heart of Manhattan is thoroughly contemporary in design and appointments, but warmth and comfort are not lost.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 13 (UP) -- Senator Kefauver said tonight the Republican foreign policy reminded him of the pocket gopher, an animal that "can run just as fast backwards as he can forwards."

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The referee had to order the ring cleared in a wild eight-round fight tonight between Miguel Diaz, 150 pounds, Havana, and Danny Giovanelli, 151, Brooklyn. Diaz went on to earn a split decision before 2,160 fans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Warner Brothers, which had four winners out of a possible five in the film Audience Awards announced last week, is mining cash dividends from the publicity generated by the popularity contest.

The long-repeated attempt to add new members to the United Nations collapsed again yesterday. It collapsed because an attempted blackmail by Russia proved unacceptable to several Governments, including the key Government of Nationalist China, which vetoed Outer Mongolia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission heard final arguments today in a dispute over railroad rates on imported iron ore handled through the Ports of Philadelphia, Baltimore, Boston and New York.
An embittered five-year struggle between "university" and "county" physicians for control of the city's biggest hospital, the Kings County Hospital Center, is nearing a final showdown.
An enlarged tournament program for the golfers of this area was recommended yesterday by Fred Marsh, president of the Metropolitan Golf Association.
CHICAGO. Dec. l3 -- Railroad Transfer Service, Inc. has been operating illegally since Oct. 1. Judge Walter J. LaBuy ruled in Federal District Court today.
The Board of Education's committee on instructional affairs decided yesterday to refer to the full board the controversial guide for teaching moral and spiritual values.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Never before has the Soviet Union's policy yielded a harvest of vetoes approaching that of this afternoon.

Directors of the Western Maryland Railway ordered payment yesterday of a dividend of $19,250,070, or $108.50 a share, on the company's $7 first preferred stock. The payment, to be made on Dec. 28 to holders of record Dec. 23, clears all arrears on the issue and puts the stock on a current basis for the first time since 1917, when the present company was organized.

Any one of his numerous contributions to medicine would justify the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in naming Dr. Charles W. Mayo the recipient of its 1955 Scientific and Research Award. A distinguished surgeon himself, Dr. Mayo has carried on and advanced the traditions of his illustrious father and uncle, whose names were synonymous with the finest in scientific medicine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Two officers of the National Wildlife Federation disagreed today on the effect on new Federal regulations dealing with oil and gas leasing on national wildlife refuges.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Syria asked today for a meeting of the Security Council to take up her new charges of armed aggression by Israel.
A battle is being shaped between the can-makers and the glass container producers over how products are to be packed.
Publishers of the defunct Brooklyn Eagle must arbitrate demands for severance and notice-of-dismissal pay, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.
A draft code for Health Department licensing and regulation of summer day camps for children 6 to 13 years old was opposed yesterday as likely to interfere with freedom of religion.

In all his 65 years Edward V. (Captain Eddie) Rickenbacker has been breaking traditions and defying the law of chance. Yesterday Eastern Air Lines, of which he is chairman, disclosed that he had broken still another tradition.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 10 to 43 point: (50 cents to $2.15 a bale) yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns and the runner-up Washington Redskins contributed seven players each to the Eastern Conference All-Star team that will meet the Western Conference Stars in the sixth Pro Bowl football game at Memorial Coliseum Jan. 15, it was revealed today.

Wool prices fell yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Hedge selling depressed prices. Scattered commission house liquidation was absorbed by short covering and hedge lifting. The market ignored steady prices on good volume at the Australian auctions and followed lower prices in London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Commission on Government Security will finally begin tomorrow its monumental task of surveying Government security programs and procedures.
A complete breakdown in the city's traffic summons system and resulting chaos in the streets was threatened yesterday by a magistrate's ruling.
NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Dec. 14 -- The Premiers of the Soviet Union and India declared yesterday that to establish world peace no course was open but that of disarmament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Dixon-Yates power interests sued the United States today for $3,534,778.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- A carefully prepared deal for the admission of eighteen new members to the United Nations was rejected today by the vetoes of the Soviet Union and Nationalist China.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 -- A drastic reduction of the maximum limit of radiation to which workers in atomic plants may be exposed was recommended today at the Nuclear Engineering and Science Congress.
Seeking to return to winning ways after losing twice last week-end, the New York Rangers will oppose the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec 13 -- The Air Force said today that a security clearance had been restored to Dr. Andrew Fejer, a University of Toledo, Ohio, professor and part-time Air Force consultant.

A total of 115,000,000 Americans own some form of life insurance. This was disclosed yesterday at the seventeenth annual meeting of the Institute of Life Insurance in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The findings are the result of a study made for the institute by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan.

A local metropolitan newspaper commented a few weeks ago on a protest lodged by the A. S. P. C. A. about the overcrowding of live turkeys into crates while being shipped to New York for the pre-Thanksgiving Day slaughter. The A. S. P. C. A. claimed that this was unduly cruel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles left for Paris today hopeful that the North Atlantic Council would agree on a common assessment of Soviet foreign policy and on a common answer to it.
BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- A. D. N., official East German news agency, said tonight the intention of Dr. Otto John to return to West Germany had been known for some time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Cotton farmers voted overwhelmingly today to continue Federal production controls for the third consecutive year.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Sir Anthony Eden intends to discuss with President Eisenhower the topics he will raise with the Soviet leaders when they visit Britain next spring.

Committee members working for the success of the Tiara Ball on Dec. 29 will attend a tea this afternoon in the home of Mrs. Wickliffe W. Crider of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street. Mrs. Crider, chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Owen R. Cheatham, vice chairmen, will be co-hostesses at the tea. A business meeting devoted to plans for the ball will follow.

When Averell Harriman made his principal campaign speech in Rockland County at Haverstraw on Oct. 24, 1954, the candidate said: One of the things we're going to do is to eliminate the practice of by-passing local agencies in planning state projects.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 13 -- The new dean of the Yale University Graduate School will be Dr. Hartley Simpson, a member of the university's history faculty since 1930. The appointment is effective next July 1.
The Federal Pacific Electric Company is considering new financing to raise about $4,000,000, stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Newark, N. J.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 13 -- A small tug, the Kevin B., caught fire in Long Island Sound about one mile off shore from here at 1 P.M. today. Her crew of three got off safely, but a falling tide hampered efforts to extinguish the blaze. At 7:30 P. M. the Coast Guard said the tug still was burning and that the fire appeared to have increased in intensity.
In cooperation with other Securities markets and the managements of 5,000 public-owned corporations, the New York Stock Exchange is starting a new census of the shareholder population of the country.

A dispatch to this newspaper from Singapore has recorded some of the impressions of British refugees as to what is happening in Shanghai. There is some significance in the fact that we should be dependent, at this point, for news from one of the largest cities in the world upon the reports of persons who have fled from it.
A recipe for sweet nut rolls won the $25,000 top prize for Mrs. Henry Jorgensen, Portland, Ore., in the seventh annual Pillsbury "Bake-off" at the Waldorf yesterday.
Governor Harriman announced yesterday his unqualified support of Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio's investigation of private detective agencies.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- December wheat showed a particularly strong tone today, advancing as shorts covered, with most other deliveries scoring smaller gains.

SILVER appointments for the fashionable English dollhouse of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries were fairly rare in their day. Today, these gleaming miniatures are being bought and sold at "lunatic prices," according to a New York dealer who recently acquired a large collection.

On a cold, clear southern summer morning on Dec. 14, 1911, Roald Amundsen reached the South Pole. Two days later he speared a Norwegian flag into the ice, the first man to make any such victor's claim to the Antarctic quest.
The test case of legislative immunity that arose in the course of a test case on the constitutionality of the emergency business space rent control law has failed to materialize.

The New York Knickerbockers gained a firmer hold on second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by halting the Minneapolis Lakers, 98 to 91, in the feature game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.
For the fifth straight year the National Football League smashed attendance records during the 1955 season in spite of miserable weather that plagued some clubs during the early part of the season.
Election of Lewis W. Douglas as a director of the Empire Trust Company was announced yesterday by Henry C. Brunie, president.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a Federal Tax Court ruling that the Pennroad Corporation did not have to report as corporate income a $12,000,000 settlement with its parent, the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Faced with the threat of punitive action by the Waterfront Commission, the New York Shipping Association yesterday suspended a new hiring procedure. The procedure had been based upon an interpretation of the word "notify," in the association's contract with the International Longshoremen's Association.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- West Coast shipowners and heads of three maritime unions covering unlicensed personnel signed today a coast-wise master contract.

A proposed merger of the Sterling Precision Instrument Corporation, Buffalo, and Yawman Erbe Manufacturing Company, Rochester, was announced yesterday. The plan must be approved by stockholders of both companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today arrangements were almost complete for purchase of 100,000 tons of surplus United States Sugar for use in the foreign aid program.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 13 -Wilber M. Brucker, United States Secretary of the Army, ended a two-day visit to Formosa today with a flying trip to Nationalistheld Quemoy Island off the mainland.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's double bill of "The Telephone" and "The Medium" was presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night as the season's third event of the Major Concert Series of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
A $1,000,000 home, modeled after a motel to give easy access to recreation rooms and open courtyards, will be built by New York State next year for 200 senile aged persons.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A St. Louis physician said today he was completely convinced that a third sex -- the neutral gender -rapidly is increasing.
The United Lutheran Church of America is moving toward liberalization of its twenty-five-year position on the remarriage of divorced persons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Navy disclosed today it had taken an important step toward the development of an atomic-powered seaplane capable of circling the earth at tremendous speeds.
New York State bankers spread some of their ideas on charging the Banking Law before a Joint Legislative Committee yesterday.
Appointments of four vice presidents at the head office of the First National City Bank of New York and two resident vice presidents overseas were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -The Indian Bureau announced today that 3,500 Indians, a record number, left their reservations during 1954-55 and moved to areas that offered greater employment advantages.

LONDON, Dec 13 -- The widening of trade gap in November, accentuated by Wall Street's setback yesterday acted as a brake on buying when the stock markets opened today. Government stocks fell rather sharply. Prices steadied later and although the closing tone was bright, losses outnumbered gains at the close.
The stocks yesterday opened mixed; staged moderate gains and then dipped near the close. Rails had a rather considerable loss and industrials a modest gain.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- A dramatic incident marked the return to West Germany today of 596 German prisoners from the Soviet Union.
Bob Friend, a right - handed pitcher who labored in the unproductive Forbes Field vineyard for the 1955 Pirates, made some major league history this year.

James D. Norris Jr., president of the International Boxing Club, has a good word to say for the Boxing Guild of New York yesterday. Recently returned from his Chicago promotion of the Ray Robinson-Carl (Bobo) Olson fight, Norris commented freely on the action taken Monday by the New York State Athletic Commission against the Guild.

General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries, including Theodore Gary Co. and subsidiaries acquired by merger on Oct. 31, reported sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for ten and twelve months ended Oct. 31.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 13 (UP) -The text of the Indian-Soviet joint declaration issued today:
Sales of homes to five professional men have been reported by Waxman Brothers, builders of Seaview Village, a development at Rockaway Parkway and Avenue M in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Paid employes of the Communist party of the United States of America and of state affiliates no longer are eligible for Social Security benefits.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.
SANTA CLAUS slid down the antenna last night for a cheerful hour in "The Miracle on Thirty-fourth Street" on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

A new split-level dwelling containing seven rooms and occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 25 Coolidge Street, in Larchmont, Westchester County, was sold by Adam Sumetz to Frank I. Bertsch, who is employed by the American Bosch Arma Corporation in Garden City, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a new proposal today for revising its proxy rules, and asked for comments from interested parties by Dec. 28.
ROBERT McFERRIN, baritone who made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera last season, sang his first Town Hall recital last evening. He left no doubt that he is a major vocal talent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- General Motors Corporation was charged today with false advertising in connection with the sale of parts for Chevrolet cars. The complaint was filed by the Federal Trade Commission.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 14 -- Governor Harriman scored the Administration tonight for permitting the "inroads being made by monopoly and bigness."

The American Heart Association will direct each of its affiliates and chapters to withdraw from community-wide united fund campaigns as soon as the association's board of directors deems it advisable.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 14--Gov. Frank J. Lausche of Ohio announced today his candidacy as a favorite son for the Democratic nomination for President. The five-term Governor, mentioned as a possible "dark horse" for the nomination, made the anticipated announcement in a letter to Rudy E. Stapleton, Fulton County Democratic chairman, who had asked permission to use Mr. Lausche's name as first choice "favorite son."

KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 14 (AP)--Unconfirmed reports from North Afghanistan today said Angus Ward, United States Ambassador, had been held by the police for three hours for having entered a restricted area.

The Rangers continued their reverse progress by losing to the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Showing quite differently from the "phenoms" of only a couple of weeks ago, the Broadway Blues found it difficult to do anything right.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Tighter Federal controls over barbiturate distribution were proposed to Congress today to make the search for elusive sleep less dangerous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The Administration announced today a broadening of its surplus disposal program to make wheat and corn available to needy persons in foreign countries through church and private welfare agencies.

Eighteen thousand commuters from Long Island's South Shore were delayed from ten to sixty-five minutes in reaching the city yesterday morning. Thirteen hundred others from Port Washington, Great Neck and North Shore points also were late.

The Ford Foundation's pioneering grants to our nation's voluntary institutions represent one of the greatest educational developments of the century. They are more than a shot in the arm to education, but an incentive and added inspiration to the men and women at the grass roots of education and health.

The American Foundation for Overseas Blind, Inc., announced yesterday that it would spend $505,000 next year to improve education, rehabilitation and employment for the blind of more than twenty countries.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The United Nations community in 1957 will be more crowded, more colorful and talkier.

The Atlas Corporation, investment company dealing primarily in special situations, plans a recapitalization tantamount to a four-for-one stock split and a lmerger with five concerns in which it has major interests. The consolidated organization would have assets of about $110,000,000.
The Waterfront Commission refused to yield yesterday on its ruling that a new longshore hiring procedure was illegal.

You have correctly stated on the editorial page of The New York Times on Dec. 8 that while the Western powers after the second World War freed some 600,000,000 people from colonial rule and continued to free others capable of self-government, the Soviets during the same period enslaved and changed into colonies of the most degrading type more than 600,000,000 free and independent people.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports in livestock trading here today:
The jet age in American aviation will result in capital expenditures as high as $3,000,000,000 in the next ten years, Selig Altschul, financial consultant, predicted yesterday.

Directors of the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation yesterday approved the formation of Hoffman International Corporation for the consolidation of European subsidiaries into one corporate unit.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 -- Premier Bulganin and Mr. Khrushchev left Palam Airport at 10:45 this morning after acknowledging the cheers of crowds along the twelve-mile route from the state guest house.

Gifts great both in amount and spirit poured into the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. The contributions for the day totaled $25,142.58. This swelled the amount of the Fund to date to $165,319.60.

There was a time when a performance of Handel's "Messiah" was the inevitable concert harbinger of Christmas. For the last five years, however, it has been Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ." Last night the Little Orchestra Society under Thomas Scherman offered its fifth annual Christmas presentation of the masterpiece in Carnegie Hall.
The United Jewish Appeal reported yesterday that it had received $17,000,000 in pledges since last month in its special drive for $25,000,000 for emergency programs among newcomers in Israel.

WITH the department stores open late these evenings for the Christmas rush, some of the ladies who customarily are before their television sets on Wednesdays to see the Kraft Theatre may have missed last night's show.

In 1951, Paul Reynaud, the French statesman who spent the war years as a prisoner of the Germans, published his explanation of how France "gravitated" into war and why her army was crushed in 1940. It was titled "Au Coeur de la Melee."
Plans have been completed for the Christmas series of Holiday Dances to be held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Huntington Tappin is chairman of the patroness committee for the dances.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- A Massachusetts Supreme Court decision today ruled that the chairman and secretary of the Democratic State Committee were elected illegally three years ago. It renewed the fight between two factions to control the committee.
PROBLEMS of what sculpture is or should be do not concern Constantino Nivola, whose vivid, inventive temperament is revealed in his work on exhibition at the Peridot Galley, 820 Madison Avenue.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Gil Turner's stronger finish tonight gained a majority ten-round decision for him over Jackie LaBua in a bristling fight at War Memorial Auditorium.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 14 -- There are signs of disagreement within Israel over the attack on Syrian positions Sunday night northeast of the Sea of Galilee.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The Temporary State Commission on Youth and Delinquency recommended today the enactment of a law under which parents could be punished for the delinquency of their children.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Japan's exclusion from the group of nations approved today for United Nations membership was a bitter pill for the State Department.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Hugh Gaitskell, choice of British socialism's right wing, was elected leader of the Labor party tonight.

The State of South Carolina borrowed $20,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of schools. The money was raised by the sale of general obligation revenue bonds maturing serially on Dec. 1 from 1956 to 1975.

Why is it, if we go out for a stroll in Manhattan, we find ourselves on Fifth or Madison, in Central Park or the corridors of the Metropolitan? Why not along the gray tenement-lined streets to the east and west or the aisles of charity hospital wards?

The Spanish Institute, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a concert to be given by Victoria de Los Angeles, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, on the night of Jan. 13 at Carnegie Hall. Mrs. Edward F. Hutton and Mrs. Julius W. Noyes are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
MOTHER'S kitchen helpers aren't always the latest electrical appliances that whip, beat and stir mechanically. Junior's little hands often are willing assistants.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, Dec. 15 -- United Nations approval of the unexpected Soviet proposal to admit sixteen states but exclude Japan and Communist Outer Mongolia produced surprise and relief mixed with wariness here today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 14 --'I Syrian and Egyptian forces fired' over the .borders at Israelia to. day, according to reports reach. ing 'A ,rmy ,headquarters. here.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 14 (UP) -- British authorities outlawed Communist organizations here today. They arrested 130 Red leaders in a new attempt to stamp out terrorism on the island.

Harry Gross, who was freed last March after a four-year penitentiary sentence as a kingpin bookmaker, was indicted yesterday by a Kings County rackets grand jury for swindling a business woman out of $13,850.
A new master, Capt. Eliezer Acsel, will be on the bridge of the new Israeli passenger liner Israel when the vessel sails from here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A group of unions outside the newly merged labor federation are talking about a merger of their own. They have a meeting scheduled for Sunday in St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Economic activity continued to increase in November with industrial production, employment and incomes showing further expansion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Rockwell Kent, artist and author, and Henry and Anita Parkhurst Willcox, of South Norwalk, Conn., filed suit in United States District Court today to compel the State Department to issue passports to them.

BERLIN, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a reply sent by Georgi M. Pushkin, Soviet Ambassador to East Germany to the United States, British and French protests concerning the four-power status of Berlin:

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Counihan Jr. dismissed today a petition to set aside probate court contempt citations against Mr. and Mrs. Melvin B. Ellis in the Hildy McCoy custody case. He also refused to nullify a habeas corpus writ ordering the couple to produce the child in Norfolk County Probate Court.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 14 (PA) -- Hamilton Richardson, a Rhodes scholar from Westfield, N. J., and Bob Perry of Los Angeles, won their second-round matches in the All-India lawn tennis championships today.
Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx charged yesterday that "Communists and other left-wing groups" were among those seeking repeal of the residence law he sponsored twenty years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The delegation of Japan, hard-hit by the nation's exclusion from the United Nations for this year, called the Security Council's action today "painful and unexpected."

ATLANTA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic floor leader, got a very favorable report from a heart specialist today and talked at length with another Southern Democratic stalwart, Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia.
The International Telephone Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries achieved in the nine months ended Sept. 30 the highest earnings for any similar period in its history.

The Christian Social Relations Committee of the Manhattan Council of Church Women wants to express to you our great appreciation of the help you have given to the effort for larger quarters and better conditions in the Women's House of Detention by your editorials of Nov. 9 entitled "Black Hole of New York" and of Nov. 29 entitled "Prisoners Are People."

At the insistence of Mary Martin and Richard Halliday, her husband and manager, Fred Coe has been assigned as television producer for the repeat performance of "Peter Pan" on the "Producers Showcase" series.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- President Luis Batlle Berres of Uruguay was taken ill at a dinner in his honor here tonight. Officials reported he would be hospitalized "for a few days."
For the first time in the ten-year history of the State Commission Against Discrimination a person charging racial discrimination has sought to overthrow a ruling by the agency.

Mrs. S. Warren Metcalf has been appointed chairman of the junior committee for the Yorkville Dance scheduled for Jan. 13. A benefit for the Yorkville Community Association, the fete will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
The head of the ski school at Dutch Hill in Heartwellville, Vt., is 32-year-old Mike Catrambone. A native of North Adams, Mass., Catrambone has been skiing since he was eight.

Around a sparkling white tree decorated with red and silver balls in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, youngsters of the New York Foundling Hospital were feted yesterday afternoon. The tenth annual Christmas party of the eighty-five-year-old institution at 175 East Sixty-eighth Street was attended by Cardinal Spellman and 1,600 friends and guests.
THOUGH whipping up smooth fudge is no longer the womanly accomplishment it was considered in the days of the Gibson Girl, an interest in fine homemade confections remains.
The proposal for a $23,000,000 housing project for middle-income families on the site of the former Luna Park at Coney Island received tentative approval by the City Planning Commission yesterday.
One way to measure the economic strength of a country is by the "hardness" or "softness" of its currency. By that yardstick, Japan has staged a remarkable comeback from postwar chaos.
Two major American airlines placed orders yesterday for a total of twenty-one turbo-propeller aircraft at a cost of $40,100,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- When the first members were admitted to the United Nations nine years ago, the event was cheerfully hailed as a turning point in history. A wartime coalition was converted into a general organization for the maintenance of world peace.

Mrs. John S. Burke, daughter of the late Justice Thomas William Churchill, will unveil his portrait at ceremonies today at City College's Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- A meeting of tavern owners and bartenders was urged today to help fight the problem of drunken driving. This has been on the upsurge here for five years.

The fifteen-day tour of India by Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin has come to an end with a joint communique issued with Mr. Nehru. There is no doubt that by their Falstaffian antics, by their exploitation of Asian "anti-colonial" sentiment and by their espousal of specifically Indian causes in Goa and Kashmir, the two Soviet chieftains scored a tremendous personal success which gave added impact to their diatribes against the West.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- A Government spokesman announced today that a decision was expected in forty-eight hours on whether there was sufficient evidence to arrest Dr. Otto John, former intelligence chief. He returned Monday from East Berlin.
Two fire lieutenants were promoted to captain and six firemen to lieutenant at a ceremony yesterday in the quarters of Engine 31, Lafayette and White Streets.
A Rumanian Princess who befriended more than 100 American airmen shot down over the Ploesti oil fields during the war arrived here yesterday as the guest of one of the former captives.

The Israeli attack on the Syrian outposts of the Sea of Galilee, in which at least forty-one Syrians were killed, was a deplorable development in the dangerous Middle Eastern dispute. On the basis of the information thus far available, including the official statement from the Israeli Government, it was a punitive and retaliatory measure, an act of force coming at the end of a long line of such acts which involved both Arabs and Israelis.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Sixteen new members were admitted to the United Nations tonight at the end of one of the most dramatic days in the history of the organization. Japan and Outer Mongolia were not included.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 14 -- Charles P. Taft, younger son of President William Howard Taft, was named Mayor of Cincinnati today.

The report of the New York State Temporary Commission on Youth and Delinquency, made public yesterday, is the first end product of an operation that merits the highest praise as an example of the working of a free democracy. This sharply underlines the significance of its contents, of first public importance in themselves.

WHEN Tom Gola was playing basketball for La Salle College in Philadelphia, he received more extravagant praise than any dribble artist in memory, going all the way back to Hank Luisetti of Stanford and beyond.
Americans have more than half of the world's telephones, but Canadians and Icelanders do more "gabbing" on Alexander Graham Bell's invention.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Administration was accused today of playing anti-Democratic politics in the "cruel and unjust" lay-off of 350 men from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, N. Y.
Pickets from struck plants of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation invaded Wall Street yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The new Cunard liner Carinthia was launched by Princess Margaret at the John Brown Co. shipyard on the Clyde near Glasgow today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 14 -- Representatives of the sixteen newly admitted members of the United Nations who appear tomorrow at the world organization's headquarters will be allowed to be seated, to talk in debate and vote.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Easy Ed Macauley's one-hand push shot from twelve feet out with six seconds remaining enabled the Boston Celtics to edge the New York Knickerbockers, 102 -- 100, tonight in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A former secretary of the National Lawyers Guild today named fifteen attorneys as his fellow members of a Communist party cell in New York in the late Nineteen Thirties.

The output of the nation's oil fields in the week ended last Friday reached a new peak, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Production of crude oil and condensate averaged 6,922,500 barrels a day, a gain of 86,100 over that of the preceding week. The previous peak was 6,863,000 barrels a day reached last March.

ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd now making his fifth trip to the Antarctic, was today nursing minor injuries -- the first he ever received en route to the bottom of the world.

C. D. Jackson, former Assistant to President Eisenhower, said yesterday the success of the United States foreign policy had forced the Soviet Union to shift from military threats and "sabre rattling" to promises of economic aid as a means of winning the "cold war."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 14 -- The Supreme Court tonight, in effect, barred Joao Cafe Filho from returning to the Presidency of Brazil.
Except for one dissenter, a panel of high school pupils expressed yesterday varying shades of pessimism about the world situation.
The first lease negotiated for office space in the Coliseum building nearing completion at Columbus Circle is scheduled to be signed today. The Federation Bank and Trust Company is the lessee.

IN the Greek War of Independence, ships sailed by the men of Hydra, an island in the Aegean, drove the Turks from the sea. The Grand Canyon of the Colorado "is perhaps the most American, the most self-explanatory and the most self-confident of natural prodigies." On the western bank of the Rhine near Duesseldorf the town of Zons "is happily free of all works of art except itself."
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, at Sea, Dec. 14 -- Half a dozen whales emerged today to welcome this Antarctic-bound icebreaker.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 8 points (40 cents a bale) lower on old-crop months and 2 to 4 points (10 to 20 cents a bale) higher on new-crop futures.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Amid cheers, sixteen new states were welcomed into United Nations membership tonight.

Again a fresh bundle of evidence has come along that makes even more insistent the question why is New York City delaying fluoridation of water supply to reduce dental decay in children. Completion and analysis of a ten-year test in Newburgh and Kingston, N. Y., bring "irrefutable evidence," according to Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, that fluoridation of drinking water is safe and effective.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Officials of the Atlantic alliance gathered in Paris today for a kind of council-of-war as it has been waged in its "cold" form since the fruitless conference in Geneva with Soviet leaders.
REPORTS from the South indicate that the fishing is improving. The first big run of sailfish should be moving in the Gulf Stream between Stuart and Palm Beach, Fla., any day.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader, reaffirmed today his electoral alliance with former Premier Pierre Mendes - France despite divergences in their views and records on European unification.

The seventy toll collectors that the Thruway will use in the Rockland-Westchester area were taken on a swift tour yesterday over all the main roads in this city and on Long Island. The State Thruway Authority expects hundreds of motorists to inquire directions daily and wants to make sure its employes know the proper routing through the intricate city maze.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings at Carlton House for the benefit performance of "My Lady Lisa" on April 4 at the Hellinger Theatre. St. Barnabas House at 304 Mulberry Street, which is operated by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, will benefit from the performance.
Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians was established yesterday as the 1955 winner of the American League rookie-of-the-year award presented annually by the Baseball Writers Association of America.
The entire toll length of the New York-Buffalo Thruway will go into operation today with the opening of the twenty-eight-mile section from Suffern to Yonkers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Following are salient facts about sixteen countries approved for membership in the United Nations today:
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson announced today that he was authorizing his supporters to enter his name in the Presidential primaries of California, Florida, Pennsylvania and Illinois.
Directors of the American Chicle Company at a special meeting yesterday proposed a 10 per cent stock dividend.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of the President's message today to the Nuclear Engineering and Science Congress:
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Governor Harriman signaled today the opening of a campaign against discrimination in housing. He did this by making two appointments.

A new schedule of rent rise allowances for landlords who improve their properties was announced yesterday. Effective today, it covers such things as installation of refrigerators, modernization of kitchens and various other benefits.

BERLIN, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union implied tonight that it considered the occupation status of Berlin at an end. In similar notes to the Ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States in Bonn, Georgi M. Pushkin, Soviet Ambassador to East Germany, not only affirmed East German sovereignty in East Berlin but indicated a change in the status of the Western sectors.
Three Brooklyn civic groups came out fighting yesterday to save a proposed city appropriation of $13,000,000 to break the DeKalb Avenue rapid transit bottleneck in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Federal Maritime Board reaffirmed today that the dual rate system was legal under certain competitive conditions.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, California Attorney General, hailed Mr. Stevenson's announcement of his Presidential primary plans as evidence of a "fighting campaign."
Billy Rose, the entertainer, turned city planner yesterday long enough to suggest "a sweeping program of rehabilitation" for Central Park.
MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Another of the surviving Dionne quintuplets is ill in a hospital here.

At the Hanover Bank, 70 Broadway, at 11 o'clock this morning, some envelopes are to be opened. The contents will provide the answer to what is currently the No. 1 question in horse racing: What's to become of Nashua?
The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare called on the insurance industry yesterday for "a renewed display of its traditional enterprise and ingenuity" in aiding the advance of human welfare.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The General Assembly approved today a new United Nations technical assistance program in the field of human rights.
WHAT must be the richest club in the world is now starting in on its latest billion.
A three-day conference on physical fitness began yesterday under the sponsorship of the National Physical Education Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--President Eisenhower was reported today to have called Governor Harriman "a Park Avenue Truman."
Business leaders expect a good year in 1956, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his Monthly Business Review, out today.

The Port Authority's $24,000,000 bus terminal will mark its fifth anniversary today -- still a deficit operation. The facility at Fortieth to Forty-first Street from Eighth to Ninth Avenue, will have handled 44,300,000 passengers this year and 830,000 bus departures, 10 per cent more than in 1951, its first full year of operation.

After repeated efforts to agree on an approach to an increase in freight rates, leaders of the three great segments of the railroad industry -- East, South and West -- will meet tomorrow in Chicago for a showdown.
PHILADEPHIA, Dec. 14 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Steigerwald Etzl wept with joy today when she was reunited with her 16-year-old son, Hansie, whom she had not ssen since 1944 when he was 5 years old.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The 6,000-ton British motor vessel Victory City, only a few months old, sank after a collision in dense fog off the coast of Holland today. Storms disrupted Atlantic shipping and damaged several small craft.

TENORS are in short supply, and the Metropolitan Opera will engage one for a single performance in a season if it thinks well enough of him. It evidently thinks well enough of Gianni Poggi, Italian tenor, who made his debut last night and will not be back until next season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Government today was urged to scrap its historic tariff structure and apply instead a quota system to restrict imports. The suggestion was made in a resolution adopted unanimously by the National Committee of Industry, Agriculture and Labor for an Export-Import Policy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Donald Heald, former Government attorney linked with the Communists, said today he had belonged to a "study group" in Washington for three years but had not known it was "Communist." He said he had never been a Communist.
Santa Claus and his reindeer stopped sidewalk traffic on Fifth Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets for half an hour yesterday afternoon.

QUEBEC, Dec. 14 -- The question of the price Quebec newspapers should pay for newsprint produced in this province has pitted the strong Government led by Premier Maurice Duplessis in a test of wills with Quebec's most powerful industry.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower did no work today as he began a period of light activity due to last at least until Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Loyd Wright, Los Angeles lawyer, was elected unanimously today to head the new bipartisan commission that will study the Government's loyalty-security programs from top to bottom.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower paid tribute today to a meeting of engineering and scientific societies. In a message to the group, he emphasized that future expansion of the peacetime uses of atomic energy in the United States "will depend on how well we are able to add more scientific and engineering brain power to our engineering force in order to make a more productive atomic future possible."

Ambassador Awni Khalidy confirmed yesterday his appointment as secretary general of the Baghdad Pact, the Middle Eastern security agreement. He expressed the hope that other nations "of like conviction" would join the organization.
IN WEST GERMANY, Dec. 14 -- It was Dec. 12 in Berlin. The hour was 4:52 P. M. Behind us was the Brandenburg Gate. I was driving slowly toward the West Berlin customs control post.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Marion N. Hardesty resigned today as managing director of the Interstate Commerce Commission. He took the post on Oct. 27 after having served the International Cooperation Administration as its counsel.
Commercial property and an apartment house changed hands in Long Island deals announced yesterday.
The Federal Government lost a legal motion yesterday to disqualify the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell from acting as defense counsel in a $35,862,288 suit brought by the Government.
It appeared yesterday that Magistrate Charles Solomon has had his last assignment in Vehicle Accident Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 7:
The nation has about 40,000 full-time teachers of undergraduates in liberal arts and sciences in 615 privately supported four-year colleges and universities.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec, 14 -- Increase of the United Nations membership will bring a revolution in voting patterns within the organization.

Futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, sugar and wool were mixed; cocoa, potatoes, onions and tin eased, and rubber, hides, copper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- An agreement to end the two-month-old strike of flight engineers against United Air Lines was reached tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis are on the verge of signing a new contract with the National Broadcasting Company, which reportedly will assure the comedy team of long-range earnings of several million dollars.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Opening of a new bookkeeping account helped industrials resume their advance today.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Governor Harriman will ask the 1956 Legislature to require the licensing by the state of all employes of private detectives.

For the fifth straight year Ted Kluszewski of the Cincinnati Redlegs topped The National League first basemen in fielding. Ted's average was .995, it was disclosed by the official statistics released yesterday.

Many parties will be given at the Yuletide Dansant for the benefit of the Gold Star Sons and Daughters of America to be held today in the ballroom of the Ambassador. Miss Beatrice Joyce heads the committee for the event, Mrs. Stass Reed is chairman of the junior committee, and Mr. and Mrs. Paul d'Otrenge Seghers are chairmen of the sponsors committee.

There are other bridges, many of them, on the New York State Thruway, but "the" bridge, the one across the Hudson twenty-five miles north of Grand Central Station, opens today. It was a tremendous undertaking to span the three-mile-wide Tappan Zee between historic Tarrytown in Westchester County and old Nyack, in Rockland County.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 14 -- India will take the initiative in seeking negotiations with South Africa to settle a long-standing dispute between them, the General Assembly was assured today.

Students and faculty of Union Theological Seminary, 120th Street and Broadway, will give blood to the Red Cross today. Blood will also be collected at the Royal Insurance Company, Ltd., 150 William Street, and the New York Telephone Company offices, 89-63 163d Street, Jamaica. Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, will give blood at Blood Program Headquarters, 214 East Twenty-first Street.

Timbertone Decorating Co, handmade wallpaper, in 90 Grand St; Millson Mills Inc, lingerie, in 166 Madison Ave; Wassell New York Co, distributor of production control systems, in 274 Madison Ave; Kate McSweeney Co, mail order house for women's apparel, in 104 5th Ave -- Boyd E. Wilson Co Inc, brokers.

For the fifth straight year Ted Kluszewski of the Cincinnati Redlegs topped The National League first basemen in fielding. Ted's average was .995, it was disclosed by the official statistics released yesterday.

Many parties will be given at the Yuletide Dansant for the benefit of the Gold Star Sons and Daughters of America to be held today in the ballroom of the Ambassador. Miss Beatrice Joyce heads the committee for the event, Mrs. Stass Reed is chairman of the junior committee, and Mr. and Mrs. Paul d'Otrenge Seghers are chairmen of the sponsors committee.

There are other bridges, many of them, on the New York State Thruway, but "the" bridge, the one across the Hudson twenty-five miles north of Grand Central Station, opens today. It was a tremendous undertaking to span the three-mile-wide Tappan Zee between historic Tarrytown in Westchester County and old Nyack, in Rockland County.

It would be fine to receive no "handy" gifts whatsoever this Christmas. Fripperies only, if Santa Claus will be so kind. Pretty tins of anchovies would be in order, and imported chocolate, and indeed anything else which can be fully used before New Year's. But no "handy" gifts.

Sidewalk superintendents had still another spot in midtown Manhattan yesterday to pursue their hobby. Hundreds clustered on Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets a little west of Fifth Avenue to watch a 120-foot power crane swing a one-ton steel ball against the ruins of three buildings. The walls fell in a shower of bricks.

The Russian proposal to halt nuclear tests presents an opportunity to end the deadlock in the negotiations about disarmament and peace. For such an agreement is self-controlling. It would also be a natural first step toward an essential improvement of the international climate.

A kind word in behalf of Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, has been spoken by a man who said his own mother was being scorned. She is living proof, he said, that there can be "different grades of Communists."
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 14 -- The rise of white citizens councils in Mississippi was likened here today to the growth of nazism in Germany.
