Despite the strength of aircrafts, which moved upward on Government spending plans, the stock market sagged in the late hours yesterday and registered the sharpest one-day loss since Nov. 21.
The American Jewish Committee reported yesterday that substantial progress toward equal opportunity for all had been achieved by the American people in the last eight years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Wheat futures moved up quite sharply today from an early break, as commission buying started short covering. The December future rose to a new high for the movement. But wheat prices reacted later and closed below yesterday's final levels.

Production plans for "My Royal Past," the musical version of Cecil Beaton's satiric novel on royal diarists, are moving apace. They are so far ahead of schedule, Gant Gaither, the producer, reported yesterday, that he was mulling over the idea of presenting the show on the West Coast in the near future.

The grandiose reception engineered for the Russian leaders here in India is of course a matter for concern to the United States, but this concern should not be exaggerated. After the excitement of the festivities many Indians are having second thoughts.
NETTIE ROSENSTEIN is designing swim suits for the first time, and making quite a splash.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- A Government land-rental program containing an entirely new provision to reduce crop surpluses was recommended today by the American Farm Bureau Federation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Nationalist China's veto yesterday of Outer Mongolia for United Nations membership has raised again the possibility of Peiping's replacing the Formosa regime.
The St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., opened its 1955-56 hockey season by defeating the Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., 4 -- 1, at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
The recent deaths of two small children from overdoses of aspirin prompted the Health Department yesterday to warn parents to keep the tablets out of the reach of inquisitive youngsters.
The critical eyes of the little-big man of major league hockey, Thomas Nathaniel Ivan, were on the Chicago Black Hawks last night, who skated against the Rangers in Madison Square Garden.

The rate of business expansion is leveling off, and it is unreasonable to expect economic growth in 1956 to maintain its extraordinary 1955 pace, Alan H. Temple, executive vice president of the First National City Bank, said yesterday.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- The Soviet leaders, on their way home from India, flew over Kabul today but were unable to land here for an intended visit because of snow and heavy clouds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- The Associates and Aldrich Company will expand its operations by providing part of the financing and arranging distribution set-ups for other independent producers. This was announced today by Robert Aldrich, director-producer.
LONDON, Dec. 14--The British Government is understood to be urging Turkey to moderate her refusal to agree to any diminution of full British sovereignty over Cyprus.

Bob Murphy, a 23-year-old welterweight from Brighton, Mass., yesterday was named the "rookie of the year" by the Boxing Writers Association. Murphy will receive a plaque in recognition of this honor at the Association's annual dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel on Jan. 19.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Hugh Todd Naylor Gaitskell, the new leader of the Labor party, is an odd mixture of emotion and calculation, ambition and reticence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Duncan Aikman, newspaper man and author, was found hanged in the basement of his residence in Chevy Chase late today. He was 65 years old.
Harold E. Stassen said yesterday he was confident President Eisenhower would run for reelection "if he concludes with full knowledge of his health that it is best for America that he do so."

The player representatives of the sixteen major league baseball clubs expressed strong dissatisfaction yesterday with the uncooperative attitude of the club owners toward proposals made by the players.

DECEMBER is the cruelest month. Along with family reunions and holiday parties comes the highest incidence of fires and accidents for the entire year. One of the principal causes of Christmas tragedies is that familiar seasonal symbol, the decorated tree.

The liquor industry is experiencing some happy days. With the big distillers going in heavily for special decanters and gift wraps, sales are reported to be triple a year ago, and advertising gets the credit, according to industry officials.
A new issue of $25,000,000 of debentures of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company will be placed on the market today at a price to yield 3.33 per cent to maturity in 1995.

Primary aluminum production in this country will exceed 1,500,000 tons this-year for the first time, raising the output record for the fourth year in succession, the Aluminum Association estimated yesterday. That production would be about 7 per cent over the 1954 figure.
A two-year "package" wage increase of $4 a week was won yesterday by 10,000 elevator operators and other service employes in 1,100 Manhattan apartment buildings.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 -Senator Clinton P. Anderson declared tonight that the time had come to lift the veil of atomic secrecy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, predicted today that many union members would vote Republican next year.
Three septuagenarians -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Miss Helen Keller and Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth -- made it plain yesterday that for them life meant useful and satisfying activity.

MASSENA, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The State Power Authority's $5,000,000 St. Lawrence bridge to Barnhart Island, the major link between the mainland and the site for a $600,000,000 powerhouse, was opened temporarily to traffic at 2 A. M. today.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Federal court jury today awarded a total of $350,000 to ten men who sued General Motors Corporation for damages in connection with a truck accident in Rensselaer County in 1950. The ten asserted that the accident had been caused by defective steering mechanism.

BOTH the scholar, interested in the ceaseless and infinite cross-fertilization that goes on in art, and the layman, desirous merely of feasting his eyes on color and delicate tracery of line, should find the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum all that they asked for.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- In this town where no one is immune from attack, Thomas Jefferson today got his.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Kosei Kamo of Japan scored a mild upset in the quarter-finals of the national lawn tennis championships today when he beat a United States Davis Cup player, Hamilton Richardson, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 1.
Leaders of the world's free trade unions called yesterday for a general boycott of all ships carrying phosphate ore from Curacao, Netherlands West Indies.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- Premier Antonio Segni, announced to a cheering Senate today that Italy had been admitted to membership of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Florida and California loomed tonight as the likeliest Democratic Presidential primary battlegrounds between Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

A STRONG case for monogamy is that is helps cut down the number of men on a woman's Christmas shopping list. But even with the law on her side, a harried shopper often runs out of imagination and endurance before she checks off the last masculine name.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Florida Pardon Board commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence .of a Negro convicted for Iris part in a Groveland, Fla., rape case in 1949.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Grants of $900,000 to more than 100 universities and colleges for the next academic year were announced today by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. This is $100,000 more than last year's grants.

BOB FELLER once wrote a book, "The Strikeout Story." If a sequel to it ever is deemed necessary, publishers won't have to search far for a qualified author. The assignment automatically will go to young Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians, the overwhelming choice as the rookie of the year in the American League.

TO THE EDITOR 6F THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dillard P. Sprigg's letter published Dec. 10 with regard to Secretary of State Dulles' Goa statement should remind us once more that we have become a nation of Puritans and, what is worse, Puritan critics. The Puritan spirit has been growing around our large cities; it spread to the suburbs and our universities and Federal Government and makes us ready targets for foreign propaganda.

In a thoroughly confused yearend tax-selling market, stocks yesterday dipped to new lows for the month and recovered to close virtually unchanged. More issues fell than gained but the industrials in the averages were able to offset the loss for the rails.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15--Japan's candidacy for membership in the United Nations was vetoed by the Soviet Union today for the third time in three days.
Maritime union and employer representatives voted yesterday to self-insure a welfare fund covering 40,000 East Coast seamen.
An eviction action has been brought by a landlord against a tenant on the ground that, as a professional writer, she is violating the terms of a standard residential lease.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While the noble effort of The New York Times to lean over backward is admirable, Prof. Frederick Schuman's attempt to vindicate the infamous Ribbentrop-Molotov pact does not stand up under scrutiny.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 15 -- Facts that probably explain how diaries of Capt. William Clark of the Lewis and Clark 1803 exploratory expedition found their way into the attic of an old St. Paul residence were developed today in the Government's legal action to gain possession of the papers.

The Federal Reserve did double duty in the week ended on Wednesday. Through the purchase of Government securities it helped ease pressure on the money market and also aided the Treasury's debt refunding operations.
Nashua, this year's champion American race horse, was sold yesterday for $1,251,200 -- the largest price ever paid for a thoroughbred.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A British Army major turned a guerrilla band's ambush of his jeep into a death trap today for the guerrilla leader, a fugitive with a $14,000 price on his head.

Events today: Verdi's "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell, conductor, Ivry Gitlis, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:45, and Hanukkah Music Festival, Temple Adath Israel, the Bronx, 8.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Eight American soldiers and former soldiers, all former prisoners of war in Korea, defended themselves at hearings here today against secret charges that they had given aid and comfort to the enemy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Prices of all grains and soybeans sagged today on the Board of Trade, more because of a lack of any important buying support than as a result of heavy offerings.

Ford Bond of the National Broadcasting Company sold the four-story dwelling with front -age of twenty-three feet at 140 East Nineteenth Street, between Irving Place and Third Avenue near Gramercy Park, to Theodore Ball of Saks-Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Luis Batlle Berres, President of Uruguay, "spent a very restful night" at Wesley Memorial Hospital. Senor Batlle Berres, who is on a tour of the United States, was taken to the hospital last night after collapsing at a dinner in his honor at the Chicago Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States has decided to take all the time it needs to give full consideration to Israel's arms needs before granting her request for weapons.
A Brooklyn machinist won a $175,000 verdict yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court as the result of the deaths of his wife and daughter in an automobile accident.
CAIRO, Dec. 15 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt warned tonight that the full might of Egyptian and Syrian forces would be used jointly against further Israeli aggression.
The fury of Atlantic winter seas was described here yesterday by the masters of two liners, both of whose ships escaped with hardly a scratch.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke said today that the Soviet Union had become the world's second sea-power and showed no signs of slowing down her arms build-up.
The Penn - Texas Corporation yesterday completed negotiations to acquire the Hallicrafters Company of Chicago in an exchange of shares.
New York State school districts raised $2,678,000 in the public markets yesterday on serial bond issues.

THOSE who have had the pleasure of seeing the Kabuki dancers with their exquisite gestures and tectonic costumes will be interested in an exhibition of Japanese master prints, all dealing with theatre, at the Meltzer Gallery (Serigraph), 38 West Fifty-seventh Street.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- All three Ardsley Curling Club rinks today survived the opening round of the Ardsley Medal competition, the feature of the first Cuthbertson Bonspiel. The event, sponsored by the Ardsley, Mahopac and New York Caledonian clubs, is in memory of Willie Cuthbertson, a Caledonian curler.
Commuters' spokesmen urged the Public Service Commission yesterday to cancel the 5-cents-a-ride rate rises instituted by the Long Island Rail Road on Dec. 6.

The General Tire and Rubber Company and the El Paso Natural Gas Company plan to build what they call the nation's first post-war, privately financed and completely integrated synthetic rubber plant near Odessa, Tex.
The Ford Foundation is warning hospitals benefiting by its $200,000,000 in new grants for improving service that they must find "other sources" to keep financing this service.

In his last official act as State Rent Administrator, Charles Abrams ruled yesterday that landlords must compensate tenants evicted from their homes to permit new apartment house construction. He also extended the waiting period in eviction cases from the present three months to six months.
Two persons suffering physical pain themselves sent gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to help ease the pains and the problems of others.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, predicted today that the decline in farm income is nearing an end.
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Dec. 16 (AP)--Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, the Labor party leader, has won a neck-and-neck race for his old seat in the House of Representatives.

Today's new film is "Storm Fear," at the Palace. The drama stars Cornel Wilde, Jean Wallace and Dan Duryea. The screen play by Horton Foote was based on a novel by Clinton Seeley. The film was produced and directed by Mr. Wilde for United Artist release.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -Supporters of Adlai E. Stevenson challenged all comers today to a Presidental primary contest in California next June.

The Joint Distribution committee adopted yesterday a budget of $29,200,000 to carry out assistance programs next year among 200,000 Jewish men, women and children in twenty-five countries of Europe, North Africa and the Near East, including Israel.
It took Governor Harriman less than an hour yesterday to whisk through five ceremonies in the State Office Building at 80 Centre Street.
TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- The Garden State Parkway will be linked to the New York State Thruway as the result of action taken today by the New Jersey Highway Authority.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Demand for the admission of Communist China intensified today as sixteen new members were enrolled in the General Assembly of the United Nations.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert Bayard Swope as chairman of the Commission on Intergroup Relations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -Ingrid Bergman has agreed to star for Twentieth Century-Fox in its adaptation of the stage success, "Anastasia."

For most of us this will be a Merry Christmas indeed. It will have been made so by higher employment, more take-home pay, bigger business profits and record consumer buying. But, as the nation as a whole rides the high tide of prosperity toward a bright new year, it leaves behind inevitably a few trapped in the eddies of misfortune.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx has now exposed the sinister forces behind the plot to repeal his 1937 law that requires most city employes to be residents within the city, and not only that, but to have lived in the city three years before they can be hired. He writes to the City Council, which is considering repeal legislation:

AMONG the most tempting fruits in the market, though not the thriftiest perhaps, are the melons from the Valencia area, the garden of Spain. Shaped like a football and sometimes sized like one, they have a rough skin and yellow flesh; their sweet delicacy recommends them for week-end meals.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 15 -- A group of Air Force paratroopers is defying governmental authority and has precipitated a threat to the Cabinet.
Poinsetta and orchids greeted previewers of the annual Christmas flower show at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park yesterday.

Peter V. Tishman, son of Norman Tishman, head of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., haS joined the concern's management department. He recently completed two years service with the Army.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. Cottonseed oil, copper, zinc, lead, wool, burlap, potatoes and onions rose; coffee, sugar, rubber and soybean oil were mixed, and cocoa and hides eased.

The National Broadcasting Company has engaged Charles Laughton to read special Christmas selections over its television network on Dec. 24 from 11:15 P. M. to midnight. The network hopes to make the Yuletide readings an annual event.
Six hundred one persons have been killed in automobile accidents in the city since Jan. 1, an increase of seventy-two over the same period last year.
PARIS, Dec. 15--The United States, Britain and France sought today to coordinate their policies in the Middle East to meet the threat of Soviet penetration in that area.

Many dinner parties will be given tonight preceding the annual Christmas Ball, a subscription dance for post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples. The ball will be held in the St. Regis Roof.

The Henry Street Settlement will be the beneficiary of a Christmas Cotillion to be held on Christmas Eve in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Henry Street Friends Committee.

At the age of 32, a fast-talking lawyer who ten years ago was a Notre Dame basketball player, is enjoying a kind of popularity in Alabama that usually is reserved for beautiful women, football heroes, baby-kissing governors and black-eyed peas. His name is Johnny Dee -head basketball coach at the University of Alabama.

The business gift industry -- business men nod politely at Christmas time to clients, customers, suppliers and others -- is heading toward a new record. While total figures are impossible to get because of the shadowy margin between the true business gift and the personal gift, estimates of holiday volume from companies dealing in such items are enough to indicate the trend.

In some ways the Soviet Union's veto of Japanese membership in the United Nations serves to clear the atmosphere. Japan should have a better idea of just what the proffered Soviet friendship is worth.
The New Cunard liner Ivernia put to sea yesterday with 631 passengers on the first of four winter voyages between New York and Cobh and Liverpool.

Snow fell on a substantial part of the ski country yesterday. Storms were reported from New Hampshire clear across to the Adirondacks of New York State. However, there was some doubt about the availability of the sport at many areas.
A proposal to expand parent education programs in the Health Department has struck a snag in the Board of Estimate.
For the first time since he left office, former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey met last night with the top Republican state leaders as a group.
ELATH, Israel, Dec. 15 -- This Israeli port on the arm of the Red Sea advanced another stage in its development today with the dedication of a jetty designed to receive 2,000-ton ships.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 15 -- Israel has notified the United Nations she is prepared to exchange all Syrian prisoners of war for all Israelis in Syrian hands.

SANFORD, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., sliced six strokes off par for a course record today and took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $15.000 Sanford open golf tournament.
Fifteen suspended motorcycle policemen were acquitted yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on charges they had profited financially in the operation of a courtesy card racket.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 15 -George Kennan, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has been made a Professor in the School of Historical Studies at the Institute for Advanced Study.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 15 -- The White House took special pains today to decry a report involving the political plans of the President.

A proposed caddie scholarship plan was endorsed yesterday by the Westchester County Golf Association. Sponsored by the Reinach-Turnesa Foundation, the plan will offer college education opportunities to young men who have served at least two years as Westchester caddies.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Harold Macmillan will replace R. A. Butler as Chancellor of the Exchequer in a thorough reorganization of the Conservative Government, a ministerial source said today.

The Murray Corporation of America, Detroit, and the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company, Chicago, have set up an affiliate to be known as the Brunswick-Murray Automatic Pinsetter Corporation. Announcement to this effect was made yesterday by B. C. Gould, president of Murray, and B. E. Bensinger, president of Brunswick.

Nicholas Sklyros is a man who believes that one does not have to be a millionaire to be a philanthropist, and he proves it. He gives away Bibles and money. This week he donated the entire contents of his pay envelope to the Greater New York Fund.

Judge Carmine J. Marasco in Kings County Court sentenced a man yesterday to a two-and-one-half to five-year prison term for felonious assult, but suspended the sentence because the defendant had made a settlement for $9,000 with his injured victim.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 15' -- The drive to win at least some New York State delegate votes for Adlai E. Stevenson at the Democratic National Convention next year got down to a grass-root basis here tonight. A Nassau County Stevenson-for-President committee was formed at a meeting of more than 400 persons in the Garden City Hotel.

IN the amphitheatre-like auditorium of the Emanuel Presbyterian Church at 729 East Sixth Street, the Shakespearean Theatre Workshop last night presented the Bard's powerful tragedy of fate and destiny, "Romeo and .Juliet."
Seven hundred students of the New York City Police Academy will give blood to the Red Cross today and tomorrow.

The Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company, producer of outboard motors and power lawn mowers, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of 313,845 shares of common stock.

" White Coolies," by Betty Jeffrey, will be published by Philosophical Library on Jan. 16. The author, a former Australian Army nurse, recounts her experiences in the hands of Japanese captors in Malaya. The author was one of sixty-five nurses who were aboard the Vyner Brooke when it was sunk by the Japanese in February, 1942.
HARTFORD, Dec. 15--The special session of the Connecticut General Assembly adjourned at 10:40 tonight after having adopted a flood relief program totaling $35,977,000.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation rejected a proposal today from one of two striking unions that would have sent 11,000 employes back to work at ten plants.

MADRID, Dec. 15 -- Members of the ruling class here today called Spain's admission to the United Nations the Franco regime's greatest foreign policy triumph since the military and economic agreements with the United States were signed in September, 1953.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15 -- The prison sentences of four persons convicted of the murder of a motion-picture union officer here in August, 1954, were reversed yesterday by the Superior Court.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 15 -- Another Eisenhower boom in New Hampshire began today to assume noticeable proportions.
LONODN, Dec. 15 -- An arbitration panel approved today wage increases for approximately 70,000 policemen and policewomen in England, Scotland and Wales.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A spectacular spill in the fifth race sent four horses sprawling over the track at Tropical Park today. Two others in the field of twelve 2-year-olds were pulled up to avoid the thoroughbreds involved in the mishap.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Opposition Socialists seized today on Japan's failure to gain entry to the United Nations to urge quick recognition of Communist China.

Following are the first ten amendments added to the Constitution. Known as the Bill of Rights, they were formulated by the First Congress and submitted to the states on Sept. 25, 1789. When ratified by the eleventh state, Virginia, on Dec. 15, 1791, they became effective:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -The Bangor and Aroostook Railroad Company of Bangor, Me., today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to redeem its outstanding $10,040,000 first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds through a refunding operation.

The White House Conference on Education has put education on the front page. If not solutions, at least the problems of education are better known than before. And the most crucial of these is, Whre are the teachers of tomorrow to come from? And how are they to be paid? Where are we to find the funds to provide the average teacher with the financial dignity accorded to bricklayers and garbage contractors?
Sixteen friendly pickets joined Governor Harriman yesterday in dedicating the $60,000,000 Thruway bridge linking Rockland and Westchester Counties.

Another great trophy in the unending battle for freedom of the press in the Western Hemisphere can now be held aloft. That grand little provincial newspaper of northern Argentina, El Intransigente of Salta, resumes publication today under the directorship of a man who deserves the highest acclaim that can be given to him -- David Michel Torino.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The 22,560 nonoperating employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad will go on strike at midnight next Thursday unless an agreement averting it is reached.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- The Indian Government has drawn up a plan for intensive propagation of birth-control methods, especially in the countryside.

MADRID, Dec. 15 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said tonight he would not permit the establishment of a Western democratic system of government in the zone of Morocco that is ruled by the Spanish regime.

The complexities of modern operations led to a drastic change in the method of conducting the business of the New York Yacht Club at the annual meeting in the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse last night.

M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., largest United States producer of printed cotton textiles, has acquired the complete cotton operation of Pacific Mills. The seller was Burlington Industries, Inc., which gained control of Pacific Mills through purchase of a majority of the outstanding stock in the summer of 1954.

TONIGHT, when city outlines melt in early winter darkness, passers-by will cut their stride at the southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue to stare in wonder through the great windows of the Manhattan Savings Bank.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday suggested that pitchers be excluded from baseball's annual most valuable player polls and voted for separately. He proposed a Cy Young memorial award be given to the outstanding hurler of the year.
Most of the country's hardwood forests east of the Mississippi River are menaced by an invasion of the gypsy moth, an insect specialist warned yesterday.

The National Electric Products Corporation has leased the penthouse floor in the seventeen -story office building going up at 545 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street. The concern, whose headquarters are in. Pittsburgh, makes electrical wiring, cables and conduits.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said today that he thought the national debt should be reduced at least a billion dollars before taxes were.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Guided by signals from the Copenhagen Observatory, King Frederik pressed a button today to start a clock that is to run for 1,000 years or more without a stop. It is to deviate only two-fifths of a second every 300 years.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 15 (UP) -- Nashua's new owner, Leslie Combs 2d, tonight told Dr. Charles H. Strub, executive vice president of Santa Anita, that he was not ruling out the possibility of the horse running in the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap this winter.
Two decisions that are expected to have far-reaching affects on the 5,000,000 persons covered by the state's Workmen's Compensation Law were announced yesterday.
The independent Newspaper Deliverers Union began picketing yesterday at the plant of The Brooklyn Daily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -Former Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland charged today the local union of streetcar and bus employes with blocking the plan of his Baltimore group to take over the dying franchise of the Capital Transit Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Investigation into gasoline price wars in New Jersey developed today into a battle between big suppliers and dealers.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Premier Edgar Faure asked the French today to vote for governmental stability next month and held out the prospect of doubling the standard of living in a decade as a reward.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The annual battle of the budget within the Administration is about over and it is ending, as most controversies end in the Eisenhower Cabinet, in a compromise.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Not since Henry Hudson sailed in the Half Moon up the Hudson River shores of Westchester and Rockland in 1609 has so much happened to these counties between dawn and dusk as today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A sharp debate is going on within the Administration over the amount of money that should go into grants for Federal aid to education.

The excess reserve position of member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased by a modest $20,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday on a daily average basis, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Public Health Service released 1,028,853 cubic centimeters of poliomyelitis vaccine for use in the national program of immunizing children. Each cubic centimeter is one dose.
Parks Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday commented thus on Billy Rose's scheme to "rejuvenate" Central Park: "As long as I'm around New York, Central Park will not be turned into a night club."

If fresh evidence were needed to confirm the close ties between contemporary American composers and our academic institutions it was supplied by the Composers Forum last night at the McMillan Theatre of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals today set aside a May 1, 1954, order of the Federal Power Commission, granting Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company a rate increase of about $12,780,000.

Accurate shooting from the free-throw line is one of the secrets behind North Carolina State's consistent success in basketball. In its first three games this season the Wolfpack quintet made good on 88 of 102 penalty awards.
The controversial report on how to teach moral and spiritual values in the public schools has become too hot to handle in its present form.

Robin Roberts and Bob Feller, a couple of fast-balling pitchers, threw a few strikes yesterday to gain what might be considered at least a "moral victory" for major league ballplayers in their controversy with the club owners.
Information reaching the United States indicates that some key functions of the Soviet secret police have been sharply curtailed and others have been transferred to the Soviet Army.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The Ford Foundation was criticized today by Raymond Dooley, president of Lincoln (Ill.) College, for its failure to include junior colleges among the institutions sharing the endowment gift announced Monday.

BAHREIN, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Forces of the Sultan of Muscat and Oman today occupied without opposition Nizwa, capital of Oman, which had been the "focus of a conspiracy'' against the Sultan, according to a statement from the Sultan received here today.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Dec. 15 -- Premier Ismail el Azhari announced in Parliament today he intended to declare the independence of the Sudan Monday.
Christmas arrived early yesterday for 500 hospitalized and disabled service men and veterans.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Hazzah Mahali, Premiere-designate of Jordan and a strong supporter of the Baghdad Pact for Middle East defense against communism, tonight formed a new ten-member Cabinet.

The New York Telephone Company lost its fight yesterday for $34,380,000 a year in rate increases, but it won increases of $8,000,000 a year. The Public Service Commission made this decision. At the same time it turned down a demand by New York City to cut telephone rates immediately by $31,800,000 a year, and eventually by perhaps $41,000,000.

THE Trapp Family Singers, last night in Town Hall, started the first of three concerts that will be concluded with a Sunday afternoon appearance. These may well be the last New York appearances of the well-known group.

The Board of Education has filed plans with the Department of Housing and Buildings for a four-story elementary school at 314 Pacific Street in Brooklyn. The building will be known as Public School 261. Michael L. Radoslovich is the architect.
THE late, and in many areas lamentable, grouse season seems to have stirred argument among those who consider the grouse to be No. 1 on the game bird list.

Unemployment compensation plans should be studied by individual employers with regard to feasibility and actual benefit to the employes, Peter G. Dirr, assistant secretary of McKesson Robbins, Inc., said yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dulles warned the West today that the Soviet Union had opened a "new cold war front" in the Middle East and Asia with the use of arms, technicians and words.
Production and consumption of newsprint set new records in November, according to reports by trade groups yesterday. The same was true of data for the first eleven months of 1955.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Johnny Peirson, a long time hex on Chicago, returned to action tonight for the first time after an eighteen-month retirement to spark the Boston Bruins to their first victory over the Black Hawks in nine games. 4 -- 1, before 5,549 Garden fans.

Gov. Frank J. Lausche of Ohio has announced his candidacy as a favorite son for the Democratic nomination for President. Whether this enterprise will go beyond the favorite-son stage remains to be seen. Mr. Lausche has indicated that he will not seek delegates in other states and "will do nothing to reach the goal" which his friends in Ohio have urged him to seek.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 15 -- The Soviet leaders brought their new policy of high-powered personal political salesmanship to an interested Afghanistan today.
A realty investment concern bought three apartment houses in the Bronx and immediately resold one of them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States denounced today the Soviet vetoes of Japan's admission to the United Nations as a cynical pressure move and a "glaring injustice."

LONDON. Dec. 15 -- The United States Air Force has been invited to send test pilots to Britain to fly the new delta-winged Avro Vulcan bomber. This four-turbojet craft is due to join the Royal Air Force early next spring.

The Scott Paper Company and Compania Industrial de San Cristobal, S. A., Mexico City, completed arrangements yesterday under which Scott acquired a substantial financial and voting interest in the Mexican pulp and paper manufacturing concern.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman warned Israel last night to "show restraint" and "respect for the sanctity of each human life" in its fight for democracy and freedom.
The Jan. 7 evening performance of "The Great Sebastians" will benefit the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy and the National Theatre Service Department.
The Pacific Far East Line, pioneer in private purchase and operation of the Mariner-type cargo liners, soon will augment its new express trans-Pacific service with a fourth vessel of this class.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Americans got their first close look today at the most advanced type of Soviet industrial automation. They were impressed.

The Dana Corporation, Ohio producer of automotive equipment, realized an increase of 162.2 per cent in earnings for the quarter ended Nov. 30 on a sales gain of 98 per cent over the levels for the period a year earlier.

Hugh Gaitskell, who now steps into Clement Attlee's shoes as leader of the British Labor party and movement, is a modest, warm, tactful, sincere man with the right amount of brilliance in a country that needs some but distrusts too much of it in its statesmen. He is clever, but not too clever; likable but not soft. He was an obvious choice.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The North Atlantic Council took steps today to give greater unity to the defenses of the Atlantic alliance and to the military and political authorities who guide it.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday that any cut in the United States foreign-aid program would play into the hands of the Russians.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 15 -- Establishment of a United Nations memorial cemetery in Korea was assured today by action of the General Assembly.
City officials and business leaders witnessed the signing yesterday of the first lease for business space in the Coliseum, under construction at Columbus Circle.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Reports reaching London from Vienna today said Endre Marton and his wife, correspondents in Hungary for United States news services, went on trial Nov. 28 before a secret Hungarian military court.

Assets of the life-insurance industry and its cash available for investment will probably double over the next ten years, O. Kelley Anderson, president of New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.
Impressed by Arnold Schulman's writing ability, Garson Kanin said yesterday he would direct the young author's drama, "The Heart's a Forgotten Hotel."
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday took the formal step of making the Boxing Guild of New York a powerless organization in the ring sport in this state.
The General Electric Company expects record sales of more than $3,128,000,000 next year.
The liberties guaranteed by the Bill of Rights were extolled, and also exercised, here yesterday.

MUSIC with its roots in nationalism -- the right kind of nationalism -- provided the program at last night's New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall. George Szell, in his third week as guest conductor, was on the podium, and the soloist was Ivry Gitlis, a young Israeli violinist.

The Federal Maritime Board's hearing on the subsidy application by the Arnold Bernstein Line opened yesterday in the agency's New York headquarters at 45 Broadway before hearing examiner A. L. Jordan. The Bernstein interests are seeking Government construction and operating subsidy for a passenger ship service embracing New York, Rotterdam and Antwerp.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 15 -- The Government took a firm stand tonight against 16,000 workers in the copper mining industry with a decree compelling them to return to work because their strike is considered illegal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The first votes cast by newly admitted members of the United Nations came this morning at a meeting of the General Assembly. The show of hands on a recommendation by the Trusteeship Committee for a plebiscite next spring in British Togoland approved the measure by 42 to 7, with 11 abstentions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today overwhelmingly reaffirmed its approval of flexible price supports.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Pee Wee Reese, the Dodgers' perennial "No. 1 guy," is still following the script. The Brooks' star shortstop and field captain yesterday became the first member of the world champions to accept terms for 1956.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (UP) -- A second-period goal by Henri (Little Rocket) Richard helped Goalie Jacques Plante register his sixth shutout of the season tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the New York Rangers, 2 -- 0, before 14,328 Forum fans.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- A witness today accepted an offer of immunity made under a recent Federal law. He then announced he would reply to questions about Communist activities he previously had refused to answer.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- Fire Chief John H. Alderson was suspended today on charges of insubordination.
Wes Santee was clocked in 4:10.2 for the mile run at the second Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union handicap track meet of the season at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, at Sea, Dec. 15 -- Against a backdrop of icebergs, this Navy icebreaker crossed the Antarctic Circle today exactly on the International Date Line.
Bail totaling $60,000 was posted yesterday for three secondary Communist leaders who surrendered last week after having been fugitives for four years.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- Development of the launching system for the nation's artificial earth satellite was put today in the hands of a former World War II infantry private.

Magistrate Albert D. Schanzer, sitting in Brooklyn Traffic Court yesterday, declared that a defendant in a parking case did not have the right to refuse to testify. His ruling conflicted with one made on Tuesday by Magistrate Charles Solomon, who held that a defendant in a parking case had the right to "remain mute."

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Cypriote terrorists threw bombs and engaged in violent demonstrations today in renewed pressure against Britain to bow to their demands for union of this island colony with Greece.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The Security Council concurred today in the decision of the General Assembly that a conference should be called to review the United Nations Charter.
Dean Hunter and Peter C. Tripp have been signed to conduct two musical programs for radio station WMGM.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 16 -Pablo Casals, the 'cellist, tomorrow will break his vow never to play the 'cello far from Prades, France, where he has been living in exile since 1939.
Christmas shoppers and children in search of Santa Claus crowded stores in all the boroughs yesterday.
The New York Telephone Company raised its rates yesterday in forty-four exchanges in Nassau and Westchester counties by 25 or 50 cents a month on flat-rate residence service.
An intensive search for fire violations in the city's 400 moving picture houses will open Monday.

AN exhibition with a didactic purpose, "Logic and Emotion," at the Terrain Gallery, 20 West Sixteenth Street, groups artists of many tendencies, all of whom attempt in their work to illustrate a theory of opposites.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Elmer Davis asserted today that the assault on civil liberties in this country had not subsided enough to justify a letdown in their defense.
A congregation of 500 persons at Brooklyn's "mother synagogue" looked back yesterday on a century of Jewish community life in the borough.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The National Capital Planning Commission today recommended against building a new $50,000,000 headquarters for the Central Intelligence Agency in near-by Langley, Va.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 16 (UP) -- Michigan State University's football team, the Big Ten representative in the Rose Bowl game, arrived today by chartered plane from East Lansing, Mich.

A Bloomingdale's warehouse man was killed and a United Parcel Service driver was wounded last evening in a Christmas hold-up that started off boldly but ended in a frenzy. The thugs got $600 but overlooked thousands.

Marcel Pagnol's "Letters From My Windmill" will open tomorrow at the Paris Theatre. The French-made film is an adaptation of three Alphonse Daudet stories of the Provencal region, "The Three Low Masses," "The Elixir of Father Gaucher" and "The Secret of Master Cornille."

In part, the great welcome given by Indians to Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin reflected a widespread popular belief that the two had come to dispense largesse, to give "brotherly aid" toward solving India's economic problems as she strives for industrialization. Now that the propaganda tour is over, it is appropriate to examine how and whether these expectations were met.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- A meeting to draft a constitution for the organic merger of all sixteen Lutheran Church bodies in the United States was proposed here today by representatives of the Augustana Lutheran Church and the United Lutheran Church in America.
CAMP FRIEDLAND, Germany, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Karl Heinz Pintsch, 46-year-old former adjutant of Rudolf Hess, once Hitler's deputy, was freed today after fourteen years in Nazi and Soviet captivity.
Robert Shaw, conductor of the Robert Shaw Chorale, has been appointed associate conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Westinghouse offered today to lend $100 cash to any striking or furloughed employe who needed money to provide "the essentials for a decent Christmas."

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 16 (UP) -- William Clarence Peddicord a blind man who once won national attention by hitch-hiking across the country in an attempt to regain his sight, has confessed exploding dynamite in crowded department store in a $50,000 extortion plot, the police announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A team of experts on medicine and crime said today sex deviation was so widespread in Britain there were "practicing homosexuals" in Parliament.
THE shooting accidents that draw blood become statistics, but only the individuals involved have record of the "narrow misses."
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 16 -- Five United States ships of Operation Deepfreeze made an abrupt departure from Lyttelton this afternoon.
The holiday travel rush began yesterday, a full week before the Christmas week-end. The peak of the flow is expected next Friday.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The president of the Meley Manufacturing Company, Inc., announced today it was buying the property of the Flagg-Utica Company and would consolidate all of its manufacturing operations in Utica.
Additional details were learned yesterday of Thursday's sale of Nashua, America's 1955 champion race horse, at world-record $1,000-a-pound figures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker said today he would run as a favorite son candidate in the Ohio Republican primary on May 8 with the hope that President Eisenhower would seek a second term. He supported the late Senator Robert A. Taft at the 1952 convention.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A Parliamentary commission recommended today that Britain permit Malta to seat three members in the House of Commons.
The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions advised its affiliates yesterday not to send delegations to totalitarian countries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The law firm of the former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission has been retained to defend a large grocery chain against commission charges.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Dec. 16 -- A bus and three automobiles piled up in a spectacular accident at Newbridge Road and Seventh Street here at 11 A. M. today. Three men and a woman bus passenger were injured, none seriously.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday an application to the Federal Power Commission for approval of a $150,000,000 expansion program that would provide its customers with 250,000,000 more cubic feet of gas a day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- When a truck tire gets soft, the driver can now be notified by radio. A system patented this week provides a special transmitter for each wheel.

The American Bosch Arma Corporation in the first nine months this year increased its consolidated net income to $2,971,878 from $1,715,962 in the corresponding period last year. Consolidated net sales were $55,660,928, against $55,747,170.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 -- The Legislature, press and a large section of the public seemed united today in anger against the Soviet Union for its third veto in three days of Japan's bid to enter the United Nations.

A COUPLE of years ago Herbert Agar took a distinguished Princetonian into the Savile Club in London. There he introduced him to another member of the club, the well-known British naturalist, James Fisher. At the time Mr. Agar's guest was touring the world by way of relaxing from what had been a fairly strenuous political campaign.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 16 -Three large copper mines owned by United States companies were placed under Army rule today on the third day of a labor strike.

" Pal" is defined in the dictionary as a "partner" or an "intimate friend." To a hundred thousand sports-minded New York City boys and girls who are active in the Police Athletic League recreation program, it is a term of affection that binds them to the policeman on the beat.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 16 -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared today that Nationalist China had blocked Outer Mongolia's admission to the United Nations to save the organization from "the force of treachery and conspiracy."

Stocks of three New York Stock Exchange listed companies will be suspended from dealings at the opening of business on Tuesday, Dec. 27, the Exchange announced yesterday. They are Atlas Tack Corporation, Ex-change Buffet Corporation and Kalamazoo Stove and Furnace Company.

Every bird watcher and dandelion fancier will be enranged cautioned Billy Rose the other day when he proposed that Central Park be turned into a sort of super amusement center. Let's, said Mr. Rose, have day and night concerts, Shakespeare festivals, underground parking, flood-lighted tennis courts in Central Park.
THE surge of Christmas shows into metropolitan galleries includes several by individual painters and sculptors of varying appeal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- It was no bombshell Senator Estes Kefauver dropped on Washington this morning when he announced that he wanted to be President Kefauver.

The Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art has taken another step in its campaign to save historically important motion pictures from decomposition. John Hay Whitney, chairman of the Museum's board of trustees and president of the Film Library, yesterday announced formation of a Committee for the Film Collection to raise additional funds for film preservation.

THE retirement of Nicholas M. Schenck from the presidency of Loew's, Inc., which he announced to the company's board of directors on Wednesday, and the immediate election of Arthur M. Loew to the position was an event of more significance and drama in the motion-picture industry than the mere announcement implied.
The Princeton University Triangle show blew into town last night. Forthwith, the young collegians dispensed with the three R's and made with the three V's -vim, vigor and vitality.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been issued recently:

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the Mayfair Assembly, which was held last night in the ballroom of the Ambassador. The fete, an annual subscription ball, was arranged under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller for debutantes, post-debutantes and their escorts.
The Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division appealed yesterday for volunteers to increase tis strength to the newly authorized total of 14,000 officers and enlisted men.
There was no decision yesterday in the case of the landlord versus the tenant who uses a residential apartment for professional writing. But there were rumblings of a storm to come.
Eddie Lopat, whose assortment of tantalizing southpaw pitches helped the Yankees win five pennants and world series, is back in the Bomber organization.

A guide to action in improving public education is scheduled for Jan. 10 publication by Harper. Written by David Dreiman, it is titled "How To Get Better Schools" and is based on the experiences of the National Citizens' Commission for the Public Schools in studying this history of the commission in gathering and disseminating the experiences of local action groups.

Sixty-five New Yorkers or visitors have unwittingly contributed $3.65 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They were persons who lost a one-dollar bill, two quarters, thirteen dimes, nine nickels and forty pennies last year.

SANFORD, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The weather turned cold today and so did Sam Snead's putter. But the West Virginia pro's par 70 was good enough to keep him one stroke ahead at the halfway mark in the $15,000 Sanford open golf tournament.
Prince Rainer III, ruler of the five-square-mile Principality of Monaco, conferred the Order of St. Charles upon Mayor Wagner yesterday in City Hall.
THOUSANDS of New Yorkers are now doing their Christmas shopping in armchairs, far from the stampeding crowds.

The new military radio communications system explained to the North Atlantic Council yesterday is probably as foolproof as electronic waves can be. But it cannot offer 100 per cent certainty of communications and United States electronic specialists say it can be jammed.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross wants to know how it was possible for a captain of prison guards to get the same pay check cashed twice.

The North Atlantic Council, attended by the Foreign, Defense and Finance Ministers of fifteen nations, has concluded its first post-Geneva meeting in an atmosphere set by the general realization that the Soviets have deliberately killed the "spirit of Geneva" and resumed the cold war.
SUCH an outpouring of Handel's music as was given in St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church last night by the Cantata Singers is an overwhelming experience.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The United States charged Communist China tonight with violation of its Sept. 10 agreement to set free all fourteen American civilians still in prison.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- There is a great deal of pessimism here about the chances of stopping inflation in the long run.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -Sam Katz, former theatre owner and studio production executive, and Joseph Pasternak, producer, have agreed to form their own producing company upon the expiration of Mr. Pasternak's employment contract with Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer. That arrangement has fifteen months to run.

In your editorial of Dec. 8 "Labor and Politics" you stated, "The speeches of Messrs. Meany and Reuther to the unity convention reflect a determination to exert far more direct influence in politics. * * * We see no objection to labor's endorsement of a candidate based on his 'competence and integrity' and on 'where his party stands on the basic issues,' as Mr. Reuther put it.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Stock markets ended the week quietly today with prices still moving narrowly and irregularly. Industrials tended to strengthen near the close after being dull. Volume declined further.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 16 -- City officials here were charged today with wasting public funds, submitting to political influence, and condoning "no-show" jobholders and excessive absenteeism in their departments.

Events today: Children's Concert, Little Orchestra Society, Hunter College Auditorium, 11:30 A. M.; "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Young People's Concert, Philharmonic-Symphony, Town Hall, 3; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3; "Barber of Seville," Opera '56, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 2:30; Trapp Family Singers, Town Hall, 5:30.

The Holland-America Line has placed an order with the Luebecker Flenderwerke, Luebeck, Germany for the third vessel in the Company's new K series of all-purpose freighters. She will be named Kerkedyk.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- The Western Big Three told the Soviet Union again today that they held Moscow responsible for all four-power agreements on Germany, including those concerning Berlin.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- A little object like a domino bearing the word "Philippines" was drawn from a box tonight by Jose Maza, President of the General Assembly.
In your editorial of Dec. 8 on "Labor and Politics" you succinctly summarized the basic aims and objectives of the contemporary American labor movement.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Syria called on the United Nations today for economic sanctions against Israel. She asked this as punishment for last Sunday's Israeli attack east of the Sea of Galilee.

HERE are some glittering garnishes for a polished, furbished Christmas - ready home. All are easy to make. For A Small End Table (above left): "Plant" a tree of Styrofoam plastic in a white flower pot. The tree shape is made by cutting a round of the plastic of a size to fit in the pot and topping it with a tapered shape of the material.
TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The New Jersey Racing Commission disclosed today the state's three flat tracks and one harness track had filed applications for a total of 200 days of racing in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Department of Agriculture has purchased about $15,000,000 worth of pork products since the Administration started its program to aid hog farmers six weeks ago.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams explained yesterday that he had disqualified himself last October as attorney for the Government in a civil action against the Esso Export Corporation and its parent, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Makers of fountain pens and mechanical pencils are saving more than a million dollars a year by "panning" precious metals from dust, waste and litter. They are salvaging valuable amounts of gold, silver, palladium and other metal dust from plant floors, carpets, work-benches, machinery, workmen's aprons, smocks, shoes and the very air.
Industrial property and leases in shopping figured in New Jersey realty transactions announced terday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been chosen to receive the Poor Richard Club Medal of Achievement for 1956, it was announced today by George M. Neil, club president.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Francois Mitterrand, who was Minister of the Interior under Premier Pierre Mendes-France, was hit on the nose by a pear the other night. The pear was preceded and followed by ripe tomatoes.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- A survey published today by the newspaper Die Welt of Hamburg shows that the Communist party has re-established a strong bridgehead in West Germany's steel, shipbuilding and engineering industries.
The Georgetown University Law Center won last night the sixth annual National Moot Court Competition of the Young Lawyers Committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

In the editorial "Twenty-one Is About Right," published Dec. 13, the question is asked, "What 18-year-old boy won't applaud when told that he is wise enough to help govern the country?" Well, I know several and it hardly seems possible that they are an isolated group.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) -Federal Judge Thomas J. Clary today set Oct. 1, 1956, as the tentative trial date in the trucking industry's $250,000,000 suit against thirty-one eastern railroads.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Adlai E. Stevenson welcomed Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee today as a rival aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 16 -- The Passaic County grand jury handed up six indictments today against a commissioner and a detective of the city of Passaic. They are accused of attempted extortion in connection with the construction of the new City Hall in Passaic.
It can be no surprise that the Giants' Willie Mays was the 1955 slugging leader of the National League, but it became official yesterday with the release of the league figures.

PETAH TIQVA, Israel, Dec. 14 -- Delegates from fifty Malben institutions in Israel met today for a Cultural Conference of the Aged. The meeting was held in Givat Hashlosha, a newly built Malben home near here.
Two clergymen and a physician on an interfaith mission of friendship will leave New York International Airport Tuesday with medical supplies for a hospital in Nazareth, Israel.
TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Mass picketing was resumed today at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's lamp plant here despite a court order yesterday drastically limiting it.

Dental authorities here emphasized yesterday that the proper use of dental X-ray machines was not a radiation hazard in their opinion.
The Playwrights Company and Gayle Stine are readying Leslie Stevens' twelfth-century drama, "The Lovers," for a Broadway opening early next March.
The mass resignation of scientific personnel from Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's missiles division is a by-product of the technological revolution in warfare.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 16 -- President Sukarno has refused to accept the resignation of Vice Air Marshal Suryadarma. He has thus openly joined those seeking to bring about the downfall of the pro-Western Cabinet of Premier Burhanuddin Harahap.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The National Biscuit Company has sold its old shredded wheat plant overlooking the Niagara River here near the falls.

CHESHIRE, brinza, grappe and reblochon -- these are cheeses, some new, some with a commendable history of several centuries. They are grouped together because all were newcomers locally this year. Also, all can be recommended as excellent fare for the holiday season.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 16 -- Mrs. John W. Nason, wife of the president of the Foreign Policy Association, was killed by a mail truck while she was Christmas shopping here yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 16 -- Another major medical check-up confronts President Eisenhower here tomorrow.

Christmas tree ornaments, delicious to eat as they are to look at, are available in variety. In many candy shops, for example, marzipan or chocolate is molded to resemble a fruit, an angel's harp or a star. The pieces usually are encased in brightly colored foil and have a loop of string or wire so they may be hung on the fir tree.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 16 -- The de Havilland Comet III reached Vancouver International Airport at 1:39 P. M., Pacific standard time, today, 5 hours 39 minutes after take-off from Honolulu. The British airliner clipped 2 hours 49 minutes off the commercial airline record for the Honolulu-Vancouver hop.
Another gift of $250,000 -- this one to the Assurance Fund of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases -- has been made by the estate of Alfred H. Caspary.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight said today that he would welcome Vice President Richard M. Nixon on his favorite son delegation to the Republican National Convention if President Eisenhower was not a candidate for re-election.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The independent liberal newspaper Haaretz declared editorially today that the Sea of Galilee attack "brought Israel dangerously close to dictatorship by the chief of Government."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- The National Broadcasting Company is scheduling a two-phase series of color television experiments in the Hollywood area next month.

An uneasy interval in the market for new prime - risk corporate debt securities came to an end yesterday as major pension funds and trust account investors hastened to put in orders for the unsold remainder of the $70,000,000 issue of Consolidated Edison Company bonds placed on the market last week.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Semi-final brackets were filled in the featured Ardsley Medal competition of the Cuthbertson Bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today. The Ardsley Curling Club won two of the berths.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A series of earthquakes shook the Imperial Valley tonight, breaking shop windows in near-by Brawley and causing patrons to leave theatres.

Throughout the year in this newspaper the new books have been reported, criticized, analyzed, discussed and advertised on their merits as literature, news, education, or just plain fun. Now we face something that has been sidestepped these many months and herewith present a quantitative analysis of the costs of being well-read in 1955.

" LA FORZA DEL DESTINO" might be called Verdi's good, gray opera. It is full of melody, but much of it is somber or resigned. Verdi, whose powers were growing all the time, set the libretto he had to set with inventiveness and dramatic pungency.
AN experiment in blending foreign intrigue with the home scene was essayed last night on Channel 4's "Star Stage."
Cotton futures moved 17 points (85 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents a bale) off yesterday. Old - crop months showed the most strength, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange light.

In the next few weeks fifteen trans-Atlantic liners, the cream of the world's passenger shipping fleets, flying the flags of the leading maritime nations, will converge upon the Port of New York for the winter cruise season.

MIAMI, Fla., Saturday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said early today charges would be filed against a 20-year-old youth in connection with an attempt to extort $600,000 from John S. Knight, editor and publisher of The Miami Herald and other newspapers.
The only general non-Communist Russian language publishing house in the world will close within a few months, it was learned yesterday.

The United Jewish Appeal's constituent agencies listed yesterday an over-all budgetary requirement of $153,146,035 to meet the needs of Jewish men, women and children over the world next year, particularly in Israel and North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Senate Investigations subcommittee made public today testimony given two years ago by William Henry Taylor in denying that he was ever a member of the Communist party or of an espionage ring.

Influenced by a better tone for steels, oils, aircrafts and electrical equipment issues, the stock market moved higher yesterday. Industrials as a whole did far better than rails, but motors were unimpressive.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 16 -- The first major project in the modernization of the seventeen-year-old Merritt Parkway is under way here.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 -- A national campaign is being mounted to improve the lot of the nation's estimated 11,000 retired college teachers. Many of them are getting retirement pay of $100 a month or less.

The announcement of Senator Kefauver that he is a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination makes the political pot boil a little more merrily. It is an announcement as welcome as it is expected, for the showing Mr. Kefauver made in his unsuccessful try for the nomination in 1952 certainly warrants another attempt.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 16 -The Taft School of Watertown, Conn., the defending champion, and St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., gained the final round of the Lawrenceville School hockey tournament tonight at Baker Rink.

A new appeal for educational television stations in New York City and Albany was made yesterday by the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York. Undaunted by a previous failure to obtain facilities, the board has recommended that the state appropriate $975,000.

MADRID, Dec. 16 -- Moroccan Nationalists said today that Spain faced trouble unless she recognized the independence and unity of the Moroccan Empire "in the shortest possible time."

A shoplifting suspect was shot and wounded late yesterday when, the police said, he attempted to escape from two detectives near the downtown Brooklyn shopping district. He was taken to Cumberland Hospital, where his condition was reported to be fair.

Elmer F. (Trigger) Burke, 38-year-old convicted murderer, spoke for twelve minutes yesterday in General Sessions Court before hearing himself sentenced to death by Judge John A. Mullen.

The official New York State canvass of votes in the Nov. 8 election reverses the unofficial early count and shows that Proposition No. 1, for $50,000,000 in state loans to limited-profit companies to build middle-income housing, won out by the narrow margin of 22,362 votes.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill said today that there was a "growing measure of goodwill" between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland that would not be within the power of a small minority to alter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Views of two trial examiners of the Federal Trade Commission collided today in rulings governing charges of misrepresentation by two accident and health insurance companies.

For five minutes yesterday the Christmas spirit halted trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Four million dollars worth of business waited while members cheered, heard a schoolboy choir sing two choruses of "Silent Night," and cheered again.

Airwork Limited, a private British carrier that began trans-Atlantic cargo flights ten months ago, announced here yesterday it would suspend the operation as unprofitable. It placed the blame on the British Government.

LADIES, not gifts, should be the prettiest packages of the Christmas season. Abraham Straus affirms this with a collection of clothes for the holiday season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Senator Estes Kefauver formally placed his coonskin cap in the Democratic Presidential ring today for a second time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The General Electric Company suggested today that many of television's financial problems might be solved if ultra high frequency channels were allocated to all stations.

Directors of the Valley National Bank, Phoenix, Ariz., voted yesterday to distribute a 5 per cent stock dividend. If shareholders approve the proposed dividend, it will mean the issuance of 60,000 additional shares.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 16 -In this capital of a remote kingdom a handful of men is matching wits with leaders of the Soviet Union. The stake is the future of Afghanistan.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production this week will drop slightly to 168,337 cars and 26,778 trucks, reflecting parts shortages and a general absence of Saturday scheduling, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

While officials of the Long Island Rail Road were gathering yesterday morning to press their defense of recent fare increases, thousands of the line's passengers were delayed five to fifty minutes.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges closed irregularly yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, sugar and rubber were mixed; onions, copper, zinc and wool eased, and hides, cocoa, potatoes and cottonseed oil rose.

Jiro Nagasawa, the national butterfly stroke champion of Japan and world recordholder for the 200-meter butterfly event, bettered a metropolitan record last night in an invitation swimming meet at the New York Athletic Club.

Ludwig Lightburn from Belize, British Honduras, defeated Ralph Dupas of New Orleans in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The fight was waged at a brisk clip and proved entertaining to the small crowd.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended last Tuesday to 111.0 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. AMONG retail and wholesale florists and growers in many sections of the country, Christmas is known as one of the "pot plant holidays." That is, the sales of potted plants of all kinds during the Christmas season usually exceed the total sales of cut flowers.

IN a northern village of the Rio Grande at the beginning of the nineteenth century two brothers, Roberto and Carlos Castillo, learned their craft of saintmakers from a testy Franciscan friar. He had once stayed in their village, sandily calling them brats, yet preferring them and the aged, as nearer God, the source and goal, to the middle-aged, who thought they knew what they wanted.
Two infant girls died and their 5-year-old brother was burned seriously yesterday in a fire in their Bronx apartment while their mother was Christmas shopping.

MIAMI, FLA. -- A greatly expanded series of wildlife tours in South Florida by the National Audubon Society will give visitors this winter an unprecedented chance to see some of the rarest birds in the United States. The tours, already in progress, will continue through next spring.

Savers who store their cash in New York savings banks are not getting so many year-end extra dividend payments this year as they did last. The chief reason is that most of what was paid as extras last year has been made part of this year's regular dividend payments.

THE opening of a new photographic show next month at the Museum of Modern Art will signalize the resumption of regular exhibition activity there, Edward Steichen, director of the museum's Department of Photography, announced last week.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- Bills designed to establish price controls in the gasoline industry and increase state aid to education are expected to top the agenda when the Republican-controlled Legislature reconvenes here Monday. It will be the last meeting of the year for both houses.

WINTER arrives next Thursday, and to some tree owners this may seem a strange time to suggest feeding of shade trees. But it isn't. Shade trees can be fed any time the ground is not frozen solid.

New York and Brooklyn department stores last week continued to top their 1954 pre-Christmas sales figures. In the previous week, sales had also showed a modest increase over last year's volume on a store-for-store basis.

MIAMI -- A novel idea in holiday travel that is growing in popularity is the "vacation from a vacation." Travelers to the Miami Beach area this winter will find waiting for them a neatly packaged three-day cruise aboard the S. S. Queen of Nassau, leaving twice a week from Miami to Nassau, with a two-day stop there.

COMPANIES and industries are extending confidence for the coming year. Their faith in the near-term outlook is justified if they have a backlog of orders and can see nothing ahead that would interfere with the flow of raw materials at current prices. There is some doubt, however, that present cost situations will continue indefinitely and a tightening of supplies could throw many things out of kilter.

A "relatively heartening" picture of farm conditions in the upper Midwest was sketched by economists of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank last week. Christmas business continued at a brisk pace last week but merchants expressed disappointment that the rate of gain did not increase over the previous week's total. Water as needed But never enough to leave, soil soggy. Turn plants in windows a quarter circle once a week so growth will 'be symmetrical.

New issues of state and municipal securities scheduled for sale this week aggregate $34,961,350 bonds and $52,208,000 short-term notes, according to the Bond Buyer. This compares with $160,341,464 bonds and $74,831,000 notes last week.

Carol Haney and her husband, Larry Blyden, are anxious to appear together next fall in "archy and mehitabel." This is the George Kleinsinger - Joe Darion musical adapted from Don Marquis' lower-case stories about the poetical cockroach and his irrepressible feline companion.

Samuel Reshevsky, the international chess ace, required two sessions, afternoon and evening, to win his first game in defense of the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy yesterday. The second tournament of the series sponsored by the American Chess Foundation started at the Manhattan Chess Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Paramount will provide financing for the Broadway musical version of "Li'l Abner," scheduled to open early next fall, and the subsequent motion picture edition. Sudan is to become an independent country by its own, unilateral fiat today. Premier Ismail el Azhari in Khartum made a surprise announcement to this effect last week, and since there is nothing and nobody in sight to prevent this development we must expect it to happen.

Charles Collingwood has been proposed as the new president of the New York local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. He is expected to be an official nominee in the coming election for eight officer posts.
TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- A report that recommends drastic changes in Federal and state tax sources and aid programs will go to the Governor and the Legislature tomorrow.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The new Tappan Zee bridge of the New York Thruway was crowded today, its first Sunday, by Westchester and Rockland County residents crossing the Hudson.
The New York Americans eliminated Malta United from the National Challenge Cup soccer competition with a 2-0 victory at Zerega Oval yesterday.

Five years after Capt. Leonard P. LaRue rescued more than 14,000 Korean civilians from death at the hands of Communist troops, the former master of the Moore-McCormack Lines cargo ship Meredith Victory is to be formally decorated by Korea. The ceremony will be held Wednesday in Washington in the Korean Embassy.

CAIRO, Dec. 18 -- Ambassador Solod went to the Egyptian Foreign Office today to express the Soviet Union's deep concern about Arab-Israeli border tension. But he carefully avoided uttering an outright condemnation of the Israeli attack on Syria a week ago.

BECAUSE it wasn't quite a bargain basement transaction, the sale of Nashua for the tidy sum of $1,251,200 brings with it feelings of light-headedness and unreality. Shakespeare was merely putting words into the mouth of Richard when he had him offering "my kingdom for a horse." This is no fictional situation, even though it packs even more tense drama. This is for keeps.

The juxtaposition of two recent news items provides an ironic contrast well worth pondering. From East Germany comes word that a Communist publishing house there is putting out a series of pocketbooks in English featuring the writings of "progressive" -- that is, pro-Communist -- writers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- American Red Cross headquarters said tonight that Communist China had agreed to set free an American medical missionary imprisoned for five years, Dr. Homer V. Bradshaw of Pittsburgh, Pa.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- A broad grouping of private French banks is under way on the Paris market under the initiative of the Banque de l'Indochine (Bank of Indochina).

ALDEN, Minn., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Richard Tenneson, 22 years old, Minnesota's turncoat G. I., was received cordially at the Alden Methodist Church today in his first public appearance here since his return from the Far East Friday.

The appointments of Robert M. Lynch as president and of Walter S. Busch as vice president of A. Johnson Co., shipping representatives, were announced here yesterday by the company's board of directors.
