GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 18 -Following are the remarks of President Eisenhower before he switched on the lights of the national community Christmas tree at the Pageant of Peace in Washington:

George Meany is backing a proposal by Robert Moses for using millions of dollars in union welfare and pension funds to tear down slums and build middle-income housing developments in this city. Mr. Meany, president of the unified labor movement, has told the leaders of New York construction unions that he believes large-scale housing investments represent a safe and socially useful way to apply the huge sums now tied up in union welfare reserves.

IT'S happy hunting at E. Joseph. That sixty-six-year-old wholesale and retail dealer in game in the Washington Market is the chief specialist in wildlife in New York, and among the leading purveyors of it in the United States.

Recourse to the Holy Spirit for guidance and support in all phases of life was urged yesterday by the Rev. Vincent F. Holden of the Paulist Fathers, in an Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He described the Third Person of the Trinity as man's "closest and most intimate friend."

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The stock markets gave a moderately good account of themselves last week. The nearness of Christmas was one factor. Another was a report on the sharp widening of Great Britain's overseas trade gap in November, creating fresh uneasiness regarding the balance of payments.

The Christmas season would not be complete without the annual presentation of "The Messiah'' by the Oratorio Society of New York. This event took place at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening, with Albert Greenfield conducting.
The members of the City Council may have their annual expense allowance of $1,000 Increased to $3,000 after all.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda complained today that Russian music, while full of "Socialist realism," was just plain dull.
The Eisenhower Administration appears to be making great efforts to ease the complicated farm surplus problem.

Mr.'and Mrs. Charles D. Donsihue of 70 East eventy-seventh/ Street gave a cocktail party andi huffeb supper at the River ClubI last night for their debutanteI granddaughter, Miss Tanis Hig-J gins. The debutante, who received with her grandmother, wore a gown of champagnecolored peau de sole and carried a bouquet of red camellias.

DETROIT, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Alex Delvecchio scored two goals and Glenn Hall turned in his third straight shutout tonight as the Detroit Red Wings gained a 2-0 victory over the Canadiens. The defeat snapped Montreal's eight-game winning streak.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., more than doubled its earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 29.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 18 -- According to reports from Jordan, some of the demonstrations in that country this week-end have been directed against what is in effect the British command of the Arab Legion, Jordan's armed force. Other factors in the outbreaks appeared to be anti-Israel and also a general anti-foreignism.
Frances Burnett, pianist, made her debut here last evening in a recital at Town Hall.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Dec. 18 -- The Saar today elected a new Parliament overwhelmingly dominated by three big pro-German parties pledged to speedy union of this industrial border state with West Germany.

Another massive volume, the third in three years, has come from the workroom of W. S. Woytinsky and E. S. Woytinsky (his wife). It is "World Commerce and Governments: Trends and Outlook," a companion to the 1953 "World Population and Production."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -Senate investigators said today that the Government was denying cash benefits due more than 250 former Korean War prisoners because of secret Army charges of collaboration.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The University of Chicago had endowment funds with a market value of $148,000,000 on June 30, its annual report shows.

THE history of America -from Valley Forge to the wedding of Eddie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds -- was reviewed in song Saturday night in the third of the "Ford Star Jubilee" presentations over Channel 2. The British now may feel that they did not lose so much after all.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 -- Production troubles and holidays will cut steel production in the next few weeks but it is now certain that more than 116,500,000 tons of steel will be turned out this year. That will make a new high mark in U. S. steel mill history.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- Today is an anniversary of peculiar interest. Exactly thirty years ago the concept of "peaceful coexistence" was introduced to an uneasy world. So far as this writer can ascertain, these precise words were first employed by Stalin on Dec. 18, 1925, in a report to the Fourteenth Congress of the Bolshevik party.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Pentagon was studying today a charge that the Defense Department had abandoned open, competitive bidding to a "shocking" degree.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Jelle Zijlstra, Minister for Economic Affairs, is pressing his struggle against price-fixing by cartels to back labor demands for wage increases.
Grants totaling $10,375,000 for theodogical education were announced yesterday by the Sealantic Fund, Inc.

Traffic was either stalled or held to a turtle's pace for several hours yesterday on Fifth Avenue, but few of the motorists grumbled. Through fits-and-starts, thousands of out-of-town sight-seeing families got long looks at the Christmas displays and store windows they had come to town to see.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Hugh Gaitskell, newly elected Leader of the Labor party, sharply criticized tonight the Government's handling of foreign affairs.
A Lutheran minister assumed a new pastorate yesterday by defining the task he and his congregation must undertake together.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored four times in a rough-and-tumble second period tonight and went on to defeat the Boston Bruins, 7 -- 1.
Seventy-five Baltimore hat strikers who lost their jobs when their employer went out of business are going back to work in a new hat company started with a $25,000 union loan.

The centennial of St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Greenwich Village was celebrated yesterday. The edifice at 81 Christopher Street stands on the site of the first Lutheran theological seminary in America.
Cardinal Spellman mailed a check for $300 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund before leaving on Friday for his annual visit to United States service men stationed in Asia.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Cornelius Shields was the most consistent skipper as the season's record fleet, thirty-eight Interclub Class dinghies, sailed seven races at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. The noted International yachtsman captured his first regatta of the frostbite championship campaign.
State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits hinted yesterday that he might run for Senator next year.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 18 -- Apathy marked today's nationwide elections for Congress and municipal offices, according to officials here.

A Protestant clergyman de-I clared himself in a yester-/ day with the view that the Dead/ Sea Scrolls provided evidence[ that Jesus Christ did not appear/ 'full-blown" as a supernatural act of God, but rather had a, llatural origin.
A number of exciting months still remain to Nov. 5, 1956, but already our collective national eyes focus on the eventful Tuesday when a President is to be elected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -Washington's annual Pageant of Peace began today as President Eisenhower lighted the sixty-five foot national community Christmas tree in the Ellipse, the park just south of the White House grounds.
The letter written by Charles A. Siepmann and published by you Dec. 12 came as a thunderbolt out of the blue to this writer.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The official organ of Soviet communism said today United States foreign policy might worsen the international situation but could not kill the "spirit of Geneva." It predicted Washington would succeed only in isolating itself from its allies.
Governor Harriman demonstrated yesterday that in drafting his 1956 legislative program he was experiencing the season's common woes -- a Christmas rush and a lot of blank spaces on his list.

Back of the tinsel and gaiety of the holiday season there are grim shadows that envelop human hearts, forced to carry burdens too heavy for mortals to bear alone. And when the ills of the flesh are compounded by delays of the law Samaritans must be called upon to ease the strain.
I should like to take issue with certain of the assumptions manifest in your editorial of Dec. 13 "The Armament Dilemma."

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -- Stories in the German press last week disclosed the sensational fact that the Union Bank of Switzerland had been approached by a Bremen client, Hermann D. Krages, a merchant, to act as intermediary for the sale of a block of stock in Gelsenkirchener Bergwerks A. G., Duesseldorf, to an American group.
Savings and loan associations are planning a long-range study of the institution that provides them with credit when they need it.

TOKYO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The United States Far East Air Forces all-star football team today won the right to face the Army all-stars in the Far East Rice Bowl Dec. 31 by trouncing Navy, 21 -- 0, in the Sukiyaki Bowl.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 18 -- Afghanistan's Foreign Minister insisted today that his country would remain neutral despite any arms or economic aid from the Soviet Union.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- Unless a threatened pilots' strike is called off, Western Air Lines will offer to lease its equipment to competing scheduled airlines during Christmas.

After losing ground at the start of last week, cotton prices turned firmer in the domestic market and closed with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 13 to 42 points (65 cents to $2.10 a bale) from the levels of a week before. The best gain was in the near-by March delivery.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 -- Uruguay's consular representative in Hong Kong was reported today to have signed a joint communique with Communist China's Foreign Trade Ministry expressing hope for a trade agreement between the two Governments.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The closing General Assembly meeting scheduled for tomorrow was postponed tonight. It is now set for 10:30 A. M. Tuesday.
Mrs. Anna M. Kross, Commissioner of Correction, said last night she did not favor the so-called "quota system" of hiring probation officers for the New York Children's Court.

Organized landlords yesterday took the side of a tenant against a landlord who is trying to evict her. The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, the largest organization of owners of residential property in this area, announced it was ready to intervene as amicus curiae -- friend of the court -- in behalf of Mrs. Adele Gutman Nathan, a free-lance writer who lives at 157 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The trucking industry's gross revenues for 1955 were estimated yesterday at $5,400,000,000, an all-time high, by the American Trucking Association. It predicted a substantial increase next year.

The news story in The Times of Dec. 11 entitled "U. S. Suit Claims Old Documents" is, so far as I know, the first account of an extremely interesting and important legal case now pending that has appeared in the public press.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 -- Premier Pibul Songgram returns from Burma tomorrow to face a problem of growing importance to Thailand: Just how free is freedom?
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 -- Leaders of some of the nation's largest independent unions met here today to discuss the formation of a new and stronger national association.
The steamship charter market continued on its "bullish" trend last week. Nearly all commodities brought rate increases, but no single cargo dominated the field.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -Pancho Gonzales made it 3 -- 1 in their professional tennis match series last night, but Tony Trabert says "I am in nowise discouraged."

An unpleasant odor, attributed variously to a skunk, gas or oil fumes, "something dead," or rotten eggs, caused 300 calls to the police yesterday. Other city agencies, public utilities and the Federal Bureau of Investigation also received calls.
A $500,000 program of grants to improve use of teachers in colleges and universities in view of increasing student enrollments was announced yesterday by the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The Mahopac Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by W. Tyler (Ty) Halsted, captured the Ardsley Medal at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today to cap the first Cuthbertson Bonspiel. The four-day tourney honored the late Willie Cuthbertson.

Red Auerbach, the fiery coach of the Boston Celtics, received many gifts, including a fire-engine red automobile, during ceremonies before the Knickbocker-Celtic basketball game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. He made a nice speech thanking all for the "Auerbach Day" and then retired to his bench and coaxed, yelled and master minded his squad to a 95-92 victory over the New York quintet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Civil Service Commission set a time limit today of six months for Government agencies to recommend employes for permanent status when their jobs are brought into the competitive Civil Service system.

" ZOO PARADE," the Sunday afternoon show on Channel 4 that has been presenting interesting views of beasts in captivity, began something new yesterday. It offered the first in a weekly series of nine films made for the program in Africa last summer.
A strong new emphasis is being placed these days on how Federal, state and local governments can stimulate housing construction and rehabilitation.
Religious instruction in the public schools was opposed from the pulpit yesterday by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

The Soviet Communist party has grown by more than 1,000,000 members in less than three years, Nikita S. Khrushchev has disclosed. This sharp growth seems to imply abandonment of a major policy laid down by former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov late in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Well-informed opinion in the capital is gradually changing to the view that President Eisenhower will seek another term.

One received a remarkably mild impression of twentieth century American music from the concert of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors that was offered yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Six persons were killed today when a speeding Ferrari racer roared out of control and crashed into a group of spectators in Colombia's annual Barranquilla-to-Cartagena auto race.
Samuel Leifer, operator, recently purchased the five-story apartment house for twenty-seven families at 2935 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, from Myron Sulzberger, who owned the property for twenty years.

A stone-and-brick residence on plot 50 by 100 feet at Devon Road and Highwood Way in Larchmont, Westchester County, was sold by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Knight to Mr. and Mrs. Ben Dundee, formerly of the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Owen A. Mandeville, Inc., was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
SANFORD, Fla., Dec. 18 (UP) -- Tommy Bolt has accused golfing galleries of illegally helping Sam Snead during tournaments by kicking balls to more favorable lies.

The apparent size and kind of the Administration's new foreign-aid program underwent a remarkable change between last Tuesday, when the President met with Congressional leaders of both parties in Washington, and last Saturday, when a high but unidentified official unloaded some startling figures.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Jacques Charland, a member of Canada's Olympic team, completed a successful week-end today by taking top honors in the eleventh annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski jumping tournament.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The touring Soviet leaders wound up their South Asian tour tonight by granting Afghanistan a $100,000,000 loan. A Moscow broadcast said the Afghans had promised to continue their policy of neutrality in world affairs.

With Santa Claus working himself and his gnomes overtime at the North Pole's 90-degree latitude, his representatives down here at longitude 74 degrees west, latitude 40 degrees 42 minutes north, entertained children yesterday.

Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, defended yesterday a city directive giving full control of Kings County Hospital Medical Center to the university's College of Medicine.
Increased facilities for higher education at moderate cost are being planned for Long Island.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 18 -- President Eisenhower, referring to the problem of world peace, said this afternoon that this Christmas was "brighter in its background and its promise for the future than any we have known in recent years."

A reorganization plan that would make the Henry J. Kaiser Company a subsidiary of the Kaiser Motors Corporation through an exchange of stocks was announced yesterday by Henry J. Kaiser and Edgar F. Kaiser, chairman and president, respectively, of both companies.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Three persona were killed and a hangar was destroyed by fire when a Navy jet fighter ran wqld at the Air Force base here.
CAIRO, Dec. 18 -- Soviet Ambassador Daniel S. Solod said here today the Soviet Union still intended to take part in the Aswan High Dam project.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The State Department reported tonight that foreigners obtained United States entry permits in record numbers during the twelve months that ended last June 30.
In the world of sports, as well as in the business, any organization with widespread activities must have a "brains" department.

Twelve films will be presented as holiday attractions in first-run theatres this week, in addition to the French-made "Letters From My Windmill," which opened at the Paris Theatre yesterday and is reviewed today. The programs follow:

Soviet pressure is being exerted, momentarily, upon Afghanistan. The "traveling salesmen" are trying to sell their wares in Kabul, and once more they are relying upon an appeal to local and chauvinistic feeling. The performance in Afghanistan has no more dignity than that in India, Burma or Kashmir, and it follows the same general pattern.
Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" will return to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Thursday evening, Dec. 29, after two years' absence.
A GENTLEMAN in town, a fellow of some means, made the rounds a few weeks ago of city savings banks that offered a free ball-point pen for anyone who would open a new account of $5, or more.

Many Park Avenue strollers were bewildered yesterday as they passed the creche in the courtyard of Christ Church, Methodist, at Sixtieth Street. They thought that the motionless characters in the familiar manger setting had an unusually lifelike quality.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 18 -- The New York State Insurance Department is holding up approval of a merger between the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company and the National Fire Insurance Company, it was disclosed tonight.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission no longer will ask license applicants the color of their skin, Governor Harriman's office announced today.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 18 -- Gen. Ivan A. Serov came into his own today.

Six brownstone dwellings at the southwest corner of Beekman Place and East Fiftieth Street will make way for a modern apartment house development as a result of their purchase by builders represented by Martin S. Kimmel.

Commercial paper outstanding in the United States increased in November to a month-end total of $2,283,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end. The total was $251,000,000 higher that a year ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The trend of grain prices continues to hinge on prospective legislative moves. Belief that means will be found to bolster the farm economy has been a background factor that has created investment demand on the setbacks.

For many years now the annual Soviet budget has presented many mysteries, not least as regards the method of its preparation. So far as the outside world has been able to see, the budget has annually been presented to the Supreme Soviet, debated gingerly for a few days, and then passed unanimously with only the most minor changes.
ERNEST KINOY fired a volley of literary buckshot when he wrote "Christmas 'Til Closing," the comedy presented last night on "Goodyear Playhouse" over Channel 4.

Following are the texts of a protocol signed Sunday in Kabul extending the Afghan Soviet neutrality and nonaggression pact, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, and of a joint statement and aid agreement between the Soviet Union and Afghanistan, as announced in Moscow by Soviet news agency:
MONTREAL, Dec. 17 -- A tramp steamer with the fancy name of Maria de Larrinaga had the distinction yesterday of bringing the season to an end for this big inland seaport.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A program designed to improve company-dealer relationships was announced today by American Motors. The concern makes Nash, Hudson and Rambler automobiles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Estes Kefauver announced today that he would enter the New Hampshire primary. He challenged Adlai E. Stevenson to oppose him there.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The meeting of the North Atlantic Council here the last few days marked a new stage in its evolution from a mainly military gathering to a mainly political one.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 18 -- A group of officers of the Indonesian Air Force has voiced its disapproval of the armed defiance of government authority by elements within the service.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Policemen and students clashed here today and troops went into action against demonstrators in Jericho. The demonstrations were against proposals that Jordan join the anti-Communist Baghdad Pact for Middle Eastern defense.

" A Paris Surgeon's Story," the autobiography of Dr. Charles F. Bove, written in collaboration with Dana Lee Thomas, has been scheduled for Jan. 26 publication by Little, Brown. Dr. Bove, for twenty-five years chief surgeon in the American Hospital in Paris, tells of his work in France and of the prominent men and women he met.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, returned today from the North Atlantic Treaty meeting in Paris and declared that European nations felt "more than ever free -- more than ever secure."

TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- The Japanese Government slammed the door today on cotton goods exporters attempting to evade the ban on shipments to the United States by slipping in through the Canadian back door. It suspended approval of cotton textile exports to Canada as of today.

When the United Nations General Assembly meets today, in the final hours of its tenth regular session, it is expected to elect Yugoslavia, by the required two-thirds majority, to the vacant non-permanent seat on the Security Council.
A helicopter company that had its beginning in a cellar and garage celebrated its tenth anniversary early this month.

The Public Service Commission granted permanent certificates of public convenience and necessity yesterday to two bus companies for routes in South Brooklyn that serve students at one college and eight high schools.

Junior Achievement, a national nonprofit organization that puts teen-agers into business for themselves so that they may learn business by engaging in it, is to have the support of more than a score of national advertisers in various media.
Directors of the Binks Manufacturing Company have increased the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share, payable on Jan. 6, from 20 cents paid in previous quarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy urged the Justice Department today to speed its investigation of conflict between sworn testimony given last spring by Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker and that of two former employes of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigation.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Dr. and Mrs. Homer V. Bradshaw crossed the Hong Kong border to freedom today after almost five years in Chinese Communist captivity.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today listed the following ski conditions at New York winter resorts:
Whether or not Mayor Wagner wants a majority of the Board of Estimate to get "tremendous" pay increases became the $70,000 question at City Hall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines and Pan American Airways urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to dismiss an application by North American Airlines and four other carriers to lower trans-Atlantic air-coach fares by 50 per cent.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 19 -- North Carolina's Governor and two United States Senators agreed today that Federal assistance was necessary for a disaster insurance program.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 (AP) -- After having been on the verge of retaining the club, Syracuse today lost its International Baseball League franchise to Miami, Fla.

For most of yesterday's session, prices in the stock market were moderately higher, with aircrafts and steels in the lead. Then, in the late afternoon, Kaiser Aluminum and Schering joined with the motors to lead the market downward.
Rehabilitation of huge areas of the city was proposed last night as a means of curtailing the flight of city-dwellers to the suburbs and of making the city more prosperous.
The Transit Authority defended last night its action in opposing a proposed extension of the Nostrand Avenue line of the I. R. T. subway beyond its present Flatbush Avenue terminal in Brooklyn.

" MOST PEOPLE," says Patrick Pringle, "enjoy reading about crime." So they do, as everyone knows who has paused to inspect the paper-bound books displayed in drug stores and railway stations. Unfortunately for Mr. Pringle, who is a diligent and able historian of crime, most people prefer their literary crime to be served up richly garnished with fictional sex and sadism.

OTTAWA, Dec. 19 -- For the second time Canadian members of the armistice commission in Vietnam have complained that North Vietnam has used force and violence to impede the movement of refugees to the South.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Official government language, better known as Washington gobbledygook, had the Administration involved in another budget dispute with Congress today.
BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- Two United States soldiers arrested Dec. 7 by the East Berlin People's Police on an assault charge were acquitted today by a United States Army court-martial.
Pre-Christmas for children dominated the city scene yesterday. Youngsters gathered in all boroughs to share the fun.

Christmas shopping should be a happy chore -- gathering up gifts to bring friends and relatives happy remembrances at a festival season of the year. But buffeting a way through even merry crowds, lugging packed-to-bursting paper shopping bags, rushing for the subway before the crowded hour, can be a tiring task.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it had accepted bids for $1,600,492,000 of Treasury bills at an average price of 99.338, which is equivalent to an annual interest rate of 2.618 per cent, highest since 1933.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Israeli sources recapitulated today a seven-point proposal for peace with the Arab states.

One of the constructive acts of the Wagner administration in the past year was the creation of a new Department of Commerce and Public Events, expanding an undernourished work previously carried on through an adjunct of the Mayor's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Two honorably discharged servicemen denied charges today that they had collaborated with the Chinese Communists in Korea. They are seeking benefits for having spent twenty-eight months in a prison camp.
More than one week-end has been lost by people who have tried to explore the terminology of the liquor industry, not wisely but too well.

The Board of Higher Education approved last night a budget request of $28,346,559 for the four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens. That is about $3,000,000 higher than this year's appropriation. The request must now be considered by the Budget Director and the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the compensation for services rendered by parties participating in the five and a half year reorganization proceedings of the Long Island Railroad Company must be limited to $72,281.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates bought $13,250,000 of city and county of San Francisco various purpose bonds yesterday. The group is reoffering the bonds to yield 1.50 to 2.25 per cent, according to maturity.

A potential work stoppage on the Brooklyn waterfront failed to materialize yesterday morning when Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, made a personal appeal to the men.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation rejected today proposals by Governors of three states that the company and two striking unions immediately end the long walkout and submit disputed issues to arbitration.

In the passing of Archer M. Huntington, American sculpture has lost its stanchest champion and most loyal friend. In an era when our country was blessed with many patrons of the arts this great man was a veritable Medici.

The tiresome, tearful chore of peeling onions may be eliminated by boiling them briefly for five minutes. The papery skins may then be slipped off with the fingers. Submerging the onions in cold water makes them easy to handle.
The Federal Reserve System soon may have to demonstrate unmistakably again its hard-won independence from the Treasury.
The Boeing Airplane Company announced yesterday it had overcome the problems of suppressing the noise of jet engines and reversing their thrust on landing.
The seniors' ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday named R. Philip Hanna of Jackson Heights, Queens, as the No. 1 senior player in the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Government filed an appeal today from an order of Judge Luther W Youngdahl directing the State Department to grant Leonard B. Boudin, New York attorney, a hearing on his passport application.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 -- The Ford Motor Company, as a preliminary to its first public offering of stock, will file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington Wednesday.

There is no need for "complete surrender to today's method of buying the Christmas celebration ready-made," the National Recreation Association reminds parents. To the contrary, it maintains that some of the homespun spirit that went into yesteryear's celebration can be recaptured by the family that enjoys preparing for the festivities together.
The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., asked the United States Court of Appeals yesterday to issue an injunction against a dual rate system on cargoes moving from Japan to this country.
The supply of lendable funds in the New York City commercial banking system tightened at the close of last week after easing slightly on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Mrs. John Eisenhower, daughter-in-law of President Eisenhower, is in the Presidential suite at Walter Reed Army Hospital awaiting the birth of her fourth child.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the letter of resignation by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Special Assistant, and President Eisenhower's letter of acceptance. The letters were given out by the White House.
Don Zimmer, the Dodgers' plucky second baseman, who has been playing, or rather has been trying to play winter baseball in Puerto Rico, will retire for the balance of the off-season.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- The motion-picture business is experiencing another box-office recession in this country, Eric Johnston said today.

Board members of the International Boxing Guild and the Boxing Guild of New York took no action last night on the decision announced last week by Julius Helfand, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

We wish to express our fear that the United Nations is falling into the path which discredited the League of Nations. The League lost its influence when it went back on its word after Haille Selassie's kingdom was attacked.
Fire violations in seventeen midtown motion picture theatres were uncovered yesterday by firemen in the first day of a citywide drive on movie houses.

Although there has been no official word, it was learned yesterday that "Waiting for Godot" is due Feb. 13 at the Music Box. Bert Lahr and Tom Ewell are starred in the Michael Myerberg presentation of Samuel Beckett's tragi-comedy. The director is Alan Schneider.
Today's new film is "The Naked Sea," a feature-length documentary in color on the drama of tuna fishing, at the Baronet. The film was produced and directed by Allen H. Miner for R. K. O. release.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- The Bonn Government had ample reason to be satisfied today with the results of the Landtag (Parliament) election in the Saar.
Winter will come on Thursday at 10:12 A. M., but New Yorkers probably will get a shivering pre-season frigidity today.

Arthur B. Bisguier, United States chess champion, and Samuel Reshevsky, international ace, played to a draw last night in the second round of the tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.

SUMMER? Where fashion is concerned, it comes to town with the Christmas trees. Even as Christmas shoppers swarm in the aisles, resort clothes sprout on the racks. In their midst are often some of the most imaginative ideas for the new clothes crop.

THOSE two unreconstructed mountain boys from the Tennessee hills, Herman Hickman and Peahead Walker, can spin tall tales by the hour about their hillbilly kinfolk and kinfolk of kinfolk. Whenever they get together at a football gathering, the chitlings and the hogfat and the revenooers drip from their conversation.

Many persons paused in their Christmas preparations yesterday to send gifts and personal messages to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. As the forty-fourth annual appeal began its second week, 519 donors sent $10,099.50 to the fund, bringing the total number of contributors to 3,995 and the grand total of contributions to $229,329.80.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House Republican leader reiterated tonight a forecast that President Eisenhower would seek re-election because "he will not fail his country."
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Air Line Pilots Association "acceded" today to a request of the National (Railway) Mediation Board and agreed to postpone a strike scheduled against Western Air Lines.

Three books about Benjamin Franklin are scheduled for publication Jan. 17, the 250th anniversary of his birth. One will be a pictorial biography compiled by M. B. Schnapper and published by the Public Affairs Press of Washington.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 18 -- One theme -- Czechoslovak-Soviet friendship -- has dominated official life in Czechoslovakia recently. The occasion was the month of Czechoslovak-Soviet frienudship, now an official tradition here.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn said yesterday that it had no power to direct Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to order his court stenographer, Sidney Strimpel, to turn over to The New York Post a copy of the judge's charge in a manslaughter case.
BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- Two West Berliners received today the highest award the United States Air Force can bestow on foreign civilians for heroism.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 19 (UP) -- Willie Hartack returned to Tropical Park today for the first time since completing a ten-day suspension and rode two winners on a nine-race program.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Mailers Union No. 40 voted tonight to join stereotypers in a strike against Detroit's three metropolitan daily newspapers.
TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry decided today that the country still was ten years behind other industrialized nations in its techniques.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The cold wave injected some buying activity into the grain market at the start this morning, but prices receded frown the early tops. On the dips, buying broadened enough to cause a secondary rally, but this also was met by free selling.

CAIRO, Dec. 19 -- Although many Sudanese and most of the press in Cairo interpreted the Sudanese resolution as an outright declaration of independence of the million square mile area on the Upper Nile, there are still some hurdles before the British-Egyptian condominium rule formally ends.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 (UP) -- New York State today stopped payment of an $80,000 award to the widow of a Brooklyn welter-weight boxer, George Flores, pending the outcome of an appeal.
New York's department and specialty stores plunged yesterday into the final week of their best Christmas season in history, with excellent prospects for a gain of 20 per cent in sales for the week.
Sale of two miles of Brooklyn waterfront property to the Port of New York Authority for $13,961,000 was approved yesterday at a stockholders' meeting of the New York Dock Company.

The Sands Point Community Synagogue lost another battle yesterday in its fight for permission to use its own property as a temple and religious school The Brooklyn Appellate Division upheld a ruling of the Sands Point, L. I., Village Board of Zoning Appeals on Sept. 7 turning down the group's application.
A critical teacher shortage has developed on certain grade levels and for some subjects in the city schools.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- The Massachusetts Democratic State Committee had two separate headquarters today. There also were enough chairmen to go around.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- United States technical experts report that Soviet industry has attained generally high technical level. Their report is qualified by the observation that much old production machinery is still in use and a lack of imported Western tools has retarded progress.

Events today: Searle Wright organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; Symphony of the Air, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Renata Tebalo soprano, Jussi Bjoerling, tenor Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 19 -- The last of the stones that were the walls of Lenox Hall here were being carted away today. The end of the neo-Gothic landmark has closed a two-year controversy between the Princeton Theological Seminary, to which the structure belonged, and advocates of preservation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Although General Assembly delegates are agreed that something must be done to avoid having the 1956 session conflict with the Presidential election in the United States, no action is expected tomorrow.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 19 -- The Administration party of President Carlos Castillo Armas said today that its full slate of sixty-six Congressional candidates was swept into office in yesterday's nation-wide election.

Mr. and Mrs. James Todd of Bedford, N. Y., and Mrs. George Keith Henderson of Montreal gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce to society their respective daughters, Miss Alice de Peyster Todd and Miss Diana Sims Greeff.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Six high school football players died from injuries suffered during the 1955 season, a death rate of 0.90 per 100,000 players, the National High School Federation revealed today.

A new motion-picture film short, now showing in theatres, will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Jan. 1. The booking of the film into theatres and on television at the same time is considered unusual.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Colgate's speedy sharpshooters buried Davidson, 86 -- 51, tonight in the first round of the Carrousel basketball classic.

The American fondness for being identified with "a team" is responsible for a not-so-well-known industry. In recent years the manufacture of embroidered emblems, used for organization or company identification purposes, has become a thriving business.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Although no official here likes to say so, the Saar election yesterday was generally considered another step toward the return of that border territory to German sovereignty.

CHRISTMAS is a time of abundance, and so is youth. A Christmas cantata written by a Chilean composer ten years ago, when he was 26 years old, had its New York premiere at Town Hall last night, and it was full to overflowing with song and religious feeling.

Two young boys left unattended with their 3 1/2-year-old older brother were burned fatally in a Harlem tenement apartment last evening while their mother was out shopping. The oldest child was critically injured.

The building with thirty-six apartments and three stores at 917 Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, was bought by B. H. Gordon, operator, from Sophie Greenberg and immediately resold to a client of A. Sobel, attorney. The sale was subject to mortgages of $148,000, according to Ehrlich, Corso Feldman, brokers in the transaction.

TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a tenant's refusal to deny membership in a list of organizations was not sufficient ground for eviction from a public low-cost housing project.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The chances of the Los Angeles Rams defeating the Cleveland Browns for the National Football League title were lessened today by the disclosure that Fullback Tank Younger would not play.
THE early run of sailfish is now under way at Stuart, Fla., and a report yesterday indicated that many of the boats were returning to dock flying as many as fifteen "fish released" flags.
MILL VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) -- James Conley delivered mail to Marie MacDonagh for four years without knowing she was the half-sister who was separated from him twenty-five years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, asked the Subversive Activities Control Board today to reconsider its decision that Harry P. Cain, a board member, was qualified to preside over a hearing involving the Washington Pension Union.
Ali Baba had to say "Open Sesame" to move the magic door to the cave of the forty thieves. Today's magic doors don't even require that much effort.

J. S. Garlick, Inc., funeral director, has leased the one-story building at 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Ace Automobiles Sales Company and will occupy it as a funeral chapel after alterations. The structure formerly was used as an automobile showroom. M. C. O'Brien, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly is now scheduled to end its 1955 session tomorrow morning after electing Yugoslavia to the Security Council to replace Turkey.

A scheduled practice session for the New York Knickerbockers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday was canceled by Coach Joe Lapchick. The change in plans was Lapchick's idea. He figured his team would be fresher for tonight's meeting with the Syracuse Nationals at Madison Square Garden.

Silvered foliage and glittering white Christmas trees set in a glow of pink light provided a brilliant holiday decor last night for the twentieth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball. The fete, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was a benefit for the New York Infirmary.

PAINTINGS on the Christmas theme by fifty invited artists from Europe and North America are shown in the third international Hallmark Art Award exhibition at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Association of Interstate Commerce Commission Practitioners has given its members a blueprint on how to lobby against a governmental reform urged by the Hoover Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- James Sheldon, who has directed shows for "Studio One," "Robert Montgomery Presents" and "The Kraft Theatre," has signed a multiple-picture contract with Screen Gems. This is the television film producing arm of Columbia Pictures.
" AIDA" was last night's opera at the Metropolitan, with Herva Nelli replacing the indisposed Zinka Milanov in the title role. It was Miss Nelli's first Aida of the season.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 19 -- The Soviet leaders left for home today after having established a basis for an economic beachhead in Afghanistan.
A public tendency to regard radar as an impregnable defense has caused some concern in Washington.
MADRID, Dec. 19 -- Spain promised the Moroccan people today that they would have immediately a greater voice in the management of internal affairs in her North African protectorate.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Dec. 19 -- The pro-Western Premier of Jordan announced his resignation tonight. He said he would let the people decide in a parliamentary election whether Jordan should join the Baghdad Pact for defense of the Middle East against Communist invasion.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Buying tended to dry up on the stock market today and some industrials lost as much as 2 shillings (28 cents). In the main, however, losses were in pennies.

WASHINGTON Dec. 19 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers today urged that the Securities and Exchange Commission tighten controls on offerings of speculative "penny" uranium stocks and what an official termed "promotional" securities.

THE New York State Board of Regents, which always has shown commendable awareness of the teaching potentialities of television, has advanced a new set of proposals designed to get educational video off the ground in this state. Some of the suggestions make eminent good sense and are altogether practical. Others must be questioned.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 -- Tension appears to be rising over some unsettled issues between the Netherlands and West Germany.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 19 -- This city, whose origins go back to Columbus, is prepared for its greatest event, inauguration of an international trade fair tomorrow.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Curtiss-Wright Corporation has filed suit in Federal Court charging patent infringement by the Link Aviation Company of Binghamton in making and selling flight-training devices to anyone other than the United States Government.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A spokesman for an insurgent group of stockholders of A. M. Byers Company said today the group would fight the proposed sale of the concern to the General Tire and Rubber Company unless Byers stockholders received the full book value of their shares.

Independent experts found that a 4-cent-a-ride fare rise would be adequate to meet wage increases and rehabilitation costs of the Long Island Rail Road, it was brought out yesterday, but on Dec. 6 the road raised the fare 5 cents a ride.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 19 -- The Democratic Administration of this city was accused today of padding the public payrolls with well-paid jobholders who never showed up for work.
CHICAGO, Dec, 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Apparently, the cold war Secretary of State Dulles has been warning us about, is spreading to basketball. Col. Harry D. Henshel, who is chairman of the United States Olympic basketball committee, yesterday named Russia as a major threat to our basketball supremacy.

MME. PIERRE DE SEYNES, an elegantly casual young woman of 21 years, works at Lord Taylor's Hermes shop. Not even a half-hearted career girl, she expects to return to France when her husband finishes a tour of duty with the French Commercial Counselor.
TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- The State Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a bill to increase state aid to schools by $4,000,000 in 1956 and by $2,000,000 annually thereafter.

In the lexicon of Communists and others who dislike us the big American companies operating abroad "exploit" the countries in which they do business, and "leave nothing behind them but a hole in the ground." The latest of the National Planning Association's reports on United States business performance abroad again documents the refutation of this charge -- this time by telling the story of the Creole Petroleum Corporation in Venezuela.
Eastern Air Lines has ordered 200 Allison engines and propellers for the fleet of forty Lockheed Electra turbo-prop airliners it will start receiving in August 1958.
Carmine Fiore of Brooklyn and Gene Poirier of Niagara Falls, N. Y., boxed a rousing ten-round draw in the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Miguel A. de Capriles celebrated his forty-ninth birthday on Nov. 30. His heavy, black hair is graying at the temples. The light rims of his spectacles set off bushy eyebrows. He is a slender, wiry man and looks to be a six-footer, although he will fall short of that by an inch or so.

POPULAR dish on a wintry day at Boston's venerable Locke-Ober restaurant is finnan haddie Delmonico. For it, the smoked haddock is flaked, creamed with hard-cooked eggs and baked en casserole with a border of mashed potatoes and a generous topping of grated Parmesan cheese.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Britain was accused today of leading a desert attack on Oman to gain control of oil-rich lands in southeastern Arabia.

LYDDA, Israel, Dec. 19 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett returned today from his mission to the United States. The first questions he faced at the airport here reflected the national debate over the retaliatory attack on Syria last week and its possible effect on Mr. Sharett's diplomatic discussions with Secretary of State Dulles in Washington.

Recently you published a letter from Mohammed Fadhil Jamali, chairman, Iraq delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, in which he refers to my statement that some day Iraq may ask Britain to cede present bases. He is technically correct in stating that "after Britain joined the Baghdad Pact an agreement was signed by which the bases were taken over by Iraq."

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Dec. 19 -- Although South Africa's 10,000,000 Negroes have no say in their country's Government, they have a strong political organization. It is the African National Congress. The congress concluded its annual convention here last night.
B. Earl Puckett, board chairman of the Allied Stores Corporation, has been named winner of the thirteenth annual Tobe Award as "Retailer of the Year."
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- British and United States diplomats here today were appraising the Russians' tour.

According to the guide books and compendiums of local folklore, the phrase "Tin-pan Alley" is somewhat older than the equally renowned phrase, "Great White Way." The latter phrase is said to have been applied to Times Square in 1901 when the theatres were taking over that area and threatening the old brownstones and livery stables which remained just to the north in Longacre Square.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Alabama, its 12-point half-time lead melted to one late in the game, overcame Holy Cross' full court press and tremendous final surge tonight to send the Crusaders to their first defeat of the season, 89 -- 84.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- An indefinite delay in the delivery of $415,000,000 worth of Illinois toll road revenue bonds to buyers was announced here today. New litigation brought about the postponement which was announced by James P. Jamieson, a partner in Glore, Forgan Co., co-manager with Halsey, Stuart Co. of a nation-wide investment banking syndicate which entered into a contract with the toll road commission on Oct. 25.

The Far Rockaway rifle team, having captured the Public Schools Athletic League title Friday despite an "off" day, is setting its sights for the National championships. The squad will compete in the Connecticut state championships in March before shooting for the big prize in April.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Dec. 19 -- The House of Representatives of the Sudan unanimously adopted today a resolution declaring the country's independence. It requested the Governor General, Sir Knox Helm, to ask Britain and Egypt, the two condominium powers, to recognize the declaration forthwith.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Tuesday, Dec. 20 -- The first of eight United States planes took off from New Zealand for Antarctica shortly after dawn today. Larger long-range planes left Harewood Airport, near Christ-church, while others took off from Taieri Airport, near Dunedin, about 300 miles farther south, to conserve fuel, since they will not have much to spare on reaching the Antarctic.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union pledged yesterday $1,100,000 in gifts to Israel for a hospital, a stadium and a trade school.

Short covering, new chart buying and stop-loss purchasing strengthened rubber prices yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Dealer selling on a soale-up basis and speculator profit taking limited the advance.
HARVARD, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Mayor Wagner pushed a handle the wrong way today and initiated the third and last phase of the Delaware Water Project.

So far as public view is concerned, there has been no more reticent figure in the Khrushchev-Bulganin party's recent Asian tour than Gen. Ivan A. Serov. From the public relations point of view, as a matter of fact, his absence would have been highly desirable.

The population of the Saar, which rejected a "European" status in a plebiscite in October, has now voted for a return to Germany. It did so in a Parliamentary election in which it gave a nearly two-thirds majority to the three pro-German parties which will now form a new Government pledged to work for a reunion of this tiny but rich and long-disputed borderland to the German "Fatherland."
BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- Valerian A. Zorin, first Soviet Ambassador to West Germany, is scheduled to arrive tomorrow, accompanied by several members of his staff and Mme. Zorin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- United States officials said today that it was this country's policy to seek a settlement of the differences between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Reflecting the vast demand for steel, the nation's mills last week established another new record with output of 2,421,000 tons, it was reported yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines of Mexico has just submitted his Federal budget to Congress for 1956, a budget which calls for expenditures of 6,696 million pesos ($535.7 millions) and which shows indicated revenue of 6,700 million pesos ($536 millions).
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The West no longer is the farm frontier of America.
The Rheem Manufacturing Company is planning to expand its home products line through a merger with the Richmond Radiator Company, maker of plumbing fixtures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States for some time has been spending $4 billions plus annually for foreign aid -- military, economic and miscellaneous -- and only a relatively small increase from the current fiscal year is contemplated for the next one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Kingdom of Yemen has retained a United States engineering company to carry out a vast public - improvement program with revenues expected from the development of the Middle East nation's oil and mineral resources.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Norman (Red) Strader was dismissed as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers today because he and the players were "incompatible."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Indian Embassy said today it has been receiving "inquiries and applications" from Chinese in the United States who want help in being sent to Communist China. The embassy did not say how many had applied.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation did not join today representatives of four other farm organizations in an effort to find common ground for new farm legislation.
The South Porto Rico Sugar Company and its subsidiaries have reported net income for the year ended Sept. 30, 1955, of $2,432,589, equal to $2.18 a common share.

Beginning at 2 P. M. today, the public will be able to see what the first celestial body "Made in U. S. A." may look like. A full-scale model of a man-made satellite will go on display at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street.
The generosity and spontaneity of the American public is real.
Railroads and port agencies serving New York and Boston are girding for a battle to equalize freight rates that now favor ocean shipments through Philadelphia and Baltimore.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 19 -- The Indonesian Air Force crisis that is threatening the stability of the Government of Premier Burhanuddin Harahap remained unsolved through another tense day of behind-the-scenes negotiation.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 -- General Motors Corporation announced today it had built and successfully tested a new experimental gas turbine automobile.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International Baseball League, said tonight the sale of the Syracuse franchise to Miami would renew a natural baseball rivalry and ease travel problems for the league.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Government's final crop report of the year today showed that farmers produced a record harvest this year despite acreage cutbacks on surplus-plagued crops.

Hearing of charges against Charles V. Gris, a private detective accused of illegal wiretapping, was adjourned yesterday until Jan. 9 by the New York Department of State after it had been testified that he was critically ill.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19 -- The Rumanian Communist party newspaper published a letter in Bucharest yesterday, signed by former Deputy Premier Titel Petrescu, in which the Socialist leader glowingly praised the regime.
BERLIN, Dec 19 -- The all-American cast of "Porgy and Bess" climbed aboard a special East German train today and headed for the Soviet Union.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 19 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as one of his Special Assistants, effective Dec. 31.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Arraignment of two members of the Truman Administration was postponed today. They are charged with conspiring to fix the $118,000 tax case involving Irving Sachs, a St. Louis shoe concern owner.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to close 6 points higher to 16 lower than on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Department of Defense drastically tightened regulations today to protect the interests of military personnel who buy commercial life insurance.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Barring further cuts in overtime operations, the auto industry will hit the 8,000,000-car production mark at the year-end almost on the nose.

Judicial warnings in parking enforcement cases won the commendation of the New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday for Magistrate Charles Solomon. The magistrate dismissed nine cases last Tuesday because patrolmen could not prove that defendants who chose to stay "mute" had owned or parked ticketed cars.
Two separate collisions yesterday involving four Air Force planes killed at least eleven airmen in Florida.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 19 -- A showdown between the Government and 16,000 workers in the copper-mining industry, on strike for six days, reached the culminating stage today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals threw out today a move seeking to free Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson under the Supreme Court's decision in the case of Robert W. Toth.

The exact figures relating to the decrease in attendance and wagering at the thoroughbred race tracks in this state were revealed yesterday in the annual report of the State Racing Commission. The board is headed by Ashley Trimble Cole, and his colleagues are L. A. Swirbul and William C. Langley.
Authorization was granted yesterday to the Long Island Lighting Company to construct a gas transmission pipeline from the Queens-Nassau County line to Garden City.

" Marty," Paddy Chayefsky's adaptation of his TV play about a lonely Bronx butcher and a spinster school teacher, was voted the best motion picture of 1955 by the committee of exceptional films of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.
A Dutch family, originally from Indonesia, arrived here yesterday to find a new home under the sponsorship of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 19 -- A highly placed Government official disclosed that the letter sent early this month by Afghan King Zahir Shah to President Eisenhower asked for United States support in the Afghans' demand for Pushtunistan.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- The Soviet leaders are believed to have recognized that there is an atomic stalemate in which war among the great powers is excluded.
Warehouse space in Trenton, N. J., has been leased by the American Pad and Textile Company of Greenfield, Ohio, a manufacturer of tents, sleeping bags, life vests and other life-saving equipment.
A one-story warehouse on a plot 100 by 100 feet at Irving Avenue and Jefferson Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company to the Chashen Realty Corporation.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A flag also was ripped from the French Consulate today.

The Appellate Division affirmed unanimously yesterday a ruling by Surrogate George Frankenthaler directing that the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee be admitted to probate except for the residuary clause.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The wise men from the East brought gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh, says the sacred Christmas story.
Three young women, all debutantes of the season, were honored yesterday evening at parties given by their parents.

The American Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born opened its defense yesterday against Government charges that it is a Communist-front organization and should register as such under the McCarran Act.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has raised thus far $12,715,014 in pledges and contributions in its campaign for $18,000,000 that began Sept. 29 and will close Jan. 31.

The harried soul who always wonders at day's end why he never seems to have accomplished all that he had in mind when he set out in the morning might do well to look into a new book titled, "How to Gain an Extra Hour Every Day."
A Christmas amnesty plea for Communists imprisoned under the Smith Act has been sent to President Eisenhower by fortysix Americans who stressed their own disagreement with the Communist party.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 20 (UP) -- Leslie Combs 2d said today he was prepared to reveal the names of his partners in the $1,251,200 purchase of Nashua, if and when they decided to race the turf champion in Florida.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Harriman today named Harry Uviller of New York, treasurer of the Liberal party and impartial chairman of the city's dress industry since 1936, as chairman of the State Mediation Board. He also appointed three others of the board.
Thomas M. Goodfellow, who has been operating head of the Long Island Rail Road since August, 1954, was elected president yesterday by the board of directors.
CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- Leaders of Egypt's Catholic churches have agreed to seek a settlement of their differences with the Government over a decree abolishing the religious courts on Jan. 1.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- The J. O. B. (Just One Break) Program for hiring the handicapped in Massachusetts placed twenty - six persons in jobs they held for at least six months during 1955.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- In his first public address since returning from his South Asian trip, Nikita S. Khrushchev reaffirmed today the primacy of heavy industry.

Frank Abrams, Meresman Co., accountants, have leased the fifteenth floor in the seventeen-story office building being erected by Joseph P. Blitz, Inc., at 545 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street.
Firemen cracked down on two more mid-Manhattan movingpicture theatres yesterday for assertedly failing to eliminate hazardous conditions.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 20 -- Anti-Western demonstrators tore down a United States flag today in the garden outside the United States Consulate in the Jordanian sector of Jerusalem. The crowd was driven off by Jordanian policemen, who have guarded the Consulate since it was stoned Saturday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- One of the paradoxes of our time is that the world's biggest single bank is in the anti-capitalist Soviet Union. Vassily Fedorovitch Popov is president of the state bank (Gosbank) -- his institution has an authorized capital of 4,000,000,000 rubles, reserves of another 4,000,000,000, and has extended credits in excess of 220,000,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The illness and injury jinx struck the Los Angeles Rams again today with the announcement that an offensive center, Leon McLaughlin, had been stricken with mumps. He may not be able to play against the Cleveland Browns here Monday in the National Football League championship play-off.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 22 points off to 3 points up yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- British official circles were reported today to be seriously disturbed over the dissolution of the Jordanian Parliament and the Government's decision to hold national elections on the key issue of Jordan's entry into the Baghdad Pact.

The women's Division of the American Jewish Congress yesterday gave a luncheon in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. More than 1,500 members of the organization attended the event in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- An original broadside listing Biblical authority for fifteen offenses punishable by death in New England 312 years ago has been added to the treasure room collection of rare American legal documents at the Harvard Law School library.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Jim Paxson, a hard-driving forward, poured in 35 points tonight to pace unbeaten Dayton to a 77-73 victory over Utah in a clash of nationally ranked basketball powers opening the Kentucky invitation tournament.
A garment union asked yesterday for a new type of wage guarantee to cover 7,500 workers in the manufacture of ski suits, sportswear and babies' coats here.

Directors of Dynamics Corporation of America and its subsidiary, Reeves-Ely Laboratories, Inc., yesterday approved a proposal to consolidate. The two produce electronic and electrical devices, air-conditioning equipment and the Waring line of home appliances.
Two new films open at firstrun theatres today.
A mother and her two children were found stabbed to death in their Staten Island apartment last night by policemen who had gone there to report her husband's attempt at suicide.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- The group of prisoners classed as "major" war criminals who were returned to East Germany by the Soviet Union last Saturday have been jailed.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP) -Thousands of employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation entered struck plants today to accept $100 loans from the company "to help provide essentials for a decent Christmas."
The city was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union to go ahead with its plans to build a television station.
HARTFORD, Dec. 20 -- A bill creating a new state primary system for Connecticut was signed today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.

Though Irvin Goldsmith, an assistant district attorney of the Bronx, was bound and robbed yesterday, he helped to catch two of the three hold-up suspects. The third was picked up last night in his furnished room by detectives.

Fire Chief Edward Connors, highest uniformed official in the department, was injured in a fall last night at a four-alarm blaze in the East Bronx. Seven other firemen, including a lieutenant were injured.
Moscow, Dec. 20 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov suggested to the Italian Ambassador today that the populace of Malta was largely Italian.
Left-handers were dominant in the American League this year, according to the pitching records released yesterday.

The Massachusetts Housing Authorities sold $51,758,000 of one year notes yesterday to a group jointly headed by Kuhn Loeb Co. and Eastman Dillon Co. The group named a net interest rate of 1.61 per cent. Proceeds from the sale will be used to help finance state-aided projects for elderly persons.

Robert J. Grueser has been elected vice president in charge of commercial operations for the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company, Columbus, Ohio, effective Jan. 1. Gerald B. Fenton, treasurer and vice chairman of the board of trustees of the Battelle Memorial Institute, has been elected a director of the company.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Pierre Mendes-France took issue today with the statement of the North Atlantic Council Friday describing Soviet tactics in the Middle and Far East as "a new challenge to the free world."
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices dipped on the Board of Trade today, with the December contract down as much as 8 1/4 cents at the close.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -Gov. Goodwin J. Knight said today he had taken preliminary steps toward seeking the election of a slate of delegates pledged to President Eisenhower at the 1956 Republican national convention.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Senator Estes Kefauver announced today his entry into the Wisconsin Democratic Presidential primary on April 3.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 -- The Nationalist party has taken a commanding lead in the early returns from Indonesia's election for a constituent assembly.

Write a jingle and win an automatic gas washer-dryer, a water heater and a color-coordinated sink-cabinet layout. That will be the substance of an advertising campaign set to start next month under the joint sponsorship of the American Gas Association and the Colgate Palmolive Company.

Advertising accounts worth millions a year in billings have been changing agencies in the last few weeks with startling frequency. The rate is far and away above the more-or-lessusual year-end run of agency switching.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department issued today the following' list of winter sports conditions:
IF the diamonds are big enough, a woman isn't likely to return a necklace because it isn't the right size. But jewelry looks best when it fits properly.
The City of New York received $928,015 for 192 parcels of real estate sold at auction on Monday. The amount was $368,054 above the upset price of $559,961.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Nashua, the horse of the year, drew the high weight of a champion today for the Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 25. His runnerup for 3-year-old honors of 1955, Swaps, was rated next.

As their own Merry Christmas drew nearer, many children drew on their allowances and piggy banks to send small sums to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Their gifts and messages were among the 729 contributions that totaled $16,925.25 yesterday.
LAST night Ruth Page brought her company from the Lyric Theatre of Chicago for a week's engagement at the Broadway Theatre in a pair of ballets and with a generous handful of guest stars.

Miss Jeanne Ansell, who controls one of the largest foreignlanguage movie chains in the city, and her accountant were convicted yesterday in Federal Court of defrauding the Government of $372,000 in theatre admission taxes.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Alfred Spear of Providence, R. I., suing on behalf of himself and 5,000 other stockholders in the old Reo Motors, Inc., of Michigan, today demanded damages totaling $37,716,116 from the new owners of the Reo assets.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP) -The Baltimore Colts, who finished fourth in the Western Conference of the National Football League, got checks for $1,000 each in the form of bonus payments, it was disclosed today.

Events tonight: Telemann Society, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 6:15 o'clock; "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, David Oistrakh, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Bach Aria Group, Town Hall, 8:30.

Nearly two months ago we, crewmen of the Soviet tanker Tuapse, came to the United States to stay. We have deliberately chosen to live in the United States and are grateful to the American people for their hospitality.
A $150,000 suit charging the Motion Picture Association of America and seven of its member movie companies with restraint of trade was filed yesterday in Federal court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Secretary Marion B. Folsom today put an end to recurring rumors that Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, would retire.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A new kind of pari-mutuel ticket, designed for the protection of horse-racing fans, will be used experimentally at the approaching Santa Anita meeting.

WHEN indignant Forty-Niner fans hanged Red Strader in effigy, the operatives of the San Francisco franchise undoubtedly regarded it as a boyish prank. But when those same fans also hanged in effigy Tony Morabito, one of the club's owners, it ceased to be fun. Something had to be done about it, and was.

THE Symphony of the Air, conducted by Leonard Bernstein, gave the second of six concerts last night in Carnegie Hall. Renata Tebaldi and Jussi Bjoerling were the guest artists, and a capacity audience turned out to hear them sing scenes from two operas by Puccini and one by Verdi.

A simmering dispute between the Van Cortlandt Democratic Club and the Riverdale Democratic Club in the Bronx boiled over yesterday. It was disclosed that the Van Cortlandt Club, long the regular Democratic organization, was seeking a court order to strike the word "Democratic" out of the Riverdale club's name.
A Career and Salary Plan appeals board was set up yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Labor Commissioner Nelson Seitel was named chairman.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A committee of independent labor unions recommended today that a national unification convention be called next May for a proposed merger of about 6,000,000 union members not affiliated with the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP) -The Pennsylvania Athletic Commission chairman, James T. Crowley, said today that a $3,000 forfeiture would be returned to a former world welterweight champion, Johnny Bratton, now in retirement at Detroit.

Despite a $10,407,602 increase in gross revenues, nets income of the Pennsylvania Railroad dipped to $3,218,650 last month from $3,862,287 in November, 1954. The decline reflected a $9,034,718 increase in operating expenses, a heavier tax bill and larger bills for equipment rentals.
Cities Service Company announced yesterday the signing of an oil development contract with Empresa Colombiana de Petroleos, government-sponsored oil company of the Republic of Colombia.
Directors of the Reserve Oil and Gas Company, San Fran-
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Following is a summary of the major decisions taken at the tenth session of the United Nations General Assembly, which adjourned today:

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Detroit's three metropolitan newspapers, closed by a strike since Dec. 1, reached agreement tonight on a new contract with pressmen. At the same time printers joined sterotypers and mailers in the strike.

Iberia, Spain's international airline, yesterday contracted with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for two new Super-G Constellations. The purchase price was announced as approximately $4,000,000. Delivery date has been set for mid-1957.
INTERIOR design has come a long way since the days of Elsie de Wolfe's zebra-skinned sofas and silver walls. Such fancies are a direct opposite to the rehabilitation work being done by Emily Malino.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court again today to rule against Louisiana's claim to a large area of oil-rich submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico.

Directors of Northwestern Bell Telephone Company authorized issuance and sale yesterday of $25,000,000 of debentures to be dated on or about Feb. 1, 1956, and to mature not more than forty years later. Invitations for sealed written bids for the purchase of the entire new issue will be published by the company, with bids to be opened on or about Jan. 31.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 (UP)-Maurice (the Rocket) Richard and Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion achieved the hat trick tonight, scoring three goals apiece to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The British Government is under increasing pressure from political and business sources to relax its restrictions on exports to Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -The Navy said today that it was accepting applications from the former Air Force Reserve students for its own Reserve program.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Harold Macmillan was named Chancellor of the Exchequer and Selwyn Lloyd replaced him as Foreign Secretary in a reconstruction of the Conservative Government announced tonight.

The Richmond Hill Savings Bank announced yesterday that construction will begin immediately on a Colonial-style branch building at Hillside Avenue and 257th Street, Floral Park. The branch will handle the bank's expanding activities in the eastern section of Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -Business, port and shipping interests here united today for an all-out fight against the equalization of railroad freight rates in North Atlantic ports on oceanborne cargoes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Government today announced it would sell its big synthetic Plant at Institute, W. Va., to Goodrich-Gulf Chemicals, Inc., of Cleveland for $11,000,000. The rubber producing facilities disposal commission, announcing the sale, said the price was the highest offered for the plant during negotiations with six bidders.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Central New York Community Baseball Corporation tonight filed a legal action against Martin D. Haske, owner of the International League Chiefs.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Roman Boss, an improving son of Roman turned back eight 2-year-old rivals in the feature at Tropical Park today.

THE good women of the Forum of the 278-year-old New Utrecht Reformed Church in Brooklyn, never dreamed when they discussed their 1955 Christmas program one mild evening last April where it might lead them.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Officials said today the main reason that the Administration planned to ask increased military aid was that it had decided that expensive new weapons must be shipped to the nation's Allies.
FORT BELVOIR, Va., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Army's engineers said today they had developed a mobile water purification unit that can make radioactive water safe to drink in thirty minutes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today he knew of no facts that would justify "any great optimism" about an early Arab-Israeli peace settlement.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- John Selwyn Brooke Lloyd -- he prefers be known as Selwyn Lloyd -- is typical of the new generation of Conservative politicians bred in the days of Laborite domination and now taking their place in the front rank of Conservative leaders.
Fordham's basketball team, eager to make up for a slow start this season, did some catching up last night by trouncing Rutgers, 94-54, at the Rams' gymnasium in the Bronx.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Britain has decided that in a nuclear war only two of her reserve Territorial Army divisions could be used on the Continent in support of the North Atlantic Treaty forces. She has eleven such divisions.
