AUCKLAND, N. Z., Dec. 20 -Four United States planes flew from New Zealand to Antarctica today. It was the first time that planes had landed on the frozen continent from another land mass.

Short covering and light commission house buying firmed wool prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Offerings were light and came from hedge selling and scattered liquidation. Tops were up 0.5 to 1.2 cents a pounds and grease wool rose 0.8 to 1.6 cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Administration was expected today to ask Congress in January for about the same amount of money that it sought last year to aid low-income farm families.

Irving Rivkin, who was cleared of a charge of professional misconduct in the 1951 arrest of a State Crime Commission witness, was reappointed yesterday as first assistant district attorney of Richmond County.
Three hundred youngsters, former patients at Beekman-Downtown Hospital, chose their own gifts with Santa's help at a party yesterday.

The Appellate Division yesterday upheld the Constitutionality of a 1953 law that permits a wife to receive separate maintenance and support when the husband has obtained a valid out-of-state divorce. It confirmed an award of $250 weekly to Mrs. Patricia Wallace Vanderbilt from her husband, Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr.

Staff members and volunteers of the New York Chapter. American Red Cross, many of whom are concerned with obtaining blood donations from others, will make their second annual mass donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Program today.
MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The United Nations Military Command today charged the Communists with "indiscriminate" firing on an unarmed United Nations helicopter.

Jay William, author of such historical novels as "The Rogue From Padua" and "The Siege," has a book of non-fiction on Random House's list scheduled for Jan. 16. In "A Change of Climate" Mr. Williams describes how he and his family, not being able to stand another Connecticut winter, set off "in the general direction of Majorca."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Secretary of State confirmed today the Administration's plan to ask Congress for $4,900,000,000 in new foreign-aid money, 81 per cent more than the current appropriation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20 -Brazil's President-elect is completing blueprints for an administration that hopes to pull Brazil out of her history of haphazard growth into a phase of orderly modern development.

EVER since the violinist Beverly Somach made her local debut in 1947 as an extremely gifted 12-year-old it has been a pleasure to observe the progress, both artistic and technical, of this young performer.

Don Newcombe, Brooklyn's 220-pound right-hander, agreed to terms for 1956 yesterday. In announcing the signing the Dodgers did not disclose how much of a salary-increase Big Newk received. However, statements by the club and the athlete made it obvious that Newcombe was handsomely rewarded for his 20-5 record for 1955.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Take it from an expert, the trouble with a United Nations General Assembly is the cocktail parties.

CHRISTMAS is a time for sweets, and windows of foreign bakeries here show that this is true in many lands. French shops offer buche de Noel, the sponge cake "log" frosted in chocolate and prettily decorated. Pannetone of Milan and pandolce of Genoa, coffee cakes with candied fruits and raisins, are among the holiday specialties in Italian bakeries.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority's $78,000,000 bridge and approaches across the Hudson will be insured for $62,400,000 if insurance companies issue the policies.

In the period between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15 the aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell 53,765 shares, from 2,634,966 to 2,581,201 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 -- Action tonight by two newsprint companies -- one lowering its recently announced increase, the other increasing the price rise still further -- cast the shadow of frequently threatened legislative controls over the entire newsprint industry operating in the Province of Quebec.

THE men who go down to the Pacific Ocean in small, squat ships to fish for tuna (or albacore) are presented as humble, hardy heroes in Allen H. Miner's "The Naked Sea." This seventy-minute documentary film in color came to the Baronet yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- An accord for emigration of many thousands of Italian workers to West Germany was signed in Rome today by Italian Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino and West German Labor Minister Anton Storch. It was applauded here as an achievement that would strengthen the Atlantic alliance.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 20 -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina opened the Dominican Republic's $30,000,000 international trade fair today with an accounting of his stewardship for the last twenty-five years.

The New York Knickerbockers, never in front at any stage, dropped a 98-91 decision to the champion Syracuse Nationals in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 20 -- A major redevelopment of the Greenwich railroad station area to handle the heavy traffic expected from the new Connecticut Turnpike was proposed here today. The project envisions a new station of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, new parking areas, including multilevel garages, and improved access roads.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 R. K. O. has entered into a producing and distribution association with Bert Friedlob Productions on an "open end" contract basis. The independent company is committed to make one picture, "Beyond a Reasonable Doubt," and an unspecified number of others, to be determined by mutual agreement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Following is the State Department transcript of the news conference held today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court said today a person could deduct the cost of an African safari on his income-tax return, provided big-game hunting served to promote his business.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly elected Yugoslavia to the Security Council today in the final action of the 1955 session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- When a Republican Secretary of State announces that foreign economic and military aid will need to go on indefinitely at the rate of about $4,000,000,000 a year, it is clear that a major change has taken place in the development of American foreign policy.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., yesterday raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 10 cents.
Voting is in progress to determine the eleven players and three coaches who will be added to the Football Hall of Fame roster in 1956.

MANILA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Shell Company of the Philippines plans to build an oil refinery here and says it will be the largest single postwar investment by a non-American enterprise in the Philippines.
Year-end influences continued to rule the stock market yesterday. Prices dipped temporarily to the lowest levels of the month, with motors, steels and chemicals notably weak.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -The Gettysburg phase of President Eisenhower's convalescence ended abruptly today.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 20 -- Attorneys for the city tried in vain today to halt further publication of Samuel A. Larner's final report on his thirty-two-month investigation of municipal finances.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, which hasn't found a sponsor for "Captain Kangaroo" since it started nearly three months ago, will expand the show to include Saturday morning performances.

The international fair that opened in the Dominican Republic yesterday is an example of the paradoxes that make life in Latin America so varied and so hard to label. The Dominican Republic has a dictatorship so completely devoid of freedom that dictators like Generalissimo Franco, Marshal Bulganin and Nikita Khrushchev must sigh in envy whenever they hear about it.

BY the end of this week, when school doors close and children hurry home for a longanticipated vacation, mothers already may be longing for a rest cure. Yet most mothers, thoroughly imbued with the holiday spirit, and ever-conscious of their offspring's need for vacationtime activities, will manage to find the strength and time to do things with their children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -The Lackawanna and Erie Railroads notified the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they planned a joint passenger terminal and ferry operation at Hoboken, N. J. The plan involves ending the Erie's ferry between Jersey City and Chambers Street in New York.
The New York Rangers will seek to square their season's series with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Eight of the sixteen new members of the United Nations made their maiden speeches in the General Assembly here today as it closed its tenth annual session.

The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Rail-Trailer Company disclosed yesterday that they had joined forces to form a new organization to provide the railroad industry with a pool of flat cars for "piggy-back" hauling of loaded highway trailers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A second minority stockholder suit has been filed in United States District Court here, seeking to bar sale of the major assets of the Midvale Company to the Heppenstall Company of Pittsburgh.

Lorne (Gump) Worsley doesn't respond with much emotion to many situations. The little goaltender for the New York Rangers faces the blasts of the enemy sharp-shooters with a calm that seems akin to aloofness.
Mayor Wagner yesterday characterized as "nonsense" charges by City Councilman Robert E. Barnes, Queens Republican, that Board of Estimate members were seeking salary rises.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 20 -The Israeli Government sent captured papers described as Syrian military documents to New York by radio tonight for study by the United Nations Security Council.
Twelve-year-old Karen Ann McGuire, a blond fifth-grader in St. Thomas's School at Pleasantville, N. Y., loves to draw. Mostly she draws horses.

A bit cold yesterday when you had to step out of your warm apartment or office or store? But what if you were spending the day, and the whole winter, in one of the thousands of cold-water flats in New York? These homes without heat, except for makeshifts supplied by tenants, have got to go.

Counterfeiting of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. All member firms have been alerted to watch for the imitation $1,000 certificates, which are lithographic copies of the steel-engraved originals.

To clarify where there appears to be confusion and to dissipate misapprehension are the simple purpose of this communication. Let me say at once no one is more keenly aware than I am of the gravity of our traffic problem.

TORONTO, Dec. 20 -- The Six Nations Indian confederacy of Brantford, Ontario, is on the warpath against an Ontario Government order requiring the registration of all tribal marriages performed on the reservation.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -Valerian A. Zorin, first Soviet Ambassador to West Germany, arrived today from East Berlin. He landed at Wahn airfield aboard a special aircraft.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Union intends to send a "large expedition" to equatorial Africa in connection with its participation in the International Geophysical Year.
Winter, unwilling to wait for its official debut at 10:12 A. M. tomorrow, trod heavily on the mercury yesterday.

So much interest has been shown in the pending first public sale of Ford Motor Company stock that the Ford Foundation has decided to enlarge the offering. It plans to put on the market next month not 6,952,293 shares, but more than 10,000,000.

Playing his third-round game in advance of schedule at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, Arthur B. Bisguier, United States chess champion, drew in twenty moves with Larry Evans to take the undisputed lead in the second tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy.

A new stage group called the Ensemble Art Theatre, which was organized as a nonprofit membership corporation, begins its career at 8 o'clock this evening in the modest quarters of the Amato Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -West Germany favors the relaxing of trade restrictions against Communist China but will not take the initiative in bringing it about. government sources said today.

Clearing up the confusion over our foreign, or rather mutual, aid program, Secretary Dulles says that Congress will be asked to appropriate a total of $4.9 billions for the next fiscal year, or $2.2 billions more than for the current year, but that actual expenditures will be increased by only $200,000,000 over the current rate.
The control of $6,189,462 in assets by a $20,500 bond investment was described yesterday at a stormy annual meeting of the Automobile Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Government asked the Subversive Activities Board today to declare the independent United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America a Communistinfiltrated union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Guided missile development and production will be pushed to a record - breaking $1,000,000,000 level, and the first atomic-powered surface warship will be ordered in the next defense budget.

VIENNA, Ga., Dec. 20 -- Senator Walter F. George announced today that he would be a candidate for re-election next year. He has been a member of the upper Chamber of Congress for thirty-three successive years.

HONG KONG, Dec. 20 (AP) -Dr. and Mrs. Homer V, Bradshaw, American medical missionaries in China for twentyseven years hobbled across the border to Hong Kong today. They were ravaged by disease and appeared aged by their five years as prisoners of the Communists.

LOUVIERS, France, Dec. 19 -In his home department, the Eure, former Premier Pierre Mendes-France faces the same problem he will later have on the national scene: Finding a majority that will assure his return to power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Administration will ask Congress to increase its medical research funds by $25,000,000 next year.

The tenth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly ended yesterday, as it had begun last September, with the "one minute of silence dedicated to prayer or meditation" that is prescribed by Paragraph 64 of its Rules of Procedure.
Santa Claus has come to the rescue of the paperboard industry.
The Atlas Plywood Corporation yesterday offered to exchange one share of Atlas common for each three common shares of Plywood, Inc.
The Transport Workers Union renewed yesterday its threat to call a strike of 2,500 tugboat and ferryboat men employed by nine railroads.
It looks as if the country's oil companies would spend in 1956 more than they ever did before.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Treasury disclosed today that the national debt reached a peak of $280,613,954,669 last Thursday.
The writer has just returned from an extensive trip throughout Puerto Rico. While there he not only visited San Juan, but also Santurce, Ponce, Arecibo, Mayaguez and the smaller cities.

Mayor Wagner rebuffed Hospital Commissioner Basil C. MacLean yesterday for having neglected "human rights and values" in abolishing the county medical division of the Kings County Hospital Medical Center.

The question whether New York State will take some small, hesitant, experimental steps in use of television for education will again confront the Legislature opening its session next month. The Board of Regents has reiterated its support, but recommends a cautious first appropriation of only $975,000.
For the first time in history world shipping has passed the 100,000,000-gross-ton mark.

THE sage who stated that duck shooting was productive only when conditions were so bad that the "shooter should be hugging a stove," would have found a lot of support in at least one Peconic Bay blind yesterday.
The unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee yesterday urged the port's dock union to purge corrupt labor leaders and officials and embark on a program of reform to win back public confidence.

MOMENTS of exploration, intuitive notation and recreation in the lives of more than fifty contemporary artists are recorded in a crosssection exhibition of drawings, water-colors and small oils at the Poindexter Gallery, 46 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 achieved the largest sales and earnings in its fifty-five - year history, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator William E. Jenner proposed today that Congress "look into" the failure of the United States to seat the Philippine Republic on the United Nations Security Council.

The Attorney General's office will take the first steps in Queens Supreme Court today to break up a "multimillion-dollar loan racket" under which home owners assertedly have been charged "astronomical" interest rates for second mortgages.

Unions in this country and Canada have a combined income of more than $500,000,000 a year, a research study disclosed yesterday. The year-long survey, compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board, represented the most comprehensive analysis ever made of union constitutions and dues structures.
Department-store sales will rise 3 to 5 per cent above 1955's record level in the first six months of 1956, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., predicted yesterday.

The new year marks a new era in Britain, and we are seeing it signalized first by the change in leadership in the Labor party and now by the important shift in posts in the reigning Conservative party. The days -- the great days -- of Churchill and Attlee are over. A new phase begins, dangerous and difficult but vigorous and hopeful.

DAVID OISTRAKH, the Russian violinist, gave a party at Carnegie Hall last night. It was a party that the house-full of paying guests will long remember. For Mr. Oistrakh played three concertos -- Mozart's A major (K. 219) and those by Brahms and Tchaikovsky, two of the towering works for violin and orchestra.
In these latitudes winter is not so much a season as it is a state of mind. There are some persons who associate winter with snow and mark the first snowfall as the beginning of the season.

The Daily Worker said yesterday that William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party, had been asked by the Social Security Administration to return $1,006.50 in old-age benefits that he had received from the Government.
Former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck has given his home at 41 Sunrise Terrace Grymes Hill, S. I., to Wagner College.
An armed robber walked into a dress shop in the crowded arcade of the Chanin Building at 122 East Forty-second Street last night and took more than $1,100 in cash.

Plenty of Christmas trees are available in the city, the Department of Markets reported yesterday. They are continuing to arrive by train from Canada, the western states and western New York. It had been feared earlier, that there would be a shortage this year.

The Automobile Club of New York performs many services for its members, one of these being, it now appears, to relieve the bulk of the members of any considerable burden in the making of club policy. Really in the driver's seat is the Automobile Club of New York Agency, which deals in insurance and controls a third of the voting power in the club.

The existence in the Westchester County Sheriff's office of the "vicious and pernicious" practice of assessing employes to buy Christmas gifts for the Sheriff was charged yesterday J. Irwin Shapiro, State Investigation Commissioner.

Whatever it was that contributed to the failure of the Indians to repeat in the American League 1955 pennant race, it could not have been defensive play. For, according to the official averages released yesterday, Al Lopez' Tribe compiled the best fielding mark in the junior loop last season.

Christmas shoppers in London, Paris, Vienna, Brussels and West and East Berlin have had an abundance of goods to choose from this year, according to a survey by Reuters. In Prague, too, store counters were filled with goods, a New York Times dispatch from Czechoslovakia reported.

The four appointments Governor Harriman has just made to the State Mediation Board are excellent. The new chairman, Harry Uviller, is widely known and respected for his remarkable record of preserving labor - management peace in New York City's huge dress industry; and the three others named to the board are well and favorably regarded in this complex field of labor relations.
With the seasonal rush about to subside long enough for the Christmas bells to be heard above the din, there is time to report how Kenyon Eckhardt observes the Santa spirit:

WASHINGTON. Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Service reported today that collections of excise (sales) taxes from July 1 to Sept. 30 ran about $300,000,000 ahead of those of the same period last year.

The orbits of two luminaries -- Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator and George Meany, president of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. -- and the interests they represent have met in a convergence that holds great promise. The conference of these two stars, including lesser building trades union lights, may well trigger a chain reaction that will benefit the city by supplanting large areas of blighted buildings with union-financed, low-rent modern dwellings.

George Washington's unbeaten basketball team, rated the top power in the Southern Conference, will oppose Manhattan, and Connecticut, which has one of the strongest fives in New England, will meet New York University in a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.
"America's Third Ear," a dramatization said to be based on actual wiretapping activities, will be televised over the National Broadcasting Company network on Jan. 24 from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.

A Supreme Court referee has upheld the Waterfront Commission in barring two Brooklyn men from employment on the docks. The men, Matthew Seifert and Vincent Corbett, had sought a permanent injunction against interference by the commission with their employment and in addition asked $200,000 in damages.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- The Soviet Union has created a special scientific research institute in Moscow for the study of poliomyelitis.
New York Central Railroad passengers will be speeding over the rails in much-heralded ultramodern lightweight trains by spring.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 19 -- The people of Czechoslovakia are preparing to celebrate what the Government has said will be the "richest Christmas" since World War II.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru strongly defended India's policy on Goa and Kashmir today.
The recent wave of hold-ups and robberies has prompted Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to put the entire detective division on emergency duty, with days off canceled.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Willie Hartack, the leading jockey in every meet in which he has participated this year, booted home four winners at Tropical Park today. He increased his 1955 victory total to 412 and his local mark to twenty-five.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter proposed today to bar lawyers from representing witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, which he heads, unless the attorneys swore they were neither Communists nor former Communists.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 21 -- Gov. Frank J. Lausche announced today he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator at Ohio's May 8 primary election next year.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Paul V. Liles was convicted today of discrediting the military service by making propaganda recordings for his Communist captors in Korea. He is the only West Point graduate to be court-martialed for collaborating with the enemy.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation is primarily interested in making money from the sale of tickets that allow persons to watch a sports event or show at the big arena. However, once inside the Garden, the ticket buyers spend a total of more than a million dollars each year.
TORONTO, Dec. 21 -- Merger of the Imperial Bank of Canada and Barclays Bank (Canada), Ltd., was approved today at the annual general meeting here of Imperial Bank shareholders.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The radical left-wing of the British Labor party today offered Hugh Gaitskell, the party's newly elected leader, the choice between accepting its views and wrecking the Labor movement in the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The State Department said today it was confident the Jordaniam Government was doing all it could to prevent further antiAmerican rioting.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Studebaker-Packard Corporation announced today agreement with the United Auto Workers on a new Studebaker contract. The accord has "competitive working standards" and a lay-off pay plan similar to those set with the auto industry's Big Three.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Treasury today rejected a complaint by American plywood makers that Japanese plywood was being imported at an unfair low price.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Following are excerpts from a report by Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, United Nations truce supervisor, concerning an Israeli attack the night of Dec. 11 on Syrian positions near the Sea of Galilee:
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Government announced today it would permit Iraq to purchase British arms and military supplies worth 2,000,000 ($5,600,000) in the next two years.

A CONSPIRACY is afoot in New York to extend all the wonderment and surprise attending Christmas into the weeks beyond. The plotters are the museums and the junior theatrical groups of this city, in silent collaboration with a million or more children.
Nick Sklyros, a short-order cook, had the vice chairman of the First National City Bank to lunch yesterday in a kitchen in Grand Central Terminal.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Union has challenged the United States to fight for the Kingdom of Afghanistan on the economic front or write it off politically.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Leonard P. La Rue, a sea captain in the Korean war and now Brother Marinus of the Benedictine Order, waited today for the hubbub of being decorated for bravery by the Korean Ambassador to die down.
DENVER, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Maurice E. Travis, a union official, was convicted tonight of falsely swearing he was not a Communist in affidavits filed with the National Labor Relations Board.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 21 -- Three hundred and fifty acres of historic Mount Hope in Bristol have been given to Brown University. This was announced today by Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, university president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The United States Consumers' Price Index edged upward a tenth of a per cent from mid-October to mid-November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Directors of the Continental Can Company, Inc., yesterday declared a stock dividend of 100 per cent on the outstanding shares, to be paid Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- At precisely 10 A. M. today a stamp descended on a sheaf of papers, and the financial details of the long-secret Ford Motor Company became public property.

A recent difference of attitude in Moscow between the Yugoslav Ambassador there and a high Soviet official has stirred diplomatic interest. It is believed to throw light on continuing differences between Moscow and Belgrade.
Miss Louise Pettibone Smith, co-chairman of the American Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born, denied yesterday that the committee was under the domination of the Communist party.
The proposed request of the Administration for an additional $25,000,000 for medical research drew both criticism and praise yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- The Security Council today suspended the attempt to adopt a resolution endorsing Japan's qualifications for membership in the United Nations.
Might it not be possible to draft college girls in the United States for two years of teaching in the grade schools? Our girls, unlike those in many other countries, have never been drafted.

"Remember these: the Neediest" goes the reminder to those who would have a care for their unfortunate neighbors. And implicit in the plea is another reminder -- that without the outflowing of deep, personal interest by the community and financial help one of the great sciences of this generation would be hindered in its efforts to give these unfortunates their new start in life.

The first $100 check of a' monthly pension plan won last summer by the Masters. Mates{ and Pilots. has been presented! to Capt. Gust Stone. veteran ofi thirty-three years' service as an officer in the merchant marine.I Captain Stone has served with! a number of ship lines, includingi Waterman Steamship Company,! Black Diamond Line, LykesI Brothers and Pope Talbot.

Following completion of the first offering of Ford Motor Company stock, here's how the public, the Ford family, and the Ford Foundation will participate in the affairs of the huge automobile producer:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture forecast indicated today that farmers next year may again produce more wheat than is needed. This would add still more to a record surplus.

THE quilted robes and the handsome handbags, the wallets, ties and tool chests, rocking horses and electric trains have been bought and hidden in the closet. Now the day has come to buy the stocking stuffers.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Japanese officials yesterday proposed to limit cotton goods exports to the United States to a little more than the 1955 level, in hope of heading off United States export restrictions.

The Glidden Company, producer of paints, foods, chemicals, pigments and metals, transacted net sales of $54,479,528 in the quarter ended Nov. 30. Net income for the period, first three months of its fiscal year, came to $1,939,978, equal to 85 cents a share.
MONTREAL, Dec. 21 -- The recent parade of newsprint price increases ranging from $3 to $5 a ton may ultimately level off to a $4 rise by most companies, it was indicated here tonight.

Sales of the United States Rubber Company will set a record high of more than $900,000,000 this year and will pass the billion-dollar mark next year for the first time in the company's history, H. E. Humphreys Jr., president, predicted yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Service and production losses to industry because of employe absenteeism may be running as high as $10,000,000,000 annually, the Research Council for Economic Security said today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Pancho Gonzales defeated Tony Trabert last night, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the sixth match of Jack Kramer's all-star professional tennis tour.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- George Bernard Shaw's last play, an unfinished one that drama critics said was not worth publishing or producing, may be staged next year in time to celebrate the centenary of the playwright's birth.

A New York detective took his wife shopping for a Christmas bargain two weeks ago. As a husband he found one too good to be true in Lindenhurst, L. I. Professionally, though, he found it too true to be good.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 21 -- King Hussein swore in today a caretaker Government headed by Ibrahim Hashim.

Miss Elsa Maxwell of the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria gave a supper dance last night in the Sert Room of the hotel for Mr. and Mrs. Stavros Niarchos. During the evening there were diverstissements by professional entertainers.

Scandinavian Airlines System announced yesterday a $50,000,000 order for seven Douglas DC-8 jet airliners. The company is considering use of Rolls-Royce Conway by-pass engines instead of the Pratt Whitney pure jets normally provided on the Douglas plane.
THIS review is based on two of the three Saroyan one-act plays that were acted at the Amato Theatre in Bleecker Street last evening.
A STIGMA of dowdiness lies on half-sizes that doesn't belong there, in the opinion of a Fifth Avenue store buyer of this type of dress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Library of Congress announced today publication of the fourth volume of a five-volume catalogue of the library of Thomas Jefferson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, demanded today that the Eisenhower Administration stop "squandering" foreign aid money.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following winter sports conditions:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said today that Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, had "left no stone unturned" in supporting the campaign of the Philippines for a seat on the Security Council.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20 -- In an effort to save the Balkan alliance, Yugoslavia has intervened officially as mediator between Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 21 (UP --The Maritime Administration reported tonight that there were 1,064 private and governmentowned vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more in the active oceangoing United States merchant fleet on Dec. 1. This was twentysix fewer than a month earlier.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Tidying up fter tile biggest ministerial reorganization since the end of XVorld War II. Prime Minister F. den announced that three junior ministers who resigned yesterday had been named baronets.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Dave Stephens, Australia's "Flying Milkman," ran Sandor Iharos of Hungary into the ground for the second time in five days today when he won a special three-mile race in the rain.

THE Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, presented a Bach program at Town Hall last night that included the Magnificat, an aria from Cantata 63, for Christmas Day, another from Cantata 56, for the third day after Christmas. and other music appropriate to the season.

Thomas J. Phillips, a theatrical producer, announced yesterday that the word "burlesque" would sparkle brightly next month on the marquee of the Orpheum Theatre in Brooklyn. But License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell declared firmly that he would be on hand, shouting, "Take it off!"

EXCEPT for one important factor, the transfer of an International League franchise to Miami would attract no more attention among casual baseball followers than the transfer of an American Association franchise to Wichita. But Miami eventually will be the most thriving minor league town in the country, hollering loudly that it's ready for major league stature.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The stock markets rallied after a dull start today but with no expansion of turnover. The rally left most medium and long-dated Government stocks with modest net gains of one shilling threepence (17 1/2 cents).

Neil Robinson, the 34-year-old head of Bromley's ski school at Manchester, Vt., is a home product. He has been sliding over Vermont terrain for about a quarter of a century. As a youngster, he skied on meadow lands and golf courses.
THE author of a play presented on television last night has protested that his script had been changed completely into "sentimental nonsense" by the show's production staff.
Stockholders of Alexander Smith, Inc., and of Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., yesterday approved the merger of their companies. The merged concern will be the nation's largest rug manufacturer.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 21 -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo has submitted to Congress a budget of $120,000,000 for the coming year.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- The Republican legislative leaders announced today that they would press for a $50,000,000 reduction in the state income tax next year.
The finances of the Ford Motor Company were disclosed in full for the first time yesterday as a required preliminary for the first public sale of Ford stock next month.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- The United Nations Palestine truce chief warned today that Israel's policy of reprisal against the Arabs might touch off "full-scale hostilities."

Firemen, working in the bitter cold, extinguished a stubborn blaze on the eleventh-floor roof of the Sheraton-Astor Hotel late yesterday afternoon. Utilizing standpipes in the hotel and on the sidewalks, the firemen put out the flames in twenty minutes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission declared today that it would start a system of competitive bidding for leasing uranium deposits it had developed on public and other commission-controlled lands.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. bought $1,650,000 of Bucyrus, Ohio, school district bonds yesterday with a bid of 101.6869 for 3 per cent coupons. The group named a net interest cost of 2.865 per cent. Subject to award, the bonds are being reoffered to yield from 2 to 2.85 per cent.
"THE season to be jolly," to quote the old carol, is also the time for a bowl of Christmas spirits.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 21 -- Patrick B. McGinnis emerged unscathed today from a storm that has been blowing about the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ever since last August's hurricane and October's floods.

Mrs. E. Bruce Merriman of Providence, R. I., gave a dinner dance last night in the St. Regis Roof for her debutante granddaughter, Miss Helen Merriman Weld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Weld of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and Montreal.
The blockfront apartment property at 238-68 Bay Ridge Parkway in Brooklyn has been sold by the Estates Securities Company, real estate operators, to the Bay Ridge Realty Company.
Five motion-picture theatres on Staten Island and two in Brooklyn were ordered yesterday to eliminate fire hazards found by Fire Department inspectors.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Five retired soldiers and thirteen civilians have been arrested in the western city of Mendoza for plotting to stir public unrest. The announcement came from Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu's press office today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
Frank Carney's Irish play, "The Righteous Are Bold," will have its local premiere at the Holiday Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

General buying raised cottonseed oil futures yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. The September position climbed to a new seasonal high. Commission houses were on both sides of the board. Prices rose 10 to 19 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 182 tank cars. Trading was influenced by strong crude oil markets in the South, good export demand and firmer Western allied markets.

MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP) -- George Welsh of Navy, the nation's leading passer, and Harold Burnine of Missouri, the country's No. 1 receiver, were chosen co-captains of the South squad today for the Shrine's North-South All-Star football game Dec. 26.
A new controversy has developed over the teaching of moral and spiritual values in the city's public schools.
The Ford Motor Company is an international operation. Its activities outside this country include:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, who ended their fifteen-year association with Universal last May, will next appear on the screen under the United Artists banner in "Dance With Me, Henry." The comedy will be produced independently by Robert Goldstein and is set for filming in March.
JOAN BLONDELL, playing the part of a middle-aged has-been actress, appeared in "White Gloves," an hour-long drama on Channel 2 last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The State Department confirmed today that the United States had offered its good offices to Pakistan and Afghanistan in working out a settlement of their differences.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- The Soviet Union has presented to the United States a claim for 12,576 marks in damages sustained by an East Berlin cabaret performer in an encounter with two American soldiers Dec. 7.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- The preliminary prospectus of the Ford Motor Company filed today gave details of the special contract between Ford and Ernest R. Breech, chairman of the board. It also listed the pay of top officers.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Eastern Airlines today gave this list of twelve passengers and five crew members killed in the crash:

Five floors in the Bank of New York Building under construction on the west blockfront of Fifth Avenue between Forty- fourth and Forty-fifth Streets have been leased by the Robert Gair Company, Inc., maker of paperboard and paper containers and wrappings.
The terse preview of next year's military budget offered by Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson stressed, as expected, guided missiles.
Two six-story loft and office buildings at 421 West Fifty-fourth Street have been purchased by the Comprehensive Service Corporation.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- People's Daily, Communist China's official party newspaper, had a good word today -- and some bad ones -- for the A. F. L.-C. I. O. merger in the United States.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 21 -- Communist penetration of West German industry was documented today in the Government's annual report of its operations.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 21 -- All seventeen persons aboard an Eastern Air Lines Constellation died when it crashed and burned in today's early morning darkness. The craft had been a few seconds away from a safe landing.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Nashua, the world's most valuable race horse, today topped a list of fifty-nine thoroughbreds nominated for the $100,000 added Widener Handicap at Hialeah Park on Feb. 18.
NEWARK, Dec. 21 -- The City Council voted unanimously tonight for an ordinance that would, in effect, ban burlesque from this city.

What started as a rout developed into a stirring hockey game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Boston Bruins, trailing by three goals to none at one stage, rallied to tie the New York Rangers. 3 -- 3.
Five new films open at first-run theatres today.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Army's quarterback, Don Holleder, who engineered the West Pointers' upset victory over Navy this year, tonight was selected over twenty other outstanding football performers as the winner of the tenth annual Nils V (Swede) Nelson Sportsmanship Award.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- High British officials believe that control of the anti-British movement in Cyprus has passed from Archbishop Makarios to right-wing extremists.

A study emphasizing that present United States standards for determining dutiable values of imports are unrealistic and hinder trade was released yesterday by the National Council of American Importers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 14:
LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 21 (AP) -- An early morning fire roared uncontrolled for five hours in the business district of this city today. It caused damage estimated at about $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Aristotle Socrates Onassis of Monte Carlo agreed today to pay the Government $7,000,000 in penalties. He was accused of acquiring twenty-three surplus ships by fraud. The agreement settled civil litigation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Norwegian Government complained today that Post Office "Mail American" practices were delaying the mail from this country to Norway.
The recommendation of the State Commission on Youth and Delinquency for the enactment of a law to enforce parental responsibility" would seem to propose a self-defeating purpose.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Delegates from the countries newly admitted to the United Nations have slipped quickly and enthusiastically into the organization's diplomatic routine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mr. Bender greeted news of Mr. Lausche's announcement by saying: "There's nothing I love better than a good fight."
Military veterans, members of their families or friends will be allowed to turn in souvenir weapons to the Police Department today through Jan. 31 without "red tape."
DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- A block of 1,000 shares of old Class A Ford stock -- following a private appraisal -- changed hands last August at a price equal to $60.16 2/3 a share on the new common.
Two Mayors underscored Israel's adherence to democratic traditions yesterday and asked the United States Government to aid the young state.

PUBLIC pressure on Congress for the preservation of wildlife and wildlife habitat probably has been greater this year than at any time in the past, and there is no indication that this pressure will be reduced during 1956.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Two unions signed new contracts with Detroit's strike-bound newspapers today, but the number of unions still on strike against the papers grew to three.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21 -- The state of siege in Brazil is to be extended for thirty more days.

The Glen Alden Corporation, producer and marketer of anthracite coal and air conditioning equipment, yesterday completed arrangements to acquire the Ward LaFrance Truck Corporation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, other than that it would be financed out of cash and future earnings.

Farrell Lines, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of John C. Gorman as vice president, traffic. Mr. Gorman, who joined the steamship line in 1938 and served most recently as assistant to the executive vice president will assume his new duties on Jan. 1.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 21 -- The Moslem Union party voted last night to recommend the suspension of the current Indonesian-Dutch talks in Geneva.

Justice Samuel Rabin of Queens Supreme Court approved yesterday application by the Attorney General's office to take legal steps against an alleged multi-million-dollar loan racket operated in the county.
Two children and two adults, including an 82-year-old grandmother, were burned to death early this morning in Brooklyn when fire swept through an eight-family apartment building.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- A strong tone developed in grain and soybean futures today.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company's earnings this year will be about $13 a share, the first time that figure will have been reached since the Nineteen Twenties.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Bobby Boyd of Chicago won a unanimous decision over Italo Scortichini tonight in a middle-weight ten-rounder that had more comedy than drama.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The United States has agreed to sell $25,300,000 worth of surplus oils and fat to Argentina and $11,600,000 worth of wheat, cotton and oil to Colombia.
The Salk vaccine probably saved 1,200 to 1,300 children from poliomyelitis this year, an executive of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis said yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company disclosed today that it had adopted a savings and stock investment program for salaried employes.

Insured mail hardly ever gets lost in the General Post Office, which runs from Thirty-first Street to Thirty-third Street on Eighth Avenue, not even in this extraordinarily busy Christmas mailing season.
A break in the coldest weather so far this season is expected today. Gentle and warmer winds were on the way to chase the nipping cold. Hopes thus were raised for a more comfortable Christmas.

HONG KONG, Dec. 21 -- A United States Air Force plane took Dr. Homer V. Bradshaw and his wife to the Philippines for medical treatment today. They were released yesterday from a long prison ordeal in Communist China.
The Spanish Government yesterday honored Mareelino Garcia, president of Garcia Diaz, Inc., steamship agents, with the Cross of Navai Merit for his distinmished services to Spanish shipping.
HEATHSVILLE, Va., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Ira D. Hinton Jr., a white country storekeeper, was found innocent late today of the pistol slaying of a Negro laborer after an argument last month.

The United States Steel Corporation, largest steel producer in the nation, announced yesterday it was planning to raise its annual production capacity by about 2,500,000 tons within two to three years.
I should like to point out to you a serious factual error in the report of your correspondent John P. Callahan, from New Delhi under dateline Dec. 13 and published in The Times of Dec. 14.

Farrar, Straus Cudahy will issue early next year a report and commentary on the Eisenhower Administration by Richard Rovere. In "Affairs of State," Mr. Rovere discusses the election campaign, the Bermuda and Geneva conferences and the Berlin meeting, the Korean debates, the Indochina crisis and the influence of the late Senator Robert A. Taft.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted John Thomas Gojack of Fort Wayne, Ind., a union official, and Harry Sacher, New York attorney, on charges of contempt of Congress. They had refused to answer questions concerning communism.

Former Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien denied emphatically yesterday that he conferred with Harry Gross and the former bookmaker's com panion, Mrs. Celia Cooperman Giddins, in a Manhattan restaurant last summer.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for November and for the eleven and twelve months ended Nov. 30.

CHILDREN'S first feelings of pride and shame will be the subject of scientific study at Cornell University during the next two years. The National Institute of Mental Health has granted funds to the New York State College of Home Economics to carry on the research.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced today the full roster of the first four A. F. L.-C. I. O. standing committees thus far constituted.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet party chief, and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin renewed their attacks on colonialism on their return to Moscow today from South Asia.
News developments, notably on defense spending, touched off a strong advance in the stock market yesterday.

INTEREST in various forms of the graphic arts has been growing steadily since the Nineteen Thirties. Many well-known painters and sculptors have broadened their activities to include print-making, widening the range of their statements, adding to their income and extending expression in the graphic field in experimental and hitherto unorthodox ways.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Pierre Poujade, leader of France's discontented small shopkeepers and artisans, indicated today that members of his movement who betrayed its program would face punishment, including hanging.

Emil Gilels, the Russian virtuoso, did more than play the piano while in this country. He went shopping, like all tourists. As a result he will have to have an extra large stocking to accomodate the Steinway grand piano he probably will receive in time for Christmas.

TEEN-agers get indirect credit for a new do-it-yourself kit. The kit contains a yardage of Fiberglas, a nylon waistband, bias tape, hooks and eyes and ribbon bows -- everything but the needle and thread to make a petticoat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A House member expressed deep suspicion today that a refugee program -- instituted with nothing but humanitarian aims -- was letting thousands of Soviet agents into free countries.
IN McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 21 -- The four United States Navy planes that arrived here last night have made this barren Antarctic continent just a little less remote from civilization.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 -- Negotiations in the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's nine-week strike were broken off today after a story session.
CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 21 -- Coming here from Asia is like shooting out of the rapids onto a still pond.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Directors of the A. M. Byers Company decided today to put a proposal for removal of the present board before the annual meeting of stockholders on Jan. 26.

A proposal to increase authorized common stock from 2,000,000 shares to 5,000,000 and split each common share into two shares was approved yesterday by the board of the General Shoe Corporation in Nashville, Tenn.

Despite Government controls, droughts, hurricanes and other factors tending to hold down agricultural production, crop output as a whole in the United States in 1955 was the second highest in the nation's history. If meat animals and livestock are included, the year set a new high for farm production.
VALHALLA, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Karen Ann McGuire, the 12-year-old who wanted Nashua, had 100 other horses to choose from today.
DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company is planning to introduce a new passenger car line within the next few years.

BAYONNE, N. J., Dec. 21 -- A Coast Guard helicopter carried Santa Claus into the lives of eighty under-privileged children at a Christmas party today aboard the battleship Wisconsin. He landed along side the 45,000-ton battleship, now in drydock here at the Naval Supply Depot, about 3 P. M., bringing presents for all, and was piped aboard with admiral's honors.
The City Planning Commission gave a unanimous "go ahead" yesterday to the construction of a $2,961,000 underground parking garage in Brooklyn.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 21 -- Guerrilla warfare mounted sharply in Algeria today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Ray Dieringer's 25 points paced unbeaten Dayton to a 89-74 victory over Kentucky tonight in the final of the third annual University of Kentucky invitation basketball tournament.

Robert Williamson of Yale and Charles Spahr of Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., gained the quarter-final round of the intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday at the University Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The American jeweled watch industry has appealed for Government intervention next year to assure a minimum production of 2,000,000 watch movements in this country in 1956.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 21 -- Twelve mince pies mailed to Sir Richard Pim, chief of the Northern Ireland police, contained cyanide, the police announced today. No one ate the pies, which had been delivered to his home.

A drop last week of 8,373,000 barrels in the nation's light fuel oil stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This reflected the unusually cold weather. It brought total supplies down to 126,040,000 barrels. A year ago, they amounted to 118,082,000 barrels.

With only two minutes to spare on his clock, Samuel Reshevsky overlooked a checkmate in one move in his fourth-round game with Larry Evans in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
Directors of the Johns-Manville Corporation yesterday proposed to change its 4,500,000 shares of common stock, no par value, to 25,000,000 shares of $25 par value.
The Board of Hospitals bowed yesterday to Mayor Wagner's request for postponement until March 1 of an order abolishing the county medical division of the Kings County Hospital Medical Center.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Philadelphia interests should join Boston and New York in seeking equalization of railroad freight rates in North Atlantic ports, the chairman of the Port of Boston Commission indicated today.

In your article of Dec. 11 (corrected Dec. 12) and your editorial of Dec. 12 you refer to the Soviet Union's high-speed electronic calculator as "equal in performance to the most advanced American machine of this type."

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- John Fell Stevenson, 19 years old, the youngest son of Adlai E. Stevenson, was seriously injured today in a traffic accident near Goshen, Ind. Two of the youth's fellow Harvard students were killed and another was injured.
The Board of Higher Education is making a special effort to encourage private gifts to the city's public colleges.
CHRISTMAS crepe paper and New Year's confetti can permanently stain rugs and carpets, warns the National Institute of Rug Cleaning.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Southeastern Conference fined Auburn $2,000 today for paying twin prep school stars $500 each to attend the school. Ralph Draughon, the president of Auburn, charged bitterly that the incident was the result of a football recruiting race.

New Yorkers shared Christmas cheer yesterday with children and older folk who suffer from physical handicaps. Special parties were arranged for the palsied, the blind and those with other disabilities.

On one of the coldest days of the year, eleven mentally retarded boys, some without proper clothing themselves, talked over the New York Times Neediest Cases this week. They then decided to send their $3.87 contribution to five children who are expected to lose their mother.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower planned to resume regular news conferences with off-the-cuff questions and answers.

Officials of the Ford Foundation here refused yesterday to give any details of plans to invest the proceeds from the sale of Ford stock. They reiterated an earlier statement that the foundation's long-range aim was a "balanced" investment portfolio, presumably divided among corporate stocks, bond and Government obligations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The nation's railroads and union representatives tonight signed an agreement that will affect about 750,000 nonoperating employes. The agreement will provide a wage increase of 14 1/2 cents an hour, plus company - paid hospital and medical benefits.
Cotton futures prices advanced 13 to 32 points (65 cents to $1.60 a bale) yesterday. There was a scarcity of contracts at times during the day.

The Red Cross here is seeking contributions of blood during the holiday season. Reserves of whole blood "have diminished seasonally," J. Harrison Heckman, executive director of New York Chapter of the Red Cross, said yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A Congressional majority may ultimately support the Administration majority which, after a sharp internal dispute, decided that foreign aid at the going spending rate of about $4.2 billions in each fiscal year should be maintained indefinitely.

The amount of funds commercial banks are required to keep on reserve with the Federal Reserve System is "altogether too high," Dr. Marcus Nadler, consulting economist to the Hanover Bank, said in a report issued yesterday by the bank.
Loans to business outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks increased $70,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, has produced blueprint for Western strategy in the "cold war." One of its cardinal points is that the West must accept the fact that the Communists and not Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists control the Chinese mainland.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Randolph Churchill has said in a letter to the weekly Spectator that Princess Margaret was not influenced by the Archbishop of Canterbury in her decision not to marry the divorced Group Captain Peter Townsend.
You could feel the closeness of Christmas yesterday.
An uproar over City Councilmen's proposed pay increases yesterday rudely shattered what had been the Council's prevailing Christmas spirit of goodwill toward every one.

Sometimes the misery described in the Neediest Cases appeal is so crushing it seems impossible anything can be done to overcome such misfortune. Yet the patience and skill of trained social workers -- plus the contributions of Times readers -- often accomplish wonders of rehabilitation in a remarkably short time.
Captain Henrich is the husband of Lois Bannerman, a well -known harpist currently appearing with the Ted Steele Show on WOR-TV.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A great deal of money will be required to finance the campaigns of Adlai E. Stevenson and Estes Kefauver in the states where they will enter the Presidential preference primaries. A grand or even a little slam by Stevenson will confirm him to the Democratic National Convention as the outstanding candidate, so in either event Stevenson's expenditures will be worth while and Kefauver's wasted
The red faces at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday were not from the cold. It was more a combination of embarrassment and a slow burn.

EVERY Christmas Eve in our town the great fir tree that stands in the middle of God's Acre is strung with lights and crowned with a Christmas star. It looks very beautiful and so do the three white New England colonial churches that give the green its name. Shortly after dark automobiles begin to park around the green and in near-by streets and the municipal parking place.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that he would visit the Middle East next month.

Caddo Parish (County), La., announced yesterday plans to borrow $5,000,000 on an issue of school bonds dated March 1, 1956, and due serially on March from 1957 to 1976. The sale is scheduled for Jan. 18.

A. rise of $805,000,000 in float -- credit extended by the Federal Reserve to member batiks to cover checks delayed in collection-helped ease the pressure on lendable funds in the nation's commercial banking System last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Army announced today plans to increase greatly its potential atomic firepower overseas.
MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (UP) - British mills have raised the price of home-produced newsprint by the equivalent of $13.32 to $164.09 a long ton, effective Jan. 1, it was learned here today.

Wall Street believes that the Ford stock that is coming on the market on Jan. 18 is going to be one of the most sought-after items ever to hit the market. go "through the roof" (sell out quickly) -- and it is saying that without even waiting to find out what the price will be.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) - The Justice Department is weighing on out-of-court settlement of its seventeen-month-old civil anti-trust suit against the United Fruit Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- A three-way partnership involving the Columbia Broadcasting System, Robert Alexander Productions and Harry Ackerman, producer of special shows for the network, has been formed to develop a television series on the life of Gen. John C. Fremont.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Joseph L. Mankiewicz' independent company. Figaro, has purchased screen rights to "The Quiet American." The new Graham Greene novel, published recently in England, is scheduled to be brought out in this country by Viking Press in March.
BRONX Rotarians and their rich-voiced Santa Claus learned yesterday that "Silent Night" had special, poignant meaning for some of God's children.

Highly pleased with the dragon's teeth they have sown in Asia, Party Chief Khrushchev and Premier Bulganin have returned to Moscow. Symbolically enough, they were greeted by the Moscow press not with their own pictures on the front pages but with the picture of Stalin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Charles J. Lowen, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, said today it would be six months before the C. A. A. could decide whether to sell its communications equipment to private industry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Government is trying to line up 5,000 volunteers to guard the nation's $5,000,000,000 stockpile of strategic war materials in an emergency.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. renewed yesterday his plea against storing Christmas rubbish in the house and against careless smoking. He cited a Brooklyn fire that claimed the lives of four persons.

One of college hockey's most colorful events is on the holiday schedule. That is Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's fifth annual invitation tournament. The four-team round-robin will be staged on R. P. I.'s rink in Troy, N. Y., on Dec. 30, 31 and Jan. 2, with two matches scheduled for each day.

Directors of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday increased the dividend on the common stock to 30 cents, pay able March 10. Shareholders had received 25 cents in the three previous quarters following a two-for-one split in June.
IN her Town Hall debut last night, Alice Baran showed herself a pianist of strong feeling and intelligence.

NOW that most of the waterfowl have arrived on their wintering ground, the annual inventory will be made by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, covering all areas from southern Canada to southern Mexico.
LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 22 -- Portugal filed an action against India today in the International Court of Justice at The Hague, the Netherlands.

QUANTICO, Va., Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Quantico Marines defeated Mount St. Mary's College of Emmitsburg, Md., 100 -- 71, tonight and won the Marine Corps School's annual Christmas invitation tournament for the second straight year.

Net profit of the Carrier Corporation for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 amounted to $8,487,220, equal to $4.82 a common share. The company's annual report, released today, indicated that earnings in the current fiscal year may drop below these figures.
M. J. Nevins Jr. has been elected secretary of the Nevins Company, manufacturer of packaging material, colored labels and folding cartons.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:

MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (UP) -Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, agreed today that Referee Jack Mehlenbacher had blown the whistle before a goal was scored by Boston against the Rangers last night.
Detroit, Dec. 22 (AP) -- All hope of getting Detroit's three strike-bound daily newspapers back into publication by Christmas vanished today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 -- Leading Communist personalities are scheduled to be present in Bucharest tomorrow for the long-postponed second Congress of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party. The first Congress met in February, 1948.

Those three little Pakistani ambassadors of goodwill are here again. Hashim Khan, his brother Azam and his cousin, Roshan, ranked first, second and third, respectively, in the world among players of the English-type of squash racquets, are ready for another try at the United States open championship.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy ordered a "reappraisal" yesterday of the activities of the detective division to rid it of incompetents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A State Department historian, dismissed last October but reinstated with back pay yesterday, faces a possible new discharge.

The rate at which American buildings of historic or architectural importance are being demolished in the interests of "progress" -- or something -- defies imagination. Latest victim to fall before the relentless blows of the wrecking-ball is an interesting example of the Gothic Revival of the Eighteen Forties -- Lenox Hall, the charming little library of Princeton Theological Seminary.

About this time of year it is not unusual to see in schools throughout the land Parents -- singly or in pairs -- hurrying through the corridors of school buildings, clutching bits of paper on which are written the names of teachers and the numbers of the schoolrooms in which those teachers may be found.

Four executives with long careers in the Hearst Corporation were elected to the board of directors, increasing the number to twenty-two members. Announced yesterday by Richard E. Berlin, president, the new directors include Fred Drake, publisher of Harper's Bazaar; Kingsbury Smith, general manager of the International News Service; Harry Dunlap, publisher of Good Housekeeping Magazine, and Frank J. Nicht, general sales manager of King Features Syndicate.

The problem facing underwriters in pricing Ford stock is not unlike the problem any manufacturer must cope with when he breaks into an established market with something he has never before sold to the public.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Recent rebel violence in eastern Algeria led today to the formation of a Government mission to study countermeasures.
" The Big Soviet Lie" spread through Asia by the Soviet leaders is not their least sinister manuever. Their flippant contempt for the truth is equaled by their irresponsible reasoning.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 22 -- Prof. Gordon A. Craig of Princeton University's Department of History called today for sweeping changes in Atlantic alliance strategy in a memorandum.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 -- There were firm indications in this Argentine capital tonight that Paraguay's President Stroessner was not overly ruffled by the developments of the last twenty-four hours.
The Greater New York Association, the nonprofit organization that now operates horse racing on the flat in New York State, said yesterday work had been halted at Aqueduct.

The Port of New York is the busiest gateway of the country for the importation of animals and birds. But Dr. B. C. Swindle, new inspector in charge of the Animal Inspection and Quarantine Branch of the Agriculture Research Service, finds New York a lot quieter and safer than a recent assignment.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The threatened strike at midnight tonight by 22,560 Pennsylvania Railroad nonoperating employes was postponed indefinitely today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Reproductions of a painting finished in a Denver Army hospital were President Eisenhower's Christmas gift to 700 White House employes today. The landscape was one dear to the President's heart. It showed his favorite fishing stream, St. Louis Creek, with Byers Peak in the distant background.
Cotton futures prices moved 7 points up to 14 points off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The State University of New York yesterday approved, in principle, a program of expanded higher education for Long Island.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Alex Delvecchio's wide-angle goal in the last minute of the secondperiod play gave a 3-2 victory to the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game with the Boston Bruins tonight before 7,052 fans.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Flooded northwestern California was in a state of emergency tonight, with all rivers out of their banks. Many towns were flooded. Two were reported destroyed.

That Central Park does not meet the recreational needs of Manhattan to the extent it might is an observation with which most New Yorkers will agree. And one of their main complaints would be that it cannot be used when people would most like to use it -- namely, in the evening especially during spring and summer.
Mayor Wagner's letter to Governor Harriman on the city's fiscal program follows:

A new volume of Lincolniana by Ruth Painter Randall, called "Lincoln's Sons," will be published by Little, Brown Jan. 12. Through the lives of Eddie, Willie, Tad and Robert, Mrs. Randall "casts light on rarely seen aspects" of their parents -- Mrs. Lincoln's "passionate" maternity and Mr. Lincoln's
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 22 -- Private Swedish landlords were given another nudge toward oblivion today.

The Heald Commission was reported yesterday to have agreed unanimously to recommend that the state increase its aid to education. The recommendations, if approved, would raise the state's contribution by $90,000,000 to $95,000,000 a year.
Red and white balloons provided a holiday decor for the second and last Junior Assembly for this season. The event was held last night in the main ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The stock of the ruling Conservative party and its leaders seems to be lower today than at any other time since the general election last May.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York has purchased a site in Orlando, Fla., for a two-story office building that will be leased to the Minute Maid Corporation for use as its main Florida office.
The season's heaviest snowstorm, on the first day of winter, caught forecasters by surprise yesterday and tangled transportation in the metropolitan area.

The nation's coal industry in 1970 will be 70 per cent larger than it is today, according to an estimate by J. D. A. Morrow, president of the Joy Manufacturing Company, a leading producer of mining machinery and equipment.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 22 -- In ugly riots that swept Jordan during the last five days, the British have seen another lid blow off a simmering pot in an area under their domination.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Dec. 22 -- Two explosions aboard a thirty-three-foot diesel tug caused its crew of two to leap overboard a mile offshore here this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- American service men all over the world will get a touch of home this Christmas, thanks to year-round efforts of the American Red Cross and church and civic groups.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 22 (AP) -- More people went to harness races this year and bet more money than ever before, the United States Trotting Association announced today.

Last October the I. L. A. leaders who had called the stupid and illegal strike against the Waterfront Commission called it off when New Jersey State Senator James F. Murray Jr. engineered the appointment of the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee pledged to give a fair hearing to the union.
Neither Mayor Wagner nor the spirit of Christmas succeeded yesterday in effecting a truce in the parking battle of Jamaica Estates.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr. will be recalled to active duty two months after he retires as Marine Corps Commandant to become chairman of the Inter-American Defense Board.
General Precision Equipment Corporation has arranged to acquire a majority of the outstanding stock of the Shand Jurs Company, Berkeley, Calif.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 (AP) --The release of former S. S. Col. Joachim Peiper, convicted of having taken part in the 1944 Malmedy massacre of 142 United States prisoners, is being considered by an international review board, informed sources said here today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Adlai E. Stevenson today brought his injured son, John Fell Stevenson, to Passavant Hospital here for treatment.

The City Center is off the hook. Credit Jean Dalrymple, who is in charge of the civic project's drama activities, with the happy outcome. Yesterday, it became known that she had engaged Marcel Marceau, the French mimic, to appear there Feb. 1-12.

Contracts totaling $14,855,964 for the construction and equipment of five schools and extension of another were awarded yesterday by the Board of Education. The board also reappointed two members of the Advisory Board on Vocational and Extension Education for one-year terms.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- "Merry Christmas, Merry Christmas Everybody!"

ARRAS, France, Dec. 22 -- On the main street of this ancient and war-battered town Christmas shoppers have been pausing for political briefing. The elections for a new National Assembly will be held Jan. 2.
HARTFORD, Dec. 22 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff ordered state officials and municipal court judges today to institute a major crackdown on highway speeders and other motor vehicle law violators.

DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union, A. F. L.-C. I. O., proposed today that he and Herbert V. Kohler "meet in face-to-face negotiations Christmas Day" in an attempt to settle a twenty-month Kohler strike.

Mayor Wagner has asked Governor Harriman and the Republican and Democratic leaders of the 1956 Legislature to help the city obtain at least $42,900,000 of additional revenue to help balance its 1956-57 budget. In a letter to Mr. Harriman the Mayor urged immediate consideration of four steps designed to raise the additional funds.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Syria today pressed her demand that the United Nations expel Israel and order economic sanctions against her for the recent attack on Syrian military outposts.

One of the biggest factors in this year's record business boom will be bigger than ever in 1956. That is the word from F. W. Dodge Corporation, which predicts that new construction, amounting to $42,000,000,000 this year will set another high in 1956.

National advertising in newspapers will achieve a record total of $675,000,000 by the time 1955 is over, Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, said yesterday.
Frankie Ryff of the Bronx will face Baby Vasquez, the Mexican lightweight titleholder, in a scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today a reduction of about 60 per cent in the mail subsidy of Pan American World Airways.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 22 -- The failure of the United States actively to oppose the admission of four Central European Communist countries to the United Nations "emphatically does not imply any approval of them," Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- A Government examiner recommended today that the Federal Trade Commission drop for lack of jurisdiction a false advertising case against the Armour Co. of Chicago.

Prices on the New York futures markets generally rose yesterday. Most markets were more active than in recent sessions. Coffee, cocoa, potatoes, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and onions rose; sugar, wool, copper and zinc closed mixed, and lead eased.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 22 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, suggested today that Afghanistan's entry into the Baghdad Pact would be "advisable."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The State Department is preparing a formal reply to the Indian Government's request for clarification of the United States attitude on Goa.

The one-story trucking garage at 371-75 West Street has been sold by the estate of Marks and Moses Ottinger to C. M. P. Terminals, Inc. The property occupies a plot 75 by 105 feet at the northeast corner of Morton Street. It is assessed at $80,000.
SUDBURY, Mass., Dec. 22 -- The Wayside Inn, immortalized in verse by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, was almost destroyed by fire soon after 2 o'clock this morning.

Appeals to President Eisenhower and other leaders to "protest, Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's continued imprisonment" were made public yesterday by the Hungarian Catholic League of America, 30 East Thirtieth Street. Christmas will mark the seventh year of the Cardinal's seizure, the group noted.
A return to the Christmas spirit is being increasingly sought by business enterprises -- through abolishing exchange of gifts tied to commercial contacts.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- A bulldozer operator helped a small plane land safely in a snowstorm today by writing landing instructions in the snow and then hastily leveling a rough field to provide a runway.
EASTON, Wash., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A missing paratrooper who survived a four-day ordeal in a snowbound wilderness hiked out of the mountains to safety at a highway inn west of here today.

In another thoroughly confused and confusing year-end market, stock prices appeared to move in both directions yesterday. Although considerably more issues rose than fell, The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks showed a small loss.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The chemical industry is doing far more basic research than any other American industry, according to the National Science Foundation.
