A determined effort to obtain funds to enlarge Arthur Kill and Kill van Kull in the next session of Congress has been promised by two Congressmen from the New York area. The kills separate Staten Island and New Jersey.
Citing the many instances when children ask in school questions concerning religion, George Vician inquires in his letter published Dec. 19, "Are these questions to be met by silence ?"

TWO matters concerning programs for children are on today's agenda. One concerns Dr. Frances Horwich, principal of television's "Ding Dong School," and the other, Miss Katherine Copeland, the guiding spirit of "Talkaround."
ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Education Department today announced winners of 100 regents scholarships for medicine and dentistry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association reported today that its mortgage buying, in a sharply rising trend, has now reached the rate of $350,000,000 a year. Last week's purchases alone were $6,427,000.

Otto Graham, a 34-year-old business man who planned to watch this year's Cleveland Browns games from the stands or on a TV screen, yesterday was named the National Football League's player of the year in the annual United Press poll.

The news from Bogota that two more newspapers, including the greatly respected El Espectador, have been fined for criticizing the dictator, President Rojas Pinilla, shows that a serious and deplorable situation continues in this once exemplary democracy.
In gala mood, City Hall yesterday bade farewell to the city's Deputy Mayor and cleared the way for bringing his successor into office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court ruled today that a race horse bookmaker may not deduct for income tax purposes the wages he pays employes.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec.22 -- India and Britain have signed an agreement providing for "close cooperation and mutual assistance" in the development of peaceful uses for atomic energy. Announcing this today the Indian Department of Atomic Energy said that Indian and British scientists would consult and work together on mutually agreed topics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives asked Donald A. Quarles, Secretary of the Air Force, today to keep open Sampson Air Force Base at Geneva, N. Y.
The constitutionality of the New York State Defense Emergency Act was upheld yesterday by Magistrate Hyman Bushel, sitting in Vehicle Accident Court.

For thirty-three years the Better Business Bureau of New York City has been promoting ethical principles of business conduct and protecting the public against misrepresentation and fraud. It is a nonprofit agency, supported by business itself, founded in the belief that it is good business to inspire public confidence in all business.

IT is unlikely that the pro football championship play-off game will get out of hand at Los Angeles on Monday when the Los Angeles Rams collide with the Cleveland Browns before a record in-person crowd and a record on-television audience. Commissioner Bert Bell of the National League normally assigns his best officials and the ones equipped with the quickest whistles.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The grain market today reversed yesterday's late strength, and prices generally declined.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- British motor manufacturers in eleven months of this year have broken the record they established in 1954 when they produced 1,039,190 private and commercial vehicles. By the end of November, 1955, their output had reached 1,114,300, 75,110 higher than in all of 1954.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The names of members of the syndicate that purchased Nashua, racing's horse of the year, for a record $1,251,200 were disclosed today by Leslie Combs 2d.
The snowfall that visited the metropolitan area yesterday had the younger set talking about skiing in terms of Van Cortlandt and Central Parks. The more seasoned skier, however, was left unimpressed.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Dec. 22 -- Israel's willingness to consider recommended arrangements with Syria was expressed by a Foreign Ministry spokesman tonight. His comment dealt with recommendations made yesterday by General Burns for gentlemen's agreements to back up the armistice agreement.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Dec. 22 -- Some Pakistanis feel that their Afghan neighbors can thank them for anything the Afghan Government squeezes out of the Soviet Union.

The nation's banks are pushing millions of dollars of coin and currency over their counters to meet the demand of Christmas shoppers. Since Thanksgiving $540,000,000 has been added to money in circulation -- currency and coin in the public's pockets, cash in the vaults of banks and the tills of merchants. At present a record $31,364,000,000 of money is in circulation. to the Federal Reserve storehouse.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22 -- Persistent reports that Premier Pibul Songgram would resign as soon as his budget passed in the Assembly were circulated today.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 22 -- City department heads here were charged today with making the public purchasing agency a "mere rubber stamp" for their personally approved orders.
ATLANTA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge today ordered the City of Atlanta to permit Negroes to use municipal golf courses "immediately."

A man who backed away from a car rounding an East Side corner was scalded fatally last night when he stepped into a steam-filled repair pit. A passing pedestrian and five policemen who made rescue attempts were blistered by the escaping steam.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22 (UP) -- India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, a professed neutral in the "cold war," was reported to have criticized Soviet leaders today for "twisting history" in anti-Western speeches before Indian audiences.
The National Broadcasting Company is plotting to upset the domestic chores of America's housewives by putting on a two-hour daytime "spectacular."
FRANK CARNEY'S "The Righteous Are Bold," which opened at the Holiday last evening, has had a considerable success in Ireland.

ABOARD U. S. S. EDISTO, in the Ross Sea, Dec. 22 -- A representative of New Zealand has expressed his deep concern over the possibility of "indiscriminate souvenir hunting" at the huts of Capt. Robert F. Scott and Sir Ernest H. Shackleton.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, just back from a first view of her latest grandchild, returned to the White House, all smiles, today.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- Twenty-one per cent of Austria's exports were said today to have been sent compulsorily but illegally to the Soviet Union and its satellites during the ten-year occupation of Austria.
Samuel Reshevsky, the international grandmaster, gained a point and a half last night at the Manhattan Chess Club and took first place in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament.
TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- Japanese store owners today were looking forward to Christmas with rare anticipation.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday gross operating revenues of $220,520,346 for the first eleven months of the year. This compared with $201,360,080 in the like 1954 period. Net income was $11,212,976, equal to $1.80 a share, compared with $7,429,506, or $1.19 a share.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 22 -- President Alfredo Stroessner said today it was a "command crisis" that broke out yesterday in Paraguay but that the situation was well in hand. Other sources described the outbreak as an unsuccessful uprising against the Stroessner regime.

MONTREAL, Dec. 22 -- The flash of a fire-warning light in the cabin of the Comet III early this morning forced the British jetliner to turn back after it had taken off on the last leg of a global flight.
Many reservations have been reported for the Christmas Cotillion to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening for the benefit of the Henry Street Settlement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that consumers were failing to get lower food prices from declining farm prices because of increased marketing margins.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 22 -- A group of Algerian politicians known as the "sixty-one" issued a manifesto tonight demanding early negotiations toward home rule.

Today's new film is "The Spoilers," a Universal-International drama, in color, starring Anne Baxter, Jeff Chandler and Rory Calhoun, at the Palace. Jesse Hibbs directed and Ross Hunter produced. The screen play by Oscar Brodney and Charles Hoffman was based on the novel by Rex Beach.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Industrial shares extended their rally today, hacked by the recovery on Wall Street. Oil and industrial shares popular with American investors were particularly firm despite further decline in stock market turnover.

Mr. and Mrs. Silas M. R. Giddings of Brooklyn gave a tea dance at the Heights Casino yesterday in honor of their daughter, Miss Anne Longmore Giddings. Miss Giddings will be presented formally to society this evening at the Yuletide Ball at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today India had sent a note to the United States Government on the question of the joint statement on Goa issued by Secretary of State Dulles and Dr. Paulo Cunha, Foreign Minister of Portugal, on Dec. 2.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Representatives of ten United States motion picture companies and Japanese Government officials today signed an agreement that will provide the yen equivalent of $7,500,000 to the Japanese Electric Power Development Corporation on a six-year loan.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. (AP) -- Ronnie Knox took his place on the pass firing line for the University of California at Los Angeles for the first time today. That may spell bad news Jan. 2 for the Bruins' Rose Bowl rival, Michigan State.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Dr. Otto John, former head of the West German political secret service who fled to East Germany and back again, will be arrested tomorrow and probably charged with high treason, authoritative sources said tonight.

A proposal to increase the authorized debt limit of the Alan Wood Steel Company from $7,000,000 to $9,750,000 has failed to receive the necessary two-thirds approval of the company's preferred shares. A resolution calling for the increase was presented Wednesday to a special meeting in Conshohocken, Pa.

A MARKETWISE menu for Christmas dinner is focused on pork, in heaviest receipt since 1952. It arrives at the table in the festive form of a crown roast, which a British critic of gastronomy has called "an American specialty and a very pretty dish."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (UP) -- Lou Santore's Helfast, overlooked in the wagering because of his poor effort in the Ponce de Leon handicap twelve days ago, responded to Joey Culmone's urging in the stretch at Tropical Park today to win the Delano Purse.

The American Distilling Company has subleased 5,000 square feet of executive office space in the Socony Mobil Building under construction by the Galbreath Corporation at Third Avenue and Forty-second Street. The space, on the thirty-third floor, was sublet from the Socony company, which will occupy most of the structure.

Unexpected payment of a long-forgotten debt will bring an extra measure of good cheer to the New York Times Neediest Cases this Christmas. The astonished collector of the bill turned the windfall over to the fund, helping to raise the day's total to $28,399.57.
The application by the United States Government of its antitrust laws to operations of American businesses in foreign countries was criticized yesterday as handicapping progress abroad.

We are asking for space in the pages of your newspaper to enter a plea for a bipartisan foreign policy. We are particularly interested in the application of this oft-praised principle to the area of the Middle East.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 22 -- Senator Estes Kefauver voiced opposition today to segregation shortly after his arrival here to attend a baby's christening and address the Norfolk Junior Chamber of Commerce.
Plans for extensive cuts in deliveries of newsprint by several large producers were reported yesterday by the American Publishers Association.

New York University, having streaked to a 72-67 lead over the University of Connecticut, fell apart in the last seven minutes and was beaten by the Uconns, 90 -- 82, at Madison Square Garden last night.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- John Isbister of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club was elected president of the International 110 Association's Western Long Island Sound fleet at the American Yacht Club tonight.

COOKBOOKS may be published every week of the year, but the literary offerings in the sister field of home decoration and planning are more meager. However, the 1955 publisher lists made up for the scarcity of their fare with high quality.

ERICA MORINI has made a specialty of the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto. At least she has played it with distinction so consistently that it may have become a specialty without her willing it. But there she was at Carnegie Hall last night as the soloist with the New York Philharmonic, and there was the Tchaikovsky concerto.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The Harriman Administration is developing a program for the distribution of surplus food to the state's needy citizens.

Add to the many all-time high marks that will go into the discard in this year of all round record-smashing on the economic front the pre-1955 peak automobile production mark. That mark, set in 1950, was 6,700,000 passenger cars.

Directors of Consolidated Freightways, Inc., Motor Carriers, proposed yesterday in Portland, Ore., a two-for-one split of common stock. A special meeting of stockholders has been called for Feb. 3 to vote on the proposal.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 22 -- District Attorney Joseph F. Gagliardi of Westchester County promised a full investigation today of the reported assessing of deputy sheriffs to buy Christmas presents for Sheriff John E. Hoy.
PROSSER, Wash., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A carpenter who was ousted from his union for picking up his paycheck on his own time was awarded an $11,000 check from the union yesterday.

Aggregate draft indebtedness of Latin American countries to United States exporters rose $4,700,000 in November to $142,200,000, the highest since November, 1953, according to the monthly survey of the experience of fourteen large commercial banks by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Frankie Ryff of the Bronx gained the decision over Jose (Baby) Vasquez, lightweight boxer from Mexico City, in the feature event of ten rounds last night at Madison Square Garden. The contest was witnessed by one of the smallest crowds in the history of professional boxing at the Garden.
FAIRVIEW, N. J., Dec. 23 -Ben Cairoli, one of 10,000 I. U. E. New Jersey workers on strike against Westinghouse, has mixed feelings about Christmas.
The following are among the special programs of Christmas music arranged by the city's churches for today and tomorrow:

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today there was no chance that the 1960 winter games would be taken away from Squaw Valley, Calif.
HOBART, Tasmania, Dec. 23 -- A French Antarctic expedition will leave here Monday for the South Magnetic Pole in a Norwegian ship and with an American leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Eisenhower gave Christmas pardons today to forty-two persons convicted of Federal offenses and commuted a condemned murderer's sentence to fifty-five years at hard labor.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 23 (AP) -George Harrison, grand president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, said today that he would call a strike immediately against Western Air Lines if the National Mediation Board would release its jurisdiction in a wage dispute.

The appointment of a new American delegate to the International Bobsled Federation in no way will affect the suspended status of Stanley Benham, the executive secretary of the Amatuer Athletic Union said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The median income for families in the United States in 1954 was $4,200. This was about the same as in 1953, the Bureau of the Census reported today.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Europe's wintry storms eased somewhat today in time for the holiday rush.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- Dr. Otto John, former West German intelligence chief, was arrested today on a warrant alleging "strong suspicions" of treason.

The stock market prepared for a three-day Christmas holiday with good gains for the industrials in the first hour yesterday. After that, the enthusiasm slowly evaporated and prices sagged, but there were still net gains at the close.

SONDRESTOM, Greenland, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, president of the National Council of Churches, took off today for Thule Air Base to spend Christmas with America's airmen of the Far North.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The University of California at Los Angeles stopped the Michigan State attack cold today in a scrimmage, but the Spartans were impersonated by the Bruins' green football squad of ineligibles and third-string performers.

Governor Ribicoff of Connecticut has taken the drastic step of ordering suspended immediately for thirty days the license of any Connecticut driver convicted of speeding. A second offender will lose his driving rights for sixty days. This is strong medicine whose effects will be watched with interest by other states concerned with murder and suicide on the highways.

Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers signed an order yesterday restraining members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, from picketing the plant of The Brooklyn Weekly and Brooklyn Daily, Inc., at 2427 Surf Avenue, Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Soviet citizens will again have access to the magazine Amerika, popular Russian-language monthly published by the State Department until 1952. The Soviet Government has consented to the distribution of 50,000 copies a month of the magazine, which is being revived by the United States Information Agency.
GENEVA, Dec. 23 -- The "Help Wanted" sign is out on all of Switzerland's four frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission upheld today the right of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its associated companies to forbid the use of telephone attachments not furnished by these companies or sanctioned by them.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 23 (AP) -- David Townsend, who has worked here since he helped stake out this sprawling military reservation forty years ago, got a Christmas note today from a former soldier's wife, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Britons are on a record buying, mailing and traveling spree this Christmas season. The vast Christmas crowds in London's gaily decorated streets are experiencing some of the mildest and brightest winter weather in memory.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The University of San Francisco lengthened its winning streak to thirty-three games tonight with a 61-43 victory over Loyola as all-America Bill Russell and the Dons' other Negro players drew applause from a crowd of 5,500.
ATLANTA Dec. 23 (AP) -- Negroes will begin play on the city's public golf courses tomorrow with the approval of Mayor William B. Hartsfield, but with the disapproval of Gov. Marvin Griffin.

Northeastern states may obtain up to a third or a half of the 45,000 Federal low-rent public housing project units allocated for the nation during the fiscal year ending July 31, 1956. The estimate was made yesterday by Herman D. Hillman, New York field office director of the Public Housing Administration.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 23 (AP) Commerce Commissioner Edward T. Dickinson announced today that the Lembo Machine Works, Inc., of Paterson, N. J., planned to build a machinery- making factory at Newburgh, N.Y.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 25 points ($1.25 a bale) higher yesterday. The May position showed the most strength.

Bowing to the Christmas spirit that pervades all peoples at this time, the Israelis and the Arabs have declared a temporary daylight truce at Jerusalem to permit Christmas pilgrims to pass from one side to the other to visit Bethlehem and other holy places or to reunite with family members torn apart by the Palestinian war.

RENO, Nev., Dec. 23 -- The Truckee River overflowed its banks this morning and poured tons of water into this city's downtown business district. Late today the water was still rising, with a crest expected later in the night.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A nightmare succession of railway crashes, the latest of them tonight, is causing serious concern to the traveling public. The accidents, with their toll of dead and injured, has thrown a shadow over the Christmas holiday.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Grand Union Company in the three months ended Nov. 26, Lansing P. Shield, president, reported yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 23 -Aroostook County in Northern Maine is suffering from a severe drought.
The Birth of the Christ Child will be hailed with joyful reverence tonight and tomorrow in the churches of New York.

CLERMONT - FERRAND, France, Dec. 23 -- In the central square of this industrial town tands a bronze equestrian statue of Vercingetorix, the chieftain of the Gauls who resisted Julius Caesar in a battle fought on a plain just above Clermont-Ferrand.

When we think of poor and unfortunate people at Christmas time most of us think in terms of providing a basket full of groceries, an armload of toys or perhaps coal for a fuel bin. However, look at the ills which beset our fellow men as they are reported in this paper's Neediest Cases.
Two new films open at first- run theatres today.
The roles of Santa Claus and Father Knickerbocker should not to be confused, even at this season of the year, in the opinion of the Citizens Union.

Futures on the New York exchanges generally rose yesterday. Despite the fact that most markets closed early for the holiday, many commodities registered substantial volume. Coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, potatoes, onions, rubber, burlap and copper went up; cocoa, hides and wool eased and zinc closed mixed.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia denounced today United States economic assistance plans as "a second echelon of the American war strategy."
Not so many years ago, the erection of machinery was largely a matter of putting together an assortment of machine parts with nuts and bolts.

Miss Mary Burwell Fowlkes,debutante daughter of Mrs. J. Winston Fowlkes of 1040 Fifth Avenue and the late Dr. Fowlkes, was the guest of honor at supper dance given last night in the St. Regis Roof by her mother and her maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. George Garland Allen.

AS half of a double bill with its revival of "Don Pasquale," the Metropolitan Opera gave us the premiere last night of an independent ballet by Zachary Solov called Soiree," and the occasion was a happy one quite in the spirit of the holiday season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Rising California floods, called a "major disaster" by President Eisenhower, today forced a city of 12,500 into a mass evacuation. They left at least sixteen persons dead, scores missing and thousands homeless.
A Brooklyn woman, fearful of her husband's wrath, finally told him and the police yesterday that she had lost-$10,00 in cash on Dec. 16 while moving into a new apartment.

HARTFORD, Dec. 23 -- John C. Kelly, State Police Commissioner, canceled all leaves today for regular and auxiliary state policemen to provide heavier highway patrols over the Christmas week-end holiday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 23 -- A New York travel agency executive reported today an "agreement in principle" with the Czechoslovak Government to facilitate United States tourist travel to this country.

The people of the City of New York and Mayor Wagner personally are to be most warmly congratulated on the appointment of James Felt as chairman of the City Planning Commission. His training, his experience, his breadth of vision and his common sense fit him perfectly for the post for which he has been selected.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 23 -- David Marshall, the Chief Minister of Singapore, returned today from his three-week visit to London. He said he had hopes that Singapore would get dominion status by next April.

It is natural that one should be pulled up with horror when one sees the pitiful photographs of Dr. and Mrs. Bradshaw, American missionaries to China, after five years of imprisonment by the Communists. Most of us are not very familiar with acute malnutrition, beriberi or even simple shock.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Ned McDonald resigned today as football coach at the University of Virginia, capping a curious month of watchful waiting in which he had made no secret of his intention to quit.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 23 -- The full bench of the New South Wales Industrial Commission refused today to direct the Federated Ironworkers Union to readmit Ernest Thornton, a Communist and its former national secretary. The union has since passed from control of the Communists to the right wing.
TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- Of 600 striking Westinghouse employes here, few appeared to be suffering any severe hardship.

Another new building is being planned for New York's financial district. The United States Trust Company, and the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company are preparing jointly to erect a structure on the sites of their present buildings at the southwest corner of Wall and William Streets.
The United States this Christmas season is receiving more Yuletide parcels and holiday greetings from abroad than in any other year since before World War II.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) -- North players concentrated today on defensive patterns they hope will short-circuit the South's expected passing attack when the squads meet in the Shrine All-Star game on Monday night.
CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 23 (UP) -- Wan and subdued, two of the four surviving Dionne quintuplets arrived home today to celebrate Christmas in this bleak, snow-blanketed northern Ontario town.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 22 -- All Sweden is smiling again. People stand and indulge in small talk on streets and laugh and take three hours for lunch.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Gold, the traditional symbol of capitalism, remains an important factor in the Soviet economy. This might have seemed bizarre to early Bolshevik revolutionists thirty-eight years ago. However, as practical problems of fiscal administration and foreign trade faced successive Communist leaders they were forced to adjust their initial Utopian dreams.

The Millinery Workers Union Health, Welfare and Retirement Funds announced yesterday that a substantial part of its $7,000,000 reserves would be used to build cooperative houses for low-income groups.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York struck hard at what it called the "reign of terror" in Mississippi in an official statement released yesterday.

THE Metropolitan Opera was a gay place last night. It was good to have Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" back after an absence of ten years. This is an opera that bubbles over with cheerful spirits, and a gifted cast presented it with an appreciation of the Mediterranean sunshine that fills it with lightness and grace.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Dec. 25 -- The Soviet Government apparently ended today the "coldwar" on taxes that it has been waging with this city.
Clarence G. Morse, who is Maritime Administrator and chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, has taken over a third Government shipping post as director of the National Shipping Authority.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Washington University Bears, sparked by a late second-half performance of Bud Cristal, beat Cornell University, 55 -- 50. Tonight in an intersectional basketball game that was tied seven times.

Charles J. Bauer and Rudolph A. Nietert have been appointed vice presidents of Appleton Cox., Inc., marine insurance concern. Miss Lydia C. Selby, treasurer, vice president and director of the company, has retired, effective Jan. 1.
New York's retailers will close their books tonight on the best Christmas season in history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today declared California floods a "major disaster" and authorized what the White House called "blank check" Federal financial assistance.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee in his Christmas-New Year's message today sent best wishes to Americans in South Korea and also to "helpless subjects" in the Soviet Union.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Interior Minister Lucio Pabon Nunez said last night there would be no let-up in the campaign against press opponents of President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla's Government. The Minister warned they might be imprisoned for terms up to five years.
When train 192 of the New York Central's Hudson Division arrived in Grand Central Terminal yesterday morning commuters were dancing in festooned aisles.
CHINO, Calif., Dec. 23 (UP) -- Rex C. Ellsworth confirmed today he might sell his Kentucky Derby winner, Swaps, in time if the price were right.
WITH the inevitable egg nog, what to serve? The first of several questions to come up in connection with holiday entertaining, it is easiest to answer with one words: Nothing.

The sign on the filing cabinet in the office of the Brooklyn Dodgers said "Confidential!" It didn't say "Positively!" but it would not have been cricket to examine the contents without official permission.

Sales of cooperative apartments were reported by William A. White Sons, brokers. The buyers were John H. O'Toole Jr., in 40 Fifth Avenue; Freida Moisseiff, in 860 Fifth Avenue; Herman Muehlstein, in 60 Sutton Place South; Russell Brown, in 17 West Fifty-fourth Street; Alfred Milo, in 4 East Eighty-eighth Street, and Frederick W. McGowan and Mrs. May C. Ross, in Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and West 183d Street.
Anybody who complains about delays in holiday mail is referred to the Rev. Werner Wedel, who has just received a Christmas card fourteen years late.
Time, which is reputed to heal all things, has had no apparent effect on the Westinghouse Electric Corporation strike.
Net income of the Great Northern Railway dipped last month to $2,487,439 from $3,137,531 in the same month a year ago.

LESTER, Pa., Dec. 23 -- The Christmas spirit of neighbors, merchants and business concerns is helping the 6,000 striking workers of Westinghouse's huge turbine manufacturing plant here. But, nevertheless, it will be a thin Christmas, materially, for most of them and their children.
The National Broadcasting Company bought the television and allied rights yesterday to the stage musical "The Boy Friend" from Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, the producers.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns today finished two weeks of "mental" practice for their National Football League championship game against the Los Angeles Rams on Monday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Paul Gregory, theatrical and film producer, plans to expand his activities in television and is being encouraged by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Samuel Reshevsky, winning his adjourned fourth-round game from Larry Evans in sixty moves at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, remained undefeated in the first five rounds of the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy tournament.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 23 -- Maj. Bryan Jackson Coombe of Britain's Royal Engineers said today that a 23-year-old Greek he killed in a gun fray Dec. 15 had been a "common criminal."
Seven United States Treasury bonds worth $25,000 disappeared yesterday under circumstances the police found unusual and mystifying.

The annual endeavor of holiday throngs to get home by Christmas Eve strained transportation centers here last night. Virtually every bus, plane and train that left the city was jammed or subject to delays ranging from a few minutes to more than eight hours.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The index of average primary market prices advanced 0.1 point over the week ended on Tuesday to 112.0 (1947-49 equals 100), the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Against a background of Christmas decorations, twelve young women were introduced to society last night at the thirty-seventh annual Yuletide ball. They were presented in the ballroom of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

On Dec. 24, 1947, the Federal Reserve System's open market committee, at the direction of Robert G. Rouse, lowered its support price for long-term Treasury bonds to a small fraction above par. The reaction of bond men was surprised and bitter.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian exports of wheat and flour in the first three months of the current crop year declined by 14,200,000 bushels from last year's level, the Bureau of Statistics has reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Interior Secretary, clashed with a conservation organization today over the new regulations governing oil and gas leasing in United States wildlife refuges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Weather Bureau has decided to brave the storm and use girls' names again for the hurricanes of 1956.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Dec. 23 -- Edward Plamondon, 11 years old, drowned today when he fell through the ice on Mill River Pond here. His brother, Robert, 12, was rescued.

YONKERS, Dec. 23 -- Light and power were cut off in 32,000 southern Westchester homes, factories and business places this afternoon by a workman's pick. The pick penetrated a high-voltage underground cable and caused a short circuit at the Dunwoodie substation of the Consolidated Edison Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- Tax revenues in eight selected Eastern and Mid-Western cities increased an average of 69 per cent between 1945 and 1954, the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia reported this week
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Details of research work on an aircraft-of-the-future, known as an "aerodyne," have been disclosed by the designer, Dr. A. M. Lippisch.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The reborn Amerika will sell for 5 rubles, $1.25 at the official rate of exchange, but in terms of purchasing power a fraction of that amount.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 22 -- A small lesson in the problems of diplomatic negotiation may be learned from the talks going on between the Netherlands and Indonesia.
The build-up for the coming battle between public and private branches of the gas industry began this week.

The Murray Hill Agency of the Prudential Insurance Company has leased the twenty-second floor in the twenty-four-story office building being erected by Samuel Rudin at 415 Madison Avenue at Forty-eighth Street. The Cross and Brown Company is agent for the building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, the Government's oldest regulatory agency, came out in opposition today to the key proposal in the Administration's new transportation policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- A former prisoner of war in Korea has been cleared of anonymous collaboration charges with an award of $2,125 in compensation payments, according to the office of Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Gerald White of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, Rossford, Ohio, got a patent this week for a land yacht that can go to sea. He calls it an amphibious house trailer.
A WHITE Christmas provides a natural holiday atmosphere, but it is rough on the game birds, whose already thin food supply is buried under snow.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The O. G. Ranch's Melzar, closing fast, drove to a thrilling victory in the feature at Tropical Park today. The 3-year-long gelding won by a half length in a finish that saw four horses almost blanketed at the wire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, urged today that private shipyards start building modern ocean and Great Lakes ore carriers to meet increased future needs.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Clifford Odets is converting a story he originally started as a stage play into a motion-picture script, which he will also direct for Columbia Pictures.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 23 -Christmas morning will dawn a bit austere for the six youngsters of George H. Merz Jr., one of the 800 members of Local 456, I. U. E., on strike at Westinghouse's elevator division here.
The paint industry is anxiously watching developments in New York City markets.

On Dec. 9 you reported that Governor Harriman ordered an end to the use of the word "color" -- denoting race -- on New York State Drivers' Licenses and that he had said the practice requiring applicants to state their color was "offensive."

We suppose there are still a few skeptics of probation's value as a substitute for jail in restoring moral health. In his annual statement Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of the Court of Special Sessions offers not merely an argument but a demonstration that should convince at least some of the doubters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- A legal officer for the Civil Aeronautics Board has recommended the selection of Northeast Airlines as a third major carrier to serve the Atlantic seaboard between Boston and Miami.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 -- Moslem Jordan and Jewish Israel put aside today the tensions of recent weeks to aid Christians making pilgrimages to Bethlehem.

WOLFSBURG, Germany, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- Volkswagen, the car Adolf Hitler promised to put in every German garage, has piled up such huge cash reserves its price could be slashed "substanitally" if Europe's present sellers' market should disappear.

Polly Adler's autobiographical book, "A House Is Not a Home," in which the author recounts the seamy side of the Prohibition Era and her difficulties in operating fancy bordellos, has been bought by Rex Carlton for Broadway presentation next season as a musical.
OTSU, Japan, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A high Buddhist priest left his mountain temple this week, looked in on a United States Army camp and decided to stay for Christmas.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 -- What bothers "Jack Jones" more than anything else in the strike is that he has no voice in the proceedings.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23 -- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu issued today a decree making all members of his Government ineligible for elective office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Government sought today a Supreme Court test of the provision of the Uniform Code of Military Justice under which civilians accompanying the armed forces abroad have been tried in military courts.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 -- The advent of summer heat and existence of a state of siege have brought a semblance of political peace to Brazil.

TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- The future Emperor of Japan was 22 years old today, and whispers as to who may be the future Empress became open speculation in the press. According to an anonymous writer in the Asahi Weekly four girls are most favored.
Christmas is for children, but all over New York yesterday the adults were having as big a time as the youngsters.

Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree, the famous Victorian actor-manager, is the subject of a new biography by Hesketh Pearson. To be issued by Harper in February, "Beerbohm Tree: His Life and Laughter" is based on private family papers, the recollections of Max Beerbohm, Tree's famous half-brother, and the author's own knowledge of the man gained while a member of his company.
MADRID, Dec. 23 -- The leader of the Falange party asked Spanish youth, today to have faith in the Government and to support official policies.

In connection with your editorial of Nov 28 "The Problem of Cyprus" may I point out that "the anti-British riots" in the island were the consequence of a stubborn British policy which categorically refused the human right of self-determination to a people under a succession of foreign yokes for 763 whole years.
LONDON, Dec 22 -- The stock markets maintained a firm tone today despite the customary pre-Christmas contraction of business. Volume of business this week was about one-quarter lower than last week.

CHICAGO, Dee. 23 -- Pit trading was of a holiday character today, evening-up for the long- week-end accounting for most of the operations. Long liquidation was in evidence early with prices lower. Later there was substantial recovery from the low spots but with rallies running into rather free selling.

A vacant plot fronting 118 feet on the east side of Chittenden Avenue, about 100 feet north of West 187th Street, has been purchased for improvement with an apartment house. It was bought by H. C. Kranchfeld, Inc., from the Cabrini Boulevard Holding Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -In 1907 a reporter noted in his story on the opening of the Market Street elevated line that "it exceeds in stability of structure all Other elevated roads."
A 6-year-old boy reported shot by a sniper's bullet Wednesday was actually killed by his aunt, the police said yesterday.
The Health Department issued an urgent warning on the dangers of carbon monoxide poisoning yesterday. Three persons had been killed and nine overcome by the gas in a twenty-four-hour period.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Soviet Government spokesmen have renewed their attacks on proponents of the policy of consumer goods first.
Sales of machine tools in 1956 will likely exceed those for the past year, but will fall short of the figures reached in the defense emergency years.
A man's right to be a miser and to save money from relief payments will be argued in the Court of Special Sessions Jan. 17.

For many years persons making jokes about a railroad running into the City of New York picked on the one that emerges from the wilderness of Long Island. Prior to that there were one or two in New Jersey that, because of their frailties, were thought humorous.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Dec. 22 -- Before he went on strike at Westinghouse, Ed Carlson and his family were managing fairly well. Most of the household bills were paid, Mr. Carlson's wife, Eleanore, was working on a seasonal basis at Westinghouse, and the family was $200 to $250 ahead.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- John Fell Stevenson, 19-year-old younger son of Adlai E. Stevenson, will undergo surgery next week at Passavant Hospital for removal of his right kneecap, shattered Wednesday in the auto-truck collision that killed two close friends.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23 -- A prediction of the doom of capitalism was the keynote of the second congress of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party that opened in Bucharest today.

A law firm here has combined reason and season to assist the New York Times Neediest Cases, while settling disputes between clients. It advises its clients at this time of year to reconcile differences by donating any disputed amount to the fund.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 23 -- The cabinet has decided on a compromise of the problem resulting from the armed defiance of governmental authority by air force paratroopers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Treasury Department reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have shown no signs of decreasing. They rose again.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., is extending its interest in the more specialized field of producing petroleum chemicals, according to a year-end statement. The cost of this program, which includes increasing the output of present products and the widening of the range, is expected to reach $22,000,000.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 23 -- Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, predicted today that the Soviet Union would attempt to use Japan as a lever to gain a United Nations seat for Communist China during next year's General Assembly.

The contents of the pay envelope can't precisely measure merriment. Christmas joy is often found in the humblest of homes. But dollars can add a great deal to the fun, and the prospect for wage workers this yuletide is especially bright. Factory pay in the United States is at an all-time peak and the cost of living has hardly risen at all in the two years that are past.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The nation's railroads have informally asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to let them raise freight rates by 7 per cent on Feb. 9. The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission said today that the railroads had asked that the rate rise become effective before the outcome of usually lengthy hearings.

"HOME for Christmas!" Whether it is one's' own or that of a friend, home is the place to be during the joyful holiday hard upon us. Presents were not meant to be unwrapped without an audience, nor carols sung by a single voice, nor the Christmas pudding served up for one.
The Veterans Administration lifted yesterday its suspension of disability payments to James Kutcher, a member of the Socialist Workers party, who lost both legs as a rifleman in World War II.

Gaetano Donizetti -- whose opera buffa, "Don Pasquale," was produced last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, preceded by the new ballet to music by Rossini -- was a merry, handsome fellow, as was his compatriot, Rossini.

Home Properties, Inc., has purchased the three six-story apartment houses at 1326-36 Brook Avenue, the Bronx. The buildings contain eighty-four apartments and seven stores. They were sold by a client of Abe and Rubin Solove, brokers. Jacob S. Lampert, attorney, represented the buyer.
VIENNA, Austria, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Poland has drafted a new penal code increasing penalties on bribe-takers, saboteurs and juvenile delinquents, according to Warsaw newspapers received here today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A threatened Christmas strike against the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad was postponed indefinitely today by the Railroad Yardmasters of America.

Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, will discuss "The Effect of Intense Competition on Savings Institutions" at the annual conference of the Savings and Mortgage Division of the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Leon W. Johnson, according to a Pentagon spokesman, will be named United States Representative to the Military Committee and Standing Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He is now chief of the Continental Air Command, Mitchel Air Force Base, L. I.

The social work field continues to be plagued by a shortage of competent personnel. Universities and colleges are not able to turn out graduates in large enough numbers to cope with the demand for properly equipped social workers. As in the teaching profession, there is rising concern that positions are being filled by unqualified staff.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Republican state legislator said today he planned to enter President Eisenhower's name in Pennsylvania's Presidential preference primary next April 24.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 -- Wide disagreement between the Canadian Government and Canadian military leaders before and during World War II was revealed today. The disclosure was contained in the first volume of a new official history of the Canadian Army's role from 1939 to 1945.

CHRISTMAS in New York! A Norway spruce six stories high, decorated with trimmings the size of basketballs. Thirty evergreens ablaze with white and golden lights, centered for three miles down the world's richest avenue. Thousands of determined shoppers milling through stores and standing, shivering, in lines for a glimpse of fabulous holiday windows.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 23 -- There is a brightly lighted Christmas tree in the pleasant living room of Elmer F. Pollard's home tonight, and there are many gifts beneath the tree.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Italy's crack Alpine ski troops are finishing "Operation Olympic."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Eisenhower expressed doubt today that he would be able to go South for a brief holiday as his doctors had urged.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- The French Government sought today to take the political sting out of a decision to send 60,000 soldiers to Algeria soon. It indicated that they were "replacements" rather than "reinforcements."

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- The most extensive cancer survey ever undertaken in this country indicates an increase of more than 50 per cent in the number of persons who will be stricken by this disease in the next twenty-five years.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- The airplane that made an emergency landing on the site of a new public school here yesterday may not be allowed to take off from the same spot.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 23 -- Premier Pibul Songgram confirmed today that he had "suggested" that he resign because of recent public criticism of individual Cabinet Ministers.

THAT beloved anachronism, the fireplace, comes into its own tonight. No longer the necessity for heating and cooking that it was for five hundred years, it still symbolizes the home and family spirit of Christmas Eve.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Traffic Violations said today the committee planned to present at the next session of the Legislature a plan to improve safety on the highways.
MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A reception befitting a potentate and his entourage awaits Nashua, the million-dollar race horse, when he comes "home" tomorrow.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 23 -- The Democratic Union of the Algerian Manifesto, a group headed by the nationalist leader Ferhat Abbas, has invited its members to resign from all representative bodies to which they may belong.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 -- Afghanistan is fighting to catch up with a world that it by centuries ago.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The auto industry's 1955 car output will fall about 32,000 units short of the coveted 8,000,000 mark, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This would put production at 7,968,000 units.
Four of this country's leading churchmen issued special Christmas messages yesterday to their followers.

DEVON, ENGLAND. THERE'S nothing can be done about it. Constant O'Casey is, he should be banished, and constant he remains to keep him so. There's nothing terrible in it; rather is it all for his own good.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 -- "These Afghans, if you give them a break, show them how things are done -- there are no people anywhere better," said a United States engineer.
MIAMI, Dec. 24 -- Nashua, the king of turfdom, arrived at the scene of his richest victory today after the most publicized equine journey since Paul Revere took his famous ride 179 years ago.
SACRAMENTO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin S. Knight flew over flooded northern California today. He said the devastation "spells disaster and heartbreak."

The tall young man busily loading shelves in the modern supermarket quite often is not a store employe at all. His business suit looks more like the garb of a salesman or a junior executive than that of a clerk or stockroom worker.
Jack Fleck of Davenport, Iowa, became the 1955 United States Open golf champion by beating the most formidable golfer of this generation -- Ben Hogan.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The Soviet Union's master salesmen returned this week after demonstrating that successful merchandising can masquerade as philanthropy when mixed with a proper amount of sympathy for the customer.

LAKEFIELD, Ont., Dec. 24, Canadian Press -- Canadian Flint and Spar Company is expected to put Canada's second nepheline syenite ore quarry into operation next spring -- forty-four years after general manager Norman F. Davis surveyed the Blue Mountain section near here for its ore possibilities.

VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- The Tass news agency's bureau here stated tonight that the Provincial Government of Lower Austria had asked the Soviet authorities for a $20,000,000 loan and had a promise of favorable consideration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- A new storm headed today toward flood-stricken southern Oregon and northern California.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 -- The Government of Gen. Pedro Aramburu this week again firmly stressed its "provisional" nature. In two statements of policy it declared that neither the military nor the civil personalities who are attempting to put Argentina on the road to democracy will be eligible for elective offices.
The Second Century Building Fund of the Lenox Hill Hospital will be aided by the first benefit performance of "The Great Sebastians" on Jan. 6 at the ANTA theatre.

MARYSVILLE, Calif., Dec. 24 -- Marysville and Yuba City, twin cities at the junction of the Feather and Yuba Rivers, stood deserted this Christmas Eve. Marysville was still dry. Yuba City was flooded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The White House announced today the resignations of James A. McConnell as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and of A. Jackson Goodwin Jr. as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A photo-copy of what is said to be the oldest known city map in history has been made public by Dr. Samuel Noah Kramer, Clark research professor of Assyriology at the University of Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Administration hopes to use special regional Middle Eastern and Asian funds as its tactical economic weapon against the Soviet economic offen sive in under-developed areas.

OLD as the phrase "the law's delay" may be, there is a new awareness of the seriousness of it, a final determination to do something about it. People are concerned about the condition and consequences. They want to know the cause and cure. They are beginning to suspect that the operation of the jury system has a close connection with the matter and they want to understand it.

DENVER, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tony Trabert defeated Pancho Gonzales in convincing fashion last night in the eighth round of their cross-country professional tennis tour, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3. The victory was Trabert's third against five losses.
SOME day soon, it may be possible to fly on frequent schedules from the United States to this beautiful island in the heart of the South Pacific in two days, with just one stop, in Hawaii.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Treasury is squeezing pennies in this lean tax collection season to keep the national debt below the legal ceiling of $281,000,000,000.

Peter Colefax, president of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation, is an executive of so single-minded a devotion to duty that he has kept his company moving forward under British, Dutch and German ownership, paying little attention to the transitions in control when they occurred.

The stock market staged a modest Christmas rally last week. Spurred by demands for shares of concerns linked to defense work, prices turned mostly higher after midweek, following some early irregularity. Trading until then was comparatively slow, due partly to holiday influences, but it expanded with the rise in prices.

LONDON Records, which has all kinds of European affiliates on which to draw, occasionally comes up with music that hardly anybody has heard, by composers hardly anybody has heard of. Cases in point are two London-International 10-inch disks, one devoted to Jacques Stehman's Symphonic de Poche and Chant Funebre (National Orchestra of Belgium conducted by Eduard van Remoortel), the other to Joseph Jongen's Piano Concerto (Edvardo del Pueyo and same orchestra under Fernand Quinet).

MEXICO CITY -- There is a new addition to the collection of the National Museum here that no tourist should miss. It is an exact, scaled-to-life reproduction of the crypt uncovered not long ago in the Mayan ruins of the sacred city of Palenque in the Chiapas jungle down near the Guatemalan border.
ATLANTA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Five Negroes took their places in line with the usual weekend crowd of white golfers at Atlanta's North Fulton Course today and played without incident.
Newspaper appeals for the needy met with unusually generous public response this year.
AUBURN, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- An election in this area Monday brought nearer the end of the "little red school house" in upstate New York.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 -- The River Divide Farm's Decathlon, an exceptionally fast son of Olympia, outclassed five other juveniles in the $8,375 Dade County Handicap at Tropical Park today.

A relatively simple reorganization of a corporate structure comprised of several different companies can create much confusion in the public mind. Baseless rumors are often spawned, motives for the changes are questioned, and prices of securities only remotely related to those involved move erratically in the stock market until doubtful investors are convinced they have screened the facts from the unsound assumptions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- When the chalky pedagogues look back at the United States in the year 1955, they are likely to be impressed by three things: its growth, its fabulous prosperity, and the revival of its sanity.

The Communists are stepping up their propaganda activities against the United States in the tiny kingdom of Laos, an American reported last week. The Communists say that Americans are flying spies instead of food into the area.

THERE is a great deal of satisfaction to be found in supplying the table with produce harvested from the garden long after the first killing frosts. Veteran home gardeners start late summer plantings of broccoli for this purpose.
Boat shows don't need slogans or themes. They are plenty exciting anyway. But years ago somebody started identifying each oncoming show, and this year is no different.

Stimulated no doubt by the approach of the 1956 Olympics, track and field's global legions displayed notable speed, stamina, spring and strength during the year. Fifteen world records were broken and two were tied in the most devastating assault on the book in recent memory.

SAFETY is an important consideration in any place and especially in a home workshop. The projects undertaken there usually involve the use of sharp, edged tools. They also frequently require climbing or lifting that may result in accidental injuries.
The joyful chorus of midnight carolers merged last night with reverent meditation and prayer as New York church-goers heralded another Christmas Day.
James Kutcher, legless veteran whose disability payments were suspended and then restored by the Veterans Administration, expects to go to Washington for a hearing next week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- University of Illinois trustees decided this week that teaching high school English was not the university's job. The trustees voted to discontinue a remedial course that has been provided for more than twenty years.

The main reading room and information desk of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will remain open today and tomorrow from 1 to 10 P. M. The central circulation branch there will be open from 2 to 6 P. M., but will be closed tomorrow. All other divisions and all branches will be closed both days.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 24 -- Tengku Abdul Rahman, the Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, said today that he would welcome a joint approach with Singapore to Britain for immediate self-government if Singapore would join the federation.

There are thirteen major college basketball tournaments scheduled to be played throughout the country this week, but the one most local fans are interested in is the fourth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival event at Madison Square Garden.

ACCORDING to Mr. Root, a "state liberal" is anyone who believes the Government has some responsibility for social welfare. This includes not only Roosevelt, Truman and the A. D. A., but Eisenhower and Republican advocates of tariffs and price supports.

In the natural search for happiness and cheer in this upset world of ours on Christmas Day there is no question where anyone would like to be today so far as Latin America is concerned. It is Argentina, which for the first time in many Christmases can celebrate in an atmosphere of freedom.

Present plans call for the construction of twelve earth satellites carrying instruments. The expectation is that at least six will be successfully launched into their orbits, circulating about the earth for periods ranging from two weeks to several months at heights between 200 and 800 miles. Six may fail.

CRIMINALS are indeed at large in an assortment of year's-end novels; and if you're tired of conventional American and English scenes, you can take your choice of France, Italy, Belgium, Germany or Siam -- possibly finding, as I often do, that the less hackneyed locales make a good novel seem better and a weak one endurable.
Mr. Weinstein quotes a secretary as saying "A girl can get a job easily these days." This remark would not be true if she were twenty years older.

IN the weeks before Christmas, the tempo of London accelerated and the city decked itself out for the holiday. For instance, along the broad sweep of Regent Street, large, lacy three - dimensional stars, each tip dotted with a silver sequin, were suspended from aloft.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 -- A brighter future for organized labor throughout Latin America was forecast today by Arturo Jauregui, acting Secretary General of the Inter-American Regional Workers Organization.
The vigorous pace in general business continued during December, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

William Weinstein's harangue about unfair feminine office behavior ("Beauty Culture, 9 to 5," Dec. 11) merits the reminder that you can't have your cake and eat it, too. [Mr. Weinstein observed that, with the girls making up all day to go out at night, "many business offices look like beauty parlors these days." --Editor.]

Almost anyone who knows a baseball from an onion also knows what made 1955 a year long to be remembered in the annals of our national pastime. It was the year the Dodgers brought to Brooklyn its first world championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Democratic race for the Presidential nomination is proceeding momentarily at a leisurely walk and even the addition of two new entrants over the past week failed to quicken its pace or add much in the way of suspense or excitement.

The New York Rangers will engage the first-place Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. With the Flying Frenchmen boasting an impressive record, the contest promises to attract more than 13,000 fans. The game will start at 7 o'clock.

IN his review of my book "Collectivism on the Campus," Sidney Hook employs old-line gags: "guilt by association," "hysteria mongers," "exaggerations," "insinuation." He did better when he coined the phrase "typhoid Marys" for those who, not Communists, yet carry the contagion of communism.
" Come on in, the water is fine." That will be the 1956 cry of the nation's swimming pool builders.

THIS is the most topical and ambitions book by that wholly delightful Indian novelist, R. K. Narayan. "Waiting for the Mahatma" is a story of the last few years of Gandhi's work, when India reaped the whirlwind. Here we sometimes see the Mahatma directly, but more often we see him hugely mirrored in events or, as it were, analyzed in the life of a disciple.

BOGOTA, Columbia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Newspaper readers of Medellin have started a National Fund for Freedom of the Press. They are raising money to pay fines imposed by the Government on papers that publish stories the Government does not like, and to help imprisoned newsmen.

The Stanley Cup, symbolic of the professional ice hockey championship of the world, was won by the Detroit Red Wings. It was the second time in a row and the fourth time in six seasons that the Red Wings took the cup.

One certain way of starting an argument among college basketball fans is to rate San Francisco over Duquesne -- or vice versa -- in listing the top quintet in the nation for 1954-55. Each team had its share of supporters, but the edge belonged to the Dons from California.

Zim Israel Navigation Company will expand its passenger and cargo services between United States ports and the Holy Land next year. Dr. N. Wydra, managing director of the company, said that Zim Lines would offer dependable service on a year-round basis in 1956. This service will include:
Working women, as well as men, may be eligible to study for an engineering degree at Columbia University under a new program. Even those who have not graduated from high school may attend.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- Hundreds of high school students here are engaged in a project aimed at giving Asian youth groups a view of youth participation in American community service.
Industrial manufacturers have hit the jack pot.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Talks aimed at settling a nine-week-old strike by the International Union of Electrical Workers, A. F. L.-C. I. O., against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation have been recessed over the holiday week-end.
ARDEN, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- The passage of a string of 103 freight cars interrupted Governor Harriman's speech at the opening of the new Erie Railroad station here today.

A CROQUEMBOUCHE is as gay as this season. It is a pyramid of caramel-glazed cream puffs that serves as an effective and edible centerpiece at any holiday party. The puffs are a pretty partner to a sweet champagne at a New Year's Eve gathering or may be used as a dessert for a buffet supper.
A University of Illinois professor of linguistics reported his discovery that most people's knowledge of grammar comes to them before their third birthday.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- As the current French electoral campaign passed its mid-point this week there was general agreement that a strong current for a "change" was running in the French electorate.
NORTH GUILFORD, Conn., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Two nuns gave their lives in a vain attempt to save a third when fire leveled the principal buildings of Our Lady of Grace Monastery last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Eisenhower declared the flooded sections of Nevada today a "major disaster" area. He also ordered Federal agencies to speed all possible aid to the flood victims in the inundated regions.
ATLANTA, Dec. 24 -- Senator Walter F. George, a key figure on the world stage in efforts to ease East-West tensions, moved this week to intensify some political tensions in his home state.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The West suffered a sharp set-back this week in its hopes to organize the Arab states into an anti-Communist alliance -- rather than, as now, an alliance against Israel.

I should like to have the words that sum up your lead editorial of Dec. 19 engraved on a Christmas card from the United States to the world at large: "The kind of aid that warms the holiday heart is the kind that helps build a dam in Egypt, develop water for the thirsty lands of Jordan, increases crop yields in India, Indonesia, and the heart of Africa."
GENEVA, Dec. 20 -- Europe is in one of its recurring periods of jitters about the international consequences of United States agricultural policy.

THE look of Christmas is everywhere today, although it isn't the same in every section of the United States. In Minnesota, Christmas is white, in Florida it is green, and in New York it may be either of these. And, in addition to the general landscape tone, each area contributes its own "local color."

CHRISTMAS marks the end of the year for retailers. There will be business this week, of course, but the big push ended yesterday and success or failure in meeting or surpassing last year's figures is now known. This last week before Christmas was a big one for most retail merchants since, in comparison with 1954, they were enjoying an additional shopping day. Last year Christmas fell on Saturday.

Ten years ago this past week New York's famed Institute for the Crippled and Disabled held an annual Christmas party. This was in keeping with a long tradition. This writer, then newly discharged from the armed forces, was a guest because the Army Air Forces during the war had used the institute as a training center for its rehabilitation personnel.

TODAY the city is filled with Christmas brightness. The joy of the traditional festivities is everywhere. But there is also something deeper and more lasting, something that will not pass with the season. It is the inner glow of goodwill between friend and friend, neighbor and neighbor.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: A flowering gift plant, whether poinsettia or kalanchoe, cyclamen or begonia, orchid or African violet, lasts best in a light but not sunny room. The location should be free of drafts from windows and doors and away from radiators. About 70 degrees is best for poinsettia, 60 degrees for others. All need watering at least once a day.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- The Pope's three points regarding atomic weapons follow closely the lines of proposals made here during the General Assembly's debate on disarmament.

When we think of Christmas in art, it is usually in terms of an Italian Renaissance or Flemish artist, a Fra Angelico or Memling. Some less familiar interpretations of Christ's birth and childhood are seen in these vivid prints, from a show now at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. They are by Baroque artists, who flourished in the seventeenth century and whose work was widely circulated in Europe.
As is the case with all sports, enthusiasts for hockey avail themselves of every possible opportunity to serve as missionaries for their pet pastime.

ARTHUR SCHWARTZ has been assigned to produce a television version of "Twentieth Century," the play written by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur. The adaptation will contain special music composed by Mr. Schwartz and will be televised on April 7 from 9:30 to 11 P. M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

BETHLEHEM, Sunday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The bells of Bethlehem heralded anew to a troubled world today the birthday of the Prince of Peace. Pilgrims worshipped again at the spot where Jesus Christ was born.

OVERLOOK Number Three, one of the best known scenic vi wing points on the East Coast, and now a vantage point for viewers of the new Thruway Bridge across the Hudson River, has become a temporary casualty of the construction of Palisades Interstate Parkway.
Christmas holiday travel, which created an enormous jam in New York railroad, bus and plane terminals Friday night, slackened yesterday afternoon.
The Russian Charitable Organizations of the United States, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the seventh annual Bal Blanc, which will be held on Jan. 12, the eve of the Russian New Year.

BARTOK: Divertimento for Strings; MUELLER: Sinfonia No. 2 for Strings and Flute; Edmund de Stoutz and Zurich Chamber Orchestra (London). Paul Mueller is a contemporary Swiss composer. This Sinfonia is neo-classic and expertly composed, but does not have many original ideas.

" THE American is a new man," wrote Crevecoeur in his classic definition when this country was being born, "a new man who acts upon new principles; he must therefore entertain new ideas and form new opinions."

COLUSA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- "My boy went out to see how deep the water was and never came back," Mrs. Opal Coats of Yuba City sobbed. She was being treated today by physicians for shock at an improvised Colusa refugee center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- If Congress follows what appears to be a historical pattern of "papa knows best" on farm matters it will proceed upon reconvening next month to "dispose" of the surplus disposal problem.

Expansion in the building industry is continuing with permit valuation for the first half of this month showing a 50 per cent gain over the year-ago period. Building permits totaled $1,326,000, about the same as in the previous week, and non-residential building has been responsible for all the recent expansion.

LONDON Records continues its observance the Mozart bicentennial with two more full-length opera recordings of The Magic Flute and The Marriage of Figaro (each three disks). Both are excellent recorded performances, made under conductors who know their business.

Adolf A. Berle Jr. in his article "Elected Judges -- or Appointed?" (Dec. 11) is correct as far as he goes. The voters are as much out of the process of choosing elective judges in New York City as they are in the case of the ninety-seven judges and magistrates now appointive by the Mayor.

ONE of the most attractive ways to increase our understanding of Herman Melville's art is to consider how Melville gradually correlated the comic and the tragic in his narrative writings. Edward H. Rosenberry, who teaches English at the University of Delaware, very pleasantly introduces us to this approach in "Melville and the Comic Spirit" by describing, illustrating and analyzing four progressive phases of that development.

TRENTON, Dec. 24 -- On June 7, 1921, a determined 26-year-old man began at Sea Girt the organization of New Jersey's first state police force. In the ensuing years he was to build that body into one of the most efficient of its type in the country and establish for himself an international reputation as a police and military official.

Mickey Mantle, the Yankees' 24-year-old seasoned campaigner, was the American League's slugging champion for 1955, according to official averages announced yesterday. Not only did the Oklahoma Kid lead the junior loop in home runs with thirty-seven, but he also carried off the slugging championship with a .611 percentage.

AFTER the holidays many people with frostbitten cheeks and cold fingers and toes rush off to warmer climes. There they bask in the sun surrounded by verdant green landscapes, a sharp contrast to the bare trees and browned fields of the North.

THE latest directorial wonder boy is Daniel Mann, formerly of Brooklyn, the Borscht Circuit and Broadway. In five years he has tattooed hits on the stage and screen (including the Broadway and Hollywood versions of "Come Back, Little Sheba" and "The Rose Tattoo").

THIS has been a year of surprises, not all of them pleasant, for the motion picture business. The major disappointment was the sudden reversal of the upward curve in the domestic earnings of pictures.

Peter T. White's analysis of the Davy Crockett fad ("Ex-King of the Wild Frontier," Dec. 11) overlooked the fact that the legend and the ballad themselves contained the seed of their destruction. [Mr. White concluded that while Davy was the greatest thing of his time, his time was brief and now he's a drug on the market. -- Editor.]
Carols sung in many places in the city yesterday celebrated Christmas Eve and heralded Christmas Day.
The Boys Brotherhood Republic, a miniature city on the Lower East Side, added $8.31 yesterday to the annual Christmas appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Eisenhower Administration has rather suddenly reversed the whole long process of tapering off foreign aid. It now proposes to refill the pipelines that heretofore were to be allowed to run thinner and thinner.
WHEN Sean O'Casey's "Red Roses for Me" bows at the Booth on Wednesday its participants will be walking on a slant. Not, mind you, because one and all had tippled beyond their respective depths.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A substantial group within the United Nations appears to favor holding the 1956 General Assembly in Rome after the Nov. 6 Presidential election in the United States.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Communist-led Laotian rebels were making an eleventh-hour bid today to draw the citizens of Laos into a boycott of a national election in the Indochina state tomorrow.
A FULL dress preview run of a new lightweight train built by General Motors will take place Thursday, Jan. 5, on both the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads.

Christmas being a day of long traditions, it was celebrated a hundred years ago in New York City much as it will be celebrated today. PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 24 -- A matter of $25,000 stands in the way of Czechoslovakians seeing the first American theatrical production since the end of World War II.

The Coast Guard, tenant Pier 9 East River since 1942, has been asked informally by the city's Department of Marine and Aviation to vacate the 620-foot structure so that it can be made a commercial ship terminal.

AMERICAN historians have delineated recurring periods of illiberal reaction in our history but have generally regarded these as minor and temporary interludes in the grand sweep toward greater individual freedom and well-being. The current retreat of McCarthyism has probably reinforced the general view. Thus it is important to take into account a new interpretation that challenges the whole idea that our national history has been marked by progress toward greater freedom for individuals and minorities.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Manchester United gained a 4-1 victory over West Bromwich Albion today and took a 3-point lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League standings.

Two colleges of the State University of New York have programs of teacher education for the handicapped. Courses are now found at the College for Teachers at Buffalo and the Teachers College at Geneseo. The programs qualify students to teach in the elementary schools and to teach children with physical impairments.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 24 -- Here on a bleak desert 10,000 miles from home, 130 American school children recaptured for forty-five minutes tonight the Christmas season's spirit of peace.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Dec. 24 -- A certificate of charter membership in the fifty-year-old United States Forest Service was presented here this week to Jacob J. Levison, a veteran landscape forester and arboriculturist.

LITTLE did Farmer Newbery or his good wife dream that their John, who always had his nose in a book, would some day go up to London to become a famous publisher and bookseller. Or that nearly two centuries after, a medal for distinguished American children's books would be named in his honor.
The president of Teachers College of Columbia University replied yesterday to criticism that education courses merely deal with "how to teach" and not with "what to teach."

WINTER PARK, Fla. -- The comparatively untrammeled lake and citrus belt of central Florida, in which this community of 16,000 is strategically placed, has numerous charms not so well known to visitors of the state's beaches and keys, and this winter season in these parts is expected to be exceptionally good.

Miss Olga von Klinkofstrom Craven and Miss Nancy Steer are among the debutantes who will be presented at the thirty-fourth annual Debutantes New Year's Ball on Jan. 2 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

On Christmas morning, 1955, the buildings on the East River, New York City, just north of Forty-second Street, are stark and deserted against the eastern sky. Yet the Star that stood over Bethlehem so long ago perhaps stands there a moment, too.
