THE true language of Christmas is an ancient, universal language, ageless and dateless. It was not first given by angels to shepherds in the fields near Bethlehem, although the New Revelation of it there, in the midst of a troubled world, added immeasurably to its riches.

VIENNA has fallen in love. The object of its affection is Jean Madeira, the young American contralto. And the feeling is mutual. For Vienna has bestowed on her the acclaim that she has not yet managed to win in her native country.
Completing its second perfect season in succession, Oklahoma was ranked as the top college football team of 1954 and awarded the O'Donnell Trophy.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Political unrest, generated by an election still five months away, led today to a Peruvian Cabinet shake-up. A new line-up tonight placed a military man in every ministry.
TORONTO, Dec. 24 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks belted each other merrily with fist and stick tonight as the Leafs whipped the Hawks, 5 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

MONTREAL -- The de Havilland Comet, the World's first jet airplane to fly in regular passenger service, was scheduled to make a spectacular non-stop dash from Dorval Airfield to London between midnight and dawn last Thursday morning to finish its round-the-world demonstration flight in a blaze of glory.

Statistics compiled by the Pennsylvania State Employment Service show that employment in the Philadelphia area continued to move up during November, but at a slower pace. Preliminary estimates indicate employment in mid-November reached 1,658,900, an increase of 1,700 since September.

THIS being a day of goodwill there could be nothing more appropriate than to lay off critical unpleasantnesses and put together here a little Christmas nosegay of miscellaneous appreciations in various fields.

Plans are being completed for the Jan. 3 benefit performance of "Pipe Dream" on behalf of Barnard College and the Public Education Association. Committees working on the benefit have been meeting recently at Carlton House.
Domestic steel mills have chalked up production and sales records this year and have embarked on a major enlargement program, an industry leader declared yesterday.
Two rabbis in their sermons yesterday expressed regret at the "temporary" quality of Christmas goodwill and wonder.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Federal and state agencies, the armed forces, the Red Cross and Salvation Army marshaled men and equipment today for the gigantic task of caring for thousands of flood-stricken Californians.

IN his own simple, vibrant style, William O. Steele again brings our frontier forests and people to life with this story of three desperate children carried off up Boone's Wilderness Trail by Shawnee savages.

Despite the customary taboo on exhibitions during the holiday week, a dozen new group and one-man shows have been announced. The inclusion of three one-man sculpture shows at once makes the list all the more unusual.

Mrs. Georgina Pagan Diaz was held without bail yesterday on a homicide charge in the slaying Wednesday of her 6-year-old nephew.

In your picture layout "Water for India" (Dec. 11) you show pictures of the Bhakra project in India and state that the Bhakra~Nangal irrigation and power plan will cost $350,000,000. Is this combined project being financed with any American funds?
ALTHOUGH about 9,225,000 motor vehicles will be built and sold by manufacturers in the United States this year, thousands of retail dealers are ruefully wondering "where do we go from here."

Yale University engineers have built a thirty-foot slingshot. It was constructed by the civil engineering department to produce and analyze the stress waves caused in metal by sudden impact. The question is important, among other reasons, because war (and threat of war) has focused attention on the possibilities of sudden structural collapse under sudden impact of bullets or bombs.

The election of Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler to the board of directors of the Lafayette Fellowship Foundation was announced yesterday. The organization, established to honor the 200th anniversary of the birth of the Marquis de Lafayette in 1957, plans a series of annual Lafayette fellowships.
Anaconda . . . American Smelting and Refining . . . Tennessee Corporation . . . South American Gold and Platinum.

THE fabulous increase in the number of home handymen has created a new crisis in the American family -- "the week-end-do-it-yourself widow." The desertion of wife and babes by grimfaced and determined men who disappear from sight and kin each Saturday and Sunday is now a major problem.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Consternation, outrage, suspicion, shock and bafflement are a few of the mental states Dr. Paul Dudley White has produced in Washington over the last three months.

IN resigning as general director of the New York City Opera Company, Joseph Rosenstock did not intend to play Santa Claus. But his action last week could amount to that if the board of directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., which maintains the opera company, uses this opportunity to reorient itself.

The appointment of Fredric R. Mann, president of the Robin Hood Dell Concerts of Philadelphia, as chairman of the annual dinner-concert of the American Fund for Israel Institutions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Jan. 12 was announced yesterday.
Much of the world still does not know what a free press is.

CARMEL, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Operators of the first major public resort in the metropolitan area using machine-made snow opened their facilities for the first time today at Fahnestock State Park on the Taconic State Parkway.
Better dresses and sportswear for spring were ordered in quantity in the New York apparel markets in the last week, resident buying offices reported yesterday.

THE television industry is gripped in a rating hysteria. Little lists of statistics are making nervous wrecks of stars and executives. Is Phil Silvers a fraction more popular than Milton Berle? Has Perry Como rung down the curtain on Jackie Gleason? Who is in the "top ten" programs? The world of TV trembles over a decimal point.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 24 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen, although a resident of Pennsylvania since 1946, is seeking to re-establish himself in a position of leadership in the Minnesota Republican party.

The Government has issued new and stricter rules governing the granting of mortgage insurance on tankers to be built by private interests for long-term charter to the Military Sea Transportation Service.
Cornell and Pennsylvania were the big names in intercollegiate rowing in 1955 as Navy's fouryear winning streak ended.

" FROM today painting is dead!" cried Paul Delaroche in alarm when the daguerreotype, the first practicable means of photography, was announced on Aug. 19, 1839, to amazed Parisian crowds, and in effect to the world. Not only did the painter's art survive the imagined blow, but it has lived on to plague the esthetic development of photography throughout its history.

ANY year in which the Dodgers win the world series has to be a historic one. That's why 1955 will have to be hammered into the minds of all future history students as being as significant as 1492 and 1776. After all, neither Christopher Columbus nor George Washington brought a pennant to Flatbush.

THE year 1955 has been a big one in bridge, the statistics say here. At least 200 new bridge books were published, more than in any other year since the late Thirties. More people played in bridge tournaments than ever before, including the Thirties.

Rocky Marciano engaged in two successful defenses of his heavyweight championship of the world. The Blockbuster from Brockton, Mass., knocked out Don Cockell of London in nine rounds at San Francisco on May 16 and he knocked out Archie Moore in nine rounds at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 21. Moore was not risking his light-heavyweight championship of the world in this clash.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO -- The Dominican Republic's International Fair for Peace and Progress which opened last week outside this spick and span capital city is a $25,000,000 bid for the attention of Caribbean-bound tourists.
The operation of the vast Iranian oil industry by an international group appears to be running smoothly.

Last night, into the homes of millions of happy children in this and many other lands, "down the chimney Saint Nicholas came with a bound." Where did he come from? If you ask any child, you will be told that he came from the midnight sky, of course.

AT 4 O'CLOCK this afternoon, viewers watching Channel 7, will see an unusual Christmas broadcast from the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine). Participants in the program will include the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of New York, the Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral, and the dean's four children, Catherine 12, James Jr., 9, Constance 7, and Christopher, 5.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 -- Rumania, the first country in the Soviet bloc to announce its new five-year plan, disclosed today an economic policy of intensive investment in heavy industry.
Many parties will be given at the tenth annual Yuletide Assembly Ball to be held Tuesday night in the main ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Graham School.

Despite pre-holiday blizzards and the icy blasts coming once more from Moscow, Europe celebrates today its best and most cheerful Christmas since the end of the last World War. The thaw of the summer which culminated in the "spirit of Geneva" has been succeeded by the winter freeze of the cold war, and many trouble spots continue to cause concern.

MICHAEL REDGRAVE is perhaps the least likely actor in the world to fall on his face. But he did, and in the most literal and appalling way, during his opening night entrance last June -- in the London production of "Tiger at the Gates," in which he is now at the Helen Hayes Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The President will attend the Christmas services at the National Presbyterian Church, and his usual prayer for divine guidance will be only one of scores of millions that will be said for him on the same day. The supplication of all these is that he may be clearly shown the path of duty, and that he may find the strength to tread this path if it leads to continued public service.

NORWALK, Conn. Dec. 24 -- The Army Corps of Engineers will begin demolition of five flood-damaged buildings in the heart of the Norwalk business center Tuesday. It will be the first step in a program to restore a large area that fell victim to the waters of the Norwalk and Silvermine Rivers last Oct. 15.

A sharp cold spell across the nation last week marked the arrival of winter. The weather served to highlight a grim fact pointed out in the Statistical Bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. About twice as many people are sick in winter as are sick in summer.
The biggest news items in racing during 1955 had as a key figure the 3-year-old colt Nashua.

Christmas business at New York and Brooklyn department stores closed with a heavy increase in sales, compared with the pre-Christmas week last year. In the previous week sales had shown a 1 per cent decline on the basis of nine major stores' volume this year against sales of the ten big stores in operation a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Eisenhower family, like millions of others across the land, was enjoying a traditional Christmas Eve at home this evening.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 -- The Eskimos of remote Baffin Island in Canada's frozen North will be introduced to the white man's Santa Claus for the first time tomorrow. An international Christmas party will be given for their benefit by United States and Canadian personnel at the Frobisher Bay Air Base.
At last a man has steered a boat nearly four miles a minute -- and lived! Once before, a year ago, John Cobb lost his life making 200 m.p.h. in a speedboat on an English lake.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- More production at lower cost is to be the keynote of the Soviet Union's sixth five-year plan, scheduled to begin early next year.
An enlarged and longer-range version of the Boeing 707 jet transport -- capable of carrying up to 145 passengers in non-stop trans-Atlantic flight -- was announced yesterday.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 24 -- A lanky forward, Larry Friend, dropped in the first four field goals of the game today to pace California to a 78-59 victory over Dartmouth before 2,500 fans.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Moscow showed few sign tonight of noticing the approach of its thirty-eighth Christmas under Communist rule.
Gloom turned to Christmas cheer yesterday for Mrs. Dorothy Buckley, 30 years old, of 97-25 147th Place, Jamaica, Queens. Her daughter Anna, 9, missing for three weeks, came home.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 -- The Cleveland Browns, appearing in the title game for the sixth straight year, are favored to defeat the surprising Los Angeles Rams Monday for the 1955 championship of the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States suggested today that "all men of goodwill" pray on New Year's Day for victims of religious persecution.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 23 -- During several months this dusty Arab capital has been the scene of intense international activity that erupted last week in violence.

If from the available world supply of wheat we deduct the world requirements for 1955-56, some 1,500 million bushels which are practically unsalable remain. From this enormous quantity about 1,000 million bushels are stored in the United States.
Numerous Christmas gift packages are being returned from Communist East Germany because they contain prohibited canned goods.
The machine design division of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers has announced plans for a conference on design engineering at Convention Hall, Philadelphia, next May 14-17.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 24 -- Some controversy has arisen about Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's address last Thursday to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on External Affairs.
Television viewers over the country were shocked at 12:29 A. M. yesterday when the singing of "Ave Maria" was interrupted by a commercial.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- Pope Pius XII, in his annual Christmas message, gave his support today to proposals for international disarmament based partly on a renunciation of nuclear weapons.

HENRI CARTIER BRESSON is one of the world's most celebrated photographers. When, in mid-1954, the journalistic world heard that he was going to Moscow to turn his lens on the people, there was a stir of excitement. Now, at last, the essence of that dramatic and historic city would be captured by a professional.

Death summoned many sports figures during the year. John (Honus) Wagner, Denton T. (Cy) Young, Clark C. Griffith, Bill Vukovich, William Woodward Jr., Tommy Burns and John F. (Jack) Moakley were among the notables who died.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 -- The provisional Government announced today a campaign against widespread rumor mongering.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Senator Alexander Wiley called today for the appointment of a White House expediter to end what he called the Government's "foot-dragging" in the disposal of farm surpluses.
LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Dec. 24 (UP) -- The Soviet radio broadcast Christmas carols tonight for the first time since the 1917 revolution.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Berlin subway riders, enraged over Communist controls, forced an East sector policeman tonight to take a Christmas Eve journey into the West. He had to use his pistol to escape.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- New York State lost 16,675 farm operators between 1950 and 1954 while the average value of farm land and buildings climbed $3,332 per farm.
HARTFORD, Dec. 24 -- Speculation has arisen about the possible political aims of former Gov. John Davis Lodge, Ambassador to Spain.

Steel production in the Chicago area set a new record during the first eleven months of this year, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Output for the period was 19,774,300 tons compared with 15,858,600 tons in the same period last year.

THE new year will bring, among other things, improved plane schedules for the man who does a lot of commuting on the mainline of mainlines -- the New York-Washington run. Where he now has three airlines to choose from, he soon will have seven.

COOKERY, like any art, is only learned by doing and the sooner one learns the feel of a wooden spoon in a mixing-bowl the easier life will be in this do-it-yourself age. Two of these new books are well calculated to ease youngsters into the kitchen without, tears and with a minimum of confusion.

Even politicians must buy Christmas presents for their families, and there was consequently some abatement -- though not much -- in the will-he-won't-he speculation last week. Three weeks ago, after the President's personal physicians had pronounced him fatigued by his heavy week of high policy and ordered a slow-down, the odds had climbed against his running.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 -- Lorrett Breaux registered his first racing victory by riding Joe W. Brown's Judy Darling to a three-length score today in the $3,000 Yuletide Purse at the Fair Grounds.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department received today the following reports on winter sports conditions:
WITH its current production of Pirandello's "Six Characters in Search of an Author," the Phoenix Theatre is presenting one of its most notable works.

THE richness, decorative power and invention that characterized Matisse's art through so many productive years were in no way diminished at the end of his life when bedridden, he fashioned final visual delights with scissors, paste and bits of colored paper.

THE millions of immigrants from all lands who settled in the United States were determined to become Americans; that was one of the attractions that drew them across the ocean. Yet they were reluctant to sever the ties of family, sentiment and religion that bound them to the lands of their birth.
Brazilians are among the most air-minded people in the world, and their country's role in aviation is expanding rapidly, two leading Latin American airline executives said here yesterday.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN'S mid - eighteenth - century electrical researches, specifically his world-famed kite experiment in 1752, will be recalled when the Post Office Department issues a 3-cent stamp on Jan. 17 for the 250th anniversary of the birth of the great statesman, philosopher and scientist.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The British Labor party will support the Atlantic alliance if elected to office, according to Hugh Gaitskell, the newly chosen party leader.

AMONG some 30,000 patents awarded to Americans in the year just ending, an imaginative few give fresh proof of the inventor's deep interest in the people of the hour -- children. Sometimes the motive is regard for their safety, sometimes a mere desire to keep the little dears amused.
Last-minute Christmas shopping may not be such a bad idea after all.

MONTREAL, Dec. 24 -- The Montreal Canadiens, scoring three goals in the middle period, defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 2, in a hard-fought National Hockey League game before a crowd of 13,373 at the Forum tonight.
Adolf A. Berle Jr.'s article overlooked the one sound and realistic reform that is pending.

THE Wise Men who came to Bethlehem from the East a long, long time ago, probably passing across what is now Jordan and around the northern end of the Dead Sea, were guided by a star. This star, as St. Matthew says, "went before them, till it came and stood over where the young child was."

" MADAME BOVARY," once exclaimed Flaubert, in a sentence often quoted, usually with some surprise by his biographers and critics -- "Madame Bovary, after all, is myself!" At first sight, it appears an astonishing assertion.

WHEN Willy Grier found the drowned man while he was swimming in Lake Michigan that moonless August night he felt like someone who has made a big catch. But it only led to a lot of fussing and talking to the police and publicity in the papers.

THE Huntington Library has presented scholars of our Western history with a bonanza by publishing for the first time five of the diaries of John D. Lee, one of the most picturesque, controversial and able of the Mormon pioneers.

Bank debits for eleven months in the Fifth Federal Reserve District show 13 per cent increased spending by check, compared with the corresponding 1954 period. Outstanding factors have been the construction industry and durable goods gains, contract construction rising 34 per cent in a year.
Saint Xavier College in Chicago has received a grant of $170,000 from the Ford Fund for the Advancement of Education to develop a three-year experimental program in teacher preparation.

THOSE Who view the restrictive McCarran - Walter Immigration Act as merely a temporary phenomenon, unrepresentative of the main stream of American thought, will find little comfort in the pages of this brilliantly executed study of American nativism since the Civil War.

Considerable attention has been given in recent months to the education of the nation's gifted children. The recent report of the Manpower Study Council, sponsored by Columbia University, focused attention on the shortage of trained personnel in this country.

PHOTOGRAPHY is by tradition a realistic medium, George B. Wright declared in a recent talk at the Village Camera Club. To prove his contentions he explored the history of photography as a means of expression, concluding that photography has been strongest and most consistent when it has cultivated the straightforward approach, weakest and "anti-photographic" when sidetracked by imitators of painting.

Ten years ago, when delegates from fifty-one countries were beginning to gather in London for the first session of the United Nations General Assembly, no one could have predicted the ups and downs in store for the United Nations. Although the recent increase in the membership to seventy-six carries unmistakable implications, it is just as risky now as it was then to predict what will happen in the organization's next ten years.

THE A. F. L.-C. I. O. hotel employes union chose the busiest season of the year in Miami Beach to renew its organizing campaign at oceanfront hotels. At 6 last Wednesday morning, when the beach area was building rapidly up to a fantastically big Christmas-New Year holiday peak, twenty pickets appeared outside the 565-room Fontainebleau Hotel.

LILLE, France, Dec. 23 -- At 6:45 o'clock every morning in a hotel in Dunkirk, former Premier Paul Reynaud, 77 years old, starts his fifteen minutes of physical culture. A little later he is off for a day-long round of campaign speeches that would exhaust a man half his age.

A PICTURE story of a boy's adventures on Monhegan Island off the coast of Maine is the theme of a special Christmas exhibit by Yolla Niclas in Education Hall at the American Museum of Natural History.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A decade ago United States troops fought the last bloody battles of World War II here on Okinawa in a campaign that brought final disaster for Japan.

Better maternity care the world over will be furthered as a result of the annual theatre party of the Maternity Center Association. Chosen for the benefit is the Jan. 4 performance of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "Pipe Dream" at the Shubert Theatre.
When "Robert X," a seaman on a merchant vessel, was put in touch with his sister in Rochester, N. Y., it marked the end of a separation that began in Latvia twenty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Justice Department officials and Hilton hotel representatives are discussing a possible out-of-court settlement of the antitrust case against the hotel chain.

WHAT a gulf between impression and expression: That's our ironic fate -- to have Shakespearean feelings and (unless by some billon-to-one chance we happen to be Shakespeare) to talk about them like automobile salesmen or teenagers or college professors.

Renville H. McMann of New York has been nominated president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1956. The nominations of McMann and other officials will be voted on at the annual meeting of the association on Jan. 21 in San Francisco.

This is a day when many of us will bow our heads in gratitude for the blessings of life, and among these the kindness of friends. This morning, as is customary on Christmas Day, we close our editorial page appeal for The Times Neediest Cases Fund with a note of appreciation for the many gifts, large and small, made to the unfortunate of our city.

Promptly at 9:45 o'clock on Tuesday morning, a housewife from Hempstead, a model from Montclair and a stenographer from Stuyvesant Town will appear at the Thirty-fourth Street entrance of Macy's department store.

IN this highly readable if more than slightly misleading book, Mr. Stern writes with considerable force and charm about Eugene Marcus, whose position in the musical comedy world is analogous to that held by George Gershwin (his real-life career, indeed, closely parallels that of Marcus).

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The Soviet Union is continuing to cultivate Iran's friendship despite Teheran's accession to the Baghdad Pact. Mohammed Riza Shah Pahlevi will make a state visit here some time next year despite recent Soviet protests against Iran's membership in the Baghdad entente.
Those spry little motor scooters that swarmed over Italy and other parts of Europe to become postwar symbols of revived energy and prosperity are looking for new roads to travel.
ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- What are the British forces up against in Cyprus?

WHAT time could be more propitious for citing the year's best films than Christmas Day in the morning -- which happens to be right now! And so, in the spirit of the season, we leap to the pleasant task of presenting our careful selections of the top films of 1955.

" MARIA and Miranda, aged 12 and 8 years, knew they were young, though they felt they had lived a long time. They had lived not only their own years; but their memories, it seemed to them, began years before they were born, in the lives of the grownups around them, old people above 40, most of them, who had a way of insisting that they too had been young once."

PROBABLY the most seen and least noticed item on television today is the "crawl." This is the list of credits for actors and technicians who appeared on a telecast, which either races or creeps past the viewer's eye, depending on the exigencies of time.

For the first time full competition has come to the color photography industry. The likely result: increased sales and profits for all concerned. Until last year the Eastman Kodak Company had retained exclusive rights to process the Kodacolor and Kodachrome color film which it had developed.

New Yorkers may dislike cold weather but the hearty Maine potato growers hope for further drops in the temperature. The declining thermometer has increased potato consumption and has helped raise prices.
The offshore queen of what may have been the greatest year for distance yacht racing was Richard S. Nye's 53-foot Rhodes-designed centerboard yawl, Carina.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Corn is still the nation's most valuable crop, the Agriculture Department reported today.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings and the Toronto Maple Leafs fought to a 1-1 National Hockey League tie tonight on first-period goals by Toronto's Earl Balfour and Detroit's Red Kelly. The game attracted a crowd of 12,011.
In humility before the Prince of Peace and in Christmas rejoicing, millions of Christians rediscovered yesterday an oasis of happiness in a threatened world.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Fort Wayne Pistons staged a 30-point third period to break up a tight ball game and defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 92 -- 87, in a National Basketball Association contest before 4,699 tonight.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A South Korean Coast Guard boat and one or more Chinese Communist gunboats traded gunfire yesterday in Yellow Sea waters patrolled by United States and South Korean warships, Korean sources said.

The Taxpayer Assistance Program, formerly conducted at the Custom House to provide guidance in filing income tax returns, will be moved next week to the Lower Manhattan Audit Division's headquarters on the second floor at 80 Lafayette Street.

For the young man and woman who is eager to taste bravery "short of being shot or blown through the air at 600 miles an hour," Robert Frost offered this piece of advice yesterday: Try one of the arts -- particularly poetry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Defense Department officials voiced the belief today that a greater proportion of service absentees would vote in next year's Presidential election than in any previous election.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- Bankers and brokers were at pains last week to convince clients who had expected the boom to go on forever that those long-term investors who followed the sound advice of experts are finishing 1955 far better off than they were a year ago.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- Pope Pius XII made a brief appearance today to impart his Apostolic blessing to a large crowd. Then for a short time the spiritual head of Roman Catholics throughout the world became just another Roman celebrating Christmas with his family.

THERE live and toll in and around New York between 400 and 500 nuns of a 165-year-old sisterhood that is extraordinary. SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (UP) -- An exhibition golf tournament for northern California flood relief was proposed today by the National Open champion, Jack Fleck.

ALTHOUGH the sources of literary inspiration are often mysterious they are almost as often perfectly obvious. Writers are wonderfully addicted to writing about themselves, particularly about themselves when they were young. And, after that eternally fascinating subject has been exhausted, they frequently write about their friends, enemies and mere acquaintances.
For the patient in a veterans' hospital who is alone, sick and far from home Christmas is a dreary day.
Jacob K. Javits will be the first guest on a new WRCA-TV program featuring New York State officials.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 25 -- It might have been a Christmas story by O. Henry. John W. Branton, a 43-year-old escaped prisoner, cast himself as the leading character.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The only exuberance displayed in the Stock Exchange in the past week has been that of personal high spirits which its members invariably give vent to at this festive season.

Pope Pius XII dealt in the course of his Christmas broadcast with a subject that would have been incomprehensible to his predecessors: the menace of the nuclear weapon to civilization and to human life itself. Of necessity, he spoke as the head of a church and a faith.

When the roster of the reorganized British Cabinet was made public last week observers on this side of the Atlantic were prompted to wonder why such medieval heritages as the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, the Lord President of the Council and the Lord Privy Seal are retained as Cabinet positions in a twentieth-century state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Representative E. Y. Berry. Republican of South Dakota. said today failure to raise support prices on next year's crops would mean "political suicide" for Republicans and "economic suicide" for farmers.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 25 -- Osten Unden, Sweden's 'Foreign Minister, proposed today that the United States, Britain and France agree to the reunification of Germany as a neutral state. He said this should be the basis of a "fresh start" of talks with the Soviet Union on the unification issue.

Resting his weary feet aboard a Europe-bound liner is Capt. Avner Freudenberg, marine superintendent of the Zim Israel America Line. The week before Christmas he tramped the sidewalks of New York to check on what had happened to the street cars and the Lackawanna Ferry he used to take from Twenty- third Street.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer urged the German people today to have faith and patience to overcome the dangers he said were facing humanity.

I have followed, with respect, the doughty, singlehanded campaign for better postal services as conducted in your columns by H. W. Hart; but I must differ with the writer when he attacks the use of murals in post offices.

Factory sales of television receivers, radios, radar and military electronic equipment will hit a record $5,500,000,000 this year, according to H. Leslie Hoffman, president of the Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturers Association.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Wide swings have been the rule in grain and soybean futures, but except for higher prices for soybeans there has been no big change in the price level. The belief that eventually the Government will create a more cheerful farm picture has created demand on the setbacks, especially for wheat and corn. This has made for a two-sided market.
Your editorial "A Minute of Silence'' in the Dec. 21 edition of The Times was read with deep interest and appreciation. The other half of the Moment of Silence is the U. N. Meditation Room.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian sector), Dec. 25 -- Political leaders who are said to have sparked the recent anti-Western violence throughout Jordon met today in Amman to map strategy for pushing through their demands.

"DANCE LITTLE LADY," the British import that arrived at the Globe on Christmas Day, has the virtues and faults of many holiday gifts. The color, the music and terpsichore of excerpts from "Swan Lake" and "Giselle" and the delightful talents of the child star Mandy Miller and Mai Zetterling are genuinely fascinating offerings worthy of appreciation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 25 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Pakistani officials today that all of their demands for increased military equipment under the United States military aid agreement could not be met.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Panthers, with just a week to get used to the warm southern climate, are scheduled to come to New Orleans tomorrow to resume training for their Jan. 2 Sugar Bowl game with Georgia Tech.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 23 - Demands have been made for a reorientation of the Government's policies. The question has arisen in the wake of last Sunday's nation-wide elections, in which a new Congress and municipal officials, the first under the regime of President Carlos Castillo Armas, were chosen.

Lily Pons, the popular coloratura soprano, will be honored at the Metropolitan Opera Tuesday evening, Jan. 3. A gala performance will be given in commemoration of her debut at the Metropolitan twenty-five years previously.

The Azuma Kabuki Dancers and Musicians of Tokyo will open their second New York engagement at the Broadway Theatre tonight. As on their previous visit last year, they are being presented by S. Hurok, with the cooperation of Prince Takamatsu, brother of the Emperor of Japan, and the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

ABOARD U. S. S. EDISTO, in McMurdo Sound, Dec. 24 -- Six Navy men were dramatically rescued during an Antarctic blizzard this Christmas Eve after they had been trapped in two tents for fifteen hours by the storm.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 25 -- The Royal Netherlands Blast Furnaces and Steelworks has announced a big expansion program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The United States Bureau of Mines, which pioneered the development of zirconium, announced today it has stopped producing the strategic metal and handed the job over to private industry.
Fourteen Unitarian clergymen formally presented yesterday their views on the controversial report regarding the teaching of moral and spiritual values in the public schools.

"The Buried People: A Study of the Etruscan World," by Sibylle von Cles-Reden, the archaeologist, has been scheduled for Jan. 30 publication by Scribners. Translated by C. M. Woodhouse from the German, the volume gives the story of the vanished people that for nearly 400 years, until the rise of Rome in the fifth century B. C., exercised power over Central Italy and the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Interior Department announced today that 413 farm units on five Reclamation Bureau projects would be opened for homesteading and sale in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The National Committee for an Effective Congress declared today that President Eisenhower's illness had given the "radical right" an opportunity for a political comeback.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Millions of American motorists are scheduled to get the full picture of the business practices that lie behind their buying of new or used cars.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The defending Cleveland Browns today remained a close favorite to defeat the Los Angeles Rams and retain the National Football League championship tomorrow in Memorial Coliseum.

To beat the Canadiens of Montreal by the score of 5 to 1 is no mean achievement. The New York Rangers did that at Madison Square Garden last night. And in so doing, the Broadway Blues showed why they are one of the powers in the National Hockey League.
TIZI OUZOU, Algeria, Dec. 25 -- The nationalist rebellion appears to he gaining strength in the rugged and densely populated Kabylia Mountains east of Algiers.

A tract of 500 acres has been opened for development as a residential and vacation community on the former De Gray White estate at Lake Neepaulin in Sussex County, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- South Korea faces economic disaster unless the United States or other Western nations come to its aid soon, a report published by the National Planning Association declared today.

Russia's parliament, the Supreme Soviet, is scheduled to open its third session of 1955 today. For veteran members of that body this year's activity must seem unusual and strenuous indeed. In past years the Supreme Soviet has normally met decorously for a week or so once a year, and hibernated the rest of the time.

Saturday evening's performance of "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" at the Metropolitan Opera presented two singers not previously seen in the work here this season. Laurel Hurley, as Olympia, undertook the role for the first time in her Metropolitan career.
Next Thursday is the day on alumni of St. Mark's and The alumni of St. Mark's and the Hill School will move in on Madison Square Garden for the big hockey game between the two schools.

Miss Charlotte Joy Minsky, daughter of Mrs. Henry Minsky of 960 Park Avenue and the late Dr. Minsky, ophthalmologist, was married in her home here yesterday afternoon to Jean-Claude Porson. The Rev. Dr. Charles E. Shulman performed the ceremony.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy cited 265 members of the department yesterday for meritorious service.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Cannibalism among snails is being encouraged by University of California scientists as a move against a widespread horticultural problem.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 (UP) -- Michigan State will open its final week of practice for the Jan. 2 Rose Bowl game with a two-hour drill tomorrow morning.
Following is a digest of the laws in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York governing absentee voting:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Exclusive hunting is under way in Yellowstone National Park to save elk.
MIAMI, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Orange Bowl regatta begins tomorrow with a 24-mile race around the island of Miami Beach.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 25 -- The men of Laos, some in traditional tribal finery, went to the polls this hot sunny Christmas Day to elect a new National Assembly. Their Communist-led compatriots boycotted the proceedings after having urged the rest of the country to do likewise.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 -- The sun shone on large sections of flooded northern California today as rampaging rivers receded. Some refugees went back to their mud and silt plastered homes.

NOW that the Great Day has come and gone, many a parent would be delighted to forget festivity for a while and concentrate on getting back to normal. Not so the youngsters in many households, however. For them the party spirit still flames high.

Three and two-story buildings on lot 25 x 100 feet at 1359 First Avenue, southwest corner of East Seventy-third Street, were bought by Benjamin J. Frost for investment from a client of Walter Scott Co. The property is assessed at $40,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $32,000.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- The Soviet newspaper reader is learning things about the United States these days that he could only guess at for many years.

Cotton prices in the domestic market were irregular last week, but ended in moderately higher ground. At the close on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 5 to 31 points from the close of the previous week.
Brookhattan-Galicia crushed the Danish eleven of the National League, 6 to 0, yesterday at Zerega Oval, the Bronx.

Our foreign aid program, it is now stated, is sufficiently flexible to permit increased efforts in the Asian area. This policy is designed in part, of course, to offset the recent Soviet economic plans and promises, which, in our view, have some sinister overtones.
There can be no neutrality regarding Christ, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday in his Christmas sermon at Riverside Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- H. Brian Holland, Assistant Attorney General, reported today that more persons had been convicted of income tax fraud in the three years of the Eisenhower Administration than in the last four years of the Truman regime.
A festive Christmas Day closed last night with the chilling probability that the number of weekend deaths in highway accidents over the country would reach a new high.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Ten years after World War II The American Red Cross still devotes 40 per cent of its budgeted funds for services to members of the armed forces and veterans.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Members of the Supreme Soviet mirrored the new line of Moscow's foreign policy today, glorifying the ties between the Soviet Union and its new Asian allies.

PANAMA, Dec. 25 -- Ships using the Panama Canal today are under orders to expose no open flame in the south end of Gaillard Cut or at Miraflores Locks. The order included a ban on smoking by crewmen, locks operators and guards.

The four-story garden-type apartment house at 48-52 South Second Avenue in Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been sold by the Mara Operating Corporation to the Judwin Realty Corporation. The sale was subject to mortgages of $100,000, according to Schiffman Goldkopf, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25(AP) -- Pentagon officials said that two-thirds of the leading twelve or fifteen aircraft companies already held primary contracts in the rapidly expanding missile weapon program.
A 73-year-old man died early yesterday as a result of a rooming house fire on the Lower East Side. His 84-year-old neighbor was treated for injuries suffered in trying to rescue the victim.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25 -- Unlike most years at this time, steel demand and production were hurtling to new peaks last week. The momentum of the heavy drive for steel will carry the industry far into the new year at capacity operations. Even then there is no assurance that such a production rate will make any dent in large backlogs among steel producers.

The decision of District Judge D. W. Bartlett in Waco, Tex., to allow the televising of a murder trial has again raised the vexing problem of accommodating the individual's right of due process with the public's right to adequate information.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The East German and Chinese Premiers issued a joint communique yesterday attacking the United States' "bankrupt policy of strength," the Peiping radio reported today.
Among the spectators at the fights tonight in St. Nicholas Arena on Sixty-sixth Street just off Columbus Avenue, will be a tall, thin, well-groomed man who counts his years somewhere in the eighties.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that India was determined to follow an independent foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Stanley N. Barnes, who runs the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department, is being deluged with letters asking why he did not stop the merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 -- Substantial absenteeism and low labor productivity in Rumania's industries were acknowledged by her highest officials over the week-end.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 -- Within the walls of the United States Embassy compound in Kabul, Alghanistan, a loudspeaker was blaring Christmas carols. The people in the United States Information Service office were playing the records good and loud, loud enough for the gentlemen across the street to hear.

LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Dec. 25 -- The "Porgy and Bess" company, believed to be the first American theatrical troupe to appear in Russia, will open its Soviet engagement tomorrow night before a selected audience of 2,200 persons at the Leningrad Palace of Culture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that United States corporations this year have set aside a record amount of money to cover depreciation of plant and equipment and to pay off debts.
MONTROSE, N. Y., Dec. 25 -- Conservationists are attempting to convert a Hudson River tidal marsh of 130 acres here into a permanent wild life sanctuary.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The increase in the gold reserves of the Bank of France, announced last Thursday, brings the reserve figure to its highest point in ten years.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe's headquarters said today United States forces in Europe soon would pack more firepower per man than any other force ever put in the field.
The drama of the Nativity was made real again yesterday as churchgoers over the city heard their pastors bring the Christmas scene of nearly 2,000 years ago into the context of the twentieth century.

The team to beat in the fourth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival, basketball event, which opens with a matinee double-header at Madison Square Garden today is, obviously, San Francisco. Whether La Salle of Philadelphia, having drawn the powerful and top-seeded Dons as first-round opponents, is equipped to spring an upset is the question that will be answered this afternoon.
PECK PECK got to Palm Beach in 1916, when ladies were still wearing bathing stockings.
A Christmas Day congregation was welcomed at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as "shepherds" in the eternal drama of the Nativity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A lagging movement to put hundreds of special Federal services on a cafeteria-style or "pay-for-what-you-get" basis is being re-examined quietly here with a view to putting new life into it.
Christmas Day in New York was mild and sunny. Even so it might have looked bleak to thousands of persons, down on their luck, if public and private welfare agencies had not provided for them.

ATLANTA, Dec. 26 -- Several thousand United States scientists gathered today for the opening of the traditional year-end meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -- History Book from Barry Richards' stable won the $23,000 Palos Verdes Handicap as Santa Anita opened its nineteenth winter meeting today with a crowd of 62,000 on hand.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 26 -Heavy armaments of the Arab states will be more than doubled within a year, mainly through deliveries to Cairo from the Soviet bloc, according to authoritative Israeli sources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that cigarette consumption in this country increased from 1954 to 1955 and predicted it would continue to make gradual gains next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Most major industries in the United States will continue operating at or close to peak levels through the first half of 1956, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks declared today.

FOR the first time in nineteen years the University of Pittsburgh will be represented in a bowl football game when Pitt faces Georgia Tech in the Sugar Bowl on Monday. This fact has been generally overlooked as a result of the furor caused by the protest of the Governor of Georgia against Pitt's use of a Negro on its squad.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 27 -- A running fight in the Yellow Sea Sunday between a South Korean Coast Guard cutter and several Communist Chinese vessels brought warlike threats today from the capitals of both countries.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 26 (UP) -- French authorities announced today that a volunteer native patrol had disappeared in the mountains where rebels hide out between Algeria and Morocco.

When Michael Quill succeeded, with the help of the city administration, in extorting a whopping increase in wages for the best-paid bus drivers in the country, it was a foregone conclusion that the people of New York City would be called upon by the same city administration to foot the bill.
This year's booming business level probably will be exceeded next year, according to the results of an annual survey announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

The National Planning Association has issued a report on the need for prompt economic aid to Korea based on a first-hand study by one of its economists. The situation is serious, he states, and unless the United States takes effective action there is imminent danger of a general economic collapse in the Republic of Korea.

New Year's Eve merrymaking in Times Square will be tempered with stern warnings on highway safety. From five huge traveling signs and three painted billboards ringing the square the multitudes of merrymakers will see slogans and other reminders that "Reckless Driving Is Kid Stuff."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns trounced the Los Angeles Rams today as Otto Graham led the way to a 38-14 victory for the Browns' second straight National Football League championship.
THE alibi plays an important role in all participation sports, but no sport offers a greater opportunity for the elaborate excuse than shooting.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 26 -- The Federation of Malaya has set Aug. 31, 1957, as the target date for self-government.
ABOARD U. S. S. EDISTO, in McMurdo Sound, Dec. 25 -- To the delight of United States Navy men and a dozen or two penguins, Santa Claus got badly mixed up on his poles this Christmas Day.
Resistance by Manhattan savings banks to a 3 per cent dividend on savings was weakened somewhat by an announcement released yesterday by The Bank for Savings, 280 Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley's stepdaughter and his grandson were married today. The bride was Jane Hadley, 21 years old, Mrs. Barkley's daughter by a former marriage. The bride groom was Cpl. Thomas H. Truitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max O'Rell Truitt.
Track fans can get some first-class entertainment free at Columbia University's South Field Friday morning at 10:30 and may see a record performance to boot.
A television war between state Republican leaders and Governor Harriman will open the New Year, with the Governor so far in position to get in the most licks.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (AP) -Bob Ikerd, an Islamorada (Fla.) charter-boat fisherman, won the twenty-four-mile 'Round Miami Beach Marathon speedboat race today. He averaged sixty-five miles per hour to set a new record for the race.

Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen said yesterday that plans for the Morningside Health Center would be filed tomorrow with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Harry M. Prince, the architect.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 26 (AP) -- The nation's railroads earned an estimated $10,100,000,000 this year, mostly by carrying freight, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
Two Harvard players scored victories yesterday in the first round of the Intercollegiate Chess League's biennial tournament at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- Expenditures on the Soviet armed forces will be reduced 8.5 per cent next year, the Government announced today. It said the money saved would be allocated to developing the national economy and providing educational facilities.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Manchester United's high-scoring team today trounced Charlton Athletic, 5 -- 1, to maintain its three-point lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- A new postwar record in shipbuilding has been rung up on the Clydeside during the last twelve months.

The number and dollar volume of open market sales of Manhattan realty during the third quarter of 1955 exceeded that of any corresponding period of the last five years, according to a survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh's football team didn't waste any time today in resuming practice for next Monday's Sugar Bowl game with Georgia Tech.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 26 -- Ninety organizations will join the West Coast Inland Navigation District in petitioning Congress for $6,500,000 to extend the Intracoastal Waterway from Fort Myers to Tarpon Springs along Florida's West Coast.
The site is almost cleared for the eighteen-story office building planned for the east block-front on Second Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets.
The Atlas Corporation has named David A. Stretch as executive vice president and Edward R. Farley Jr. as a vice president, Floyd B. Odlum, president, has announced.

A new office building is being constructed in Elizabeth, N. J., for a group of mutual funds whose aggregate assets of well over $333,000,000 places it as one of New Jersey's largest financial institutions.
That protean fellow, Santa Claus, showed up in many guises again yesterday, as he has for some weeks now.

Soviet Finance Minister Zverev set a post-war precedent in Moscow yesterday when he presented the 1956 budget to the Supreme Soviet. The notion that the budget for a calendar year should be submitted and approved before that year begins may seem elementary to Western minds.

BUTTER is that invaluable ingredient, often not apparent to the eye, that makes a good dish better. But knowing enough to use it in cooking is not the same as knowing how. Butter smokes readily, spatters, seems to burn in a second. Why bother with butter, the novice may sometimes wonder, when other fats, though less flavorable, also are less messy?

The United States Civil Service Commission opposes the proposed thirty-year retirement bill for Federal employes on the ground that it will cost the Government an additional $37,000,000 annually. At the same time a House Post Office and Civil Service subcommittee demands an over-all 10 per cent across the board lay-off of Federal personnel.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- John Fell Stevenson's shattered right knee-cap was removed today in a two-hour, fifteen-minute operation.

ATHENS, Dec. 26 -- General elections are set for Feb. 26, a reliable Greek Government source revealed today. If any postponement takes place it will be "for purely technical reasons," the source added.
CAIRO, Dec. 26 -- The Egyptian Foreign Ministry issued the following communique today:
EUREKA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Two Indian brothers were credited today with saving thirty- three persons from the raging Klamath River after most of their town, Klamath, had been swept away.

MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- George Welsh, Navy's brilliant quarterback, easily surpassed West Virginia's Freddy Wyant in a daring aerial duel tonight as the South whipped the North, 20 -- 7, in the Shrine's annual college All-Star football game in the Orange Bowl.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- The colorful story of the American "Stock Exchange has been dramatized in a short movie called "Behind the Ticker Tape." It tells the story of the exchange from its founding as the Curb Exchange in 1849, when its business was conducted on the sidewalks in New York's financial district.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- California's flood waters, swelling from fresh rains, surged again tonight on stricken Yuba City, 120 miles northeast of here. They were expected to reflood the town early tomorrow morning.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Otto Graham bowed out as football player in a blaze of glory, today after seventeen seasons. He won acclaim from Coach Paul Brown of Cleveland as "the greatest quarterback ever to play in that spot."

AT matinees for the rest of the week, Bil and Cora Baird's marionettes will put on their show at the Phoenix, where they opened yesterday. There will be performances at 1 and at 3:30, except on Saturday, when there will be only the performance at 1 o'clock.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A record crowd for a racing program at Tropical Park -- 20,634 -- got an unexpected thrill today when Marked Game, a Florida-bred, won the $11,450 Christmas Handicap.
ROME, Dec. 26 -- Premier Antonio Segni's Cabinet is facing its most critical challenge since it was formed six months ago.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Premier Edgar Faure and former Premier Pierre Mendes-France, two leading opponents in the present electoral campaign, termed Algeria today the most urgent problem for the next National Assembly and Government.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26 -- Harvard Divinity School stands today on the threshold of a longcherished goal.
Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States chess champion, played his sixth draw in seven matches last night in the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Those companies whose assets were frozen were dropped as of today from Argentine stock market listings.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 26 -- The Danish motor vessel Kista Dan has just completed the annual relief of the Australian Antarctic station at Macquarie Island. She will leave Melbourne tomorrow with nineteen men to relieve fifteen men who have been at the Mawson Australian station on the Antarctic mainland for the last twelve months.
Mr. and Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt were hosts at a supper dance last evening for their debutante granddaughter. Miss Giulia Roosevelt. The fete was held in the St. Regis Roof.
The entire film library of a major Hollywood motion picture studio has been sold for television distribution at a price of $15,200,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The Committee for Educational TV reported today that educational television expanded in 1955 the number of its broadcasting stations from eight to eighteen.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Reports about the "atrocious state" of wild life in several African game parks under British control are to be investigated unofficially by a party of conservationists from the United States early next year.
The fare on the major routes operated by private bus companies will rise Sunday from 13 to 15 cents a ride.

Duquesne, the defending champion in the fourth annual Holiday Festival basketball event, needed a last-gasp field goal by Sihugo Green to draw even with Fordham last night at Madison Square Garden. Then the Brooklyn-reared stylist netted all 7 points for his team in the overtime period as the Dukes from Pittsburgh downed the Rams, 73 -- 70.
Thirty fire companies and two fire boats put a deep freeze yesterday on a fire that started before daylight in a Brooklyn lumber yard.

The number of New Yorkers who received public assistance dropped to 275,774 in November. This was a reduction of 2,312 cases, compared with the October figure, Acting Welfare Commissioner Crystal M. Potter reported yesterday.

Your pungent editorial of Nov. 23 entitled "No Helicopters Wanted?" fell on deaf ears, for the Mayor still allows his Commissioner of Marine and Aviation to stymie the construction of a much-needed temporary heliport at the foot of West Thirtieth Street, Manhattan -- a site over which there is no dispute.

Everybody knows that New York is a changing city. In the memory of many New Yorkers it has passed since 1900 through three transformations before it became the city we know today. It is the business of the Museum of the City of New York to keep a record of the past and bring back a lively image of significant periods.
CAIRO, Dec. 26 -- Saudi Arabia placed its forces with those of Egypt and Syria under one commander today.
The six-story store and apartment building at 485-487 Third Avenue and 200-202 East Thirty-third Street has been sold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to Leon and Morton Lane and Milton Sass.
Ernest Borgnine and Jennifer Jones have been voted the best actor and actress of 1955 in an annual poll of film critics conducted by The Film Daily.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 -- A woman's "smoldering hope" and the success story of an East Indian immigrant are converging into what is likely to be one of the most colorful Congressional contests of 1956.
MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Nashua, the million-dollar horse, was as playful as a kid out of school when he returned to the race track for a workout today.

HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- Cuban sugar workers went on strike today in an attempt to enforce their demand for additional wages during the harvest of the 1955 crop. At the same time workers in all ports refused to load sugar for export.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Noting that 1955 marked the completion of ten-year tests of fluoridation of drinking water in three North American cities, The Journal of the American Dental Association quoted four dental authorities this week-end on the effectiveness of fluoridation as a tooth-decay resistant.

Donna Fox of Larchmont, N. Y., is the former official United States delegate to the International Bobsled Federation according to the National Amateur Athletic Union, but the current delegate according to himself.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Dollars flowed out from the United States to foreign countries in record amounts in the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- Twenty-five observers covered this area today for the Rockland Audubon Society as part of the national bird count.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Casey Stengel, the New York Yankee manager, visited London tonight for the first time in thirty-one years and said he found the people unchanged.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 26 (AP) -- President Alfredo Stroessner's Cabinet has accepted the resignation of Epifanio Mendez Fleitas as president of the Paraguayan Central Bank, Asuncion newspapers reported today.
THE dream of many New Yorkers -- modernizing a brownstone -- has been realized by a young man with more energy than the law governing human fatigue usually allows.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 26 -- Announcement has been made by Nathan Richardson Allen of Greenwich and Mrs. Norman Williston Osher of Milwaukee, Wis., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancie Brown Allen, to Herbert William Marache Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marache of Scarsdale, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that its 1956 survey of consumer spending and saving plans would begin next month in the twelve largest metropolitan areas and fifty-four smaller communities.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson has announced his intention to dump a million or two bales of cotton on the world market. This news has everyone worried in this cotton-producing country and elsewhere in Latin America where cotton is produced in large quantities and where it accounts for a considerable percentage of dollar-producing exports.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 25 -- Bright prospects for the South African economy have been predicted by Dr. F. J. du Toit, chairman of the Council for the Development of Natural Resources.
The men's clothing industry operated at 83 per cent of capacity in November, compared with 76 per cent in the 1954 month, according to the Clothing Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- Presidential campaign strategy moved forward on both the Republican and Democratic fronts in California last week.
I read your editorial of Dec. 21 on the Dominican Fair With much interest. It is a source of gratification that you put the Generalissimo in a truer light than heretofore.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 -- The provisional Government froze today the Argentine assets of ninety-seven more companies, including an affiliate of the Henry J. Kaiser enterprises.

Three four-story apartment houses accommodating sixty-six families at 148-152 Parkside Avenue and 5 St. Pauls Place in Brooklyn have been sold by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York to the Biswald Realty Corporation represented by Stuart Miller, attorney.

After rejecting a detailed seventeen-point program for lifting the Iron Curtain, submitted by the Western powers at Geneva, the Soviets have now consented to open at least one little chink in the barrier that imprisons their people by agreeing to one point in the Western plan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Democratic majority of a House subcommittee charged today that increasing corporate and bank mergers were killing free competition and leading to dangerous monopoly.
The city school system is making a special effort to answer some of the questions parents raise about the school program.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis offered new evidence yesterday of the effectiveness of the Salk vaccine in preventing poliomyelitis.
Josef Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary was described yesterday as "a living indictment of Communist regimes everywhere."

HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, declared today that a "better than expected" enlistment rate indicated the Navy would need to draft less than half the men it had thought it would between now and next June.

The chairman of the board of directors of the American Chemical Society for 1956 will be Dr. Ralph A. Connor, vice president in charge of research for Rohm and Haas Company of Philadelphia. He succeeds Dr. Ernest H. Volwiler, chairman for the past two years.
MILAN, Italy, Dec. 26 -- A miniature La Scala Opera House came into being in Milan tonight. Its purpose is to uphold the same high musical ideals as its larger, older and more famous counterpart.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 12 -- Dark-skinned students from lands long held in distrust here are doing a remarkable job of breaking down some old Australian prejudices, according to accounts from the University of Melbourne.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Five demonstrators were killed and three injured by police rifle fire during anti-tax riots in this British West African colony during the Christmas period, it was officially announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- From coast to coast and by land sea and air, the annual count of migratory waterfowl will begin Jan. 3.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Wendell B. Barnes, Small Business Administrator, predicted today that 1956 will see a further rise in earnings by small manufacturers.
The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday its sales of products and services for this year would exceed $1,000,000,000, to set a record high for the company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson today called for Congressional approval of a Government-supported insurance plan to help provide medical care for dependents of service men.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru described Indian Communists today as reactionaries clinging to outmoded and outdated theories.
Yama Bahama, a fast-punching welterweight from Bimini, the Bahamas, gained an easy victory over Paola Melis of Montreal in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Judge David W. Peck of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court spoke for an increasing number of thoughtful citizens, in Sunday's New York Times Magazine, when he raised the question: "Do juries delay Justice?" And he challenged public attention when he answered "yes."
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Heavy week-end rains put large areas of southwestern Oregon under water again. The Coquille River repeated its rampage of last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Post Office Department announced today ten additional new postage issues for 1956, making a total of seventeen scheduled for next year.

WILTON, Conn., Dec. 26 -- A beautiful old fourteen-room house was razed by fire here early today. Its ten occupants were saved because the family dog woke them, put the dog died because it rushed back into the house apparently to make sure that its favorite little girl was not in it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower discussed world affairs for seventy minutes today with John Foster Dulles, his Secretary of State.

LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Dec. 26 -- The traveling company of "Porgy and Bess," which has captured the hearts of audiences all over Europe and Latin America in the last four years, opened tonight its peaceful assault on the Soviet Union. It scored a moderate success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The United States could intern 5,000 spies and saboteurs almost immediately in the event of war, an invasion or an insurrection. Thousands more could be put in detention camps as fast as they were rounded up.

"PROFILES IN COURAGE," a new book by John F. Kennedy, United States Senator from Massachusetts, will be published Monday by Harper. It is an account of the courage and patriotism of "a handful" of Americans who at crucial moments in history had revealed greatness.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- Gen. Chu Teh, Vice Chairman of the Chinese Communist Government, asserted in Bucharest today that world tension had eased, thanks to the Soviet Union.

ANYONE who reads much fiction -- good fiction, that is -- must pause occasionally to regret that he is neither as observant nor as perceptive as the authors he finds most rewarding. In novels and short stories the commonplace is often illuminated with significance; a trivial episode or a snatch of uninspired conversation suddenly acquires meaning.
Lighted nightsticks and white reflector belts may become standard equipment for policemen on traffic duty or those on duty at the scene of accidents.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A fire destroyed St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church early today, toppling a 200-foot steeple. Damage was estimated at $500,000.

The number of "dependents" per 100 "producers" in the United States rose from sixty to seventy-three between 1940 and 1955, according to a population analysis by the National Industrial Conference Board.
IN Army posts, camps and stations across the nation, officers of the Judge Advocate General's Department have reasons this morning to glower and fume.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 22 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Wisconsin Republican, has launched a fence-mending campaign. His success has confounded his critics and has caused a previously hostile state G. O. P. organization to reconsider plans to block his drive for a fourth term.
Almost everyone agrees that basketball has become a game strictly for tall athletes. Still there are some persons who would disagree with that "truism."
A sharp increase in production of titanium metal products in 1956 to meet a fast-rising demand was forecast yesterday by the spokesman for a leading producer.
PLAINEDGE, L. I., Dec. 26 -- Sixty college-trained parents here are studying nights to become substitute teachers in the district's public schools.
On the day after Christmas, the grand total for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached $359,623.05, given to the forty-fourth annual appeal by 8,656 donors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The booming aircraft industry expects its volume of sales next year again will pass the $8,000,000,000 level.

Thirteen persons were injured early today when a crowded New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad train jerked to a sudden stop at Pennsylvania Station. They were treated at St. Vincent's Hospital. None was reported seriously hurt.
Santa Claus still exists in the hearts, minds and books of those who make up the local charter industry.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The auto industry apparently abandoned its chance for an 8,000,000-car-production total this year when the "big three" reduced output last week.

THE Azuma Kabuki Dancers and Musicians from Tokyo returned to the Broadway Theatre last night for their second New York season. They made it quite clear that the success of their first visit last year was neither an illusion nor an accident. They have very definitely done it again.
Mayor Wagner's vast West Side rehabilitation project has run into unexpected opposition to some of its phases. This has come from within the circle of the Mayor's own expert advisers.

A musical adaptation of "The Innocents Abroad," Mark Twain's satirical account of American tourists in Europe and the Near East during the late Eighteen Sixties, is headed for the Broadway stage. The adaptation was completed recently by Melchior Lengyel, whose movie, "Ninotchka," provided the story line for the musical "Silk Stockings."
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 26 -- Segregation will continue to be the main problem facing the new Mississippi Legislature, which convenes here Jan. 3.

Newspaper advertising linage for the full year 1955 will show a good-size advance over the 1954 volume. This conclusion is obtained from a study of figures compiled by Media Records of linage for November and for eleven months of 1955 in fifty-two cities.

One hundred fifty rabbis and religious educators attended yesterday the first session of the convention of the National Association of Temple Educators at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street.

More persons were killed on the nation's highways this Christmas holiday than on any previous week-end. Safety officials spoke of a "Black Christmas" as they saw the traffic toll climb to 577 at 2:45 A. M. today. Late reports were expected to push the figure still higher. The number of deaths surpassed the record of 556 set over the Christmas week-end in 1952, when the holiday extended to four days.

JAMES REYNOLDS, a learned, aristocratic and romantically minded Irishman, writes and illustrates books so fast no single publisher can keep up with them. Just reading their titles provides the key to Mr. Reynolds' principal interests, which are four: travel ("Fabulous Spain" and "Pageant of Italy"), horses ("World of Horses"), ghosts ("Ghosts in Irish Houses" and "Gallery of Ghosts") and architecture ("Andrea Palladio and the Winged Device").

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 -- Another year of economic expansion and general prosperity was forecast for Canada today by Clarence D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, in his annual review of the nation's economy. In the last year, he noted, the country achieved the greatest rise in physical production in its history.

The Franklin National Bank will move its main offices to a five-story building at Roosevelt Field, L. I. The structure will be the first unit of the office center section of the business and industrial development.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -Fullback Tom Jenkins held the key to Pittsburgh's defensive strength today as he waited to learn whether an injured knee would let him start against Georgia Tech in the Sugar Bowl Monday.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Dec. 27 -- A jet fighter plane crashed in flames on a street in this thickly settled residential community today. The pilot had bailed out, and the only casualties were a parked automo bile and a child's bicycle.

How can there possibly be a shortage of pennies when so many people have so many of them? How can pennies be scarce when their custodians, harassed by bulging pockets and cluttered change purses, would gladly exchange them for more portable coinage at the first opportunity? Yet there is a shortage, almost everywhere in the nation except New York.

In the largest single airline financing plan yet to be announced, United Airlines, Inc., completed arrangements yesterday to raise $150,000,000 in new capital. The money will be used for part of the company's expansion program into the jet age.

A $5,400,000 jump in operating expenses to $45,584,000 held net income of the Southern Pacific Railroad and its wholly controlled affiliates to $3,646,213 last month. In November last year net income was $5,133,701.
The city is so desperate for new policemen that it intends, if necessary, to show extreme leniency in marking test papers.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Supreme Soviet may not have the international prestige of the Houses of Westminster or the United States Congress but, on the surface at least, it presents many similarities.

The United States Golf Association published yesterday its revised code of amateur status. The new rules, stricter in most parts, extend the principal provisions of amateurism to cover all golfers. Previously, players under 18 years of age were exempt from many restrictions.
The desire to share their good fortune and happy holidays with others was expressed by many of the 318 contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. They sent $8,258.65.
MIAMI, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Coach Jim Tatum of Maryland and the Miami press battled verbally over secret workouts for the Terrapins' Orange Bowl football game with Oklahoma on Monday.

Predictions about the future of the stock market ran through an impressive range yesterday. They commenced with a prediction by Shelby Cullom Davis, securities dealer, that, because of the inflation being built into the economy, stocks could be valued at eighteen times present earnings when taking a ten-year view.

With selling to establish profits for tax purposes over for the year except for cash sales, the market opened yesterday on an optimistic note. Selling to establish losses may continue "regular way" until the close on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- It will cost $1,600,000,000 for new construction to meet the traffic troubles of the eight-county Philadelphia metropolitan area during the next quarter century, Mayor Joseph S. Clark was told today.

ATLANTA, Dec. 27 -- The discovery and isolation in pure form of a substance producing a serum that inhibits the division and multiplication of specific cells was announced today. The report was made at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

United States foreign trade should maintain the higher levels achieved this year through the first half of 1956, or even register slight increases, according to a forecast issued yesterday. This optimistic view was offered by Gerald LeVino, chairman of the world trade committee of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, and was backed by similar opinions of fifty member concerns surveyed.

It was both interesting and reassuring to learn through a dispatch from Mexico City and The Times editorial comments that Mexican economic recovery during the current year was the result of the sound fiscal policies of Mexico's Treasury Department, and that much of the credit for that country's 1956 Federal budget being balanced should go to Antonio Carrillo Flores, Secretary of the Treasury.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- Pope Pius XII is exploring the chances of Vatican mediation for an East-West accord on the limitation of nuclear experiments.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 27 -- Flags were flying here today to mark another chapter in the city's recovery and growth as a great world port.
The United States Court of Appeals has ruled that a union may picket consumers using services provided by a struck employer.
