CLERMONT - FERRAND, France, Dec. 27 -- One of the issues in the French national election is the demand for modernization and expansion of the French economy to raise standards of living. In numerous official reports industry has been indicted as backward, timorous and inefficient, consequently having production costs too high and wages too low.

VIENNA, Dec. 27 -- A sixteen-hour strike of hotel and restaurant personnel in Vienna's "inner city" gave its patrons a rude shock today. It deprived hotel guests of food, heat and service; night club patrons of late entertainment, and ordinary Viennese of their habitual "mocha" or "espresso."

Four new directors were added to the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, increasing the board to sixteen members, Fred J. Emmerich, president, announced yesterday. The new directors are John J. McCloy, Kerby H. Fisk, Charles W. Nichols Jr. and Harry S. Ferguson.
Members of the Young Adults Club of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church will donate blood today at the Red Cross blood center at Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 27 -- The North Atlantic Alliance faces a greater problem today than existed a year ago, Admiral Jerauld Wright, Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic, said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A committee of Congress announced today an inquiry into the expansion and operation of the United States Government's $100,000,000 nickel plant in Cuba.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 -- A special Royal Navy squadron led by H. M. S. Narvik, a tank landing ship, will take part in atomic weapons tests by the United Kingdom and Australia in the Monte Bello Islands next year.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- Commuters driving into Boston by the right bank of the Charles River between 6 and 7:30 A. M. these days have developed a tooting acquaintance with a young man they see jogging along in sweat clothes.

The former Bailey Alling Lumber Company property at 1214 and 1230 McCarter Highway in Newark, N. J., has been sold by Mildred Bailey to Joseph Solimine. The parcel comprises a site of 100,000 square feet and a number of buildings. The property, which has riparian rights along the Passaic River, had been controlled by the Bailey family for more than seventy-five years.

The comprehensive summary of the controversy over the selection of probation officers for the children's division of the Domestic Relations Court, compiled by your distinguished reporter Harrison E. Salisbury and printed in The Times of Dec. 18, seriously unbalances the picture by omission of two vital factors.
The population of the United States, now 166,000,000, is expected to pass the 200,000,000 mark within twenty years.

In an effort to curb fly-by-night operators in the field, the State Education Department is planning to accredit private nursery schools and kindergartens on a voluntary basis. The accreditation will signify that the schools have met approved standards.
MIAMI, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Nashua headed a list of sixty-five nominations announced today for the Feb. 4 running of the $50,000 added McLennan Handicap at Hialeah.

LAC BEAUPORT, Que., Dec, 27 (Canadian Press) -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier, announced today he soon would place before the Quebec Government plans to start iron ore mining in the subarctic region between Hudson Strait and Ungava Bay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Eisenhower will fly to the Key West, Fla., naval base early tomorrow for the two-week vacation repeatedly recommended by his physicians.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -The Soviet Union may be transferring experts from satellite countries to underdeveloped regions in the Middle East and Asia, according to students of affairs in Eastern Europe.
The nation's colleges and universities are estimated to have received $507,000,000 from gifts and grants in the fiscal year 1954-55.
Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with September increased its sales to a new high of $42,577,925 from the previous year's volume of $40,975,621.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (UP)--The VatervlHe Valley -4-10 inches, State Commerce Department reinches powder; good. ceived today the following reMAINE ports of winter sports conditions:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The American Cancer Society has awarded a $27,000 clinical research grant to the Philadelphia Tuberculosis and Health Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the time for which private lenders must hold insured farm purchase loans before the Government will buy the notes was being reduced from ten to five years. The aim is to encourage greater private participation in the loan program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has relented and will, after all, fill out tax forms for anyone who wants such help. Russell C. Harrington, the...

" Marty," Paddy Chayefsky's simple and poignant drama of the loneliness and romance of a Bronx butcher and a spinster school teacher, yesterday was voted the best motion picture of the year in the twenty-first annual balloting of the New York Film Critics.
Erich Leinsdorf, music director of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, has been named general director of the New York City Opera Company. He succeeds Joseph Rosenstock, who resigned on Dec. 19.

ROSEBURG, Ore., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A wave of mud, higher than a house, crashed into a farm home and killed five members of a family of eight yesterday in the worst single blow in nearly a week of storm and flood in southwest Oregon.

San Francisco's defending National collegiate champions, drawing close to a major-college record, for winning streaks, rolled up the highest point total in history yesterday in again leading The United Press college basketball rankings.
A thirty-year library career will be ended on Saturday when Miss Muriel Baldwin, chief of the New York Public Library's Art and Architecture Division, retires.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Two picket-line melees broke out today at plants of the struck Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The British experimental jet airliner, Comet III, left here at 11:33 o'clock tonight on the delayed last lap of its globe-circling flight.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Argentine agricultural experts predicted today that a "heavy infestation" of grasshoppers in parts of this nation's wheat and corn-growing regions will be wiped out within a month.

Thirty different species of wild birds were counted in the sanctuary of Central Park on Monday. For Manhattan as a whole, the bird-watchers, mostly from the Linnaean Society, raised the total to forty-eight.
PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The French Communist party extended its hand to the Radicals and Socialists again tonight, but it was again rejected.
Former Presidents Herbert Hoover and Harry S. Truman and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, voiced tribute yesterday to Woodrow Wilson as one of the great men of history.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 -- The Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tengku Abdul Rahman, will meet tomorrow the man who has been directing the Communist guerrilla warfare in the Malayan jungles for the last eight years.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Trading was still of a holiday character on the Board of Trade today, but wheat, soybeans and rye showed a firm tone.
The head of one of the country's largest discount houses yesterday called on the General Electric Company to end its fixing of minimum store prices on small household appliances.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, was summoned today to appear in person, or send an authorized operating official of the road, before the Massachusetts Public Utilities Commission tomorrow "to explain service deficiencies."
BUFFALO,. Dec. 27 (AP) -- Dr. Fronezak was a lieutenant colonel in the Army Medical Corps during World War I and served on the Polish National Committee in Paris.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Bette Davis, one of Hollywood's big-star television holdouts, will make her TV debut a double-barreled one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A House of Representatives investigating panel has set out to review the whole maze of spending programs in which the Federal, state and local governments participate cooperatively. It wants to find out which programs should remain as they are, be expanded, reduced, or eliminated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Frederick B. Lee will be the first witness in a Senate inquiry opening Jan. 4 into his dismissal as Civil Aeronautics Administrator.
Harold Stanley, prominent in the financial world for more than forty years, is about to retire as an active partner of the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley Co.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Americans are using more of their income than ever before to pay off installment debt, a Federal Reserve study revealed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Suggestions by Pope Pius XII for halting the testing of nuclear weapons and banning their use have been scrutinized by United Nations diplomats. However, most delegations shared the United States view, expressed today, that official comment must be put off pending more careful analysis.

Over a period of twenty-eight years, since it began to advertise, the Greyhound Lines, operating a fleet of buses, has multiplied its annual revenue ten times. Credit for this accomplishment is given to planned and localized advertising, with newspapers getting twice as much of the budget as any other medium.
Most of the City Councilmen are slated to receive their long-expected $2,000-a-year increase in "contingency allowances" from the Board of Estimate tomorrow.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The Conservative Government and party are planning an extensive review and perhaps a revision of British policies in defense, economic planning and labor relations.

Profits of the Governmentowned Canadian National Railways system after operating expenses, but before taxes, equipmerit rentals and fixed charges, rose nearly 300 per cent in the first eleven months this year.

ATLANTA, Dec. 27 (AP) -Explorers announced today the discovery of what they called the world's largest cave. It is a thirty-two-mile maze of passageways and cavernous rooms near Cave City, Ky., 100 miles south of Louisville.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 27 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns expects further word from Egypt on the United Nations proposals for pacifying the El Auja demilitarized zone.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The C.-P. Farm's Deedee O., a black filly that had earned only $250 in five previous races this year, paid $186.50, $40.50 and $13.20 for $2 in scoring her first success of the season today.

WITH incomes at an all-time high in 1955, Americans have eaten well. They have consumed more meat this year than ever before, an estimated 161 pounds a person. Egg consumption has been at a record high. Though poultry cost more than in 1954, more has been enjoyed than at any time in our history.
Trans World Airlines, Inc. completed its thirtieth year of operations with new traffic records and plans further advances in 1956.
The National Electrical Manufacturers Association predicted yesterday that sales of its industry next year would go to a new peak of $18,700,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney called on the nation's advertising agencies today to go bipartisan in the 1956 Presidential election.

" IT scared me the first time it happened," said Bill Russell, the 6-foot 10-inch center for the University of San Francisco, "and I had the same strange feeling the other two times as well. I leaped up for a jump shot and was -- well, let's say I was shocked to find myself looking down into the basket."
A NEWSREEL history of Russia from the people's revolution against Czarist oppression to the death of Stalin was presented last night on Channel 4 under the title of "Nightmare in Red."
Hammond Edward (Ham) Fisher, creator of the comic strip "Joe Palooka," was found dead last night in a friend's studio. Detectives called the death an apparent suicide.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 27 -- Premier Pibul Songgram's Seri Manangasila party met today to decide whether the Premier should resign and form a new Cabinet or force the Ministers he has criticized into resigning.
MANY a beginning skier takes one look at all that snow, shivers at the thought of tumbling into it, then starts piling on all the heavy clothes she can find.

The Hobart Club of New York will pay tribute today to one of Hobart College's most enthusiastic supporters. On the dais with Eddie Tryon, the Hobart football coach, and Henry Zimmerman, alumni secretary, at the club's annual Christmas luncheon at Toots Shor's will be Arthur Kenney.
THE wildfowlers who are concentrating their hunting activities during the last few weeks of the season are finding plenty of birds on Long Island and the Connecticut shore of the Sound.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -Auburn's Tigers laughed at the cold, blustery weather in Jacksonville today and stole another practice session on Vanderbilt, their football rivals in the Gator Bowl Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A $750,000,000 United States stockpile of arms in Europe became available to West Germany today.

Most New York City Councilmen now receive $7,000 in salary and $1,000 in "contingent" expenses. They would like to have a pay rise, of $2,000 a year in expense money, and Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate seem to look with favor on this "legitimate" request.
Two Manhattan savings banks joined the move toward a 3 per cent dividend rate on savings yesterday.
The Christmas holidays set a record as the most dangerous week-end on the nation's roads.

THERE are emotionally healthy reasons for staying single just as there are forgetting married, according to Dr. Abe Pinsky of the American Institute for Psychoanalysis. Regardless of the opinions of cocktail party psychiatrists-without-portfolio, the perennial bachelor or unmarried career woman, Dr. Pinsky holds, can be just as "well adjusted" as contemporaries long wed -- in some cases even more so.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- More than half of the antitrust cases terminated this year were by consent judgments, Stanley N. Barnes, Assistant Attorney General, reported today.
A 10-year-old Bronx girl was shot and critically wounded last night as she walked on a sidewalk near her home.
MADRID, Dec. 27 -- The Spanish Government urged the nation's workers today not to fall prey to propaganda of enemies of the regime.
Several New Year's swearing-in ceremonies were staged yesterday at City Hall.

A dozen years after its world premiere in Dublin, Sean O'Casey's "Red Roses for Me" will open at 8 o'clock tonight at the Booth. An interim booking, the offering can remain there until Jan. 21. Coming to that house the week of Jan. 23 is "Time Limit," starring Arthur Kennedy and Richard Kiley.
Karen Ann McGuire will receive her horse tomorrow.
NEW HAVEN, Dec, 27 -- Social scientists discussed automation at a conference at Yale University today. But they said it was too early to tell whether men would be better off because of it.
Two men were questioned yesterday by the police in connection with the murder of two women on Nov. 15 in an electrolysis parlor in the Jackson Heights section of Queens.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A visitor from California, I am appalled at the terribly poor conditions of the tenement flats and streets around Bellevue Hospital. Entrances are flanked by six to eight garbage cans, and the stench is almost unbearable. Also there are those smelly, dirty stores on Twenty-eighth Street close to First Avenue.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 27 -- Ely Culbertson, contract bridge expert and chairman of the Citizens Committee for United Nations Reform, died here tonight at his home, Brookside Terrace. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Clarence G. Morse, Federal Maritime Administrator, said today that more than $500,000,000 worth of ship construction and conversion was expected to get under way in United States shipyards by next June 30. This would be almost double the value of work now under way.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 27 -- The propriety of a transaction in which the wife of City Commissioner Donald Spence has been named was questioned today in a report on this city's finances. Mrs. Spence is the commissioner's administrative secretary in the Department of Revenue and Finance.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Coming from 17 points behind, the University of Miami's young Hurricanes scored a stunning 92 -- 90 upset victory over Yale in the second game of the opening round in the Orange Bowl basketball tournament tonight.

A one-story factory building is planned at 59-07 Thirty-ninth Avenue in Woodside, Queens. The site has been purchased by the Lockwood Construction Company from Louise Winkle. A two-story dwelling now on the property will be demolished.

It will be San Francisco against Holy Cross and Duquesne against the University of California at Los Angeles in the semi-final round of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament at Madison Square Marden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today the business had resumed its climb in November and early December, after a pause in October.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales defeated Tony Trabert in a gruelling three - set match tonight, 18 -- 16, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

ATLANTA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The world's largest scientific organization, now meeting in Atlanta, has been asked "to adopt a resolution saying we will not meet again in a city where segregation is practiced."
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Two leading British statesmen, Earl Attlee and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd, defended the United Nations today against criticisms that it had failed.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Princeton connected on sixteen of thirty-two field goal attempts in the second half tonight to subdue the Northwestern basketball team, 88 -- 65. It was the Wildcats' sixth straight defeat of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A Senate subcommittee said today that a public fully informed on Communist objectives and activities was the only alternative to a secret police force numbering up to a million men.

Christmas parties were continued yesterday for a few thousand children and adults who were not included in pre-holiday festivities sponsored by political organizations, service clubs and social welfare groups.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -The Rumanian party congress...

There is no better illustration of the lag in traffic safety here than the announcement by Police Commissioner Kennedy that studies are to be made to determine how to protect policemen assigned to traffic duty.

Future prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Hides, coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil, lead, sugar and burlap rose; zinc, copper, rubber and silk eased, and wool and cocoa closed mixed.
AT their Town Hall concert last night the Vienna Choir Boys gave a sample of the illustrious traditions for which their group is famous.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Administration is expected to announce soon the offering of another large quantity of surplus dairy products for sale on world markets on a competitive bid basis.
NORTH BAY, Ont., Dec. 27 -- The parents of the Dionne quintuplets said today the four surviving girls ignored them at Christmas and did not send so much as a greeting card.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 27 -Brazil's incoming President and Vice President apparently agreed today on the main outlines of their Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- There is much more behind the resignation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as the White House foreign policy adviser than a dispute over the size of foreign aid.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP) -Christmas season retail sales in Detroit were as much as 5 to 15 per cent below expectations, a business information concern reported today.
Some of the details of the Navy's Mark 63 gunfire control system, which is capable of tracking speedy jet aircraft with 3-inch and 5-inch naval guns in any weather, were made public yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A special committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation proposed today that West Europeans coordinate their atomic power development trader that organization.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 27 -- The Indian Government has approved the sale of machinery and equipment displayed at Indian Industries Fair, subject to import policy and foreign exchange regulations.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 -- Australia's million migrants are changing the face and culture of a continent. In the stores, on the streets, in the factories and offices and newspapers, the effect of the influx from Europe is plainer every day.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 27 -There is a growing feeling among Pakistani foreign policy makers that the United States has let Pakistan down.

HARTFORD, Dec. 27 (AP) -Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, called upon to deal with the aftermath of two Connecticut floods in August and October, offered today to share the information gained from that experience with the Governors of three flooded Western states.
ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 27 -- Three thousand students from seventy-five countries gathered here today for a religious conference on "Revolution and Reconciliation."
It was a matter of "finding the woman" that led to the arrest yesterday of a former merchant seaman charged with ignoring seventy-eight parking tickets accumulated during the last three years.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Harriman will ask the 1956 Legislature to reduce taxes $50,000,000. In his message to the lawmakers on Jan. 4, the Governor will propose that the personal income tax be cut $40,000,000 through a credit of $5 for each taxpayer and each dependent. The other...

Prince and Princess Edward Joseph de Lobkowicz of 164 East Seventy - second Street entertained with a dinner dance last evening to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anita Olga de Lobkowicz. The party was held in the Georgian Suite of 1A East Seventy-seventh Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- A fair weather forecast lessened tension today in flood-ravaged northern California. Rivers there and in southern Oregon dropped sharply as the death toll stood at forty-six -- thirty-four in California and twelve in Oregon.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- A Peiping radio broadcast this morning said the Chinese Communist Government had offered to return four South Korean Coast Guardsmen it had inadvertently taken prisoner if South Korea would return a Chinese fisherman it had seized.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 26 -- The Communist anti-election campaign has fizzled out, according to a Government spokesman. He estimated that 300,000 men voted yesterday to elect a National Assembly.

Seven of the twenty-six players competing in the tournament for the individual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League repeated their victories of the opening day in the second round at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, yesterday.
HOBOKEN, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Tugboat and ferryboat crewmen for nine railroads voted tonight to call a strike Jan. 4 if their wage demands were not met by that time.

LENINGRAD, Dec. 27 -- Since Stalin's death the U. S. S. R. has been experiencing a gradual retreat from the rigid political and cultural isolation that marked much of recent Bolshevik history. The glacial formation which seems to obscure much of Soviet life and its inner perceptions is again moving.

Samuel Reshevsky, the international chess ace who is leading the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy tournament, adjourned his eighth-round match with Walter J. Shipman at the Marshall Chess Club last night. Forty-one moves had been recorded.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- British civil aviation leaders are planning, with Government support, to challenge the United States world commercial aviation leadership in about ten years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Labor leaders think that Adlai E. Stevenson would draw more labor votes than any other possible 1956 Democratic nominee for President.
The Citizens Budget Commission presented an experimental research approach yesterday to determine a standard of performance for municipal services.
Van Norman Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it has acquired H. W. Butterworth Sons Company of Bethayres, Pa., through an exchange of stock.
BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- Soviet authorities in East Berlin turned over to United States officials tonight an Air Force master sergeant who had been involved in an East Berlin traffic accident.
New Year's Eve revelers will blow their tops and an estimated total of $8,000,000 for hats, horns and sundry noisemakers.

The Department of the Interior, which in addition to its other duties is supposed to protect the natural resources of the United States, is in hot water with conservationists once again. Obviously stung by the repeated charge of "give-away," Secretary McKay has in recent months been busily defending his record in this regard and citing an impressive array of statistics to prove his department's interest in conservation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The railroad industry today pushed ahead with technical steps of its plan for a 7 per cent freight rate increase, effective Feb. 9.

We political leaders now in exile from the Central-Eastern European nations which fought on the side of the Allies in the first World War have founded the Central-Eastern European Woodrow Wilson Committee and consider it our moral duty to participate in the anniversary of his birth.
THE world's most wealthy potters -- men and women of distinguished New York families -- labor in monastic quiet in a sub-basement in the former Ransom Hooker Mansion at 175 East Seventy-first Street.

The Dodgers' 1956 pennant stock dropped a few points yesterday. Johnny Podres, the Brooks' ace left-hander and the hero of Brooklyn's first world series championship last October, has been notified by his draft board that he has been classified 1-A. He therefore becomes subject to immediate military call.
A $90,000,000 anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Sperry Rand Corporation against International Business Machines Corporation.
A $90,000,000 anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Sperry Rand Corporation against International Business Machines Corporation.

THE considerable talents of Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra were congenially employed at Carnegie Hall last night in the Sibelius Symphony No. 7 in C major, programmed by the Philadelphians in honor of the composer's ninetieth birthday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- The Australian 1956 Antarctic expedition left here today twenty-four hours after a party of French scientists had left Hobart, Tasmania, for the polar region.

Carl Braun's set shot from just outside the keyhole with three seconds of the game left gave the New York Knickerbockers a thrilling 80-to-79 triumph over the Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden last night.
The police issued 2,134 summonses for moving violations of the traffic laws over the holiday week-end -- between 3 P. M. Friday and 8 A. M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Administration appears to be nearing the end of its program for reducing Federal spending.

Net assets of Group Securities, Inc., increased by $24,835,788, or 33.3 per cent, in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30. According to the twenty-second annual report released yesterday, this raised net assets to $99,377,781 from $74,541,993 a year earlier.

Hues of pink and silver provided a colorful background for the tenth annual Yuletide Assembly Ball held last night in the ballroom of the Ambassador. Five young women were presented to society at the fete. The event served also as a benefit
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -Only four of ninety-two teams in the four English soccer divisions emerged today from their three-match Christmas program with a clean sweep.
Alan Tobias of New York and Dave Brechner of Brooklyn led the way into the third round of the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -Argentina's provisional government placed 360 additional individuals on its economic blacklist today. This action is part of an effort to put "ill-gotten gains" into the nation's treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Office of Defense-Mobilization announced today it has cleared the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation, Mobile, Ala., for special tax benefits on a $63,000,000 project for building special coastal vessels.
It's now official. Christmas buying in New York's department stores wound up strongly and topped last year's record holiday volume.

Paramount Pictures Corporation is about to conclude the sale of 1,600 filmed short subjects to UM, Inc., a New York company that syndicates films to television. The sale price was reported to be about $3,500,000.
The proposed increase in fares to 15 cents on the major routes of the city's private bus companies was assailed yesterday by Harris J. Klein in a letter to Mayor Wagner.

Domestic steel production last week declined to the lowest level since mid-October, apparently reflecting preparations for cutbacks in operations over the Christmas holidays. The industry operated at 96.9 per cent of capacity and turned out 2,338,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The French general elections of next Monday have now approached close enough for us all to brace ourselves for what may or may not be a shock. The French voter is just about the most conservative in the world in the sense that once he starts voting Socialist or Radical or Independent -- or even Communist -- he goes on doing so.

A Christmas candle set fire to four rooms in the Sherman Square Hotel late yesterday afternoon. Five women were overcome by smoke and about one hundred residents were evacuated as the firemen poured water on the blaze.

A sale and lease-back transaction has been closed on the new six-story apartment house accommodating 147 families at 711 West End Avenue. The property occupies a plot 200 by 135 feet in the block between Ninety-fourth and Ninety-fifth Streets. It has an assessed valuation of 81.750,000.

Today is the ninety-ninth anniversary of the birth of Woodrow Wilson. Today also marks the birth of a year-long re-examination of the great President's ideas -- not in a historical review, but in an effort to apply those ideas to the problems of today and tomorrow.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Oklahoma City University defeated a surprisingly tough University of Pennsylvania quintet, 74 -- 62, in the twentieth annual All-College tournament tonight.
HONG KONG, Dec. 27 -- A drive has developed in Communist China to complete the Peiping Government's 1953-57 economic plan ahead of Schedule in both industry and agriculture.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 27 -- The committee designated by Parliament to screen senior officer material has approved ninety applicants for generalships and colonelcies in West Germany's armed forces.
Sale of stock in Eagle Newspaper Enterprises, Inc., a group hoping to revive The Brooklyn Eagle, will begin early in January, it was announced yesterday.
Cotton futures rose 2 to 11 points yesterday. The steadiness was attributed to closing price-fixing orders.

The Robin Line, Inc., which operates ships between the United States and South and East Africa, has sold its twelve-story office building at 39 Cortlandt Street. The company has leased back about 20,000 square feet of space it now occupies on several floors.
The editorial entitled "Good-by to Old Lenox" which appeared in The New York Times of Dec. 23 leads me, as president of the institution to which "Old Lenox" belonged, to make a few observations.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 28 -- Mental tension is supplanting muscular fatigue as the chief complaint of workers in newly automated factories, social scientists were told today.

Mayor Robert F. Wagner's appointment of a fifteen-man Commission on Intergroup Relations and his abolishment of the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs merits praise. The latter act is the culmination of a four-year battle by the Spanish-American Youth Bureau to destroy the myth that the Puerto Ricans are New York's only problem.
Samuel Reshevsky was held to a draw by Larry Evans in the ninth round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 28 -- Dr. Arthur A. Schuck, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, announced today the appointment of Raymond E. Williams of near-by Metuchen, as his administrative assistant.
Karl Spooner, whose importance in the Dodger picture has been magnified by the likelihood that Johnny Podres soon will be drafted into military service, signed his 1956 contract yesterday.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday in generally more active trading on the New York exchanges. Hides, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper, lead and tin rose; rubber, zinc and onions eased, and moves in cocoa, coffee, sugar and wool were mixed.
TWO important twentieth-century American figure sculptors, the late Gaston Lachaise and William Zorach, are represented in two of this week's one-man exhibitions.

THE only team in the National League to have strengthened itself considerably since the end of the season has been the Brooklyn Dodgers, the one ball club that needs strengthening least. The Brooks latched on Randy Jackson, the long-ball hitter from the Cubs, and gave away a couple of expendables in exchange.

Year-end influences of no great force governed the stock market yesterday. In the narrowest market in more than a week and the dullest market since Nov. 21, prices underwent changes in fractions for the most part and closed unimportantly lower.

"The Fiction Factory," a new book by Quentin Reynolds, will be published by Random House on Jan. 16. It is a history of the Street Smith publishing house in the last 100 years. Its subtitle is "From Pulp Row to Quality Street."
WATERVILLE, Me., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Bowdoin College pulled an opening-round upset by defeating Harvard, 78 -- 66, tonight in the New England collegiate basketball tournament.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- L'Osservatore Romano noted today that the ncclear powers talked of disarmament but continued testing new weapons. The Vatican organ reminded the Soviet Union that the last such experiments had been carried out on its territory.
QUEBEC, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Premier Maurice Duplessis said today he would press his newsprint control bill as soon as the Legislature reconvene on Jan. 10.

A forty-nine-count criminal information was returned yesterday against two officers of a company making women's coats. They were charged with counterfeiting labels on garments sold by them to leading department stores in the nation.

ATLANTA, Dec. 28 -- Dr. Warren Weaver, vice president for Natural and Medical Sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, declared here tonight that science was "a universal human activity, and a friendly companion of art and of moral philosophy."

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The General Council of the Press, called today for legislation extending the right of the press to cover the meetings of public bodies. The council was formed to encourage high standards in the British press and protect its freedom.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The British Government is examining means of tightening export regulations to prevent further shipments of surplus tanks to Middle East countries.
Directors of the Warren Foundry and Pipe Corporation late yesterday recommended a four-for-one split of the outstanding common stock, according to F. S. Shahmoon, chairman.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The approach of the new year finds British employers in almost every major industry facing demands for higher wages and improved working conditions.

The Veterans Administration added neither to the prestige nor to the security of the United States Government by suspending disability payments to James Kutcher, legless veteran of World War II who also is a member of an insignificant Trotskyite splinter group called the Socialist Workers party.
The chairman of the Citizens Waterfront Committee has completed the rough draft of a proposed code of fair dealing for the stevedoring industry, it was learned yesterday.

As the year 1955 draws to its close the free world finds itself still compelled to face up to what is the decisive factor of our day. This factor is the unrelenting hostility to all free nations on the part of international communism directed by the Soviets.
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., yesterday announced plans to separate the $75,000,000-a-year S. Klein department store operation from its chain of seventy- five specialty shops.

THE first year of an experiment in New York State government is drawing to a close. During 1955, the consumer, often the forgotten man or woman, had a voice in Albany in the person of Dr. Persia Campbell. She served in the new post of Consumer Counsel to the Governor.
The State Power Authority hinted yesterday that it was again considering a judicial test of a Senate reservation to the Niagara treaty between the United States and Canada.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The stock markets here resumed business today on a firm note, though turnover remained small. The demand for medium-dated Government loans lifted prices 1s 3d (171/2 cents).
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Dec. 29 -- The harsh character of the Soviet leaders' speeches in India is reported to have annoyed Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru.
Charles U. Harvey has been named general sales manager of the container division of the Robert Gain Company, Inc., manfacturer of paperboard and paper product Jan.1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The railroads' request for a quickly established 7 per cent freight rate increase appeared temporarily sidetracked today as two important industries attempted to block a railroad suggested procedure leading to a quick decision.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Two scholarship funds as memorials to two Harvard University undergraduates who were killed Dec. 21 in a highway crash were announced today by the Harvard Club of Chicago.

Net income of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was held to $867,065 last month as the road's wage bills soared. The company's income statement, issued yesterday, showed that more than 56 per cent of the month's total operating revenues of $13,294,632 went for payrolls.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 -- The stolen Walt Whitman diary, valued at $27,500, has been anonymously returned by mail to the Detroit Public Library.

Production is under way at the new factory of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company in Toledo, Ohio. The plant is said to be the largest making automotive safety glass and the largest plate glass plant ever built at one time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -The Agriculture Department announced today that it would offer an additional 10,000,000 pounds of Government - owned surplus butter for sale in the export market on a competitive-bid basis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- State Department sources discounted today concern over Communist worker penetration of vital industries in West Germany.

THE outlook for the coming year in books is magnificent. A secret poll of lit'ry astrologists, prophets and soothsayers reveals that the art and commerce of the printed word, like the rest of the American economy, is probably going to boom and zoom in 1956. Although our informants must be nameless here, they believe this to a man, or, rather, to a woman, since we are in the province of sibyls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Speakers at the seventieth annual meeting of the American Historical Association today warned against the "siren song" of the Soviet Union policy of peaceful coexistence since Stalin's death.
The city will make another try at easing tensions between motorists and residents near transit line terminuses who have objected to all-day parking in front of their homes.

CUTTING across the happiness of the holidays are the accounts of a record traffic accident toll and fatalities from fires. If each of us adhered to a list of safety resolutions in the new year, however, the newspapers might go begging for such stories in 1956.

TORONTO, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Striking twice in the second period, the Toronto Maple Leafs moved into a fourth-place tie in the National Hockey League tonight with a 2-0 victory over the league-leading Montreal Canadiens. The Leafs share fourth place with the Chicago Black Hawks.
A banker and an economist looked at the national economy yesterday and came to different conclusions on its prospects for 1956.

Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d of 1 Beekman Place gave a dinner dance last night in the St. Regis Roof to introduce their daughter, Miss Hope Aldrich Rockefeller. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a bouffant gown of white faille and carried a bouquet of pink camellias.

Guatemala had national elections last week that might charitably have been left in discreet silence by friends of the new and struggling anti-Communist regime of President Castillo Armas. However, it would not be wise to let something go by default on the theory that it might do temporary harm to call attention to errors or misjudgments in a Government that on the whole is trying to do the right thing for freedom and democracy.
MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Howard Abbey of Miami set a world record for F service runabouts today when he averaged 59.801 miles per hour in time trials of the orange bowl regatta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A high Justice Department official said today that subterfuges that states might adopt to circumvent the Supreme Court's decision outlawing racial segregation in the public schools would not "stand up" in court tests.

San Francisco and the University of California at Los Angeles, the first and second seeded quintets, respectively, in the holiday festival basketball event, will meet in the final tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. These teams advanced last night with convincing victories in the semi-finals before 18,496 fans at the Eighth Avenue Arena.

The board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday its "unqualified support" of the position taken by the company's management in the face of a strike of 55,000 workers.
ROME, Dec. 28 -- Communist-controlled unions accepted today a face-saving formula and called off a twenty-four-hour railroad strike scheduled to start at midnight.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to close 11 points higher to 6 points lower than on Tuesday.

We recently read statements and slogans advanced by the two top Soviet "traveling salesmen" during their visit to India, Burma and Pakistan. Your editorial of Dec. 19 about their performance without dignity was a highly intelligent and unbiased answer to Stalin's successors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An urgent demand for hogs was a feature of trading in livestock today. Not all orders were filled despite the fact that buyers paid 25 to 50 cents higher prices than yesterday for both butchers and sows.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A big majority of Republican leaders seem to be convinced President Eisenhower will run again.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Federal Social Security coverage has been extended to 1,000 employes in twenty-two more of New York's political subdivisions, Arthur Levitt, State Controller, announced today.

"Third Person," a play by Andrew Rosenthal, will have its local premiere at the President Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. David Clive, son of the silent- screen actor E. E. Clive, is producer of the venture, his first managerial effort.
"DISNEYLAND" took its viewers on a trip around the moon last night. The imaginary journey was a television treat called "Man and the Moon" that combined scientific fact with diverting fancy.
Four new front-rank city officials were sworn in yesterday at City Hall pre-New Year's ceremonies. One of them immediately received a major assignment from Mayor Wagner.

A group of business men headed by Frederick W. Richmond, New York financier, announced yesterday the acquisition of the assets of Pressed Metals of America, Inc., large manufacturer and distributor of automotive suspension parts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Mayor Alex M. Clark of Indianapolis, Ind., announced today he has accepted the chairmanship of the Joint Committee of Consumers and Small Gas Producers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Air Force shifted its procurement system today to a state of readiness to multiply weapons production in the first phase of a nuclear war.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 28 -- The "dean of commuters" on the Jersey Central Lines was honored at a birthday breakfast today aboard the 8:03 from Westfield.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- An alarm against Communist infiltration has been sounded in West Germany.
Lernen Newell, Inc., and the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee will end their agency-client relationship by mutual consent as of March 1.
A bold plot for an armed break by dangerous prisoners in the Federal House of Detention has been nipped in the bud.

Four hold-up men got about $1,400 in a Central Park West pharmacy last night. Their own carelessness coupled with quick thinking by a probationary patrolman landed them and the money in the hands of the police within two minutes.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Navy's twenty-one Demon jets, which cost more than $1,000,000 each and will never fly, had more bad luck today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Allie Reuben of Toledo, became the nation's leading money-winning stable of 1955 when Sea O Erin earned $1,000 by finishing second to J. W. Rodgers' Duc de Fer in the feature at Tropical Park today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Dec. 28 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada discussed border questions today with Col. Salah Gohar, Director of Palestine Affairs in the Egyptian Ministry of War. The meeting was held in Gaza.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Grain trading was almost at a stand-still at times today. There was little in the way of news to make for any activity.
TORONTO, Dec. 28 -- The rift between the four surviving Dionne quintuplets and their parents became clearer today.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Jacob Malik, the Soviet Ambassador to Britain, said today that a "wide exchange of politicians" and specialists in other spheres "will help to strengthen mutual trust and will promote cooperation between peoples and countries."

TUCKERTON, N. J., Dec. 28 -Five hours and several contretemps behind schedule, the 763-foot Tuckerton radio tower was toppled for scrap today. The structure had transmitted trans-oceanic messages for forty-one years.
'Tis the season to be jolly, and in the appliance-radio-television field 'tis the time to introduce new models.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Powerful Democrats in the House of Representatives are working on an election-year formula to give "the little fellow" a tax cut without interfering with prospects of a balanced budget.

FOR several months earlier this year, home to Mrs. Frank Schoonmaker was a storybook villa in Palamos, a small Spanish fishing village on the Mediterranean coast. In a recent interview, the wife of the wine importer extolled the beauty -- and the bargain prices -- of that quiet spot on the Costa Brava.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The craziest of all crazy quilts is made up of the clutter of constitutional clauses, Federal and state laws and major regulations of the two major political parties that deal with the nomination and election of the President and Vice President of the United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- Northern California's disastrous floods, which claimed several dozen lives and caused upward of $100,000,000 in property damage, have produced these widespread reactions:
Two holding companies with substantial interests in the reviving coal industry cut up bigger melons for their stockholders yesterday.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 28 -- The political struggle resulting from the Israeli attack on Syrian positions near the Sea of Galilee Dec. 11 has reached the showdown stage. Critics of the raid are reported pressing at a meeting tonight in Tel Aviv for a change of control in security affairs.
The Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund reported yesterday that it wound up its fiscal year on Nov. 30 with assets, shares outstanding and number of stockholders at record highs.
The Board of Estimate approved informally yesterday a 15-cent fare for private bus lines now charging less.

Formal announcement was made yesterday that Sidney Kingsley, the playwright, had signed a five-year television contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System. It had been indicated earlier that such an arrangement was pending.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- A renewed drive to socialize land in Rumania has been indicated at the second congress of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party meeting in Bucharest.
Sixteen young women made their formal debuts last evening at the seventh annual Forest Hills Gardens Cotillion, which took place in the Community House in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

Brooklyn College's basketball team gained its second victory this season over City College, 77 to 58, on the Kingsmen's court last night. The game was the twenty-first in the series between the schools. Despite the defeat, City holds a commanding lead in the rivalry, 19 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Veterans Administration officials agreed today to allow newsmen to cover a hearing at which the loyalty of James Kutcher, a legless ex-serviceman, will be argued on Friday.
A state guarantee of loans for the construction or rehabilitation of private middle-income housing is to be proposed at the new session of the Legislature, which starts next week.

An office building is planned for the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street where a site of 32,500 square feet has been purchased by Jerome, Henry and Myron Minskoff of Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., builders. Preliminary plans call for a thirty-story structure.
A leading Biblical scholar warned yesterday that "we are still in as much danger from 'authoritarian' dictation of religious and theological views as our fathers were in days gone by."

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Shareholders of the United States Gypsum Company approved today a 5-for-1 split of the common stock. They also voted to increase the authorized shares from 3,000,000 to 18,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Multiple purpose dams and reservoirs in Central California and elsewhere in the West limited flood damage in protected areas, the Department of the Interior said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has asked for authority to penalize railroads that hoard box cars during actual or threatened freight-car shortages, the Senate Commerce Committee said today.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 21 -- Formosa's rice exports averaged 650,000 tons a year from 1936 to 1939 on an annual crop yield of 1,300,000 tons. That was while Japan was in control here.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- Special procurement contracts in Japan for the United States armed forces were $69,367,000 less in the first eleven and on-half months of 1955 than they were in 1954, the Economic Planning Board reports.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An offer of a million dollars for the New York Giants of the National Football League has been turned down by the club's owners.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 28 -- According to British sources, 190 Valentine tanks exported from Britain to Belgium as tractors were among materiel shipped from Antwerp to Egypt recently.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Judge George H. Moore of the United States District Court ordered today an end to segregation in low-rent public housing projects in St. Louis.
ST. ETIENNE, France, Dec. 28 -- North Africa, especially Algeria, has become the dominant issue in the electoral campaign in the Department of the Loire.

"Adorable Creatures," a French-made comedy, will have its American premiere at the Baronet Theatre after the run of "Naked Sea." Daniel Gelin, Martine Carol, Danielle Darieux, Renee Faure and Antonella Lualdi head the cast.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The emergence of women in the archaeological field was pointed up here today. Nine women were on hand to tell of their findings at the annual convention of the Archaeological Institute of America.
A blind woman whose apartment building is being razed said yesterday that she would refuse her landlord's offer of another apartment at one-half the ceiling rental.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The Popular Republican party proposed today that all political groups except those of the extreme Left and Right agree on a joint program immediately after the Parliamentary elections Monday. The Roman Catholic center party, identified with the conservatives during the campaign, thus extended an olive branch to former Premier Pierre Mendes-France, one of its principal enemies..

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 28 -- Muhlenberg, the pre-tournament favorite, reached the semi-final round of the Hofstra invitation affair tonight by trouncing Delaware, 87-69. The tourney is being held in Calkins Gymnasium on the Hofstra campus.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Net assets of $1,900,000 would be distributed to stockholders under a proposed sale of the Sheraton Hotel and liquidation of the St. Louis Sheraton Corporation, present owner of the hotel.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28 -- Two Richmond banks voted today to merge, effective next Sunday. Together they will form the state's largest banking institution in total resources. The two are the State Planters Bank and Trust Company and the Bank of Commerce and Trusts.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- A man who is studying for an unusual profession in this mechanical age is Donald Jacobs, a 28-year-old trainee in horseshoeing, or farriery, at the Cornell University Veterinary College.
Somewhere, someone may be wondering about a boy, about 6 years old, who got lost on Monday. To date, though, no one has claimed him.
ROME, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- One of the four engines of a Pan American airliner fell off an hour after the aircraft took off from here late today with forty-two passengers on board.

Five members of the eight-man United States Olympic speed skating team left from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a series of meets in Europe leading to the Winter Olympic Games.
THE versatile electric blender is well suited for making Old World marzipan, the almond paste used particularly in Germany for cookies and candies.
A profit of $1,221,341 in additional interest earned in the last two years from investment of city funds was reported yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- The Supreme Soviet approved today the Government's 1956 budget in slightly altered form. Revenue is to exceed expenditure by 23,200,000,000 rubles.

HONGKONG, Dec. 28 -- A French Army lieutenant held in Communist China for more than fifty-six months declared on his release today that the Chinese Communists "definitely" had participated in the Indochinese war in the spring of 1951.
WYCKOFF, N. J., Dec. 28 -- A group of teen-agers here started to read the Bible at 11 o'clock Christmas night and are determined not to stop until they have read every word of it.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The heads of two of the auto industry's three largest companies came up with production forecasts for 1956 today, and they differed somewhat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 21:

It is doubtful that any of the three previous Holiday Festival basketball events moved into Madison Square Garden with so many standout individuals as the fourth edition, now in progress, boasts. Each quintet has at least one big "name" player.
James Stewart has been named box-office king of the year in the annual poll of exhibitors conducted by The Motion Picture Herald.
The Radio Corporation of America plans to expand its operations in marine radio Communications, Frank M. Folsom, president, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad received a sharp scolding here today from the Massachusetts Public Utilities Commission about service failures. They promised to do better.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department received today the following reports on winter sports conditions: ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The l0,000 displaced residents of Yuba City streamed back into their flood-shattered town today to begin rebuilding their homes and their lives. A warm sun shone on most of the Western disaster areas.
Orders for seventeen more American-made jet transports were announced yesterday by three airlines.
MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Viscount Portal of Hungerford will head the new Canadian British Aluminium Company, Ltd., with head offices in Montreal, the company, announced today
CALCUTTA, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Bob Perry of Los Angeles and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark gained the men's singles semi-finals today in the Asian lawn tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- A curly-haired little girl helped John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, open the 1956 March of Dimes drive today by blowing up two "polio fighter" balloons.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The General Electric Company's accessory turbine department announced today it was beginning work on a $45,000,000 production program at Lynn, Mass., for hydraulic turbopumps for B52 eight-jet strategic bombers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Arthur Freed, staff producer at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the last fifteen years will have his own independent producing unit at the studio. Final details of negotiation are being worked out with Arthur Loew, new president. Contracts are expected to be signed soon.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 28 -- President Eisenhower began his Florida holiday today with a thirty-minute golf practice session and a fifty-five-minute leisurely walk in the bright sunlight.

YONKERS, Dec. 28 -- This city's teachers will be asked next month to protest their failure to receive 5 per cent salary increases by giving "only minimum service" and curtailing after-school activities next semester.

LONDON, Dec. 28--The de Havilland Comet Mark III jet airliner crossed the Atlantic from Montreal to London today in 6 hours 18 minutes. It was an unofficial record. The average speed was 548 miles an hour. The plane was on the last lap of a world tour.
RICHMOND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Richmond's Kenny Daniel tonight paced the Spiders' rally that gained them a 96-84 victory over Army in the first round of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Publishers of Detroit's three strike-bound newspapers declared today that they were caught "squarely in the middle of a dispute between rival unions."

YET another set of illustrations for La Fontaine's fables, this time by the Swiss illustrator Hans Erni, are shown at the Wittenborn Gallery, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. Following closely in the footsteps of Picasso, Erni in his lithographs never achieves the satiric bite or imaginative take-offs that others before him have derived from the fables.

CAIRO, Dec. 28 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser rolled out the red carpet today for Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, a champion of neutralism between East and West. The independent Communist leader arrived in Cairo at noon for a ten-day state visit at Premier Nasser's invitation.
ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 28 -- A Presbyterian missionary said today that Western civilization had helped start a global revolution that could shatter its own political and religious institutions.
GENEVA, Dec. 28 -- The big economic question facing Western Europe now is whether the economy is on a peak or a plateau.

"Truce" talks between the leader of the Communist guerrillas in Malaya and the leaders of the Malayan and Singapore Governments have now begun. There is at the moment a lull in the terrorist activities that have plagued Malaya for eight years.

Oil prices are likely to hold awhile around current levels despite rising costs of operation, Eugene Holman, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said yesterday in a year- end statement.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Dec. 28 -- A fiery dispute raged today between the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and the Woodbridge Fire Commissioners. It began late yesterday when a Woodbridge fire truck driver, who helped put out a grass fire on the shoulder of the superhighway, received a summons for reckless driving.

The apparel industries must not continue to "tag along" behind gains in the national economy if they are to survive as major competitors for the consumer dollar, a credit agency head declared yesterday.
AFTER an absence of twenty-one years, Sean O'Casey has returned with a beautiful play, "Red Roses for Me," which was acted at the Booth last evening.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, in the quarter ended Nov. 30, realized a 42.3-per cent increase in earnings and an 18.2 per cent gain in sales over the corresponding three months last year.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Columbia University, led by All-America candidate, Chet Forte, defeated Santa Clara, 76 to 73, in an overtime game of the Orange Bowl basketball tournament today.

The successor of the late Hannes Schneider, the famed ski instructor, as head of the ski school at Cranmore Mountain in North Conway, N. H., is his son, Herbert. Born in St. Anton am Arlberg, Austria, Herbert has been skiing since he was 3 years old.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 28 -- The Chief Ministers of Malaya and Singapore met with the leader of the outlawed Communist party for six hours today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- There is little likelihood that any other union will overcome the dominant position of Harry Bridges' West Coast longshoremen's union in Hawaii's basic industries, a study of Hawaiian labor conditions indicated today.

BY mid-January local sportsmen will be limited in their outdoor activities to hunting rabbits and foxes, and fishing through the ice or from the heaving deck of a codfish boat, but several southern states offer good hunting and fishing right through February.

The ripest opportunity a parent will have to start the new year right with orderly habits among the young may be at this time. For in most homes, by now, there will be a plentiful assortment of brand new toys, playthings and clothes for proud young owners to learn to care for and to keep in order.
BALING, Malaya, Thursday, Dec. 29 -- The Malayan Communists agreed today to call off their jungle war against Britain if the Government met certain conditions, but no agreement was reached.
The city's Department of Marine and Aviation fired its heaviest barrage to date yesterday in its controversy with the Port of New York Authority over a Manhattan heliport.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The Republican Senate leader charged today that Governor Harriman was planning tax reductions "to bolster his sagging chances for the Democrat Presidential nomination."

A cluster of Persian cats and one Siamese posed, toyed with food and lapped at milk yesterday in the Belmont Plaza Hotel. The show animals were taken to the "banquet" by their owners, members of the Empire Cat Club. The event was held to bring attention to a club project for finding homes for stray felines.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, presented an award of merit yesterday to Lester Crown, a director of the Empire State Building Corporation. The ceremony was in the Empire State Club.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 -Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne received honorary degrees tonight on the stage of the Colonial Theatre after a performance of "The Great Sebastians."
Four teen-age boys were charged with juvenile delinquency yesterday in connection with the "live target" shooting of a 10-year-old girl. The victim was in critical condition in Fordham Hospital.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 29 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin told the Supreme Soviet today that "this year will go down in history as a definite turning in the relaxation of world tensions."

The sight of service personnel home for the holidays for "on the town," many of them hurrying along this city's streets without overcoats, reminds a reader of a directive issued some weeks ago by the Fort Dix Post Command.
Mid-city traffic reached saturation yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 28 -- A revolt against censorship has erupted in the Brazilian press.

American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $188,552,157 for twelve months ended Sept. 30. This compared with $200,973,949 in the like 1954 period. Net income of $12,402,448 compared with $17,349,052 a year earlier.
To all employes: It's O. K. to work as hard as you want on your job and your boss can't discharge you for it. You have a labor arbitrator's word for it. Here are the facts:
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 -- Mexican authorities announced today that they were trying to work out a solution to the stalemate of a United States-Mexico border problem.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Creation of midget-sized hydrogen bombs in the laboratory may be possible, the American Physical Society was told today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Farmers will vote in four separate referenda tomorrow on Department of Agriculture proposals to impose marketing quotas on different types of tobacco during the next three crop years.
A Greenwich Village resident who called the police this week to report a minor crime is still a bit bewildered by the response that she received.

Everybody is getting into the act now in favor of cutting state personal income taxes. On Dec. 21 Republican legislative leaders announced that they would press for a $50,000,000 reduction. Six days later an Albany dispatch says that Governor Harriman will ask the 1956 Legislature to reduce taxes by $50,000,000.

A helping hand for the city's Neediest was extended from foreign lands yesterday. Mariona and Miquelet of Figueres, Spain, and a British subject who "finds the U. S. A. kinda nice" were among 567 who contributed $8,727.68 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 28 -- The United States is expected soon to reassure India that it is in no way a party to the dispute between India and Portugal over Goa.

It is not really 1955 any more; the year is worn out, issues no more commands, breathes more and more slowly and is about to die. It is not yet 1956, which somewhere some millions of miles out yonder, at a spot the astronomers have selected, waits to keep its rendezvous.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The four top-seeded players in the boys' division of the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament gained the semi-finals today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Methodists and the teachings of their church are not always in agreement, even on basic matters, it was reported today after the first nation-wide opinion poll among them.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Robert Kennon's office said today he had signed New York extradition papers for Harry Gross, former Brooklyn bookmaker, and his younger brother, Jackie Gross.
LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Dec. 28 -- Admiral Richard E. Byrd returned early today to Little America.
The State of Michigan is planning to borrow $20,000,000 in the public market on Jan. 17 to finance construction of expressways.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Harriman is preparing a New Year's present for the state's civil service workers.

Two in the aisle were all that Mr. and Mrs. Jack Harrison Pollack could find on a New Haven train early yesterday after an evening at the theatre. It was then that they conceived a dramatic, if somewhat luxurious, way around the commuting crush.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Health authorities are concerned about the relatively high rate of diphtheria this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Army announced today that it had bought twelve experimental models of the Aerocycle, a one-man flying machine designed to give the foot soldier mobility in an atomic war.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follow:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Tobacco farmers voted overwhelmingly today to accept strict Government marketing quotas during the next three years.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 29 -- The Malayan jungle warfare is expected to revive in all its fury following the collapse today of the talks between the head of the Malayan Government and the chief of the Communist guerrillas.
The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a 15-cent fare on the eight privately operated bus lines in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx.

There is today a considerable trend toward the ranch-type house. A trend is a trend, and, besides, this one has certain advantages. A ranch-type house is perhaps easier to heat, and it definitely is easier on the cook.
Casey Stengel, still very much the manager of the Yankees, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning to wind up his around-the-globe tour.
The Academy of American Poets announced yesterday that its 1955 Fellowship, a grant of $5,000, had been awarded to Rolfe Humphries, New York poet and anthologist.

The seventh annual Post Debutante Tiara Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Artificial jewels and pink and gold gossamer studded with sparkling gems provided a simulated jewel box setting. The fete was attended by debutantes of last season and young women who were presented during the two preceding seasons.

IT is not yet Twelfth Night, but for most of us the festivities of Christmas have drawn to a close. Accordingly, it would seem an opportune moment to take a calm backward glance at the holiday season on television.
Your editorial "Union Funds for Housing" on Dec. 22 outlines a practical program of how housing for moderate-income families can be achieved.

A young girl from Rome, who stoutly defended New York as a quiet city, and an Indonesian student of criminology, whose hardest problem is to find out who is boss in the American family, said a belated Merry Christmas to each other yesterday at the Institute of International Education.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev Soviet Communist party chief, swept aside today whatever remained of the Geneva spirit, in the opinion of United States officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A joint Congressional subcommittee said today that tax reduction next year "might well be inflationary" and suggested that any budget surplus be applied to the national debt.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- George F. Kennan appealed today for greater attention to the problems of peace. War, he said, has brought communism its greatest advances.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted yesterday rookie Patrolman James F. Dougherty, who captured four men Wednesday night after they assertedly had robbed a drug store of $1,200.

Another volume on German naval warfare will be added to library shelves when Dutton issues next Wednesday "Night Raider of the Atlantic" by Terence Robertson. It is the story of Capt. Otto Kretschmer, German submarine commander. It describes his exploits in sinking 350,000 tons of Allied shipping "in the darkest days" of World War II, his capture by the British in 1941 and his internment in Canada.

CASEY STENGEL, the renowned world traveler, failed to put in an appearance yesterday. The man who had just completed his circumnavigation of the globe deliberately stayed away from the premiere of the world series motion pictures at Toots Shors. He doesn't like movies with unhappy endings.

Electricity power production in the week ended last Saturday reached 11,614,000,000 kilowatthours, the fourth consecutive week of record output. The figure for last week was 11,602,000,000 and for the comparable week last year it was 9,431,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

Considered a soft touch, the Chicago Black Hawks turned out to be surprisingly strong at Madison Square Garden last night. They beat the New York rangers, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League game that was witnessed by a crowd of 14,376.

MANY of the 1,100 deer hunters who attained membership in the "Biggest Bucks in Maine" Club by bringing in deer scaling, more than 200 pounds, wished they had shot smaller deer by the time they reached the nearest highway.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -Minnie C. Mangum, 51 years old, a building and loan association officer known for her personal generosity and charities, was arrested today on charges of thefts from her firm that may reach $1,000,000 or more.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Nineteen young women were introduced to society this evening at the second annual Holly Ball, held at the Scarsdale Golf Club.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 29 (UP) -- A 15-year-old 'Chicago girl has stroked her way into all four finals of the national junior girls' indoor tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -Without minimizing Soviet technological advances, United States officials doubt that the Soviet Union has built an inter-continental ballistics missile as implied by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Leonard B. Boudin, New York lawyer, asked the Federal Court of Appeals today to order the State Department to give him a temporary passport to travel abroad on legal business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Strike idleness in 1955 was less than in any year since World War II except 1954 and 1951.

Building construction in New York City showed a decline of 8 per cent in the first eleven months of 1955 compared with the corresponding period the year before, according to preliminary figures prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Cotton manufacturers tried a new tack today in their effort to combat imports from Japan.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Italian fellow travelers of the Communists urged Government today to back the efforts of Pope Pius XII toward an international accord on nuclear disarmament. The Left- Wing Socialist party announced it would "most loyally" support any "concrete political initiative" seconding the Pope's action.

The University of California at Los Angeles, the last team to beat San Francisco, will get a chance to break the Dons' thirty-five-game winning streak tonight in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival basketball tournament.
LONS-LE-SAUNIER, France, Dec. 29 -- Although Premier Edgar Faure's own re-election is assured, he is "running scared" in his own department of the Jura.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (UP) -- California's biggest reconstruction job since the earthquake of 1906 was under way over three-quarters of the state today. Bulldozers cleared away flood wreckage and debris to make way for new building projects.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions asked employers in the engineering industry today for a 15 per cent increase for nearly 3,000,000 workers.

Late selling wiped out a promising gain for the stock mark yesterday. The close was thoroughly mixed. Although ,the standard issues represented in the averages more than held their own, the market as a whole was lower.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29 -- Brazil's erratic press censorship in effect prevented today the publication of one of Rio de Janeiro's most important morning newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that $1,300,000,000 of farm products were exported during the July-November period. This was 4 per cent more than in the corresponding 1954 months, but a lag developed by November.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., scored his twentieth victory in a row tonight by knocking out Peter Mueller of Cologne, Germany, at 2 minutes 51 seconds of the second in a scheduled ten-rounder in the Milwaukee Arena.
Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss a suit against the Panama Canal Company involving "excessive" canal toll charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Four Star Productions is negotiating the sale of its television film library, involving about 115 pictures, for a figure reported to be $2,000,000. The unidentified bidders are said to be two major theatrical movie studios, two TV networks and two TV film distributing companies.
The new governments of French Morocco and Tunisia have promised to eliminate discrimination against Jews.
The case of Johnnie Kronchek found wandering in the Bronx last Monday, was solved yesterday when his astonished mother claimed him at a children's shelter.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -About 200,000 farmers in the state of Lower Saxony have decided to stage a buyers' strike for one month starting Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -Department store sales in the United States during the week before Christmas were 21 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The nation's steel-making capacity, which has risen for nine years in a row, will be rated at a record high of 128,363,090 net tons, as of Jan. 1, Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, reported yesterday.

Richard Razzetti led the advance to the semi-finals yesterday in the Eastern indoor tennis championships for juniors and boys at the 102d Engineers Armory. Razzetti, fourth seeded in the junior division, defeated William Landis, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-finals.
The Union Pacific Railroad, one of the nation's largest railroads, wants to absorb the little Spokane International Railroad.

It is now reported that there may shortly be a resumption of talks between Pakistan and Afghanistan designed to relieve the tension between the two neighbors. If this is true, and it is earnestly to be hoped that it is, there have been some wise second thoughts in Kabul after the departure of the touring Soviet salesmen.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- The long-rumored dissolution of the Hollywood Coordinating Committee was announced officially today by George Murphy, president.
State commissions and departments regulating utilities in four states served by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will meet in New York on Jan. 11 to discuss the line's service.
HARRISBURG, Dec. 29 -- Pennsylvania Republican leaders at a meeting here today decided unanimously to enter President Eisenhower's name in the preferential primary on April 24.

As one thinks of the world in the now ending year of 1955 and the great forces that swayed its major developments, colonialism -- or some would say anti-colonialism -- certainly played a major role. It is one of those basic themes that have to be identified and grappled with if one is to hear the new world symphony of 1956 with any true understanding.
Three television stations here will present special New Year's Eve programs tomorrow night. All three will carry pick-ups from the Times Square area at midnight.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that West German policy in 1956 would give priority to reunification of Germany, European unity and fighting Communist infiltration.

Stockholders of Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation will be asked at a special meeting on Feb. 7 at Houston, Tex., to approve two measures that would permit a public offering of new preferred stock in the first quarter of 1956.
