LOOKING over the decorative arts for 1955, a reporter could well observe that not only do Americans look upon their homes as their castles but -- going the English one better -- they attempt to make their homes look like castles. And castles of oriental potentates, at that! The twelve months just passed saw an unprecedented desire for color and luxury on the part of people furnishing their homes.

Delegates from twelve Southern states met in secret in Memphis this week and completed formation of a national organization to fight racial integration and what were termed "other efforts to destroy the Constitution."

IN food stores this week-end, consumers will find Long Island ducklings plentiful at moderate prices. The birds are largely frozen, packaged in transparent Cry-O-Vac bags. Very conveniently, they are ready to cook once they have been thawed. One chain sells such birds at 53 cents a pound.
The Federal Government will give approval soon for 8,000 additional subsidized low-rent apartments to be built by the New York City Housing Authority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States Government welcomed today Pope Pius XII's appeal for a world-wide system of controlled nuclear disarmament.

WHEN the Transit Authority gets new buses to replace the McDonald Avenue and Church Avenue trolleys in Brooklyn, which should be within a few weeks, only one trolley line will be left in New York City -- the Steinway stretch from Second Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street in Manhattan across Queensboro Bridge to Queens Plaza in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The State Department released the bound volumes of the Yalta documents late this afternoon after the chief of its historical division had mentioned them at a meeting here of the American Historical Association.

I am troubled by your editorial of Dec. 27 "Justice Without Juries?" I wish the question mark had been changed to an exclamation mark. I trust The Times will not fall for the argument that speed alone should determine forms of justice.

Continued cold weather in the week ended last Friday caused a further drop of 8,086,000 barrels in the nation's light fuel oil supplies, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week's end they were 117,954,000 barrels, compared with 126,040,000 a week earlier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -An overwhelming majority of Democratic leaders believe Adlai E. Stevenson is now the best bet to win their party's Presidential nomination again in 1956.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 4 to 6 points yesterday except in the near March delivery, which was off 4 points.

" Dancing in the Chequered Shade" isn't ready yet for the Broadway trade. Consequently, John van Druten's four-character comedy, which the author directed, will not arrive on Jan. 11, at the Playhouse, as scheduled.
In the past few weeks the papers generally, and The New York Times in particular, carried articles on the subject of water.
LEWES, Del., Dec. 29 -- On New Year's Day this town of 3,000 persons will become debt-free for the first time in its 325-year history.
Some unfinished business between a lawyer and his client prompted a $100 gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. The donation was one of 405 that brought in $7,578.57.

The big magazines in the women's, service and home fields usually get a major share of the advertising for such items of intimate apparel as the brassiere. Newspapers usually have been second best in terms of total linage.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The speeches of Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, party chief, were received today with cold composure in British official circles and newspaper editorials.

The coming year will see the greatest economic activity in the history of the United States, in the combined opinion of twenty economists participating in the National Industrial Conference Board's annual economic forum.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- A cameraman working for Fox Movietone News was said today to have paid a French gendarme to shoot an Algerian prisoner for a news film he was making.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in real estate transactions reported yesterday.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 30--a message from Dr. Vivian Fuchs, leader of the British Antarctic expedition, reported that on Tuesday his ship, the Theron, was trapped in ice in the Weddell Sea.
A Miami Beach labor dispute and New York repercussions yesterday.

Today's new film is "The Square Jungle," a drama about prizefighting with Ernest Borgnine, Tony Curtis and Pat Crowley, at the Palace. Albert Zugsmith produced and Jerry Hopper directed George Zuckerman's screen play for Universal-International.

WHEN Ian Stephens resigned in 1951 from his post as editor of the famous British-owned Indian newspaper The Statesman, he had lived in India for nineteen years. He resigned because it was no longer possible for an English newspaper editor to work in India and even try to write and print objective news and comment about Pakistan and Indian-Pakistani friction.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- Donald A. Quarles, making his first tour of the Far East since his appointment as Secretary of the United States Air Force, said today that he saw a "continued build-up of our strength in this area."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Hongkee Karl, the South Korean Government's information chief, has again denied that South Korea was holding any Chinese Communist fishermen, as the Communists' Peiping radio charged.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 -- The domestic life of President Sukarno came to the forefront of the Indonesian political scene today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Wendell B. Barnes, head of the Small Business Administration, ruled today that pools of small newspaper publishers are eligible for loans from his agency to build newsprint plants.
The Board of Estimate unanimously, approved yesterday the plans of Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley for an underground parking garage, the first of its kind in the city.
CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- Cairo's Arabic-language newspapers gave a full spread today to Nikita S. Khrushchev's denunciation of the West's Baghdad Pact, the defense alliance in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A new catalogue of documents on the Yalta Conference, released today, disclosed that President Franklin D. Roosevelt spent the last month of his life in a series of bitter disputes with the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Wheat showed a little firmer tone today but corn was weak and local pressure weakened soybeans. Trade was still largely of a holiday character. Weather continued in the dry Southwest, where moisture had been expected.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Notre Dame defeated Alabama tonight, 86 -- 80, and gained the final of the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament against powerful Utah.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Mark Binstein shattered three records today as he contributed 50 points in Army's 99-74 victory over Rhode Island in the consolation round of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading jockey of the year, went on another winning binge at Tropical Park today. The 23year-old lad rode four victors in a row, the last one Bronze Warrior, 17 -- 20, in the featured seventh race.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Small Business Administration announced today a new loan program aimed at meeting the credit needs of small merchants and service establishments.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Following are the texts of previously unpublished documents on the wartime conferences at Malta and Yalta released today by the State Department:

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Quiet buying today lifted The Financial Times index of industrial shares to 200, about halfway between the year's low point of 175.7 and the high of 223.9. Steel, electrical equipment and engineering shares made the best showing with gains of as much as 1s 6d (21 cents).

MONTREAL, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Production of Canada's pulp and paper industry in 1955 was a record 10,400,000 tons, compared with 9,900,000 tons in 1954, R. M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, said today.
Directors of the Reynolds Metals Company approved yesterday an issue of $40,000,000 of new preferred stock to help finance construction of its seventh aluminum reduction plant.

Loans to business outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks increased $1,605,000,000 during 1955, a year marked by broad economic expansion. In contrast these loans declined $962,000,000 in 1954.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion received a vote of confidence from his party today at a three-day meeting called by critics of his firm policy against the Arabs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- National Park Service naturalists expressed some skepticism today over the reported discovery of the "world's largest cave" near Cave City, Ky.

Skiers hoping for plenty of sport this week-end faced the strong possibility of disappointment yesterday. Reports from most of the northlands emphasized that more cover was needed for favorable ski conditions.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 29 -- Two members of the Grand National Assembly (Parliament) were expelled from the Democratic party tonight by the party's disciplinary committee. A decision on the ousting of a third Deputy was reserved by the committee.
The number of uranium stock issues filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission has been declining steadily since September, J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman, said yesterday.

Philip Morris, Inc., has formed a division to coordinate and consolidate expanding overseas operations. In making the announcement yesterday O. Parker McComas, president of the cigarette manufacturer, said Joseph F. Cullman 3d had been elected chairman and president of the Philip Morris Overseas Division.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- The acreage of East German collective farms has increased almost 66 per cent in the last eighteen months.
Detailed studies for the evacuation and survival of the metropolitan area's 16,000,000 residents in the event of a hydrogen bomb attack or other disaster will begin immediately.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 29 -- Israeli officials said tonight that negotiations for pacification of the El Auja demilitarized zone had broken down. They said Israel had accepted the plans of Mr. Hammarskjold but that the Egyptians had put forward conditions that were tantamount to rejection.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Under pressure of attacks in Congress the National Labor Relations Board has blanketed more than 300 field jobs into the "sensitive" category.

Heavy demands for capital on savings and loan associations and other suppliers of mortgage credit are causing such institutions to sell their portfolio investments to the Federal National Mortgage Association at the fastest pace since the federal corporation started its secondary market operations thirteen months ago.

The Board of Estimate yesterday appropriated $42,000,000 for new school construction. It was the largest amount ever voted by the board for this purpose at a single meeting. After the board acted, Mayor Wagner disclosed that during 1955 the city has appropriated a total of $114,500,000 to build new schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced today the personnel of the group's Economic Policy Commitee.

TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that unless state revenues exceed present anticipations in the next six months new taxes or cutbacks in state spending might become unavoidable in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

EACH of David Oistrakh's Carnegie Hall appearances has generated its particular excitement. First came the two recitals. Last week there was the excitement of his playing three concertos with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

The British pioneers in the revolutionary world of jet air transportation must have felt a justifiable glow of satisfaction at the completion of the pace-setting round-the-world trip of Britain's newest commercial jet airliner, the De Havilland Comet Mark III.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Karen Ann McGuire has her horse. She did not have to ransom a kingdom for it or, in fact, pay a cent. Karen is the 12-year-old girl who, having read that the champion racehorse Nashua was to be sold at auction earlier this month, put in her "sealed bid" of $24.03 for any of Nashua's equine friends "that no one will buy."

Samuel who had Reshevsky, who had held the lead since the beginning of the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy chess tournament at the Marshall Club, lost it yesterday. He sustained his second defeat in his adjourned game from the eigth round with Walter J. Shipman.
NEW ORLENS., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Dick Savitt today overpowered Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the quarterfinals of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that American industry in 1955 consumed a peacetime record amount of 1,486,000 tons of refined copper.

A Jamaica, Queens, woman saw bundles of envelopes through the grill of a storm sewer yesterday. As a result, two Queens men are to be charged today in Brooklyn Federal court with dumping Christmas mail.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The two ranking Soviet leaders loosed today their sharpest criticism of the West since the Geneva spirit arose.

Bank clearings of the twenty-six leading cities of the nation for the Christmas week ended on Wednesday amounted to $18,909,226,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was 5.1 per cent below the $19,934,270,000 of the comparable 1954 week, when the holiday fell on Saturday and had little effect on transactions.

Details of a plan for a public athletic facility to be built at the south end of Morningside Park by Columbia University were announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
A steel pellet, probably fired by a powerful sling shot according to the police, punctured a window yesterday in the office of Assistant District Attorney Karl Grebow.
Installation of newspaper vending racks in city-owned buses is being considered by the Transit Authority.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation has sold the Jefferson Hotel in St. Louis to the Sheraton Corporation of America, it was announced here yesterday. The price was announced as $7,500,000 plus adjustments.

Cottonseed oil futures climbed yesterday for the sixth consecutive trading day on the New York Produce Exchange. Most months hit new seasonal highs on the third largest volume of the year. New buying, short covering and hedge lifting offset profit taking and hedge selling. Trading was influenced by good export demand and strength in crude oil prices in the South.
The Board of Education awarded thirteen school contracts totaling $36,773,530 yesterday at its final meeting of the year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The dating of ancient glass, which has often baffled scholars, is now on the verge of close assessment.
ANDREW ROSENTHAL'S "Third Person," which was acted at the President last evening, is a soberly written play about some post-war neurotics.
TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church of Jersey City and its Holy Name Society were charged here today with having violated state laws governing bingo and raffles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The railroads today won the first round of the contest for a short-cut freight rate increase. The Interstate Commerce Commission issued an order removing all legal barriers from a general 7 per cent rate rise.

If Mrs. Mabel Morris parlays her expert knowledge of Dickens to win the top prize on the $64,000 Question television program, the public treasury will benefit even more. heavily than from previous winners.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- West Virginia joined Miami in the final of the Orange Bowl basketball tournament tonight with a 70-60 triumph over Columbia.

ATLANTA, Dec. 29 -- One of the artificial moons to be launched by the United States in 1958 will travel in an orbit as high as 800 miles above the earth. This was disclosed here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The price of lead was raised one-half cent a pound yesterday, to 16 cents, New York -- the highest level since early October of 1952. The St. Joseph Lead Company initiated the advance, which was soon matched by other sellers.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals has upheld the legality of construction of a new high school near Schenectady. Many districts have delayed construction pending the decision.
An Air Force pilot bailed out of his F-86D Sabre Jet over the south shore of Long Island last evening after running out of fuel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- General Kuter has said the latest intelligence estimates show the Communists have more than 7,000 aircraft in Asia. The United States has about 2,000 stationed there.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message is expected to include an appeal to Congress to put foreign aid on a long-term basis, Administration officials said today.

In an editorial in the Dec. 21 issue of The Times you accurately described the current situation in the Middle East as a "time of troubles." But I do not believe you were so accurate in your analysis of the cause of these "troubles."
" SAMSON ET DALILA" was restored to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera last night after a two-season absence. Rise Stevens and Ramon Vinay sang the principal roles, and Pierre Monteux conducted.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Savage gales with gusts up to 70 miles an hour lashed the British Isles today, halting ocean liners and sending little ships scuttling for shelter.
The Standard Oil Company of California and the Texas Company have received seven exploratory concessions covering a total of 1,235,000 acres in the Philippines, the companies announced yesterday.

MONTREAL. Dec. 29 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored the 500th goal of his National Hockey League career, including play-off games, when the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2, tonight.

We do not so much mind the report, made by Dr. Frank Press of the California Institute of Technology to the American Physical Society at Los Angeles this week, that the moon does not consist of a chunk of something or other that used to occupy what is now the Pacific Ocean.

Ike Matza, a New York University junior, and Reginald Pearman of the Pioneer Club scored impressive victories in the feature events of a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union development track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 29 (UP) -Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., moved into the semi-finals of the Asia lawn tennis championships today with a 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5 triumph over Ramanatan Krishnan of India.
A front-page item on Dec. 23 reads, "The season's heaviest snowstorm caught forecasters by surprise yesterday."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) --The Administration is expected to urge Congress to pool unused immigration quotas and modify the controversial fingerprinting requirement for most foreign visitors.
The steel-making capacity of the United States, by far the largest in the world, has increased sizably this year. And it's going to jump again, by a big margin -- and fast.

CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia had his first long formal talk today with Egypt's Premier, Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser. The two avowed neutralist leaders of the Mediterranean area were said to have covered the whole range of international affairs, including the troubled Middle East.

Shortly after Mayor O'Dwyer began his second term on Jan. 1, 1950, the word was given out that a survey of all the departments of the city government would be made with the aim of increasing efficiency and reducing operating costs. This became the Mayor's Management Survey, with Dr. Luther Gulick in charge of "the most momentous review of civic management ever undertaken."
A fleet of unmarked police cars will ride herd on city traffic over the New Year's week-end in a desperate move to cut the accident toll.

The fifteen commercial banks that make up the membership of the New York City Clearing House Association held daily average deposits during 1955 of $25,409,057,000, highest since 1947 when they totaled $22,741, 983,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate, has proposed that a prayer be spoken at the opening of United Nations General Assembly meetings.
TORONTO, Dec. 29 -- Three of the Dionne quintuplets decided today to go home and make a New Year's peace with their embittered parents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) --The Administration is expected to urge Congress to pool unused immigration quotas and modify the controversial fingerprinting requirement for most foreign visitors.
The steel-making capacity of the United States, by far the largest in the world, has increased sizably this year. And it's going to jump again, by a big margin -- and fast.

CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia had his first long formal talk today with Egypt's Premier, Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser. The two avowed neutralist leaders of the Mediterranean area were said to have covered the whole range of international affairs, including the troubled Middle East.

Shortly after Mayor O'Dwyer began his second term on Jan. 1, 1950, the word was given out that a survey of all the departments of the city government would be made with the aim of increasing efficiency and reducing operating costs. This became the Mayor's Management Survey, with Dr. Luther Gulick in charge of "the most momentous review of civic management ever undertaken."
ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 29 -- When the church builds on racial segregation, it builds on "very rotten foundations," a clergyman from Southern Rhodesia declared here today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the text of addresses to the Supreme Soviet today by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, as issued in English by Tass, the Soviet news agency:
Operation Beefsteak, described by an airline official as the "largest cattle airlift in history," takes to the air today.
KEY WEST, Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower looked out his window at Florida sand and palms today and painted a picture of his beloved Colorado mountains.
Assemblyman Thomas A. Duffy of Queens was designated yesterday as the Democratic candidate in a special election to fill a vacancy in the State Senate.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 -- The Central Committee of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party has been increased from forty-six to sixty-one members.
The pioneer of home freezers is about to be laid to rest.

YONKERS, Dec. 29 -- As the members of the Board of Education met late this afternoon to complete their report to the State Education Commissioner there were strong indications that they would declare the public school program for 1956 "inadequate."
LONDON, Dec 29 -- Flag discrimination by other nations was described today as one of the most serious threats the British shipping industry has ever had to face.
The chairmen of two of the nation's leading steel companies issued year-end statements yesterday saying that 1955 has been the industry's best year to date.
Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank New York, suggested yesterday that the Federal Reserve System receive permanent authority to regulate consumer credit.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Union contended today that illegal dealings in Soviet currency were going on in the United States and warned prospective tourists that buying rubles outside the Soviet Union was illegal.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 29 -- Yale Divinity School has embarked on a $6,500,000 expansion program that may lead eventually to the establishment here of an institute of advanced theological studied. The seminary's "master plan" was announced today by the Rev. Dr. Liston Pope, dean of the Divinity School.

The Federal Reserve System pumped a little more money into the commercial banking system in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PITSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The president of Koppers Company, Inc., in a year-end state-ment said his concern would spend $25,000,000 next year to expand and improve present facilities and construct new plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The threat of new dust storms hangs over wide areas of the Great Plains, the Agriculture Department reported today.
The Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis rejected unanimously yesterday some of the claims made on behalf of the "so-called Yonan Codex," a manuscript of the New Testament in Syriac.

Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland created a sensation in the international chess tournament at Hastings by winning from Mark Taimanov of Russia in the first round, according to a report received yesterday from London. The victor is 20 years old, the youngest of the ten competitors.

Basketball fans who are unhappy over the current heavy unbalance of the court sport in favor of the offense have reason to feel gratified at developments in Wednesday's semi-finals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -Charles J. Lowen, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, urged New York City and the Port of New York Authority today to settle their dispute over the site for a Manhattan heliport.
A Bronx man who operated driving school illegally for three years found yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court that Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was in the driver's seat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The real concern in the Government over some aspects of the galloping boom of 1955 is finally coming to public expression. Today the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, publicly forecast some probable "breathing spells" in the industrial economy "later on," but added that slowdowns in the boom would not be troublesome "if the Government and the people act wisely" (an "if" of record-breaking proportions).
THE young American pianist, Rosemary Clarke, made her New York debut last night in Town Hall.
The publisher of the Dominican Republic's leading newspaper said yesterday he was seeking asylum here because an error in a picture caption angered Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo.

The New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, yesterday to investigate the Federation for Constitutional Government as "subversive."
Harry Gross was held in $50,000 bail yesterday in Kings County Court when he was arraigned on a charge of swindling a Brooklyn dress shop owner.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30--The Columbia Pictures Corporation will lease, rather than sell, 104 of its old feature films to television.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- The United Nations truce supervisor, Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, reported today that Syria violated the armistice agreement by firing on an Israeli police boat in the Sea of Galilee Dec. 10.

The New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins will meet in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 13,000 fans is expected to see the contest which is to begin at 8:30.
Police Capt. Robert R. J. Gallati, who is an attorney and a Naval Reserve officer, was promoted yesterday to deputy inspector and named the new head of the Police Academy.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 30 -- The military campaign against the Communist terrorists in Malaya will be stepped up immediately following the breakdown of talks between Government and Communist officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that manufacturers' sales and new orders both climbed in November, on a seasonally adjusted basis. At the month's end manufacturers had a backlog of work orders amounting to about $53,750,000,000.

A busboy at the El Morocco Restaurant in New York City gets $80 a week for carrying dishes to the kitchen and back, or fetching a table. A teacher in the public schools of Yonkers, in well-to-do Westchester County, gets a starting salary of $61.50 a week, after having spent at least four years acquiring a college education.
PINEHURST, N. C., Dec. 30 -- General of the Army George C. Marshall will mark his seventyfifth birthday anniversary quietly tomorrow.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 30 -- Prof. Aaron M. Sakolski, 75 years old, for eighteen years a member of the Department of Economics land Statistics at City College School of Business in New York before retiring nine years ago, was killed last night when an automobile in which he was riding skidded on an icy highway and was in collision with another automobile.

PASSAIC, N. J., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Botany Mills, Inc., announced today that it was disposing of its sole remaining textile operation -- a dyeing and finishing plant here -- by setting up an affiliate company, Clarence Worsted. The plant, which employed as many as 6,000 persons during World War II, now has a force of about, 150.
A large section of Times Square became no man's land for more than half an hour yesterday when a simulated bomb was found.
TORONTO, Dec. 31 -- The rift in the Dionne family apparently has been healed.

ATHENS, Dec. 30 -- Authoritative Greek sources said tonight that conversations between the British Governor of Cyprus, Field Marshal Sir John Harding, and Archbishop Makarios, leader of the Greey Cypriotes, would probably be resumed in the New Year with "good prospects of success."

Supreme Court Justices Philip M. Kleinfeld of Brooklyn and James T. Hallinan of Queens will be designated by Governor Harriman to serve on the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Robert R. Nathan, an officer of Americans for Democratic Action, said today he thought that President Eisenhower could be defeated if he ran again. But Mr. Nathan thinks the President will retire "for health reasons."
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 30 -A mathematical way to judge whether art is "good" or "bad" was discussed here today.

PHILADELPHIA has a strong claim (based on the activities of the enormous Peale family of artists) to be considered the cradle of American realist painting. Down through the nineteenth century, with Eakins and, later, the circle that formed around Robert Henri, this tradition continued to flourish. It is not yet extinct, as a visit to Harvey Dinnerstein's show of recent drawings at the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street should prove.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -James Kutcher, who lost his legs fighting for the .United States in World War II, declared today that he was innocent of disloyalty charges brought against him by unidentified informers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 30 -Nationalist China will definitely withdraw from the International Sugar Agreement next year unless its annual sugar export quota of 600,000 tons is increased, Yang Chi Tseng, manager of the Governmentowned Taiwan Sugar Corporation, announced today.
KAINAN BAY, Antarctica, Dec. 29 -- The Kainan Bay area was chosen today to be the site of Little America V, the major station in support of the current United States Antarctic program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- With the use of a technique new to archaeology, a scholar has identified a widespread litter of stony wreckage in the arid central Negev as the network of an ancient system of irrigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A Senate investigating panel charged today that the wholesale recantations, by Harvey M. Matusow, a former Government witness against alleged Communists, had developed into a definite and deliberate aid to Red strategy here and abroad.
Nineteen new captains and twenty-five new correction officers were sworn into duty in the Correction Department yesterday by Commissioner Anna M. Kross. Three of the new captains were women.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 30 (UP)--Snowbound Alaskans from here to Yakutat dug out today from an early winter snowfall of unusual intensity.

MELBOURNE, Australia Dec. 30 -- Rex Ingamells, 42-year-old South Australian poet and author, was killed in a road accident today. The automobile in which he was traveling overturned after a tire blew out near Dimboola, Victoria.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau issued today the following forecast and list of winter sports conditions:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- An organization raising funds for the purchase of an ancient Bible text, known as the Yonan Codex, says questioning of the $1,500,00 price tag put on the manuscript comes from "disgruntled persons."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -"Dig that channel" is expected to be the theme in the next session of Congress for a bipartisan chorus of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware members of Congress.

Switching of holdings for tax purposes accounted for most of the volume yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Although most markets were open only a half day, trading was active. Balancing of holdings for the year-end also added to the volume.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, the nation's No. 1 amateur, and a former Wimbledon champion, Dick Savitt, today slugged their way into the singles final of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.

Appraising the Yankees for the press before taking off for Glendaie, Calif., on the last leg of an around-the-world journey. Casey Stengel exuded confidence yesterday. He said the Bombers were strong enough as they stood to repeat their 1955 American League pennant victory.
FLUSHING, the Netherlands, Dec. 30 (UP) -- An American Liberty Ship that smashed a hole in one of the Netherlands' dikes was placed in custody today by Dutch authorities.
Midnight in Times Square tonight will be signaled by the descent of a 180-bulb ball of light that will be making its forty-ninth New Year's journey to the base of the flagpole atop the Times Tower.

The Assembly of Captive European Nations declared here yesterday that the anger of Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party in his speech Thursday was provoked by "the very fact that the truth has once again been imparted to the captive peoples" by United States leaders.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30--The American Association for the Advancement of Science took formal action today on the question whether to hold its annual meetings in any city in which racial segregation is practiced.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Ford Motor Company today filed two registration statements covering the sale of stock available only to its key employes under option plans.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A 25 to 50 cents drop in butcher hogs today left them not far above the fourteen-year low on the last trading session of the year. Sows sold steady to 25 cents lower.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today that was issued by James C. Hagerty, President Eisenhower's Press Secretary, and approved by the President and by Secretary of State Dulles, on the liberation of the captive European peoples.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, the all-America halfback from Ohio State, makes his final appearance as an amateur gridiron star tomorrow as he leads the East against the West in the thirty-first annual Shrine game at Kezar Stadium.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The stock markets here ended 1955 quietly with volume of business far below normal.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Cambodia's governing party, headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, voted unanimously today to accept more United States aid for this Indochinese mountain kingdom.

The new coordinating group formed in the South to fight for segregation, with the blessing of Senator Eastland of Mississippi and former Governor Talmadge of Georgia, calls itself the Federation for Constitutional Government. Somehow it seems misnamed, for from the accounts of its recent organization meeting in Memphis its aim is apparently to circumvent the Constitution as interpreted by the Supreme Court.
Prices of cotton futures moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 5 points (25 cents a bale) off yesterday. Strength was most pronounced in the near months.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Dick Lindheimer of Miami won the Orange Bowl regatta's nine-hour marathon today with an average speed of 40.561 miles an hour. Only twenty of the forty-two starters finished.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist warship Yungning damaged five Communist gunboats Wednesday night during a Nationalist Commando raid in the Matsu Islands areas, the newspaper Hsin Sheng Pao said today.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong wound up a threemonth tour of Europe on a high key tonight -- and with one blue note.

Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland was again a winner in the third round of the international masters tournament in progress at the annual chess congress in Hastings, England, yesterday, but was tied for first place at 2 1/2 -- 1/2 by Victor Korchnoi of Russia.

A major airline cuts absenteeism by 20 per cent. A pharmaceutical company persuades thousands of druggists to modernize their merchandising practices. An appliance giant teaches its supervisors how to run a successful conference.
A conference with the Automobile Club of New York over racial bias issues was sought yesterday by nine organizations.

SHALL we resolve, on this last day of the old year, to turn our backs on iceberg lettuce and seek more flavorful greens? Shall we bid good-by to the flaccid, ready-to-eat hams and vow to obtain the old-fashioned country hams of character?
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Two of Governor Harriman's top aides reported today that his first year in office had been favorable for "management, labor, stockholders and small business men."

HARTFORD, Dec. 30 -- The order by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to suspend for thirty days the driving rights of first-offender speeders in this state found its first victim today -- a New York City driver.

The Court of Appeals has ruled in Albany that vacation pay or other fringe benefits accruing under a contract between employer and employe may not be termed wages within the definition of the Penal Law.

An election has been in progress in Laos, smallest of the Indochinese states which have recently become independent. This election was envisaged in the Geneva agreements of last year and its purpose was to set up a representative government for all of Laos. In the interim the Communists were allowed to retain control of the two most northerly provinces of the country.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- North Carolina, trailing by 16 points in the first half, staged a spectacular comeback to knock Duke from the unbeaten ranks tonight, 74 -- 64. The Tarheels gained the final of the Dixie Classic against North Carolina State, which had defeated Wake Forest, 70 -- 58, this afternoon.
Satiris Galahad Fassoulis, 33year-old former wealthy promoter, was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with a $350,000 fraud perpetrated on two banks.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference Commissioner, Bernie Moore, Today fined the University of Alabama $1,000 for illegal recruiting activities by Alabama supporters.

ST. ETIENNE, France, Dec. 29 -- When Antoine Pinay, the Foreign Minister, arrived in the small country town of Feurs to make a campaign speech at 11:30 A. M. the weather was mild. Under leafless trees in the village square, children skipped ropes and dogs played hide and seek.
MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- Western observers commented today that the dualism of Soviet foreign policy had now become more pronounced than ever.
New York's department and specialty stores this week maintained their record sales pace by staging the most widespread preNew Year clearances in years.

As 1955 passes into history the cold war resumed by the Soviets has taken a turn that casts a new shadow over the New Year. In speeches before the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet leaders have reaffirmed their opposition to any solution of existing international problems that does not disintegrate and disarm the West and, in doing so, have introduced at the top level a degree of acrimony rarely known even under Stalin.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (AP) -The year 1955 was the greatest in the Aluminum Company of America's history and the company looks for even greater growth in 1956, I. W. Wilson, Alcoa president, said today.

As a result of injuries to three patrolmen last week in traffic accidents, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy took steps yesterday to protect his men. As an experiment he ordered six traffic patrolmen on the 4 to midnight tour last night to wear white caps, belts and gloves of reflective material so they could be seen more easily by motorists.
An elderly man now retired and living in St. Petersburg, Fla., sent $5 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and recalled his own childhood as an orphan.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 31 -Japan begins tomorrow a weeklong celebration of the coming of the New Year.

There need be no reason for surprise over the breakdown of "truce" negotiations in Malaya. The Communist terrorists had been losing ground steadily in the field. So their leader, Chin Peng, proposed these talks in which he would discuss the terms under which the Communists would call off their overt operations in Malaya. The chiefs of government in the federation and in Singapore agreed to meet with him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 672,355 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,233 cars, or 5.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 111,160 cars, or 19.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 191,377 cars, or 39.8 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A moderate increase took place this week in the backlog of corporate financing coming to market. Bonds and preferred stocks for which definite offering dates had been set totaled $198,018,240 yesterday, according to the Investment Dealers Digest.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 30 -- This Fairfield County town wants Lewes, Del., to know that it is not the only debt-free town in the country.

Additional space in Long Island City, Queens, has been acquired by the World Wide Automobile Corporation in an expansion move. The company distributes Volkswagen automobiles and products to dealers in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Delaware.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Auburn will play Vanderbilt tomorrow in the Gator Bowl. Some 36,000 fans are expected to witness the meeting of Southeastern Conference football powers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The index of average primary market prices advanced 0.2 point over the week ended on Tuesday to 111.4 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 30 -The White House reaffirmed today that United States foreign policy was aimed at the peaceful liberation of "captive peoples."

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the New York and Richmond Gas Company to establish basic fees for several types of service for which charges in the past were made on a haphazard basis.
The Cities Service Company will end twenty-nine years of network radio broadcasting on Jan. 16.

TROY, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's two goals within 2 minutes 13 seconds broke a 1-1 tie and enabled the Engineers to defeat Princeton, 3 -- 2, in the R. P. I. hockey tourney tonight.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 30--President Eisenhower virtually completed today his State of the Union message outlining the Administration's legislative program for the new Congress.

A wage formula providing for a 16 1/2-cent across-the-board hourly pay increase, plus improvements in holiday and vacation clauses, ended the threat of a tie-up of tug and ferry fleets in four harbors. The agreement was announced last night by Federal Mediator A. Alfred Della Corte.

ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 30 -- A primary task of the church in the modern world is to smash the barriers of racial segregation and prejudice everywhere, Christian leaders from East and West said here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 -- Despite the speeches yesterday by Soviet leaders criticizing the West, the Yugoslav Government professed optimism today about a further relaxation of tension in the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, urged today that all states push ahead with their anti-poliomyelitis campaigns, using available supplies of Salk vaccine as rapidly as possible.
BROCKVILLE, Ont., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The daughter of the late Mayor, Charles Hanna of Syracuse, N. Y., was charged with murder tonight in the fatal shooting of a fishing guide in her island cottage.
The Playwrights Company has renewed its interest in Jean Anouilh's romantic comedy, "Time Remembered," for a Broadway presentation this season.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- The Church Times, a religious weekly newspaper, has criticized Queen Elizabeth's Christmas message to her peoples for not referring specifically to the birth of Christ.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 30 -The Flying Dutchmen of Hofstra College won their own invitation tournament by defeating Muhlenberg, 91 -- 78, in Calkins gymnasium tonight.

VANCOUVER, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The first shipment of Alberta crude oil to California is scheduled for Sunday, Trans Mountain Oil Pipe Line Company announced today. Tide Water Associated Oil Company has purchased 118,000 barrels of Alberta crude which will be delived by tanker in a single shipment to San Francisco.
An off-duty probationary fireman on his way to a luncheon engagement stopped yesterday to rescue two little boys from a fire that apparently had started when a kerosene stove exploded.

SAGINAW, Mich., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Michigan Bean Company voted unanimously today to merge with the Wickes Corporation of Saginaw. The merger will be effective at the close of business tomorrow.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Wes Santee, the longlegged Kansan who has been trying to crack the four-minute mile for three years, ran under ideal conditions tonight but fell short of his goal by more than six seconds.

" STYLES in career women have changed a lot in the past twenty years, but business schools and colleges don't seem to have caught on yet," a career "woman" of two years' experience commented this week. "For 1956 I'm giving up tailored suits and the efficient manner.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP) -A partly disabled veterans, who holds the Bronze Star Medal for bravery and spent thirty-three months in a North Korean prison, declared today that he had been branded as a Red collaborator and was denied $2,507 in prisoner-of-war claims.

YONKERS, Dec. 30 -- With the deadline only a day away, the Board of Education late this afternoon completed its report to the State Education Commissioner. It will be sent to Albany as soon as it is put in shape, probably tomorrow.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 30 -President Ngo Dinh Diem announced today that 100,000 refugees would soon be resettled permanently on abandoned riceland in southwestern Vietnam.

Doubtlessly a large number of the fatal accidents in the recent "Black Christmas" massacre on the highways were caused by rear-end collisions. The speed with which a car can be stopped lies in the physical formula: braking distance equals the square of the velocity of the auto divided by thirty times the coefficient of friction of the road, plus the distance the car moves during a person's reaction time.
Many farmers will appreciate your editorial of Dec. 22 on "Revolution in Agriculture."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered railroad freight rates cut on many shipments to, from and within the Far West.

Stocks tried hard yesterday to end 1955 at a new high, but fell short by a small margin. Under the leadership of du Pont, which ran up 3 3/8, and General Electric, up 1 7/8, they made the best gains in a month. Volume expanded to 2,820,000 shares from 2,190,000 on Thursday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A proposal to expel any member school that bars qualified Negro students failed to pass today at the annual meeting of the Association of American Law Schools.
The Long Island Rail Road had difficulty again last month in making both ends meet.
Tuskegee Institute and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed somewhat divergent reports yesterday on the progress of race relations in 1955.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department received yesterday the following reports on winter sports conditions:
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Butler put on a display of Hoosier basketball skill tonight to defeat a touring Princeton team, 89 -- 70.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- The National Broadcasting Company is moving to strengthen its Saturday schedule of children's television programs. The network will add "Choose Up Sides" on Jan. 7.
The woman of 1956 will be surrounded by less mystery than any female in history, says The United Press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A Japanese language telegraph printer was patented this week. It is designed to print more than 2,300 characters.
The Urban League of Greater New York will present its first labor-management award to a union leader and a management representative of the baking industry on Wednesday.
Sales and earnings of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company in the six months ended Nov. 30 declined from the corresponding period a year ago.

CHICAGO, Dee. 30 -- Grain and soybean futures, after being under pressure at times early today, turned strong in late trading. Covering by shorts followed commission buying. Early in the session there was some belated long liquidation for tax purposes, but commission absorption was active on the setbacks.

Flotations of new bonds in December fell off to the smallest volume since July and were the lightest for a December since 1952. But stock issues, down only slightly from November, were the largest for any December since 1951.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Hundreds of persons attempting to stir up trouble for the new Government have been arrested, but the forces against it are strong.
New York churchgoers will mark the end of 1955 tonight. Thousands will attend Watch Night services, where in prayer and song the old year will be bade farewell and the New Year welcomed.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 30 (AP) -West Virginia's accuracy at the foul line helped the Mountaineers to an 83-78 victory over the University of Miami in the final of the Orange Bowl basketball tournament before a crowd of 3,571 tonight.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Nancy O'Connell, a 15year-old player from Chicago, set a tournament record by capturing the four titles in the national junior girls' indoor tennis championships that concluded tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- A French camera man denied today that he had paid a gendarme to shoot an Algerian rebel prisoner for a news film. His denial later received official support.
PARIS, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A ground personnel strike that paralyzed French airports for fifty-one days collapsed today with a back-to-work movement of strikers seeking to collect back-pay checks.

Show business, engaged these recent months in honoring Helen Hayes' fifty years of service to the American theatre, capped its homage last night with a $50-aplate champagne supper dance in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Six records were set and one was tied in the third annual Holiday track meet sponsored by the University of Chicago Track Club tonight.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The automobile industry fell short of its coveted 8,000,000-passenger -units production goal for 1955 by 59,138 cars, or about one and one-half normal production days, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Academy of Architecture today called a news conference whose main purpose seemed to be to establish that the academy's president, Alexander V. Vlasov, was in good standing.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 30 -- Debate on Guatemala's new Constitution was ended at 6 A. M. today by the National Constituent Assembly. It is slated to go into force March 1, 1956.

The five-story tenement at 347 East Sixty-first Street will be converted into a modern apartment house by a client of Max S. Seidler, attorney, who purchased it from the estates of Julia Landera and Jonas Litt. The building is on a plot 25 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Weather Bureau proposed today some changes in the language of weather forecasting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Farm prices continued to decline in the month ended Dec. 15, falling 1 per cent to make farm prices 7 per cent below the level a year earlier, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

The major redeployment of the Army during the next fiscal year will emphasize armored and airborne units in Europe. In the Far East, Okinawa will be stressed as a base as United States troops in Japan are reduced in numbers.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation took delivery of two Bristol Britannia 100 turbo-prop airliners today. A few hours earlier the craft received an unrestricted airworthiness certificate from the Air Registration Board.
A free Polish merchant marine, in spirit if not in flag and country of registry, will come into being next week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -Lieut. Gen. Randolph McCall Pate, who started his military career as an Army enlisted man, was sworn in today as the new commandant of the Marine Corps.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Janice Rule, who shared top billing with Ralph Meeker in the stage production of "Picnic," will be teamed again with the actor in "Brief Rapture," for Republic Pictures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Dr. Avery S. Hoyt, an Agriculture Department scientist whose pest control research helped protect service men and civilians from disease in World War II, will retire tomorrow after forty-four years in state and Federal service.

HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai has proposed the resumption of through traffic on the Canton-Kowloon railway, according to a Hong Kong University delegation that returned here today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Alan Lennox-Boyd, British Colonial Secretary, described the British Commonwealth of nations today as a free association of peoples unique in history.
The New York City Omnibus Corporation has ordered 100 air-conditioned buses for use in Manhattan and Queens.
A good year for most Americans, 1955 will be committed to history at 12 o'clock tonight with the usual mixture of saturnalia and solemnity.
THERE'S one New York career woman who ice-skates in a Zuckerman suit with a cashmere sweater underneath. There are grandmothers who skate in velvet hats, and teen-agers who skate in Bermuda shorts.
Prof. Charles S. Ascher has been chosen an associate director of the Institute of Public Administration, 684 Park Avenue. He is Chairman of the Political Science Department at Brooklyn College.
HILLSIDE, N. J., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A. Hillside High School junior, who recently flunked a life-saving test, saved a younger boy from drowning in the Elizabeth River yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said today that if the Communists started anything in Korea "we are ready."
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The State Conference Board of Farm Organizations urged Governor Harriman today to work for a statutory open shop.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 30 -Westchester should vote no further restrictions on the use of its recreational facilities before 1957, the County Park Commission reported today.
WATERVILLE, Me., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Connecticut tonight won the New England basketball tournament for the second time in three years. The Uconns beat Colby, 79 -- 71, in the final.

The port's regular longshoremen fared better financially in the past year than in any previous period for which statistics are available, according to Local 856 of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Robert E. Lewis, economist of the First National City Bank of New York, said yesterday the present record high in consumer credit was not, in itself, a cause for alarm. It is part of our growing economy, he added, and it will go higher unless there is a major economic reversal.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- There were 420 successful candidates in the state bar examination given Nov. 2 and 3, the State Board of Law Examiners announced today. There were 920 applicants.

One thing that is going to make a good deal of difference in the speed and degree toward which the Western World moves toward the reducing of trade barriers is the extent to which countries other than the United States are able to build up their reserves of gold and dollars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The nation's railroads today gave formal public notice of their intention to raise freight rates by 7 per cent, effective Feb. 25.

The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday it has redesignated Jay E. Crane as chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Federal Reserve Agent for 1956. Mr. Crane is vice president of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.).
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 -Brazil's trade with the Communist nations reached a record level this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today directed Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, Kansas City, to refund within fifteen days $36,116,056, plus interest at 6 per cent annually to some fifty wholesale users of natural gas in the Midwest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The State Department revealed today it was investigating a complaint that a Chinese student was being held in the United States against his will.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The American Red Cross said today "this country was harder hit" by natural disasters during 1955 "than for many years."
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 30 (AP) -The United States agreed today to give South Korea an additional $25,000,000 for this fiscal year to bolster its sagging economy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -The Treasury announced today that its short-term borrowing costs had dropped after increasing steadily for more than a month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- V. K. Krishna Menon, representative of India at the United Nations General Assembly, commended today the appeal of Pope Pius XII for a ban on nuclear explosions and the use of atomic weapons.
Foreign political leaders paid tribute yesterday to the late President Woodrow Wilson, whose centennial anniversary will be observed next year.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Britain has agreed to increase her economic aid to Jordan next year by 500,000 ($1,400,000) to a total of 3,350,000 ($9,380,000). The increase is designed to speed development of a deep water port at Aqaba, at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba. The rapidly developing Israeli port of Elath is near by.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 -- The arrest of 125 persons accused as subversives was ordered today by the Provisional President, Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu. He acted under state-of-siege regula tions.

EVERY year about this time most women quietly make little resolutions to themselves about how they intend to look the following year. In this modern age, these promises can be radical, as changing from brunette to blonde, or from size 16 to 10.
TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Communist North Korea has reshuffled its Cabinet, the Pyongyang Government newspaper Minju Choson (Democratic Korea) says.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- It is reasonable to expect that 1956 will be an arduous year for the United States and its allies. The U. S. S. R.'s leadership clearly intends to press the struggle for ideological ascendancy. Both Bulganin and Khrushchev are brimming with confidence that, by means short of war, communism can gain world paramountcy in an era of all-out competitive coexistence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -The Department of Justice announced today that $44,000,000 in claims and counter-claims revolving around Government use of steel rolling patterns during World War II have been Washed out by agreements.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Cincinnati crushed Richmond, 89 -- 60, and won the second annual Richmond invitation basketball tournament tonight.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Bobby Ussery, the leading jockey at the meeting, rode three winners at Tropical Park today as Willie Hartack failed on eight straight mounts. This made Ussery's total thirty-two, three ahead of Hartack.

Directors of ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., have elected Nathan W. Lurie of Detroit as chairman and Sylvan N. Goldman of Oklahoma City as president, it was announced yesterday. Other new officers are John E. Lurie of Detroit, executive vice president, and Norman Hirchfield of Oklahoma City, financial vice president and acting treasurer.

Willard Maas, experimental film-maker, will present a program of short films on Friday at 8:15 P. M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The program is second in the series "16mm. -- New World of Cinema" under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -Two major airlines opened a court fight today on the recent Civil Aeronautics Board order granting nonscheduled air services more freedom in operations.

AT the Village Art Center, 39 Grove Street, a show of sculpture and drawings continues this institution's policy of offering exhibition space to artists who have not yet established regular gallery connections.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing said today the 11,954 persons deported from the United States during 1955 included thirty-five alien subversives.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 30 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett summoned the Soviet Ambassador today and conveyed to him the Government's view of criticisms of Israel made by Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief.

Directors of the City Auto Stamping Company yesterday voted a 100 per cent stock dividend, subject to stockholder approval at a special meeting on Feb. 1, 1956. Shareholders also will be asked to vote on an increase in authorized capital shares to 1,000,000 from 500,000.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The state's two top Republican legislative leaders issued a six-count indictment of Governor Harriman's Democratic State Administration today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Notre Dame won its second straight Sugar Bowl basketball tourney tonight, defeating Utah, 70 -- 65. John Smyth, a forward, turned in a 27-point effort for the Irish.
Business on the New York Stock Exchange in 1955 shared the glowing statistics of the nation's economic barometers. Trading on the Exchange was the largest since 1933.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A 23-year-old former high school and college basketball captain was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army Medical Forces today to set a record.
Mayor Wagner signed a local law yesterday granting tax exemption and abatement to lands lords who rehabilitate substandard tenement houses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -President Eisenhower's message to the peoples of five Soviet satellite countries, which caused sharp criticism in Moscow yesterday, was regarded as "normal." in most quarters here today.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- Pope Pius XII has urged Roman Catholics in Poland not to collaborate with the Communist regime. The admonition was contained in an apostolic letter sent to the Polish hierarchy three weeks ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Leaders of the American Federation of Teachers accused the Eisenhower Administration today of trying to dodge the recommendations of the White House Conference on Education.

Three apartment buildings at 402, 404 and 406 Albee Square, near Fulton Street, in downtown Brooklyn have been sold by the estate of Helen B. Fredericks to a customer of John F. James Sons, Inc., brokers in the transaction. The property has an assessed valuation of $87,000.
The weather has dashed hope that two major stretches of the Third Avenue elevated would be completely removed by New Year's Eve.

Somewhere among the thousands of skillful amateur wrestlers across the nation are sixteen outstanding grapplers who will win a place on the American team that competes in the 1956 Olympic Games at Melbourne next November.
Motorists throughout the state are receiving a special New Year's message from Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The American Historical Association was told today that the pattern of segregation against the Negro of distinction still persisted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today his House UnAmerican Activities Committee intended to question Dr. Robert M. Hutchins about the views of the Fund for the Republic on communism and Congressional investigations.

Somewhere in the nation there may be a better college basketball team than the University of San Francisco's. Before the campaign runs its course one or two quintets may put in such a claim, but for the time being, at least, the stamp of approval must go to the tall and talented Dons.

NEW DELHI, India, Dee. 30 -John Sherman Cooper, United States Ambassador to India, talked with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for more than an hour today. He was reported to have discussed Goa and other issues.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)--Unbeaten Clarkson broke its game open after a tight first period tonight to swamp Boston University, 10--5. The Knights' Ellard Gutzman scored three goals in a holiday hockey tournament triple-header.

JOSEPH ROSENSTOCK is planning to present Rolf Liebermann's "The School for Wives" as his final major novelty with the New York City Opera in the spring. The work, with a libretto derived from Moliere by Dr. Heinrich Strobel, is rococo in style.

The terrain of northern and central California is dominated by parallel mountain ranges running north and south. Down these slopes and along the valley between run rivers that find their outlet through the Golden Gate. Most of the rivers are dammed.

Another unit has been completed in the Park City apartment colony in the Forest Hills North section of Queens. It is the fifth building in a group of six fourteen-story structures. The Carol Management Corporation, of which Alfred L. Kaskel is president, is the ownerbuilder.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 31--Leslie C. White, vice president of the American Symphony Orchestra League and former manager of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, has been appointed executive director of the United Fine Arts Fund and executive secretary of the Fine Arts Institute here.

WINNETKA, Ill., Dec. 31-- Miss Ruth Z. Crosby, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Crosby of Winnetka, was married here yesterday to Charles G. Beattie. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Beattie of Rio de Janeiro.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals today signed Gordon Jones, a right-handed pitcher, for 1956. Jones won one game and lost four for the Cards last season, but has a 6-4 record with Havana in the winter league.

HAMDEN, Conn., Dec. 31-- Miss Marilyn Ann Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clemence H. Cole of North Haven and Short Beach, was married here this morning to George Henry Lawrence Jr. He is a son of Major Lawrence, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Lawrence of Hamden.
PAINTING concrete floors was once a highly speculative job. The home handyman didn't know how the paint would hold to the floor or how long it would withstand heavy wear or the attacks of dampness.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (UP)-- Manchester United moved to a 4-point lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League today by rallying for a 2-1 victory over Manchester City.
Dave Brechner, a Princeton University freshman, and Alan Tobias of New York's McBurney School, won the finals of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis tournament yesterday.

In the first nine months of its operation, Sharpstown, a housing development southwest of Houston, Tex., described as the largest project of its kind in the world, saw 875 dwellings either completed or under construction, As of Dec. 13, 1955, the development contained 1,627 persons.

Bob Backus, the national champion ih the 35 and 56-pound weight throwing events, led the New York A.C. athletes in point-scoring during 1955. He tallied 150 points on twenty-two first places; twelve seconds and two thirds.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 31 (AP)--The Indonesian Government today appointed two intermedi aries in the divorce action brought against President Su karno by his first wife, Fat mawati.

The twenty-second anniversary of Youth Aliyah, worldwide child rescue and rehabilitation organization, will be marked Tuesday at the Plaza Hotel. More than 600 leaders of Hadassah from all parts of the country will attend.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 31-- The engagement of Miss Joanne Sayre to Robert Burroughs Wolf has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Baker Sayre. Mr. Wolf is a son of Mrs. H. Carl Wolf and the late Mr. Wolf.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 31 (AP) --Jack Jerome of Savannah, Ga., beat the world champion driver of Class D stock hydroplanes partly through his own driving skill and partly through luck, in today's outboard races in the Orange Bowl regatta.

Eduardo Lausse, Argentine middleweight, will oppose Milo Savage of Salt Lake City at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The pair will meet in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Dec. 31--St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church was the Setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Noel Janet McArdle to Lieut. Paul Hurley Bogardus Jr., U.S.M.C.R. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. C.R. Mullen.
Because today's students are getting higher marks than those of earlier generations, Yale University has raised the requirements for being named to the dean's honor list.

Department store sales in the nation in the week before Christmas zoomed to a point 21 per cent. above the level of the comparable week last year. It was the thirty-sixth consecutive weekly gain reported by the Federal Reserve Board and the largest gain for a single week in three years.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 31--James Heavener, stage manager for the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra since 1909, has retired. OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 31-- Sing Sing Prison authorities re ported today that in 1955 a total of 1,800 offenders had been re ceived at the prison. This was 113 more than was admitted in 1954. There were 1,756 prisoners on the Sing Sing rolls today. The normal capacity is 1,822 inmates.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3--Communist instigation, planning and financial support are blamed by the French Government for the bloodshed, riots and arson that occurred last summer in the French Cameroons.

GUILFORD, Conn., Jan. 3-- The closing days of the Connecticut duck season made up in productivity for the blank days of the early season. However, only the more hardy hunters were willing to accept the rigors of the off-shore blinds.
ALBANY, Jan. 3--Teacher salary increases being proposed by the Heald Commission would add $18,000,000 a year to public school payrolls in New York State.

ALBANY, Jan. 3--Three major problems are facing the Legislature, which begins its 1956 session tomorrow in an atmosphere highly charged with Presidential politics. Forty-six thousand members of the International Union of Electrical Workers, A.F.L.-C.I.O., left their jobs in thirty Westinghouse Corporation plants on Oct. 17. Nine days later 9,000 more workers, members of the independent United Electrical Workers, went on strike in ten plants.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 3--One of the most articulate and active spokesmen for the Virginia plan to cope with the Supreme Court's decision against racial segregation in public schools is Colgate W. Darden Jr., president of the University of Virginia.

Yesterday's fog gave New York City an odd-colored sun --and unusually polluted air. Many persons noticed that the sun, when it could be seen, had a dull orange cast. The Weather Bureau said this was caused by moisture in the air and the suspension of dust particles.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 4-- Mrs. Sands Dickson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Julia Sands Bernard, to Comdr. Jewett A. Baldridge., U.S.N., son of Mrs. Harry A. Baldridge and the late Rear Admiral Baldridge of Annapolis, Md.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered hearings on an application by the nation's railroads for a 7 per cent freight rate rise.

Governor Harriman starts his second year in office with a message to the Legislature more cheerful because of the prosperity which has improved the state's financial base, and more aggressive in its attack on the social welfare problems that command his sympathies.

PARIS, Jan. 4 (UP)--Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris methodically wore down Torben Ulrich, Denmark's slender southpaw, to score a 6-4, 6-2, 6-0 victory today in the quarter-finals of the Pierre Gillou indoor tennis tournament.

The Fleischmann Distilling Corporation announced yesterday the election of Charles S. White as president. He succeeds Warren Oakes, president of the company since 1934, who becomes board chairman and continues as chief executive...

MEXICO CITY (AP)--The Government reports 495,496 motor vehicles were registered in Mexico last year 137,092 of them operating in the capital area alone. The registrations were almost double that of 1945.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 4 (AP)--The Cambodian National Assembly today inaugurated Oun Cheeang Sun as Premier. He replaces former King Norodon Sihanouk, who had accepted the post only temporarily.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 4--The number of persons to view the body of former Mayor Frank Hague reached 6,000 this afternoon. Mourners began gathering on the porch of the Lawrence G. A landlord-tenant dispute that might have taken the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission several months settle was resolved in two hours yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (AP)-- The police arrested seventy-two Negro passengers tonight after they allegedly had refused to comply with segregated seating arrangements on a city bus.

OTTAWA--Canada's multimillion-dollar tourist industry continued to stride forward in 1955. The volume of visitors rose above that of 1954, and more money poured into the national coffer than in the peak year of 1953.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A Congressional subcommittee urged today the expansion of all facets of foreign aid and commerce to meet the challenge of Communist aggressiveness in these fields.
Traps-Atlantic cargo operations of Pan American World Airways will reach the 10,000,000-pound mark in 1956, Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president for traffic and sales, predicted yesterday.
There will be a bitter fight over sugar distribution this year. The United States must pass a sugar bill setting limits for imports.
AS usual the Lunts are giving a bright performance in a dullish play.

VACOUVER, B.C.--The hydroelectric power developments in British Columbia since World War II, principally by the British Columbia Power Corporation, are an indication of the province's industrial and population growth.
GUATEMALA--Despite a number of agricultural problems Guatemala appears to face a year of strong economic activity in 1956.

MONTREAL--Whether a visitor arrives here by air, rail or motor vehicle, he cannot fail to see evidence of Montreal's real estate boom.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (UP)-- The Big Ten and the Pacific Coast Conference commissioners today cleared up some of the misunderstandings on the signaling of penalties in the last few minutes of the controversial Rose Bowl game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Department of Justice has ordered an investigation to determine whether there has been systematic exclusion of Negroes from juries in Cobb County, Ga.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press)--Lynn Patrick, general manager of the Boston Burins today said he would apply for. Coach Milt Schmidt's reinstate ment as an active player at a National Hockey League meeting in Montreal tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)-- The United States and West Germany agreed today to set up a joint committee to protect patent rights and foster the exchange of technical information.

CHESTER, Vt., Jan. 4--Albert Walter Harvey of Chester, a former United States marshal, died last night in Rutland Hospital. He had been operated on Dec. 24 for a kidney ailment. He was 76 years old.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 4 (AP) --Rain poured down on western Oregon today for the second straight day. Rivers rose and earthslides brought a return of troubles that plagued the area ten days ago. There was no immediate threat of disaster and some slackening in rainfall was forecast.
MONTREAL--One of the big hopes in Canada's economic future is the emphasis placed by the Federal Government on encouraging immigration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP)-- Defense Mobilizer Arthur S. Flemming today announced plans for a study of the shortage of nickel and the future supply outlook.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 --The year-old contractual dispute between Marilyn Monroe and Twentieth Century-Fox has ended in victory for the star.
The Canisius basketball squad rallied last night to defeat Fordham, 71--63, on the Rams' court.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 4 (UP)--A Three-man court of honor ruled today there were no grounds for a duel between President Luis Batlle Berres and Opposition Congressman Washington Guadalupe.

A New York County grand jury indicted eight correction officers at the City Prison yesterday for taking unlawful fees and delivering contraband to inmates.
PARIS, Jan. 4--Premier Edgar Faure disputed today the victory claims of former Premier Pierre Mendes-France, his principal rival in the recent parliamentary elections.

The annual convention of the eastern region of the American Association of Nurserymen opened yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel. Dr. George Lawrence, director of the Bailey Hortorium, Ithaca, N.Y., reported on the recent International Horticultural Congress at the Hague.
LONDON, Jan. 4--British officials began today a two-day review of problems confronting the West in the Middle East.
