HALIFAX--Sustained demand for paper and other wood products, steel, fish and other basic products kept the Maritime Provinces' economy on an even keel in 1955. Troubles were encountered, however, in marketing heavy crops of apples and potatoes and in the dwindling demand for coal.

Jacob Fass purchased an apartment in the cooperative building at 1070 Park Avenue through the Westhampton Realty Company, broker. Hollyday Ives, Inc., broker, sold an apartment in 131 East Sixtyninth Street to Roger Lewis, and one in 150 East Seventythird Street to Frank C. Baker.

Dr. Alois Huppert, 55 years old, of 817 West End Avenue, was found dead yesterday on a park bench at Riverside Drive and 101st Street. The police said that a note found in the physician's pocket indicated he had taken poison because of poor health.

OTTAWA--From April 5 to 15 the Province of Quebec will display 140 exhibits dramatizing the rise of its industrial produc tion from $697,000,000 in 1938 to more than $3,000,000,000 in 1954. The eleven-day show, sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce of Montreal is aiming at a goal of 200,000 visitors.

Mrs. Chester Welde Cuthell of 150 East Seventy-second Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Priscilla Cuthell, to Charles Wigton Ward, son of Mrs. C. Wayne Ward of Orlando, Fla., and the late Mr. Ward.
VANCOUVER, B.C.--Fishing and hunting in British Columbia seem to be gaining the stature of an industry.
READING, England, Jan. 4 (Reuters)--Berkshire beat Dorset and Wiltshire, 11--6, in a Rugby Union county championship play-off match today.

Mrs. Mamie Fertig Rosalsky, widow of Judge Otto A. Rosalsky, died on Tuesday in the home of a son, Sydney Sutton, in Great Neck, L.I. Her age was 75. Her husband was dean of the General Sessions bench, of which he had been a member for thirty-one years at his death in 1936.

HAVANA--Cuba's tourist trade is improving yearly, according to the National Tourist Institute.

Net operating earnings of Chemical Corn Exchange Bank for 1955 set a record high of $17,116,597, or $3.62 a share. This compared with $15,022,782, or $3.18 a share, in 1954. N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4--Mr. and Mrs. Allan Hunter White of St. Davids have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Yale White, to Richard Kimball Fenn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Thomas Fenn of Oberlin, Ohio. Miss White is a graduate of Smith College and Mr. Fenn is an alumnus of Yale. Both are attending Union Theological Seminary in New York.

EDMONTON, Alta.--Two railway projects, aimed at tapping the greatest mineral wealth in the world may play major roles in the future development and economy of the Canadian Northwest. They involve an estimated cost of more than $100,000,000.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 4 (UP)--Alaska's moose were busy searching for pasturage again today and terrifying residents in the process. Fish and Wildlife Seuvice officials said that the moose had charged two automobiles and killed a sled dog yesterday after scaring one woman to the point where she fell and injured herself in escaping.

A north-northwest wind late last night blew away the fog that had strangled transportation in the New York area for two days.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (UP)--A small "incendiary device," which had baffled explosives experts since it was found last night on a Trans World Airlines plane carrying thirty-two passengers, was "positively" identified tonight as a harmless, self-contained heater for a soldering iron.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 --The world premiere of Eugene O'Neill's unpublished play, "Long Day's Journey Into Night," will be staged by the Royal Dramatic Theatre here on or about Feb. 10. The King and Queen are expected to attend.

HAVANA--Cuba's hopes of taking her place among the oil producing nations of the word are rising slowly. There has been no spectacular strike but the steady increase in production from small wells and the inflow of capital for exploration work is highly encouraging.
With the merger yesterday of the Square D Company and the Electric Controller and Manufacturing Company, A.G. Patterson was named president and F.W. Magin chairman of Square D, the surviving company.

The price of refined lead was advanced cent a pound yesterday, to 16 cents, New York, by a major custom smelter. Other sellers soon matched the new price. The increase was the second -cent advance within one week.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Nesbitt of 770 Park Avenue and Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth H. Nesbitt, to Dr. Henry A. Chase, son of Dr. Oscar J. Chase of 30 Sutton Place and Weston, Conn., and the late Mrs. Chase.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 4 (UP)--Russia scored a spectacular sweep of the first international Olympic tryout today when its women skiers took the first six places in the 10-kilometer (6.2-mile) crosscountry event of the Swiss open championship.

PARIS, Jan. 4--Premier Edgar Faure urged today that all the moderate French parties should join in a "temporary union." The purpose would be to preserve the republican regime by amending the Constitution.

W.C. Handy, 82-year-old composer of "The St. Louis Blues," were reported in "fair condition yesterday at Sydenham Hospital, where he underwent an operation last Saturday for an intestinal obstruction. Mr. Handy, however, is still on the critical list.

Formation of an Eddy Duchin Fund Committee, which will establish scholarship awards at the American Theatre Wing in memory of the pianist and bandeader, has been announced. Mrs. Averell Harriman is honorary chairman.
HAVANA--All of Cuba's efforts today are directed toward maintaining her balance on the uncertain economic road that lies ahead in 1956 and the more distant future.
Wellington Fund had its most successful year in its history, A. J. Wilkins, vice president, reported yesterday. He placed gross sales at $72,350,000, a record, topping 1954 sales by $8,550,000.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed firm yesterday. Prices were unchanged to 30 points ($1.50 a bale) up, with new-crop months showing the most strength.

Forty-one policemen, detectives and railroad agents vainly searched 2,600 lockers in Pennsylvania Station for ninety minutes early today for a bomb that an anonymous caller claimed to have hidden. They abandoned the hunt at 1:50 A.M.
One hundred men with neurotic tendencies are among the 360 policemen assigned to light duty whose activities will be studied to see where they best fit in the department.

BOSTON, Jan. 4--The Boston Museum of Fine Arts opened today an exhibition in honor of the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of John Singer Sargent, a leading portrait painter of fifty years ago. The exhibition will continue through Feb. 7. Sargent's paintings of Bostonians are still largely in private hands. Many have been lent by the owners for the exhibition.

TORONTO--Canada's expansion was demonstrated at the Toronto Stock Exchange, which was believed to have set a North American trading record in 1955.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti-- Government statistics show that Haiti's consumption of foodstuffs in the year ended last Sept. 30 increased slightly over the previous fiscal year. Some of the increases, however, may be attributed to 12,000 tons of grain and 500 tons of oil supplied by the United States after Hurricane Hazel struck.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan, 4 (AP)-- Senior Bowl officials today arranged for sudden-death overtime if the North and South football teams end the regulation playing time in a deadlock in the seventh annual all-star game Saturday. The North coach, Buddy Parker, and the South coach, Paul Brown, agreed to the plan.
Plans have been announced by Deering, Miliken Co., Inc., textile concern, for the construction of a seven-story office building at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

Hot, tempting waffles, uniformly baked, can be made with the new "Thermo-Grid" waffle baker by Toastmaster. The thermostatically controlled appliance insures a consistent fluffiness, texture and moisture content. It has cast aluminum grids, treated to prevent the batter from sticking, which produce round, plate-size waffles, The baker is $21.95, at Gimbels.

Research activity at the New York University College of Engineering rose 23.6 per cent during the last year, increasing the total annual expenditure from $2,235,000 to $2,763,000. This was announced yesterday by Dean Thorndike Saville.

Assertions made last week by Dr. German Ornes Coiscu, publisher of the Dominican Republic's leading newspaper, that he had been forced to seek asylum here were denied yesterday by the newspaper's acting publisher and editor.

Hammond Edward (Ham) Fisher, creator of the comic strip "Joe Palooka," left an estate of about $2,500,000, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. The cartoonist, who was 54 years old, was found dead on Dec. 27 in the studio of a friend. His death was listed as an apparent suicide.
GENEVA, Jan. 4--British and Canada are preparing to take sanctions against French trade because of the continued use of export subsidies by France.

OTTAWA--The nation's lagging Trans-Canada highway construction program received another shot in the arm toward the end of-last year. But the 1956 goal for completion of the 4,600-mile road was set back until 1961.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (UP)-- The burro, the Mexican farmer's best friend, is a vanishing breed.

The quest for an inexpensive source of coffee has opened the United States market to African producers. The unusually high price for green coffee has disrupted the normal flow of coffee beans into consumer channels.

LIMA, Peru--Foreign credit assistance to Peru in the last year has shown a steady increase. Such loans are concrete evidence of this nation's free economy, its favorable climate for foreign investments and a stability to be found in few other countries today in Latin America.

Harry W. Faath Jr. of Braun, Bosworth Co., Inc., has been elected chairman of the "Toppers" for the ensuing year, according to James F. Reilly of Lehman Brothers, retiring chairman. The Toppers is an organization of municipal bond men.

Mrs. Marie O'Brien of 2027 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was charged with fatally stabbing her husband, Thomas, 55 years old, yesterday. Bronx Assistant District Attorney Irvin J. Gold smith said that the stabbing arose from a series of argu ments. The O'Briens have four children, three of them living in foster homes. The defendent was held without bail.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4--A mileStone in Miami's efforts to develop the fine arts was reached last night at the opening of George Engle's Coconut Grove Playhouse. The play was "Waiting for Godot," which is receiving its pre-Broadway tryout.

The New York Spokesmen defeated the Bulova Watchmakers, 40--36, in an Eastern Wheelchair Basketball Association game at the Flushing (Queens) Armory last night. The victory, tied the Spokesmen with the Jersey Wheelers for the league lead. Each team has won its two starts. Frank Spinelli led the Spokesmen with 13 points.
The appointment of Robert J. Fitzpatrick as director of public relations was announced yesterday by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, Shreveport. La.
HONG KONG, Jan. 4--Communist China is continuing its efforts to develop closer ties with Asian and African countries in the "spirit of Bandung."

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (Reuters)-- Tass, the Soviet news agency, said today that Mrs. Aziz Agabekova of Yessentuki in the northern Caucasus, celebrated her 120th birthday today. She has twenty-one children, including two daughters in their 90's, the news agency said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--At least two railroads operating in the South intend to comply with an Interstate Commerce Commission order to end segregation on trains and buses and in waiting rooms. The order applies to interstate travel.

Few regions in the world offer greater promise of more rapid and profitable development than does Latin America, Andrew B. Shea, president of Pan AmericanGrace Airways, declares in his year-end statement.

LONDON, Jan. 4--Queen Elizabeth II has approved the nomination of the Right Rev. Arthur Michael Ramsey, Lord Bishop of Durham, to be Archbishop of York. He is to succeed Dr. Cyril Forster Garbett, who died Saturday after thirteen years as Archbishop.

An Air Force Sergeant's wife and their ten children were processed yesterday at Fort Hamilton's Overseas Replacement Center to join the sergeant in Germany. Mrs. Catherine Medor, 31 years old, shepherded her six girls and four boys.

MEXICO CITY--This country has fully recovered from the effects of the drastic peso devaluation of April, 1954.

KARACHI, Pakistan. Jan. 4-- The Council of Ministers of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty is scheduled to meet here March 6. Government spokesmen said today the meeting of the Manila pact council would coincide with the visit of Secretary of State Dulles. In addition to the United States and Pakistan, the members are Britain, France, Australia, New Zealand, Thailand and the Philippines.

The First National City Bank foresees a higher income from loans this year. This was predicted in its annual report to stockholders released yesterday.
The Open Stage, organized by David Bowen, Norma Frances and Lynn Michaels, has joined the mushrooming group of offBroadway theatres at 15 Second Avenue, near First Street.
Russell V. Cruikshank, who has just completed fifty years with the Cruikshank Company, was honored by the officers and members of the Twenty-five Year Club of the realty concern ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Administration was accused twice today of trying to cover up its farm difficulties by setting farmers against city workers.
The Downtown Athletic Club defeated the Harvard Club, 5--0, in a Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B match on the winner's courts yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (UP)-- The Cleveland Indians today signed for the 1956 season the only two regular left-handed pitchers on their 1955 roster Herb Score and Don Mossi. It was believed each got about $13,000.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 4-- The engagement of Miss Judith Gray Stahr to Ensign David Maynard Stembel Jr., U.S.N. son of Mr. and Mrs. Stembel of Pittsburgh, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Stahr.
TORONTO--Canada's share of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project took its first big strides during 1955.
SUDBURY, Mass., Jan. 4--A final decision on suggestions to restore the Wayside Inn will not be made for at least a month. Ford Company officials visited the scene of last month's $250,000 fire today.
Walter S. Robinson, a lawyer singe 1921 with White Case, 14 Wall Street, died yesterday in the Brooklyn Hospital after a short illness. His age was 57. He lived at 1 Grace Court, Brooklyn.

A daughter, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Blackman of 60 East Ninetysixth Street on Dec. 27 at Doctors Hospital, Mrs. Blackman is the former Miss Nancy DeRoy Rittmaster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Rittmaster of 47 East Eighty-eighth Street.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay--A two-month-long drought added to the economic and financial worries besetting many Uruguayans as a critical 1955 came to an end. The new year started with little hope for solution of the many ills stemming from the inflationary trend.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 (AP)--Schenley Industries, Inc., and its pharmaceutical subsidiaries today filed suit for triple damages in Federal Court against Sterling Drug, Inc. The suit charged illegal restraint of trade in the distribution of certain Germanmade drugs.

A School for Advanced Study is to be established at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It will be similar in objectives to the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, ... N.J., but structurally different.

CALGARY, Alt.--The postwar oil boom in Alberta continued this year with the average daily production rising to about 340,000 barrels a day, according to early estimates. With plans for exporting gas becoming more finalized a bright immediate future in this field can be expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, returned today from an inspection of West Coast aircraft factories in which some of the nation's new and secret weapons are made. He said he was pleased with what he saw. But he talked only cryptically of his tour of factories in California, declining even to list all plants and places visited. "I saw all the newer stuff," Mr. Wilson said.
The State Attorney General took legal steps yesterday to prevent Walter F. Tellier, New Jersey securities broker, from dealing in stocks and bonds in this state.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (UP) --Lovely Lauri, with Robert Lee Baird up, clung to a slim lead in the stretch at the Fair Grounds today to score a halflength victory in the feature.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4--Edmund G. Brown, California's Attorney General, has been named by Adlai E. Stevenson to head his Presidential primary campaign in that state.

ATHENS, Jan. 4 (AP)--Premier Constantine Karamanlis announced tonight the formation of his own political party, the National Radical Union. It will present candidates in the projected general election.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4--The first meeting between representatives of the Soviet Union and West Germany since Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Moscow last September occurred today. Valerian A. Zorin, Soviet Ambassador to Bonn, paid his first courtesy call on Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, Foreign Minister.

WINNIPEG, Man.--The close of navigation on the Great Lakes last month left Canada with the greatest oversupply of grain in her history. With stocks of wheat at a peak and other grains at near-record level, commer cial, public and farm storage facilities were overflowing.

Edward F. Dalton, a senior sales representative of the New York Subways Advertising Company, Inc., died on Sunday at the South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L.I. He was 65 years old and resided at 3 Judson Place, Rockville Centre, L.I.

LONDON, Jan. 4--The stock markets here opened a new bookkeeping account today with uneven gains, though some shares, especially those popular with United States investors, reacted toward the close on the news that Wall Street had opened dull.

MIAMI, Jan. 4 (UP)--The Miami City Commission had a change of heart today. It agreed to work out terms for the purchase of the Miami Stadium and to draw up a lease with the investors who intend to operate an International League franchise here.

LITTLE AMERICA V., Antarctica, Jan. 4--Five acres of Antarctic ice were dedicated today as Little America V, site of the major United States base in the South Polar program of the International Geographical Year.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (AP)-- The Pitt-Columbia basketball game, scheduled here tonight, was postponed until tomorrow night because of a fog that curtailed plane flights from New York's two big airports.

PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 4 (AP)-- The resignation of Howard E. Crawford as general sales manager of the Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation and the appointment of Frank V. Bridge to succeed him was announced today. Mr. Crawford's resignation was announced as owing to ill health. It is effective immediately.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 4 (AP) --A group of sixty-one leading Algerian officials put a threepoint demand tonight to the newly elected French National Assembly. They threatened to resign them office in a body if they met with refusal.

State Rent Administrator Robert C. Weaver has halted the eviction of forty tenants in an apartment house owned by Columbia University pending a determination of "the good faith" of the institution in pressing for their ouster.

A $25,000 gran to a national Methodist Church board to study "The Challenge of Communism to Christianity" was announced yesterday by the Fund for the Republic. The grant was among six announced by Fund directors.

The Public Service Company of Colorado expects 1955 earnings to reach more than $2.65 a share, William D. Virtue, president of the electric and gas utility, told a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile--A vast Technical Cooperation Program has shown in two years of operation the possibilities of international cooperation and the application of modern science.

A great upsurge in highway planning and construction is going on in the Central American republics. Within the next three years, more money will be spent on road development here than in all of the preceding years combined.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 4--Lon Spurrier, the world 880yard record holder, beat John Landy, the mile record holder, by two inches in a half-mile race at Olympic Park tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 (AP)--Governor Harriman appointed Justice Nathan A. Lashin of New York City's Municipal Court to the Bronx branch of the City Court of New York today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4--Systems Research Corporation, a newly formed research group composed largely of scientists who resigned last month from Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, has been engaged by Republic Aviation Corporation, Farmingdale, L.I., to conduct specific studies on advanced weapons and guided missile systems.

Looking every bit the lowliest minor league sextet for the first two periods, the New York Rangers flashed a dramatic change of form at Madison Square Garden last night. In so doing, they defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 4.

The formation under New York State laws of Ascot Chemical and Adhesive Corporation with $1,000,000 of initial paid-in capital was announced jointly yesterday by Harold Holden, president of the Eastern Corporation,

LONDON, Jan. 4(Reuters)-- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight a message from the ship Ob of the Soviet Antarctic Expedition, saying she was "in the immediate neighborhood of the Antarctic Continent." The Russians' plans have been to go this season to the Indian Ocean-Australia sector.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4--John Fell Stevenson, youngest son of Adlai E. Stevenson, will walk out of Passavant Hospital tomorrow. His right knee will be in a plaster cast, but he will be able to balance himself with the help of a cane. The youth was injured in an auto-truck crash near Goshen, Ind., Dec, 21.

GENEVA, Jan. 4--Netherland and Indonesian Ministers met here today in another attempt to agree an a mutually satisfactory method of dissolving the economic and financial union between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, and his deputy were accused today of assuming the powers of President Eisenhower in requesting the resignation of Frederick B. Lee as Civil Aeronautics Administrator.

The Earle Theatre in Jackson Heights, Queens, has terminated the successful run of the controversial motion picture "I Am a Camera" under the threat of a boycott by a Roman Catholic Church in its locality.

FROM green lentils no larger than the head of a pin, to big, broad fava beans, dried legumes come in a variety of shapes, sizes and colors. Twenty-five different kinds were assembled recently in The New fork Times' test kitchen. Admittedly, groceries in foreign neighborhoods, such as Ninth Avenue in the Thirties, had to be scouted for some of the more obscure specimens.

SYRACUSE, Jan. S (AP)--Unleashing 15 straight points in the fourth period the New York Knickerbockers turned a tight battle into a 103--86 rout of the Boston Celtics in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The New York Board of trade announced that Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, has become its new president. He succeeded Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., who became board chairman of the trade association.

Libby, McNeill Libby, food packers, achieved record sales and earnings in the six months ended on Nov. 26 for any similar period in its history. Charles S. Bridges, president, yesterday so reported in the first semi-annual statement to stockholders.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP)--Lady Churchill, wife of Sir Winston Churchill, has entered a London hospital for observation, it was announced today. She will be 70 years old next month.

A group of first graders made a sacrifice at Christmas time to assist the Neediest Cases. They decided not to buy Christmas candy canes for the class and sent $1.50 to the Neediest instead.
A record budget of $122,729,500 that reflects confidence in further Substantial economic progress has been set by the Dominican Republic for 1956.

George Axelrod, author of the successful "The Seven Year Itch" and the current comedy "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?", will turn Broadway producer next season with Gore Vidal's play, "Visit to a Small Planet."

MILAN, Italy, Thursday, Jan. 5 (Reuters)--A powerful homemade bomb was thrown early today into the palace of Archbishop Giovanni Battista Montini, formerly a right-hand man of Pope Pius XII. Damage was done to the palace, but no one was injured.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Senate Internal Security subcommittee resumed today its inquiry into possible Communist infiltration of newspapers, radio, television and other communications media.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) --The Federal Power Commission refused today to set aside its approval of plans by Idaho Power Company to develop Hell's Canyon. Last Aug. 4, the commission issued a license to the company for construction of the Brownlee and Ox-Bow Dams. Revised exhibits were approved Nov. 3. A petition to set aside the Nov. 3 order was filed Dec. 5.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 4-- Mitchel Air Force Base, target of heated criticism recently following a series of airplane crashes, contracted this week for an extension to its main runway.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (UP)-- Mexico reduced her quota today to 200,000 migrant laborers who would be allowed to work on United States farms in 1956. The number was 80,000 fewer than last year. Government officials said they hoped to persuade most of Mexico's itinerant farm population to stay on this side of the border to harvest Mexican crops.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--Establishment of a Canadian park at the United States boundary near Point Roberts, Wash., south of here, complementing a park in Washington, is the objective of a group of park enthusiasts here.

The President-elect of one of our stanchest allies, Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil, arrives in the United States on a short visit today, It goes without saying that he will receive a warm welcome from officials and citizens of our country.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Jan. 4 --The conversion of the former all-Negro state school here to an institution for mentally retarded children will take nearly a year longer than originally expected. Also, it apparently will cost far more than the $1,400,000 thus far estimated by state officials.
HOUSTON, Jan. 4 (UP)--The Southern Methodist University backfield coach, Harold Hagen, tonight accepted a post as assistant football coach at Rice Institute.

A DINNERPLATE becomes a work of art in an unusual design exhibit at the showrooms of Josiah Wedgwood and Sons, 24 East Fifty-fourth Street. On display until February 18 are examples of current favorites, new shapes and styles, and ideas for they future.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 4--The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis granted $200,797 to the University of Cincinnati and the Cincinnati Children's Hospital Research Foundation today to enable Dr. Albert E. Sabin to continue his search for a live virus vaccine to provide lifelong immunity to polio. Dr. Sabin is Professor of Research Pediatrics at the university and a fellow of the hospital's foundation.
A rapid rise in tourism and a projected expansion of bauxite ore mining, gave the island of Jamaica, largest of the British West Indies, one of its most promising years in 1955.

The Ames Textile Corporation announced yesterday purchase of the majority of common stock in Buresh Nonwovens, Inc. Ames is a large manufacturer of wool goods and Buresh makes nonwoven fabrics for automobiles and apparel.
United States business men are stepping up their purchases of Canadian property.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 4--Completion of a $3,000,000 plant for production of penicillin in the state of Bombay with United Nations aid was made known here today. The project has been under construction since 1951.

MADRID, Jan. 4--New lowrent apartments for more than 50,000 workers were built by the Spanish Government during 1955. The large-scale housing program was termed by the Spanish press as proof of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime's concern for the welfare of the workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP)-- Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, Republican of California, said today he would seek appropriations amounting to "all the Army engineers reasonably can spend" for flood control projects in California for the next fiscal year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4-- "The Soft Touch," an original scenario by Ernest K. Gann, is being polished by the National Broadcasting Company for use as a color television spectacular.
A $2,200 fine was imposed yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh on an autoist who pleaded guilty to forty-four parking and traffic violations dating from 1949.
Stocks yesterday slipped to the lowest levels since November but managed a fairly steady close.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--A Navy plane flew over the South pole yesterday.

Mrs. Caroline Bird Menuez of 60 Gramercy Park has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Menuez, to John Paul Barach. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvan L. Barach of 35 East Eighty-fourth Street.
Four United States-flag scheduled air carriers announced plans yesterday to start flights out of New York on routes recently awarded by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) --Senator Henry M. Jackson said today the Soviet Union was giving the highest priority to weapons "even more fantastic" than the intercontinental ballistic missile.
The New York City Housing Authority plans to sell two issues of short-term notes aggregating $14,122,000 next week, according to Philip J. Cruise, chairman.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras-- Relatively, this nation made economic progress last year, but it was part of a process of recovering from recent major, setbacks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4-- Congressional hearings on defense-contract profits of the nation's major aircraft companies will open here sometime after Jan. 15.

A six-story apartment house accommodating thirty-six families at 64-48 Booth Street in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by the Booth Street Apartments, Inc., to an investing customer of Ossip Associates, Inc., broker in the transaction.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. (Canadian Press)--The Federal Fisheries Department disclosed today that commercial fish landings during 1955 in Newfoundland declined 62,000,000 pounds from 1954. The total value was $13,200,000, a decline of $1,500,000 from 1954.
TORONTO--Gilbert A. LaBine, founder of Canada's uranium boom, has this advice for his country's youth: Go north, young man, go north.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 4--Syracuse's quintet romped to an 85-67 victory over' Cornell before' 5,000 spectators in Barton Hall tonight. Ron Gillespie, Waterford (N.Y.) senior, led the Orange to their fifth victory in eight games with 27 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) --The Navy announced today that Rear Admiral William R. Smedberg 3d would succeed Rear Admiral Walter F. Boone as superintendent of the United States Naval Academy early next spring.
HAVANA, Jan. 4--President Fulgencio Batista signed a decree today authorizing the start of the sugar harvesting season on Jan, 16. All sugar mills must start grinding before Feb. 15.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4-- The President-elect of Brazil, Juscelino Kubitschek, left by air for the United States today.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. (AP)--About 12,000 minks on a dozen new ranches under government sponsorship at a subsisting on 6,600 pothead whales driven ashore in 1955 in Trinity and Bonavista.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti-- Although the 1954-55 fiscal year was one of the worst in recent Haitian history because of Hurricane Hazel, the outlook for 1956 is favorable.

The distant cottonseed oil positions on the New York Produce Exchange rose to new seasonal highs yesterday while the near-by options eased. The volume, 275 tank cars, was surpassed only three times last year.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 4--Abolishment of eight tax collection posts at an annual saving of S55,000 in salaries was recommended here today by Samuel A. Larner.

The New York Telephone Company, in a report to the Federal Communications Commission, yesterday showed sizable gains in gross revenues and net income for the first eleven months of last year and for November over the like 1954 periods.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)-- Tokyo Rose, one of the siren voices of the Japanese radio during World War II, will get out of jail at the end of the month.

ALTHOUGH there has been a resurgence of interest in the human figure, few artists have grappled with the problem of the figure as an emotional conveyor. Wolfgang, a young painter trained in Chicago, and now showing at the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue, is an exception.

Dr. William Beebe, the naturalist, sailed yesterday aboard the Alcoa Pegasus on his seventh annual trip to the New York Zoological Society's field station at Simla.

Chesapeake Industries, Inc., an investing company, announced yesterday the formation of a new subsidiary, Mineral Resources, Inc., to engage in the natural resources field. The new company has purchased rights in three producing gas wells in Starr County, Tex.

Canadian production of asbestos, the fireproof and heat-andweather-resistant mineral fiber, rose to a record of 1,000,000 tons in 1955, the Quebec Asbestos Mining Association reported.

THE experts were aghast when Harrison (Bones) Dillard announced that he in tended to dry out for the 1948 Olympic team both as a sprinter and as a hurdler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)-- Heavy spending by registered lobbyists continued well beyond the adjournment of Congress last Aug. 2. The Congressional Record showed today.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 (UP)--Governor Harriman has proclaimed tomorrow George Washington Carver Day in New York State. VANCOUVER, B.C.--The fishing industry in British Columbia had an indifferent year in 1955.
Retailers increased their profits in the first nine months of 1955, thanks chiefly to their ability to cut operating expenses, the National Retail Dry Goods Association reported yesterday.

Expenditures for advertising in daily newspapers in Canada rose by more than 300 per cent between 1944 and 1954. This is indicated in a report just issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics based on a special survey.

MONTREAL--Civil aviation here enjoyed a big year in 1955, not so much for the number of flights and passengers at Dorval Airport, but for the progress made in terms of passenger comfort and the latest in aircraft.
VANCOUVER, B.C.--An irrigation experiment involving 650 acres of bench land above the Eraser River near Lillooet may lead to similar farming developments in other dry regions of the province.

The Advisory Board on the Pulitzer Prizes has announced the appointment of nineteen persons to the Pulitzer Journalism Juries for 1956. The jurors will meet at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism on March 12 and 13 to examine exhibits nominated in eight journalism categories.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4--The first major change in the provisional government of Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu took place today. Commodore Julio C. Krause was sworn in as Minister of Air and a member of the fiveman military junta ruling Argentina.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 4-- A son, their fourth child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward Richard Trippe on Dec. 27 at the Orange Memorial Hospital. The child, who has been named Jonathan Frommel, is a grandson of Mr. and Mrs. W. Rutherford Lane of New York and Flat Rock, N.C., and of Mrs. Edward Trippe of Mantua.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) --Senator James O. Eastland, commenting on an editorial that will appear in tomorrow's New York Times, said tonight: "The New York Times denies when no one has accused it".

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4-- The Matson Navigation Company plans to invest about $20,000,000 of "private, unsubsidized capital" in the purchase and reconstruction of the liner Monterey for passenger service between California and Hawaii.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP)--The California State Olympic Commission today approved a $5,000,000 plan to get Squaw Valley ready for the 1960 Winter Olympic Games.
The small taxicab was certified as safe yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

Alexandra Tikhonovich Gretchaninoff, composer and one of the last members of the nineteenth-century romantic school of Russian music, died Tuesday afternoon at his home, 57 West Seventy-fifth Street. His age was 91. He had lived in this city since 1939.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4.--Soviet commentatars to-day hailed the French election, results as a victory for the Communist party. They said the returns were a repudiation of bourgeois coalitions that had ruled France since 1947.

Sir Thomas Beecham has signed a recording contract with Electric and Music Industries (U.S.), Ltd., Dario Soria, president, has announced. The recordings will be made in England with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

Paul and Paula Kann Valar have been co-directors of the Franconia (N.H.) Ski School at Cannon Mountain since Sept. 1, 1950. Between seasons, this husband-wife team operates a 285acre dairy farm. Mountainview, near Wallingford, Vt.
DETROIT, Jan. 4--Henry H. Sanger, former chairman of the board of the Manufacturers National Bank, who retired in 1948. died yesterday at his home in suburban Grosse Pointe. His age was, 89.

SEBRING, Fla,., Jan. 4 (AP)-- Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore posted an 80 today to take low gross honors in the opening round of the first national tournament for women amateur golfers with handicaps of 15 or under.

TRENTON, Jan. 4--Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. today designated Deputy Attorney General John G. Thevos as acting administrative director of the State Department of Law and Public Safety, Mr. Thevos succeeds Brig. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf in the $13,000-ayear post.
LONDON, Jan. 4--Settlement of a bitter stockholders' dispute has made the merger of two of Britain's best-known steamship lines virtually certain.

A legion of youngsters who are wondering why they didn't get the ice skates they wanted for Christmas might as well know the truth. They didn't ask for the skates early enough. And even if they had, there probably wouldn't have been enough to go around.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee set a target date of Feb. 15 today to lay before President Eisenhower new legislation to raise farm income.
ALBANY, Jan. 4--The state's harness tracks renewed today their bid for governmental assistance in building bigger and better plants.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4 (Reuters)--The imminent resignation of the Lebanese Government was reported tonight. After a Cabinet meeting this afternoon, three Ministers resigned as a result of "the impossibility of cooperation" with Premier Rashid Keramy. They were Foreign Minister Selim Iahoud, Finance and Public Works Minister Jamil Milckawi and National Economy Minister Nazih Bizri.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 4-- Two Israeli Army patrols were attacked from an Egyptian position in the Gaza strip, according to an Israeli Army announcement today.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Jan. 4 (AP) --Welcomed by the blare of the town's fire whistle and the cheers of 400 spectators, the Canadian ferry Bluenose completed a maiden crossing from Yarmouth, N.S., today in six and a half hours, Gov. Edmund S. Muskie and five members of his Executive Council flew from Augusta to greet the vessel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Installment credit outstanding rose another $284,000,000 in November in the face of a sharp drop in automobile credit.
Harold Clurman, Broadway director, will deliver the third public lecture in the "Modern American Theatre Series" next Tuesday night at Princeton University.
Led by Lew Brown and Fred Silveublatt, Columbia University's swimming team defeated Manhattan College, 59--25, in the Lions' pool yesterday.
The Coast Guard cutter Tuckahoe knifed through swirling waters and heavy, sullen fog yesterday to land an expeditionary force of New Jersey officials on Ellis Island.

The appointment of Bernard R. Krashin as president of the Cotton Chemical Company division of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., was announced yesterday. He succeeds H. Seymour Cotton, who resigned to devote his time to personal affairs.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 4-- Mr. and Mrs. William B. Forsythe have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Lou Forsythe, to Christopher Weymouth Hammond. Mr. Hammond is a son of Mrs. Charles M. Adamson of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and Gordon E. Hammond of Portsmouth, N.H.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 4 (Reuters)--Seven men, including two former Cabinet ministers, were a sentenced to death here today on charges of treason. They had been linked to an attempt to assassinate President William V.S. Tubman last June 22.

The Long Island Daily Press said yesterday that it had charged publicly in 1937 that its Guild unit was Communist-dominated but that since then it had weeded out employes who were Communist-controlled.
QUEBEC--In this French-Canadian province the oldest society of North America measured another year of growth and prosperity in 1955.

BABYLON, L.I., Jan. 4--The Long Island State Park Commission and the Army Engineers have agreed on final plans for keeping open Fire Island Inlet and protecting the barrier beach on the northwest side of the channel.

Nine charitable organizations in this city will receive assistance as a result of the Bargain Box luncheon scheduled to take place on Feb. 7 in the grand ballroom of the Ambassador.
Dr. Nahum Goldmann said yesterday the Jewish Agency for Palestine would be able to resettle only 50,000 North African Jews in Israel this year because of its limited financial resources.

Confident that the nation's outlook is "bright with promise," President Eisenhower appealed yesterday for bipartisan support of the legislative program outlined in his State of the Union message.
Nomination of James R. Dyer to be chairman of the board of the American Stock Exchange was announced yesterday.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony subscrib ers cannot complain about a dearth of solo violinists. For four successive weeks now there has been one every Thursday and Friday, and others are booked for the coming fortnight. The patrons will be forgetting what a piano sounds like.

Eduardo Lausse, middleweight boxer from Buenos Aires, and Milo Savage of Salt Lake City will furnish the action in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The arrival in the Dodgers office yesterday of Charley Neal's signed contract may be the first signal for two other second basemen--Junior Gilliam and Don Zimmer--to "move over."

FOR more than five years a group of young Baptist Congregationalist ministers in Greenwich Village have lived through incredible trials in a quietly heroic project to save neighborhood teen-agers from the human discard heap.

After a lean winter thus far, the Berkshires may get into the skiing picture this week-end. Resort operators in northwestern Massachusetts were preparing for large crowds yesterday and hoping that temperatures would remain low enough to protect their snow covers.

ANNE-MARIE-LOUISE D'ORLEANS, Duchesse de Montpensier, says Francis Steegmuller in his able biography, "The Grand Mademoiselle," was "one of the most picturesque, the most eccentric heroines of French history." She was indeed, and her fame in her own country is still green.
The vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn, Heights nominated last night the Rev. Dr. Irving S. Pollard as rector.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10--Four major banks in Chicago today held their annual meetings of stockholders or directors or both.
Retailers came to grips with the problem of revitalizing their downtown trade yesterday. They were assured that grass need not grow in the streets of big cities.
A woman theatre executive and her accountant received jail sentences and heavy fines yesterday for defrauding the Government of $372,000 in theatre admission taxes.
A new record of $335,000,000 in orders for commercial airliners was chalked up last year by the Lockhead Aircraft Corporation.
When Art Devlin was 4 his father tools him into the backyard of their Lake Placid (N.Y.) home and gave him a pair of skis.

The Theatre Guild hopes to place "Affair of Honor" in rehearsal before the end of the month. A mid-March Broadway opening is in store for Bill Hoffman's romantic comedy dealing with the Revolutionary War.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (UP) The University of Miami (Fla.) probationary period was extended for another year today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association council for alleged failure to follow the rules and regulations set down by the colleges.

The 11,600 officers and men of the Fire Department are being asked to answer questionnaires on any outside jobs they hold. The questionnaires were sent out in the final phase of a survey that has been under way for many months by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

CAIRO, Jan. 10--Jordan charged tonight that Egyptian and Saudi Arabian broadcasts had helped instigate the violence that swept through Jordan during the last four days. The Egyptian Ambassador in Amman returned home tonight to report the Jordanian protest.
The Boy Scouts here in the city need the active support of all who are interested in boys. More troops are needed to accommodate the thousands of boys who would be Scouts if they had the opportunity.

Remember how the toothpaste entrepreneurs were offering chlorophyll, anti-histamine and various other types of products not very long ago? Pretty much the same sort of thing is about to break in full-flowering advertisink for fluoride tooth paste.

Stockholders of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation approved a two-for-one stock split at a special meeting yesterday at Houston, Tex. There are 3,530,000 shares of common stock outstanding.
LONDON, Jan. 10--The drop in stock prices precipitated by the adoption of shorter working hours by British automobile plants continued today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- President Eisenhower resumed today his weekly conferences with Republican Congressional leaders but gave them no clue as to whether he would seek reelection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Education Association reported today that approximately 900,000 children were going to school in shifts because of the teacher and classroom shortage.
IF Pinero's "Dandy Dick" has not been acted in New York since 1887 it is easy to guess why. In the arch performance put on at the Cherry Lane last evening it is heavy going.

In its current issue The Virginia Quarterly Review carries a leading article on "The Challenge of the Underdeveloped Lands" by a man who is uniquely equipped to discuss this subject. He is Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Virginia's strong endorsement at the polls of a program for maintaining racial segregation in its public schools underscores the many factors contributing to the controversy in the South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) --The Government formally opened the door today to shipments of United States radioactive materials to Russia and other Soviet-bloc nations for peaceful uses. Atomic materials with a military potential still will be barred.
A study of mental patients and mental hospitals, filmed mostly on location, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday, March 18, from 5 to 6:30 P.M.
Los Angeles, Calif., borrowed $40,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.584 per cent.
Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley asked yesterday for a major increase in his budget. But he said that even if it were granted New York would not be on a comparable basis with Detroit or Los Angeles.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan.10--Advovates of the Virginia plan to sidestep the Supreme Court's ban on racial segregation in public schools claimed a mandate from the voters today to carry the program forward.

AT NOON today the Illuminating Engineering Society, with 9,000 members all over the country, will take luncheon at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel where the society got its start fifty years ago when the establishment was just the Astor Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 10--A notorious racketeer and his longtime underworld associate were identified here today as the sponsors of a would-be housing project that eventually cost local taxpayers $94,000.

Manhattan College's basketball team defeated a game Muhlenberg team in overtime, 85 to 79, and Seton Hall checked Xavier University of Cincinnati, 84 to 73, in the collegiate double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The Colonial Office declared today that a Chinese had admitted being promised a reward by Chinese Nationalist agents for putting a time bomb in an aircraft in which Communist aides were killed.
Warehouse workers affiliated with the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, reached a tentative agreement with employers on a new contract late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Republican chairman of the Civil Service Commission testified today that about 41.2 per cent of Government employes separated from jobs under security risk implications were appointees of the Eisenhower Administration.
PARIS, Jan. 10--The French contract bridge team increased its lead in the world team-of four championship match over the United States team to sixtythree European match points this afternoon.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--Few statesmen have made such a virtue of patient obstinacy as Molotov. His earlier revolutionary colleagues seemed to underestimate his intellect although acknowledging his capacity for work. Lenin supposedly called him "the best filing clerk in Russia."

DR. ERNIE VANDEWEGHE received word a week ago that the patient was ailing and in need of a doctor. It couldn't be any doctor, however. It had to be a specific one, a certain resident pediatrician at Babies' Hospital in the Medical Center.
OTTAWA, Jan. 10--The third session of Canada's twenty-second Parliament was opened today by Governor General Vincent Massey with traditional ceremonial.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Governor Harriman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging a $2,000,000 emergency state appropriation for flood relief.
Directors of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation yesterday voted a 10 per cent stock dividend on the common stock, payable on Feb. 10.
INTERESTING new food products are appearing on grocery shelves here. Some add a new zest to dishes. Others simplify the business of cooking. Some do both.

SCIENTIFIC survey, designed to show the harm ful effects of pollution on the coastal fishery, is planned for this spring under the sponsorship of the Sportsmen's Council of the Marine District of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Government made it more difficult today to get priority for supplies of steel, copper and aluminum.

Manufacturers of nationally branded daytime dresses expect that the growing preference of women for cotton wearing apparel will help increase their 1956 sales above the 12,000,000 dozen garments produced by the industry last year.

FOR the first time in its seventy-four-year history, Lu chow's Restaurant now freezes three of its specialties for general distribution to retail groceries. Packed in individual portions, the dishes are Salisbury steak, beef goulash and Swedish meat balls.
For the first time in the history of the Port of New York, international ship travel last year ran second place to foreign travel by air.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10--The Western Big Three plan to submit a joint resolution tomorrow censuring Israel "in the strongest terms" for a raid on Syrian military posts.
WARD THREE: FOUR P.M. TO MIDNIGHT" was the somewhat unwieldy title of the drama presented last night on the "Armstrong Circle Thtatre" over Channel 4.

Two talented youngsters, one 11 years old and the other 14, were the soloists last night at the National Orchestral Association's second concert of the season at Carnegie Hall. They were chosen to emphasize the importance the twenty-five-year-old association attaches to youth.

LONDON, Jan. 10--Native Africans of Kenya will receive qualified rights to vote for the first time next fall, according to recommendations published today by the Colonial Office and the Kenya Government.

Net operating earnings of the Hanover Bank for 1955 amounted to $11,600,000, or $3.88 a share, compared with $10,100,000, or $3.37 a share, in 1954, the bank announced in its annual report to stockholders released yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--The Harriman Administration proposed today a salary increase for the state's 80,000 employes. The program would cost about $28,300,000 a year.
Queens Republican Councilman Robert E. Barnes yesterday made good his pledge not to accept the $2,000 increase in "contingency allowance" voted Dec. 29 by the Board of Estimate.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Jan. 11--Communist China charged today that two United States military planes "intruded" over Manchuria Monday. The alleged flight over Chinese "territorial air" was called "a grave act of military provocation."
Mrs. Borg was extraordinary for the breadth of her interests, and the news account yesterday that told of her death did not exaggerate when it said that she "was a leader ...
The Randolph Trading Corporation has purchased the apartment house at 125 Marcy Place in the Bronx from Fred Lese, whose family had owned it twenty-three years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The embattled International Boxing Guild took a fresh blow today, this one from the Justice Department.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10--Adlai E. Stevenson, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, today attacked President Eisenhower's farm message as "recognition, at last, that the farmer needs help--at least in an election year."
Prices of cotton futures advanced 16 to 28 points, 80 cents to $1.40, a bale yesterday. Business on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat more active than it has been of late.

The voters of Virginia have now endorsed, by two to one, the first step leading toward an attempted circumvention of the Supreme Court decision forbidding racial segregation in the state's public schools. Once again there is given to the country a striking illustration of the depth of feeling in the South over the irresistible force that will eventually wipe the color line out of our educational system.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Sharp differences of opinion in both parties on state tax legislation were disclosed today.
Four foreign statesmen gave tributes to Woodrow Wilson yesterday on the thirty-fifth anniversary of the opening of the first League of Nations Assembly.
QUEBEC, Que., Jan. 10--Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec said today he would push through curbs on newsprint even if the industry now were to cut prices within the Province.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Secretary of State Dulles is expected to visit India in early March for important talks with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10 --United States Ambassador Max Waldo Bishop today paid his first call upon Premier Pibul Songgram.
The Florida State Turnpike Authority announced yesterday plans for the sale of $185,000,000 of bonds late this spring or early in the summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor declared today the Army would try hard to produce an intermediate ballistics missile with a range of 1,500 miles. In a news conference the Army Chief of Staff said the goal was being treated as a national necessity.

A check for $2,050.50 to be "applied toward the Neediest Cases, which you well know exist," was received yesterday. The donor was Carrie L. Day. She was among eighty-one contributors who sent a total of $4,124.12.

World communism is seeking a "non-military showdown" to isolate the United States, Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, said last night. He explained that it was doing this by trying to identify itself with basic needs of peoples in Africa and Asia.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 10--Marshal Tito said today that Egypt wanted peace. Egypt is not threatening anyone, he asserted on his return from a trip to Africa.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP)--Despite blustery winds, Herman Barron sliced five strokes from par today and took top money in the one-day $7,500 Bayshore pro-amateur golf tournament.
AT M'MURDO SOUND BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 10--A comparative heat wave with temperatures up to 39 degrees has set back construction plans of Operation Deepfreeze.
BOSTON, Jan. 10--Patrick McGinnis moved today to withdraw his petition to become president of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

FOR the second of its retrospective one-man exhibi tions of work by American artists this season, the Whitney Museum will open today a show of forty years' work by the water-colorist Charles Burchfield.
The Navy has awarded a contract for research on a "flying barrel" vertical take-off plane.
An ill-tempered crowd of more than 3,000 persons waited as long as five hours yesterday to pay for or plead to summonses in one of the worst jams in Manhattan Traffic Court history.
IN the season's third per formance of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" at the Metropolitan Opera last night, the focus of attention was on the singers of the two principal roles.
Political and industrial leaders of the city and the nation yesterday supported the principles of scouting as a means of counteracting juvenile delinquency.
A gigantic offshore Atlantic storm, believed to be 2,000 miles in diameter, yesterday reversed the normal weather pattern for most of the Eastern seaboard from Maine to Florida.

BUFFALO, Jan. 10 (AP)--A three-company combination of contractors from New York City and Montreal submitted today the apparent low bid of $20,172,451.17 for the first major United States construction project on the St. Lawrence Seaway, the Robinson Bay lock.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10--A Mayors' conference tonight proposed an interim agreement between Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers to permit 44,000 strikers to go back to work immediately.
ATLANTA, Jan. 10 (UP)--The Governor of Louisiana branded as illegal today a Federal order to integrate public waiting rooms, but many Southern cities quietly complied with it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Republican leadership in the Senate moved today to unify all wings of the party there and to bring all Republican Senators into closer association with the White House.

A $1,000,000 center for controlling air traffic was formally dedicated yesterday at New York International Airport Idlewild, Queens. Actual operations were switched from the cramped and tired center at La Guardia Airport to the huge and gleaming new control room at Idlewild some time after midnight.

THE AMERICAN OPERA SOCIETY, evidently unaware of the widespread conviction that the age of bel canto is gone irretrievably, undertook one of the most exacting of bel canto operas at the Town Hall last night.
San Francisco University's top-ranking basketball team will have to fight through the rest of its schedule without the assistance of one of its top reserves.
College trackmen will have a chance for some "spring training" at the United States Marine Corps schools base in Quantico, Va., in early April.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10 (AP) --Mrs. Edith J.R. Isaacs, author of several books about the stage and a former editor of Theatre Arts Magazine, died today at a nursing home here. The widow of Lewis M. Isaacs, he was 78 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Mayors Wagner's administration offered formally today to give up New York City's automobile use tax in exchange for $10,500,000 a year in state funds.
THE new model rooms opened today by Bloomingdale's prove once more that department store exhibits of this type are one of the best sources of inexpensive decorating ideas.
The American National Red Cross is entering the "disaster season" with its uncommitted reserves for that purpose at low ebb because of last year's floods.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 10-- A letter, signed with the name of an important Algerian rebel chief and addressed to the Premier of Egypt acknowledging receipt of an arms shipment has been turned up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--In discussing his political future with the reporters at Key West last Sunday, President Eisenhower promised to study all the medical, historical and political aspects of the question and then announce his decision.
LONDON, Jan. 10--The Eden Administration began tonight a sharp counterattack against its critics.
General Motors' shiny new stainless steel, lightweight, lowslung Aerotrain jumped the New York Central tracks under Park Avenue last night.
LONDON, Jan. 11--After a year of prosperity and record production, Britain's automobile manufacturers are worrying about their 1956 prospects.

Many Indian experts in this country--led by the Association on American Indian Affairs--have been expressing concern over the tendency to "terminate" Federal responsibility for the Indian tribes and to lessen various forms of Federal protection.
Commodity futures prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges.
An occupant of a Washington Heights apartment building, hearing a muffled roar at 4 A.M. yesterday, discovered that the courtyard and a section of the sidewalk had caved in.
Three men questioned by the police last night threw new light on the disappearance of Jacqueline Smith, a 20-year-old fashion designer.
The New Orleans Public Service Company raised more than $6,000,000 yesterday by the sale of preferred stock at competitive bidding.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 --The Soviet Union has made new offers to help India build up her industrial strength.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- President Eisenhower refused publicly today to assent to or dissent from entry of his name in the April 10 Illinois Presidential preferential primary.
Long Island is expected to get state-sponsored higher educational facilities that will cost $25,000,000.
The New York Rangers toppled the Montreal Canadiens to their worst defeat of the season, 6--1, in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Lincoln Square redevelopment is growing into a bigger project than was envisioned nine months ago. At that time the city made its first open move to keep the mid-Broadway area from becoming an expanse of slums.
Ernie McCulloch, ski school head at Mont Tremblant in Montreal's Laurentians, has been skiing since he was 8.
WHENEVER the head man in a sport takes it upon himself to plead with someone to join his organization, that someone has to have extra special qualities and qualifications.
Robert Moses estimated last night that the cost of building five middle-income cooperative housing projects here would be $90,000,000, using mostly union welfare and pension funds.
ALBANY, Jan. 11--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed two bills today to help combat an "alarming increase" in narcotics addiction throughout the state.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 --Hecht-Lancaster Productions has added two more novels to its library of stories for future filming. They are "Blaze of the Sun," written by Jean Hougron, and "Cry Tough," by Irving Shulman.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UP)-- Johnny Holman, an 8-to-5 shortender after a late flood of heavy bets, scored an eight-round technical knockout over Bob Satterfield in a televised fight from the Chicago Stadium tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 11--By unanimous vote the state's Democratic county chairmen today formally proposed Governor Harriman as the next Democratic candidate for President.
LONDON, Jan. 11--Members of one party of the British expedition to the Antarctic have berthed their ship at the ice near the coastline of the Weddell Sea.
CENTERPORT, L.I., Jan. 11--In a real-life drama plagiarizing a popular play and movie, two women, an elderly man and a child were held prisoner overnight in their home here by two young gunmen.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11--Following is the text of the resolution on Palestine introduced in the Security Council today by France, Britain and the United States:
CHICAGO. Jan. 11--Activity in futures trading on the Board of Trade today was at a low ebb much of the session. But wheat and corn were firm until near the close. Soybeans and oats were heavy.
SATURDAY, 11 A.M.: Stories will be told and films shown at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
Mayor Wagner said last night that the city in the next two years would have to emphasize special problems created by its business growth.
AN investment banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. is making a public offering today of 160.000 shares of common stock of the General Shoe Corporation at $60.50 a share.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 11-- Capt. Bob Reese sank two free throws with sixteen seconds left tonight to give Fordham a 66-64 basketball victory over Princeton in Dillon Gymnasium.

Greenville, S.C., awarded yesterday $3,000,000 of water revenue bonds due from 1957 to 1989 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and associates at a borrowing cost of 2.85627 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- New standards for dispersing defense plants beyond the reach of enemy bombs were accepted by the Government today.

The Pennsylvania Athletic Commission met with Julius Helfand, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday and pledged full support to the New York official in his fight against the Boxing Guild.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The aviation industry made its first over-all survey of jet-age problems today.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 11-- Car styling and soaring traffic demands will make obsolete at least 80,000 miles in the Federal road system this year, it was forecast today.
CAPE ROYDS, Antarctica, Jan. 11--Almost five decades of the world's windiest weather have failed to knock over a wooden hut built near here by Sir Ernest Shackleton.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 11-- Valerian A. Zorin, first Soviet Ambassador to West Germany, and his small staff have begun their work in modest circumstances.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11--A plea for more attention to the education of women because they have become major factors in the country's economic life was made here today.
MOZART'S "Jupiter" Symphony opened the Boston Symphony's program last night in Carnegie Hall, and Ravel's "Bolero" ended it, but the main interest of the concert lay elsewhere.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 12 (AP)--At least sixty-five of seventy passengers aboard a tiny coastal ship were burned to death early today in a fire that broke out in a cluttered thirdclass cabin, the National Police reported.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 11 --What amounts to an ultimatum has been served on the Masjumi Moslem party by the Moslem Teachers party and the Moslem Union party.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11--Sweden's mandate that kings reign but the people rule was re-enacted according to ancient ritual today.
Pillsbury Mills, Inc., yesterday reported a net profit of $2,766,000 for the six months ended on Nov. 30, against $2,747,000 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.
PARIS, Jan. 11--Large rebel areas of the coastal mountains of Algeria were placed under military command today as a prelude to a major effort at pacification.
The stock market yesterday won back half of Tuesday's loss and a fifth of its loss for the first two days of the week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- House Republicans added today to the clamor within the party for quick Congressional action on farm relief. They called for more immediate steps than proposed by President Eisenhower to get money into the farmers' pockets.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 11-- Maryland State's undefeated basketball team gained its seventh victory of the season by downing Hofstra, previously unbeaten, 82--74, at Calkins Gymnasium tonight.
OTTAWA, Jan. 11--A new and more generous plan for sharing the revenues of direct taxation with Canada's ten provinces was laid before Parliament today by Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (UP) --The National Collegiate Athletic Association revealed today that twenty-five member institutions were under investigation for rules violations.

The warden of City Prison (the Tombs) and an administrative assistant were accused yesterday of attempting to "whitewash a larceny" in the institution. The accusation was made by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 (AP) --Undefeated Pascual Perez of Argentina retained his world flyweight boxing title tonight.
American business will spend millions this year to freshen up its offices.
The waterfront was calm yesterday as various port interests digested a court appointed referee's report.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, issued today a statement telling the country to face up to the economic contest with the Soviet Union in such countries as Egypt, India and Burma.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--President Eisenhower, pronounced in "excellent" physical condition today by his three official physicians, has now reached the period of decision about his political future.
The Jordanian riots, which the British are answering with the dispatch of 1,600 paratroopers to Cyprus, merely emphasize what has been clear for months: there is a crisis in the Middle East.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 11 --W. Le Roy Marshall, assistant advertising manager of the Remington Rand Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation, died at his home here last night. He was 66 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--A new law to govern chemical additives to foods was urged today as a principal aim of the fiftieth anniversary this year of the Food and Drug Act.
NEWARK, Jan. 11--Seven records were set tonight as Montclair State Teachers took a commanding lead in the third annual Collegiate Track Conference indoor championship at Newark Armory.
DETROIT, Jan. 11--Wilber M. Brucker asserted tonight that the Army must develop greater mobility in order to perform its mission effectively.
Hal Keith, a television producer and director for the National Broadcasting Company since 1947, died of cancer yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
THE nineteenth annual Silver Sailfish Derby, which attracts a number of northern anglers to Gulf Stream waters each year, will begin its twenty-eight-day run on Saturday.

"Nightmare in Red," a filmed documentary on the birth of communism in Russia, will be televised again over the National Broadcasting Company network on Tuesday, Jan. 24, from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.

Further expansion of the growing center for large hosiery concerns on Fifth Avenue in the vicinity on Thirty-sixth Street was indicated yesterday with announcement that a wholesaler in that line had purchased the sixstory building at 381 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Street.

Boat builders, thank goodness, are sportsmen willing to try most anything once. They can be intransigent.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday. Old-crop months rose 12 to 25 points (60 cents to $l.25 a bale), and new-crop months fell 8 to 19 points (40 to 95 cents a bale).

Net operating income of the New York Trust Company amounted to $5,885,875 in 1955, up from $5,610,329 in the previous year, Hulbert S. Aldrich, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Democratic Congressional investigators charged today that the mining claim awarded to Al Sarena mines by the Department of the Interior had yielded the company a $110,000 windfall in public-land timber.

THE January white sales are white no longer. Colored sheets and brightly hued towels, pillows covered with decorative prints, and mattress tickings attractive enough to serve as sofa upholstery are the order of the day.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 (AP)-- A. M. Byers Company, largest United States producer of wrought iron, said today General Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to acquire a substantial interest in Byers and is considering a merger.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11-- The Chilean Government has drawn up a far-reaching legisative program designed to control inflation.
