Accras were at 28.9 cents and Bahias at 27.25 cents. Trading volume was 248 lots. There were fifty-three unsatisfied offerings at the limit decline at the market's close.
MOSCOW, Jan. 16--The Soviet Union has made its strongest bid to date to win an economic and commercial foothold in Latin America.
A Dutch transport has become the second turbo-prop plane of foreign make to be purchased by a United States airline.
LACONIA, N.H., Jan. 16-- Senator Estes Kefauver counseled Republican hopefuls today to stand up and be counted.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16-- The first units of the new West German Navy will put to sea in April, the Defense Ministry announced today. A flotilla of eighteen minesweepers will be the vanguard of the Navy, scheduled to expand to 170 ships and 17,000 men by 1960.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Aggres sive buying was lacking today in grain and soybean futures trading. Prices during the first part of the session drifted lower in all pits.

IZMIR, Turkey, Jan. 15--Boycotting of Turkey's new tobacco crop, the principal source of the country's vital American dollars, by major American cigarette concerns has alarmed United States and Turkish economists in Izmir (Smyrna) and in Ankara.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 16--The club car was crowded with sports celebrities last night as the athletic caravan headed for Rochester and the annual polio fund dinner. In one corner were Johnny Podres of the Dodgers, Joe Collins of the Yankees and Al Schacht, baseball's Clown Prince.
LAS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (UP) --Professional football took action today to reduce injuries when it adopted a rule that would atop "piling on" a ball carrier when he is down.

"Fallen Angels," starring Nancy Walker and Margaret Phillips, will be revived tonight at the Playhouse. Curtain time is 8 o'clock. Featured in the company of six are Alice Pearce, William Windom, William LeMassena and Efrem Zimbalist Jr.
Plans to sell $4,750,000 of building bonds on Jan. 26 were announced yesterday by Stockton, Calif., Unified School District. The bonds are dated Jan. 16 and will mature from 1957 to 1981.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 16--Dwight R.G. Palmer, State Highway Commissioner, disclosed here today the routes that the state was considering for the proposed $110,000,000
WITH the help of three soloists in two concertos, Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society continued their exploration of the symphonic byways at Town Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP)-- The Government accused the United Fruit Company today of promoting a banana monopoly in the Nineteen Twenties by buying out one rival concern and organizing a "bogus" company to stifle another competitor.
PARIS, Jan. 16--The plan for a Republican Front government of Radicals and Socialists was approved today by the executive committee of the Radical party.
The unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee was unable to hold its scheduled hearing yesterday.

COLUMBIA, Ky., Jan. 16 (AP) --Kentucky's first court-ordered integration was accomplished without incident today as seventeen Negro students filed from a school bus into the Adair county Consolidated High School.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- President Eisenhower's Budget Message to Congress recommended today an increase of more than $500,000,000, or 24 per cent, in outlays for human welfare.
QUEBEC, Jan. 16--The dairy farmers of Quebec petitioned the Federal Government of Canada today to protect them from margarine.
Robert Moses has called upon the Air Force to give up Mitchel Field in congested Nassau County as an "urgent matter Of public interest and safety."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- President Eisenhower's estimate of tax receipts in his budget today was based on the conservative assumption of practically no growth in profits and incomes this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that present laws did not give the Immigration and Naturalization Service power to subpoena as "witnesses" persons who were potential defendants in denaturalization proceedings.
Directors of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., proposed yesterday the payment of a 25 per cent stock dividend late in June. Such payment would require about 9,000,000 new shares.
A billion-dollar increase in defense spending is necessary next year to keep our armed forces modern and effective, Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said last night.
Mrs. Mabel Morris cashed in a $32,000 chip on "The $64,000 Question" last night under doctor's orders.
The displeasure of several City Councilmen with some traffic laws and enforcement caused a series of bills on the subject to be introduced into the Council yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--An organization that speaks for many New York City business and industrial corporations urged the Legislature today to go slow in cutting personal income taxes.
A snowfall that began shortly after midnight yesterday left only an official "trace" in New York City, but shrouded suburbia with a covering of two to twelve inches.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17--Syria asked the United States today to cut off economic help to Israel because of her recent attack on Syrian military posts near the Sea of Galilee.
Commodity futures volume increased on most of the New York exchanges yesterday. Cottonseed oil, rubber, potatoes, cocoa and the domestic sugar contracts registered heavy trading.
Airmen at electronic consoles are beginning to play the major motif in air defense, the Defense Department revealed last night.

The bright plans for General Motors' new stainless steel, lightweight, low-slung Aerotrain have been derailed temporarily by the Pennsylvania Railroad. The reason: a slight case of shake, rattle and roll.

The powerful, eight-man Standing Committee of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will meet today in special session to determine a course of action in the controversy at Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn Heights.
Proposals are recurrently made that the four municipal colleges --City College, Brooklyn College, Queens College and Hunter College--form a football league.

THE luscious lemon meringue pie pictured in a subway advertisement may set the hungry straphanger thinking of the dinner that awaits him at the end of the line. But he probably never wonders about who took the picture.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17--A weak tone dominated the grain futures market today. Wheat was especially heavy, with some selling of new crop deliveries because of a light snowfall in eastern Kansas.
Augustin J. Powers of 50 Park Avenue, a founder and vice president of the Powers Photo Engraving Company, died yesterday in his winter him in Miami, Fla. His age was 82.

A talk with Bruce Parker at the Kingsbridge Armory made it clear that one of the few courses left for the jaded sportsman was to buy a pair of seagoing slats and go skipping over the wavelets at high speed on the end of a tow-line.
An airliner with twenty-four persons on board landed safely at La Guardia Airport last night after flying three hours and ten minutes through fog and snowstorms without lights or radio.
One of the most appreciated accomplishments of the Wagner administration is the better policing of New York City.
Measured by 1955 earnings, the underwriters of the Ford stock offering have set a price midway between that of General Motors and Chrysler.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Floor managers indicated today that they had adopted the unusual strategy of fighting virtually any change in the natural gas bill now before the Senate.
Michigan yesterday borrowed $20,000,000 in the public market on two lots of highway bonds.
ONE of the season's pleasantest hours of television was provided last night by three of television's nicest people.
Embattled tenants in the Yorkville area pleaded last night for a central City Relocation Bureau to help persons facing eviction from their homes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Secretary of State Dulles redefined today his hotly debated doctrine on the "necessary art" of risking war to keep the peace.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 17-- Measures to gear Israel's life to a state of national emergency were discussed in Jerusalem tonight by the leaders of the country's dominant political party, the Mapai.
CAIRO, Jan. 17--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser has set out on a new campaign to establish Egypt as the leading Arab power.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17--No important phase of the oil business will be adversely affected by atomic energy in the foreseeable future, Robert E. Wilson, chairman of the board of Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 --Evidence of the stimulation that the Dead Sea scrolls have had on biblical studies was demonstrated today at the Harvard Divinity School.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Administration presented to Congress today a bill that would make the Secretary of Agriculture the absolute boss of a farmaid soil bank.
There would have been no public subscription to shares of the family-controlled Ford Motor Company if two crucial conditions had not been met.
The Park Avenue committee of the Fifth Avenue Association has been recognized and enlarged "in view of the continuous tremendous growth of building and business activity taking place on Park Avenue."
Two major stories in this week's news supply further refutation of the once popular theory that ours is a "stagnant economy."
ALBANY, Jan.17--The city of Yorkers asked the Legislature today for a share of state revenues from Yonkers Raceway as a long-term solution to its school finance problem.
NEXT to Beatrice Lillie, Nancy Walker is the fun niest woman in the theatre. Just now, she is trapped in a revival of Noel Coward's "Fallen Angels," which opened at the Playhouse last evening.
The Ford common stock will be offered today by 722 underwriters, the largest group to participate in a corporate underwriting.

ABOARD U.S.S. WYANDOT, Off Ross Island, Antarctica, Jan. 15--Admiral Richard E. Byrd has welcomed the Soviet expedition to Wilkes Land. At the same time he noted the United States got a first look at the general area where the Russians plan to set up inland scientific stations.

THE average woman may arrange a household once or twice in her life, but home furnishing experts such as Rebecca Petrikin of Sterns direct the decorating of what amounts to a six-room house two or more times a year.

PARIS, Jan. 17--A resolution for pooling part of the sovereighty of six nations in a European atomic energy commission was being drafted here tonight for approximately simultaneous introduction into six Parliaments.

Charles J. Hardy, former president of the American Car and Foundry Company, now ACF Industries, Inc., died in his sleep early yesterday morning in his home at 1 West Seventysecond Street. He was 89 years old. Death was attributed to old age.

Stock of the Ford Motor Company was sold yesterday to the public for the first time. The stock was priced at $64.50 a share in an agreement signed yesterday by the Ford Founda-... tion and a syndicate of 722 underwriting houses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--(UP) --The House Appropriations Committee today rejected Defense Department plans to close four naval industrial plants at Boston, Mare Island, Calif., and Norfolk, Va.

United States Lines Company and its subsidiaries increased net income last year to $8,300,000 from $5,177,454 the year before, according to preliminary figures reported yesterday by John M. Franklin, president.
The Fund for Adult Education has received a grant of $17,500, 000 from the Ford Foundation to support its activities for the five-year period beginning next Jan. 1.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., will reopen the south yard of its large Delaware River plant to house a newly established equipment division.
TRENTON, Jan. 17--Gov. Robert B. Meyner removed Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr. from the New Jersey Superior Court bench today. He accused the veteran jurist of "intemperance in his judicial conduct."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 17--Adlai E. Stevenson demanded today that President Eisenhower dismiss John Foster Dulles, or repudiate publicly a statement attributed to the Secretary of State defending the policy of risking war for the sake of peace.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 17--The Brussels Motor Show which opened yesterday is expected to have a record attendance this year, reflecting the growing market for automobiles especially the economical low-powered models.

The final United States Olympic eliminations for the Star Class will be conducted at the Atlantic Highlands (N. J.) Yacht Club and those for the 5.5 Meter and Finn Monotype classes on Buzzards Bay in Massachusetts. The Sharpie trials probably also will be on Buzzards Bay.
FLOWER paintings from 1910 to 1952 by Maurice Vla minck, are on view at the Schoneman Galleries, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street. Vlaminck's virtuosity is always impressive.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- President Eisenhower submitted to Congress today a long-range water resources program designed to assure adequate supplies and provide greater flood protection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Committee for the White House Conference on Education will recommend to President Eisenhower that he call a conference on higher education.

ONE of the significant developments in music in the last decade has been the revival of the taste for little symphonies. Last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Dmitri Shostakovich's Ninth Symphony benefited from the change in taste.
The Blatz Brewing Company announced yesterday in Milwaukee the appointment of Kenyon Eckhart, Inc., to handle its advertising account. The account has been handled by Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--A gathering Democratic attack on the Eisenhower Administration went beyond John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today to bring military as well as foreign policy into question.

With Constance Bennett, Robert Strauss, Frank McHugh and Todd Andrews comprising the cast, "The Best of Steinbeck" will be mounted sans scenery. Portions of the program will consist of "Grapes of Wrath" and "Of Mice and Men," plus two of Mr. Steinbeck's short stories...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- President Eisenhower scheduled today a news conference Thursday and a televised political speech Friday night.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Jan. 17 --Contract negotiations between the Screen Actors Guild and the Association of Motion Picture Producers, which represents the major studios, got under way today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 17-- The West German Government has been advised that it must not expect the United States to cover the deficit in its threeyear armament build-up.

TOO few Americans who go to Paris are acquainted with one of the more intimate and individual museums--the Jacquemart-Andre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- The Federal Reserve Board said in a preliminary estimate today that United States industrial production last year set a new record--39 per cent above the averabe for the 1947-49 "yardstick" period.

Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa apparently were still at loggerheads yesterday over finances. The question was the city's ultimate ability to relieve its own financial situation through a more efficient collection of sales taxes.
A return to "free and available" consumer credit was advocated yesterday by Harlow H. Curtice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--At the joint request of the United States and Turkish Governments, Clarence B. Randall, President Eisennower's top adviser on foreign economic policy, will fly to Turkey at the end of this month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Leaders of seventeen American Jewish organizations and Zionist groups appealed to American Jews tonight to express "publicly, repeatedly and forcibly" their concern over what was termed Communist and Arab designs against Israel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Recent Federal regulations requiring faster repayment of Government-backed home loans were eased today.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company last year showed substantial increases in operating revenues and earnings, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17--Time was running out today on the Illinois Toll Highway Commission and its ambitious plans to build 193 miles of northern Illinois turnpikes.
Louis Schleifer, real estate operator and a leader in Jewish community life, died early yesterday at his home, 2016 Avenue N, Brooklyn.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (AP)--The International Boxing Guild, its president said flatly today, "will keep right on operating."
The fourteenth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists will open tonight with a preview reception at the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--In a special message to the Legislature, Governor Harriman proposed today an expansion of state health services, particularly in research.
The Tavern-on-the-Green is being refurbished at a cost of $400,000.

LONDON, Jan. 17--The British Government warned today that, should the British Isles undergo a nuclear attack, it probably would be by hydrogen bombs equivalent to 10,000,000 tons of TNT and dropped at ground of near-ground level.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Robinson Kirkham of San Francisco have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Kirkham, to James Stillman Jr. He is a son of Dr. James A. Stillman of Pleasantville, N. Y. A late June wedding in San Francisco is planned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 --The Columbia Broadcasting system has signed Orson Welles to star as the colorful stage producer in the April 7 spectacular, "Twentieth Century."

Italian-Americans were invited yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer to buy a $100,000,000 interest in a plan to help Italian industry. Seven years ago Mr. Frazer was associated with Henry J. Kaiser in the KaiserFrazer Corporation, maker of automobiles.

WITH most other seasons closed, the "dinner sea son" of most rod and gun clubs is opening. The first of the big assemblies was scheduled yesterday by the New York Chapter of Ducks Unlimited for Feb. 2 at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, Jan. 17--Government stocks extended their rally today, while industrials weakened further. A shortage of stock accentuated the gains in government shares which ranged up to 15s ($2.10) in the War Loan and 3 per cent conversion issues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- President Eisenhower decided today to appear in person at a Republican fund-raising rally Friday night for his first political speech since his Sept. 24 heart attack.
Patrick B. McGinnis is out as president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--A Grandma Moses painting of President Eisenhower's farm at Gettysburg, Pa., was the Cabinet's gift to the President today to mark the third anniversary of his inauguration.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP)-- The National Football League today wound up its annual meeting by grinding out the final rounds of the draft of college prospects for the 1956 campaign.
It was Ford all the way in Wall Street yesterday. From shortly after sunrise to well after sunset the new Ford stock monopolized trading facilities.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18-- Rudolf S. Hecht, board chairman of the Mississippi Shipping Company and of New Orleans' famed International House, died today at the age of 70. Death was attributed to a heart attack.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, in his first Senate speech since a heart attack last July 2, assailed the Supreme Court today for trying to "write the laws of this nation."
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (UP)--Sandy Saddler, using his head as well as his fists with telling effect, retained the world featherweight title with a thirteenth-round technical knock
Mayor Wagner joined yesterday with members of the Advertising Club of New York in observing the fiftieth anniversary of the organization.

The business of the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union at the New York Yacht Club last night included reports on the locations and dates of the national sailing championships for men, women and juniors.
THERE is more than the in evitable shrimp cocktail at restaurants to prove Americans like shrimp. Last year this shellfish was valued at $70,000,000, a fifth of the value of all fish in 1955.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 --The Columbia basketball team won its third Ivy League game in a row tonight by downing Yale, 80--54, in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 18 --United States diplomats are taking a hard look at their country's approach to Indonesia in view of the critical shift in the political situation here.
In the struggle against materialistic communism, the United States must bring up the "heavy artillery" of spiritual and moral forces, a noted industrialist asserted last night.

TOMORROW, 5 P.M.: The King-Coit Children's Theatre, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street, will present "Aucassin and Nicolete," a Medeival play, and repeat the performance on Sunday at the same time. Tickets are $3. For information call MUrray Hill 80166.

HONG KONG, Jan. 18--Communist China declared today it would reject a United States formula for a mutual renunciation of force qualified by the right of "individual and collective self-defense" in the Taiwan (Formosa) area.

A "thorough judicial investigation" of the conduct of the Rev. William Howard Melish was called for unanimously yesterday by the powerful eight-man Standing Committee of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.
PARIS, Jan. 18--France's new National Assembly prepared to meet tomorrow for the first time, without a sign of a governing majority in sight.

TOKYO, Jan. 18--An invitation to American cotton textile industry representatives to visit Japan and investigate the voluntary export quota system in force here was issued today by the All Japan Cotton Spinners Association.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., Jan. 18--Bertram H. Saunders, retired industrialist and banker, died last night after a long illness in his home on Franklin Lake Road. He was 82 years old.
I have called a special meeting of the board of directors of the New Haven Railroad on Friday for the purpose of resigning as president.
Miss Charlotte P. Taylor has enlisted the aid of a group of young men and women to serve with her on the junior committee for the annual Blue Ridge Ball.

MICKEY WALKER will be sitting on the champions dais at the Boxing Writers Dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt tonight. He will not make a speech or accept an award. For him it will be a quiet and relatively uneventful evening.

BERLIN, Jan. 18--The East German Parliament approved today the creation of a Defense Ministry and a "People's Army," Presumably this will lead soon to the redesignation of the People's Police in Bar racks as an army.

The master and nine seamen of the United States Lines freighter American Miller will be honored today for risking their lives to aid two Italian seamen seriously injured in an explosion last November.
A modified project for the proposed $23,000,000 Luna Park Houses for 1,500 middle-income families in Coney Island was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 18--Malayan representatives asked today for immediate self-government in internal affairs and full independence next year within the British Commonwealth.

The debate new proceeding in the Senate on the Fulbright-Harris bill to exempt independent producers of natural gas from Federal regulation as public utilities may sound technical, but it is of direct practical...

A forty-two-year leasehold on the six-story building at 422 Madison Avenue, near Forty-eighth Street, has been sold by Loomis J. Grossman to Chock Full O'Nuts, the restaurant chain. The building, which is being reconstructed, is on a lot 28 by 65 feet.
Commodity futures generally rose in light trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, wool, lead, zinc and tin rose;
"The Lord Don't Play Favorites," a drama about horse racing that would have a cast including Louis Armstrong, the trumpeter, and Kay Starr, the
Walter Gieseking will arrive here in March for a ten-week concert tour of the United States and Canada.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 18--An annual discussion of race problems by an organization of South African Nationalists has produced some interesting statements.

Bill Hovey, the ski school head at the Lake Placid Club's Mount Whitney, has a football background. As an undergraduate, he played with the Notre Dame varsity in 1949 and 1950. As a Marine, he saw action with service elevens at Pensacola and El Toro.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 18--One of the misfortunes of the big Dulles-Ridgway magazine controversy is that a convalescent President Eisenhower is now left to deal in his news conference tomorrow with some of the most emotional issues of his entire administration.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Jan. 18 --Henry Sahlin, founder and Chairman of the Sahlin Engineering Company, Inc., died yesterday in Bloomfield Hospital. He was 62 years old. He was the inventor of the "Iron Hand," an automatic unloading machine for metal-working presses.

PARIS, Jan. 18--Representativesof the major political parties and trade unions of West Europe decided today to urge their countries to entrust the development of their atomic resources to a supranational commission.

LONDON, Jan. 18--Prime Minister Eden warned tonight that a world war could easily be touched off by hostilities in a critical region such as the Middle East. "There is plenty of dry tinder about," he declared. "Governments should beware lest in trying to undermine long-established friendships be tween others they embroil themselves in graver perils."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway informed a House Appropriations. subcommittee today that he was ready to testify in the controversy over national defense policy whenever called.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18--France made a clear though indirect appeal to the Soviet Union today not to use a SyrianIsraeli dispute promote its "special interests" in the Middle East.
America's only--perhaps the world's only--woman builder of sports boats has her headquarters and main yard in New York's Lower Bay.

For weeks--and particularly this week--the news spotlight has focused on the Ford Foundation. Yesterday the giant philanthropic organization officially sold part of its holdings of Ford Motor Company stock, touching off the wildest investor scramble in memory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--"The only Washington building older than the tempos," a disgruntled citizen said here recently, "must be Dolly Madison's house." He was expressing the mixed sentiments of annoyance and resignation felt by most Washingtonians toward the city's familiar "temporary buildings."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The United States regards its agreement with France on bases in Morocco as "fully valid." State Department officials said today France is Morocco's legal rep resentative in foreign affairs.
Long Island Rail Road passengers may expect further fare increases if labor costs continue to rise, Thomas M. Goodfellow, president of the line, said yesterday.

Stock market operators changed their minds in the final half hour of yesterday's trading. What had been an inactive and fairly optimistic session suddenly changed character and recorded the third largest loss of the year.
Ten thousand motor-minded visitors yesterday attended the opening of a ten-day automotive exhibition at the Chrysler International Auto Salon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) --Harold E. Stassen said tongiht the United States would make every effort to reach a "sound agreement" with Soviet Russia for ending the armaments race.
Eugene de Joly de Sabla, a retired California industrialist, died here yesterday in his home at 200 East Seventy-eighth Street. He would have observed his ninety-first birthday tomorrow.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 18 --Lieut. Gen. Charles B. Stone 3d, taking command of the Continental Air Command headquarters at Mitchel Air Force Base here today, said that there were no plans to move the base.
Joseph (Sandy) Saddler has been a world champion longer than any of the other current titleholders in boxing. The Harlem fighter has been ruler of the 126-pound division since Sept. 8, 1950.
BOSTON, Jan. 18--Salk vaccine for combatting poliomyelitis received a rating of 53 per cent effectiveness from a committee of public health experts studying the 1955 epidemic in Massachusetts.
On high, rolling ground just east of the Hudson River between Tarrytown and Ossining in Westchester County a fine new hospital, the Phelps Memorial, has been receiving its first patients.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Industrial Relations Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers has voted for employer participation in the International Labor Organization for one more year.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18 --Gene Fisher scored 27 points to pace Army to an uphill 89to-78 victory over Pennsylvania Military College today.

The announcement by Patrick B. McGinnis of his intention to resign as president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is the latest in a series of upheavals that has marked the eighty-four-year history of the line.
A man with modest means and a large family would do best to buy a used car, one year old, Charles A. Chayne, vice president in charge of the engineering staff of General Motors, said yesterday.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Jan. 18 (UP)--Another explosion today shook a 130,000-barrel tanker that was turned into a holocaust last night by a thunderous blast that caught many crew members on board.
The Rev. Pierre Maury, president of the Reformed Church of France and one of the leaders of the World Student Christian Federation, died Friday in Paris. He was 65 years old.
GENEVA, Jan. 18--Representatives of twenty-six nations today began another effort at mutual reductions in tariffs.
TRENTON, Jan. 18--Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr. today was considering legal action to obtain his reinstatement to the New Jersey Superior Court Bench.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 18-- Nationalist rebels have struck in many parts of Algeria in the last thirty-six hours attacking French military convoys, burning schools and wrecking railway lines.
GENEVA, Jan. 18--The Chinese Communist statement, which also was issued here today, reviewed the record of the talks that have been going on here since Aug. 1, 1955.

FRANCOIS MAURIAC, who won the Nobel Prize in 1952, has passed the threescore and-ten mark and is still writing novels with a vitality and drive that should give courage to all sad young men of letters.
Premier Nasser, who dominates Egypt at the head of a military junta that has ruled ever since the overthrow of King Farouk three years ago, has presented his country with a new Constitution.
PARIS, Jan. 18--Pierre Poujade, who used to sell books and stationery ink the small town of St. Cere, denied today that he was now selling fascism and anti-Semitism to France.
A preview of the $2,000,000 General Motors Motorama at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was held for 5,000 invited guests yesterday.

The Sino-American Ambassadorial talks have been going on for more than four months without any agreement being achieved on the second item of the agenda, ever since agreement was reached on Sept. 10, 1955, on the return of civilians of both sides.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18--A tapering off in business and credit expansion and relaxation of credit restraint were predicted today by Roy L. Reierson, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York.
What is announced as the first American professional presentation of Christopher Marlowe's "Tamburlaine the Great" will be unveiled tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the Winter Garden.
An admirable choice has been made for one of the most sensitive official posts in the Western Hemisphere. Ambassador Jose A. Mora

ROSS ISLAND, Antarctic Jan. 18--Forty-four years ago today Capt. Robert Falcon Scott of Britain reached the South Pole. Since then no one has even tried to duplicate his feat of getting there on the ground.
R.E. McNeill Jr., president of the Hanover Bank, said yesterday he favored the imposition of Government control over consumer lending terms and down payments. In making
ALBANY, Jan. 18--The State Superintendent of Insurance called tonight for a bipartisan effort to solve the problem posed by uninsured motorists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- Democratic attacks on John Foster Dulles increased in vigor today with charges of a dangerous disharmony between the foreign and military policies of the Eisenhower Administration.
An amnesty period for the city's scofflaws, to run through Feb. 29, was announced yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.
A signal maintenance worker and his helper were killed yesterday by an I. R. T. shuttle train 200 feet west of Grand Central station.
MONTREAL, Jan. 18--The demand for Canadian newsprint will double in the next quartercentury, R.M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, today told the Royal
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation last year attained the highest earnings and sales and operating revenues with increases of 21 per cent and 18.4 per cent, respectively, over the 1954 totals.
The Military Air Transport Service is not the most glamorous of our various military establishments. Much of its work is routine. It takes men and materials from place to place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Internal Revenue Service has ended tax exemptions on some types of alumni and "booster" organizations whose purpose is to recruit athletes for a school.
ALBANY, Jan. 18--Mayor Wagner's administration renewed its efforts today to gain full control over multiple dwelling regulations for New York City.
Mayor Wagner said last night he had "high hopes" that the strike of fuel oil and coal truck drivers would be settled today.

The total short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange as of last Friday was the lowest reported since Oct. 15, 1953, the exchange announced yesterday. The figure was 2,289,880 shares, against 2,581,201 shares on last Dec. 15 and 2,192,659 shares on Oct. 15, 1953.
The Dodgers yesterday signed their world series hero to a 1956 contract, but with no certainty that he would be with them much beyond spring training.
THIS year's Brooklyn Artists Biennial, now on view at the Brooklyn Museum, has been exceptionally well selected by the jurors--Isabel Bishop, Jimmy Ernst and Hertha Wegener.

IN many homes a rosy-cheeked member of the diaper set is getting the household off to a lively New Year start. In countless others, though, the newest --and perhaps even more lively --attraction is of the fur, feather or fin species.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18-- For the first time in twenty years of turbulent Louisiana politics, a candidate swept to victory in a Democratic first primary when former Gov. Earl K. Long turned back four opponents.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 18--Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Burkett Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Upson Burkett, to Gilbert Heyward Stevens.

The New York Stock Exchange is stepping up its advertising campaign for public education sharply. The exchange will spend $600,000 for this purpose in the first half of this year, Keith Funston, president,
ALBANY, Jan. 18--State tax collections were 15 per cent higher in the first nine months of this fiscal year than in the corresponding period a year ago.
There was a taxicab strike yesterday. How much of a strike it was depended on who was talking.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Johnny Layton, former world champion billiards player, was found dead today at the rooming house where he lived. He was 69 years old.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 18 (AP)--Art Devlin of Lake Placid, N.Y., who is regarded as America's No. 1 ski jumper, tried the Olympic hill today, then saw an unheralded Russian outjump the best of six nations.
A drop of 6,195,000 barrels last week in the nation's stocks of light fuel oil was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 11:
Bernard M. Baruch issued a statement yesterday replying to charges made by former President Harry S. Truman in the second volume of his memoirs.

All Souls Unitarian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Lunt Saunders, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hyde Saunders of 1185 Park Avenue, to Townsend Hornor.
In 1935 a 20-year-old graduate of Brooklyn College took a long and serious look at the world and decided that was no time to come to grips with reality.

MONTIBELLO, Que., Jan. 18 (UP)--Canadian and United States shipowners joined today in demands that their two countries regulate use of the Great Lakes and the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway by foreign freighters.
Supposedly fictitious documents said to reveal "illegal activities" by a Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were offered yesterday in Federal Court.
"Prosperity Beyond Tomorrow" by Samuel H. Ordway Jr., has been scheduled for Feb. 14 publication by Ronald Press. It is a projection of America's future in terms of material and human resources.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and an Assistant District Attorney of Kings County clashed yesterday over the legality of the indictment against Harry Gross, former bookmaker.
Hurricane Dulles and Hurricane Ridgway were alarming Washington yesterday but the full impact of the storms was yet to come.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 --Leo Durocher, after two times at bat on the new "N. B. C. Comedy Hour," has walked away from the third attempt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- "Phantom freight" charges often add $75 to $125 to the price consumers pay for automobiles, Senator A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Proposals to liberalize trading rules on exports to the Soviet Union and its satellites will be held up by the Government indefinitely.
